title: On AIDS: Three Lessons From Africa
description: An AIDS fable: Once upon a time, in the years after AIDS went from being a death sentence to a manageable disease, at least for people rich enough to take antiretroviral therapy, many of the people who ran the world believed that these medicines werent appropriate for residents of very poor countries. Even leaving aside the cost, they thought that poor people couldnt take their medicines on time. Andrew Natsios, the head of the United States Agency for International Development in the George W. Bush administration, argued against funding antiretroviral therapy in Africa. People do not know what watches and clocks are, he told the Boston Globe in June, 2001.

title: The Partys Over When the Flesh-Eating Virus Arrives
description: CABIN FEVER

title: Injury to Wilson Puts the Giants Backfield in Motion
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants General Manager Jerry Reese was asked in the spring if the team was counting on running back David Wilson to return from off-season, career-threatening neck surgery. Reese answered that he viewed Wilson, the teams first-round draft pick in 2012, as a bonus because the team had made other plans for its backfield.

title: The Making of a Musician
description: FINDING FELA

title: A Suggestion for the Right Shoe for Unusual Moments
description: MARKETING for womens shoes often includes recommendations for when to wear particular styles, suggesting that a gladiator sandal would be perfect for, say, a picnic, or a pointy pump for a bachelorette party. But a new campaign from Nine West, the shoe and accessories brand, takes a decidedly more cheeky approach with when-to-wear suggestions.

title: Mundanity at Home, Furry Little Pet Included
description: Spelled wrong, almost every word seems funny, says Karin (Anjorka Strechel) in The Strange Little Cat. Shes referring to the habitual writing errors of her sister, Clara, but she might also be describing the method of the movie, a radically disorienting, disarmingly odd first feature from Ramon Zrcher.

title: Taking Selfies, 35,000 Feet Down
description: To the public, James Cameron is a director of top-grossing movies who moonlights as a deep-sea explorer. Mr. Cameron might see it the other way around.

title: North Carolina Budget May Raise Teacher Pay
description: The North Carolina Senate moved toward sealing a long-sought budget accord on Thursday, voting in favor of a $21 billion plan that would raise the salaries of public schoolteachers but impose cuts elsewhere in state government.

title: U.S. Seeks Release of Couple in Qatar, Creating Tensions With a Crucial Arab Ally
description: The United States on Thursday called on Qatar, the tiny gulf emirate and important Arab ally, to lift a travel ban on an American couple held there for more than 19 months on a criminal prosecution over the death of their adopted African daughter, a case that critics contend is riddled with irregularities, racial prejudice and cultural misunderstandings.

title: Argentina Is in Default, and Also Maybe in Denial
description: Argentina may be in default, but you might not know it if you lived in Buenos Aires.

title: This Weeks Movies | Aug. 1, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Guardians of the Galaxy, Get On Up and Child of God.

title: Stock Market Ends July in Dive, but Analysts Are Upbeat
description: The stock market ended July with the sharpest decline in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index since April, while the Dow Jones industrial index fell more than 300 points, enough to eliminate all of its gains for the year.

title: Rising Star Enters the Ryder Cup Picture as Outsiders Look to Qualify
description: AKRON, Ohio  Early in the week of the British Open, Ryan Moore was eating with his caddie in the Royal Liverpool clubhouse when Tom Watson approached their table. He wanted to know if he could join them.

title: New Rules Say Poultry Plants Can Conduct Own Checks
description: WASHINGTON  The Agriculture Department released long-awaited poultry-inspection rules on Thursday that will give plant operators the option of conducting their own inspections for bird defects and feces on the processing lines and allow government inspectors to concentrate on other food-safety issues in the plant.

title: Ancient Haven for Refugees Sees Signs of Strain
description: ISTANBUL  A Syrian boy stood on a white stool under a giant Turkish flag in Taksim Square, selling cold water one hot evening last week. His sales efforts went mostly unnoticed, until a Turkish teenager approached him and pulled him by the ear, berating the boy for working on his territory.

title: The Character Factory
description: Nearly every parent on earth operates on the assumption that character matters a lot to the life outcomes of their children. Nearly every government antipoverty program operates on the assumption that it doesnt.

title: Weak Links in Chinas Food Chain
description: When McDonalds opened its first restaurant in China in the early 1990s, it did not turn to local suppliers for meat, which most likely would have been cheaper. Instead, it relied on its longtime partner the OSI Group, which had been linked to the fast-food titan ever since Ray Kroc, the McDonalds founder, in the 1950s tapped the Chicago butcher Otto & Sons to provide consistent, reliable meats to his expanding empire.

title: Perfect Colt Anointed Hambletonian Favorite
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Rev. Patrick McDonnell seeks to guide his congregation at St. Anthony of Padua Catholic Church in Hightstown, N.J., during challenging times, he might point to his four-legged namesake as a model.

title: Sizing Up Senator Thad Cochran Alongside Tomatoes, Pies and Cows
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss.  They came to award ribbons to the fattest tomatoes and prettiest pies, and to admire the beauties at the annual Pretty Cow Contest. They crowned 19-year-old Macy Martin Miss Neshoba County after the Rev. John E. Stephens delivered the invocation.

title: Big Banks and Treasury See Positive Signs in Report on Financial Industry
description: Citigroup is a huge bank that would most likely have collapsed during the financial crisis if the government had not bailed it out.

title: Holding McDonalds Accountable
description: For nearly two years, fast-food workers nationwide have been striking and demonstrating with increasing frequency and in increasing numbers. They want to be paid at least $15 an hour; the average fast-food wage is currently about $8.90. They also want to be able to form a union without retaliation.

title: The C.I.A.s Reckless Breach of Trust
description: In March, John Brennan, the C.I.A. director, was indignant when Senator Dianne Feinstein charged that the agency had broken into computers used by staff investigators from the Senate Intelligence Committee, which she leads. As far as the allegations of C.I.A. hacking into Senate computers, he said, nothing could be further from the truth. I mean, we wouldnt do that. I mean, thats just beyond the scope of reason.

title: Jury in Ex-Virginia Governors Trial Hears of Money Transfer
description: RICHMOND, Va.  The star witness in the corruption trial of former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, described on Thursday a private meeting at which he and Mr. McDonnell had discussed ways to secretly transfer $50,000 to the governor.

title: In Line for Spot on Ryder Cup Team, Dustin Johnson Takes a Leave
description: AKRON, Ohio  Dustin Johnson, who won his first start of the PGA Tours wraparound season and was poised to compete for the United States in the Ryder Cup, is out of the game for the foreseeable future. In a statement released Thursday by his management company, Johnson said he was taking a leave of absence from professional golf to seek professional help for personal challenges I have faced.

title: To Lift Sales, G.M. Turns to Discounts
description: In February, General Motors hit a milestone of sorts when its sales incentives, as tracked by the research firm Edmunds.com, dropped below those of its domestic rivals, Ford and Chrysler.

title: MoneyPak, a Popular Prepaid Money Card, Opens Path to Fraud Schemes
description: Federal authorities are sounding alarms about a wide range of fraudulent schemes involving a popular prepaid money card product.

title: Alibaba Is Investing Huge Sums in an Array of U.S. Tech Companies
description: Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet retailer, is coming to America with its checkbook wide open.

title: Senate Approves Veteran and Highway Bills
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate gave final approval on Thursday night to a significant expansion of veterans health care and to legislation to replenish the Highway Trust Fund through next spring, then left town for a five-week summer break.

title: How Many Ebola Patients Have Been Treated Outside of Africa?
description: Questions and answers on the scale of the outbreak and the science of the Ebola virus.

title: California Candidate Veers From Campaign Trail to Test Life on Streets
description: LOS ANGELES  With $40 in his pockets, a duct-taped backpack and a cameraman following him closely, Neel Kashkari, the multimillionaire Republican candidate for governor of California, spent a week posing as a homeless man looking for a job, he revealed Thursday, releasing a 10-minute video on his website about the curious experiment.

title: African Leaders Coming to Talk Business May Also Be Pressed on Rights
description: WASHINGTON  When Barack Obama made his first trip as president to Africa in July 2009, he memorably told lawmakers in Ghana that Africa doesnt need strongmen; it needs strong institutions. Next week, several of those strongmen will travel to Washington as part of a landmark gathering of nearly 50 African leaders.

title: Vintage Blockbusters Reshuffle Race
description: The Oakland Athletics had the best record in the American League in mid-June when their catcher, Derek Norris, tried to explain their success after another victory at O.co Coliseum.

title: School Shelters in Gaza Offer Limited Safety, and Even Less Comfort
description: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip  The makeshift shelter of upturned desks, cardboard boxes and dirty blankets in the courtyard of a United Nations school here was a considerable downgrade from the first refuge Fatima Kafarna found when shelling forced her from her home near the Gaza border with Israel two weeks ago.

title: American Held in North Korea Says Health Is Failing
description: Kenneth Bae, the American missionary imprisoned in North Korea for almost two years, said in an interview released Thursday by a pro-North Korea newspaper that he felt abandoned by his own government and had developed new lung and liver ailments, in what appeared to be part of a new effort by the North Korean authorities to use him as leverage with the United States.

title: Wash, Dry, Fold. Now!
description: The competition among apps that deal with users dirty laundry is intense, as suggested by an article in New York magazine this year dissecting various competitors.

title: Perils of City Drivers Ed: Pigeons, Taxis and Litigious Pedestrians
description: The New York State driving test awards no extra credit for overcoming the curbside taunts of East Harlem teenagers.

title: Tensions Escalate Between Israel and a Second Party in Gaza: The United Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS  In the midst of Israels battle with militants in Gaza over the past three weeks, skirmishes opened on a second front in recent days: Its strikes on United Nations facilities and the steep civilian casualties brought a barrage of rebukes and warnings from senior United Nations officials around the world, reaching a fever pitch just before the announcement of a cease-fire late Thursday.

title: Tough to Figure Out
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE This puzzle by Ashton Anderson and James Mulhern has to be one of the most oddly satisfying Friday puzzles Ive solved in a while.

title: Rent-Stabilized, but Otherwise in Flux
description: Between Riverside and Crazy, the rich new play from Stephen Adly Guirgis at the Linda Gross Theater, resides in an in-between land of its own. Id locate it somewhere south of cozy and north of dangerous, west of sitcom and due east of tragedy.

title: Gas Suspected in Fatal Blasts That Jolted a City in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  A series of explosions ripped through the city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan on Thursday night, killing 25 people and wounding more than 260, the authorities said. The dead included at least four firefighters.

title: Mets, Neither Buyers Nor Sellers, Look to Off-Season to Make Moves
description: The Mets could have made a trade before Thursdays nonwaiver trade deadline. They said they discussed deals involving significant players, but ultimately they stayed put. They held on to Bartolo Colon  for now. They held on to Daniel Murphy. They held on to their stash of young, talented starting pitching prospects.

title: Cuomo, a Prosecutor and a Fight in the Mud Over a Shuttered Ethics Panel
description: Against the odds, the civic hygiene in the Moreland Commission affair took a drastic turn for the worse this week.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 31, 2014
India: Dozens of Villagers Still Missing After Landslide
description: Although heavy rains hindered their work, rescue workers on Thursday pulled eight survivors from the mud a day after a huge landslide hit the village of Malin in the Pune district of Maharashtra State in western India. The workers also recovered the bodies of 31 people. The landslide buried at least 40 homes and more than 150 people, officials said. The chances of finding anybody else alive are remote, but we still do not rule out the possibility, said Surjeet Singh Guleria, a senior officer of the National Disaster Rescue Force. We have deployed 378 soldiers and officers on the ground. They are working around the clock, but their work is hampered by continuous rains. Indias home minister, Rajnath Singh, and Maharashtra States chief minister, Prithviraj Chavan, both visited Malin on Thursday. This is a very heart-wrenching scene here, Mr. Singh said.

title: In Gaza, a Pattern of Conflict
description: Similarities and differences in the last three major conflicts between Israel and Hamas.

title: A Fight to Shackle the Chain Stores in East Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  The first spark was the opening of a 7-Eleven in Montauk four years ago. It led to the creation of a Facebook page that called for a boycott and even a protest from the usually business-friendly Chamber of Commerce.

title: At World Trade Center Site, Rebuilding Recreates Intersection of Long Ago
description: On Friday, New Yorkers will be able to do something they have not done in nearly half a century: stand on the corner of Cortlandt and Greenwich.

title: De Blasio on Police-Community Relations
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio hosted a round table on police-community relations after a Staten Island man, Eric Garner, 43, died in police custody.

title: Once Leader of Outcry, de Blasio Is Now Trying to Quell It
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio barreled into City Hall as a fierce critic of the New York Police Department, leading rallies against the use of the stop-and-frisk tactic and urging a new era of comity between minorities and law enforcement.

title: Federal Panel Might Consolidate N.H.L. Lawsuits
description: A hearing was held Thursday before a federal panel in Kansas City, Kan., that will decide if several concussion lawsuits recently filed by former players against the N.H.L. will be consolidated into a single class-action suit. Lawyers for the former players and the league met before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, which is expected to issue a decision in one to three weeks.

title: For a Thrill Seeker at Ease in the Sky, a Birthday Jump Turned Fatal
description: CALVERTON, N.Y.  It was to be the big birthday thrill.

title: Kerry Announces Cease-Fire
description: Secretary of State John Kerry announced a 72 hour cease-fire in the Gaza conflict Thursday.

title: Contractor for 1 World Trade Center Is Charged With Fraud
description: The owner of a construction company hired to do extensive steel work on 1 World Trade Center was charged on Thursday with fraudulently obtaining $76 million by falsely claiming he was in compliance with requirements for hiring minority and female subcontractors.

title: Dick Smith, Oscar-Winning Makeup Artist, Dies at 92
description: Dick Smith, who made flesh peel from famous actors faces, who made the young old and the beautiful hideous and who transformed a girl into a particularly possessed tween  all while working as one of film and televisions most original and accomplished makeup artists, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 92.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 1, 2014
description: Its kind of like taking an exam, all the time. You always have to have the answer.

title: Corrections: August 1, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Montauk for Members Only
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  A simple concrete bench four miles from the tip of Long Island has for generations sufficed as the throne of East Coast surfing.

title: Julio Grondona, Argentine Power in World Soccer, Dies at 82
description: Julio Grondona, who ruled over Argentinas soccer association for 35 years and wielded influence far beyond it as one of the most powerful figures in FIFA, international soccers governing body, died on Wednesday in Buenos Aires. He was 82.

title: Ed Sprinkle, Defensive End Known for Violent Play, Dies at 90
description: Ed Sprinkle, who gained a reputation as the meanest man in football while playing for the Chicago Bears, leveling quarterbacks with ferocity in becoming a rugged prototype for pro footballs pass-rushing defensive ends, died on Monday in Palos Heights, Ill. He was 90.

title: Robert L. Drew, Pioneer in Documentary Filmmaking, Dies at 90
description: Robert L. Drew, a journalist and filmmaker who altered both journalism and filmmaking when he helped develop the hand-held camera and a synchronized sound recorder and put the new equipment to use making documentaries in the put-the-audience-in-the-room style known as cinma vrit, died on Wednesday at his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 90.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) DAVID BOWIE: FIVE YEARS (2013) Drawing on Mr. Bowies personal archive of costumes, set designs, lyrics and memorabilia, the director Francis Whately touches on five seminal years in this performers career, exploring the source of his inspiration and where his ideas led him. The film begins in 1971, with the creation of his persona Ziggy Stardust, and then moves to 1975, when he released the album Young Americans and adopted yet another persona, the Thin White Duke; 1977, and the albums Low and Heroes; 1980, and his No. 1 single in Britain, Ashes to Ashes; and 1983, the year he conquered nightclubs with Lets Dance. (Above, Mr. Bowie in 1979.) Next month, the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago presents David Bowie Is, a retrospective of his career.

title: Videos Capture Terror of Deadly Taiwan Explosions
description: A series of powerful explosions late Thursday in the southern Taiwanese city of Kaohsiung killed 25 people and injured more than 260.

title: For the Clintons, Vacation in the Hamptons Begins With a Fund-Raiser
description: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton will arrive at their Hamptons summer rental this weekend, but relaxation is not the only item on their vacation agenda.

title: Cantor, Ex-Majority Leader, Is Planning Early Exit From House
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Eric Cantor, the Virginia Republican whose last day as House majority leader was Thursday, said on Friday that he would resign his seat effective Aug. 18 in hopes that his successor will be able to participate in the lame-duck session after the November elections.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Anticorruption Campaign Targets Second CCTV Head
description: Liu Wen, the director of China Central Televisions documentary channel, CCTV-9, and producer of the hit series A Bite of China, on the countrys culinary traditions, has been detained on suspicion of corruption, state news media outlets have reported.

title: Socit Gnrale Profit Rises as Loan Problems Recede
description: Socit Gnrale, Frances second-largest bank after BNP Paribas, reported a 7.8 percent rise in second-quarter earnings on Friday as it benefited from a decline in its exposure to risky loans.

title: Ebola Virus Is Outpacing Efforts to Control It, World Health Body Warns
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  In an ominous warning as fatalities mounted in West Africa from the worst known outbreak of the Ebola virus, the head of the World Health Organization said on Friday that the disease was moving faster than efforts to curb it, with potentially catastrophic consequences, including a high risk that it will spread.

title: ArcelorMittal Returns to Profit as Steel Demand Rises
description: LONDON  ArcelorMittal, the worlds largest steel maker, said on Friday that it earned $52 million in the second quarter, a substantial improvement from a $780 million loss in the same period last year, as demand for steel rose in Europe and North America.

title: Gaza Fighting Intensifies as Cease-Fire Falls Apart
description: JERUSALEM  Palestinian militants sprang from the ground and confronted Israeli soldiers Friday morning, as they have repeatedly in recent days. This time, Israeli officials said, one exploded a suicide belt while another unleashed machine-gun fire. This time, two Israeli soldiers were killed and the militants apparently escaped with a third.

title: Called to a Gay Church in the Bronx
description: The Rev. James Dusenbury Jr. started In the Life Ministries in the Bronx eight years ago with three members and a singular inspiration. I said, Theres no gay church in the Bronx,  Mr. Dusenbury, 43, said. My mentor said, Thats God calling you.

title: Bank of Ireland Reports First Profit Since 2008
description: LONDON  The Bank of Ireland said on Friday that it had returned to profit for the first time since a housing crisis derailed the Irish economy six years ago.

title: Research Plan on Bear Bile Medicine Is Hailed by Animal Activists
description: Chinas leading producer of bear bile pharmaceuticals says it is searching for synthetic alternatives, a move hailed by animal welfare advocates.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: The Joy of Becoming a Veterinarian
description: This article is from a special issue of Education Life that looks at professional schools.

title: New York Today: Life Without the G
description: Good morning on this fine Friday.

title: Morning Views
description: The Central Intelligence Agency needs a thorough overhaul, at its very core for breaking into the computers of the Senate Intelligence Committee, says an editorial in The New York Times. C.I.A. director John Brennan apologized privately to the committees leadership and promised to determine who was responsible for the hacking, but the accountability and the apologies should go much further, the editorial says. Its not just two senators that the C.I.A. has offended by this shocking action. It is all of Congress and, by extension, the American public, which is paying for an intelligence agency that does not seem to understand the most fundamental concept of separation of powers. The committee was working on a classified report detailing the agencys controversial antiterror program when the hacking occurred. Congress is supposed to oversee the intelligence community and rein in its excesses. It cannot possibly do so effectively if it is being spied on by the spy agency, which is supposed to be directing its efforts against foreign terrorists and other threats to national security.

title: Daily Report: Alibaba Pours Big Money Into Some American Tech Companies
description: Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet retailer, is coming to America with its checkbook wide open, Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced report.

title: The Prospect of Peace Between Israel and Gaza
description: Following a cease-fire that took effect on Friday, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators will attend talks in Cairo.

title: An Assault Upon Our Children
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After my older brother fell ill from the stress of being a student in South Korea, my mother decided to move me from our home in Seoul to Vancouver for high school to spare me the intense pressure to succeed. She did not want me to suffer like my brother, who had a chest pain that doctors could not diagnose and an allergy so severe he needed to have shots at home.

title: Politics, Culture and Perfect Timing
description: This week the Book Review cover features Frank Rich on The Invisible Bridge, the third volume in Rick Perlsteins series about the history of American conservatism. Rich is, of course, the former New York Times columnist and theater critic, and still an occasional contributor to the Book Review.

title: Evaluating That Third  Boring  Year
description: One proposal to improve legal education: give students less of it.

title: Campus Sexual Assault Bill Relies on Public Shaming of Colleges
description: The bipartisan sponsors of the campus sexual assault bill introduced this week say they are proud of the stiff fines and real teeth they would impose on colleges that underreport assaults. But there is a weakness in the legislation that makes the prospect of fines somewhat illusory: a lack of funding to hire more investigators.

title: This Is Law School?
description: The students are pitching.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In The Times this week: High Time, a six-part series from the Times editorial board calling for the repeal of the federal ban on marijuana.

title: Fatal Blasts Jolt Taiwans Second Largest City
description: At least 25 people were killed and more than 260 injured in Kaohsiung.

title: Morning Agenda: Markets Fall but Strategists Shrug
description: MARKETS FALL BUT STRATEGISTS SHRUG | The stock market ended July with the sharpest decline in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index since April, while the Dow Jones industrial index fell more than 300 points, eliminating all of its gains for the year, Jeff Sommer writes in DealBook. The reasons for the losses on Thursday were not entirely clear  a few disappointing earnings reports, Argentinas default and fears about global conflict may all have been factors. But whatever the causes of the decline, it wasnt entirely unexpected, and the reaction of several strategists was fairly upbeat.

title: Believe It Or Not, Atheists, TV for You
description: Atheists are angry, and watch out, because now they have a television channel.

title: More Rejoin Labor Force; Jobless Rate Up to 6.2%
description: Little to rave or rant about.

description: The questions of whether traditional fashion shows have any validity anymore, and whether they are actually entertainment and we should just embrace the change, are about to enter the conversation again.

title: Swing Dancing in a Wheelchair
description: Dear Diary:

title: French Telecom Iliads Flaky Offer for T-Mobile US
description: Iliad has delivered what could be a Trojan horse for Sprints plans to buy T-Mobile US. In a rival approach, the $16 billion French telcommunications company has offered $33 a share, or $15 billion, for 57 percent of the No. 4 U.S. mobile operator. Its a flaky offer on several levels. But the intervention may intensify antitrust objections to Sprints wish to merge.

title: Ask Well: Do I Need a Measles Shot?
description: Question:

title: The Making Of | Christophe Lemaires Striking, Sculptural Leather Bags
description: Even two-plus decades into his distinguished and varied fashion career, the Paris-based designer Christophe Lemaireis still very much a man of the moment. He recently stepped down from his post as the artistic director at Herms to focus on his own namesake line, which embodies fashions tilt toward discretion while maintaining its own specifically French brand of chic. As it has grown in renown, Sarah-Linh Tran, Lemaires studio director, muse and partner, has also become more prominent, reliably appearing on tastemakers Pinterest and Tumblr feeds. The two met eight years ago, when Tran was still a student and Lemaire was just restarting his business. Very naturally, very quickly, we discovered that we had a certain sensitivity and complicity about aesthetics and style and art and movies, Lemaire says. And very naturally, we ended up doing what everybody said we shouldnt do: work together.

title: Outstanding in Our Fields
description: TIMES INSIDER  Welcome to the August Times Premier Puzzle Pack. Its hot and humid, but well be inside enough during the winter, so lets make the most of our time outdoors. There is plenty to do, as youll discover in this months puzzles.

title: Scientific Games to Buy Bally Technologies for $3.3 Billion
description: Scientific Games said Friday that it would buy the slot-machine maker Bally Technologies for $3.3 billion in cash.

title: What to Expect When You Shouldnt Expect Lunch: A Dads Guide to Delivery Day
description: My wife went into labor in the middle of the night. Not knowing how much time we had, I grabbed our hospital bag and headed for the door. I had wisely preassembled the bag from countless online lists  nightgown, toiletries, even a flashlight. Fifteen hours of labor later, I was proud: That bag had everything my wife needed. But as hard as this father-to-be had tried to think of everything, I had failed to pack my own necessities. Two hours into one of the most important days of my life, I suffered an excruciating case of the munchies.

title: A Soldier Poet, Baring His Soul
description: LONDON  He yearned for a genuine taste of the horrors. He never thought he would become a great poet, and if it were not for mother and friends he would pray for a speedy death. In a place of war, he wrote, I never thought to find such peace.

title: Summer Job? Time to Start a Roth I.R.A.
description: When teenagers earn money for the first time, there are so many things they can do with it.

title: Israel and Hamas on Cease-Fire Collapse
description: Spokesmen for Israel and Hamas gave their versions of the events leading to the collapse of a 72-hour cease-fire shortly after it began.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 1
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images from a Greenwich Village shootout and the area of a mysterious 2010 death on Long Island.

title: Six Charts That Explain the Jobs Report
description: The new jobs numbers are a mild disappointment, with emphasis on the mild. Yes, the total of 209,000 jobs reported to have been added to United States payrolls was a bit below the 230,000 economists were expecting, and well below the revised 298,000 of June. And yes, the unemployment rate ticked up to 6.2 percent from 6.1 percent.

title: The Cocaine, the Blood, the Body Count
description: The Burns Archive, a trove of more than a million historic photographs crammed into a ramshackle townhouse on East 38th Street in Manhattan, is well known to scholars as one of the worlds most important repositories of early medical history, and to the ophthalmology patients who visit its proprietor, Dr. Stanley Burns, one day each week as surely the most atmospheric place in New York City to get an annual eye exam.

title: Free to Pack Heat in Washington, D.C.
description: Representative Thomas Massie, a Republican freshman from Kentucky beloved by the gun lobby, could barely wait to get to the House floor after a federal court struck down as unconstitutional the District of Columbias strict ban on carrying handguns in public.

title: Uganda Anti-Gay Law Struck Down by Court
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A Ugandan court struck down a punitive anti-gay law on Friday that has strained Ugandas relations with the West, but the court ruled on narrow technical grounds, preserving the possibility that the measure could be revived.

title: Cantor Gives Farewell Address
description: Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, thanked his fellow representatives for their service on Thursday, his last day as House majority leader.

title: Santa Fe Food Festival Revels in the Regional
description: Tired of being leapfrogged by locavore newcomers from Brooklyn to Portland, organizers of Santa Fes new food festival, Fuze.SW, aim to get diners thinking about the regions culinary history.

title: Hawks Be Gone
description: The inflation hawks went on another mini-rampage yesterday, after the latex number on the employment cost index came in above expectations. Inflation is here!!!!

title: Lois Lowry on Giving Up The Giver to Hollywood
description: The author talks to Jessica Gross about all the ways young-adult fiction has changed since she published The Giver two decades ago.

title: Who Made That Dog Biscuit?
description: For most of their history as human companions, dogs have scavenged scraps from the supper table. But that all changed in 1860, when an Ohio electrician named James Spratt journeyed to London to sell lightning rods. After watching quayside mongrels feasting on hardtack, the dry biscuit that fed sailors on long voyages, Spratt set about making a biscuit for dogs that could serve as their primary food.

title: How Ramen Got Me Through Adolescence
description: When I was in fifth grade, I developed an intense dislike of eating around other people. The cafeteria was a place of foul odors, gelatinous spills, horrific mixtures of chocolate pudding, fruit cocktail and ketchup consumed on dares, and I found myself fasting from breakfast, at about 6 in the morning, until 3:35, when I walked home through the woods from the bus stop. Each step up our hill, a narrow ridge in rural California, I fantasized about the big bowl of ramen I would make myself when I reached the top.

title: Reply All: The 7.20.14 Issue
description: THE TRIALS OF GRAHAM SPANIER

title: Spoon, the Molecular Gastronomists of Rock
description: Britt Daniel thought it would be cool to play a game.

title: Can Parenthood and Pessimism Live Side by Side?
description: When I was about 10 or 11, my father took me to a nursing home one summer evening. As a pharmacist in the small Irish city of Kilkenny, he sometimes visited customers and other elderly acquaintances who were hospitalized or bedridden, and I would insist on going with him, as in those days I insisted on accompanying him wherever he went, relishing even the prospect of a trip to the dump if it meant spending time alone with my father, whom I idolized. This nursing home, a low and dreary building, was a place Id never been to before; known locally as the poor house, it was a state-run institution for elderly and senile patients whose families could not afford to pay for their care.

title: Son of a Sign Painter
description: Also, fine art meets fast fashion; a space for women in China.

title: Campus Police: Precrime Division
description: I study computer science at a midsize university, and my school has cameras that cover almost every part of campus. The development of video-processing algorithms that can discern race, height and approximate age is ongoing in the field. Already, some modern video systems can alert owners of loitering, abnormal behavior and other common precursors to crime. Would it be ethical to hone the university security system to calculate and publicize the real-time probability of impending crime based on live video processing and existing statistics on criminal demographics? D. D.

title: Scratch-Off Art on Subway Platforms
description: To subway riders feeling impatient, restless or a little destructive, the print advertisements lining the walls of a station can make irresistible targets. Kevin Shea Adams, a photographer, began taking iPhone shots of ads in various states of decay and modification about four years ago. When layered on top of one another, the ads produce collage like art, as strips are peeled away to reveal underlying images. Theyre participatory, theyre public, theyre sort of chaotic and random, he says. Because Adams commutes between Bushwick and Greenpoint, most of the stations he has frequented are in Brooklyn, where they tend to be less well maintained. The ads are very tactile, he says. When youre standing waiting for a train, bored out of your mind, you just want to pull them. Julie Bosman

title: An Unemployment Line, From Coast to Coast
description: Heres an unusual but extraordinarily graphic description of the current state of the labor market: If you lined up all of the unemployed shoulder-to-shoulder, the queue of people looking for work would stretch all the way from New York out past San Francisco.

title: 1914: Vociferous Crowds Cheer Kaiser
description: BERLIN  Fifty thousand persons assembled yesterday [Aug. 1] afternoon before the Imperial Palace and cheered the Kaiser and the Empire vociferously and continuously. At 6.15 p.m. the Kaiser appeared at one of the windows of the palace, and the enthusiasm of the crowd then became almost frantic. Addressing the great throng in a loud clear voice, the Kaiser said: This is a dark day and a sombre hour for Germany. Envious people on every side have forced us to a just defence. The sword is placed in our hands by force. I hope that, if at the last moment my efforts to bring about an understanding between ourselves and our adversaries and to maintain the peace do not succeed, we may, by the help of God, so use our swords that when all is ended we can replace them in their scabbards with honor. A war will ask from us enormous sacrifices of men and of money, but we shall show our enemies what it means to provoke Germany. And now I recommend you all to God. Go to church, kneel before Him and pray that He may sustain our brave army.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 2, 1914

title: Facts Still Have, Well, You Know
description: The Columbia Journalism Review has more about Stephen Moores fact-challenged attempt to demonstrate the virtues of tax cuts, which I wrote about the other day. We learn a bit more about the story  the piece was published because Moore demanded the opportunity to reply to my column about Kansas  which makes it even funnier and more remarkable that he couldnt be bothered to get the numbers right. Also, my favorite line from the piece:

title: Foreign Crises Fade on Congressional Campaign Trail
description: WASHINGTON  Crises in Gaza, Iraq, Syria and Ukraine have dominated the news this summer and even grabbed the attention of many Americans who are usually indifferent to international affairs. Yet the events might as well be in a parallel universe for all the notice they are getting in this years congressional campaigns.

title: Math
description: HOW NOT TO BE WRONG  The Power of Mathematical Thinking  By Jordan Ellenberg  Penguin Press, $27.95.

title: Letters: Contemporary Poetry
description: Contemporary Poetry

title: Paperback Row
description: SUBTLE BODIES,  by Norman Rush. (Vintage International, $15.) A sophisticated romp through the joys and tribulations of friendship and marriage, Rushs third novel has many of the qualities that defined its predecessors, Mating and Mortals. In 2003, with the invasion of Iraq looming, a group of college friends and self-styled wits, now middle-aged, gather in the Catskills after the sudden death of their ringleader.

title: Editors Choice
description: A SPY AMONG FRIENDS: Kim Philby and the Great Betrayal,  by Ben Macintyre. (Crown, $27.) This account of the high-level British spymaster who turned out to be a Russian mole reads like John le Carr but is a solidly researched true story.

title: Inside the List
description: Power Couple: The title of Daniel Halpers Clinton, Inc. refers to the marriage of Bill and Hillary Clinton  Halper, the online editor at The Weekly Standard, argues that the couple function as co-chief executives of a mighty enterprise whose main business is politics. But you could be forgiven for thinking his title also describes the publishing industry. With the books debut this week at No. 10, there are now three Clinton-related volumes on the hardcover nonfiction list; Halper joins Edward Klein, whose Blood Feud is No. 3 after five weeks, and Hillary Clinton herself, whose Hard Choices is No. 5 after seven weeks. This state of affairs is nothing new. By my count, the Clintons have featured in more than 60 best sellers since entering the national stage in 1992. And they retain a close interest in whats written about them, according to Halper. While I was still reporting on my book, he told Politico last month, James Carvilles office called, seemingly out of the blue, to grill me on whom Id already spoken to. I obviously refused to indulge the questioner. Halper also said that Clintons publisher had reached out to his publisher for information about the book, and that Clintonites were scrambling to identify his unnamed sources. Ive found the task of covering the Clintons fascinating, he said. Theyre not exactly the people we see on television. They may, however, be the people we see in literature  Halper sets his tone by opening Clinton, Inc. with a damning line from The Great Gatsby: They were careless people, Tom and Daisy  they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into . . . whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: Tingling to sleep, infectious greetings and the long-lasting benefits of running. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Moving Crosstown
description: A decade ago, living on a crosstown thoroughfare like 14th or 23rd street was considered undesirable. Now numerous residential towers are sprouting up along these four-lane streets.

title: T.R.s Son Inspired Him to Help Rescue Football
description: From his adolescence, Theodore Roosevelt felt an emotional kinship with football. He liked rough, manly sports, he told a crowd as president in 1903. I do not feel any particular sympathy for the person who gets battered about a good deal  so long as it is not fatal.

title: Busy. Noisy. Homey.
description: A mere decade ago, frantic crosstown thoroughfares like 14th Street, 23rd Street and even 57th Street were not yet the apple of any residential developers eye. If not out of sight, they were out of mind because of their traffic, noise and commerce.

title: Syrias Mental Health Crisis
description: One day in June, I sat in an Istanbul coffee shop with a Syrian source. Hes a young man in his 20s, a former activist who has, over the course of the war, fled from Damascus to Beirut and Amman before settling in Turkeys largest city  a dusty urban sprawl whose mayor has reportedly said he intends to round up Syrian refugees and forcibly return them to border camps.

title: In Legal Field, Using Technology to Stay on Top of a Shifting Market
description: Its no secret that law school has lost its reputation as a sure pathway to wealth.

title: A Thawing in Iceland
description: Failure is in fashion these days. We read about failing fast and failing well, about grit incubated by repeated failure in school and innovation by repeated failure in business. So it may be a good time to consider the hidden virtues of failure in foreign policy. And who better to demonstrate those virtues than one of modern Americas great optimists?

title: The Music of Time
description: A novel can afford to unveil its secrets slowly. Not so a short story. With its constricted circuitry, it has to be a stairway of surprise (in Emersons phrase) or the reader will stop climbing at the second or third step. The most incisive stories by Jane Gardam, a writer well known in Britain for childrens books and a host of novels (including the Old Filth trilogy that has recently won her new readers in America), are constructed, more often than not, around a double take. From colonial postings abroad, from buried love affairs, from the lists of the presumed dead (or near-dead, as they are called in one of Gardams ghost-ridden stories), a once-familiar figure suddenly looms. The unsettling appearance of such revenants  as in Proust or Anthony Powells A Dance to the Music of Time  brings about, in these deftly written tales, a shift, a re-evaluation, a fresh sense of what really happened in the past and an opening into a possibly altered future.

title: Mind Ablaze
description: Stephen Crane, whose likeness appears on the album cover of Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band, was Americas first rock-star writer. He self-published his realist novella Maggie: A Girl of the Streets at 21, losing so much money that he took to starving himself and wearing rubber boots because he couldnt afford shoes. By the time he was 23, he had imagined a creature, naked, bestial, / Who, squatting upon the ground, / Held his heart in his hands, / And ate of it. / I said, Is it good, friend? / It is bitter  bitter, he answered; / But I like it / Because it is bitter, / And because it is my heart.

title: Enchanted Connections
description: If Lev Grossmans The Magicians was like The Secret History crossed with Harry Potter, and if its sequel, The Magician King, was a descendant of The Chronicles of Narnia (with a touch of the 1990s flick The Craft thrown in), then what cultural mash-up does Lev Grossman conjure in The Magicians Land, the trilogys final book? I cant tell you, because I was too thoroughly swept away by this richly imagined and continually surprising novel to be concerned with cute comparisons.

title: Nowhere to Run
description: Once you flip past the title page of a novel or story collection, you are entering into a relationship with someone, the fiction writer, who will try to deceive you for his or her own selfish reasons  literary glory, financial gain, sexual display, take your pick. At some point you decide whether or not you will let yourself look past the motive that helped bring the book into being, a decision that depends on your sense of how fairly the writer has treated you.

title: Best Exotic Kingdom
description: I have done almost everything in life except two things. I havent had a son, and I have never come down in a parachute.

title: Sundance Plans Screenings in Hong Kong
description: LOS ANGELES  Sundance is sprouting an Asian offshoot.

title: International Arts Events Happening In the Week Ahead
The Townhouse, Minus the Past
description: In response to surging demand for larger spaces, developers in Brooklyn are going back to the classic townhouse, but building new variations with contemporary families in mind.

title: Rules of Style | Danny Bowien on How to Look Sharp and Why He Chopped His Locks
description: The chef and restaurateur Danny Bowien claims hes not into fashion, but hes clearly got his own idiosyncratic ideas about style. A typical look involves an oversize, vintage Bulls athletic tank jersey turned inside out, blazing red nylon shorts from Creatures of Comfort and dark leather Bragard slip-on kitchen shoes paired with black knit socks. His trademarks are a pair of worn-in, sciencey specs and his two-tone hair, which he recently trimmed himself. The cut was inspired both by his six-month-old son Mino (I didnt want to be that dad with weird hair) and his insanely busy schedule, which leaves little time for grooming. With two restaurants to run  Mission Cantina in New York and Mission Chinese Food in San Francisco  along with various pop-ups, including his newest at Mile End Deli on Bond Street, Bowien has been living out of his Y-3 backpack and traveling on his 3Rensho bike whenever possible. Earlier this week, he took a break in between lunch and dinner services to talk about his love of band T-shirts, why he had to quit using cologne and his former stint as a Uniqlo model (watch out, it could happen again).

title: Deep End
description: Rules, rules, so many stupid rules: Dont switch point of view. Dont give away the identity of the killer. Dont write in the second person. Yannick Murphy, an author who seems drawn to high cliffs, ignores all the warnings in THIS IS THE WATER (Harper Perennial, paper, $14.99), an inventive thriller set in suburbia  and in the troubled minds of her characters. The second-person narrative voice that feels alienating at the outset (This is the water. . . . This is the swim mom. . . . This is the bathroom) soon becomes hypnotic (This is you, Annie) and then seriously unsettling (This is the killer). Annie, the mother of two girls on a competitive swim team, is the most appealing of all the moms in their pretty New England town who shell out $1,000 per child to get their kids on the team and hundreds more for those sadistically engineered racing suits that are supposed to shave milliseconds off their records. But while Annie dutifully volunteers to time the girls practice swims and drive to out-of-town meets, she can never satisfy a fanatic like Dinah, who monitors everyones moves and complains that Annie and her daughters always seem to be doing what theyre not supposed to do.

title: What the Hearts Want
description: Our American present seems best served by a literature of swerves. Whiplash plot changes. Arrivals that surprise, departures that are kicks in the teeth. Characters who veer violently off course: Think of poor Ned Stark from A Game of Thrones, or erratic Amy Dunne from Gone Girl. This is popular fictions response to the cloud of dark news that wont quit raining on us. If life really has taken on a schizoid vibe, then maybe a narrative schizophrenia has come to look like real life.

title: All Over the Map
description: This year, three of the worlds largest democracies are holding national elections  vast polls spread over several days and thousands of miles of territory, involving more than a billion voters. Two of these elections have attracted intense media coverage, or will. Indias national elections, which took place in May, swept out of office the long-ruling Congress Party and handed government of a rising economic and political power to the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party. Brazils elections, which will be held in October, are coming on the heels of the World Cup, one of several high-profile events that have marked the countrys emergence as the second giant of the Americas.

title: Head Count
description: Getting people to attach an ian (or an ist) to the end of your name is pretty impressive. Getting them to keep doing so 180 years after your death, not as a musty reference but as part of vital contemporary debates, well, thats a phenomenon worth studying.

title: War Comes to America
description: Our understanding of the past is shaped in no small part by the letters and memoirs of the people who made history, or claimed to. Rival statesmen have long understood this. In their nearly 40 years of intimate but tendentious correspondence, Thomas Jefferson and John Adams were jockeying for posterity; in dueling memoirs a century and a half later, so were Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger. Indeed, one reason Nixon installed the secret White House taping system was to make sure he could rebut Kissingers version of events.

title: Searching For John Milius
description: My post on conservatives and the arts has prompted an interesting reply from Micah Mattix, of the Prufrock blog and newsletter:

title: How Conservation and Groundwater Management Can Gird California for a Drier Era
description: Its way past time for California to come to grips with the possibility that its extraordinary water woes are the new normal  and essentially the return of the old normal given the states climate history, in which drought has been the rule and the verdant 20th century the exception. In the weekly update to the U.S. Drought Monitor site yesterday, nearly 80 percent of the state was in extreme or exceptional drought conditions.

title: Amazon Wants Cheaper E-Books. But Should It Get to Enforce Prices?
description: In ashort blog postmeant to shed light on its contract dispute with the publisher Hachette,Amazon argued this week that its data proved that lower e-book prices were better for everyone in the market for books. That includes authors, publishers, customers and Amazon itself.

title: What Happens When You Mess With Nerds
description: The role of the nerd in mass culture occasionally pops up as a topic of national debate (see for instance the perennial question of whether nerds are cool now). Now Charles C.W. Cooke of The National Review has issued a critique of nerds in the political sphere  and in so doing hes placed himself in the middle of one of nerd cultures biggest arguments.

title: Ambassador to Russia Is Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON  Before leaving on its recess, the Senate confirmed John F. Tefft as the United States ambassador to Russia, filling a post that had been vacant since February, when a frayed relationship between the two countries began to deteriorate further over the separatist uprising in Ukraine.

title: Singers Stretch Their Genres
description: Borders have always been porous among jazz, R&B, pop, world music and, lately, hip-hop. Two musicians comfortable in the overlaps perform this week.

title: Now, Its Almost Family-Hour Fare
description: As television and film have pushed the boundaries of sexual explicitness, an examination of the sleek, soft-core movies that were once viewed as upscale exploitation fare for prurient audiences resistant to hard-core pornography is long overdue. On Thursday, the Film Society of Lincoln Center begins its series This Is Softcore: The Art Cinema Erotica of Radley Metzger at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center with Carmen, Baby (1967), this directors take on Prosper Mrimes 19th-century novella that inspired the Bizet opera Carmen. Uta Levka plays the Gypsy temptress who, much to the distress of the policeman who loves her, sleeps her way to the top of the social ladder in 1960s Spain.

title: Triple the Space and Right in Town
description: Next Saturday at 5 p.m., after a week of member previews, the 35-year-old Aspen Art Museum in Colorado will open the doors of its new building to the public and then keep them open for a 24-hour celebration.

title: An Auteur, in His Own Words
description: Robert Altman was, by most accounts, a man who burned a lot of bridges during his long career as a director. That career receives a slick and enjoyable recapping on Wednesday at 8 p.m. when Epix offers Altman, a documentary in which Altman, who died in 2006, tells much of his own story via archival interviews.

title: Hold On to Your Phone!
description: From the outside, Bounden may look like two people arduously inspecting the same iPhone: twisting and turning while grasping opposite ends of the device, eyes fixed on the screen. And essentially thats what it is, though, if done right, those twists and turns have the elegance of choreography. Created by the Dutch design studio Game Oven, this recently released app steers users through entwining duets choreographed by Ernst Meisner of the Dutch National Ballet. To replicate the swinging, circular moves, you and your partner maneuver an icon along arcing, ever-shifting pathways, inevitably getting tangled. If we cant put down our phones, Bounden exploits that isolating tendency to bring us closer  physically, at least. Its fun, especially at early levels, where good dancing isnt the point. As the game advances, it becomes trickier, monitoring your accuracy and flashing Hurry up! if you fall behind the music, like a good-natured ballet master. Videos, featuring dancers from Dutch National Ballets junior company, offer something to aspire to. (gameovenstudios.com.)

title: Sci-Fi Beats With a Pacific Flavor
description: SEATTLE  It was a bright summer day here, but inside Shabazz Palaces studio, located in the Old Rainier Brewery building, it was dark as midnight. There were no windows, the walls were painted black, and the womblike interior was broken up only by a leopard-print rug. Hip-hop should only take place at night, said Palaceer Lazaro (real name: Ishmael Butler), 45, the mastermind of Shabazz Palaces, the eccentric experimental hip-hop act. The parties, this, everything.

title: Delayed Zombification
description: Like zombies, dormant scripts in Hollywood can rise from the dead. Jeff Baena knows this better than most. His directorial debut, Life After Beth, a zombie romantic comedy splashed with existential angst and starring his real-life girlfriend, Aubrey Plaza, arrives in theaters on Aug. 15, some 11 years after he wrote it.

title: They Help You Listen With Your Eyes
description: There is no difference between ballet music and other music; there is only good and bad music, Pavel Sorokin, the conductor of the Bolshoi Orchestra, said in a tiny sitting room backstage at the David H. Koch Theater before a performance of Swan Lake last month as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Pick a Soundtrack for the Summer, or One Will be Given to You
description: Jason Derulo

title: A Helping Hand in Brick and Mortar
description: Most civic buildings such as post offices and firehouses are spread out every 10 or 20 blocks, solitary outposts of municipal order. In a few cases they were built in little pockets, such as the unusual group around York Avenue in the far East 70s, which included three model tenement complexes, a school, a library, a settlement house and a public bath. All served an area once called Little Bohemia.

title: Where the Din Is on Mute
description: Phil Grucci is accustomed to working on a grand scale, but he is relatively new to living on one.

title: What the Republicans Failed to Accomplish
description: Many House members were at the airport yesterday, desperate to begin their five-week vacation, when the chambers leadership called them back. An emergency bill to provide money for the humanitarian crisis at the Southern border had earlier been pulled from the floor because of objections from the hard right; now some Republicans wanted to try again.

title: Today in Small Business: Are Employees Champions?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: House Republicans Agree on Border Measures
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans emerged from a closed-door emergency meeting Friday morning largely unified over how to handle the flood of tens of thousands of young migrant children from Central America pouring over the nations southern border.

title: Procter & Gamble to Streamline Offerings, Dropping Up to 100 Brands
description: After years of expansion into areas like pet food and beauty products, Procter & Gamble announced on Friday that it would cut as many as 100 brands from its arsenal to focus on others, like Tide, that made the company a powerhouse over the decades.

title: Ebola Vaccine Possible, but Many Doubts Persist
description: Even as federal health officials announced plans to speed development of an Ebola vaccine, scientists who study the virus warned that the task would be arduous and that success was hardly guaranteed.

title: Kerry Calls on Qatar and Turkey to Gain Release of Israeli Soldier
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany  Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday urged Qatar and Turkey to use their influence to secure the release of an Israeli soldier who apparently was captured in Gaza shortly after an announced cease-fire went into effect.

title: A Cuomo Opponent Tilting at Corruption
description: On the morning of July 23, Zephyr Teachout was filming a video for her campaign, produced by a friend of hers, the actor Chris Eigeman. The script played on her unusual name and her anonymity. Ms. Teachout is challenging Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in the Democratic primary, though a recent Siena College poll found that 91 percent of Democratic voters had no idea who she was or held no opinion of her.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Whats Almost as Certain as Death? Not Talking About the Inheritance
description: IF there is a boogeyman when it comes to family conversations about inheritance, it is not death. That happens whether people talk about financial plans or not. Its the $40 trillion that financial advisers say their baby boomer clients are going to pass to their children either in an orderly way  or in a chaotic mess.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: The Justice of Argentina's Default
Argentina Default Is Ruled a Credit Event for Swaps
description: Updated, 12:41 p.m. | The repercussions of Argentinas sovereign debt default continued to spread through global markets on Friday, as an industry body decided that financial instruments used to insure against the default must pay out.

title: Real Estate Agents for Older Adults Are Part Broker, Part Therapist
description: VERA LIGHTSTONE, a sculptor, jeweler and ceramist, never planned to move out of her loft in Manhattans Hells Kitchen, especially not in her 81st year. Why would she? She had 1,800 square feet of living and work space, high ceilings and a clear view of the Hudson River. In New York, that was a real estate trifecta.

title: Botox Maker Allergan Sues Valeant and Ackman, Claiming Insider Trading
description: Updated, 6:52 p.m. | Allergan, the maker of Botox and other pharmaceuticals, is suing Valeant Pharmaceuticals and the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, accusing them of insider trading as part of their hostile effort to take it over.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Invisible Bridge
description: This week, Rick Perlstein discusses The Invisible Bridge; Alexandra Alter has notes from the field; Jan Swafford talks about Beethoven; Amy Rowland discusses The Transcriptionist; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: French TV Executive Aims to Entertain North Africa, Too
description: PARIS  BOUCHRA REJANIS parents had planned her career for her: She would pursue medical studies and become a doctor. At 18, Ms. Rejani responded by lowering herself out a window of the family home in Cholet, a small town in western France, and leaving. For good.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Invisible Bridge
description: This week, Rick Perlstein, Jan Swafford and Amy Rowland.

title: Rooftop Parties Galore
description: An elaborately appointed triplex penthouse, crowned by a rambling 3,000-square-foot rooftop terrace that accommodates 100 merrymakers and offers multiple cityscape views from its 11th-floor perch at 655 Park Avenue, is poised to enter the market at $11.5 million. The monthly maintenance charges are $8,177.99.

title: Honoring James Baldwins 90th Birthday in Harlem
description: James Baldwin, a Harlem native who died in 1987, would have turned 90 on Saturday. Among the many tributes in a year in which his legacy as a major writer is being celebrated, one on Saturday is close to home: a portion of East 128th Street, between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue, will be renamed James Baldwin Way.

title: English Museum Loses Accreditation for Selling Ancient Egyptian Statue
description: A British organization that accredits museums on Friday sanctioned a small English museum that sold off an ancient Egyptian statue last month, for which it received a portion of the $27 million sale price.

title: Dogged Persistence Pays Off, With Interest
description: In this episode, the story of an epic, four-year battle between a man and a health insurer. Typically, these stories end with the same score: Health Insurer 1, Patient 0.

title: At Union-Owned Amalgamated Bank, New Chief Charts a Progressive Course
description: One of New Yorks biggest small banks has a new leader.

title: The Battle of Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: The internal message board of the One Brooklyn Bridge Park luxury condominium is generally used to post babysitter wanted notes or to remind residents to pick up their dry cleaning. Last spring, residents used it to air their dirty laundry.

title: The Magic of Feeling Safe at Work
description: Updated, 11:52 a.m. |

title: Fresh and Fruity Salsas
description: I was inspired to work on summer salsas this week, not just because of the heat wave that had begun to settle over Los Angeles, but also by a recipe called Tropical C Burst. It was created by the Los Angeles students Jenifer Mendez and Kimberly Sanchez for a national high school Cooking Up Change competition in Washington.

title: S.U.V.s and Trucks Lift Monthly Vehicle Sales
description: Sport utility vehicles are back, and in July they helped bolster auto sales nationwide.

title: Many Problems Lead to Thoughts of Suicide, Study Finds
description: Older adults contemplating suicide do not cite depression as the primary reason, according to research presented recently at the annual meeting of the American Association for Geriatric Psychiatry. More often, they blame their struggles with illness, disability, financial concerns, family difficulties and bereavement for their suicidal thoughts.

title: Deadline Set to Redraw Voting Map in Florida
description: MIAMI  The Florida judge who ruled last month that two of the states congressional districts were illegally drawn to favor Republicans issued a new court ruling Friday, this time admitting that he was unsure how to resolve the problem by Novembers election.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Tutto Italiano, Massachusetts-Style
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: The Squeeze on the Middlebrow
description: Capital in the 21st Century, by the French economist Thomas Piketty, has become this years most unlikely best seller, a crossover from the world of scholarship into general public discussion of a kind that seems rarer than it used to be. The books thesis  that economic inequality in the developed world is increasing, with potentially dire consequences for social justice and democratic governance  has struck a nerve in the American body politic. But its implications extend beyond the realm of political economy. Though it is expectedly dry, careful and data-driven, the book invites the re-examination of deeply held assumptions about the world.

title: Noel Black, 77, Dies; Directed Dark Comedy Cult Hit
description: Noel Black, a director whose first feature film, the 1968 black comedy Pretty Poison, divided critics but became a cult hit, died on July 5 at a hospital near his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 77.

title: Airbnb Pushes to Modify San Francisco Housing Laws
description: Airbnbs is intensifying its campaign to change San Francisco housing rules.

title: 2 Palestinians Killed in West Bank Clashes
description: JERUSALEM  Two Palestinians were fatally shot by Israeli security forces during clashes in the West Bank on Friday, according to the Palestinian news media.

title: Banksy Surveillance Work Is Vandalized
description: LONDON  Now it really is graffiti.

title: Problems With the Bill Limiting Surveillance
description: Like other people who have been concerned about the erosion of our constitutional rights since the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the editorial board was happy when Senator Patrick Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee, introduced a bill the other day that aims to eliminate the mass collection of data on Americans communications. The House had tried to do that, but failed after the White House pressured its members into watering down the measure.

title: Insurgents Kill a Lawmaker in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Gunmen killed a Somali lawmaker as he left a mosque in Mogadishu on Friday, officials and witnesses said. The lawmaker, Aden Madeer, was the fifth member of Parliament to die in a violent attack this year.

title: Hyundai Recalls 419,000 Vehicles in Three Actions
description: Hyundai is recalling about 419,000 vehicles in the United States in three separate actions for brake, electrical and suspension problems, according to reports the automaker posted Friday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: 1939: Hitler Proclaims War Holiday
description: BERLIN  The twenty-fifth anniversary of the outbreak of the last war will be celebrated tomorrow [Aug. 2] by the entire German nation. Twenty-five years after Russian troops invaded East Prussia and German troops crossed the Belgian frontier, this anniversary has now completed the full cycle of change from a symbol of defeat to a harbinger of eventual German triumph. By Chancellor Hitlers personal command, tomorrow will be a holiday for the entire German Army  the largest and strongest in German history. Every garrison in the Third Reich will hold special exercises to mark the beginning of four years of war which ended in defeat for Germany. This paradox is elaborated  if not explained  in columns of historical comment which fill the German press today. The grim situation in Europe this summer is explained in this official history as a parallel to that of 1914 only in its external form. The difference between 1914 and 1939 is summed up in most German newspapers by the black headlines August, 1914, Kaiser Wilhelm  August, 1939, Adolf Hitler. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 2, 1939

title: Brown Sugar-Cured Salmon
description: Melissa Clark uses hickory wood chips to grill salmon cured with brown sugar, allspice and mace.

title: Top 15 Fantasy Football Running Backs
description: Images of the top 15 running backs in fantasy football.

title: Fantasy Football: Running Back Primer
description: Along with a pass-happy mentality, a running back by committee approach has become the norm for N.F.L. offenses in recent years. This has made the most coveted of all positions that much harder to plan for on draft day. Last season, we had to endure nine running back busts among the first 20 taken, based on their Average Draft Position. That is a 20 percent increase from a rate of just 25 percent in 2012. As a result, more owners are de-emphasizing the running back position in favor of top-tier receivers and quarterbacks in the early rounds.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: Since the genome was sequenced 10 years ago, personalized medicine has caught fire. Pharmaceutical companies are now developing drugs for so-called orphan diseases, which affect only a small sliver of the population. It sounds great, but some of these drugs cost a thousand dollars a pill.

title: George Hobica Finds Air Travels Rare Silver Linings
description: With the Transportation Security Administration increasing its fees and airlines charging extra for everything from seats to bags, flying has become an even costlier proposition, especially for families.

title: James Franco on Fame, Directing and How Hed Spend a Night in Jail
description: In a corner booth at the Tribeca Grand Hotel, James Franco scans the menu and announces hes getting the chopped salad. Professionally, however, hes become notorious for ordering everything, ricocheting among projects like a pinball. His latest is Child of God, a bruising, low-budget adaptation of a 1973 Cormac McCarthy novel set in the Tennessee backwoods. Franco co-wrote, directed and appears briefly in the film, which follows Lester Ballard (Scott Haze), an unhinged loner who descends into madness, menacing the townsfolk with a shotgun, which he becomes increasingly eager to use. Franco, who recently wrapped a successful Broadway run as the star of Of Mice and Men, spoke with T about his unique fan base, his notorious productivity and his uneasy relationship with fame.

title: First Extended Talks at Met End Without a Labor Deal
description: The Metropolitan Operas coming season  and the livelihoods of its workers  continued to hang in the balance on Friday, as the company continued labor talks with two of its biggest unions and a federal mediator in an effort to make progress before a Sunday night deadline.

title: Strahan Still in Spotlight Ahead of Hall of Fame Induction
description: It was Monday morning, days before Michael Strahan was set to be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and Strahan, a star defensive end for the Giants for a decade and a half, was busy being Michael Strahan.

title: Argentina Ordered to Resume Talks With Hedge Fund
description: A lawyer for Argentina told a federal judge on Friday that the nation had lost faith in the mediator appointed to work with a group of hedge funds that hold the countrys bonds.

title: Marissa Mayers Post-Alibaba Reckoning
description: Yahoo is a big company with a much smaller one struggling to get out. A 22.5 percent stake in Alibaba accounts for well over half the companys roughly $36 billion market capitalization, according to a new Breakingviews calculator.

description: Part 12: Lucy Liu, Maggie Gyllenhaal and Mira Sorvino talk about how they get the right people involved with their ongoing projects, and discuss the beliefs they bring to their work.

description: SEATTLE  Sometime this fall, a huge vertical shaft lined with 84 concrete pilings, designed to hold back the slurry that defines underground Seattle, will be finished, and a Mr. Fix-It operation unlike any other will begin.

title: In Tunnel War, Israeli Playbook Offers Few Ideas
description: JERUSALEM  Israel entered its latest conflict with Hamas armed with a high-tech arsenal, real-time battlefield intelligence and strong domestic support for dealing a heavy blow to Hamas.

title: Court Allows Groin Searches of Detainees at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  Military guards may continue to touch the groins of detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, when they search for contraband before the prisoners are moved to speak with their lawyers, a federal appeals court ruled Friday. Because of the procedure, which was put in place in May 2013, some inmates have stopped meeting with or calling their lawyers.

title: Weekend Reading: Searching for Answers in Falling Stocks
description: The market dipped 2 percent on Thursday, erasing the Dows gains for the year. Some analysts said the drop was healthy, but there was less agreement about the reason for the losses.

Japan Invades Hawaii
description: Remember Pearl Harbor? Lots of people in Hawaii do, which made me wonder what the reaction there was to this video.

title: A Republican Victory by a Nose, Not a Wave
description: The Republicans get the six seats they need to retake the Senate in this weeks spin of Leos Senate election predicting wheels, which provide random simulations of what could occur in November. But does it qualify as a wave election?

title: Heres The Thing That Lasting Love Is Really About
description: Do you see love as a union of two people who are destined to be together? Or is it more of a journey they undertake, facing obstacles and working together to overcome them? According to new research, how you answer these questions may affect how you handle relationship troubles.

title: 2014 Ford Fiesta EcoBoost
description: Will Americans pay a premium for the Fiesta 1.0 EcoBoost, a car with an engine block thats the size of carry-on luggage?

title: Obama Casts Doubt on Chances of Gaza Cease-Fire
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday demanded that Hamas release a captured Israeli soldier unconditionally and expressed pessimism that another cease-fire could be reached because of the deep reserves of mistrust between the two sides.

description: Julia Preston has been reporting on the immigration crisis at the United States border with Mexico where Central American migrants are crossing. We asked her to share some of her experiences reporting the story.
