description: Where can you find what is possibly the worlds largest gathering of classic Detroit metal, along with a fervent gearhead subculture fascinated with the American South? Sweden, of course.

title: Detroit Love, Swedish Style
description: VASTERAS, SWEDEN  It was the evening of July 3, and a phalanx of American steel was arriving in this town an hour or so northwest of Stockholm.

title: Big Ticket | A Light-Filled Townhouse for $17.3 Million
description: A dignified brick-and-limestone townhouse built at the turn of the last century and owned since 1975 by the Permanent Mission of Burkina Faso to the United Nations sold for $17,310,250 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Eliot Sumner Changes Her Name, but Not Her Electro-Pop Beats
description: For the last four years, Eliot Sumner has performed under her nickname Coco as the frontwoman for the band I Blame Coco. Then this June she scrawled a handwritten note, snapped a photo of it and posted it on her social media accounts. The contents revealed that, after taking some time off since releasing her first album, The Constant, she had some news: I am happy to inform you that I am alive and well. New music is on the way! A bit further down came this revelation: New music will be released under my birth name, Eliot Sumner. I am looking forward to you hearing it. Its nice to be back.

title: TimesTalks | Powerful Women: Preview
description: The actresses Lucy Liu, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Mira Sorvino and Taylor Schilling talk about why theyre doing work on television that wouldnt be possible in the movies.

title: A Ferrari for You and Two Friends
description: When the door of the garage in a rural Connecticut town rolled open one day last month, the morning sun revealed a historically important  and long-stored  Ferrari.

title: Ptria Investments Raises $1.8 Billion Private Equity Fund in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The Brazilian firm Ptria Investments has closed a new $1.8 billion private equity fund, its largest ever, in yet another sign that investors still find Brazil attractive despite the nations many macroeconomic challenges.

title: 1966 Ferrari 365 P Berlinetta Speciale
description: A look at the 1966 Ferrari 365 P Berlinetta Speciale, which will be auctioned later this month by Gooding & Company.

title: Version 1.0: More Boost Than Eco
description: The standard-issue Ford Fiesta is powered by a 1.6-liter 4-cylinder that generates a modest 120 horsepower at 6,350 r.p.m. and 112 pound-feet of torque at 5,000 r.p.m. The lofty r.p.m. numbers for the power and torque peaks tell you all you need to know: This car is largely gutless unless youre riding it to the redline. Even then, the base Fiesta wont strain your sternocleidomastoid with undue G forces.

title: Good News on Financial Reform
description: The two big achievements of the Obama administration are health reform and financial reform. (Maybe carbon regulation will be added to the list; stay tuned.) For the most part, however, neither has gotten much respect. I think this may finally be changing on health reform, as the evidence piles up for a dramatic improvement in coverage in states that didnt obstruct the law. But financial reform is still unloved, attacked by the right as anti-business and by the left as too weak to work.

title: Roger Goodell Defends Length of Ray Rices Suspension
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell defended his decision to suspend Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice for two games despite an uproar from critics who said he was too lenient.

title: Video Reviews of Guardians of the Galaxy, Get On Up and Child of God
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the adaptation of the Marvel comic book series Guardians of the Galaxy, the adaptation of the Cormac McCarthy novel Child of God and the biopic on James Brown Get On Up. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: The HiFi Bar in the East Village Has Rock Credentials
description: After dinner one late spring Wednesday, the regulars assembled at the HiFi Bar. A gathering of musician-bartender types and their much taller girlfriends, all in the classic East Village uniform of worn leather jackets and slim, dark pants, leaned against the far corner of the bar, sipping cocktails. At a series of low, round tables, holdovers from the post-work happy-hour crowd, in button-downs and good shoes, laughed loudly, faces flushed, while they finished up their final pints.

title: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz, Over the Edge
description: Havent posted anything by this group for a while; but I really love both the music and watching these young talents interacting.

title: New Frontier in the Efficiency Quest: Cutting Heat Losses
description: DETROIT  Heres how you know that automakers are feverishly pursuing ways to improve fuel efficiency by harnessing engine heat: They wont talk about it.

title: New York City Asks Clergy to Calm Ire Over Homeless Shelters
description: New York City is asking religious leaders to help overcome community resistance to new homeless shelters after a series of testy confrontations in neighborhoods where they are being placed.

title: Three Myths About the Brain
description: IN the early 19th century, a French neurophysiologist named Pierre Flourens conducted a series of innovative experiments. He successively removed larger and larger portions of brain tissue from a range of animals, including pigeons, chickens and frogs, and observed how their behavior was affected.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Tell Me What You See, Even if It Hurts Me
description: Sammie, a shy 13-year-old girl from New Jersey, stepped out of the shower and pulled on a plain gray T-shirt. She left her hair wet and decided not to apply makeup. Careful not to wake her family, she looked into the camera and spoke in a near-whisper.

title: Impeachment Julep
description: If there is one thing that Sarah Palin and Dan Pfeiffer can agree upon, it is that the impeachment of President Obama is a matter of pressing concern.

title: The Best of West and East
description: Dale Jamieson, who runs the Animal Studies Initiative at New York University, has a very silly laugh, and it can be welcome sonic accompaniment when he talks about the destruction of the planet. His most recent book, Reason in a Dark Time: Why the Struggle to Stop Climate Change Failed  and What It Means For Our Future, is a stormy read for hurricane season. Mr. Jamieson, 66, is also a professor of environmental studies, philosophy and law. You could say that bummer is his business. The whole presupposition is that we failed to solve this problem, he said. Now how are we going to suck it up and go on despite the failure? Cue the silly laugh. Mr. Jamieson lives in I. M. Pei-designed faculty housing with Chun-Mei Li when she is in the United States; based in Shanghai, she runs womens and childrens health programs in Asia and Africa for Johnson & Johnson.

title: Obama Criticizes Congress on Immigration
description: The president said House Republicans were putting together an extreme, unworkable version of an immigration bill before their monthlong hiatus.

title: In India, Kerry Seeks Compromise With Prime Minister
description: NEW DELHI  In the first meeting between a senior Obama administration official and Indias new prime minister, Secretary of State John Kerry urged Narendra Modi on Friday to drop his opposition to an international trade treaty and pursue a compromise on food subsidies.

title: Investigators in Ukraine Begin Long-Delayed Search of Plane Crash Site
description: GRABOVO, Ukraine  Dutch and Australian police officers on Friday were finally able to fan out over the site where Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed in Ukraine last month, to search for human remains overlooked by local emergency workers.

description: James Franco wears his sunglasses at night so he can see amid the flashbulbs.

description: Updated | Sept. 4, 2014

description: Michael Kors and Danny Meyer looked a little rattled when told, at the beginning of their recent lunch, that they had been paired up because they had each built empires  one in fashion and the other in restaurants  through persistence and hard work.

title: The Easy Banter and the Vicious Retorts of Married
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Scenes from a Hollywood marriage, the cable television version:

title: Suit Says Owl Killings at Kennedy Airport Were Excessive
description: In December, three snowy owls that had taken up residence at John F. Kennedy Airport, probably because airfields look similar to the Arctic tundra where the birds make their homes, were shot and killed by airport contractors.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Ukraine and South Korea.

title: Obama Confident in C.I.A. Director
description: The president said that he had full confidence in the C.I.A. director, John Brennan, despite the agencys extraordinary interrogation techniques in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Obama on Failed Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: The president called for the release of an Israeli solider captured just moments after a cease-fire was reached in the Gaza conflict.

title: Obama Expresses Confidence in C.I.A. Director
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said on Friday that he has full confidence in John Brennan, the director of the C.I.A., despite Mr. Brennans admission this week that his agency improperly searched the computers of the congressional committee that is preparing to release a report on the use of torture in the fight against terror.

title: Bill Cunningham | Great Lengths
description: Hemlines have long vanished as a dictate of fashion. This summer, for women in Midtown Manhattan going to work or out for midday shopping, the long, sensuous jersey dress or skirt is a dominant look. Some of the most elegant are in neutral colorings, often in shades of sand and gray. Best to beware of horizontal stripes unless youre toothpick-thin.

title: Onstage at a Club They Couldnt Get Into
description: Two-thirds of the members of the Los Angeles band Cherry Glazerr are too young to be customers at the Mercury Lounge. But the band headlined there on Thursday night and began its set with Teenage Girl, a song that serves as its introductory note, manifesto and apotheosis.

title: Evening Hours | Echoes of the East
description: Bill Cunningham covers the parties of the week.

title: A Highland Fling Would Not Be Unexpected Here
description: Diana Gabaldons Outlander novels and Starz are a good match. Starz has become premium cables primary destination for scantily costumed costume drama  Black Sails, Da Vincis Demons, Camelot, the soft-core extravaganza that was Spartacus  and Outlander lets the channel do what it does best. At a preview screening in New York, the biggest response came when the heroine and her husband paused during their exploration of an abandoned Scottish castle to engage in a sex act that was not necessarily the one youd expect in a scene set just after World War II. The women in the audience loudly expressed their approval.

title: In a Swirl of Limbs, a Bird Takes Flight
description: Alvin Aileys 1972 work The Lark Ascending, set to romantic music by Ralph Vaughan Williams, begins not with the image of a light, fluttering bird, but with a male dancer poised on his knees with outstretched arms. His face wears a look of reverie; could he be dreaming of his lark? Other dancers cross his path: Four men move in lunging unison walks, while a couple breeze past in jumps and lifts that impart jubilance. Finally, the lark appears. Springing through the air in grand jets, she soars.

title: Bird? Plane? No, Its the Wedding Photographer
description: The next time you go to a wedding, be sure your hair is done, your lipstick is on, and your Jockeys arent sticking out of your pants. You never know if a drone is lurking in the sky about to zoom in and take your picture.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Warning: What Noah Wrought Upon Us
description: If Ebola and climate change and the threat of wars arent making you paranoid enough, the National Geographic Channel stands ready to help. Its ridiculously overheated Urban Jungle, a special in three parts (all on Sunday night), is eager to convince you that animals are massing against us, preparing to retake the planet. Yes, similar to that sci-fi movie with the apes.

title: More Online Publishers Let Readers Fill the Space
description: To most English speakers, platform is a noun. But among news organizations, it is quickly becoming a verb.

title: A Coveted Internship, but Its Holder Sues Anyway
description: Kimberly Behzadi felt lucky to land an internship as a college senior with ICM Partners, the talent and literary agency.

title: Under Cover: The Candid Camera
description: At first glance, it looks like a straightforward photo of a boy and his dog. But the boy in this picture, Mark Macluskie, was classified as autistic at 3 but is not at 16. Macluskie is one of the subjects of this weeks cover story by Ruth Padawer about children who have shed their autism symptoms. Mark Peckmezian was chosen to photograph the families featured in the article because of his ability to put people at ease. Mark is personable and very good at getting his subjects personalities to shine through, says Christine Walsh, a contributing photo editor at the magazine. Recently he discussed what it was like spending time with those subjects.

title: In Bridge, the Collegiate Championship in Las Vegas
description: The last two rounds of the Collegiate Championship were played in Las Vegas on July 20.

title: Is Facebook Liable? Did O.J. Do It? Do Skunk Works Work?
description: Professors shared a few tough questions from their classrooms. Get Thinking.

title: The Drawn-Out Medical Degree
description: Should medical education be shorter?

title: Going Professional: The Ins and Outs
description: Were not talking about humanities here. A professional degree is all about pragmatism  acquiring a specific set of career skills that often leads to a certification. Pursuing one takes a considerable investment of time and money. So how hard is it to get into programs? What kind of job market can you expect at the end of the day?

title: An M.B.A. Your Way
description: If full-time study is too much of a commitment, there are plenty of other ways to fit M.B.A. training into a harried schedule.

title: Advice From the Field
description: EDUCATION | STICK THROUGH THE BAD YEARS AND GET BETTER AT IT.

title: Business Schools Add Admissions Bells and Whistles
description: Of course you need killer G.M.A.T.s and sparkling recommendations. But amid all the coaching, packaging and prep, M.B.A. gatekeepers also want to see the authentic you  working in teams, under pressure, unscripted.

title: Survey Gets (Too?) Personal
description: Looking for a business school where youll find a mate, or maybe a hook-up scene? Wonder how classmates lean politically?

title: Grad School Tweets
The Physician Assistant Will See You
description: Flora Traub is a 37-year-old mother of three with a masters in public policy from Harvards John F. Kennedy School of Government. But after years as a policy analyst, she found herself reflecting on her undergraduate premedical studies and the happy year she spent in AmeriCorps Community HealthCorps after college. She decided she wanted a new career, in medicine, but not as a doctor.

title: Time Management: One-Year M.B.A.s
description: Streamline, accelerate, graduate. Educators have been scurrying to figure out how to cut short just about every field of professional study, be it law, medicine or business.

title: What I Learned in Professional School
description: The important lessons of post-graduate life.

title: Why You Cant Catch Up
description: College counselors have used this chestnut to assuage ambitious, cash-strapped students for decades: Dont worry about attending a top college. What matters is where you go to graduate school. A stellar masters degree can scrub an undergraduate diploma from a less prestigious, and more affordable, institution.

title: Suitable for Framing? Submit Yours
description: Has a school sent you an amusing, head-scratching or just interesting correspondence?

title: For a Playwright Long Gone From New York Theaters, a Small Step Back
description: Time away from the spotlight can make a writer contemplative, cooling youthful passions and leading to hard-earned, gnomic wisdom. Or it can drive the writer into a lather about pretty much everything that has happened in the interim.

title: Security Secrets, Dated but Real
description: ANNAPOLIS JUNCTION, Md.  Was the National Cryptologic Museum designed using a code of some kind? Something perhaps meant, cryptically, to mask its character and significance? Something that can be deciphered only by those familiar with mysterious organizations like the Black Chamber?

title: Chekhovs Seagull Acquires New Wings
description: WASHINGTON  The expletive smacked splat in the middle of the title indicates clearly that Aaron Posner will be playing fast and loose with the vaunted delicacies of Chekhov in his play Stupid ______ Bird, which is being remounted for a summer run at the Woolly Mammoth Theater after debuting there to acclaim last year and winning the Helen Hayes Award for best new play.

title: After the White Lie Implodes, a Rich Narrative Unfurls
description: Lacey Schwartz, a 37-year-old Harvard Law School graduate turned filmmaker, moves with ease in circles in which her identity as both black and Jewish seems unremarkable. What makes her biography striking is that Ms. Schwartz, a woman with light brown skin and a cascade of dark curls, grew up believing she was white.

title: A Happy Little Oceanside Shack
description: Beach cuisine, generally speaking, is not known for its imagination or distinction: There are sturdy standbys (pizza, fish tacos) and serviceable snacks (nachos, chips and guacamole). But at the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, a happy little shack on Beach 87th Street in Queens, the usual oceanside austerity has been elevated into a sort of laid-back chic. The restaurants owners, Brady Walsh, a tattooed city firefighter, and Brandon DLeo, a sculptor with elaborate hair, have adorned their joint with colorful surfing murals and, perhaps for balances sake, an art installation that is part of this summers Rockaway! show sponsored by MoMA PS1 and others. The chef, Patrick Quinn, meanwhile has equipped his menu with kale and quinoa and sriracha-dipped chicken wings. On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Surf Clubs outdoor patio was filled with suntanned brunchgoers eating meals from paper-lined baskets before walking the few short blocks to the beach.

title: Raptly Absorbing the Quirks of a Rumpled Virtuoso
description: The intimacy, informality and late-night starting time of the A Little Night Music series at the Kaplan Penthouse have made it one of the most popular innovations to come out of Lincoln Center in years. On Thursday night, the eminent pianist Richard Goode, fresh from his performance of a Mozart concerto with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall, played the first of six programs in the series that the festival is presenting this summer.

title: Still Life With Soldier and Bullets
description: Hector Rene Membreno-Canales makes photographs that combine elements of classical art with military iconography.

title: A Ride Across America | A Last Meal on a Hilltop Farm in Oregon
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty biked 4,500 miles across the U.S.to talk to strangers about food. This is their final dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: A Man and His Cat
description: I LIVED with the same cat for 19 years  by far the longest relationship of my adult life. Under common law, this cat was my wife. I fell asleep at night with the warm, pleasant weight of the cat on my chest. The first thing I saw on most mornings was the foreshortened paw of the cat retreating slowly from my face and her baleful crescent glare informing me that it was Cat Food Time. As I often told her, in a mellow, resonant, Barry White voice: There is no luuve  like the luuve that exists  between a man  and his cat.

title: Times Foreign Editor Responds on Israeli Censorship
description: Jodi Rudoren and Isabel Kershner reported Friday in The Times that detailed information about a kidnapped Israeli soldier would be subject to a rare instance of Israeli military censorship. The passage from the article reads as follows:

title: A Night of Dinosaurs and Stargazing (No Children Allowed)
description: Some childhood fantasies age poorly, the charms of space travel or magicians school fading with time. An evening at the museum need not be among these.

title: In Wartime, Optimism and Intolerance Collide
description: As the orchestra plays the overture to South Pacific at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts, a series of black and white snapshots of Long Islanders who served during World War II  the era in which the musical is set  are projected on a large screen at the front of the stage. The scenes include an injured man with a nurse and a few weddings. Most of the men and women are in uniform and smiling bravely or hopefully.

title: Microsoft Sues Samsung Over Android Royalty Payments
description: SEATTLE  Apple and Samsung have been suing each other for years over patent disagreements. But Microsoft and Samsung took a different tack, signing a patent licensing deal in 2011 that has kept the peace between the two companies.

title: Stitching Together Yarn, Memory and History
description: This summer, the main galleries of the Hudson River Museum have been transformed into a fantastical world where majestic figures and 19th-century artifacts mingle among giant crocheted sculptures. Mandy Greer: The Ecstatic Moment is a multipart installation that includes textiles, photography, video, sound, found objects and dozens of items from the museums decorative arts collection. Bartholomew F. Bland, the museums director of curatorial affairs, described the resulting environment as lush, operatic and slightly disturbing in many ways.

title: Heading Down East for a Spell
description: Im going to be in slow blogging mode through the coming week, on a long-overdue visit to Winter Harbor, Me., where my mother in law was born, resides and paints. Its mostly a sleepy backwater, but once a year things get very loud and fast.

title: Its August. Here Is Your Beach Reading.
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics of Paying Ransom to Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chokehold and a Pattern
They Went Thataway: A Good (if Fruitless) Clue for a Chase on Fifth Avenue
description: The door to BC Wireless on Madison Avenue opened on Wednesday afternoon, and Sandeep Kumar, 33, looked up from the back counter. He is the youngest of three brothers from Punjab, India, who own and operate the 12-year-old store, and in particular, hes the customer service brother. He lives in Woodside, Queens, but has his eye on Long Island for the schools.

title: Kemp Is Repositioned and Revitalized, but Staying Put With the Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES  Matt Kemp could not seem to move around the field Thursday without sprinkling some joie de vivre. Whether he was clowning with the son of his teammate Juan Uribe in the dugout, taking a good-natured ribbing from the adviser Don Newcombe around the batting cage, or celebrating a victory by pantomiming a crossover dribble, Kemp had a smile on his face and a bounce in his step.

title: After Heated Week, President Blows Off Steam
description: WASHINGTON  At the end of a week of frustrating developments for the White House, at home and overseas, President Obama took time on Friday afternoon to vent.

title: A Test for Ukraine in a City Retaken From Rebels
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  When Denis Bigunov, a civil servant, recently returned to work after a long break, he found three prisoners hoods wrapped in masking tape stashed in his office at City Hall, sinister mementos left behind by the pro-Russian rebels who controlled this eastern Ukrainian city for nearly three months.

title: Trade Winds Scatter a Roster of Champions
description: BOSTON  The Boston Red Sox may accomplish something never done before in major league history. If they hold their current place in the American League East standings, they will be the first team ever to zig from last place to first place to last place across three seasons.

title: Income Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: Warren G. Bennis, Scholar on Leadership, Dies at 89
description: Warren G. Bennis, an eminent scholar and author who advised presidents and business executives on his academic specialty, the essence of successful leadership  a commodity he found in short supply in recent decades  died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: McDonalds Labor Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: California Asks: Should Doctors Face Drug Tests?
description: LOS ANGELES  At a time when random drug testing is part of the job for pilots, train operators, police officers and firefighters  to name a few  one high-profile line of work has managed to remain exempt: doctors.

title: Victims of Defective G.M. Ignition Switches Begin Filing Claims
description: DETROIT  A fund General Motors put in place to compensate victims of accidents caused by its vehicles faulty ignition switches began accepting claims on Friday. The process will ultimately help calculate how many people were killed or seriously hurt by the deadly defect.

title: Postwar Melodies Through an Abstract Lens
description: Evoking memories through music can be a straightforward affair: Play a tune as it was originally rendered, and the thoughts, feelings, sights and smells associated with a specific time and place come rushing back.

title: Britain Fails to Find Riches It Expected in Swiss Accounts
description: LONDON  When the British tax authorities struck a landmark deal with the Swiss to crack down on tax evasion, they sat back and waited for the cash to flow in. Almost three years later, they are still waiting.

title: Congress Off for the Exits, but Few Cheer
description: WASHINGTON  House and Senate lawmakers scrambled to leave town on Friday night for a five-week recess, with a failure to address the refugee crisis at the southern border only the latest indignity in a year that may redefine congressional dysfunction.

title: Jets Ambitions Breed Optimism and Skepticism
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Enthusiasm really is contagious.

title: Square Said to Be in Talks to Buy Food Delivery Start-Up Caviar
description: Its not enough for Square to handle the way you pay for dinner. Soon, the company will have a hand in putting the food on your table.

title: Measuring the 113th Congresss Futility
description: How this Congress is on pace to becoming the most ineffectual in history.

title: Also Missing: Explanation for an Absence
description: AKRON, Ohio  Josh Gordon, a Cleveland Browns receiver with abilities that separate him from his peers, spent Friday pleading his case before an arbitrator in an effort to avoid a minimum yearlong suspension after testing positive a third time for recreational drugs.

title: The Labor Picture in July
description: The Labor Department reported that employers added 209,000 jobs in July, but the unemployment rate rose slightly, to 6.2 percent.

title: Head for Home
description: It is one of the fundamental rules of baseball. To score, a runner must step on home. When a hitter leaves the batters box after making contact, he knows exactly where he is going. He runs with certainty, guided by the white lines and the white bases, circling in the hope that he will arrive safely at the same place from where he departed. Runners operate on instinct: They must get home. And the efficiency with which they round those bases, often with the help of others, is a matter of winning or losing.

title: Barbecue With Lighter Sides
description: I will drive anywhere to get good barbecue, especially in New Jersey, where it is tough to come by. The ride to Mighty Quinns Barbeque in Clifton required a trip up the Garden State Parkway from my central Jersey outpost, but the anticipation of smoked meat was too much to resist, especially when I saw a Brontosaurus Rib on the menu.

title: Congress: The Road to Roads
description: Well, all I can say is thank God weve got that Highway Trust Fund fixed.

title: Anti-Semitism Rises in Europe Amid Israel-Gaza Conflict
description: BERLIN  Across Europe, the conflict in Gaza is generating a broader backlash against Jews, as threats, hate speech and even violent attacks proliferate in several countries.

title: Popular Snack on Indias Streets Is at the Heart of a Manhattan Court Fight
description: The kati roll is a traditional Indian street food that consists of various fillings  chicken tikka, paneer cheese, mixed vegetables, potatoes and egg  wrapped in a layered paratha, a kind of Indian flatbread.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 1, 2014
Sympathy for the Devil
description: What does it mean for a company to do the right thing after an industrial accident?

title: A Creole Solution for Haitis Woes
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  IN a classroom in Port-au-Prince, Chantou, 9, sits silently at her desk. Nervously watching the teacher, she hopes to be invisible. Like most of her 60 classmates, she understands little of the French from the lecture. But if her memorized lesson is not recited with perfect pronunciation and grammar, she may be ridiculed or punished by her teacher.

title: Where Small Plates Bear Surprises
description: A week has passed, and I am still dreaming about that perfect pepper: a finger-size green Padrn, flame-cooked to a blistery softness, then coated in Ligurian olive oil and sea salt. Grab by the stem, put it in your mouth and bite. That perfect pepper inaugurated a spree of culinary blisses at Cafemantic, whose small-plate, farm-to-table fare showcases Jonathan Hudaks inventive and delicious cooking.

title: Staten Island Zoo Capitalizes on the Small and Obscure
description: In a city where lions, tigers and  yes  bears are only a subway ride away, the Staten Island Zoo is betting on the binturong.

title: Censorship in Your Doctors Office
description: WHEN a doctor asks her patient a question, is the doctor engaged in free speech protected by the Constitution? If you think the answer is obvious, think again. According to a recent decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, everything a doctor says to a patient is treatment, not speech, and the government has broad authority to prohibit doctors from asking questions on particular topics without any First Amendment scrutiny at all.

title: Obama Expresses Confidence in C.I.A. Director
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that he had full confidence in John O. Brennan, the director of the C.I.A., despite his admission that the agency improperly searched computer files of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: Robert Halmi, 90, Producer of TV Films, Dies
description: Robert Halmi Sr., a Hungarian-born, adventure-loving photographer for Life and other magazines who in a second career after age 50 became one of televisions most prolific producers of movies and mini-series, often adapted from literature, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Mets Sleepwalk Through a Loss to the Giants as Harvey Begins Easy Throwing
description: David Wright spent his day off on Thursday at his father-in-laws lake house in the Poconos. He did some fishing, watched his wifes half-siblings go wakeboarding, and decompressed. That also meant staying off his phone as the nonwaiver trade deadline passed. He checked the phone later and saw that the Mets had done nothing.

title: Executed Arizona Inmate Got 15 Times Standard Dose, Lawyers Say
description: PHOENIX  Lawyers for an inmate who was executed last month by lethal injection said Friday that his executioners injected him with 15 times the standard dose of a sedative and a painkiller during a procedure that lasted nearly two hours before their client was declared dead.

title: Websters First
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  When Kristian House thinks about his legacy, as we all do at some point in our lives, I truly hope he includes the fact that he is the first person ever to include the entry BUTT NAKED in a New York Times crossword puzzle. Because that rocks, as far as legacies go. Thats the kind of story you can dine out on for years to come.

title: A Dozen States File Suit Against New Coal Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Twelve states filed a lawsuit against the Obama administration on Friday seeking to block an Environmental Protection Agency proposal to regulate coal-fired power plants in an effort to stem climate change.

title: Birthright Trips to Israel Continue Despite Mideast Conflict
description: WASHINGTON  Lila Faria, 19, a student at New York University, heard the whine of a bomb siren for the first time last month in Jerusalem. Along with several dozen other Americans on a trip with the Taglit-Birthright Israel organization, she was quickly hustled into a bomb shelter.

title: Growth Without Jobs
description: In a statement last Wednesday  just hours after the government reported headline-grabbing economic growth of 4 percent in the second quarter  the Federal Reserve said it would continue to stimulate the economy because, despite overall growth, the labor market remained weak. In a speech the same day in Kansas City, Mo., President Obama echoed the Fed. Im glad that G.D.P. is growing, and Im glad that corporate profits are high, and Im glad that the stock market is booming, he said, (which it was before profit-taking at weeks end dented its performance). But what I really want to see is a guy working 9 to 5, and then working some overtime.

title: Lebanese Adoptee, Searching for His Roots, Finds Islam
description: The weekly TV recap  the snarky, obsessive, scene-by-scene description of a TV show, written by a fan working through whats clearly a love/hate relationship  is now a ubiquitous genre, peddled online by Slate, The Onion, New York magazine, and others. But its progenitor was Daniel Drennans Beverly Hills 90210 recap, which he wrote online from 1994 to 1998. Columbia Journalism Review credited Mr. Drennan with inventing the form, citing his successful mix of opinions on bad writing and terrible acting; pointed attacks on receding hairlines and terrible outfits; and personal stories tangentially related to what was on the TV screen.

title: A Mound of Forgotten Money, and Even You May Have a Claim
description: For years, Jerry Seinfeld and Joan Rivers, and as many as 6,914 other customers, have never claimed refunds due them from Bergdorfs. General Motors has been in hock to Rupert Murdoch for nearly a decade. Russias mission to the United Nations is still hoarding unredeemed gift certificates from BJs Wholesale Club.

title: Rounding Up Journalists in Iran
description: For all the hints of a thaw in Irans hard-line behavior since President Hassan Rouhani took office, the governments oppression of working journalists has continued unabated  most recently with the egregious arrest of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Posts correspondent in Tehran, and his wife and fellow journalist, Yeganeh Salehi. The two were taken for questioning on July 22 by security police who confiscated their laptops and other property, with Iranian justice officials later commenting darkly about being vigilant towards all kinds of enemies activities. The couple has not been heard from since.

title: On A-List and on a List
description: New York State is holding a record $13.3 billion in unclaimed funds, as The Timess Sam Roberts reports. Here is a selection of other notable New Yorkers who are owed money:

title: Congress, Unhinged on Immigration
description: It was a remarkable two days of legislative dysfunction, even for congressional Republicans, who have been pushing the limits of unhinged governance.

title: A Recipe, and Hometown Pride
description: Everybody goes to Tecas.

title: Two Arrested in Dogfighting Case
description: A new police squad focused on animal cruelty raided a home in Queens early Thursday, arrested two people on charges involving illegal dogfighting and seized 20 emaciated and scarred pit bulls, the authorities said Friday.

title: This Time, a Different Kind of War Between Israel and Hamas
description: THE collapse of a 72-hour cease-fire in the Gaza fighting only two hours after it began marked a new phase in the violence, as the reported capture of an Israeli officer by Hamas gave the Palestinian militants a powerful bargaining lever and fired an all-out effort by Israel to get its soldier back.

title: North Koreas Antipathy for the U.S. Is Seen at a New High
description: North Koreas reclusive government signaled new anger toward the United States on Friday, equating it to a mentally retarded patient over an annual military exercise with South Korea, and offering hints that two American tourists arrested in North Korea four months ago would soon be put on trial and face long imprisonments.

title: Cost of Putting Mayors Family in Gracie Mansion Nears $145,000
description: Moving to Manhattan has its price.

title: At an 85-Year-Old Summer Retreat, a Makeover
description: On a recent sunny afternoon, Lee Fong, 26, and Lisa Wong, 25, arrived at the Central Mall of Jones Beach hauling coolers, beach blankets and packed lunches. But when they noticed a placard just off the main boardwalk pointing to SmorgasBar, a new open-air food court, they took a detour and skipped the brown bags in favor of fish tacos with cilantro, fried whiting and chips, and pineapple strawberry smoothies.

title: Yanks Fall to Red Sox as Day of Debuts Follows Day of Deals
description: BOSTON  Some 24 hours after a hectic day in which the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox made seven separate deals, the dust settled over Fenway Park, and two reconfigured teams took the field heading in different directions.

title: Manny Roth, 94, Impresario of Cafe Wha?, Is Dead
description: Just got here from the West, the gangly 19-year-old told Manny Roth, owner of the Greenwich Village nightclub Cafe Wha? Names Bob Dylan. Id like to do a few songs? Can I?

title: Explosion Kills Dozens at Eastern China Plant
description: BEIJING  At least 68 people were killed Saturday morning when a blast tore through a metal products factory in Chinas eastern Jiangsu Province, state-run news media reported.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 7:35 A.M. (Encore) THROW MOMMA FROM THE TRAIN (1987) Danny DeVito directs and stars as Owen, a downtrodden writer who dreams of killing his dominating and trollish mother (Anne Ramsey, above, with Mr. DeVito), but cant bring himself to finish the deed. Larry (Billy Crystal) is Owens writing instructor and is similarly plagued by a famous ex-wife who is airing their dirty laundry to the entire country. When Larry suggests that Owen watch Alfred Hitchcocks Strangers on a Train to help his writing, it instead gives Owen a different kind of inspiration: a murder swap. Most inspired, however, is the teamwork between Mr. Crystal and Mr. DeVito, who make one of the oddest pairs imaginable but have a rapport thats a delight, Janet Maslin wrote in her review for The New York Times. Speaking of Mr. DeVitos performance, she said, Hes irresistible even when playing someone only a mother could love.

title: Corrections: August 2, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 2, 2014
description: So much for her being called the Material Girl!

title: Missing Soldier Killed in Battle, Israel Confirms
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military said early Sunday morning that an officer thought to have been captured by Palestinian militants during a deadly clash Friday morning, which shattered a planned 72-hour cease-fire, was now considered to have been killed in battle.

title: That Honeydew Melon Looks Good, but Does Anyone Eat It?
description: Every time I see a fruit platter at a hotel or a conference, I ask myself the same question: Where does all this honeydew melon come from, and does anyone actually want to eat it?

title: Where Tech Is Taking Us: A Conversation With Intels Genevieve Bell
description: Genevieve Bell grew up among Aboriginal people in Australia, taught anthropology at Stanford and for the past 16 years has worked for Intel. It all shows in her lively mind: Ask her the time and, along with the hour, you might hear about how native Australian languages fuse the words for past, present and land, along with the history of the mechanical clock and how that determined peoples feelings about robots.

title: Analytics: The Penn State Review
description: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the Aug. 3 issue of the magazine.

title: Landslide in Nepal Kills at Least 8; Hundreds Are Missing
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  A major landslide early Saturday morning near Nepals border with China killed at least eight people and left hundreds missing, officials in Nepal said. It also washed out part of a crucial highway and blocked a river, leading to a dangerous buildup of water.

title: Anti-Intellectualism That Dares Not Speak Its Name
description: The right-wing attack on Neil deGrasse Tyson  which has reached a sort of apogee in the National Review cover story  is notable for a number of reasons. Whats especially interesting, as I see it, is the attempt to have it both ways. On one side, theres the sneering disapproval of anyone who tries to bring facts and evidence into political debate  you think youre so smart, huh? At the same time, theres the claim that liberal experts are poseurs, not real experts. Hey, were not anti-science, not us!

title: 1914: Last Fashion Supplement
Up on the Roof
description: Rocio Farias, 32, is a solar panel installer at the Chatsworth, Calif., office of SolarCity.

title: In Jackson Hole, the Rugged and Refined Meet
description: The rugged and the refined meet in the Jackson Hole Fall Arts Festival, which turns 30 this year. The 11-day affair, taking place Sept. 3 to 14 in Jackson, Wyo., features over 50 events, ranging from studio demonstrations, artist receptions, auctions and gallery walks to ranch tours that culminate in a barbecue, an outdoor food fair and a tour of local homes.

title: An Appeal to Our Inner Judge
description: Editors note: Heres one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

title: Jiminy Cricket! Bugs Could Be Next Food Craze
description: In October 2012, Megan Miller walked out of a San Francisco pet store carrying a bag filled with mealworms squirming in soil. When she arrived at her apartment, she took them straight to her kitchen.

title: Feds Goldilocks Economy Just Right for Stock Investors
description: Two decades ago the notion of a Goldilocks economy was very much in vogue. It was a snappy way of saying that the economy was growing at a nice, steady pace  fast enough to create jobs but not so rapidly that it would lead to runaway inflation.

title: Shattering Myths to Help the Climate
description: Each new climate-change study seems more pessimistic than the last. This May and June, for example, were the hottest ones on record for the planet. Storms and droughts occur with increasing frequency. Glaciers are rapidly retreating, portending rising seas that could eventually displace hundreds of millions of people.

title: American Doctor With Ebola Arrives in U.S. for Treatment
description: ATLANTA  The first of two American aid workers infected with Ebola while working in West Africa arrived in the United States on Saturday aboard a private air ambulance specially equipped to isolate patients with infectious diseases and was quickly admitted to a hospital here.

title: Big Banks Still a Risk
description: Big bankers are usually good at arithmetic. But when it comes to assessing the benefits of their too-big-to-fail status, their calculators tend to go haywire.

title: Sharon Sloane of Will Interactive: See Yourself as Others See You
description: This interview with Sharon Sloane, C.E.O. of Will Interactive, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Divorce and the Board
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Estrella Burgos, an Improbable Trailblazer, Takes Aim at U.S. Open
description: WASHINGTON  The longest road to the biggest stages of tennis started where no road had before.

title: Footballs Hall of Fame Enjoys Boom to Go With Busts
description: CANTON, Ohio  Football has long since overtaken baseball as the United States most popular sport. But when it comes to pomp and nostalgia, baseball has been the leader thanks in part to the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: California Revises Policy on Mentally Ill Inmates
description: Californias Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation has introduced new policies for the use of force against mentally ill prisoners that are among the most detailed in the nation.

title: A Little Extra Night Music
description: The stupendous Swedish clarinetist Martin Frost, who won high praise for his appearance with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in December, returns to New York for two programs with the Mostly Mozart Festival. Both on Monday night! Earlier that evening he joins the Emerson Quartet at Alice Tully Hall for Mozarts Quintet for Clarinet and Strings. (7:30 p.m., 212-721-6500, mostlymozart.org)

title: Paul Georges Injury Fuels Concerns in N.B.A. Over International Competition
description: The severity of Paul Georges injury  the sight of his right leg bent grotesquely  has sent a jolt through the N.B.A.

title: Square-Foot Supersizing in the Tropics
description: As two rival mega-resorts prepare to compete for tropics-loving travelers, one thing is clear: Nassau wants your business in a big way.

title: More Remains Found at Ukraine Crash Site
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  International experts examining the crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine on Saturday found the remains of victims overlooked by local emergency personnel who first searched the debris two weeks ago.

title: Jets Lineman Prepares for Shift From Interviewee to Interviewer
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  After watching film for hours at the Jets training camp, Leger Douzable goes home. And watches more.

title: Strong-Legged Kickers Put Giants in a Quandary, and Its Good
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Head-to-head competition for a starting job at an N.F.L. training camp is an exhausting marathon of effort. There are hundreds of plays run in front of dozens of scrutinizing coaches, with all of it recorded by video cameras so the performances can be analyzed again late into the night.

title: $1,000 Hepatitis Pill Shows Why Fixing Health Costs Is So Hard
description: A new drug for the liver disease hepatitis C is scaring people. Not because the drug is dangerous  its generally heralded as a genuine medical breakthrough  but because it costs $1,000 a pill and about $84,000 for a typical persons total treatment.

title: The Marijuana Divide
description: In Colorado, two towns near each other have divergent reactions to their states legalization of marijuana.

title: High in the Rockies, a Chill Marijuana Debate
description: GUNNISON, Colo.  Getting a feel for Gunnison, Colo., a town in the Rockies about four and a half hours southwest of Denver, takes a bicycle and a few minutes. On Main Street and nearby blocks you will pass a Wal-Mart, a pizza place called Pie-Zans, a bike-repair-and-espresso shop, the offices of The Gunnison Country Times, the campus of Western State Colorado University and Traders Rendezvous, which claims to have the states largest collection of antlers and mounted animal trophies. Ride long enough and you will find seven churches and five liquor stores, six if you count the Safeway.

title: The Great Colorado Weed Experiment
description: In January, Colorado defied the federal government and stepped with both feet into the world of legal recreational marijuana, where no state had gone before.

title: The Marijuana Divide
description: I traveled to Gunnison County, Colo., to make this video about two towns that had taken different paths since medicinal marijuana was legalized in 2000 and recreational marijuana sales began this year. One, Crested Butte, has embraced the sale of retail and medicinal marijuana; the other, Gunnison, has so far rejected it. (While anyone in the state over 21 is free to use the drug on private property, its up to local governments to decide whether it can be sold.)

title: Quadrillions and Quadrillions
description: I figured that I could count on Dean Baker to debunk Larry Kotlikoffs Eeek! Debt! column. But Dean doesnt go far enough.

title: No Longer Ignored, Evidence Solves Rape Cases Years Later
description: MEMPHIS  Meaghan Ybos was 16 and had just arrived home from school when a man in a ski mask held a knife to her throat and raped her.

title: Lenny Dykstra: Out of Prison, and Still Headstrong
description: Lenny Dykstra read a report online the other day that said he had just launched a website to dispense investment advice, 13 months after he was released from a federal penitentiary.

title: Leery Golfers Have a Policy for Trophies Not Yet Won: Hands Off
description: AKRON, Ohio  After a practice session in Florida last weekend, Rory McIlroy invited his neighbor Keegan Bradley back to his Jupiter home. Displayed on McIlroys kitchen counter was a one-of-a-kind pitcher: the silver claret jug he received for winning the British Open.

title: Spider-Man Unmasked! Elmo and Minnie, Too
description: Ricardo Rodrguez did not arrive lightly at his decision to become a cartoon character.

title: The Fantasy Italy
description: I GET why Americans are wild about Eataly, the cavernous emporium of Italian gastronomy that opened in New York City in 2010, and in Chicago last year. Where else in the United States, under one roof, can you select from more than a dozen varieties of perfectly sliced prosciutto, a loving selection of Italian wines and olive oils that are hard to find in the United States, as well as the perfect Romanesco broccoli, an odd cone-shaped vegetable that is actually related to cauliflower?

title: For Young Soccer Players, Vast Ambitions Grow in Tight Spaces
description: Soccer is no stranger on the fields of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, where mostly Spanish is spoken and women sell empanadas and cold drinks from baby strollers that double as rolling bodegas. The players are mostly from Latin America, enjoying the game they brought from home.

title: What to Wear: Your Game Face and a Kilt
description: Highland games, with a mix of athletics, dance and musicianship, are regarded as an integral part of Scottish culture and heritage. Bagpipes, flamboyant kilts and caber tossing are key elements at these events, which enliven Scotlands relatively brief and unpredictable summers.

title: The Times and the Go Big Approach
description: WHEN The New York Times decides to put its full weight behind a topic, it packs a powerful punch.

title: Goodbye Albuquerque, Land of Violence
description: TWO weeks ago, in a vacant lot on the west side of Albuquerque, a few teenagers beat two homeless men to death. I read about the attack in a hotel room in Nebraska, en route to a new job, hours after leaving New Mexico for good. I wish I could say the news surprised me. But after three years of living in Albuquerque, Id gotten used to hearing stories about arbitrary violence, especially against the homeless.

title: Eben Upton
description: Eben Upton, an Englishman, is the co-inventor and chief engineer of the popular Raspberry Pi device, an affordable credit-card-size computer that children, as well as adults, around the world are using to learn programming.

title: Why Americans See Israel the Way They Do
description: TO cross the Atlantic to America, as I did recently from London, is to move from one moral universe to its opposite in relation to Israels war with Hamas in Gaza. Fury over Palestinian civilian casualties has risen to a fever pitch in Europe, moving beyond anti-Zionism into anti-Semitism (often a flimsy distinction). Attacks on Jews and synagogues are the work of a rabid fringe, but anger toward an Israel portrayed as indiscriminate in its brutality is widespread. For a growing number of Europeans, not having a negative opinion of Israel is tantamount to not having a conscience. The deaths of hundreds of children in any war, as one editorial in The Guardian put it, is a special kind of obscenity.

title: Throw the Book at Him
description: WASHINGTON  I CANT wait to read the book W. wont write.

title: Facebooks Gateway Drug
description: SILICON VALLEY was once content to dominate the tech world. But recently, its leading companies have ventured deep into areas well outside its traditional bailiwick, most notably international development  promising to transform a field once dominated by national governments and international institutions into a permanent playground of hackathons and app-fueled disruption.

title: A Two-Handed Push Elevates Phoenix Mercury to No. 1
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Players for the Phoenix Mercury, the best team in the W.N.B.A., take their cues from two equally competitive people: their new coach, Sandy Brondello, and the charismatic veteran guard Diana Taurasi.

title: Orioles Strong Hand Has No Ace (Yet)
description: Kevin Gausman retired the first 14 hitters he faced at Camden Yards on Wednesday, and then he walked the bases loaded. Two hits followed, and three runs scored. Gausman recovered to throw two more scoreless innings, and after his Baltimore Orioles held on to beat the Los Angeles Angels, he said something revealing.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, August 3
description: An American aid worker infected with the Ebola virus while working in Liberia returned to the United States on Saturday and was transported to Emory University Hospital, where he will be first patient with the virus to be treated in an American hospital.

title: A Paper Mill Goes Quiet, and the Community It Built Gropes for a Way Forward
description: MILLINOCKET, Me.  Pass a playground and follow a dusty road, and there, on the other side of a chain-link fence, is the wreckage of the paper mill that was born before this town was.

title: Letters to the Sports Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The War of Words in China
description: BEIJING  I DIDNT ask for a Wikipedia page, but a few months ago, alerted by a friend, I found that someone had created one, ostensibly devoted to my journalistic achievements.

title: Palm Springs Dreams
description: About eight years ago I became a part-time resident of Palm Springs, Calif., after years of visiting as a tourist from Los Angeles. Discovering sides of this iconic American resort town that I hadnt seen before, I began to document the lush world that lies just out of eyeshot of the Palm Springs tourist.

title: Postcard From Saratoga Springs: Eternal Rest at a Shrine He Enlivened
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  There was good-natured grousing as the funeral procession made its way to the turf writer Paul Morans final resting place in the infield of the revered racecourse. There were rails to duck, a makeshift plank to walk and a break in the hedges that rimmed the turf course to shimmy through.

title: A Parchment on Millennials
description: GOOD morrow. Tis I, Aelfric the Elder, with a piece of calligraphic parchment containing statements that I think  a think piece, let us call it  to be posted with a nail on our villages biggest log, concerning youthful denizens born around A.D. 1000. These millennials are, without a doubt, the most narcissistic and hopeless cohort I have witnessed in my 35 long years on this stationary planet.

title: Missouri Weighs Unusual Addition to Its Constitution: Right to Farm
description: KINGDOM CITY, Mo.  Missourians already have the constitutional right to religion, speech and guns. On Tuesday, they could make a novel addition to the State Constitution: the right to farm.

title: Obamas Impeachment Game
description: SOMETHING rather dangerous is happening in American politics right now, all the more so for being taken for granted by many of the people watching it unfold.

title: Israel Vows to Continue Gaza Campaign
description: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Saturday that Israel would continue its military campaign in the Gaza Strip as long as necessary to stop Hamas, the militant group said it was not holding a missing Israeli soldier.

title: Go Take a Hike!
description: PACIFIC CREST TRAIL, Ore.  ESCAPING a grim world of war abroad and inequality at home, I fled with my teenage daughter here to the mountains of Oregon to hike the Pacific Crest Trail and commune with more humane creatures. Like bears and cougars.

title: How This War Ends
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  I HAD held off coming to Israel, hoping the situation in Gaza would clarify  not in terms of whats happening, but how it might end in a stable way. Being here now, it is clear to me that there is a way this cruel little war could not only be stopped, but stopped in a way that the moderates in the region, who have been so much on the run, could gain the initiative. But  and here is where some flight from reality is required to be hopeful  developing something that decent out of this war will demand a level of leadership from the key parties that has simply never been manifested by any of them. This is a generation of Arab, Palestinian and Israeli leaders who are experts at building tunnels and walls. None of them ever took the course on bridges and gates.

title: The Mayors Showroom
description: WHEN Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg redid Gracie Mansion in 2002, it was featured in Architectural Digest. Mayor Bill de Blasios redecoration was featured this week on Instagram (2,718 likes by Friday). The medium by which the reveal was made says as much about the changing of the guard as the difference in taste shown by the photographs in question. Federal end tables are out, coffee tables you can rest your feet on are in. For New York Citys first family, the move to Manhattan from Park Slope clearly felt more like an upheaval than a dream realized. The story line was less about being true to the houses roots than being true to their own.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Less Ego in Architects
Ocean Radioactivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Legalizing Marijuana: Other Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Newly Insured, Many Now Face Learning Curve
description: PHILADELPHIA  Advocates of the Affordable Care Act, focused until now on persuading people to buy health insurance, have moved to a crucial new phase: making sure the eight million Americans who did so understand their often complicated policies and use them properly.

title: Hope Dwindles for Hondurans Living in Peril
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  The pastor came one afternoon to survey his church, or what was left of it: remnants of a welcome sign and a strip of Christmas garland still tacked to the wall.

title: At Harlem Rally, Calls for Action in Chokehold Case
description: Responding to a ruling by the New York City medical examiner that the death of a man in police custody last month was caused by a chokehold and compression of his chest, the Rev. Al Sharpton and the mans family said emphatically on Saturday that prosecutors had reason to take action against the officer involved.

title: Otherworldly Downpour Preceded Landslide in India
description: MALIN, India  When the storm came to this tiny village on Wednesday morning, with a resounding blast and mere seconds of a downpour so heavy it could not be called rain, Dilip Bhagwa Lembeg was walking to his paddy fields.

title: China Experiences a Booming Underground Market in Surrogate Motherhood
description: WUHAN, China  In a small conference room overlooking this citys smog-shrouded skyline, Huang Jinlai outlines his offer to Chinas childless elite: for $240,000, a baby with your DNA, gender of your choice, born by a coddled but captive rural woman.

title: Putin Strives to Harness Energy of Russian Pilgrims for Political Profit
description: SERGIYEV POSAD, Russia  The pilgrims tramped toward the storied monastery by the thousands  chanting prayers, singing and embracing the kind of nationalist fervor that President Vladimir V. Putin seeks to harness as his own.

title: U.S.-Russia Nuclear Deal Stalls as Tensions Over Ukraine Rise
description: WASHINGTON  The growing confrontation between Washington and Moscow over Ukraine has derailed a recent accord that promised one of the most expansive collaborations ever between the countries nuclear scientists, including reciprocal visits to atomic sites to work on projects ranging from energy to planetary defense.

title: How Facebook Sold You Krill Oil
description: Joao Rodrigues had been listening and holding his tongue. For a day and a half, brand managers, ad agency creative types and Facebook strategists had gathered in airy conference rooms and around cafeteria tables in Facebooks Madison Avenue offices, filling up whiteboards and scratch pads with one heartfelt or clever tagline after another.

title: Chee Whiz!
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  It can be discouraging when you get off to the wrong start in a puzzle, especially one the size of a Sunday grid. What you really hope for is that the rest of the puzzle is a balm to the soul, a smooth solve that makes you forget about the fact that you confidently plunked in A-RONI at 1 Down instead of PILAF. Thankfully, that is pretty much what we have today in this puzzle by Ian Livengood.

title: Variety: A Fashionable Diagramless
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Are you part of the IN group? You are if you try this diagramless crossword by Paula Gamache.

title: Living Amid Violence and Poverty in Honduras
description: Economic distress and migration have fueled the rise of gangs in Chamelecn, one of the most dangerous districts of San Pedro Sula, one of the hemispheres most dangerous cities.

title: Chinese Parents Discuss Surrogacy
description: Despite its illegality, surrogacy is still practiced in China. We asked parents in a Wuhan park what they thought of the controversial practice and its impact.

title: Shadowy World for Chinese Surrogates
description: Chinese law forbids surrogacy, so some agencies send poor women to Bangkok for the embryo implantation, then fly them back to China, where they live hidden lives during the pregnancy and birth.

title: Gunmen From Syria Hit Army Checkpoints in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Gunmen who crossed into northeastern Lebanon from Syria attacked several army checkpoints in a border town on Saturday in what appeared to be an effort to win the release of a Syrian rebel who had been detained by Lebanese troops.

title: Two New Teenage Champs as Scholastic Events Boom
description: Two 16-year-olds have won their first championships at scholastic tournaments.

title: Theater Must Lose a Little Charm to Stay Open
description: WIMBERLEY  Moviegoers celebrated the first day of summer at Wimberleys Corral Theater on June 21 with an out-of-season singalong fund-raiser. As the sun set on the summer solstice, 202 Hill Country residents belted out the lyrics to Do You Want to Build a Snowman? alongside the snow-covered, computer-generated characters of the Disney movie Frozen.

title: Russias Politicized Patron Saint
description: Some historians and church figures are crying foul over what they say are the Kremlins efforts to reshape the legacy of St. Sergius to enhance political goals.

title: A Delicate New Mission for a Leader Familiar With Special Operations
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: With Uncertainty, Texas Schools Brace for New Arrivals
description: Federal officials along the border have scrambled in the last few months to house and care for tens of thousands of unaccompanied minors from Central America crossing the border into the United States.

title: In El Paso, a New Homeless Shelter With Female Veterans in Mind
description: EL PASO  Slightly more than a decade ago, Hope Jackson, then a lieutenant colonel in the Army, was serving in the Middle East and entertaining thoughts of retiring to her native Florida after 25 years in the military.

title: With Mets in the Hunt, a Pitching Prospects Promotion Is in Limbo
description: With yet another quality outing in the minors on Friday, the Mets pitching prospect Noah Syndergaard continued to make a case for a September call-up.

title: Love Begets Low Scores for Garca, Who Keeps Lead at Bridgestone
description: AKRON, Ohio  An electrical storm moved into the area of Firestone Country Club on Saturday afternoon, forcing Sergio Garca off the course with a five-stroke lead and three holes left in his third round at the Bridgestone Invitational.

title: Dressing Up in Times Square
description: Juan Carlos Arias performs as the Statue of Liberty in Times Square.

title: Lockout Is Delayed While an Independent Analyst Examines the Mets Finances
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which had threatened to lock out its workers if it did not reach new deals with its labor unions by Sunday night, said Saturday evening that it would extend its current contracts for about a week while an independent analyst examined its finances.

title: Senate Rivals Exchange Barbs at Kentucky Picnic
description: FANCY FARM, Ky.  A day after Congress ingloriously left Washington, leaving town for a summer break with few accomplishments, members shifted to their real focus this year: the midterm elections, specifically control of the Senate.

title: With Game in the Balance, One Pitch by Kelley Helps Seal a Yankees Win
description: BOSTON  As Mike Napoli prepared to dig into the batters box in the fifth inning, with the game teetering in the balance, catcher Francisco Cervelli got up from his crouch. The situation called for clear communication, so he headed to the mound to talk to Shawn Kelley about the pitch to be thrown.

title: In Times Square, Freelancing as Elmo
description: The costumed characters posing for pictures have become ubiquitous in recent years, replacing the more sordid denizens of the past.

title: A Group Revels as Its Godfather Is Inducted
description: CANTON, Ohio  In May, a couple of months after Ray Guy was chosen as the first pure punter to enter the Pro Football Hall of Fame, Bryan Barker and Greg Coleman, two fellow punters, decided they had to do something to commemorate the moment.

title: Colorful Trainer and Suddenly Brilliant Gelding Win the Whitney
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Eric Guillot was right where he thought he would be after the 87th running of the Whitney Handicap: in the winners circle with a gelding named Moreno who, until 5:50 p.m. on Saturday, had shown more promise than winning performances in a hard-knock career.

title: Hospitals in Gaza Overwhelmed as Attacks Continue
description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip  It was clear from the bodies laid out in the parking lot of the maternity hospital here that it had assumed new duties: No longer a place that welcomed new life, it was now a makeshift morgue.

title: Clubs Flirt With Dual No-Hitter, but Mets Will Settle for a Victory
description: The final score line at Citi Field on Saturday night will not do justice to the nerve-racking buildup through the first six innings, in which the Mets and the San Francisco Giants appeared headed toward a special night. The starting pitchers, the Mets Jacob deGrom and the Giants Jake Peavy, threatened to do something that had not been done in almost a century.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 2, 2014
Rising From Riveras Shadow, Yankees Bullpen Carves Its Place
description: BOSTON  In the far right corner of the visitors bullpen at Fenway Park, protected under glass in a frame above the bench, the greatest reliever left his mark. Mariano Rivera autographed the wall out there last September, after his final game at Fenway as an active player. The Red Sox preserved the section he signed as a subtle and lasting tribute.

title: Vows | Here Comes the Drone
description: More videographers are using small drones to capture that perfect, death-defying shot  of a wedding.

title: Gillian Fell, Bryan Doherty
description: Dr. Gillian Lynapp Fell and Bryan Barry Doherty were married Saturday at St. Cecilia Roman Catholic Church in Boston. The ceremony was performed by the churchs pastor, the Rev. John J. Unni.

title: Lily Lyman and Alexander Vannoni
description: Olivia Lincoln Lyman, a daughter of Bambi Putnam of New York and Lincoln P. Lyman of Millbrook, N.Y., was married Friday to Alexander John Vannoni, a son of Patricia Vannoni and Leo Vannoni of Winthrop, Mass. The Rev. Charles E. Bourke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Northeast Harbor, Me., and on Saturday, led a blessing ceremony in Seal Cove, Me., at the summer home of the brides maternal grandfather, George Putnam.

title: Scott Arsenault, Gerald Daniello
description: Scott Robert Arsenault and Gerald Joseph Daniello Jr. were married Friday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Bernard W. Poppe, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Liberty Warehouse, an event space.

title: Richard Hatter, Philip Montello
description: Richard Wayne Hatter and Philip Joseph Montello were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerks office officiated.

title: Rebecca Speiser and Nicholas Skipper
description: Rebecca Anne Speiser, the daughter of Willa R. Speiser and Jeffrey A. Speiser of Warwick, N.Y., was married Saturday to Nicholas Huntley Skipper, a son of Jessica H. Skipper and John D. Skipper of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

title: An Ultimatum Pays Off
description: Erica Grace Tibbals and Brian Philip Cischke were married Saturday at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington. Msgr. W. Ronald Jameson performed the ceremony.

title: Dori Klotzman, Henry Haber
description: Dori Lee Klotzman and Henry Peter Haber were married Saturday evening at the Tudor Arms Hotel in Cleveland. Rabbi Melinda Mersack, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

title: Nicole Panza, Justin Rindos
description: Dr. Nicole Anne Panza and Justin Michael Rindos were married Friday at the New York Botanical Garden. The Rev. Andrew Butler III, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Calvin Wilson, Timmy Cuevas
description: Calvin Earl Wilson and Timmy Jose Cuevas were married Friday by Emil K. Wilbekin, a Universal Life minister, at Duane Park, a club in Manhattan.

title: Christine Burrill, Bernadette Grosjean
description: Christine Rehbock Burrill and Dr. Bernadette Mariette Fernande Grosjean were married Saturday in Berne, N.Y., on a farm owned by Ms. Burrill and Edith Rea, her friend and matron of honor. Judge Noel Ann Brennan, who presides at the United States Immigration Court in New York, officiated.

title: Kirsten Walpert, Kyle Stout
description: Kirsten Ellen Walpert and Kyle Lawrence Stout were married Saturday evening at West Mountain Inn in Arlington, Vt., by Christopher M. Kobran, a brother-in-law of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Lindsay Slote, Lawrence Delevingne
description: Lindsay Julia Slote and Lawrence Pierre Delevingne were married Saturday at the Massachusetts Horticultural Society in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Anne Bancroft, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Chelsea Cooke and Justin McKay
description: Chelsea Collier Cooke, a daughter of Adrienne Collier and Harold E. Cooke of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married Saturday to Justin Joseph McKay, a son of Richard G. McKay of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Mary Jayne McKay. Harry Dammers, an uncle of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Brotherhood Winery in Washingtonville, N.Y.

title: Grace McRae, Kevan Yalowitz
description: Grace Lila McRae, a daughter of Elizabeth E. W. McRae and David J. McRae of Shrewsbury, Mass., was married Saturday to Kevan Scott Yalowitz, a son of Jan A. Yalowitz and Kenneth G. Yalowitz of Seattle. The Rev. Robert G. Wollenburg, a Lutheran minister, officiated at Point Robinson Park on Vashon Island in Washington state.

title: Margaret Sallay, John Peck
description: Margaret Parks Sallay and John Walter Hyer Peck were married Saturday at St. Peters Episcopal Church in Weston, Mass. The Rev. Stephen O. Voysey, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Fleming, Edward Weisiger Jr.
description: Elizabeth Anne Fleming and Edward Innes Weisiger Jr. were married Saturday in Aspen, Colo. The Rev. Dr. William P. Woodall, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Aspen Community Church.

title: Tiffany McGuffee, Jordan Haverly
description: Tiffany Danielle McGuffee and Jordan Michael Haverly were married Saturday evening at the Capitol Hill Club in Washington. The Rev. Julin Bermudez, who was ordained by the International Ministerial Fellowship, officiated.

title: Matthew Pate, Samuel Garrett
description: Matthew David Pate and Samuel Paul Garrett were married Saturday evening aboard the yacht Athena in Newport Beach, Calif., by Kevin Jennings, a Universal Life minister.

title: Elizabeth Hardwick, Michael Kornheiser
description: Elizabeth Dana Hardwick, a daughter of Monie T. Hardwick and T. Chandler Hardwick of Okatie, S.C., was married Saturday evening to Michael Phillip Kornheiser, the son of Karril M. Kornheiser and Tony Kornheiser of Washington. Anne T. McCormack, an aunt of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Rehoboth Beach Country Club in Rehoboth Beach, Del.

title: James Bekier, Jonathan Swaden
description: James Martin Bekier and Jonathan David Swaden were married Saturday at the Sunstone Vineyards & Winery in Santa Ynez, Calif. The officiant was Martin Swaden, Mr. Swadens father, who became a minister with American Marriage Ministries for the event.

title: Caroline Nacey, Christopher Hedges
description: Caroline King Nacey, the daughter of Jane V. King and Michael Nacey of Boston, was married Saturday evening to Christopher John Hedges, a son of Jennifer A. Hedges and Robert J. Hedges of Southampton, Bermuda. Judge Nancy Gertner, who is retired from the Federal District Court in Boston, officiated at Stone Meadow Farm in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Fiona Goldstein, Michael Boyce Jr.
description: Fiona Ann Kelly Goldstein and Michael John Boyce Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Kaaterskill farm in Catskill, N.Y. Jeanne Stark, a minister ordained by the Universal Ministries, officiated a ceremony that was led by Larry Pine, an actor and friend of the brides mother.

title: No Curbs on Their Enthusiasm
description: Cheryl Hines and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. were married Saturday at the home of the grooms mother, Ethel Kennedy, in Hyannis Port, Mass. The Rev. William F. Schulz, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Kathryn Girolamo, Samuel Miller
description: Kathryn Elizabeth Girolamo, a daughter of Patricia E. Girolamo and Robert H. Girolamo of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Samuel John Miller, a son of Bonnie C. Miller and William F. Miller III of Houston. The Rev. James B. Teague, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Stone Church in Yorktown Heights.

title: Kara Gorski, Edward Reed
description: Kara Marie Gorski and Edward Joseph Reed were married Saturday by the Rev. Patrick M. Sullivan, the brides uncle and a Roman Catholic priest, at the Holy Comforter Catholic Church in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Francesca Gazzaniga and Richard Novak
description: Francesca Smylie Gazzaniga, the daughter of Charlotte Smylie Gazzaniga and Michael S. Gazzaniga of Carpinteria, Calif., was married Saturday to Richard Novak, the son of Dr. Lea Novak and Jan Novak of Birmingham, Ala. Judge Suzanne I. Gazzaniga of Placer County Superior Court, in Auburn, Calif., a cousin of the bride, officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Sarah Weiss and William Strom
description: Sarah Faye Weiss and William McHenry Strom are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Seth Limmer at Prairie Production, an event space in Chicago.

title: An Event for Bigs Led to the Big Day
description: Jill Christine Simonson and Fernando Luciano were married Saturday at the Lewiston Museum in Lewiston, N.Y. Terry C. Collesano, the mayor of Lewiston, officiated.

title: Editors' Note: August 3, 2014
description: An article on Oct. 13, 2013, about the difficulties brokers face selling apartments that have been occupied by hoarders included an example of a two-bedroom prewar co-op on the Upper West Side. After publication, editors received more information and concluded that neither the owner, Mimi Turque Marre, nor her apartment belonged in the article; they should not have been included.

title: Airstrike Near U.N. School Kills 10 as Israel Shifts Troops in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  As Israel began to redeploy significant numbers of its troops away from populated areas of Gaza on Sunday, an Israeli Air Force missile struck near the entrance of a United Nations school sheltering displaced Palestinians in Rafah, killing 10 people and wounding 35 others and drawing a new round of international condemnation.

title: 1914: Germany Officially Declares War on France
description: Germany officially declared war upon France at 5.45 yesterday evening. The notification was made by Baron von Schoen, the German Ambassador to France, when he called at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Paris yesterday to ask for his passports. Baron von Schoen declared that his Government had instructed him to inform the Government of the Republic that French aviators had flown over Belgium and that other French aviators had flown over Germany and dropped bombs as far as Nuremberg. He added that this constituted an act of aggression and violation of German territory.

title: Cloud Revenue Jumps, Led by Microsoft and IBM
description: The virtue of fear as a source of animating energy has long been recognized in the quicksilver tech industry. Only the paranoid survive, as Andrew S. Grove, Intels longtime leader, put it  a guiding principle that was also the title of his 1996 book on management.

title: The Case for Bribing Kids to Memorize Poetry
description: My 11-year-old son, Nate, perches on a stool in the kitchen, frowning at the sheet of paper in his hands. O.K., I think Ive got it, he announces.

title: Why Our Expectations of Childbirth Are Changing
