description: When the filmmaker Irene Lusztig got pregnant, she prepared for the arrival of her child by collecting instructions about motherhood. She ordered home videos and used baby scrapbooks from eBay and unearthed medical and instructional videos.

title: 1939: Woman M.P. Is 1st to Wed in Commons Crypt
description: LONDON  Miss Thelma Cazalet, Conservative Member of Parliament for East Islington, London, was married today [Aug. 3] to David Keir, political correspondent of the London News Chronicle, in the ancient crypt of the House of Commons, which had been decorated with lilies. It was the first time that a woman Member of Parliament had been married in the crypt, which members may use for their weddings on payment of 25 for a special license from the Archbishop of Canterbury.

title: China Says Nearly 100 Are Killed in Week of Unrest in Xinjiang
description: BEIJING  It was a bloody week in Chinas far west, with nearly 100 people killed in unrest that the authorities have characterized as terrorism but that Uighur advocacy groups have said is a consequence of a sweeping crackdown aimed at silencing opposition to the governments hard-line policies in the region.

title: Nonprofits Provide Jobless Men With a Fitting for a Second Chance
description: Joseph Campbell noticed them whenever he hunted for work on the streets of Manhattan: the purposeful men wearing pinstripes or herringbone, seersucker or linen.

title: City Ballet Plans a Fashionable Fall Gala
description: Do the clothes make the dancer? The worlds of ballet and high fashion have intersected ever since Coco Chanel designed costumes for Diaghilevs Ballets Russes, and this year the combination of the two fields will once again be the theme of New York City Ballets fall gala. City Ballet is to present three world premieres at the Sept. 23 gala, with the choreographers sharing the top billing with the couturiers.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 6:30 P.M. (13) MOYERS & COMPANY Bill Moyers interviews the Tony-winning actor John Lithgow about playing King Lear in the Public Theaters Shakespeare in the Park production, and how the role speaks to our times. To me, the most pointed line in the whole play is: Ive taen too little care of this, says Mr. Lithgow (above, with Jessica Collins as Cordelia). You know, we live fairly comfortable lives. And every day youre reminded of  of the  the astonishing misery in the rest of the world. He adds, I dont think there is a play which is so nakedly painful. Mr. Lithgow, who has been blogging about the experience for The New York Times, is in rehearsals with Glenn Close for the Broadway revival of Edward Albees A Delicate Balance. His new film, Love Is Strange, in which he and Alfred Molina play a couple of 39 years who are forced to live apart after marrying, opens on Aug. 22.

title: On the Bowery, Questions About the Catholic Churchs Shifting Mission
description: Men lined up outside St. Joseph House on the Lower East Side on a recent morning, some with their belongings stuffed in worn bags, all with their stomachs empty. Inside the dining hall, which is run by Catholic Worker, a hearty meal of stew and bread awaited. Most of the men were homeless, though not necessarily hopeless  this daily ritual gave sustenance and respite in a neighborhood that has steadily pushed them aside as tenements and poor people give way to luxury buildings.

title: Airstrikes and Mourning in Gaza
description: The death toll in Gaza mounted on Sunday, with Palestinian officials reporting a strike near the entrance of a United Nations school sheltering displaced residents.

title: Sunni Extremists in Iraq Seize 3 Towns From Kurds and Threaten Major Dam
description: BAGHDAD  Sunni extremists seized control of three towns in northern Iraq on Sunday after fierce battles with Kurdish security forces, sending thousands of people fleeing to the nearby mountains and threatening the countrys largest dam.

title: New Study Sees Atlantic Warming Behind a Host of Recent Climate Shifts
description: Updated, 3:10 p.m. | Using climate models and observations, a fascinating study in this weeks issue of Nature Climate Change points to a marked recent warming of the Atlantic Ocean as a powerful shaper of a host of notable changes in climate and ocean patterns in the last couple of decades  including Pacific wind, sea level and ocean patterns, the decade-plus hiatus in global warming and even Californias deepening drought.

title: Gotham Chamber Opera Hands Out Music Award
description: The Gotham Chamber Opera, a small outfit that has become an increasingly important voice in New York since the demise of New York City Opera, has announced that David Hertzberg would be the first winner of a new award: the Catherine Doctorow Prize for Music.

title: Earthquake Kills Hundreds in Southwest China
description: BEIJING  A powerful earthquake that rocked a mountainous region of southwest China on Sunday killed at least 367 people and injured more than 1,800 others, according to the state news media. With dozens of people reported missing on Sunday night, the death toll was expected to rise.

title: Guardians of the Galaxy Leads Weekend Box Office
description: For the seventh time in 19 weeks, a Marvel movie was a huge No. 1 at the North American box office. Guardians of the Galaxy, about the galactic adventures of a quirky group of obscure comics characters, including a machine-gun-toting raccoon and a grunting plant-person named Groot, took in an estimated $94 million, the third-highest movie opening of the year.

title: Tap Water Ban for Toledo Residents
description: Residents of Toledo, Ohios fourth-largest city, spent the weekend under a water advisory after tests revealed toxins in the citys water supply, likely caused by algae growing in Lake Erie.

title: Confessions of a Cat Guy
description: Tim Kreider, the author of the Sunday Review cover article A Man and His Cat, spoke with Op-Talk about people and their pets, and his relationship with the cat who inhabited his life and home for 19 years. He was interviewed by Peter Catapano, an editor in Opinion.

title: Assessing the Damage and Destruction in Gaza
description: The damage to Gazas infrastructure from the current conflict is already more severe than the destruction caused by either of the last two Gaza wars.

title: One Awkward Swing Reinjures Woodss Back and Jeopardizes His Future
description: AKRON, Ohio  Tiger Woodss switchback comeback trail is at an impasse after he was forced to withdraw midway through Sundays final round of the Bridgestone Invitational, the World Golf Championships event at Firestone Country Club.

title: Evercore to Buy Research Firm Institutional Strategy & Investment
description: Evercore Partners said on Sunday that it planned to buy Institutional Strategy & Investment, a move intended to bolster its research and trading arm.

title: Fighters From Syria Kill 10 Lebanese Soldiers in Battle Over Border Town
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Islamist fighters from Syria killed 10 Lebanese soldiers and appeared to have captured more than a dozen others in an armed offensive that left them in a tense battle for control of a Lebanese border town, Lebanons army chief said Sunday.

title: Viennese Classicism, Varied and Revealing
description: Innovation has been the watchword of the once staid Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center over the last dozen years, with Jane Moss as artistic director and Louis Langre as music director. But those worthies can still muster a long, rich night of more or less Mozartean fare without resorting to an early-music or new-music band, a fully staged opera or an injection of dance or world music.

title: Excerpt: Fidelio
description: A scene from the production at Santa Fe Opera.

title: Con Men Arent Stupid
description: Brad DeLong finds Larry Kotlikoff fulminating about how mean I am  so mean that he apparently couldt bring himself to read what I wrote. No, I didnt say that Paul Ryan is stupid. I did imply  and have said explicitly on many other occasions  that he is a con man. Why did I do that?

title: A Heavy Metal Alloy, Fused With Youth
description: Unlocking the Truth, a trio of black middle-schoolers from Brooklyn who received extensive coverage from the news media recently after signing a lucrative record deal, is a boy band, but only in the most literal sense of the term.

title: In Giants Rout of Mets, the Biggest Hit May Be to Colons Trade Value
description: As the trading deadline approached last week, Mets Manager Terry Collins sought out the veteran pitcher Bartolo Colon to see if the constant trade rumors about him had become a distraction. Colon, considered the Mets most marketable and available asset, simply shrugged his shoulders. Rumors are part of the game, he told Collins.

title: An Antidote to Illusion, Examining Restive Borders
description: Thousands of Western tourists visit the temples of Tibet, the spice markets of Xinjiang and the lush jungles of Yunnan each year. David Eimer did, too, repeatedly, over the past decade, but he had a larger purpose in mind: to investigate the nature of Chinese rule in the restive border regions where its 55 ethnic minorities live.

title: At Roth Open Swiss Teams, a Declarer-Play Problem
description: The Roth Open Swiss Teams, played over the final weekend at the Summer Nationals in Las Vegas last month, was won by Paul Fireman of Chestnut Hill, Mass.; Gavin Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Vincent Demuy of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.; John Kranyak of Las Vegas; and John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge of New York City.

title: Mourning a Champion of Eclectic Performance With Pomp and Spirit
description: If you didnt know Jenneth Webster personally, you might have known her just by walking through Lincoln Center on a summer day. As the director of Lincoln Center Out of Doors for 28 years, Ms. Webster filled the plazas each summer with her eclectic, lively choice of dance and music, all of it free to the public. She died in April, and on Friday in Hearst Plaza, artists and guest speakers, including many of the choreographers and dancers she had championed, gathered for a concert in her memory.

title: A President Hoist With His Own Petulance, Secretly Recorded
description: The strange little documentary Nixon by Nixon: In His Own Words (Monday on HBO) is engrossing despite itself. Timed to the 40th anniversary next Saturday of Richard M. Nixons resignation, it samples Nixons secret White House tapes to sketch the familiar portrait of the president as a closeted monster: paranoid, vicious, racist, sexist, anti-Semitic, with a casual disregard for anything besides his own standing.

title: Familiar Faces Join Forces to Portray an Unlikely Duo
description: The new FX sitcom Partners might have you doubting your own memory. The series, which stars Kelsey Grammer and Martin Lawrence, is so labored and unfunny that you may find yourself asking: Wasnt Frasier sharp and urbane? Didnt Martin have some spunk? Where are those two guys?

title: Memorial Plan Called a Five-Star Folly
description: Fifteen years ago, federal officials approved the idea of building a memorial on the Washington Mall to honor Dwight D. Eisenhower, the general and president, and they later selected one of Americas foremost architects to design it. But the memorial is still far from being built, and congressional critics have come forward in recent days to depict it as just another Washington boondoggle or, in the words of a new report, a five-star folly.

title: Holocaust Grafted to Beethoven
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  No audience members staggered out of the Santa Fe Opera House in search of assistance on Thursday evening after Stephen Wadsworths production of Beethovens Fidelio inspired by Bergen-Belsen. This wasnt Burkhard C. Kosminskis staging of Wagners Tannhuser, which last year upset audience members in Dsseldorf, Germany, so much with its graphic depiction of gassings and shootings that some required medical attention. Mr. Wadsworths concentration-camp spin on the tale of a political prisoner who is liberated by his wife after she has disguised herself as a man and apprenticed with the prison warden was perfectly tasteful.

title: Where the Stars Come to Shine in New and Unexpected Ways
description: VAIL, Colo.  High in the Rockies amid pine forests and ski slopes, the Vail International Dance Festival, now in its 26th season, has become an event of prestige, history and startling ambition. Each year, it features premieres, debuts, new partnerships and an admirably eclectic taste. Even for those performers and choreographers who return each year (a large number, and high level), it often opens some new chapter in their careers.

title: Candlelight Reflections to Illuminate Harmonies
description: Some musicians experience synesthesia, associating certain colors with particular harmonies or sounds. For the violist Antoine Tamestit, Bachs Suite No. 1 in G for cello evokes the color blue, along with a sense of fluidity and tranquillity. The Suite No. 3 in C makes him think of the sun and thus the color yellow. He feels the color in the sound, which informs his interpretation, he explained during his impressive solo recital at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday evening.

title: Banco Esprito Santo to Be Split Up in Rescue by Portugal
description: The troubled lender Banco Esprito Santo will be shut down, and its healthy businesses transferred to a new bank, as part of 4.9 billion euro rescue plan financed primarily by the Portuguese government, European and Portuguese officials said early on Monday.

title: Trombone Shorty Helps a Young Victim
description: The news reports shook New Orleans: A 14-year-old boy was robbed of his trombone last week by a gunman who fired several shots at him as he ran away. When one of the citys best-known musicians, Troy Andrews, who performs as Trombone Shorty, heard about it while on tour in the Northeast, he decided to do something: He asked his foundation to replace the boys stolen instrument. It is very unfortunate that this young man was robbed of his instrument and had to be a victim of New Orleans crime, Mr. Andrews said in a statement. Im replacing his horn, because I want to make sure that he has what he needs to continue his education in music without missing a beat. He is the future of our music. Mr. Andrewss band, Trombone Shorty & Orleans Avenue, has performed at the Grammy Awards and the White House and has become familiar to television viewers of the HBO series Treme. His Trombone Shorty Foundation is dedicated to passing on New Orleanss musical heritage through educational initiatives. Bill Taylor, the foundations executive director, said that on Saturday he brought the new trombone to the robbery victim, whose name was withheld for his safety. Then he put the teenager on the phone with Mr. Andrews, who was at the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: A News Giant Going It Alone
description: After spending years in the shadow of bankruptcy proceedings, management turmoil and its more prominent broadcasting stations, the Tribune Companys publishing division, including well-known newspapers like The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, is striking out on its own.

title: Q. and A.: Dan Washburn on The Forbidden Game
description: As a journalist in Shanghai, Dan Washburn discovered that, while writing about golf for outlets like ESPN.com, Slate and Foreign Policy, he was able to tell not just stories about a sport, but also about the vast transitions sweeping across China. He expanded that focus into a book, The Forbidden Game: Golf and the Chinese Dream, which examines the broad effects golf has had on the country, from the poor worker who becomes a golf pro to the farmer whose land is taken to build a new course.

title: Strands at a Chalet
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  When Joel Fagliano was going back and forth to college in California from his home on the East Coast, he probably had a lot of time to decide where he best liked to sit on an airplane. And he probably came up with the theme for this puzzle there, because a flight of that length leaves a young man lots of time to think.

title: Tackling Corruption in China
description: President Xi Jinpings campaign against corruption continues.

title: Jittery About Teams Future, Bills Fans Remember a Titan of Its Past
description: CANTON, Ohio  For more than a half-century, the Pro Football Hall of Fame game has served as the true start of the N.F.L. preseason and a chance to commemorate the titans of the sport.

title: Air Force Academy to Examine Conduct of Cadet Athletes
description: WASHINGTON  The superintendent of the Air Force Academy has begun an investigation into allegations of sexual assault and other misconduct among its cadet athletes, academy officials said Sunday.

title: Florian Homm Wanted by the F.B.I.
description: Mr. Homm is accused of buying and selling lightly traded shares among entities he controlled in a practice known as portfolio pumping. Authorities say his goal was to artificially inflate the value of the hedge fund he managed, Absolute Capital Management Holdings Ltd.

title: What Would Krishna Do? Or Shiva? Or Vishnu?
description: This is the ninth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Jonardon Ganeri, currently a visiting professor of philosophy at New York University Abu Dhabi and the author of The Lost Age of Reason: Philosophy in Early Modern India 14501700.

title: Florian Homm, Toppled Financier, Finds Safe Harbor in Germany
description: FRANKFURT  Florian Homm had long maintained that he was not guilty of charges that he defrauded investors of more than $200 million. Still, he wasted no time when word reached him in an Italian jail late on the afternoon of June 3 that Italys supreme court had  much to the consternation of United States authorities  set him free.

title: Man Who Filmed Fatal Police Chokehold Is Arrested on Weapons Charges
description: Narcotics officers on Saturday arrested a Staten Island man whose visceral cellphone images of the forceful and ultimately deadly arrest of Eric Garner helped galvanize protests and set off a citywide debate over police practices.

title: River Grime? Triathletes Are Swimming in It
description: They call it the Hudson Mustache, the thick band of silty debris that clings to a swimmers upper lip after a nearly mile-long paddle down the Hudson River in the New York City Triathlon. The race is one of the few times a New Yorker will voluntarily plunge into the sometimes unsanitary waterway. So on Sunday morning at dawn, under a light veil of rain, 4,000 wet-suited athletes gamely leapt off the dock at 99th Street to swim, bob or, in some cases, back-float downstream, carried by the rivers swift current.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Aug. 4
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Disputes Threaten to Derail Audit of Afghanistan Vote
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Wrangling over Afghan election results continued Sunday as campaign aides of the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah accused one of President Hamid Karzais vice presidents of involvement in fraud in a runoff vote that they say was stacked against Mr. Abdullah.

title: 40 Years Later, Still Trying to Define Presidential Power
description: WASHINGTON  Talk of impeachment is in the air. A handful of conservatives issue statements and sell T-shirts promoting an impeachment their party leaders consider a fools errand. Democrats beat the drums even louder, raising money by scaring supporters into taking it seriously.

title: A Web Guerrilla Breaking News From the Jungle
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  On approaching Glenn Greenwalds home office high in the jungle-encrusted mountains above Rio de Janeiro, all is tranquil, bucolic even. A gurgling stream at the entrance frames the idyll.

title: In Conversation With Glenn Greenwald
description: Glenn Greenwald talks about his evolving role in the new media landscape in an interview with David Carr.

title: Nepal Enthralled by Visit of India Premier, Who Hits the Right Notes
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  In a visit that has transfixed this impoverished country, the Indian prime minister, Narendra Modi, told Nepals legislature on Sunday that its effort to write the nations Constitution was a sacred process.

title: Scrap the Extra Point, a Hall of Fame Kicker Says
description: CANTON, Ohio  When New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick proposed in March that the extra-point kick be pushed back to the 25-yard line to make it more competitive, place-kickers around the league winced. A tougher point-after kick might reduce their point totals, which could hurt them in salary negotiations.

title: Group Earns Oil Income Despite Pledge on Drilling
description: The nations largest environmental group is earning money from an oil well on land it controls in Texas, despite pledging a decade ago not to permit new oil and gas drilling on land supposedly set aside for conservation.

title: Adventures in Prior Authorization
description: DEAR Doctor, the letter from the insurance company began. We are writing to inform you that a prior authorization is required for the medication you prescribed.

title: A Tale of Two Dollar Stores
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  WHEN Dollar Tree and Family Dollar, two of the largest dollar stores in North America, agreed to a merger on Monday, it was the ultimate collision of Wall Street and Main Street. While hedge funds stand to make millions of dollars from the deal, the millions of Americans on limited budgets who rely on such stores will unfortunately be left behind.

title: Harun Farocki, Filmmaker of Modern Life, Dies at 70
description: Harun Farocki, an avant-garde German filmmaker and video artist whose work examined the ways images are used to inform, instruct, persuade and propagandize, died on Wednesday near Berlin. He was 70.

title: Women in Low-Wage Jobs; Black Men and Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Two State Poets Laureate Tell All (in Prose)
To Evade Russians, Plane Crossed Into Sweden
description: WASHINGTON  In an encounter reminiscent of the Cold War, an American reconnaissance plane crossed into Swedish airspace last month as it sought to avoid being intercepted by Russian fighters, American military officials said on Sunday.

title: On Abortion, Words Are Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer-Client Emails
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrests of Subway Dancers
description: To the Editor:

title: Strained Infrastructure in Philippines Erodes the Nations Growth Prospects
description: MANILA  Chris Ibasan travels only about five miles to work each day in one of Manilas business districts, but it is often a grueling two-hour commute that gets him into the office late.

title: The Eyes of Texas Are Upon a Man Who Kept to the Shadows
description: Adm. William H. McRaven has a 37-year record of things he cannot talk about, in a realm where orders are orders. Rising from Navy SEALs member to commander of all United States Special Operations forces, the admiral  who directed the raid that killed Osama bin Laden  has worked almost exclusively on secret operations.

title: Adm. Charles R. Larson, 77, Dies; Twice Led Naval Academy
description: Adm. Charles R. Larson, a former military commander in the Pacific who twice led the United States Naval Academy, the second time to help it recover from the worst cheating scandal in its history, died on July 26 at his home in Annapolis, Md. He was 77.

title: A Childhood Glow Reflected in the Box Score
description: As a youngster growing up in Upper Manhattan in the 1960s, I never tired of looking out the bedroom window of my parents top-floor apartment on Amsterdam Avenue during the baseball season and being able to view the bright lights of both Yankee Stadium nearby in the Bronx and, beginning in 1964, Shea Stadium off in the distance in Queens.

title: The Do-Even-Less Congress
description: Congress is a joke. But the joke isnt funny  unless, of course, youre into dark humor.

title: Crashing Without a Cushion
description: Talladega Superspeedway is known on the Nascar circuit for high speeds, packs of cars racing inches apart and spectacular multicar wrecks that fans love and drivers endure. A crash occurs during almost every race at Talladega, a huge Alabama oval, like the one in the final laps of a Nationwide Series event there in May 2012.

title: Obamas Other Success
description: Although the enemies of health reform will never admit it, the Affordable Care Act is looking more and more like a big success. Costs are coming in below predictions, while the number of uninsured Americans is dropping fast, especially in states that havent tried to sabotage the program. Obamacare is working.

title: European Central Bank Meeting and Bank of England Interest Rates
description: TRIAL TO SET PENALTY IN MICHAELS STORES CASE

title: Drones Outpacing Rules as Popularity Soars in New York
description: Jeremiah Johnson was flying his battery-powered drone above a park in Brooklyn on a recent weekend when he saw something in the distance.

title: European Sanctions Force Russian Carrier to Suspend Flights
description: MOSCOW  A low-cost subsidiary of the Russian state carrier Aeroflot announced on Sunday that it would suspend all flights as a result of sanctions imposed on Russia by the European Union.

title: Omar Khadrs Untold Story
description: The Canadian government has denied a request from a Toronto newspaper to conduct an on-camera interview with a former child soldier and detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Omar Khadr. Mr. Khadr, a 27-year-old Canadian, was captured in Afghanistan in 2002, when he was just 15, and accused of throwing a grenade during a firefight that killed an American soldier.

title: Wealth Managers Enlist Spy Tools to Map Portfolios
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Some of the engineers who used to help the Central Intelligence Agency solve problems have moved on to another challenge: determining the value of every conceivable investment in the world.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 3, 2014
description: Its like sending kindergartners up against an N.B.A. basketball team.

title: Global Trade Talks Suffer Another Setback
description: The collapse last week of a global trade agreement on simplifying customs rules will make it much harder for the World Trade Organization to finish its much-delayed Doha round of negotiations, which has a much broader agenda to lower tariffs and reduce barriers to trade.

title: The Custom-Made Super PAC
description: Attention, parents of political candidates. There is now a way to spend an unlimited amount on your childs campaign for Congress, completely ignoring that annoying $2,600 legal limit on what you can give. All you do is set up a super PAC for your kid and start writing checks. Its not much harder than that 529 account you used for the same kids college education.

title: Stumbling Along in the Race to Be Provocative
description: Stephen A. Smith will return to active duty this week at ESPN, which suspended him for being overzealous  and imprecise  while doing what he is paid to do: provoke and incite.

title: Former Head of Barclays Mergers Unit to Join Goldman
description: The former global head of Barclays mergers and acquisitions business, Paul G. Parker, is set to join one of his former rivals, Goldman Sachs.

title: McIlroy Follows British Open Win by Overtaking Garca at Bridgestone
description: AKRON, Ohio  Rory McIlroy was in the grips of the second-round yips when he sat down in Florida in June for a casual meeting with Jack Nicklaus, the golfing great, who has taken a paternal interest in McIlroys career.

title: As Oysters Die, Climate Policy Goes on the Stump
description: OLYMPIA, Wash.  Billions of baby oysters in the Pacific inlets here are dying and Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington is busy spreading the bad news.

title: A City Divided Over an Occupation Without End
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The summer tourists, in shorts and sundresses, walk the steep slope of Institutska Street, toward Independence Square, pausing to snap pictures of themselves in front of the fortresslike mounds of tires, cobblestones, twisted metal and hunks of wood that still stand as barricades, as if the riot police could return at any moment.

title: Virtuous Fast Food
New York City Pension System Is Strained by Costs and Politics
description: For years, New York City has been dutifully pumping more and more money into its giant pension system for retired city workers.

title: As Chamberlain Returns to Bronx, the Bug Game Lives On
description: CLEVELAND  As the Detroit Tigers arrive in the Bronx for a four-game series against the Yankees that begins Monday  and that should feature Tigers reliever Joba Chamberlains first appearance against his former team  a reminder of one of his most memorable outings clings to the windows of a hotel about 500 miles west.

title: Separatist Cadre Hopes for a Reprise in Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Early in the separatist struggle for eastern Ukraine, a leading Russian nationalist, Aleksandr G. Dugin, painted a glowing portrait of what the newly captured territories, referred to in Russia as Novorossiya, would become.

title: Nickelodeons Digital Generation
description: Meet Olly Timbers. Olly, an orange-haired 10-year-old boy, says he likes rum raisin ice cream, going on adventures, getting scratched just behind his elbow and also other kinds of ice cream.

title: Neighbors Say Barn Weddings Raise a Rumpus
description: GRANT, Minn.  For legions of young couples, there is no wedding venue more desirable than a barn in the country, with its unfussy vibe, picturesque setting and rural authenticity.

title: Airstrikes and Mourning in Gaza
description: The death toll in Gaza grew on Sunday, with Palestinian officials reporting a strike near the entrance of a United Nations school sheltering displaced residents.

title: Back Behind the Wheel
description: Eric McClure, a driver in Nascars Nationwide Series, sustained a head injury in a 2012 crash but has continued racing.

title: Affordable Housing Draws Middle Class to Inland Cities
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Americans have never hesitated to pack up the U-Haul in search of the big time, a better job or just warmer weather. But these days, domestic migrants are increasingly driven by the quest for cheaper housing.

title: Tanakas Road to Health Starts With a Game of Catch
description: BOSTON  One of the most scrutinized games of catch may take place at Yankee Stadium on Monday, a five-minute exercise that could help determine the outcome of the Yankees season, as well as the prospects of their 2015 campaign.

title: Ohio Lottery Trades the Promise of Riches for the Joy of Instant Gratification
description: COMMERCIALS from state lotteries tend to highlight the opulence that awaits winners, but a new campaign from the Ohio Lottery takes a more unusual approach. It makes no mention of winning, focusing instead on the pleasure that some instant-game players derive from scratching the opaque resin from the cards.

title: Barrier to Business in the Philippines
description: Inadequate transportation, electrical service and telecommunications add up to a multibillion-dollar drain on the economy.

title: Popular Demand
description: Somewhere inside the national imagination where pop culture, television and cult films intersect, the premiere last week of Sharknado 2: The Second One generated 581,000 tweets, which were seen 67 million times somewhere via Twitter.

title: In New Jersey, Workers Advocates Aim to Put Paid Sick Time on Ballot
description: Frustrated in their efforts to make paid sick leave mandatory for businesses throughout New Jersey, workers advocates are now pressing their campaign city by city, emboldened by laws recently passed in Newark and Jersey City, as well as in New York City.

title: Recounting a Tragic Past Through the Eyes of Survivors
description: Milos Dobry and Hana Pravda have apparently never met. Possibly Milos saw one of Hanas early films, like Marijka the Unfaithful. Maybe she strolled past a Prague soccer field where Milos made save after save at goal. Or maybe, a few years later  now wretched, terrified, half-starved  they might have crossed paths at Auschwitz.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 3, 2014
True Blood Recap: Doing the Vampire Tango
description: Season 7, Episode 7: May Be the Last Time

title: A Celebration of Ecuadorean Pride
description: Scenes from this years parade celebrating Ecuadorean pride in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Barrier to Business in the Philippines
description: Inadequate transportation, electrical service and telecommunications add up to a multibillion-dollar drain on the economy.

title: British Citizens Flee Tripoli on Ship as 25 Libyans Are Reportedly Killed in Fighting
description: CAIRO  A British Navy ship on Sunday evacuated about 100 British citizens from the Libyan capital, Tripoli, as 25 Libyans were reported killed in the fighting between rival militias that has torn apart the city and destroyed its airport.

title: In Gaza, a Shelter Comes Under Fire
description: After a United Nations school sheltering displaced Palestinians was hit by Israeli shells last week, leaving 21 dead, many questions have emerged.

title: Questions of Weapons and Warnings in Past Barrage on a Gaza Shelter
description: JABALIYA, Gaza Strip  An examination of an Israeli barrage that put a line of at least 10 shells through a United Nations school sheltering displaced Palestinians here last week suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have unleashed weapons inappropriate for urban areas despite rising alarm over civilian deaths.

title: Celebrated Trial Lawyer to Head Group Challenging Teacher Tenure
description: David Boies, the star trial lawyer who helped lead the legal charge that overturned Californias same-sex marriage ban, is becoming chairman of the Partnership for Educational Justice, a group that former CNN anchor Campbell Brown founded in part to pursue lawsuits challenging teacher tenure.

title: Immersed in a Holy Tradition
Australian Winemaker That Owns Beringer and Penfolds Weighs K.K.R.s Revised Bid
description: HONG KONG  Treasury Wine Estates, the Australian vintner that owns Penfolds and Beringer Vineyards, said on Monday that it would consider an improved $3.2 billion takeover offer led by the private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts after rejecting an earlier bid.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: Doing Your Own Dirty Work
description: Season 2, Episode 4: Dirty Jobs

title: The Leftovers Recap: Grief and Its Hucksters
description: Season 1, Episode 6: Guest

title: Halt and Catch Fire Recap: In a Flawed Series, a Very Big Truth
description: Season 1, Episode 10: 1984

title: Hillary Clintons Fee for a Hometown Speech: Free
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton apparently gives a steep hometown discount.

title: Jon Cavaiani, Medal of Honor Recipient in 1974, Dies at 70
description: Jon Cavaiani, a retired Army sergeant major and former prisoner of war who was awarded the Medal of Honor in 1974 for fending off an overwhelming number of enemy soldiers in Vietnam while allowing most of his men to escape, died on Tuesday in Stanford, Calif. He was 70.

title: Chess as a Contact Sport
description: Dear Diary:

title: Picking a Nursing Home Shouldnt Be Trial and Error
description: It took three tries before Leslie Reid-Green found a suitable nursing home for her 88-year-old mother, Bella Solomon, who has advanced dementia.

title: Word of the Day | misadventure
description: misadventure \mi-sd-ven-chr\ noun

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 10 P.M. (13) 15 TO LIFE: KENNETHS STORY After being tried as an adult in Florida starting in 2001 and receiving four consecutive life sentences at the age of 15 for a series of armed robberies he committed with his mothers crack dealer, Kenneth Ray Young, above, came to believe that he would die in prison. But in 2010, the Supreme Court ruled in Graham v. Florida that life sentences for juveniles convicted of crimes other than murder were unconstitutional. This POV documentary, directed by Nadine Pequeneza, follows Mr. Youngs case while examining a social system that doles out sentences to juvenile offenders intended for the most dangerous criminals. In Bob Herberts OP-ED.TV, at 9:30 a.m. on CUNY, Ms. Pequeneza and Mishi Faruqee, a juvenile justice policy strategist at the American Civil Liberties Union, discuss the issue.

title: Yanks Get Win, and Another Scare on a Pitchers Health
description: By DAVID WALDSTEIN

title: On Day of Pageantry, Just Along for the Ride
description: The threat of rain did not keep revelers from flocking to a parade celebrating Ecuadorean pride in Jackson Heights, Queens, on Sunday. Mayor Bill de Blasio was among those on hand to mark the occasion.

title: Wilfred Feinberg, Federal Appeals Court Judge and Mentor, Dies at 94
description: Wilfred Feinberg, a federal appeals court judge in New York who ruled in major cases involving the Vietnam War and labor rights over his five decades on the bench and shepherded the careers of many young lawyers to prominence, died on July 31 in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 4, 2014
description: Its murky and green  nothing I would swim in. Its sort of like the wicked witch from the Wizard of Oz: lime green.

title: Corrections: August 4, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Student Crossword | Landmarks and Monuments
description: Test your knowledge of landmarks and monuments by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Li Ka-shings Company in Talks to Buy Planes From Guy Handss AWAS Aviation
description: LONDON  Li Ka-shing, Asias richest man, is in preliminary talks to acquire aircraft being sold by AWAS Aviation Capital, the aircraft leasing company owned by Guy Handss private equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners.

title: Amateur Terrorist Hunters Offered Millions in Cash in Xinjiang
description: The Chinese government will strike with awe-inspiring force against people it says are Islamic terrorists causing bloodshed in the western region of Xinjiang, Zhang Chunxian, the top Communist Party leader there, said last week.

title: Chemical Company Apologizes After Deadly Explosions in Taiwan
description: A petrochemical company has apologized to the residents of Taiwans second-largest city following explosions that left 28 people dead and more than 300 injured.

title: Chinese Group Fosun International Bids $441 Million for Roc Oil of Australia
description: HONG KONG  Fosun International, the Chinese investment group that likens itself to Warren E. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway, announced on Monday that it was making its first push into the oil and natural gas business, with a $441 million bid for Roc Oil of Australia.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Ohio Residents Told Not to Drink Tap Water
description: In Toledo Faces Second Day of Water Ban, Emma G. Fitzsimmons reports on the Ohio citys efforts to keep people safe from contaminated water.

title: Still Life With Soldier and Bullets
description: Hector Rene Membreno-Canales relied on everyday objects when he started photographing still lifes at the School of Visual Arts. Under soft lighting, he arrayed grapes, cheese and strawberries atop the folds of a tablecloth. Then, after consulting with some of his classmates, he would add an assault rifle, a gas mask or an ammunition box with dozens of bullets.

title: Shadowy World for Chinese Surrogates
description: Surrogate motherhood is illegal in China, but thanks to rising infertility, a cultural imperative to have children and relaxation of the one-child policy, the country is seeing a boom in births via hired rural women, Ian Johnson and Cao Li report.

title: On Centenary of World War I, Europe Sees Modern Parallels
description: LONDON  With a dimming of the lights and ceremonies across this country and in Belgium, monarchs, princes, presidents and citizens commemorated on Monday the day 100 years ago when Britain entered World War I at the start of four years of carnage once called the war to end all wars.

title: 100 Missing in Bangladesh as High Waves Capsize Ferry
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A ferry overloaded with more than 200 passengers sank while crossing a river in central Bangladesh on Monday morning, and despite rescue efforts by naval forces and fire brigades, at least half the passengers were missing and presumed dead, officials said.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: Why Is the Economy Still Weak? Blame These Five Sectors
description: The economy keeps underperforming. Yes, new G.D.P. data last week were better than expected. But the United States is still producing around $800 billion a year less in goods and services than it would if the economy were at full health, and as a result millions of people arent working who would be if conditions were better.

title: New York Today: Early Birds
description: Good morning on this muggy Monday.

title: Profits Decrease at HSBC as Business in Asia Slows
description: Updated, 7:35 p.m. |

title: Morning Views
description: Attention, parents of political candidates. There is now a way to spend an unlimited amount on your childs campaign for Congress, completely ignoring that annoying $2,600 legal limit on what you can give,says an editorial in The New York Times. All you do is set up a super PAC for your kid and start writing checks. Its not much harder than that 529 account you used for the same kids college education. This is apparently what Martine Rothblatt, the founder of Sirius Satellite Radio, did for her son, Gariel Rothblatt, who is running for a Florida congressional seat. A group calling itselfSpace PAC,in promoting Mr. Rothblatts campaign, has raised $225,000, all of it from Martine Rothblatt. The Times says, family-financed super PACs are only the latest and most outrageous examples of how super PACs are used in this campaign cycle to evade the limits on donations. Congress shouldpass theEmpowering Citizens Act, a bill introduced in the House that would put strict limits on these kinds of coordinated contributions. But the more members of Congress depend on these groups, the less chance they will want to put a stop to them.

title: Why House Deportation Vote Wont Hurt the G.O.P.
description: Republican hopes for attracting more Hispanic voters suffered another setback on Friday when the House passed a bill to effectively end President Obamas program to defer deportations of undocumented children. Yet the vote is unlikely to deal a severe blow to the partys chances in Novembers midterm elections. Hispanic voters may be flexing their growing political muscles in presidential elections, but they have far less sway over the composition of the House or the Senate, particularly in 2014.

title: Weed World: What I Saw at the Revolution
description: Lawrence Downes wrote the lead editorial on Colorados experiment in marijuana legalization. We asked about the trip he took to research the issue.

title: Balancing Lean Company Culture With the Perks of Success
description: In February, my company, RJMetrics, moved into a new office. It was bittersweet to outgrow our old space, partially because it had a pretty amazing legacy. Before us, a company called VoiceStar had built a business in the exact same suite and sold it to Marchex for millions. Those guys drove away in Ferraris, our old landlord liked to say.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Ruth Padawer on Autistic Children Who Shed Their Symptoms
description: Ruth Padawer, a contributing writer for the magazine, is the author of this weeks cover story about children who have recovered from autism. Her previous article for the magazine was about gender-fluid children.

title: Daily Report: Turning Users Into Customers at Facebook
description: Ever since it began selling ads 10 years ago, Facebook has been fighting doubts about its value to marketers. Search engines like Google offer advertisers a direct link to people seeking out particular products, while television remains the dominant way to reach a mass audience. Now, Facebook claims, it can provide the best of both, Vindu Goel reports.

title: Test Yourself | Beyonc and Jay Z On the Run
description: This week were experimenting with a new, slightly more elaborate version of our long-running English language-arts Test Yourself feature. Please, tell us what you think.

title: Morning Agenda: Rescue Plan for Portuguese Bank
description: The troubled lender Banco Esprito Santo will be shut down, and its healthy businesses transferred to a new bank, as part of 4.9 billion euro rescue plan financed primarily by the Portuguese government, Jack Ewing and Chad Bray write in The New York Times. In a plan announced on Monday, the Portuguese government will provide most of the money for the rescue in the form of a loan, but the heaviest losses will be absorbed by Banco Esprito Santo shareholders and some creditors.

title: Israel Moves to Wrap Up Gaza Military Operation
description: JERUSALEM  Claiming it had achieved most of its objectives and pressured by Western allies to stop causing civilian casualties in Gaza, Israel moved to wind down its operations there on Monday  either unilaterally or through a new Egyptian-brokered cease-fire announced late in the day.

title: A New High Performance Chronograph With a Luxurious Facade
description: In this weekly series, the mens fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Christopher David Ryan captures a timepiece from Girard-Perregaux.

title: Marcato Capital Adds to Pressure on InterContinental Hotels to Sell Itself
description: LONDON  The hedge fund Marcato Capital Management said on Monday that it had hired the investment bank Houlihan Lokey as a financial adviser, as it seeks to put more pressure on InterContinental Hotels Group to sell itself.

title: In Televised Confession, Guo Meimei Blames Vanity for Her Misdeeds
description: Guo Meimei, whose name has come to be inextricably linked with the Chinese publics distrust of official charities, was shown on CCTV state television on Sunday night confessing to having fabricated her association with the Red Cross Society of China purely out of vanity.

title: Weekly Quandary: Sharing  or Not Sharing  a Good Babysitter
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

title: Germany Blocks the Delivery of Military Parts to Russia
description: BERLIN  The German government, increasing the economic pressure on Russia over its involvement in Ukraine, has blocked delivery of parts for a high-tech military training center that was to be completed in Russia by the end of the year, a spokeswoman for the Economics Ministry said Monday.

title: Algae Blooms Create Water Crisis in Toledo
description: Mayor D. Michael Collins of Toledo, Ohio, announced that a ban on drinking water had been lifted after test results showed toxins were no longer at dangerous levels.

title: Dealing With Opioid Abuse Would Pay for Itself
description: Once championed as the answer to chronic pain, opioid medications and painkillers have become a large and costly problem in the United States. Fatal overdoses have quadrupled in the last 15 years, and opioids now cause more deaths than any other drug, over 16,000 in 2010. Prescription opioid abuse is also costly, sapping productivity and increasing health care and criminal justice costs to the tune of $55.7 billion in 2007, for example.

title: Extended Land Stays on Long-Haul Cruises
description: For avid cruisers, having insufficient time to more thoroughly experience a destination is a frequent complaint. Several cruise lines have stepped up to meet this growing demand by offering longer stays at ports of call.

title: In Fatal Flash, Gaza Psychologist Switches Roles, Turning Into a Trauma Victim
description: GAZA CITY  Hassan al-Zeyada has spent decades counseling fellow residents of the Gaza Strip who experience psychological trauma. Now, as he prepares to aid his neighbors after a new round of combat and carnage, he has a challenging new patient: himself.

title: Warburg Pincus to Invest in Zenith Energy, a Fuel Terminal Business
description: Warburg Pincus said on Monday that it planned to invest up to $600 million in Zenith Energy, a company that aims to build oil and natural gas terminals abroad.

title: U.S. Inquiry Finds a Culture of Violence Against Teenage Inmates at Rikers Island
description: In an extraordinary rebuke of the New York City Department of Correction, the federal government said on Monday that the department had systematically violated the civil rights of male teenagers held at Rikers Island by failing to protect them from the rampant use of unnecessary and excessive force by correction officers.

title: China Tells Microsoft Not to Interfere With Inquiry
description: BEIJING  In another sign that China is aiming at Microsoft, the government warned the company on Monday not to interfere with its antitrust investigation, days after officials conducted surprise raids on four of the technology giants offices across the country.

title: Behind Toledos Water Crisis, a Long-Troubled Lake Erie
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  It took a serendipitous slug of toxins and the loss of drinking water for a half-million residents to bring home what scientists and government officials in this part of the country have been saying for years: Lake Erie is in trouble, and getting worse by the year.

title: Top Medicare Prescribers for Acthar Have Links to Its Maker
description: Many of Medicares top prescribers of the expensive specialty drug H.P. Acthar Gel have financial ties to the drugs maker.

title: Sweetgreens Tumblr, Chris ODowds Twitter and More
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: The Obscure Drug With a Growing Medicare Tab
description: An obscure injectable medication made from pigs pituitary glands has surged up the list of drugs that cost Medicare the most money, taking a growing bite out of the programs resources.

title: From Out of Doors to Your Device: Lincoln Center to Stream Three Concerts
description: Lincoln Center will be streaming three concerts from the final week of its free Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. The concerts, part of the first Americanafest, a collaboration between Lincoln Center and the Americana Music Association, a Nashville organization that promotes American roots music, will be streamed live in their entirety, including the opening acts.

title: 1914: Belgians Eager to Take Arms
description: BRUSSELS  An extraordinary wave of patriotism has passed over Brussels, and, indeed, the whole of Belgium since the news of the declaration of war. No fewer than 45,000 volunteers have been enrolled, and eager crowds fight for entry to the recruiting offices. In fact, it has become a question whether the Ministry of War possesses sufficient rifles and ammunition to equip all those who wish to take arms for the defence of their country. King Albert will proceed to the frontier to defend the national territory, which was invaded this morning by the Germans, who entered Belgium, near Arlon. The New York Herald, European Edition, August 5, 1914

title: An Indian Sculptor With Monumental Ambition
description: NOIDA, India  He may be historys most prolific monumental sculptor, and now he hopes to win what may be one of historys largest artistic commissions.

title: Emmys 2014: Who Would You Pick for Lead Actress in a Drama?
description: The Emmy nominations are like the weather  everyone complains about them but no one does anything.

title: Judges Ruling Against Bank of America Showcases a Novel Enforcement Strategy
description: Teddy Roosevelts admonition to speak softly and carry a big stick applies to the Justice Department these days as it seeks multibillion-dollar penalties from banks for their role in the financial crisis. One of its sticks just got a little bit bigger as a result of a decision last week by Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan in a lawsuit against Bank of America.

title: Upending Expectations About the Hottest Handbag Brands
description: Guess what It-bag brands get talked about most online: Herms? What fools these mortals be! Balenciaga? Not really.

title: What Is the Worlds Most Livable City?
description: Copenhagen is the worlds most livable city, according to a collaboration betweenMonoclemagazine and the organization Cities for People. The city took the top spot in an annuallist of the worlds 25 most livable citiesfor the second year in a row.

title: Democrats Seize on Social Issues as Attitudes Shift
description: WASHINGTON  Facing re-election, Gov. Scott Walker, Republican of Wisconsin, no longer talks about stopping same-sex marriage. Its those on the left that are pushing the issue, he says.

title: Joe Fendel: At the Video Store
description: Our challenge this week was suggested by Numberplay regular contributor Joe Fendel, whose original puzzles often emerge from everyday family activities. His current creation leaves us with a practical tool for group decision-making. Heres Mr. Fendel with

title: Today in Small Business: The Best and Worst of Family Business
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Her Throne Defunct, a Princess Fights Eviction From Her Manhattan Walk-Up
description: Tutankhamen, Richard III, Louis XVI  throughout history, the deaths of monarchs have set off wars, revolutions and writing careers. Now, the passing of the last of the imperial Ottoman Turks has led to a battle over the rent-controlled apartment of an Afghan princess on the Upper East Side.

title: The Meaning of Emancipation Day
description: By August 1864, the abolitionist writer and former slave Harriet Jacobs had spent more than a year and a half providing relief for the refugees flooding the contraband camps of Alexandria, Va.  some 6,000 people, she reported that spring to her employer, the New York Yearly Meeting of Friends. By Jacobss count that March, the freedmen had put up 700 small houses in just eight months.

title: Tunisian Grilled Peppers and Tomatoes with Couscous
description: This makes a heavenly summer meal. Reconstitute some couscous and top with this spicy, juicy mix of grilled pepper and tomato salad. You can serve the couscous warm or at room temperature. The pepper salad is typical of Tunisian grilled salads (mechwya), of which there are many versions (eggplant can be included in the mix). In Tunisia, a spice mix called tabil would be used to season the peppers. I keep the mix on hand, without the dried garlic, but here Ive given you a mix of spices to use. You can substitute tabil if you have some; the mix will be a little hotter because there is cayenne in the tabil.

title: A Hungry Little Squatter
description: FLORIDA CITY, Fla.  Deer flies swarmed around Frank Mazzotti and Joy Vinci as they stooped to get a closer look at the creature thrashing around in a metal trap they had laid off a weedy dirt road. Inside it was what some biologists consider the most troublesome invasive species in the Everglades: not a Burmese python, but a 24-inch lizard, the Argentine black and white tegu.

title: During Broadway Week, Two-for-One Deals
description: The average price of a Broadway ticket topped $100 for the first time this year, according to the Broadway League, a nonprofit industry association. Some 12.2 million theatergoers in the 2013-14 season typically paid $103.88 per seat, and many much more, an inflationary trend that NYC & Company, New Yorks tourism office, aims to relieve, at least temporarily, with Broadway Week.

title: Justices Rulings Advance Gays; Women Less So
description: WASHINGTON  When Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg reflects on the Supreme Courts recent rulings, she sees an inconsistency.

title: Photos From the Pickathon Music Festival
description: Robbie Fulks, Nickel Creek and Those Darlins were among the acts playing at the Pickathon festival in Happy Valley, Ore.

title: Border Fighting Intensifies Between ISIS and Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A deadly confrontation worsened on Monday between Lebanons armed forces and Islamist insurgents from Syria who seized the border town of Arsal over the weekend in what appeared to be the most serious spillover of the Syrian civil war into Lebanese territory since the conflict began more than three years ago.

title: Popeyes Offers Chicken With Its Own Playlist
description: Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen Inc. has introduced its latest limited-time-offer menu item, made from chicken tenderloin, with an ad campaign featuring a Spotify playlist.

title: Behind the Scenes at Marc Jacobs
description: The artisans at Marc Jacobs reveal the laborious process of making a signature handbag.

title: Alabamas Requirement for Abortion Clinic Doctors Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A federal judge on Monday rejected as unconstitutional an Alabama law requiring doctors at abortion clinics to have admitting privileges at local hospitals.

title: A Behind-the-Scenes Video Shows the Making of Marc Jacobss New It Bag
description: Though Marc Jacobs is no stranger to shock value  he posed naked for his Bang mens fragrance ad in 2010 and made Miley Cyrus the controversial face of his spring/summer 2014 campaign  his latest launch is an homage to understatement. A modern interpretation of a doctors bag with clean lines and a hand-constructed pleat detail, the Incognito is now available at Marc Jacobs stores in a range of custom colors and materials ($2,100  $38,000). Here, an exclusive video provides an up-close look at the process of constructing the bag, which is comprised of 124 different pieces, at Jacobss atelier in Milan.

title: Investigation Into Violence Toward Teenagers at Rikers Island
description: Preet Bharara, the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, released a 79-page report saying the New York City Department of Correction had systematically violated inmates civil rights.

title: Joshu Sasaki, 107, Tainted Zen Master
description: Joshu Sasaki, who died on July 27 at the age of 107, was one of the most influential and charismatic Zen masters in America, imparting a mix of paradox, personality and transcendental insight to an estimated half-million people during a 50-year career.

title: A Permanent Port of Call Tending Bar
description: NEW ORLEANS  There are as many versions of the Sazerac here as there are bars. Still, the one made by the bartender Paul Gustings stands out.

title: Japanese Music Festival to Be Renamed in Honor of Ozawa
description: The Saito Kinen Festival, which the conductor Seiji Ozawa founded in 1992, in Matsumoto, Japan, as a tribute to his teacher, Hideo Saito, will be renamed in honor of Mr. Ozawa, The Japan Times reported. At a news conference in Tokyo on Monday, the festival announced that starting in 2015, the annual summer series will be called the Seiji Ozawa Matsumoto Festival. Its principal ensemble, however, will continue as the Saito Kinen Orchestra.

title: Time Warner Rebuff of Fox May Not Just Be Negotiating Ploy
description: Rupert Murdoch tends to finish what he starts. So from the moment the news broke last month that Time Warner Inc. had rejected an $80 billion bid by Mr. Murdochs 21st Century Fox, the assumption on Wall Street and in the media world was that it was only a matter of time before a deal was struck.

title: President Obama Acknowledges Torture, Upsets Liz Cheney
description: Nothing annoys a Cheney like anyone of prominence talking about the disasters that Vice President Dick Cheney helped engineer during the last Bush administration. So it wasnt surprising that his daughter, Liz, was outraged when President Obama talked about the torture of prisoners after the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

title: You Wont Meet the Beatles in Space
description: When you think about the far future of the human race, do you dream of sailing the tropical oceans on Gliese 1214b? Walking around like Superman on Kepler 7b?

title: Death Toll Rises in Nepal Landslide as Search for Bodies Continues
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  The death toll from a major landslide near the Nepal-China border reached 33 on Monday as efforts to recover what was expected to be at least 120 more bodies continued.

title: Calm After a Banks Collapse in Portugal Could Signal Eurozone Resiliency
description: FRANKFURT  The collapse of the Portuguese bank seemed to have all the makings of a disaster. With little warning, a government in one of Europes most financially weak countries was suddenly confronted with a multibillion-euro rescue of Banco Esprito Santo. And the crisis hit during a period of acute uncertainty in Europe brought on by fighting in Ukraine.

title: Photos From the Pickathon Music Festival
description: Robbie Fulks, Nickel Creek and Those Darlins were among the acts playing at the Pickathon festival in Happy Valley, Ore.

title: Monday Motorsports: Earnhardt Sweeps Pocono
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr., enjoying his most productive season in a decade, won the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday at Pocono Raceway in Pennsylvania. Earnhardt, in scoring his third victory this season, got the best of the runner-up Kevin Harvick on a restart, with three laps to go in the 160-lap contest. Harvick had battled back from a midrace stop-and-go penalty for speeding on the pit road that placed him near the rear of the field.

title: Sake With Your Burger? Japan Is Looking West to Save a Tradition
description: LONDON  Kensuke Shichida, the head of a centuries-old sake brewery in southern Japan, had spent a dizzying week in London restaurants tasting a variety of exotic and confounding dishes: pub food, gourmet burgers, French food, Angus beef, ceviche.

title: Maker of Penfolds Wine May End Resistance to K.K.R. Buyout
description: Treasury Wine Estates has decided that a grape is worth more in the bottle than on the vine.

title: Protesters in Sri Lanka Disrupt Meeting on Civil War Missing
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Protesters allied with the Sri Lankan government prevented American and European diplomats from leaving a meeting of families of missing people for nearly two hours on Monday.

title: The Dog Who Had His Day on Film
description: Running 130 otherwise perfect minutes, Sidney Lumets Dog Day Afternoon was punctuated by only two inauthentic moments as a feature film. One was invisible, and the other was barely audible.

title: Music Festival From Beijing to Make American Debut in New York
description: The Modern Sky Festival, a music festival with indie leanings that was established in Beijing in 2007, plans to make its American debut in October when it presents two days of concerts at the Rumsey Playfield in Central Park, the organizers announced on Monday.

title: Taking a Bullet, Gaining a Cause: James S. Brady Dies at 73
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was wounded in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan and then became a symbol of the fight for gun control, championing tighter regulations from his wheelchair, died on Monday in Alexandria, Va. He was 73.

title: How Wikipedia Could Improve Your Internet Surfing
description: For years, critics have feared that the Internet will kill interestingness, offering us only what were looking for with none of the happy accidents that can spur creative thought. Might a solution to this problem come from the kind of browsing we do on Wikipedia?

title: Whos Moving In Now?
description: Are we really seeing a return to The Waltons? Family members sharing the old farmhouse, with Grandma and Grandpa helping to raise the young uns and then, when they get too frail to bake pies or go fishing, being cared for by their adult children?

title: Jason Dufner Finds a Voice, if Not His Putting Stroke
description: AKRON, Ohio  Enlisted to make a celebrity appearance during a gala charity announcement on the eve of last weeks Bridgestone Invitational, Jason Dufner appeared to have put the most trying part behind him when he stepped away from the microphone after delivering a brief speech.

title: Working in the Medium of Science
description: Scientists are logical, making observations and running experiments, then building theories that explain the data. Artists are emotional, working in solitude and by intuition. Or so we are told.

title: $320 Million Facility to Stoke Chinas Musical Theater Industry
description: With musical theater markets growing robustly in South Korea, Japan and Australia, China is taking a step toward increasing its relatively modest role in the industry by building a major new musical production center outside Beijing, according to the China Daily website.

title: Early Nick Drake Recording Pulled From Auction
description: An early demo tape by the singer-songwriter Nick Drake, which was to have been auctioned this week in London, may make its way to court before it gets near an auctioneers gavel. The tape, a demo probably recorded in 1968, before Drake beganwork on his debut album, Five Leaves Left, has been in the possession of the British folksinger Beverley Martyn, a close friend of Drakes, since shortly after Drakes death from an overdose of antidepressant medicine in 1974, when he was 26. Martyn had consigned the tape this spring to Ted Owen & Company, a London auction house, saying that she was selling it because she was in poor health and needed the money.

title: Walkabout: C.D.C. Issues Ebola Travel Guidelines
description: Agency Issues Ebola WarningsThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines to airlines in response to the Ebola outbreak that has killed more than 800 people in western Africa. People exposed to the disease are asked not to travel for 21 days, and the C.D.C. suggests that airlines consider using their legal authority to deny boarding to sick passengers suspected of carrying the virus. The C.D.C. has also advised Americans to avoid nonessential travel to Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, the three countries most affected by the outbreak. (The New York Times)

title: Judge Awards $24.6 Million to Former Rauschenberg Trustees
description: The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation said Monday it was considering its legal options after a judge in Florida awarded $24.6 million to three trustees who had administered the late artists estate.

title: Challengers From the Right Struggle in G.O.P. Senate Primaries in 2 States
description: WASHINGTON  Like most incumbent Republican senators this year who are facing a primary challenge from the right, Pat Roberts of Kansas refused a one-on-one debate against his hard-line opponent.

title: Lollapalooza Festival Fashion
description: Here are some looks that stood out from the crowd in Chicago.

title: U.S. to Shut 3 Interim Shelters Housing Immigrant Children
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government is shutting down three temporary shelters that had been opened to house a surge of unaccompanied children from Central America entering the United States across the southern border, officials said Monday afternoon.

title: Reactions on Twitter to James S. Bradys Death
description: Users of social media platforms like Twitter quickly shared remarks about the life of James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was shot in the head in 1981 during an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan.

title: Iraq Agrees to Help Kurds Battle Sunni Extremists
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Monday ordered Iraqs air force to support Kurdish forces fighting Sunni extremists in the north, a move that represented a thaw, out of military necessity, in the fraught relations between the central government and Kurdish leaders.

title: 1964: Attack in the Gulf of Tonkin
description: WASHINGTON  North Vietnamese PT boats tonight [Aug. 4] made a deliberate attack on the U.S. destroyers Maddox and C. Turner Joy in the Gulf of Tonkin and two Communist vessels were believed sunk, the Defense Department announced. The department said the attack, involving six to ten PT boats, took place in the same general area where the Maddoxs guns drove off an attack on Sunday. The announcement of the new attack was made shortly after President Johnson had summoned congressional leaders to the White House to brief them on the turn of events in Southeast Asia.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 5, 1964

title: Weekly News Quiz | July 22-Aug. 4
description: Because we were on hiatus last week, the quiz below covers two weeks of news. How many of these stories have you followed?

title: A Global Trip to Find Himself Led Back Home
description: IM 59 years old, and at one point in my life it would be nothing for me to be in six different cities over the course of a week. Im very active, but I dont miss those kinds of trips. Two or three times a month is fine with me. Im president and chief executive of my familys owned and operated grocery stores, Stew Leonards, so I go to a lot of trade shows and have to visit a lot of suppliers.

title: Israel Suspends Attack in Parts of Gaza
description: Minutes after a partial cease-fire was to begin, the Israeli air force struck a refugee camp in Gaza City, killing an 8-year-old and wounding at least 29 others.

title: Betty Fussell: Still Blazing Trails
description: I walked the druid path through an oak grove to the Casa Dorinda, a retirement community in Montecito, Calif., where Julia Child spent her final days. I could have driven the main road like everyone else. But those werent the directions that Betty had given me.

title: Caught in Indecision, Bulgarian Government Is Urged to Solve Banking Crisis
description: Pressure is building on Bulgaria to deal with its worst banking crisis since the 1990s as the European Union and international investors have issued warnings about the fate of one of the countrys largest banks.

title: David Wilson to Leave Football and Retire From Giants at 23
description: During his rookie season in 2012, Giants running back David Wilson delighted fans and irked opponents by performing a back flip in the end zone after scoring, stealing a page from the showmanship playbook of the Hall of Fame shortstop Ozzie Smith.

title: In Libya, Parliament Convenes Amid Battles
description: CAIRO  Libyan leaders, struggling to keep their country from spinning further out of control, convened a newly elected Parliament for its first session on Monday.

title: A Nose for Their Favorite Foods
description: Q. Dogs have such exquisite olfactory abilities; do they also possess a superior ability to taste things?

title: Washington Meeting of African Leaders Opens to Protests
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of protesters gathered outside the State Department on Monday, the start of a summit meeting here of more than 40 African heads of state, to denounce some of the leaders as torturers and killers.

title: Exclusive Google Camp Draws Elite to Sicilian Resort
description: Googles latest innovation is not computerized eyeglasses or self-driving cars. Its major selling points are the more old-fashioned pleasures of sand, sun and schmoozing.

title: White House Spokesman on James Brady
description: The White House press secretary, Josh Earnest, reflected on the death of an earlier press secretary, James Brady, during the daily press briefing.

title: Americans Are Bad at Math, but Its Not Too Late to Fix
description: When I lived in Las Vegas, there were billboards everywhere advertising different casinos. One of the most common was the type that promised 98 percent payouts. I remember thinking how amazing that was. After all, 98 is a lot of percents! It seemed like a really good deal  until I thought about it for a minute.

title: Penguins That Get Their Point Across
description: Adult African penguins use four vocal cries, and babies only two, according to a study in PLOS One. Adults have a combat call, a contact call if lost, a come-hither song and a love song for birds paired in the nest. Both baby calls are pleas for food: one a peep, the other a moan.

title: A Look at How We Process Painful Experiences
description: A tiny part of the brain keeps track of painful experiences and helps determine how we will react to them in the future, scientists say. The findings could be a boon to depression treatments.

title: A Key Malaria Drug Becomes Less Effective
description: The parasite that causes the most deadly form of malaria is becoming more resistant to the most effective drug used to treat it, scientists in Southeast Asia are reporting.

title: Chegg Finds Partner to Handle Its Textbooks
description: For years, Chegg worked to become one of the biggest players in the business of renting textbooks to students. But since going public late last year, the company has suffered from a big investor concern: that its signature business was becoming obsolete.

title: Xiaomi Tops Chinese Smartphone Market
description: Just last year, Xiaomi was a relatively obscure Chinese handset maker. But last quarter, Xiaomi was the top smartphone seller in the largest handset market in the world: China.

title: Patients Symptoms Raise Concern About Ebola in New York
description: Heightened concern about the Ebola virus has led to alarms being raised at three hospitals in New York City. But so far, no Ebola cases have turned up.

title: Rules for the Marijuana Market
description: As voters and lawmakers in more states decide to legalize marijuana, policy makers will have to answer a fresh and difficult question: How should governments regulate the production and sale of the drug?

title: One-Two Punch in the Bullpen Takes Some Knocks
description: Jenrry Mejia held his palms to the sky and then put his hands on his hips as the gravity of the moment sank in. The first two outs of the ninth had come so easily, and now slowly, methodically, the San Francisco Giants had ground their way back.

title: U.S.-Africa Summit Reading List
description: As President Obama hosts a gathering of more than 40 African leaders in Washington, explore the forces that are reshaping the African continent.

title: An End to Free Rides Through Speedier PreCheck Security
description: IF youve grown accustomed to being waved through the PreCheck security lanes at the airport without having paid to enroll in the popular program, time is running out. The program has been so successful that the agency is planning to limit it soon to those who enroll  and pay up.

title: Comet Siding Spring
description: Comet Siding Spring will sweep past Mars in October, then follow other recent comets around the sun and back into deep space.

title: Off the Web and Into TriBeCa
description: OF ALL THE MANY pockets of fresh new money in New York, TriBeCa must be the freshest, the cleanest, the most insulated from the worlds horrors  even those enshrined in immediate proximity. Its a microclimate, said an esteemed author I met at the still-chugging Odeon the other night, feeling very Bright Lights, Big City (though we were not sneaking off to do lines of blow in the bathroom but nursing tame little glasses of sauvignon blanc at our table).

title: A Celestial Traveler Closes on Mars
description: One day early last year, the Australian comet hunter Robert H. McNaught spotted something unusual from his post at the Siding Spring Observatory in the foothills of the Warrumbungle Mountains.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: In Performance | Coln and Henderson
description: Rosal Coln and Stephen McKinley Henderson in a scene from Stephen Adly Guirgiss new play Between Riverside and Crazy, about a retired policeman. The show is at the Linda Gross Theater.

title: What Lykke Li, Andr Benjamin, Blood Orange and Other Stars Were Wearing at Lollapalooza
description: This year, the blissful Chicago summer turned nasty during Lollapalooza. The music festival, which celebrated its 10th year in Grant Park, saw plenty of rain and mud  conditions that have become as much a part of the festivals tradition as shirtless frat boys and the sight of its its wiry founder, the Janes Addiction frontman Perry Farrell, roaming the premises. Still, the 300,000 revelers (including Malia Obama) who turned out didnt seem to mind. They roared their approval for young stars like Lykke Li and the Chicago native Chance the Rapper (This is the coolest show Ive ever done, he told the Sunday-night crowd), and turned out in full voice for elder statesmen like Eminem and OutKast. The photographer Andres Gonzalez braved the inclement conditions  and the mosh pits  to capture it all.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, China and Germany.

title: Gerald Albright and Karen Mantler Release Albums

Sequestered, which begins on Tuesday on the digital service Crackle, is a refreshing change. It, too, is pretty good, but in an easy-to-digest way.

Ford Amphitheater here  certain artists return each year to the Vail International Dance Festival. title: Stereotypes Behind the Mask

His messy set of songs established how sharp-edged satire about race (among other topics) could be at once witty and warmhearted, expressing confusion with ease. Then came the difficult part, the dance half of the evening: Mr. TOL E. RAncE by the choreographer Camille A. Brown.

title: Buzzing Mars, Darwins New Finch, Tegu Takes Florida

A moment later the result was visible: a 6-foot-by-3-foot image, resembling a detailed woodcut, that featured a pair of wings surrounded by roses.

She also has a role in the Top Five, a film by Chris Rock set to play at the Toronto Film Festival in September. Born in Omaha, Ms. Union splits her time between Los Angeles and Miami, where she shares a home with her fianc Dwyane Wade, who plays for the Miami Heat of the National Basketball Association. Here, she discusses her beauty routine.

title: A New Explanation for New Man
description: A discovery in a cave on the Indonesian island of Flores, reported 10 years ago, moved one scientist to hail it as the most important find in human evolution for 100 years. The fragmentary bones, but only one full skull, of several individuals led the discoverers to conclude that these were remains of a previously unknown extinct species of humans.

Graham announced a year ago that he was selling The Washington Post to Jeff Bezos for $250 million, it was unclear what Mr. Graham, one of journalisms most revered executives, would do next. The Post had been a Graham family jewel for 80 years and a giant in the field of journalism; but in a deal forged quickly last summer, it was suddenly under someone elses control.
