description: MOSCOW  Russia retaliated on Thursday for Western sanctions against Moscow, announcing that it was banning imports of a wide range of food and agricultural products from Europe and the United States, among others. The move raised the level of confrontation over Ukraine with measures that seemed likely to affect Russian consumers at least as much as European farming.

title: Morning Views
description: In the first good news in a long time, a 72-hour cease-fire appeared to be holding on Wednesday as Israelis and Palestinians tallied what was lost, and gained, during the latest war over the desperate Gaza Strip, states an editorial in The New York Times. Both sides are claiming victory  Israel for wiping out 32 underground tunnels and Hamas for still being alive  but the result is a more entrenched status quo: Neither side has achieved its main goal of destroying the other. The possibility of a peace plan appears ever more remote: There seems to be little room left in Israeli politics for those who would end the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza and create an independent Palestinian state. The editorial adds, it is so important that indirect talks between Israelis and Palestinians this week, mediated by Egypt, lay the ground for something bigger and more durable than one cease-fire.

title: China Lighthouse Plan Likely to Raise Tensions in Disputed Sea
description: China is planning to build lighthouses on five islands in the South China Sea, the official China News Agency reported on Thursday, in what would be Beijings latest rebuttal of criticisms of its construction projects in the disputed waters.

title: Snowden Said to Be Allowed 3 More Years in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Edward J. Snowden, the American intelligence contractor who divulged a raft of secret documents and then fled to Russia, has been granted a three-year residence permit here, his lawyer announced Thursday.

title: Daily Report: To Compete Against Amazon, Google and Barnes & Noble Team Up
description: Google and Barnes & Noble are joining forces to tackle their mutual rival Amazon, zeroing in on a service that Amazon has long dominated: the fast, cheap delivery of books, Alexandra Alter reports.

title: Mary Pilon, Whats in Your Bag?
description: Oh, no. Youre a reporter on assignment and youre riffling through your carryall. You think youve left something behind. Whether you find it or not can make or break your day. We asked several reporters what they need to do their jobs when they leave home or office. Well share their answers over the next few weeks.

title: Letting Someone Go With Dignity
description: Obviously, its no fun to get fired. But its also no fun to be the one doing the firing.

title: In Fight With Hackers, We Are on Our Own
description: Call it the hack whipsaw.

title: Ukrainian Armys Artillery Hits Hospital, Killing Dental Patient
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  An artillery barrage on Thursday that was apparently aimed at a rebel headquarters here smashed into the dental wing of a nearby hospital instead, killing at least one patient and wounding several others.

title: Test Yourself | Comic-Con 2014
description: Below are the first seven paragraphs of the article, Rule Followers Flock to a Convention Where Fake Violence Reigns.

title: Larry David Will Make Broadway Debut in His First Play
description: The comedian and actor Larry David, the star of HBOs Curb Your Enthusiasm and the Emmy Award-winning co-creator and head writer of Seinfeld, will make his Broadway debut this winter in his first play Fish in the Dark.

title: How Obama Can Stop Corporate Expatriations, for Now
description: The Obama administration has broad legal authority to stop corporate inversions.

title: E.C.B. Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged, Despite Geopolitical Risks
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank said on Thursday that the Ukraine crisis posed a risk to the eurozone economy, but that the impact was not yet severe enough to warrant a shift in monetary policy.

title: G.O.P. Senator and 3 Justices Prevail in Tennessee Election
description: NASHVILLE  Tennessee voters backed Senator Lamar Alexander against a Tea Party challenge and turned down an aggressive bid by conservatives and business interests to oust three members of the State Supreme Court in primaries on Thursday.

title: Rio Tinto Profit Doubles, Helped by Aluminum and Copper
description: LONDON  Rio Tinto, the London-based mining giant, said on Thursday that its first-half profit more than doubled to $4.4 billion as the company shrugged off a sharp drop in iron ore prices, and reported improvements in its smaller aluminum and copper mining businesses.

title: No Leeches, No Rusty Saw, But Hell Nonetheless
description: In 1900, Freud published The Interpretation of Dreams, Ferdinand von Zeppelins airship took its first flight, and Max Planck formulated quantum theory.

title: Londons Master of Stage Spectacle
description: LONDON  Patrick Bateman has been haunting the theater director Rupert Goold lately. And its not just the ax, chain saw, and nail gun that Bateman uses on flashy A-listers  people not unlike Mr. Goold  in American Psycho, Bret Easton Elliss satire of Manhattan yuppies in the go-go 1980s.

title: Only 9 Chinese Cities Pass Clean Air Test
description: If you are looking for a Chinese city with clean air, your best bets would be Shenzhen, Zhuhai, Zhoushan, Zhanjiang, Yunfu, Beihai, Haikou, Sanya or Lhasa, according to the Ministry of Environmental Protection.

title: Prominent Rights Lawyer Is Freed From Chinese Prison, His Relatives Say
description: HONG KONG  One of Chinas most famous dissident lawyers, Gao Zhisheng, was released from prison on Thursday, his wife and brother said. But it remained unclear how much freedom Mr. Gao would enjoy and whether he would be able to reunite with his exiled wife and children eight years after he disappeared into a shroud of repeated detention and, he has said, torture.

title: Morning Agenda: Bank of Americas Big Mortgage Settlement
description: BANK OF AMERICA NEARS DEAL WITH JUSTICE DEPT. | After months of talks, Bank of America suddenly caved in to the government, agreeing to the largest single federal settlement in the history of corporate America, DealBooks Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write. The tentative deal  which would cost the bank more than $16 billion to settle investigations into its sale of toxic mortgage securities in the run-up to the financial crisis  came together last week after an unexpected ruling in another Bank of America case that undercut the banks negotiating leverage.

title: Throwback Thursday | Philippe Petit Walks Tightrope Between the Twin Towers
description: On Aug. 7, 1974, Philippe Petit, the French-born high-wire artist and street performer, walked a tightrope strung between the World Trade Center towers. After perhaps 45 minutes of knee bends and other stunts, Phillippe Petit, balancing pole in hand, turned himself over to waiting policemen, The Times reported.

title: Winners and Losers of New N.C.A.A. Model
description: New N.C.A.A. rules could widen the gap between the haves and have-nots in college sports.

title: Yellens Remarks Not Expected to Dent Allure of Biotech Companies
description: The new head of the Federal Reserve, Janet Yellen, does more than supervise banks and set monetary policy. She gives stock tips.

title: Israels Fair-Weather Fans
description: TEL AVIV  The Israeli song Ein Li Eretz Acheret is a curious tune. I have no other country, go the lyrics, even if my land is on fire.

title: A New Era in British Fashion
description: Theres a new regime in British fashion, and it could have far-reaching implications for the future because it involves the people who will shape it.

title: An Insiders Perspective on Corinne Days Posthumously Published Book of Photographs
description: Throughout her career, and especially during the 1990s, the photographer Corinne Day often escaped the fashion scene in which she had forged her reputation with a controversial Kate Moss shoot and other projects for glossies like Vogue. Instead, she documented her friends: models, stylists and musicians caught in a drug- and sex-addled haze. Day, a relentless diarist who died in 2010 at age 48, was unapologetic in her gaze. A portion of her 90s-era snapshots appeared in Diary (2000), a stark, dark book that helped cement her position in the mainstream fashion industry as a grunge-era pioneer. Now, more than 150 additional images have been carefully documented in May the Circle Remain Unbroken, a photo book from the British publisher Mrel (the first since Days death in 2010).

title: Simple Solutions for Back-to-School Student Organization (Sorry, No Trapper Keeper)
description: While updating my calendar today, I realized that my older son returns to school in less than a week. The end of summer always takes me by surprise, but it has been particularly swift and stealthy in its approach this year. Just as I was wrapping my head around the hideous reality of back-to-school shopping, I spotted a sweet tweet that made me yearn for my long-lost adolescence:

title: Mockingbird Interrupts Second Avenue Bar Scene
description: Dear Diary:

title: 21 Guilty in Mine Shaft Murders Echoing Chinese Film
description: Twenty-one people have been convicted by a court in Hebei Province in connection with the murder of four miners in a scam to collect compensation money.

title: A U.S. Journalists Arrest Points to a Power Struggle in the Leadership of Iran
description: TEHRAN  Jason Rezaian knew he was being watched. A man on a motorcycle had been following him and his wife for weeks, his colleagues said. The tail was so blatant that Mr. Rezaian, The Washington Posts correspondent in Tehran, had even managed to take a picture of the license plate.

title: K.K.R., Blackstone and TPG Private Equity Firms Agree to Settle Lawsuit on Collusion
description: Updated, 8:05 p.m. | Three of the leading private equity firms on Wall Street have agreed to pay a combined $325 million to settle accusations that they colluded with one another to drive down the prices of corporate takeover targets, according to a court filing on Thursday.

title: Kerry Visits Afghanistan to Urge Deal on the Election
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Secretary of State John Kerry made an unannounced visit here on Thursday to press Afghanistans rival presidential candidates to form a government of national unity and rescue the political agreement he negotiated almost four weeks ago.

title: When a Meeting Runs Off the Road
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Garrison Keillor: By the Book
description: The host of A Prairie Home Companion and the author, most recently, of The Keillor Reader collects hymnals, phrase books and tales of heroic collies. And Im a connoisseur of bad poetry of the elegiac variety.

title: Andreessen Horowitz Invests in Big Data Analytics Firm Adatao
description: For years, the concept of big data has promised companies all manner of insights about their businesses. Now, one Silicon Valley start-up is trying to make that data easier to use.

title: 1889: Hereditary Imagination
description: PARIS  The story of Victor Hugos grandsons escape from shipwreck going round the Paris press was made out by the young gentleman to be rather more dramatic than it was in reality. M. George Hugo was a guest on board the 80-ton yawl Gilda, which left Havre last Monday to make a run to Trouville. The tide carried the yacht on to the Banc du Ratier. At low water the Gilda was left high and dry, but floated again on the return tide. In the meantime she had sprung a leak; she managed, however, with the help of a tug and under trysail, to return to harbor, when she sank in shallow water. Later she was floated into dry dock. M. George Hugo imagined it was necessary to wire to his friends that the Gilda had sunk and no lives lost.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 8, 1889

title: Lawyers on Khmer Rouge Sentencing
description: Nicholas Koumjian, a prosecutor, and Victor Koppe, a defense lawyer for two former Khmer Rouge leaders, discussed the sentences delivered in a Cambodian court room.

title: A Manhattan Apartment for Sisters
description: For the first three years of her residency at Jacobi Medical Center, Taiwo Odufunade had her own one-bedroom apartment in the Bronx, and a 25-minute walk to work.

title: Life and Loves of a Brooklyn Bank Robber
description: It turns out that the true story bit about Dog Day Afternoon was, well, pretty true. Thats one of the jaw droppers in The Dog, an absorbing, rollicking documentary about John Wojtowicz, whos best known as the guy Al Pacino performed, with heart, soul and a river of flop sweat, in Dog Day Afternoon. In Sidney Lumets magnificently squalid 1975 classic, Mr. Pacino plays Sonny Wortzik, whose new career as Clyde Barrow goes south as soon as he pulls out a gun in a Brooklyn bank. Thwarted by bad planning and legions of cops, Sonny eventually ends up in cuffs. The same pretty much happened to Mr. Wojtowicz, except that he was immortalized in a Hollywood masterwork.

title: Wooing Hispanic Voters at Home, Republicans Turn to Latin America
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will journey to Mexico next month to meet with the countrys new president, court its corporate titans and mingle with its cultural leaders.

title: Cyanobacteria Are Far From Just Toledos Problem
description: Over the weekend, an entire city was brought to its knees by pond scum.

title: Today in Small Business: Legal Sea Foods Is Not a Chain!
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Musicians Who Are Bigheaded but Only When Onstage
description: Who was that masked band? Other artists who have preferred to keep their faces covered:

title: Self-Invention in a Papier-Mch Head
description: We have grown used to verisimilitude in our musician biopics. The Buddy Holly Story, Walk the Line and Ray, and even those that seem a little campy today, like Oliver Stones The Doors, follow the rules: The wigs cant be too terrible, and the facts need to be intact. The recent James Brown biopic, Get On Up, is similarly straightforward. Even 24 Hour Party People playfully broke the fourth wall but treated the life and death of its most famous figure, Ian Curtis, faithfully. But what if the musician at the heart of the story was a man who wore a giant puppet head in public?

title: No Comment Necessary: Blaming the Ebola Victim
description: Ann Coulter, the conservative firebrand, expressed little sympathy for the American doctor, Kent Brantley, who contracted Ebola in Liberia and was transported back to the United States on Saturday for treatment.

title: Snowdens Lawyer on Residence Status
description: Anatoly G. Kucherena, the lawyer for the former American intelligence contractor Edward Snowden, said Russia has granted his client a three-year residence permit.

title: Publisher of American Banker Is Sold to an Investment Firm
description: The owner of SourceMedia, the publisher of financial trade publications like American Banker and The Bond Buyer, said that it had sold the media company to Observer Capital, an investment firm.

title: Introducing Frank Bruni and Ross Douthat as the Moviegoers
description: Welcome to The Moviegoers, an occasional new series in which the Op-Ed columnists Frank Bruni and Ross Douthat banter about movies, pop culture, television and other real-world distractions. From 1993-95, Frankwas a movie critic for The Detroit Free Press, and he has written frequently on culture for The New York Times Magazine and for the Arts & Leisure section. Rossis the film critic for National Review and frequently writes about film and TV on his Times blog.

title: Books for the Road
description: Patti Smith, who reviews Haruki Murakamis Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage this week, first discovered the Japanese authors work while browsing in the East Village. Attracted by the title, I picked up A Wild Sheep Chase about five years ago in St. Marks Bookshop, Smith said in a recent email interview. She quickly read that novel and Dance Dance Dance, and was hooked. I love how he weaves the interdimensional and the mundane and the offhanded way certain characters negotiate these shifts, Smith said. I love that there are sequels and reoccurring characters. Like Roberto Bolao, he offers an ever-expanding, interconnected universe.

title: Wedding Q. & A.
description: A Less Hurtful Exclusion

title: After a War, Life on the Mississippi
description: A Marine veteran took a canoe on the Mississippi in an effort to deal with post-traumatic stress disorder.

title: Some Flexibility If Hawaiian Hurricanes Affect Travel Plans
description: With two hurricanes expected to hit the Hawaiian islands beginning Thursday night, several airlines and some hotel chains have offered to waive change fees for customers with reservations for travel in the next few days.

title: Obama Allows Limited Airstrikes on ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday announced he had authorized limited airstrikes against Islamic militants in Iraq, scrambling to avert the fall of the Kurdish capital, Erbil, and returning the United States to a significant battlefield role in Iraq for the first time since the last American soldier left the country at the end of 2011.

title: Ocean Liners Set Records, 6 Years Into the Jet Age
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. 9,270 Will Sail for Europe Tomorrow on 10 Ships appeared on Aug. 7 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: Recalling the Crash, the Icelandic Way
description: The global financial crisis of 2008 spread its pain far and wide, but it delivered a particularly stinging wallop to the tiny island country of Iceland, where a speculative banking bubble in the 2000s lent its people an unsustainable prosperity before bursting with gale-force shock. You can read the financial pages to chart the countrys recovery since, or you can head to the Minetta Lane Theater in Greenwich Village, where a troupe of Icelanders has been hunkered down since mid-June, making an odd new rock musical with an American cast and a British choreographer.

title: Bloomberg Lays Off 25 and Cancels a TV Show
description: Bloomberg Media canceled its Washington-based talk show Political Capital With Al Hunt and laid off about 25 employees, mostly in its television operations, as part of a broader effort to restructure the company and its news offerings, according to two staff members with knowledge of the moves.

title: If We Link Boys With Bedlam, What Does That Say to Our Girls?
description: We are in London when my 6-year-old starts to climb the walls. Yes, he and his 3-year-old brother have been cooped up in trains a lot in the last 10 days  from Paris to Brussels to the North Sea to London  but theres also something about the Victorian molding in my friends terraced home that looks enough like the parkour course at his school to encourage him to make the attempt.

title: Hawaii Prepares for First Hurricane in 22 Years
description: HONOLULU  Hawaii is no stranger to natural disasters. The state has endured tsunamis. Lava flows almost constantly from its volcanoes. An earthquake shook the Big Island on Thursday morning.

title: Both Sides in Gay Marriage Fight in Utah Agree: Supreme Court Should Hear Case
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for three couples challenging Utahs ban on same-sex marriage said Thursday that they would join with their opponents to urge the Supreme Court to hear their case, even though they recently won an appeals court ruling striking down the law.

title: Gray Tassels Along the Fringe
description: FOR the past couple of summers, Joan Shepard has packed up her cabaret show and headed for Scotland to perform at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. This summer, shes working much closer to her East Village home.

title: County of 95 Sees Opportunity in Toxic Waste
description: MENTONE, Tex.  Loving County is big, dry and stretches for miles, and is the perfect place, local officials say, to store high-level radioactive waste.

title: We Welcome Nuclear Waste
description: Some people in Loving County, Tex., the second-least-populous county in the United States, think that storing the entire countrys nuclear waste would be a good thing for their community.

title: Celebrity Magazine Sales Plummet on Newsstands
description: Celebrity magazines used to be the impulse purchase at the airport or the supermarket checkout line. But those impulses are apparently being resisted.

title: Museum Under Fire for Selling Its Art
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  If the Delaware Art Museum has a signature painting, surely it is Howard Pyles Marooned. A native of this city, Pyle is justly remembered as the father of American illustration. His Marooned (1909) is an image of genuine drama and distress. It shows a pirate near death, curled up on a sand bar, a tiny figure enveloped by a burning yellow sky.

title: Take the Job Seriously, but Not Yourself
description: This interview with Logan LaHive, chief executive of Belly, a customer rewards company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Berghain, Berlins Legendary Nightclub, Celebrates Its 10th Anniversary With an Art Show
description: With its 10th anniversary approaching in December, the Berghain  Berlins most famous electronic music institution  is kicking things off tonight with a fine art prelude to a series of upcoming house- and techno-fueled celebrations. Titled simply 10, the show takes place at the Halle, a vast section of the converted neoclassical power plant just beyond the dance floor that is open only on special occasions. Each work in 10 interprets the trinity of music, clubbing and debauchery in relation to Berghains potent architecture.

title: 1939: Albanian Royals at Versailles
description: King Zog, exiled monarch of Albania, now an Italian principality, and Queen Geraldine were expected to take up residence in Versailles today, coming from Antwerp, where they arrived yesterday from Oslo aboard the steamer Brabant. With them were the infant Prince Alexander, Princesses Myzein, Ruheje and Maxhide, sisters of King Zog, and a royal entourage of a score who will take up residence with the King and Queen. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 8, 1939

title: N.C.A.A. Votes to Give Richest Conferences More Autonomy
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The first step toward an aristocracy in college sports was codified Thursday, when the five richest conferences and their 65 universities were awarded the right by the Division I board of directors to make their own rules on several issues affecting athletes and competition.

title: Combining Culture and Exercise: The First Elastic City Walks Festival
description: Music and dance festivals are so last month. Next month New York will have what organizers are calling a participatory walks festival. Elastic City an organization that since 2010 has engaged artists in various disciplines to lead walks that are less about sightseeing than about finding fresh ways to think about a citys history, architecture and traditions, is presenting its first Elastic City Walks Festival, from Sept. 26 to Oct. 7.

title: Robert H. Ellsworth Is Dead at 85 After a Life Devoted to Chinese Art
description: Robert H. Ellsworth, a prominent dealer of modern Chinese painting, Ming dynasty furniture, archaic jade and other examples of Asian art who helped amplify many of the major Asian collections in the United States, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: The Pain and Pleasure of Falling in Love
description: The chicken wing was juicy and laced with an invisible layer of tempestuous spices, and the moment I bit into it, I turned into Nicolas Cage in Moonstruck. Words welled up inside. I needed to tell that chicken wing how I felt: Im in love with you. At that instant, the spices reared back and smacked me across the lips. Delicious agony began to spread to the rest of my mouth. Sips of cold beer did nothing to diminish the impact. Hours later, I could still feel the sting.

title: Wine Dealer Sentenced to 10 Years for Defrauding Clients
description: A well-known wine dealer was sentenced on Thursday to 10 years in prison for defrauding wealthy clients out of millions of dollars by selling bottles of purportedly rare wines that were actually old bottles of wine mixed together.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The One I Love
description: The director Charlie McDowell narrates a sequence from The One I Love, featuring Elisabeth Moss and Mark Duplass.

title: Charlie McDowell Narrates a Scene From The One I Love
description: Things arent quite as they seem with a couple in The One I Love, Charlie McDowells romantic comedy with a twist. In this video, the writer and director discusses a scene between the films two main characters, Ethan (Mark Duplass) and Sophie (Elisabeth Moss). The One I Love is currently available on demand and opens in theaters August 22.

title: Wheelies: The Million Franc Delahaye Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: China Moves to Rein In Messaging for Mobile
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities imposed new restrictions on the countrys most popular mobile instant messaging services on Thursday, including rules meant to curb the sharing of unauthorized political news and information.

title: 2 New Interns at City Hall: Teenagers Named de Blasio
description: New Yorks first daughter and son  Chiara and Dante de Blasio  are spending the rest of the summer at City Hall as unpaid interns.

title: IBM Develops a New Chip That Functions Like a Brain
description: Inspired by the architecture of the brain, scientists have developed a new kind of computer chip that uses no more power than a hearing aid and may eventually excel at calculations that stump todays supercomputers.

title: Yes, Alaska Is Hard to Poll. So Is Everywhere Else.
description: Alaska is notorious for being difficult to poll. Its a common refrain, common enough that you could be forgiven for not stopping to wonder why.

title: Domestic Surveillance Has a Fan
description: Judge John D. Bates, who has appointed himself as a spokesman for the entire judiciary from his sinecure as secretary of the Judicial Conference, has sent a third letter to Congress denouncing its attempts to reform the domestic surveillance law.

title: Screen Voices, Banished but Not Silenced
description: The close-up, the big screen, the eternal klieg light of unending media coverage: Motion pictures, especially those made in Hollywood, are a technology of magnification. How else to explain that the tale of the 300 or so movie studio employees whose political associations cost them their jobs has come to dramatize the repressive hysteria of the McCarthy era?

title: Recording the Not-So-Dolce Vita
description: The prolific screenwriter and sometime filmmaker Cesare Zavattini (1902-89) was the chief theoretician of Italian neorealism. Zavattini, who once proposed a two-hour feature dramatizing the purchase of a pair of shoes, was also a pioneer of documentary fiction (sometimes called hybrid cinema), in which nonactors essentially play themselves, dramatizing their particular situations.

title: Russia and E.U. on Food Sanctions
description: Dmitri A. Medvedev, the Russian prime minister, and Frdric Vincent, a spokesman for the European Commission, discussed Russias ban on food imports from the United States and other countries.

title: How New N.C.A.A. Rules Will Work
description: To the typical fan, college sports will look much the same. The football field will still be 100 yards and a 3-pointer will still be worth, well, 3 points.

title: Keep It Healthy by Warpaint
description: A single from the all-girl band.

title: Fun Home Will Reach Broadway Just Before Tonys Deadline
description: The new musical Fun Home, which had a critically acclaimed run last fall at the Public Theater, will move to Broadway this spring, the producers announced on Thursday. The show, about a young woman awakening to her sexuality and to her fathers secrets, is scheduled to begin preview performances on April 4 at Circle in the Square Theater and hold its opening night on April 22. The deadline for potential Tony Award nominees is typically at the end of April.

title: Owner of Lingerie Chain Agent Provocateur Said to Hire Goldman to Run a Sale
description: Over two decades, Agent Provocateur has become one of the best-known purveyors of high-end lingerie, thanks in part to notoriously risqu advertising. Now the retailer may sell something even pricier: itself.

title: Phong Bui Curates Bloodflames Revisited
description: BLOODFLAMES REVISITED

title: Two Girls Fuel Their Teams Push Toward Little Leagues Pinnacle
description: BRISTOL, Conn.  As the only girl in New Jersey Little League all-star baseball, Kayla Roncin is used to attention.

title: When the President Does It, That Means
description: Im grateful to Greg Sargent for conducting this probing interview with John Sandweg, who served as a Department of Homeland Security counsel during the crafting of the Obama administrations 2012 deferred action program for illegal immigrants who arrived in the United States as minors. Here is Sandweg explaining the legal justification for that program, and (by extension) for the course the White House is currently considering, which could extend the same provisional legalization to up to half the illegal-alien population:

title: Westwood, Despite Troubles, Shares Lead
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Lee Westwood was having an unlucky day at the 96th P.G.A. Championship. Three times Thursday, his golf ball rolled into a fairway divot or the pitch mark of another players ball, a rare trifecta of star-crossed doom given the green, unblemished expanse of Valhalla Golf Club.

title: New Scenic Routes in the Outer Banks
description: Four new driving trails link cultural and natural heritage sites along the Outer Banks National Scenic Byway in North Carolina, and a new kayak network weaves through miles of pristine coastal creeks and sounds.

title: Long Days in the Fields, Without Earning Overtime
description: RED HOOK, N.Y.  In the early stage of the harvest season, Antonio, a farmworker in his 50s, picked peas from daybreak until sundown, 14 hours a day, six days a week, with an hour off each day for lunch.

title: Marni Kotak: Mad Meds
description: MARNI KOTAK

title: Build an Open Source Community Platform With New York Times, Washington Post and Mozilla
description: Each year, Knight-Mozilla OpenNews selects developers, technologists, civic hackers and data crunchers to spend 10 months working as fellows embedded in their partner newsrooms. Fellowships are paid positions, and emphasize open source development that strengthens specific newsrooms and the larger journalism-code community.

title: Detroit-Area Man Convicted of Murdering Teenager on His Porch
description: DETROIT  No one disputed that in the early morning hours of Nov. 2, Renisha McBride, 19, stood on the front porch of a bungalow in suburban Dearborn Heights, Mich. She pounded at the door with her hands, moving to the side of the house and back to the front. Minutes later, the homeowner, a 55-year-old airport maintenance worker named Theodore P. Wafer who had been roused from his sleep, opened the inside front door, fired a single shotgun blast and killed her.

title: A Hip Way to Take Street Photos
description: A plastic auto-focus camera freed Ken Heyman to shoot New York City streets from odd angles, often going unnoticed by his subjects.

title: Paper Robot That Puts Itself Together
description: Using flat materials and a design inspired by origami, the art of paper folding, researchers have created a robot that can assemble without human intervention.

title: 2 Officials at Queens Tutoring Center Charged With Assaulting Children
description: The children, here from South Korea without their parents, were hit, made to hold piles of books above their heads and denied food and bathroom visits.

title: Origami Inspires Rise of Self-Folding Robot
description: An intricately cut sheet lies flat and motionless on a table. Then Samuel Felton, a graduate student at Harvard, connects the batteries, sending electricity coursing through, heating it. The sheet lurches to life, the pieces bending and folding into place. The transformation completes in four minutes, and the sheet, now a four-limbed robot, scurries away at more than two inches a second.

title: Tiny Furniture: A Diaspora of Dollhouses
description: Major collections of dollhouses and dollhouse furniture are appearing on the market, providing ample evidence of the evolution of the industry.

title: Discord Among Private Equity Firms Is Their Best Defense in Lawsuit
description: Even when it might help them, private equity firms cant seem to cooperate.

title: Conceptual Art by Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler
description: The artists Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler, who worked together from the late 1970s until Ms. Ericsons death in 1995, fused Conceptual art, community action and Americana in ways few others have, before or since. For a 1991 project in Charleston, S.C., they painted the exterior of a house just outside the citys historic district in a riotous camouflage of colors (each one drawn from a list approved by the citys Board of Architectural Review, which probably had not anticipated anyone wanting to use them all at once).

title: Living With Cancer: Difficult Choices
description: As if confined in a sinister maze, cancer patients often discover that some routes lead to forking branches. It may be impossible to find a way through the bewildering medical labyrinth without feeling lost. My oncologist Dr. Matei, pointing out treatment paths, tells me to choose: Its up to you, she says.

title: Kevin Love to Be Traded to Cavaliers
description: In a move that transforms them from an intriguing contender to a possible favorite in the Eastern Conference, the Cleveland Cavaliers have reached an agreement in principle to acquire power forward Kevin Love from the Minnesota Timberwolves, according to a person in basketball briefed on the deal.

title: Art at the Terminal and Beyond
description: It seems to happen every summer: Just as the Miser starts to feel as if he finally had a grasp on what he wants to do with it, the calendar rolls ruthlessly over into August. So as not to squander our last few precious weeks of warm weather, lets hit some of the citys ferries, beaches, gardens and parks.

title: On the Record: The Nixon Tapes 1971-1972 and The Nixon Defense
description: On June 1, 1972, President Richard Nixon triumphantly reported to a joint session of Congress on the summit meeting in Moscow from which he had returned just hours earlier. He trumpeted the signing of major arms-control agreements with the Soviet Union, conspicuously including a long-sought antiballistic missile treaty. The foundation has been laid, he exulted, for a new relationship between the two most powerful nations in the world.

title: Red Alert
description: The nucleus of All That Is Solid Melts Into Air, Darragh McKeons whirling first novel, is the Chernobyl nuclear accident, a catastrophe that embodies the political, economic and moral bankruptcy of the waning Soviet Union. McKeon makes it the center of a much larger, interconnected story, as the great Soviet writer Vasily Grossman did with the Battle of Stalingrad in Life and Fate.

title: Winged Victories
description: Avian migration is such a vast and complex phenomenon that it can accommodate star treatment in two new books. The Thing With Feathers, by Noah Strycker, takes on the miracle of navigation as part of a sweeping look at bird behavior. For Bernd Heinrich, in The Homing Instinct, the biannual odyssey of billions of birds is the heart of the matter.

title: A Finale to Soothe Cravings for Magic
description: Toward the end of The Magicians Land, the final volume of Lev Grossmans wonderful trilogy for grown-ups, Julia and Quentin, both 30-ish, visit a magic garden whose plants are expressions of human emotions. The garden is in Fillory, the Narnia-like world that appeared in a series of books that they loved as children and that, thrillingly, turned out actually to exist.

title: How to Pre-Game Like a Grown-Up
description: Editors note: Were resurfacing this 2014 Drink column for Smarter Living so you can enjoy the sophisticated pleasures of a pre-dinner aperitif cocktail all year long.

title: Michael Phelpss Best Event Is Same, but Talent Is Deeper
description: IRVINE, Calif.  With the applause not meant for him ringing in his ears, Michael Phelps moved on from his seventh-place finish in the 100-meter freestyle at the United States long-course swimming championships. Speaking after his race Wednesday night, Phelps said, There is going to be another chance to swim that race in a couple of weeks.

title: Unicef on Iraqs Crisis in Sinjar
description: Will Parks, the United Nations Childrens Fund chief field officer in the northern Kurdish region of Iraq, discussed the crisis in Sinjar, where tens of thousands of people are stuck in the mountains.

title: Senator Quits Montana Race After Charge of Plagiarism
description: WASHINGTON  Under pressure from fellow Democrats, Senator John Walsh of Montana, who has served in office for just six months, said Thursday that he was dropping his election bid, clearing the path for his party to nominate a new candidate.

title: A Waiver to Let the de Blasio Children Work as Unpaid Interns
description: The citys Conflicts of Interest Board determined that Mayor Bill de Blasios children may serve one-month, unpaid internships at City Hall.

title: Too Many Cooks Spoil the Village
description: The first faces on screen at a recent advance showing of The Hundred-Foot Journey belonged to Oprah Winfrey and Steven Spielberg, who do not appear in the movie itself but are credited among its producers. Its a bit unusual to be subjected to a promo trying to sell you on a movie you have already committed to seeing, but Mr. Spielberg and Ms. Winfrey clearly could not contain themselves, and took a moment to share their enthusiasm. In the clip (which has also aired on television), Ms. Winfrey, using the trademark falsetto singsong that is her version of conversational italics, tells us how excited she is to present this amazing movie, while Mr. Spielberg uses variations on the word incredible at least three times. Noting that The Hundred-Foot Journey, based on a popular novel by Richard C. Morais, is about food, Ms. Winfrey asks, Can I say its delicious?

title: Unorthodox Star Took U.S. Soccer on New Path
description: Traditionally, starting lineups in soccer feature players who wear jerseys numbered 1 through 11, with each number referring to a particular position. No. 1 is always the goalkeeper, for example. No. 3 is a stout defender. No. 9 is a lone striker.

title: Yankees Take Series vs. Tigers Behind Starter and a Stopper
description: Francisco Cervelli was a talented soccer goalie in his youth in Valencia, Venezuela, leading his school, Cruz Vitale, to a state tournament before quitting the sport at 15 to concentrate on baseball.

title: Lululemon Strikes Deal With Yoga Sportswear Makers Founder, Avoiding Fight
description: Updated, 7:24 p.m. | Lululemon Athletica has reached a pact with its founder, Dennis J. Wilson, potentially averting a costly battle over control of the embattled sportswear makers board.

title: Readers Respond to Friedman and Saif on the Gaza Conflict
description: As the war in Gaza appears to wind down, readers are responding to Times columns about the self-perpetuating nature of armed conflict, the ethics of the United States position toward the Israeli offensive, and the suffering of the victims of war.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Artist Comes Cackling Back to the Limelight
description: It isnt until late in Fifi Howls From Happiness that you learn the meaning of the cryptic title. Even so, you may soon intuit that theres a strong link between the howling and the cackling that regularly erupts from the movies subject, the Iranian artist Bahman Mohassess. Its an unnerving sound because of its wincingly harsh, broken resonance, but also because of the eerie juxtaposition created by the image of Mr. Mohassesss cigarette smoke curling around his head, not far from a portable oxygen device. Its hard not to think that he may be on a suicide mission, though this thoughtful, moving documentary does make you wonder if, after a lifetime of trouble, hes just laughing at fate.

title: Star Wars: Still The One
description: For readers who wish this blog had more pop culture commentary and fewer rants against presidential despotism, Im very pleased to announce that my colleague Frank Bruni and I are launching a new feature in which we ping-pong back and forth about the movies weve seen lately (and possibly the occasional TV show as well, when it seems appropriate), sometimes touching on their political significance but hopefully also offering a partial refuge from the politicized life as well. The feature should run monthly, roughly, but perhaps more frequently depending the quality and significance of whats showing at a given moment; I hope readers find it to be an entertaining, not-too-self-serious diversion amid the Op-Ed teams coverage of thegrim and getting grimmer issues of the day.

title: The Executive Editor on the Word Torture
description: Dean Baquet is the executive editor of The Times.

title: Dipping Into Fitness: Workouts in the Water
description: NEW YORKERS are surrounded by water, but working out in it can present financial and logistical challenges. Fortunately, if you know where to look, ample water aerobics options around the city offer refreshing and affordable ways to shape up amid the summer heat.

title: When Getting to a Body Count Takes More Than Math
description: How do we count the dead? Why do we do it? Two striking graphics  on the conflict in Gaza, in The Washington Post, and on gun violence, at Slate offer examples and clues.

title: Digging Into Fitness: Sandbox Play for Grown-Ups
description: FOR many people, time spent in the sand means relaxing on a blanket or in a chair. Not so for Andia Winslow, a 31-year-old professional athlete and sports performance coach: The sand presents an opportunity to get fit.

title: Israels Supporters Try to Come to Terms With the Killing of Children in Gaza
description: While the precise number of civilians killed in Israels monthlong bombardment of Gaza is once again the subject of a debate, outrage over the hundreds of Palestinian children killed has been expressed by partisans on both sides of the conflict.

title: What Warpaint, L.A.s Coolest All-Female Band, Packs on Tour
description: When Warpaint returned to Los Angeles in July after a two-month tour that spanned the western hemisphere, Emily Kokal, one of the all-female quartets vocalist/guitarists, would often find herself wandering the hills of her Echo Park neighborhood instead of relaxing at home. Im so used to moving and seeing new things, she said over coffee recently at a local cafe. Its hard to be in the zone of staying still.

title: Walsh Statement to Supporters
description: Senator John Walsh of Montana said on Thursday that he was dropping his election bid in an email to supporters.

title: Two Parks, One Statue, Lots of Pieces Lying Around
description: If you can get past the glaring obviousness of its central metaphors, Danh Vos We the People  a fragmentary replica of the Statue of Liberty, made in China  looks pretty compelling in its latest incarnation as a Public Art Fund project. After popping up in various American, European and Asian museums, the work  or a portion of it, at least  is now ideally situated in two city parks at opposite ends of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: A Return to the Fight in Iraq
Where Minimalist Meets Showy
description: MOUNTAINVILLE, N.Y.  Sculptures by the two artists featured here in temporary presentations at Storm King Art Center this year couldnt be less alike. A single Minimalist piece by the New York sculptor Virginia Overton is gracefully fitted to the landscape of gently rolling hills. Six monumental, figurative sculptures by Zhang Huan of Shanghai are ponderously theatrical.

title: Elevated Perspectives
description: Archeo is this seasons exhibition of artworks presented on the High Line, the elevated railway turned greenway on the West Side of Manhattan that has become a tourist magnet and emblem of gentrified New York. Shortening the word archaeology, the exhibition of outdoor sculpture by seven contemporary artists focuses on technology and obsolescence. It also provides some connection with the history and culture of the High Line, which, with its carefully selected benches and botanicals, can otherwise feel like a detached people mover carrying you through a bucolic landscape in the sky.

title: Fine Lines Drawn Among the Flora
description: Rachel Feinsteins Folly, a set of three sculptures in Madison Square Park, evokes the whimsical garden structures on vast 18th- and 19th-century estates. Each sculpture is a sort of frothy confection, whipped up from thin sheets of aluminum that have been coated in white powder and printed with gray lines to look like enlarged sketches. One looks like a house on a cliff; another is a rococo hut. Most intriguing, if least accessible, is the ship moored high overhead in a tree.

title: Millennials Turned Yuppies (Really), Pulling Together
description: ABOUT ALEX

title: Museums See Different Virtues in Virtual Worlds
description: LIKE vodka and fun-house mirrors and trips to Japan, the Internet can make you feel bigger than you are.

title: Ordinary Objects, Reimagined
description: There is a lot of art on Governors Island, much of it mounted in buildings along the waterfront or the bright yellow houses in Nolan Park. Past years have included ambitious installations of monumental sculpture by Mark di Suvero, as well as Allison Smiths Muster, a mock-military gathering inspired by the islands history. This is the first year of a new public art program headed by Tom Eccles, and it features four sculptures by Mark Handforth that fit in well with the islands increasing move to becoming a Colonial Williamsburg-type family playground.

title: Dealing With Home-Equity Resets
description: New research from TransUnion, a credit information service, suggests that the payment shock expected to hit millions of consumers with home equity lines over the next few years may not pose as much of a risk to lenders as feared.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Voyage to the Actual Bottom of the Sea
description: DEEPSEA CHALLENGE 3D

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: DeGrom Keeps Mets in the Game, but Harpers Home Run Ends It
description: WASHINGTON  Jacob deGrom put his glove under his armpit, massaged a baseball with his hands and paced a few feet beyond the mound. He had just allowed his first home run in about two months, a period in which he had become the Mets most consistent starter and adversity had faded to a foreign concept. The question now was simple: How would he respond?

title: Summer Art, Barefoot in the Park
description: A QUESTION that has long dogged modern art is: Whos it for? Animated by antipathy to mainstream tastes and values, it first appealed mainly to a self-selected minority of cognoscenti. Since the 1960s, however, the audience for modern and contemporary art has grown, and the answer now would be something like: For anyone whos interested.

title: The Questions We Share
description: How can we repair our public discourse?

title: Animal Welfare Advocates Notch a Win Against Dog Traders
description: Its rare that stories of grass-roots activism in China end well, yet that seems to be the case for a group of animal lovers who rescued some 2,400 dogs that might have otherwise ended up on the menu.

title: 36 Hours: Lake Como, Italy
description: In the foothills of the Alps in northern Italy, Lake Como deserves its reputation as a playground for the wealthy. Virtually deserted during the winter, the wishbone-shaped lake awakens from its slumber in mid-March when glamorous crowds begin flocking to the pretty towns clustered around its midsection: Bellagio, Menaggio, Tremezzo, Varenna. But in recent years, the city of Como, on the lakes southwestern tip, has quietly blossomed into the most interesting spot for visitors of all bank account sizes. A raft of openings has infused new life there, transforming the oft-overlooked transit hub into the lakes new place to be seen.

title: Visiting Shawshank Sites, 20 Years Later
description: Richland County refers to itself, because of its character and geographical location, as the heart of Ohio. But for a large number of visitors, it is better known as the home of perhaps the most storied prison in movie history.

title: The Fifth Season
description: The title of this stimulating group show comes from a centrally placed installation by Mark Dion. Called Harbingers of the Fifth Season, it presents the imaginary workroom of a scientist-illustrator who is studying shifts in animal behavior caused by drastic environmental change.

title: Making the Best of Trash, While Finding Meaning
description: Participant Medias Pivot aims its programming at millennials and uses the motto Its your turn. But plenty of millennials have found that it is not their turn. Theyre stuck in drab low-level jobs despite excellent educations and high aspirations.

title: An Eclectic Mix of Hard-Luck Tales
description: Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell foraged through history both distant and recent at the Damrosch Park Bandshell on Wednesday night, finding some of the strongest traction in vintage songs of their own design. Among them was Til I Gain Control Again, written by Mr. Crowell and originally recorded by Ms. Harris in 1975, not long after their first meeting. Underplaying its broken reassurance and desperate devotion, they made it feel lived-in and true.

title: Does Zephyr Teachout Live in New York? The Governor Wants to Know.
description: Zephyr Rain Teachout, a law professor at Fordham University in New York, is a very brave woman. So brave, in fact, that she is running for governor in the Democratic primary against Andrew Cuomo.

title: The Marijuana Series: Other Views
The St. Petersburg Paradox at the Swiss Institute
description: This shows introductory text panel defines the economic and gambling conundrum of risk known as the St. Petersburg Paradox. But you barely need to read (or understand) it to grasp that the works of the exhibitions 13 artists revolve around themes of chance and games.

title: The Invisible but All-Seeing Servant
description: THE MAIDS ROOM

title: Santander Consumer Gets Subpoena in Subprime Car Loan Inquiry
description: Santander Consumer USA disclosed on Thursday that it had received a Justice Department subpoena related to its subprime auto lending business, the latest company to be touched by a federal investigation into the booming industry.

description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors, Patients and Guns
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: On the morning of Aug. 7, 1974, New Yorkers awoke to a French funambulist walking between the Twin Towers.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Beauty of the Moment Blurs the Pain of Memory
description: WHAT NOW? REMIND ME

title: Africas Economic Model
description: To the Editor:

description: Ukraine and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Gaza City, Berlin and Pakistan.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: gender differences in marathon running, cheaper medical tests and Ebola. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

description: TEENAGE MUTANT

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Events on Long Island for Aug. 10-16, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Once Scorned, Now Rich and Vengeful
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  Chita Rivera knows how to bide her time. Portraying the much-married, well-widowed Claire Zachanassian, a billionaire for whom patience is a vicious virtue, Ms. Rivera holds calm and queenly sway over the macabre frenzy of The Visit, John Doyles newly revamped version of the 2001 John Kander and Fred Ebb musical at the Williamstown Theater Festival.

title: Events in Westchester for Aug. 10-16, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Friendship Ripens Into ... Well, You Know
description: WHAT IF

title: In a Balm of Space and Time, Healing
description: Twelve years ago, my husband, Nick, and I were halfway through a yearlong round-the-world trip when we arrived in Jaisalmer, India, on a furnace-hot July afternoon. As we made our way from the train station up the winding streets to the cheapest hotel we could find, our rickshaw became snarled in traffic in an alley alongside other rickshaws, a donkey cart and cows noshing on garbage.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Sympathy Can Wait
description: A year ago, we lost our 18-year-old son to an undiagnosed heart condition. We are still grieving, though time is making things a little better. But we find it extremely distressing when people we havent seen in the last year rush up to us at social events to tell us how sorry they are and how they just cant imagine our loss. We know they mean well, but it makes us overwhelmingly sad and ruins festive occasions. My husband doesnt want to go out anymore! What can we do to stop people from launching into their grief for us?

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 8-14
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: From Gate-Crashing to the Grammys
description: NO CAMERAS ALLOWED

title: Throwback Thursday
description: Yes, this is a photo of me when I was 26. Am I not the most adorable thing you have ever seen? Can you believe that was my real, gorgeous hair color? I ask because I cant always post stories of my work, or share photos of my grandchildren or link to the work of the successful people I want to suck up to here on Facebook. It is important to give back.

title: Events in Connecticut for Aug. 10-16, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 8-14
description: The Little Apple

title: Spare Times for Aug. 8-14
description: Summer Streets (Saturday and Aug. 16) Play continues to have the right of way on some Manhattan streets during this free festival, which began last week. For the next two Saturdays, from 7 a.m. to 1 p.m., Park Avenue will be vehicle-free, from the Brooklyn Bridge to 72nd Street, and parts of Lafayette Street and other streets will also be closed. In its seventh year, Summer Streets is part of the New York City Transportation Departments Weekend Walks, an effort that encourages civic groups and businesses to sponsor free street events.

title: An Invitation to Play, and Then Wash
description: FOR decades Mr. Bubble, the brand of bubble bath for children, has used a slogan that aimed to win over children who hate taking baths, Makes getting clean almost as much fun as getting dirty! Now adults are being pitched a similar message that exalts washing up after exercise or messy projects, but this time it is to sell faucets and showerheads.

title: China Curbs on Metals Are Again Found to Violate Trade Law
description: China lost an appeal on Thursday of a World Trade Organization ruling that found it had broken international trade law by restricting exports of raw materials used in hybrid car batteries and other energy-efficiency products.

title: In Texas Panhandle, a Growing Need for a Shallow Lakes Water
description: Water systems in the Texas Panhandle and South Plains started last week to draw from a once-empty lake that is now just over 4 percent full, an indication of how strapped the region is for drinking water. The Canadian River Municipal Water Authority, which supplies about half a million people in Lubbock, Amarillo and surrounding towns, began pumping recently from Lake Meredith for the first time since the summer of 2011.

title: An Expert in Disaster
description: INTO THE STORM

title: Dean Baquet, Times Executive Editor, on the Word Torture
description: Over the past few months, reporters and editors of The Times have debated a subject that has come up regularly ever since the world learned of the C.I.A.s brutal questioning of terrorism suspects: whether to call the practices torture.

title: A Family With Problems, Not All of Them Obvious
description: AFTER

title: This Weeks Movies | Aug. 8, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review The Dog, Web Junkie and The Hundred-Foot Journey.

title: Fools at the Fire
description: In the heat, in the still gloaming, we set up camp near a snowbank across from a glacier and a symphony of waterfalls. North Cascades National Park, a few hours drive from Seattle, can always be counted on as a compress to the rest of the countrys fever.

title: Credit Scores Could Rise With FICOs New Model
description: The creator of one of the most widely used and influential credit scores, FICO, said on Thursday that the latest version of its score would no longer weigh medical debts  which account for about half of all unpaid collections on consumers credit reports  as heavily as it did in previous iterations.

title: In the Grip of Ebola
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  LIBERIANS have begun calling the days between July 27 and Aug. 3 the dark week  173 new Ebola virus cases and 94 new deaths. How much darker things may get is anybodys guess.

title: Inequality Is a Drag
description: For more than three decades, almost everyone who matters in American politics has agreed that higher taxes on the rich and increased aid to the poor have hurt economic growth.

title: The Architect Behind the Rebuilding of Rick Perry

title: Regulators Fine Hyundai $17.4 Million After It Is Slow to Report Defect
description: Federal auto regulators on Thursday imposed a nearly $17.4 million penalty on Hyundai because it did not promptly report to the public a safety defect that affected braking in its cars.

description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

description: Welcome to Walmart. The nurse will be right with you.

description: Princeton University may soon end the policy that limited the number of students who received As for their course marks, an approach designed to thwart grade inflation but one that many students cited as the worst part of their Princeton experience.

description: The Hachette Book Groups deal to acquire the independent publisher Perseus has collapsed after months of negotiations, representatives from each company said on Thursday.

title: Upstart Bank in China Rides High on Technology I.P.O. Crest
description: HONG KONG  When Alan Guo was chief strategist at Google China, he would have leisurely conversations with Fan Bao, a Beijing banker, exchanging ideas about the future of the Internet in China and swapping gossip about industry personalities. Mr. Bao, who had been a strategist at a Chinese technology company before setting up his own boutique investment bank in 2004, would occasionally prod Mr. Guo about his plans.

title: Second Drug Is Allowed for Treatment of Ebola
description: The Food and Drug Administration helped clear the way on Thursday for a second experimental drug to be tried by people in Africa stricken with the Ebola virus.

title: Key Cleric in Egypt Rejects Executions
description: CAIRO  In a rare official rebuke, Egypts highest Muslim religious authority refused to approve death sentences imposed by a court on senior leaders of the Islamist Muslim Brotherhood, saying that the case lacked evidence, court officials said on Thursday.

description: It is nothing new for a top N.B.A. player to leverage his impending free agency to force a trade to his preferred destination. That is how Carmelo Anthony ended up in New York. However, it is a novel idea for that destination to be Cleveland.

description: He was a skilled-enough impersonator that he pulled off his scheme for years, talented enough at it that he seemingly could have chosen any identity. A celebrity, or a scholar, perhaps.

title: Obama Signs Bill Aimed at Fixing V.A. Shortfalls
description: FORT BELVOIR, Va.  Promising a major change in the way the V.A. does business, President Obama traveled to this Army base outside Washington on Thursday to sign a bill that will expand access to health care for veterans and strengthen the powers of the Department of Veterans Affairss new leader to clean up abuses in its troubled network of hospitals.

title: Russia Sanctions Itself
description: The sad truth of the tit-for-tat sanctions that Russia has imposed against the West is that they will hurt Russians far more than they will hurt Westerners.

title: Combat Stress Among Veterans Is Found to Persist Since Vietnam
description: Most veterans who had persistent post-traumatic stress a decade or more after serving in the Vietnam War have shown surprisingly little improvement since then, and a large percentage have died, a new study finds, updating landmark research that began a generation ago. Members of minorities who enlisted before finishing high school were especially likely to develop such war-related trauma, as were those veterans who had killed multiple times in combat, the study found.

title: Plot Thickens as 900 Writers Battle Amazon
description: ROUND POND, Me.  Out here in the woods, at the end of not one but two dirt roads, in a shack equipped with a picture of the Dalai Lama, a high-speed data line and a copy of Thoreaus Civil Disobedience, Amazons dream of dominating the publishing world has run into some trouble.

title: Unkind Life for Young and Old
description: In a wheelchair, the 86-year-old man was getting ready for a parole board hearing to see if he might leave New Yorks prison system after 33 years behind bars. It was essential that he express remorse for his crime. He asked me to read the sentencing minutes, said Elizabeth Gaynes, the director of the Osborne Association, an inmate advocacy organization. He wasnt sure he could remember his crime well enough, and was worried that he would sound like he wasnt taking responsibility for it.

title: The N.C.A.A.s Nod to Reality
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has acknowledged what everyone always knew  that not all college sports programs are the same.

description: WASHINGTON  A public feud between two senators of opposing parties is hardly a rarity. But it usually does not involve the threat of legal action.

title: Introspective or Narcissistic?
description: Some people like to keep a journal. Some people think its a bad idea.

title: Yankees Follow Winding Road but Keep Playoffs in Sight
description: Facing a two-time most valuable player with two on, no outs and a one-run lead in the ninth inning Thursday, David Robertson meant to place his pitch low and away. But as he threw it, Robertson said, he simply cut loose. The ball ended up over the middle of the plate.

title: Dorothy Salisbury Davis, Suspense Novelist, Dies at 98
description: Dorothy Salisbury Davis, an award-winning mystery author whose fascination with motivation, morality and manners  more than violence  powered the intricate plots of the suspense novels she wrote over a half-century, died on Sunday at her home in Palisades, N.Y. She was 98.

title: Preventing a Slaughter in Iraq
description: The catastrophe of Iraq has been growing steadily worse for weeks, but by Thursday, it became impossible for the United States and other civilized nations to ignore it. Iraqs bloodthirsty Sunni extremists were threatening the extermination of tens of thousands of members of religious minorities who have refused to join the fundamentalist Islamic state the terrorist forces want to create.

title: Zynga Stock Drops After Social Game Maker Lowers Forecast
description: Updated | Things just got worse for the game maker Zynga. The question is whether they will keep going in that direction.

title: Uighurs Veils Signal Protest Against Chinas Restrictions
description: URUMQI, China  Fond of denim and lace, fluent in multiple languages and proud of her success as an international business translator, Luna appears to be a model of the assimilated Uighur that the Chinese government is striving for. She grew up in the far-western region of Xinjiang, where marrying and mothering was the paramount role for women of her largely Muslim, Turkic-speaking minority ethnic group, and eventually moved to distant Beijing, where she feels more comfortable among the countrys Han majority than in the conservative world of her youth.

title: Stampede of Mergers Could Mean Growth, or Irrationality, Ahead
description: Something big is happening on Wall Street that is making investment bankers richer. It is also supposed to signal better times ahead for the rest of the country.

description: This week, the Rev. Al Sharpton announced plans for a march across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Aug. 23 to protest the role the police played in the death of a Staten Island man.

title: Jim Frederick, Journalist Who Wrote Book About Iraq War Crime, Dies at 42
description: Jim Frederick, a former foreign correspondent and editor whose 2010 book about an atrocity committed by American soldiers in Iraq was praised for its thorough reporting and acuity in parsing the psychological erosion of men in war, died on July 31 in Oakland, Calif. He was 42.

title: For 3rd Date, a Trip to an Abortion Clinic
description: When Scott Organs Phoenix begins, Bruce and Sue are on their second date. It isnt going well. I cant see you anymore, Sue says. She makes this declaration after shes rated their drunken night together better than most, but before shes revealed that a faulty condom has left her pregnant, and that she intends to terminate the pregnancy.

title: Neighbor of the Adams Apple
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Bruce Haight is back, and he has brought a snack with him. You might not see it until you stare at the grid for a while, but theyre there: three goldfish, swimming playfully upstream. These are not the kind of live goldfish that people have been known to swallow on a dare, thank goodness, but are those snacks that smile back, the Pepperidge Farm Goldfish Crackers that are so popular among the pre-K set.

title: Rikers Health Contractor Fined for Worker Assaults
description: The New York City contractor that provides medical and mental health services to inmates at Rikers Island was issued the highest level of censure by the federal Labor Department on Thursday for failing to protect employees from violence at the jail complex.

description: KENEMA, Sierra Leone  So many patients, nurses and health workers have died in the government hospital that many people in this city, a center of the worlds worst Ebola epidemic, see it as a death trap.

description: Amid the gold pocket watches and glittering brooches, pearl necklaces and turquoise rings, there was the bland quarry of Lot 2039: a palm-size rock, a yellowing notebook, a knife decorated with neon tape, a smudged silver bowl and another rock bound by leather string to the end of a bone, creating a sort of primitive club.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Rex Ryan wanted to see production from the Jets offense in the teams preseason opener Thursday night, and production is what he got. On their third possession, the Jets drove 80 yards in 14 plays for a touchdown, and afterward, as green fireworks boomed above MetLife Stadium, the quarterback who guided them into the end zone was greeted warmly on the sideline.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants top draft pick caught punts and made cuts during practice Wednesday but still could not say when he might return to full strength.

description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress questioned Thursday whether the American response to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa had been effective, and a spokesman for a group battling the virus went further, saying no country had done enough.

title: Obama, With Reluctance, Returns to Action in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  In sending warplanes back into the skies over Iraq, President Obama on Thursday night found himself exactly where he did not want to be. Hoping to end the war in Iraq, Mr. Obama became the fourth president in a row to order military action in that graveyard of American ambition.

title: Afraid of Heartbreak, a Celebrity Campaign Begs Scotland to Stay

title: Syria: Progress on Chemical Stockpile
description: Nearly 75 percent of Syrias known chemical arms material has been destroyed, the international organization responsible for policing a treaty banning the munitions announced Thursday, nearly a year after a devastating nerve agent attack in a Damascus suburb focused global attention on the Syrian stockpile. The announcement, by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, said a significant volume of the material had been incinerated at Ellesmere Port, a site in Britain, mainly ingredients for making the nerve agent and hydrochloric acid. Facilities in Finland, Germany and the United States are also destroying portions of the Syrian stockpile, which was exported from Syria in June after repeated delays.

title: Palmer Gets the Score While Woods Gets the Attention
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  On Wednesday, Ryan Palmer had some fun with a gaggle of photographers whose lenses were trained on Tiger Woods as he played a heavily scrutinized practice round at Valhalla Golf Club before the P.G.A. Championship.

title: Ebola Drug Could Save a Few Lives. But Whose?
description: With hundreds of Africans dying from the outbreak of Ebola, some activists have said it is wrong that extremely scarce supplies of an experimental drug went to two white American aid workers.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) AMERICAN HUSTLE (2013) Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale), a con man with a rococo comb-over, and Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), his seductive mistress, are forced by an F.B.I. agent (Bradley Cooper, above right, with Ms. Adams and Mr. Bale) to help ensnare politicians in this screwball comedy directed by David O. Russell and inspired by the Abscam sting operation begun in 1978, which netted corrupt elected officials but also resulted in charges of entrapment. Jennifer Lawrence plays Irvings adenoidal stay-at-home wife; Jeremy Renner is the mayor of Camden, N.J., whose ambitions trump his decency. Mr. Bale has long been a great actor, if not an especially likable screen presence, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Its a pleasure to see him warm up, soften up, not only because he looks as if he were having a good time, but also because hes extraordinary here. The film giddily embraces the excesses of its era, from spandex to staches, though its a farce that speaks as well to this tarnished age, she added. But all the shiny surfaces, the glitter ball and the gaudiness, also suggest a world in which everyone is anxious to shake off the post-Vietnam War, post-Watergate funk. The ghost of Richard M. Nixon hovers in the air; everyone is a fake, and everyone wears a mask.

title: New Fighting a Bid for Leverage as a Gaza Cease-Fire Expires
description: GAZA CITY  Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip resumed cross-border air assaults after a three-day cease-fire expired on Friday, but the renewed violence seemed less about meeting military goals than about jockeying for leverage in talks that had made little progress toward a more durable truce.

description: PRETORIA, South Africa  The defense concluded its arguments on Friday at the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius, with his lawyers contending that he had killed his girlfriend in a tragic mistake that warranted a far less serious charge than murder.

title: Why TerraCycle Keeps Trying to Create a Reality TV Series
description: Back in 2011, I wrote a post about TerraCycles ongoing quest to create what we call negative-cost marketing. In other words, were always looking for ways to persuade other people to pay us to tell the world about TerraCycle, rather than our having to pay them. So far, weve had a good bit of success doing this.
