description: In The Times this week: news about Russian hackers stealing more than a billion Internet passwords, as well as advice for keeping your passwords out of hackers hands.

title: Morning Agenda: Whats Behind the Surge in Mergers
description: WHATS BEHIND THE STAMPEDE OF MERGERS | Something big is happening on Wall Street that is making investment bankers richer, Peter Eavis and David Gelles write in DealBook. That something is a boom in mergers and acquisitions, which is expected to continue even after Rupert Murdochs bid for Time Warner and Sprints attempt to buy T-Mobile crumbled earlier this week. A sharp upturn in deal activity is often thought to herald a stronger economy and a buoyant stock market. The theory is that corporate chieftains see strength building in their business lines, which gives them the confidence to pursue ambitious acquisitions of other companies.

title: Cigarettes, Coffee, a Stop at the Liquor Store
description: Frank OHaras Lunch Poems, the little black dress of American poetry books, redolent of cocktails and cigarettes and theater tickets and phonograph records, turns 50 this year. It seems barely to have aged.

title: Great Divide at the Concert Hall
description: Weve been invisible, the composer T. J. Anderson declared, almost immediately after answering the phone for an interview. Like Ralph Ellison said, you know: Were invisible, and any chance we get for exposure is very important. Ellison, who in his youth aspired to be a composer before turning to literature, might have sympathized with Dr. Andersons plight.

title: Selling an Old iPhone? Here Are Things to Consider
description: Apple usually announces a new iPhone in September, so its not too early to start thinking about your old iPhone.

title: Taking Over My Mind
description: Dear Diary:

title: 1889: Thomas Edison Testifies
description: An unusually interesting hearing in the Kemmler case in New York was the recent one when the great electrician, Thomas A. Edison, testified. Everyone present, including W. Bourke Cockran, Kemmlers attorney, was extremely anxious to hear the evidence of the man who, by general consent, is regarded as the greatest electrician of the age. The clear, concise way in which Mr. Edison explained many subjects which had not been understood after two weeks of evidence from numerous witnesses would have convinced anyone who did not know his reputation that his knowledge of electricity was at once comprehensive and accurate. All listened to his testimony with the greatest interest, and when he had finished felt that their knowledge of electricity had been greatly increased.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 9, 1889

title: A Family Puts Itself Under the Lens
description: Louis Garrel was 5 when he first starred in a film directed by his father. In that 1989 drama, Emergency Kisses, his actual parents, Philippe Garrel and Brigitte Sy, played his movie parents, a filmmaker and actress like their real selves. They separate in the film, as they would later in real life.

title: The 80s Supermodel Leslie Winer Reissues Her Lost 90s Album
description: Leslie Winer was, in the words of Jean-Paul Gaultier, the first androgynous model. In the 1980s, her angular features landed her campaigns for Valentino and Miss Dior; covers of The Face and European editions of Vogue; and shoots with legendary photographers like Helmut Newton, Irving Penn and Pierre et Gilles. She fell into fashion by happenstance after moving to New York City from Massachusetts to attend the School of Visual Arts. There, she became a protgof William Burroughs, partied hard and ran with the downtown demimonde of the era, dating Jean-Michel Basquiat for a time. Modeling, however, was just a job; music and writing were her true passions. The fashion world was much smaller and less mainstream then than it is now, she says. No one outside of fashion had any idea who you were. There wasnt the big money or the celebrity that occurred later.

title: Top 15 Fantasy Football Wide Receivers
description: Wide receivers are even more coveted in fantasy football this season, as the pass-heavy trends in the N.F.L. continue.

title: U.S. Jets and Drones Attack Militants in Iraq, Hoping to Stop Advance
description: DOHUK, Iraq  The United States launched a series of airstrikes against Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Friday, using Predator drones and Navy F-18 fighter jets to destroy rebel positions around the city of Erbil, the American military said Friday.

title: Finding an Identity Beyond the Workplace
description: WHEN Guy Johnson retired from his tax management position at Unilever, one of the worlds largest consumer products companies, he was sure that he was prepared. But he was fooling himself.

title: Fantasy Football: Wide Receiver Primer
description: Last season was a record-setting offensive year in the N.F.L., which included the most passing touchdowns (804) and combined passing yards per game (471). In the fantasy world, that resulted in the most total points generated in the last 15 years (standard 74,798; PPR 85,900). As if we needed another reason to covet the wide receiver position, the league decided to make things even more difficult for N.F.L. secondaries by instructing its officials to emphasize the 5-yard contact and defensive holding rules.

title: Need Kids to Follow Instructions? Dont Ask. Tell.
description: A year ago, I committed what is known as a mom fail (basically any false move committed during the act of mothering). Preparing my then-2-year-old son to go out in the morning for a play date, I asked him, Do you want to go to H.s house? Emphatically, he said no. Well, we have plans; hes expecting us, I amended lamely. My son burst into tears, and no matter how I tried to spin it, he was adamant. Maybe he was tired; maybe the dark, cloudy morning visible from our windows was too uninviting. Whatever the case, I was now in the awkward position of having to drag him, kicking and screaming, down four flights of stairs (we lived in a walk-up) while also toting my younger boy, then an infant. So I canceled the play date (thus committing a friendship fail, too, all in one morning).

title: Swarovski Gets Into the Fashion Awards Game
description: Following in the footsteps of LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuittons Young Fashion Designer Prize, and Chanels involvement with the Hyres International Festival of Fashion and Photography and its Premire Vision Grand Jury Prize, comes Swarovski. To celebrate its 15 years of supplying up-and-coming designers with crystals, the Austrian company has created the Swarovski Collective Prize for Innovation.

Easing the Transition From One Nanny to the Next
description: OVER the last 12 years, Donna Levin has come to know exactly what she needs in a nanny: someone on her way to or in graduate school who has an interest in children and a flexible class schedule.

description: In this weeks video, Times critics review The Dog, Web Junkie and The Hundred-Foot Journey. See all of this weeks reviews.

description: Regulators in Washington won not one but two major merger battles this week  without even firing a shot.

title: Summer Camp as a Place to Study
description: Its a summer camp but there are no color wars or folk songs. At Camp Rav Tov DSatmar in the Catskills in New York, 3,000 Hasidic boys study the Talmud more than six hours a day. Joseph Berger wrote about the camp in Thursdays paper. We asked him about his approach to the story.

title: Emmys 2014: Who Would You Pick for Lead Actress in a Comedy?
description: In advance of the Emmy Awards on Aug. 25, were asking you to tell us who deserved their nominations and who should have been nominated. Today the subject is lead actress in a comedy series. Take a look at this alternative list  its made up of the actual nominees, popular and critical favorites who werent nominated, and my own choices. Cast your votes in the comments, and let us know whos still been left out.

description: Plus: A dress that deflects; a look at conspiracy theorists.

title: Reply All: The 7.27.14 Issue

title: Who Made That Twitter Bird?
description: Twitter is the bird, the bird is Twitter, the social networking companys former creative director, Doug Bowman, said in a 2012 announcement about the latest redesign of the Twitter logo. Its slightly goofier predecessor had a tufted head and was sometimes accompanied by the company name; Bowmans new bird was a sleeker update. Resembling a mountain bluebird with a dash of hummingbird thrown in, the Twitter bird has a beak and body that point toward the sky in what Bowman called the ultimate representation of freedom, hope and limitless possibility. Unlike previous iterations since the companys 2006 launch, all of which were named Larry the Bird after the Boston Celtics legend, the current logo is known simply as the Twitter Bird.

title: Staking Out the Great White Shark
description: In the nearly 40 years since the premiere of Jaws, defenders of the great white shark have tried diligently to repair the animals reputation. The sharks are not all that hungry for humans, scientists say; seals are their preferred prey. One way great whites capture them is by breaching. Michael Muller, a photographer, used waterproof strobe lights he designed himself and a boat dragging a seal decoy to get a rare photo of a shark breaching at night. Muller, who traveled to False Bay, South Africa, to photograph sharks for a book coming out in 2015 from Taschen, said waiting for a shark in the dark is an intense experience. They come up like a missile, knock the seal to shock it and then they bite it, he says. Theres no noise, no warning. Im sitting there for hours on end looking through my lens, and then all of a sudden the shark appears." Julie Bosman

title: The Driver Just Didnt See You
description: As I crossed Hudson Street in Manhattan, I brooded over what the vet said that morning. It was just before my husband and I watched the needle disappear into our old dogs thick fur. I know that if the situation were reversed, Coco would want you to be out of pain, too, he said. It was an absurd image but, oddly, a comforting one. I wondered if the vet rehearsed that line over the years, but when he said it, it sounded so unpracticed and sincere.

title: Aubrey Plaza Is Not Mocking You
description: The actress talks to Eric Spitznagel about reforming her deadpan ways and longing for simpler times in Hollywood.

title: Who Knows How This Column Will End?
description: Spoiler Alert: I have no idea how this ends.

title: Compassionate Capital Punishment
description: A physician friend oversees the lethal-injection program in another state. I say this is unethical. He says just the opposite. Before him, he says, executions were often prolonged and painful. Now they are fast and painless. Because the state will continue the program with or without him, he feels that his work is humanitarian in nature. Whos right? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: The Brazilian Bus Magnate Whos Buying Up All the Worlds Vinyl Records
description: Paul Mawhinney, a former music-store owner in Pittsburgh, spent more than 40 years amassing a collection of some three million LPs and 45s, many of them bargain-bin rejects that had been thoroughly forgotten. The worlds indifference, he believed, made even the most neglected records precious: music that hadnt been transferred to digital files would vanish forever unless someone bought his collection and preserved it.

title: Is Marriage Going Back to the Supreme Court?
description: The already favorable odds of a historic Supreme Court reckoning in the coming term over the right of same-sex couples to marry have just improved.

title: Clintons Support de Blasios Push to Bring Democratic Convention to Brooklyn
description: She goes to Broadway musicals. She shops at Bergdorf Goodman. She works in Midtown Manhattan and spends summers on the shores of Long Island. Hillary Rodham Clinton has never been more of a New Yorker than she has since she left the State Department a year and a half ago. And if she runs for president in 2016, she would appreciate a Democratic National Convention on her home turf.

title: Afghan Rivals Back a Deal, Once More, for President
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans rival presidential candidates issued a joint statement on Friday, reaffirming their commitment to accept the results of an internationally monitored recount brokered by Secretary of State John Kerry and to abide by a power-sharing arrangement regardless of who prevails.

title: Covering Ebola, Carefully
description: Adam Nossiter is the West and Central Africa bureau chief. He has been covering the Ebola outbreak in West Africa since the spring, when it quickly began to spread from areas in Guinea to Sierra Leone and Liberia. We asked him how close a reporter can get while reporting the story of this highly infectious disease.

title: R.B.S. Is Said to Revamp Unit Under Scrutiny
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland is revamping its controversial unit that assists businesses facing serious financial difficulties, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 8
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images from a museum sleepover and a Catskills summer camp for Hasidic boys.

title: Cook a Peck of Peppers
On Reaganolatry
description: The truly vile attack on Rick Perlsteins new book has been revealing in a number of ways. Its not just the instinctive effort to suppress and punish anyone who raises questions; its also the way supposedly reasonable, civilized conservatives have contorted themselves to support the party line (which they always do when it matters, no matter how much open-mindedness they seem to display when it doesnt).

title: A Quandary Over Textbooks: Whether to Buy or Rent
description: TED FOSTER, a student at Fitchburg State University in Massachusetts, has become more discerning about how he obtains textbooks for his college classes.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: All That Is Solid Melts Into Air
description: This week, Darragh McKeon discusses All That Is Solid Melts Into Air; Parul Sehgal and Gregory Cowles talk about Haruki Murakami; Christopher Beha discusses Arts & Entertainments; and Mr. Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: A Maverick Golfers Struggles in a More Conformist Time
description: Mildred Ella Didrikson Zaharias, universally known as Babe  here shown after winning the Womens Western Open in 1944  was best known as the most accomplished female golfer of the 1940s and 1950s. Barred, because she was a woman, from the 1948 United States Open, she thereafter helped to found the Ladies Professional Golf Association.

title: The Financial District Gains Momentum
description: Anyone who enjoys a good comeback tale might find a lot to like in the financial district.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: All That Is Solid Melts Into Air
description: This week, Darragh McKeon and Christopher Beha.

title: A Cooking Tour in Southern Turkey
description: Expanding on its roster of one-day food tours in five major cities, the neighborhood-focused Culinary Backstreets will inaugurate its first multi-day trip with a three-day visit to Gaziantep in southern Turkey.

title: Strong Winds Ahead of Hurricane Iselle
description: Strong gusts batter Honolulu as Hurricane Iselle approaches Hawaii.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE TWO HOTEL FRANCFORTS,  by David Leavitt. (Bloomsbury, $16.) In Leavitts atmospheric novel of 1940 Lisbon, two couples are thrown together while awaiting passage to New York: Pete and Julia, American expatriates fleeing occupied Paris; and Edward and Iris, bohemian novelists indulging their intellectual and sexual flights of fancy. As Portugals neutrality and the worlds future hang in the balance, there is deceit, manipulation and a torrid affair.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE INVISIBLE BRIDGE: The Fall of Nixon and the Rise of Reagan,  by Rick Perlstein. (Simon & Schuster, $37.50.) Engrossing and at times mordantly funny, Perlsteins book treats the years 1973-76 as a Rosetta stone for American politics today.

title: Inside the List
description: Coming Clean: The Australian novelist Liane Moriarty, like a lot of writers, is ambivalent about modern technology. I have social media anxiety, she confessed on her blog last year, and she wasnt kidding  that post, dated May 6, 2013, remains her most recent as this column goes to press, and the blog as a whole has averaged just a handful of entries per year since it began in 2010. Too bad, since Moriarty turns out to be a natural blogger, droll and daffy and confiding. Here she is, for instance, on reading Fifty Shades of Grey: Why didnt any of you lovely readers tell me that you wanted more spanking? (Ha.) . . . Maybe you realized that I couldnt write a sexy spanking scene to save my life. (Well, I dont know. Perhaps I could to save my life. Except Id be quite nervous and distracted by the person trying to kill me.) Moriarty does maintain an active presence on Facebook, where, to promote her latest novel, Big Little Lies  new at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list  she recently asked readers to reveal little lies of their own. My publishers asked me to get in the spirit of things by also making a confession, she wrote, so heres one: When my sons kindergarten class was putting together a recipe book of favorite easy recipes I sent in a nutritious-sounding avocado muffin recipe that I had never made in my life just so I would look like a good mother.

title: The Interpretation of Freud
description: This book is a biography not of Freud and psychoanalysis but of Freud as psychoanalysis. Adam Phillips explains that what the reader does not need in any biographers attempt to write that impossible thing, a Freudian life of the young Freud, is the always fanciful (i.e. wishful), novelettish setting of scenes, and thumbnail sketches of characters, with their suppositions about what people were thinking and feeling and doing. What is needed, he believes, is what he supplies: a sketchy chronology of Freuds first 50 years threaded through the step-by-step story, richly told and richly interpreted, of how psychoanalysis came to be.

title: World War II Lit
description: ABOVE THE EAST CHINA SEA  By Sarah Bird  Knopf, $25.95.

title: Reality Bites
description: Why? Why would anyone put himself through this? Its a question I often ask myself while watching the endless parade of reality stars cavorting/jiggling/crying/strutting/tottering across my television screen. Why subject oneself to the vicious cycle of ridicule, redemption, repeat? The promise of easy money must prod many into the field, but a vast majority of reality show participants never make substantial cash from their television appearances. What else is there, then? Well  duh  fame. And what is the purpose of fame? Well  duh  more fame.

title: W.H.O. on Ebola Emergency Declaration
description: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the World Health Organization, said the current outbreak of the Ebola virus in West Africa is of international concern.

title: Letters: A Troublesome Inheritance
description: A Troublesome Inheritance

title: Seduction and Betrayal
description: No Amy Bloom character ever acted out of boredom. Once a practicing psychotherapist, Bloom knows that dire circumstances can drive people to their most compelling extremes. At her best, when she sets these driven souls on a journey across a landscape shadowed by immigration or war, the results can be stunning.

title: Striking It Rich
description: The American mining frontier burst on the scene with an undeniable frenzy in the spring of 1849. No one, Edward Dolnick writes, could have imagined how quickly the West would change. Shouts of Gold! would later be raised in such scattered locales as Bannack, Mont., Cripple Creek, Colo., and Nome, Alaska, but it all began in California near a place called Sutters Mill.

title: Enlisted Women
description: Helen Thorpes comprehensively researched new book, Soldier Girls, follows the lives of three women from enlistment in the Indiana National Guard through deployment and back home again.

title: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Copenhagen Shows
description: A glimpse at what some of the women and men were wearing in Copenhagen during the citys just-concluded fashion week.

title: Unmasters of Sex
description: One of the most compelling panels in Lena Finkles Magic Barrel, Anya Ulinichs engrossing graphic novel about the vicissitudes of love, family, immigration and art, is a full-page depiction of the title character staring into a mirror. With resolve in her deep-set eyes, she hacks away at her hair with a fearsome pair of scissors. This is Lena Finkle, and Ulinich renders her in a naturalistic style, with sophisticated use of perspective, shadowing and ink-wash technique. As Lena lops off her hair, she recalls an argument with her ex-husband. This memory is presented cartoonishly; the remembered Lenas frown is a slash, her curly hair a furious scribble.

title: You Mean Its Not Dead?
description: Michael Schmidts 1,172 pages encompass similarly big numbers. Seven hundred years of fiction are chronicled, hundreds of novelists looked at, and even more novels summarized. The biggest number of all, which can only be guessed at, wincingly, is how many hours of reading this intrepid book distills between its straining covers. Schmidt reveres Cervantes as one of the fathers of modern fiction, and there is something quixotic about Schmidts own enterprise. As the French general Bosquet said, watching the charge of the Light Brigade into the valley of death, Cest magnifique. But, to paraphrase the second half of his tribute, Ce nest pas la critique littraire. It is not literary criticism  at least not the currently approved kind that gets you a Ph.D., tenure and an endowed chair.

title: The Search Continues
description: I am convinced, Wayne C. Booth wrote in The Rhetoric of Fiction in 1961, that most novelists today . . . feel an inseparable connection between art and morality, quite apart from what it is popular to say about morality. He argued that a novelists control of narrative distance  his manipulation of the relationships among author, narrator, character and reader  has everything to do with the novels moral life. And yet we go on talking as if technical triumphs had no relation to the value of what they achieve.

title: Between God and the Fhrer
description: Coming to terms with the genocidal century just past, especially the unvarnished evil of Nazi Germany, has prompted theologians and philosophers to adjust and recalibrate much of what they thought they knew. Writers as diverse as Reinhold Niebuhr, John Pawlikowski, Richard Rubenstein and Elie Wiesel  some more successfully than others  have all struggled to reconcile the existence of the divine with unspeakable atrocities, many of them carried out in the name of God.

title: Paul McCartney Collaborates on a Video Game Score
description: Collectors of Paul McCartneys music may have to add a new format  a version of PlayStation or Xbox  to their stacks of LPs, tapes, CDs, DVDs and digital downloads. His next major project is the score for Destiny, the highly anticipated video game from Bungie and Activision, due on Sept. 9.

title: A Ranch With 1,000 Acres, for Your Inner Buckaroo
description: Most New Yorkers would barely know what to do with 1,000 square feet of space, let alone 1,000 acres. But whats to stop us from trying to figure it out.

title: The Distance Between
description: Jose Venegas, the father at the center of Maria Venegass vividly evocative memoir, Bulletproof Vest, is an outlaw in the grand tradition. He is, in other words, a moving target  sometimes mythic, sometimes depressingly real. We romanticize outlaws, which is our romantic word for criminals. I suppose it has something to do with their vitality, an extraordinary life force manifested by brilliant clothes, flamboyant sexuality, bullets and dead bodies. Even victims can be susceptible to a form of awe. And an outlaws children, of course, can be prone to a vexed and powerful love.

title: Britains Drinking Problem
description: LONDON  The British relationship with strong drink, which might be even more tangled than the American one, has taken a new twist: London is to experiment with the sobriety tags for which much success has been claimed in the United States, where the bracelets are known by a more snappy acronym, SCRAM, or Secure Continuous Remote Alcohol Monitoring. Those committing minor crimes in which alcohol has played a part will be barred from drinking for up to 120 days in a pilot program employing the alcohol-detecting anklets, which are made by a Colorado company and have been modeled by celebrities like Lindsay Lohan, Tracy Morgan and Jayson Williams.

title: Creating Captions on YouTube Videos
description: Q. Some YouTube videos have closed captioning that may be automatically generated by computer, perhaps on the fly. What software is available to caption simple videos with a clearly spoken soundtrack?

title: Movie Review Web Junkie
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Web Junkie.

title: Movie Review: The Hundred-Foot Journey
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews The Hundred-Foot Journey.

title: Book Review Podcast: All That Is Solid Melts Into Air
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Anthony Marra reviews Darragh McKeons new novel, All That Is Solid Melts Into Air, which branches out from the Chernobyl nuclear accident to tell a larger story. Mr. Marra writes:

title: Movie Review: The Dog
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Dog.

title: Today in Small Business: No Snacking
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Cava Is Overlooked Everywhere but Catalonia
description: ST.-SADURN dANOIA, Spain  If ever a grape needed a champion, it may well be xarello. It suffers pronunciation woes (in Catalan, its shah-RELL-lo; in Castilian, hah-RELL-lo; in English, zah-RELL-oh). It has spelling issues (its often written xarel-lo among numerous other renderings). Most important, it is guilty by association as a key component of cava, the Spanish sparkling wine that most people consider at best cheap and cheerful and at worst a headache in a glass.

title: In China, British Investigator Hired by Glaxo, and Wife, Sentenced to Prison
description: SHANGHAI  In spring 2013, GlaxoSmithKline, a British pharmaceutical giant, hired a firm to investigate a former employee, who was suspected of trying to smear the drugmakers top executive in China. Glaxo management told the firms British investigator that the company had received a sex video of the executive. The investigator called the case Project Scorpion.

title: Why You Lie About Where Youre From
description: I am from Chicago. I am also not from Chicago. It depends on who you ask.

title: 1914: France Reclaims Alsace
description: Official despatches made public by the French Ministry of War at 11.30 last night [Aug. 8] show that the French troops are advancing rapidly in Upper Alsace, driving the Germans before them at the point of the bayonet. Mulhouse has been occupied, and French cavalry is pursuing the fleeing Germans further to the north. The occupation of Mulhouse followed upon that of Altkirch, reported earlier in the day. The entrance of the French troops into Alsace is a historic event, which will arouse the enthusiasm of the whole French nation. The advance guard of the French army reached Altkirch at nightfall on Friday. The town was defended by very strong field works and was occupied by a German brigade. The French advance guard also consisted of a brigade. The French troops dashed to the assault with magnificent ardor. An infantry regiment, in a furious bayonet charge, carried the German trenches after a hot engagement in front of the lines. Once again the bayonet charges put the Germans to flight. The New York Herald, European Edition, August 9, 1914

title: Searching for Vintage Toilet Seats and Other Parts
description: THERE you are, performing one of the most mundane of household chores: lifting the toilet tank lid to see why the toilet wont flush. You casually lean it against the wall, and suddenly  disaster  it slides down and your lid is in several unsalvageable pieces.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Coys Classics at the Ring
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Crime Writer Signs Deal to Advertise on Jerseys
description: The space on the jersey fronts of the worlds top soccer teams is valuable real estate. Manchester Uniteds new sponsorship deal with Chevrolet will pay the club almost $80 million a year  the most of any team, anywhere. The financial food chain descends from there, as the big multinational advertisers fall away and opportunities arise in unlikely places and for unlikely prices.

title: Strikes Resume in Gaza Strip
description: Cross-border strikes between Israel and militants from Gaza resumed after a three-day cease-fire expired.

title: Home Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: What We Mean When We Say Student Debt Is Bad
description: Once again, the headlines are filled with claims that student loans are bad. Several articles have highlighted results from a Gallup poll that shows that college graduates who borrow for college are less happy, healthy and wealthy than debt-free graduates. The Gallup report (which is cautious in its interpretation of the data) has been drawn into a rising chorus of news media reports on the negative consequences of borrowing: Student loans not only make you sick but also hamper homeownership and delay marriage.

title: Going for a Run Around the World
description: After struggling with depression and anxiety in his early 20s, Kevin Carr, 34, decided mental illness must never be confused with mental weakness. He set out to prove this through extreme running. He ran 50 marathons in 50 days and then tackled the mountainous route between Lands End, England, and John OGroats, Scotland, taking a roundabout 1,200-mile, six-week journey between the two points on opposite ends of Britain. Now, he is about halfway through an around-the-world run in which he will cover more than 18,000 miles over six continents.

title: Seeing Mexico City, Guided by Architects
description: When you first arrive in Mexico City, your senses are overwhelmed by the sheer size and the never-ending hum of activity. Choosing a focal point can be exhausting. Every facet of the city seems as important as the next.

title: Restoring Acadias Trails
description: A 120-foot white pine shaded what was left of the trail. The best indication of which way to walk was an auburn arc of fallen pine needles, bending to the right. Then a small clearing. Then flecks of blue filtering through the branches and the muted growl of the Atlantic meeting the shore of Mount Desert Island, in Maine.

title: A Boy at Play in Gaza, a Renewal of Warfare, a Family in Mourning
description: GAZA CITY  Sabah Dawawsa was in the kitchen Friday morning, frying the chicken livers her 10-year-old son, Ibrahim, had requested for the after-prayer meal. With Palestinian rockets having resumed at the 8 a.m. expiration of a 72-hour cease-fire, followed by Israeli airstrikes, Ms. Dawawsa said she had told Ibrahim to stay inside, in their house in Gaza Citys Sheikh Radwan neighborhood.

title: Blast in Ukraines Capital Stirs Fears of New Conflict
description: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine  An explosion in downtown Kiev, Ukraine, on Friday injured at least two people and ignited fears of new conflict in the city, where protest barricades and tents still stand in the central square months after demonstrations that toppled the government.

title: The Magic of Swimming on Marthas Vineyard
description: A correspondent friend, whose work has taken him to hundreds of places here and abroad, has a huge map pocked with colored pins marking every place hes visited in his journalistic travels. My comparable map, which exists only in my mind, is not of the worlds majestic cities or one-stoplight towns, but of its bodies of water in which I have swum  oceans, sounds, ponds, rivers, cenotes and pools indoor and out.

title: The Flavor of Corn, but With Sizzle
description: Sweet tender corn, one of summers great joys, is in season, though it may seem too obvious to mention. Its pretty much everywhere, theres a lot of it, and its oh so easy to love.

title: Ryerson, an Old Chicago Steel Company, Slumps in Market Debut
description: Ryerson Holding, a Chicago steel distributor with a history almost as long as that of the city itself, stumbled on Friday as it began a new chapter on the public markets.

title: Restaurant Report: The Raeburn in Edinburgh
description: At first glance, the scene outside a slate-brown Georgian house in the quaint but currently trendy neighborhood of Stockbridge in Edinburgh on a Friday night is a little befuddling. The swarm of beer-toting young professionals buzzing about biergarten-style benches in the front yard implies something very casual, with a slight whiff of a dating meat market.

title: When a Mormon Teenager Takes a Transgender Journey
description: Transmormon is a short documentary detailing the life of Eri Hayward, a 25-year-old Mormon woman from Orem, Utah, who also happens to be transgender.

title: Etihad Airways Completes Deal to Buy 49% of Alitalia
description: ROME  The money-losing airline Alitalia on Friday concluded months of negotiations with a deal in which Etihad Airways of Abu Dhabi will take a 49 percent stake in it.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Where the Grande Dame of the Thriller Chills
description: Alvirah Meehan, a recurring character in the ever-expanding oeuvre of Mary Higgins Clark (46 books and counting) lives in an apartment at the fictional 211 Central Park South.

title: On Fishers Island, N.Y., Summertime Style and Flavors Run in the Family
description: Not much happens on Fishers Island, New York, pop. 236, a low-key, 9-mile-long stretch of sand east of Long Islands North Fork that can only be reached by ferry from New London, Conn. And thats just how residents and holiday regulars like it. This summer, however, one family is offering up several reasons to visit. Sisters Kate and Bronya Shillo  alongside their parents Greg and Debi Shillo, the proprietors of the no-frills Pequot Inn  have launched a spiked lemonade business, a chic beach boutique and a curated gourmet market.

title: A Tax Inversion in All but Name
description: Behold the unversion.

title: Bloombergs Bruised Legacy
description: Last year, toward the end of Michael R. Bloombergs mayoralty, many who deliberated the matter of his legacy concluded that, although he had driven inequality to untenable extremes, liked charter schools too much and perhaps heavyset people not enough, he ran New York City efficiently and, ultimately, extremely well.

title: Cars to Watch, and Wish For, at the Monterey Auctions
description: Rob Sass offers his take on some notable cars up for auction in Monterey.

title: Papers, Please!
description: By early 1864, members of the Confederate Congress had had enough. Despite their high positions in the government, for years they had suffered constant humiliation at the hands of provost marshals, military guards and passport clerks who forced them to comply with the regulations of a unique, and frustrating, feature of the Confederacy: the domestic passport system, a mechanism of population control they had never actually approved. Now they were demanding to know who had established this system in the first place, and under what authority. The answer revealed much about the nature of the Confederacy, a paradox that was, at the same time, a weak political entity and an oppressive slavocracy.

title: Driven | 2015 BMW 435i Convertible
description: A ray of sunshine, even on a cloudy day.

title: The Pesh Mergas Fight Against ISIS
description: A look at who the pesh merga are, their history as Iraqs most formidable force, and why President Obama has now authorized airstrikes against ISIS to support them.

title: The Alchemist
description: Ben Ratliff talks to Jennifer Herrema of the band Black Bananas.

title: 2014 Volkswagen Jetta GLI
description: Volkswagen has hit a rough patch, but the harsh-riding GLI wont be enough to put it back on track.

title: Video: The BMW 435i Is a Ray of Sunshine, for a Price
description: During photography of the 2015 BMW 435i convertible, I shot beautiful video of flowers, clouds, horses and scenic vistas along rural roads. Almost none of it is used in the piece. This is, after all, a car review, not a CBS Sunday Morning sound and picture piece. But, as a convertible owner myself, Im compelled to communicate what I see and smell when the top is down. Its not only about getting a deeper tan (something doctors will frown upon anyway).

title: A Two-Step Plan to Stop Hackers
description: There are a number of ways that consumers could react to the news this week that Russian hackers got their hands on 1.2 billion username and password combinations.

title: When Downtown Real Estate Turned Upward
description: Land costs for developable sites now exceed $15,000 per square foot so its official: at $100 per square inch, investors are probably even looking at telephone booths, if they can find one.

title: Popcast: The Alchemist
description: Electric Brick Wall, the second album by Black Bananas, is an extraordinary thousand-layer cake of sound-flotsam, bright scraps of riffs and funk as organized by Jennifer Herrema, our guest on this weeks Popcast. All this tossed-off stuff is my gold, she explained. Im a garbage collector.

title: Back to American Force in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Ticket | Luxury Near the Zoo for $31.86 Million
description: A full-floor condominium at 838 Fifth Avenue, an imposing 12-story limestone building originally designed by Harry M. Prince for the Union of American Hebrew Congregations in 1950 and converted to condominiums in 2000, sold for $31,861,500 and was the most expensive sale of week, according to city records.

title: Board of North Miami MOCA Announces Move to Miami
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami has moved its employees out of its city-owned building and has announced plans to set up shop with a new name elsewhere.

title: McIlroy Shines Through the Sogginess
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It was early Friday afternoon, which meant the 96th P.G.A. Championship had not even reached its halfway point. There were many hours of golf left to be played.

title: On the Market in New York City
On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Hearing Is Set on Voiding Conviction in Murder of Utah Tourist
description: A man convicted in the killing of Brian Watkins, a tourist from Utah who was protecting his family from muggers, has raised enough new evidence to warrant a full hearing on whether the verdict should be vacated, a judge ruled on Friday.

title: Airstrikes in Iraq Seen Near Erbil
description: Smoke can be seen rising from the Khazer checkpoint outside the Kurdish capital of Erbil, where targeted airstrikes were authorized against Islamic radicals.

title: A Tax Inversion in a Glass
description: You may have heard about corporate inversion this week. Thats a tax-avoidance maneuver in which an American company is acquired by a smaller foreign competitor, allowing it to move its tax residency abroad while keeping most of its operations in the United States.

title: Weekend Reading: The Business of Being a Bank
description: The weight of tens of billions of dollars in legal costs may be coming to an end for Bank of America, allowing the bank to turn its attention back to, as DealBook reported, the business of being a bank.

title: Not Enough to Smooth the Bumps
description: Volkswagen has been languishing in the United States. While its Audi luxury division has done well, the VW brand itself has been losing sales traction.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Losing It Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 55-year-old man who suddenly began to lose his leg hair, his strength and his muscle mass. I asked for the cause of the losses and the underlying disease process. More than 300 of you wrote in with suggested diagnoses. Many of you had half of it right, and a dozen of you had it totally right.

title: Bipartisan Support, With Caveats, for Obama on Iraq Airstrikes
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama drew bipartisan support on Friday from members of Congress for his decision to authorize military strikes in Iraq, but the backing was tempered with substantial concern  including within Mr. Obamas own party  about his strategy for the operation.

title: How Math Got Its Nobel
description: ON Wednesday in Seoul, the International Congress of Mathematicians will announce the winners of the Fields Medal. First awarded in Oslo in 1936, the medal is given every four years to two to four mathematicians. It is considered the Nobel Prize of mathematics (even the organizers of the congress call it that), filling a gap left by Alfred Nobel, who did not include mathematics among the prizes endowed on his death in 1896.

title: Voice Recognition Still a Top Complaint, Study Says
description: The technology in new cars that bedevils drivers more than any other is voice recognition.

title: For Car Lovers, Summer Peaks on the California Coast
description: The annual celebration of the automobile on the Monterey Peninsula of California, a vintage-car enthusiasts version of the Academy Awards, hits the starter button this week.

title: Much to Do Around Monterey
description: The number of concours, tours, car shows and galas surrounding the Pebble Beach concours and auctions seems to grow each year. Here are some of the events around the Monterey peninsula scheduled for the coming week:

title: As Dealers Settle In, Residential Developers Come Knocking
description: The history of real estate in Manhattan is one of ebbs and flows. The diamond district moved from Canal Street to Midtown, the citys banks have gravitated from Wall Street to Park Avenue, and the theater district shifted north to Times Square.

title: At a Brooklyn Institution, Old School Goes iPad
description: Jerry Costigliola has spent 29 years, or more than half his life, working at Gargiulos, the Brooklyn restaurant and Coney Island institution. In all that time, Mr. Costigliola, 45, has relied on a pad and pen to scribble orders of linguine in clam sauce and fried mozzarella. But three months ago, he traded in his paper for an iPad.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Gaza City and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Iraq, Syria and Turkey.

title: Watergates Emotional Legacy
description: This morning, Linda Wertheimer of NPR recalled her days covering the resignation of President Richard Nixon for the same network 40 years ago.

title: After Decades in Exile, a South African Writers Remains Will Head Home
description: On a July morning nearly half a century ago, Nat Nakasa, a black South African living in exile in New York, plummeted from a seventh-story window on Central Park West and 102nd Street in Manhattan, suffering multiple fractures and internal injuries. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Knickerbocker Hospital in Harlem. Mr. Nakasa was 28 years old.

title: 90-Year-Old Sex Columnist Shatters Taboos in India
description: MUMBAI, India  EVERY morning, a 90-year-old newspaper columnist named Mahinder Watsa takes a seat in the study of his apartment, where, on a good day, a breeze lofts in from the direction of the Arabian Sea.

title: Iraq Strikes Seen as Giving Putin Pretext in Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  The president orders his military into action in a war-torn country to protect a vulnerable population, authorizing strikes in service of a humanitarian mission. That was President Obama on Thursday. But it could be President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in the not-too-distant future.

title: N.C.A.A.s Vote on Autonomy Generates Criticism
description: The decision on Thursday by the N.C.A.A. Division I board of directors to grant more autonomy to the wealthiest conferences in college sports was the subject of contentious deliberations for many months. But momentum had built for a big change.

title: Crossing Rivers, Searching for the Future
description: In his years covering immigration, Nick Oza has assembled a body of work that reflects the complexity of human beings flowing across borders.

title: Bill Cunningham | Gray Is the New Black
description: Gray is the summer shade in the city.

title: Share Your Hijab Fashion on Instagram
description: For many Muslim women around the world, the hijab  the scarf covering their hair  is not just a religious accouterment but also a symbol of their identity.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Bill Cunningham | Gray Matters
description: A woman on Fifth Avenue wore a T-shirt proclaiming GREY IS THE NEW BLACK. Gray is the summer shade in the city. There are gray handbags; note the briefcase of a man in a gray suit and shirt. Silver jewelry and gray pearls add to the effect. And women with gray hair are having a fashion moment.

title: Read This Before You Write Your Dating Profile
description: Do you have a tattoo on your back? Would you let your kid jump on a trampoline? Are you happy?

title: The Youngest Are Hungriest
description: WHY are Indian children so short?

title: Miami Grows Up. A Little.
description: MIAMI  IF you had asked me what I wanted when I was 12 years old, I probably would have said, to marry a plastic surgeon.

title: Pity the Poor Working Artist in Las Vegas
description: The Step Up series is the rare franchise that has grown more ambitious with each installment. As the dance numbers have become flashier and splashier, the stories have become more fanciful, occasionally even supplementing their be-yourself bromides with socially engaged ideas.

title: Evening Hours | Sentimental Journeys
description: A benefit in the country, and a centennial in the city.

title: He Rarely Stops Writing
description: The Hungarian novelist Laszlo Krasznahorkai isnt exactly a late bloomer. Its just that the English-speaking world has been tardy in discovering what European readers already know: If gloom, menace and entropy are your thing, then Laszlo is your man.

title: The Half-Century-Long Renovation of Rundale Palace, the Versailles of Latvia
description: Last May, Rundale Palace, a 18th-century Baroque palace in Latvia, celebrated the completion of 50 years of renovation work with the opening of the Dukes Library, one of several rooms finally open to the public for the first time. The Duke in question was Ernst Johann von Biron, the Duke of Courland, for whom the palace was built between 1736 and 1740 by the Italian architect Francesco Bartolomeo Rastrelli as a summer residence. It boasts 54 rooms, including a 1770s-era billiards room and a banquet hall known as the Great Gallery, which have also finally been restored to their original splendor. Some have called the palace the Versailles of Latvia.

title: With This Ships Shackle I Thee Wed
description: John Doswell and his longtime partner, Jean Preece, were married July 25 aboard the John J. Harvey, a decommissioned fireboat, on the Hudson River.

title: Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams
description: LAS VEGAS  At the Summer Nationals here last month, the Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams had an exciting final round.

title: All Brahms, by the (Smaller) Numbers
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival has been offering more varied fare lately, but plenty of it still looks staid. At first glance, an overture-concerto-symphony program of Brahms, Brahms and Brahms  with encores of Brahms  appears conservative. But it didnt turn out that way with Paavo Jarvi and the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen, who stormed through this Thursday concert at Alice Tully Hall with a rare intensity.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Burned by Losses on Portuguese Bank Bonds, Hedge Funds Ponder Next Steps
description: Hedge fund investors, furious at having their bond holdings in Portugals Banco Esprito Santo written down to zero, are weighing a legal action against Portuguese regulators.

title: A Letter to the President, and a Well-Timed Response
description: In June, a Marine Corps veteran named David Nelson wrote a letter to President Obama expressing concern that the rapid advances of Islamist militants in northern Iraq might prompt the United States to send troops back to bolster the shaky government in Baghdad. In his letter, Mr. Nelson, who was a judge advocate during the Vietnam War, wondered whether the Obama administration might use the successes of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, much the way President Lyndon B. Johnson used confrontations between North Vietnamese torpedo boats and an American destroyer in August 1964 to justify expanded military action in Vietnam.

title: A Voyage That Is Finally Complete
description: As a girl in St. Petersburg, Fla., in the 1940s and 50s, Jean Preece lived for her dance lessons and the 50-cent double feature at the local movie hall, where she sat transfixed as Gene Kelly and Debbie Reynolds cavorted in Singin in the Rain. She was so devoted to the film that years later, when she was working with a New York-based Spanish dance troupe visiting Madrid, she saw that the movie was playing in a local theater, in Spanish, and went. It did not matter that she spoke almost no Spanish; it was about the songs, the dancing. She knew what she wanted in a movie.

title: The Murakami Effect
description: This week our cover features Patti Smiths review of the new Haruki Murakami novel, Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage. Murakami is, of course, an internationally best-selling author with a huge following here and in Japan, where this most recent novel sold one million copies in its first week.Murakami always merits attention in the Book Review. His last book, 1Q84, was reviewed on our cover by Kathryn Schulz, now the book critic at New York magazine. Even before we had our review assigned, we were pretty sure this new novel, which was unusually  for a major literary novel  released in the summer rather than the fall, would merit a cover review. (Even in a year when Murakami doesnt have a new book, he can wind up in the Book Review, as he did in this delightful Sketchbook Grant Snider did for us two years ago, Haruki Murakami Bingo.)

title: Where Big Stars and Little Stars Shine, for a Bargain
description: VAIL, Colo.  Every summer, the Vail International Dance Festival presents one evening when the prices match the year  sort of. So in 2013, all seats in the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater were $20.13, with all places on the lawn going for $13; this year theyre $20.14 and $14. (Children 12 or under sit free on the lawn.) Obviously, this system wont last beyond 2020, but while it does, it has extraordinary value.

title: A Trip to the Big City
description: I knew what I was up against the moment I opened the Save the Date email. It was from a childhood friend, begging me to bring my parents to her summer wedding in New York City. It would mean so much to me to see your folks sitting in the church, she wrote. It would be as if my own parents were there, she added of her now deceased mother and father.

title: Tennessee Ignores the Koch Brothers
description: Participants in Tennessees judicial elections on Thursday rejected a malodorous effort to oust three capable sitting state Supreme Court justices: Chief Justice Gary Wade and Justices Cornelia Clark and Sharon Lee.

title: An Old Love Story, Tinkered for the Times
description: In his two-act staging of Acis and Galatea at the David H. Koch Theater, Mark Morris plunges his audience into the heart of the pastoral genre. He sets the love story of the shepherd Acis and the sea nymph Galatea within a landscape chorally filled with lovers. Though, on the one hand, these other people are anonymous, its as if they were Daphnis and Chloe, Phyllis and Corydon, and all the amorous couples created by Theocritus, Virgil, Longus and other classical authors. On the other, its as if they were nature itself. And so Acis and Galatea  whose story is found in the Metamorphoses of Ovid  become part of a long tradition of the classical idyll in which love is interrupted by death.

title: Court Rejects Deal on Hiring in Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There is ample evidence that Silicon Valley was engaged in an overarching conspiracy against its own employees, a federal judge said on Friday, and it should either pay dearly or have its secrets exposed at trial.

title: Sacred Music and Movement, With an Infectious Beat
description: You dont generally go to a performance of Bharatanatyam, the classical South Indian dance style, expecting to want to get up and dance. The form inspires a more removed kind of reverence, as something to be admired from afar, like a sacred object.

title: Theres Always Someone Youre Smarter Than
description: Its basic economics: If you have a natural resource, try to exploit it. One resource we have in abundance is stupidity, and televisions long history of exploiting it continues with two new shows in the next few days, one whose title is its most attention-getting feature, the other equally drab but in different ways.

title: Story Lines (and More) Assembled in Parts
description: The playwright Gary Winter has created a monster. Kind of. In Daredevil, at the Brick, hes invented a character, Missy, who assembles a creature out of various corpses. He just needs a finger  then hes done, she explains proudly.

title: Less Like a Chef, More Like an Actor
description: Im going to give you a preface, Manish Dayal said. Im not a chef. I just play one in a movie.

title: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Revised
description: Miss Rae Cassidy, love Charlene Kaye, love the evolving stage presence of the band, hate the haircuts  but hey, its Brooklyn. Theyre in Prospect Park tomorrow night:

title: Choice Cuts: Zero Freitass Rarest Records
description: In this weeks magazine, Monte Reel writes about Zero Freitas, a Brazilian bus magnate whose personal mission is to buy up all of the worlds vinyl records. Among the several million he has amassed so far, stored in a 25,000-square-foot warehouse in So Paulo, are some rare albums that could easily sell for thousands of dollars on eBay. Heres a sampling of 10 from his collection.

title: For a Bit of Broadway, Turn Left at Space Mountain
description: For amusement park fans, summer is all about new rides. But if taking the 180-foot drop at the recently opened Goliath roller coaster at Six Flags Great America sounds like an afternoon gone horribly wrong, a new batch of live shows offers more down-to-earth pleasures.

title: Facebooks Change of Face
description: On my Facebook page this week, I shared a photo of my daughter wearing a melted chocolate ice cream bar on her face. I also reposted a cartoon Id seen on a yoga teachers page of one half of an avocado chasing the other half with the caption, I said youre the good kind of fat!

title: Coroner Is Said to Rule James Bradys Death a Homicide, 33 Years After a Shooting
description: WASHINGTON  The death this week of James S. Brady, the former White House press secretary, has been ruled a homicide 33 years after he was wounded in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan, police department officials here said Friday.

title: CrossFit Flirting: Talk Burpee to Me
description: On a recent Saturday night at the Promenade Bar and Grill in the Kips Bay neighborhood of Manhattan, the gym buddies Festa Radoni, 26, and Ellen Gerlach, 29, flexed their biceps, comparing muscles as a male friend snapped photos.

title: His Own Redemption Story
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For a time, in the 1990s, there were few celebrity journalists who lived quite as large as Vanity Fairs Kevin Sessums. He smoked a joint with Heath Ledger in Prague. He interviewed Courtney Love while she soaked in a tub. He crawled into a bed with Cher.

title: Finding Sharp Differences in the Similarities
description: An opening act can work as a warm-up or an appetizer, but sometimes the main function of the show before the show is contrastive, putting into relief the virtues of the main event. Such was the case at SummerStage in Central Park on Wednesday, when Sidra Bell Dance New York opened for Spectrum Dance Theater from Seattle.

title: Rihannas Legal Maneuver, Kate Mosss Run-In With Justin Bieber and Lupita NyongOs Latest Honor
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Under Cover: Decidedly D.I.Y.
description: Libertarians are the acerbic sideline critics of American political theater, Robert Draper writes in this weeks cover story  but now they find themselves in the spotlight, trying to capitalize on their potential to reach young voters. Today, for perhaps the first time, the libertarian movement appears to have genuine political momentum on its side.

title: Watching Your Back, and Whats on It
description: If there were a sartorial equivalent of email spam, T-shirts adorned with logos and messages might well be it  fast fashion easily dismissed with barely a flick of the eye.

title: Sunday Routine: Khajak Keledjian
description: Mr. Keledjian, the co-founder and C.E.O. of Intermix, meditates at his home in Sagaponack, on Long Island.

title: Khajak Keledjian: Zero to 60, and Back Again
description: Khajak Keledjian, 41, is the co-founder and C.E.O. of Intermix, a luxury fashion retailer that was sold to the Gap for $130 million in 2012. Lebanese by birth, Mr. Keledjian moved with his siblings from Beirut to Manhattan when he was a teenager. In 1993, at 19 years old, he opened the first Intermix store with his brother. Mr. Keledjians wife, Maryam, a former lingerie model who now works in fashion sales, is expecting their first child. In the summer, the couple spend most weekends at their 4,000-square-foot home in Sagaponack, on Long Island.

title: Judge Threatens Argentina With Contempt Over Its Statements
description: At times the battle between a group of New York hedge funds and the country of Argentina feels more like a game of legal Ping-Pong than a case involving billions of dollars at stake.

title: Medicine Man and Mayor, Blended
description: On the corner of Fulton Street and South Elliot Place in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, theres a distinctive summer soundtrack: the whirring of blenders, the crunch of pressed sugarcane and the occasional thwack of a machete opening a coconut.The source of it all is a nattily dressed man who, depending on the day, might be wearing a white linen suit and straw boater, a newsboy cap and striped dungarees, or a kilt. And who, like his seven-year-old juice stand, is known as Coconut Rob.

title: N.C.A.A. Must Allow Colleges to Pay Athletes, Judge Rules
description: In a decision that could drastically reshape the world of college sports, a federal judge ruled on Friday that the N.C.A.A.s decades-old rules barring payments to college athletes were in violation of antitrust laws.

title: Cold and Sweet, No Trip to the Jersey Shore Necessary
description: As a child, Emma Taylor spent summers eating Kohr Brothers frozen custard with rainbow jimmies on the Jersey Shore.

title: G.M.s Woes Multiply as It Announces Further Recalls
description: Defective ignitions continue to plague General Motors, which on Friday recalled more than 312,000 vehicles worldwide, bringing its total this year above 29 million cars.

title: Recollections, Past and Future
description: The French filmmaker Chris Marker (1921-2012) has been described as a cine-essayist, which is true but inadequate. His movies are the work of a poet and collagist and slightly obsessive philosopher, who roams widely but keeps looping back to a potently cinematic theme: memory. BAMcinmateks retrospective Chris Marker also roams widely, providing a chance for the curious to catch up on films from his best-known works, like La Jete (1962), a time-traveling meditation on war and (of course) memory, made up mostly of still photographs, to Level Five (1997), receiving its North American theatrical premiere in a weeklong run (Friday through Aug. 21).

title: Cashew Juice, the Apple of Pepsis Eye
description: RATNAGIRI DISTRICT, India  When the cashew harvest starts here, the orchards clinging to the lush, wrinkled hills are blanketed by a brilliant yellow, orange and red carpet, created after farmers pluck the nut and toss its stem to the ground. There, the cashew apples, as the stems are known, quickly rot, except for a few used to brew a local spirit called feni that is popular in neighboring Goa.

title: Defense Seeks to Move Trial on Boston Marathon Bombing
description: BOSTON  Citing an overwhelmingly massive and prejudicial storm of media coverage here, lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in last years bombings at the Boston Marathon, pressed their case this week for moving his trial to Washington.

title: Chimney Swift: Suited for Ashes and Soot
description: Dark and streamlined, chimney swifts dart past, their long, stiff wings in constant motion as they chase tiny flying food like mosquitoes, gnats, flies and beetles. The birds are well named. Appearing completely black against a bright sky, when examined closely they are colored exactly as if they really had flown through a chimney  virtually uniform except for a slightly paler gray patch under their throats.

title: U.S. Jews and Israel: Support and Criticism
description: To the Editor:

title: School Lessons, From South Korea to Finland
description: To the Editor:

title: Facebook Messenger Switch Controversy Is Part Misunderstanding, Part Mistrust
description: The great Facebook Messenger migration is upon us, and Facebook users are not happy.

title: Claims Against BP
description: To the Editor:

title: Khmer Rouge Convictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Ex-Governors Trial Keeps Focus on Key Donors Character
description: RICHMOND, Va.  The corporate mentor of the dietary supplement executive who lavished gifts on former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia denounced the businessman on Friday as someone who continually put politics above science and jeopardized his company as he tried to curry favor.

title: Yields on 10-Year Treasuries Fall, Confounding the Experts
description: The mantra in the bond market over the last several years has been that yields will inevitably rise. From time to time, that has even been true. But not lately, and especially not on Friday.

title: Its a Cant-Lose Year
description: Wow, it appears that Republicans in Tennessee just gave a vote of confidence to a right-wing congressman-doctor who has a history of having sex with his patients and encouraging the women in his life to end inconvenient pregnancies by abortion.

title: Taking the Express to Zen
description: Max Dixon  handyman, hobbyist, household tinkerer  says he has not used the subway in nearly 25 years and couldnt even guess what the fare is now.

title: 29 States Seek Tighter E-Cigarette Regulations
description: Twenty-nine state attorneys general on Friday urged the Food and Drug Administration to strengthen its proposed regulations on electronic cigarettes, a business that has exploded into a $2.5 billion industry with virtually no regulatory oversight.

title: Half a Ton of This, Half a Ton of That: Russia Is Calm Over Food Import Bans
description: MOSCOW  When the chef Jonas Grip heard that the latest Russian sanctions included banning all fish imports from Europe, he instantly called his Russian suppliers.

title: Tiny Lead for Incumbent in Tennessee Primary Vote
description: MURFREESBORO, Tenn.  Less than two years after tawdry details of his divorce and extramarital relationships burst into public view, Representative Scott DesJarlais, Republican of Tennessee, held a minuscule advantage on Friday in a primary election battle that could become a startling example of political survival.

title: Inquiry Seeks Twitter User in Brooklyn Bridge Flag Case
description: The Twitter account purportedly representing an all-powerful coalition of radical cyclists has claimed responsibility for knocking out Metro-North Railroad service, swinging the World Series and strong-arming Bruce Springsteen into changing a song title to Thunder Lane.

title: Speaking Openly, but Giving Conflicting Accounts of Knockout Game Assaults
description: The man accused of playing the so-called Knockout Game, sucker-punching unsuspecting strangers in Brooklyn late last year, nodded politely and held open the front door of his home on Friday.

title: Nazi Spies and New York Perspectives
description: The opening credits to the 1945 spy thriller The House on 92nd Street, released just a month after Hiroshima, coyly proclaim that the film could not be made public until the first atomic bomb was dropped on Japan.

title: Living, and Leaving, the Dream
description: Sitting in a Greenwich Village cafe one afternoon this spring, Adrian Cardenas was hunched over a laptop with a cup of coffee in one hand. With books tumbling out of a backpack on the floor next to him, he looked every bit a college student as he animatedly discussed his latest poetry.

title: Questions on Telephone Poles and Subway Globes
description: Q. I know there are no telephone poles in Manhattan, where all utility wires are supposed to be strung underground. But how many utility poles are there in the other boroughs?

title: Motorbikers in North Korea Are Told to Park to Save Fuel
description: SEOUL, South Korea  It is no secret that North Korea suffers chronic shortages of fuel, to the point that nighttime satellite photographs of the Korean Peninsula show a glittering south and a darkened north, beginning exactly at the 38th parallel that divides them. Now the scarcity, apparently made even worse by a drop in oil imports from China, has claimed a new class of victims: motorbike riders.

title: Guided by History, a Jew Tries to Unite Two Faiths Divided by War in Gaza
description: NEWARK, Del.  Shortly after the latest cease-fire expired in Gaza on Friday, Jacob Bender gingerly climbed the steps of the mimbar, the pulpit at the Islamic Society of Delaware here. A Jew in a mosque, his hands palpably quivering but his reedy voice steady, he read some brief comments to close the afternoons worship service, called Jumaa.

title: Massachusetts: Health Site Will Stay State-Based
description: Officials saidFridaythat they would use a retooled state health exchange website for this falls open enrollment period. The Massachusetts Health Connector was established by the states 2006 health overhaul law, butit sputtered when it was updated to comply with the Affordable Care Act, sending 250,000 people to temporary coverage. In the spring, Connector officials decided to buy new software for the state health insurance marketplace while preparing to join the federal exchange if necessary. They metThursdaywith federal officials, who supported the decision to move forward with the state-based exchange. Connector officials plan to contact up to 450,000 individuals, including those with temporary or legacy coverage, who need to apply this fall for plans that comply with the Affordable Care Act.

title: Dashing Good Looks With a Menu to Match
description: On a November night swirling with snow, weeks before the Inn at Pound Ridge by Jean-Georges opened, I caught a glimpse of white toques bobbing under bright lights in the new kitchen as I drove past. The late hour, and the formality of the toques, somehow spoke to the seriousness of the enterprise.

title: De Blasio to Gather Clergy on Police-Community Divide
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, under increasing pressure to contain an escalating controversy over aggressive policing, said on Friday that he would convene a meeting of religious leaders led by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan to heal and deepen the relationship between the police and community leaders.

title: Turkey Votes for a President
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan Erdogan is considered the leading candidate as Turkey conducts its first direct election for president.

title: Frustrated and Clutching His Back, Woods Misses the Cut
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Whether Tiger Woods would, or even should, play in this weeks P.G.A. Championship generated a great deal of debate, given the state of his back. But the poor state of his game over 36 holes at Valhalla Golf Club, the site of one of his most notable victories, left little doubt that 2014 would go down as another lost season for him.

title: Turkeys Premier Tries to Keep Power, as President
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Just before Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogans motorcade swept into the airport here, workers rolled up a red carpet that had been used for the departing president and put down a turquoise one for Mr. Erdogan.

title: New Jersey Republican Killed in Apparent Murder-Suicide
description: A former county clerk who served as a Republican freeholder alongside Gov. Chris Christie in the 1990s was found dead in her home this week with her husband in what the authorities said Friday was an apparent murder-suicide.

title: Out-of-State Clinic Is Central in Texas Abortion Law Fight
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Of all the clinics and facilities at the center of a federal lawsuit challenging Texas sweeping abortion law passed last year, one has stuck out.

title: A Water-Propelled Jetpack
description: Jetpack America instructors and their customers fly over water in Newport Beach Harbor.

title: New York Settles Lawsuit Over Man Killed by Police Car
description: The family of Tamon Robinson, who was killed two years ago by a patrol car at a housing project in Canarsie, Brooklyn, has reached a $2 million wrongful-death settlement with New York City.

title: Thrill Ride Flies in the Face of Gravity, as Well as Cautious Officials
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  When the jetpacks first began flying here a few years ago, they were their own best form of advertising. Residents and tourists would see a person strapped to a small water-propelled rocket, whooshing high above the ocean, then wander into the small storefront tucked behind a bayside dock and ask, Can I do that, too?

title: Keep Planes a Quiet Space
description: Cellphones have provided humanity with many benefits. They have also enabled the most annoying among us to find new ways to disturb the peace in all sorts of public places, like trains, theaters and restaurants. One shared space that has heretofore been protected from the chattering of cellphone users may soon join that list: airplanes.

title: Spot on U.S. Ryder Cup Team Is Possibility for Stricker
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Among those making a charge at Rory McIlroy in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship was 47-year-old Steve Stricker, who, earlier this week, was picked as an assistant captain on the United States Ryder Cup team. That was meant to signal that Stricker, who now plays sparingly on the PGA Tour, would not likely be a competitive member of the team.

title: A Misguided Tobacco Proposal
description: The Food and Drug Administration has received thousands of comments on a proposed rule to regulate electronic cigarettes, cigars and other tobacco products. Among its important criteria is a cost-benefit analysis that strikes us as misguided, if not absurd.

title: Keeping Track: Another Labor Suit for Apple, Stop-and-Frisk
description: Apples Labor Violations

title: Judge Backs New Limits on North Carolina Voting
description: ATLANTA  A federal judge in North Carolina on Friday rejected an effort by civil rights groups and the Justice Department to block the application of key elements of a Republican-backed state law that curtailed early voting and other opportunities for residents to cast their ballots.

title: In Pursuit of the Perfect Pie
description: For 40 years or more, Ive been on a search for the perfect pie. Part of it may be false nostalgia: Mom was no pie maker, and the only pies that I remember from my childhood were the gummy but delicious slices behind the peepholes of Horn & Hardarts Automat.

title: Arrest in New Jersey Boys Death Stirs Memories, but Mysteries Remain
description: Michelle Lodzinskis screams rose above the din of clanging rides and carnival games. It was a spring evening in 1991, and she told anyone who was listening that she had brought her 5-year-old son to the carnival in Sayreville, N.J. Now, he was missing.

title: Florida Redraws an Election Map That Was Ruled to Be Unconstitutional
description: MIAMI  With Floridas election schedule in disarray after a judge ruled the states congressional map unconstitutional, state lawmakers moved one step closer to resolving the uncertainty during a special session on Friday in Tallahassee.

title: To Curb Drug Use, an Electronic Music Concert in Brooklyn Restricts What Guests Can Bring
description: After a series of drug-related deaths at electronic dance music concerts across the country and in Canada, an unusual set of safety measures has been put in place for a similar outdoor show scheduled for Saturday in Coney Island.

title: Swinging Joints
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I prematurely gave myself a big head by starting in the northwestern sector of Josh Knapps twisty Saturday puzzle. Once I had that filled in, however, things sort of crawled to a snails pace  as opposed to a NAUTILUSs  and it took me much longer to finish the puzzle than I had anticipated, considering that it only had 64 entries.

title: Obama on the World
description: President Obamas hair is definitely grayer these days, and no doubt trying to manage foreign policy in a world of increasing disorder accounts for at least half of those gray hairs. (The Tea Party can claim the other half.) But having had a chance to spend an hour touring the horizon with him in the White House Map Room late Friday afternoon, its clear that the president has a take on the world, born of many lessons over the last six years, and he has feisty answers for all his foreign policy critics.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 8, 2014
Obama on Israel
description: Thomas L. Friedman asks President Obama if he is worried about Israels survival. This is an excerpt of the full interview.

title: Obama on Americas Place in the World
description: President Obama talks to Thomas L. Friedman about how the United States can be a benevolent force as well as a superpower. This is an excerpt of the full interview.

title: Differences Between Israel and U.N. Over Gaza Episodes Go Back Years
description: UNITED NATIONS  Israel said Gaza militants had been firing from inside what it called a booby-trapped United Nations school. Its forces responded with mortar rounds that exploded in front of the school, wounding seven people who had taken shelter inside and killing many more outside.

title: This Is Reform?
description: TOO little, too late.

title: A Front Line Against Ebola Runs Through Newarks Terminal B
description: Erica J. Sison has dealt with sick and dead dogs and cats, 40 dead lab rats in bags, trophy animals, cooked monkey meat on sticks, human skulls from Indonesia and a live Asian bat that flew out of an airplane cargo hold.

title: When a Car Loan Means Bankruptcy
description: The mortgage industry set the stage for the recession by luring people into ruinously priced loans they could never hope to repay, then selling those loans to Wall Street in mortgage-backed securities that went bad. The federal government has since tamed that industry, outlawing most of the risky and deceptive practices that led to that crisis. It must now do the same with the auto lending industry, where the practice of roping people into loans that damage them financially is all too common.

title: A Spot for Local Tastes and Good Cheer
description: In an ideal world, a restaurant should function not just as a place to eat, but as a hub for kinship and connection. By that logic, an eatery that enlivens and elevates a community deserves special recognition, even if whats happening in the kitchen isnt always magical.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Gets View of Detroit Outside Courtroom
description: DETROIT  Judge Steven W. Rhodes, who is overseeing Detroits reorganization in federal bankruptcy court, took a bus tour of the city on Friday, ahead of hearings later this month on a proposed plan of adjustment.

title: While Offering Support, Obama Warns That U.S. Wont Be Iraqi Air Force
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that he was open to supporting a sustained effort to drive Sunni militants out of Iraq if Iraqi leaders form a more inclusive government, even as he vowed that the United States had no intention of being the Iraqi air force.

title: OBannon Case Decision
description: Judge Claudia Wilkens 99-page decision issued a resounding rebuke to the foundation of the N.C.A.A., issuing an injunction against current rules that prohibit athletes from earning money from the use of their names and images in video games and television broadcasts.

title: Fear of Another Benghazi Drove White House to Airstrikes in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  On Wednesday evening, moments after finishing a summit meeting with African leaders at the State Department, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff delivered a stark message to President Obama as they rode back to the White House in Mr. Obamas limousine.

title: Rudderless Craft to Get Glimpse of Home Before Sinking Into Spaces Depths
description: A 36-year-old NASA spacecraft, still largely in working condition, will zip through Earths neighborhood on Sunday for the first time in decades before receding again into the solar system.

title: A World Desperate for a Little Good News
description: The world is too much with us, wrote the poet, a sentiment President Obama most likely shared this past week as he reluctantly ordered warplanes back over Iraq. As he did so, another Israeli-Palestinian cease-fire ended in resumed bombardment, Vladimir V. Putin defiantly ordered his own sanctions against the West and a terrible virus spread farther through West Africa.

title: Love Reaches the Technologically Challenged
description: When Leo went to an eye doctor, he says, he was told that there was good news and bad. The bad news was that he would soon be blind. And the good news? I didnt have to renew my prescription.
