title: What the OBannon Ruling Means for Colleges and Players
description: The landmark decision in the so-called OBannon case that found that the N.C.A.A. violated antitrust laws may be precedent setting and may ultimately cost colleges hundreds of millions of dollars. But it is unlikely to create a windfall for any individual athlete. In her 99-page decision, Judge Claudia Wilken laid out the justification for her injunction.

title: China Looks to High-Speed Rail to Expand Reach
description: BEIJING  A favorite export from China to its neighbors these days are high-speed rail lines designed to make trade routes in the vast stretches of Asia more accessible and fortify Chinese dreams of turning its southern reaches into the capital of mainland Southeast Asia.

title: Idris Muhammad, Drummer Whose Beat Still Echoes, Dies at 74
description: Idris Muhammad, a drummer whose deep groove propelled both a broad career in jazz and an array of hits spanning rhythm and blues, funk and soul, died on July 29 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 74.

title: Fiddling and Matchmaking, 50 Years Later
description: In the theater, some things are sacrosanct. Nobody will cut Hamlets To be or not to be speech. Godot will never arrive. And there will always be a bottle dance in Fiddler on the Roof. Moreover, it will bring down the house, as it did when the show opened on Broadway 50 years ago and as it does in the tender, impeccable revival at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam.

title: The Knick Recap: Blood, Scalpels and a Good Dose of Racism for 1900 New York
description: Season 1, Episode 1, Method and Madness

title: Lessons From Libya
description: Barack Obama discusses what hes learned about foreign policy during his presidency. This is an excerpt of his full video interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

title: Before Victory, Mets Look to Future With Decision on Shortstop
description: PHILADELPHIA  Over the All-Star break, Wilmer Flores walked into a parlor in Las Vegas and got his first tattoo. He decided on a bracelet design that wrapped around his right wrist. He had no particular reason for going, and the design carried no significance.

title: Flugelhorns and Fame, by Way of Serbia
description: Michael Ginsburg, a lean man with a lifetime of teaching gym behind him, might at first seem more suited to the ball field than the bandstand, knocking out Balkan tunes. But as he worked his way through a selection of such tunes last month, coaxing an expertly controlled vibrato and adroitly turned ornaments out of his rotary valve flugelhorn, the Yonkers resident was clearly in his element.

title: Phelps Shakes Off Rust in His Favorite Event
description: IRVINE, Calif.  Linus van Pelt, the Peanuts character, has his blue blanket; Michael Phelps, the swimming star, has the 100-meter butterfly. There is no greater source of security for Phelps, the three-time reigning Olympic champion in the event who has had a lock on the world record for the past five years, including the 18 months he spent retired.

title: Iraqis Squandered Opportunities
description: President Obama explains that the United States military cannot do for the Iraqis what they wont do for themselves. This is an excerpt of a full video interview.

title: Chapman Pincher, Fleet St. Scoop Specialist, Dies at 100
description: Chapman Pincher was ballyhooed by his own newspaper, The London Daily Express, as the worlds greatest reporter, and he introduced himself as such. He insinuated himself into the murky world of spy chiefs, generals, politicians and royalty by taking them to lunch at a fine French restaurant, say, or joining them for pheasant hunting and salmon fishing.

title: A Soundtrack for His Ears Only
description: In a flashback to an experience when he was 7 years old, Parker, the bewildered hero of My Life Is a Musical, discovers that he is apparently the only person who hears people bursting into song all around him every day. His mother tries to teach him the difference between song and spoken conversation by demonstrating: This is singing. This is talking. But the audience hears her as he does, trilling with operatic abandon (in a funny performance by Wendi Bergamini) during the second sentence as well as the first.

title: China as a Free Rider
description: President Obama on how the United States is a different sort of superpower from China. This is an excerpt of a full video interview by Thomas L. Friedman.

title: Yankees Continue to Use Stadium to Their Advantage
description: Through the end of its 85-year tenure, the old Yankee Stadium remained a place where opposing teams feared playing. The lore grew to the point that ghosts were rumored to inhabit the building.

title: Corrections: August 9, 2014
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 9, 2014
description: Fifty percent of my questions are about why their hair is not falling out. It is the zillionth time I have answered it.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) OUTLANDER Claire Randall (Caitriona Balfe, above), an English combat nurse, touches a druid monument while on her honeymoon in Scotland and is transported back to the 18th century, where shes kidnapped by Highlanders and meets the sensitive hunk Jamie (Sam Heughan) in this new series, adapted from the novels by Diana Gabaldon. The Outlander books date to 1991, but it seems likely that TV executives looked at them and thought, oh, Game of Thrones meets Downton Abbey, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. Ms. Balfe, Mr. Heughan and Tobias Menzies as the modern husband (who also pops up, inconveniently, in 1743) acquit themselves well, sharing the screen with the scenery and costumes and keeping straight faces through all the fantasy-romance conceits. They seem to be having a good time, and if you have a weakness for muskets, accents and the occasional roll in the heather, you probably will too.

title: Analytics: Common Denominators
description: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the Aug. 10 issue of the magazine.

title: 2 Hawaii Democrats Face Tough Primary Challenges
description: HONOLULU  With two hurricanes bearing down toward his state, Gov. Neil Abercrombie refused to discuss this weekends Democratic primary election in which he is fighting to preserve his political life.

title: Obsessed? Bewildered? Ask Dr. Mahinder Watsa
description: For nine years, Mahinder Watsa, 90, has been shocking Indian sensibilities with his Ask the Sexpert column for The Mumbai Mirror. Tens of thousands of people have sought advice on a variety of issues, including the size and shape of penises, fears of masturbation and hymen reconstruction. Following are selections from his correspondence published in The Mumbai Mirror and a site created by his fans.

title: At Bletchley Park, a Reminder About the History of Cracking Codes
description: Hackers are regularly in the news these days for cracking secret codes, so its sometimes easy to forget that breaking codes has a long history. The newly restored Bletchley Park heritage site in Britain offers a nice reminder.

title: Dispute Between Amazon and Hachette Takes an Orwellian Turn
description: Maybe Amazon really is rattled by the wholeAuthors United phenomenon organized by Douglas Preston. The writers are encouraging their readers to email Jeff Bezos, the Amazon chief executive, and tell him to stop holding books hostage asthe companynegotiates with Hachette Book Group.

title: Iraq Airstrikes May Continue for Months, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said on Saturday that the airstrikes and humanitarian assistance drops he ordered last week in Iraq could go on for months, preparing Americans for an extended military presence in the skies there as Iraqs leaders try to build a new government.

title: Libertarian Fantasies
description: Robert Drapers long magazine piece about the possibility of a libertarian moment has drawn a fair bit of commentary; much of it involves questioning the supposed polling evidence. As Jonathan Chait points out, independent polling  as opposed to surveys conducted by libertarians seeking to boost their own profile  suggests that young Americans are actually much more pro-government than their elders. They may look relatively kindly on anti-war libertarians, but they really dont support the policy agenda.

title: Sarah Barnett of SundanceTV: Your Imperfection Can Be Your Strength
description: This interview with  Sarah Barnett, president of SundanceTV, a cable and satellite network owned by AMC Networks, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Thrills, Chills and Memories
description: Raheem Echols, 24, is a supervising ride operator at Luna Park, on the site of the former Astroland amusement park at Coney Island, Brooklyn.

title: Living Like the Kardashians, via Smartphone
description: It was quite a glamorous weekend. First, I flew to Los Angeles to star in a commercial for athletic wear. Then I flew right back to New York, where I met my handsome boyfriend, Christian, a famous music producer, for a romantic date at our favorite nightspot. That was all on Saturday. On Sunday, I jetted off to Miami with my entourage for a glitzy club appearance.

title: The Trucking Industry Needs More Drivers. Maybe It Needs to Pay More.
description: Swift Transportations 20,000 workers haul goods in almost 14,000 big-rig trucks that travel the interstates and back roads of the United States every day. The companys performance is closely tied to the nations economy, which has been looking increasingly sunny lately.

title: Where Surfboards Meet Whiteboards
description: Steve Ellis is the executive vice president and head of the wholesale services group at Wells Fargo in San Francisco.

title: Israelis and Gazans Clash, but Fighting Is More Subdued
description: JERUSALEM  Cross-border hostilities between Gaza and Israel continued on Saturday, a day after a temporary cease-fire expired. But the simmering exchanges were on a lower scale than the fighting that has raged for most of the last month, as Egyptian-brokered efforts continued for a new cease-fire and a resumption of talks on a more durable end to the conflict.

title: A Corporate Tax Break Thats Closer to Home
description: Rage is rising over American corporations that chop their tax bills by acquiring entities in lower-tax countries. Medtronic, AbbVie and Mylan have all announced such plans  known as inversions  in recent months. And Walgreen was poised to relocate to Switzerland after it completes its purchase of Alliance Boots, but did an about-face last week in the face of widespread denunciation.

title: Fee for Dumping the Furniture
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: When She Talks, Banks Shudder
description: Bankers are nearly unanimous on the subject of Anat R. Admati, the Stanford finance professor and persistent industry gadfly: Her ideas are wildly impractical, bad for the American economy and not to be taken seriously.

title: Obama Says Iraq Airstrike Effort Could Be Long-Term
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended presence in the skies over Iraq, telling reporters on Saturday that the airstrikes he ordered this week could go on for months as Iraqis try to build a new government.

title: Oversize Expectations for the Airbus A380
description: To get a sense of the Airbus A380s size and ambition, walk up the grand staircase of an Emirates version of the aircraft, past the showers and the first-class suites and then through endless rows in business class to the bar at the back of the upper deck. This sleek semicircle, alluringly underlit and fully stocked with pricey spirits like Grey Goose vodka, is undoubtedly one of the defining features of this aircraft, which can hold more than 500 passengers. The plane dwarfs every commercial jet in the skies.

title: What, No Teddy Bear?
description: One of the biggest luxuries in a time-pressed world might just be a good nights sleep, and now hotels are offering new ways to help their guests get the best rest possible, often with a dose of wellness before bedtime.

title: Variety: An Unpredictable Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  As someone who writes every day, my honest reaction to this weeks quote was a loud Amen! Its always comforting to know that a genius like RAY BRADBURY also struggled to conjure up his Muse. And its a good reminder not to give up if IDEAS are elusive.

title: As ISIS Militants Exert Their Control, U.S. Pursues a Military Middle Road
description: In carrying out limited airstrikes in Iraq, the Obama administration is pursuing a strategy that attempts to contain the threat posed by Islamic militants but that does not seek to break their hold on northern and western Iraq.

title: Watson Wants His Team to Have a Trait Hes Never Lacked: Heart
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Tom Watsons slacks were covered by dark rain pants on a wet Friday morning at Valhalla Golf Club, but his shirt and golf glove were yellow. That look would have been at home during the 1970s, when Watson was forging his reputation as one of the best golfers born after World War II.

title: For Refugees on Mountain, No Water, Nothing
description: FISHKHABOUR, Iraq  Amid the low scrub on Mount Sinjar in northern Iraq, new piles of loose stones mark a bleak landscape: makeshift graves for scores, perhaps hundreds, of Yazidis, left behind by survivors desperate to find an escape from the Sunni militant fighters chasing them.

title: A Paternal Touch Yields a Smooth Swing
description: Hitters change their swings subtly throughout a season, with slight alterations that can make a big difference. Most of these are unintentional, but inevitable.

title: Tracing Ebolas Breakout to an African 2-Year-Old
description: Patient Zero in the Ebola outbreak, researchers suspect, was a 2-year-old boy who died on Dec. 6, just a few days after falling ill in a village in Guckdou, in southeastern Guinea. Bordering Sierra Leone and Liberia, Guckdou is at the intersection of three nations, where the disease found an easy entry point to the region.

title: Can Family Leave Policies Be Too Generous? It Seems So
description: When measured by who holds a job, American women are falling behind women in other developed countries. Yet the American women who are working tend to have more high-achieving careers. Within that paradox lies a puzzle about how to shape maternity leave.

title: President Obamas Statement on Iraq
description: President Obama said on Saturday that airstrikes he ordered in northern Iraq had destroyed arms and equipment held by Islamic State forces but that it will be a long-term project.

title: Informant Debate Renewed as Air Force Revisits Cadet Misconduct
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  Eric Thomas was a third-string linebacker at the United States Air Force Academy who also played a far more secretive role on campus: He was a confidential informant, one of dozens of student spies assigned by the academy in the past decade to investigate drug use and sexual misconduct.

title: Ukraine Strategy Bets on Restraint by Russia
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The warnings from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the White House over the past week could not have been graver in tone: The Russian Army, they said, had massed enough forces on the border with Ukraine to invade.

title: Soaking Up Catalina, Tourists Pose a Dilemma
description: AVALON, Calif.  Just an hourlong ferry ride from Los Angeles, Catalina Island is enjoying a renaissance. After years of declining tourism, businesses here have spent more than $40 million updating this quaint island town. Hotels have been remodeled and new restaurants added. A zip line overlooking the ocean was installed. The beach  long among the dirtiest in California, befouled by an aging sewer system  was cleaned up.

title: Deadly Clashes With Police Erupt at Pakistan Protests
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Violent clashes between the police and opponents of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif swept across Pakistans Punjab Province on Saturday, leaving at least two people dead and more than 100 injured as Mr. Sharifs 14-month-old government sought to forestall a series of planned street protests aimed at ousting it.

title: Despite Failure, Campaign to Oust Tennessee Justices Keeps Conservatives Hopeful
description: NASHVILLE  When a Tennessee Supreme Court justice who had been targeted for defeat by conservative groups and business interests declared victory on Thursday night, it did not take long for grateful sentiments to give way to a bit of swagger.

title: McCain Says Limited U.S. Strikes on Militants in Iraq Are Not Enough
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas authorization of limited military operations against militants in Iraq is not enough to counter a growing threat to the United States from the richest, most powerful terrorist organization in history, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said on Saturday.

title: After Flight, a Fight to Survive in Iraq
description: A refugee crisis has struck Iraqi Kurdistan, once the most stable part of the country, as Sunni militants have advanced.

title: Vikings Temporary Home Rife With Gophers
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Rick Thomet bought his first Minnesota Vikings season tickets in 1971, when he was 16 years old. One of the most noteworthy plays in Vikings history happened in front of his section at Metropolitan Stadium  the 50-yard touchdown catch by Dallas Cowboys wide receiver Drew Pearson that eliminated the Vikings in a 1975 playoff game. Vikings fans insist Pearson pushed cornerback Nate Wright to get open.

title: Nina Hoss
description: Nina Hoss is a German actress. Her most recent film is the adaptation of John le Carrs novel A Most Wanted Man, in which she stars opposite the late Philip Seymour Hoffman.

title: A Cathedral Under Siege
description: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz.  WHEN I worked as a white-water guide at the bottom of the Grand Canyon, I was often struck by how many passengers concluded their odyssey through the most iconic landscape in the United States by invoking the very same epiphany. At the end of each two-week, 277-mile journey down the Colorado River, someone would often come up to me and declare that the canyon was Americas cathedral  a church without a roof.

title: Is a Hard Life Inherited?
description: YAMHILL, Ore.  ONE delusion common among Americas successful people is that they triumphed just because of hard work and intelligence.

title: The Starchitect Image
description: Readers respond to a letter by Peggy Deamer, an architect, calling for less arrogance and more collaboration in architecture.

title: Hit the Reset Button in Your Brain
description: THIS month, many Americans will take time off from work to go on vacation, catch up on household projects and simply be with family and friends. And many of us will feel guilty for doing so. We will worry about all of the emails piling up at work, and in many cases continue to compulsively check email during our precious time off.

title: Dont Let Your Children Grow Up to Be Farmers
description: NEW HAVEN  AT a farm-to-table dinner recently, I sat huddled in a corner with some other farmers, out of earshot of the foodies happily eating kale and freshly shucked oysters. We were comparing business models and profit margins, and it quickly became clear that all of us were working in the red.

title: A Broadcaster Knows Long Shots, and Not Just Those of the Slap Variety
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Before Eddie Olczyk was a hockey player, he was a horseplayer  a serious one. When he talks about his method for handicapping, it may as well be from the pulpit. Eddie O. preaches race flow and considers ignoring surface biases one of handicappings deadly sins.

title: The Pigeon Fliers of New York
description: A decade ago, when I lived in Bushwick, Brooklyn, I used to watch the sunset from my rooftop. All around me were large flocks of pigeons, their white wingtips glittering as they swirled in the suns golden hour. These were not street pigeons. Their movements were too choreographed, and they hovered above particular tenements as if attached by marionette strings. Atop the buildings, I could just make out the silhouettes of men whistling at the birds while waving jerry-built flags. These were the puppeteers.

title: Protest March in Chokehold Case Is Moved From Verrazano Bridge to Staten Island
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, seeking to defuse political and logistical concerns over his proposal to lead a protest march across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, said on Saturday that the march against aggressive policing would instead be held on Staten Island, where a man died last month after an encounter with the police.

title: The Opposite of Stagflation
description: One of the truly amazing (and disheartening) things about the Great Recession and its aftermath has been the continuing insistence of many economists that its somehow a supply-side slump, driven by the evils of Obamacare or something. This tends to come from people who view stagflation in the 1970s as having permanently refuted all things Keynes.

title: In Praise of the DMV
description: OK, not exactly. But I see that some of the commenters on my libertarian piece invoke the old horrors of the DMV line to claim that government never works.

title: Gastro-Architecture
description: A tour of the worlds edible architecture. Take a photo, or a bite.

title: Medical Marijuana Research Hits Wall of U.S. Law
description: Nearly four years ago, Dr. Sue Sisley, a psychiatrist at the University of Arizona, sought federal approval to study marijuanas effectiveness in treating military veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder. She had no idea how difficult it would be.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 10
description: In a brief news conference on Saturday, President Obama called the crisis in Iraq a long-term project, but reiterated that the United States would not send ground forces to the region. Earlier this week, Mr. Obama said the stranded Yazidis, a religious minority, were in danger of genocide at the hands of militants with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. Mr. Obama authorized targeted airstrikes against ISIS on Thursday, drawing bipartisan support from Congress.

title: Men Often Mentored by Women at the Pool
description: IRVINE, Calif.  The San Antonio Spurs hiring of Becky Hammon on Tuesday as the N.B.A.s first full-time female assistant coach caught the eye of Dorsey Tierney-Walker, who was thrilled to welcome another woman into a club that she never viewed as exclusive.

title: Uniting to Take Congress, G.O.P. Tries to Become the Party of Yes
description: WASHINGTON  With control of Congress within reach, Republicans arequietly assembling an aggressive 2015agendabuilt around a push for a balanced budget and quick passage of measures, likeapproval of the Keystone XL pipeline and repeal of a medical equipment tax, to show they can govern.

title: Swimming Against the Rising Tide
description: IT never feels like summer starts until the first time I go to the beach. To stand nearly naked and heavy from winter on the waters edge, wade awkwardly into the shallows, dive under the first cold wave, taste first salt, surface and dive again to reach the calmer waters beyond, floating there until water and skin become the same temperature  this is the best way I know to belong again, body and soul, to some larger part of the planet, not just the city, not just the job. But its already August, and I still havent gone swimming.

title: Grief, Smoke and Salvation
description: PHILADELPHIA  PEOPLE who dont know the full truth about Mike Solomonov judge him by his fried chicken at Federal Donuts, a cult favorite in this city, and by his hummus at Zahav, an Israeli restaurant here of national renown. Theyre the signposts in a career that has burned bright in recent years and seems destined to burn brighter still.

title: Mr. Obama, Your Move
description: Sometime in late summer, if predictions are right, President Obama will use his executive authority to protect many unauthorized immigrants from deportation.

title: Back to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  IT was exhilarating to drop a bunch of 500-pound bombs on whatstheirname.

title: J. W. Hastings, 87, a Pioneer in Bioluminescence Research, Dies
description: J. Woodland Hastings, a Harvard biochemist whose improbable discovery of how bacteria communicate became the foundation for groundbreaking research in the development of more effective antibiotics, died on Wednesday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 87.

title: Too Big to Regulate
description: If the Dodd-Frank financial reform law was working as it is supposed to, the biggest American and European banks would soon be facing stricter capital and leverage requirements, restrictions on their growth and operations, and even, in some instances, the forced divestiture of entire business units.

title: The Right War
description: THREE times before last weeks decision to launch airstrikes against the self-styled caliphate, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, President Obama was urged to intervene in Middle Eastern conflicts: in Libya in the spring of 2011, in Syria from 2011 onward and in Iraq two short months ago, when Baghdad was threatened by the swift advance of ISIS.

title: A Witness to Ebolas Discovery
description: It was October 1976 in Atlanta, and a disease that no one had ever seen was coming into focus. Word came from an amateur radio network in Africa that the mystery illness had killed hundreds of people in just over a month. The chief of the viral pathology branch at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was standing over an electron microscope. Dr. Frederick Murphy, now a professor of pathology at the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston, was the first to see this unknown killer up close.

title: A Star-Powered School Sputters
description: DALLAS  A few years back, Deion Sanders, the Hall of Fame cornerback and N.F.L. commentator who still digs being called by the nickname Prime Time, was approached with a splendid business proposition.

title: A View From the Sea, as China Flexes Muscle
description: ABOARD CSB-8003, in the South China Sea  As the large white Chinese ship closed in, the smaller Vietnamese Coast Guard vessel could only veer off, black exhaust billowing from its stack. The Vietnamese vessel had advanced to within 13 miles of the Chinese offshore oil rig, and the Chinese decided it could come no closer.

title: Will the Voices of Conscience Be Heard?
description: THERE are good people and bad leaders the world over, but perhaps nowhere more so than in the Middle East. Plenty of Israelis and Palestinians work to build bridges, but their voices are lost in the stampede of zealots schooled in hatred and cynics adept in the manipulation of fear for the consolidation of power.

title: Eric Cantors Big Payoff
description: Residents of Virginias Seventh Congressional District wont be able to meet their representative at a town hall during the August recess because they wont have one as of Aug. 18. Their congressman, Eric Cantor, announced his resignation a few days ago after losing the Republican primary in June to someone further to the right. Ostensibly, he did so to give his successor slightly higher seniority (which might mean nothing more than a better office), but the real reasons are more venal.

title: Olympiad Is Shadowed by Leadership Showdown
description: It is election season at the World Chess Federation, with a vote at the Chess Olympiad on Monday that pits the incumbent president against a former world champion.

title: Classy Dames in Desperate Straits
description: Some real classy dames are tearing up the joint at City Center, where the Sydney Theater Company is performing its rip-roaring production of Jean Genets The Maids as part of the Lincoln Center Festival through Aug. 16. You might add that these ladies, embodied in the august personages of Cate Blanchett and Isabelle Huppert,  are stinking up the place, as well.

title: Moves Rarely Seen in the East Village
description: August is typically dances hibernation period. But last year, some extraordinary sights and sounds filled La MaMas intimate East Village theater when it was transformed into a haven for classical Indian music and dance. Beginning Monday, the Drive East festival is back with another week of exceptional programming, organized by Navatman, the South Asian performing arts group, and devoted to the dance styles of Bharatanatyam, Kathak and Kuchipudi, as well as a rarer form: Sattriya, originally practiced by celibate monks.

title: Bringing the Harp to Center Stage
description: I recently heard the harpist Xavier de Maistre for the first time at the Istanbul Music Festival, where he performed with the soprano Diana Damrau and impressed with his musicality, muscular technique and imaginative flair. Mr. de Maistre, the former principal harpist of the Vienna Philharmonic, has carved out a career as an orchestral soloist, chamber musician and recitalist and has expanded the repertory for harp with commissions and his own arrangements. He will perform some of them at 10 p.m. Thursday in the intimate, candlelit series A Little Night Music, part of Mostly Mozart, at Lincoln Centers Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse. That program includes his arrangements of pieces by Mozart, Liszt, Faur and Smetana.

title: Crossing a Line in the Sea
description: The Wallace Line swerves among the islands of Indonesia from just west of Bali to the seas south of the Philippines. Its named after the British naturalist Alfred Russel Wallace, who discovered in the mid-19th century that different species of flora and fauna grew on either side. East of the Wallace Line: Monumental Art From Indonesia and New Guinea, opening Friday at the Yale University Art Gallery, will present more than 120 works of art and craft from the 17th to the 19th century made by people living east of that line. These habitats include the islands of Timor, Flores and the Moluccas of eastern Indonesia and, in western New Guinea, the Raja Ampat Islands and Cenderawasih Bay. Drawn from the gallerys Indo-Pacific art collection, the exhibition will include large, ritual and ancestral statues carved from wood; small, intricately carved ceremonial and utilitarian objects made of wood, ivory, and brass; richly patterned textiles; and wooden shields inlaid with mother-of-pearl. (1111 Chapel Street, New Haven; artgallery.yale.edu.)

title: With No Regard for Pop Conventions
description: All those years in isolation/helped me want for you, FKA twigs sings in Closer, a track deep into her first full album, LP1. Lead me to a place Im free from/all the wrongs I do. Like a lot of lines on the record, these can be understood in three ways: a call to an old lover, a plea for spiritual salvation or a credo of the young perfectionist artist facing a new audience. Or perhaps in one big way: transformative desire, private and public, in body and soul, in real life and metaphor.

title: If Friends Play Your Songs, They Just May Change Your Tune
description: Gustavo Santaolalla

title: Im Not a Doctor, but I Play One ...
description: On the long-running BET series The Game, Jay Ellis plays Bryce Westbrook, a Heisman Trophy-winning wide receiver and first-round draft pick for the fictional San Diego Sabers football team. The role has made Mr. Ellis a favorite among the shows female fan base and sparked numerous magazine articles that promise to reveal this 32-year-old actors sexy secrets.

title: Identity Crisis Under Cover
description: Who am I? becomes more than just metaphysical navel gazing in Legends, starring Sean Bean as Martin Odum, a deep-cover F.B.I. operative who morphs into a different character with each new job, then loses his compass when fact and fiction blur. Its not fair, he says, apparently channeling an alter ego. I did everything right. Learned a trade. Worked hard. His craggy British accent turns stuttering American. I deserve better.

title: Imperfect Duo, on a Short Tour
description: Eminem and Rihanna may be two of the biggest pop stars of the 2000s, and are frequent collaborators, but the similarities stop there. Eminem is a scabrous self-excavator, a man who raps his way through trauma at lightning speed and with a disregard for the feelings of others (or his own, for that matter). Rihanna is a chilly narcissist with a slick voice thats almost never touched a feeling. Still, theyre uniting for a brief tour  first a pair of shows in Pasadena, Calif., then a pair in New Jersey before closing out with a pair in Eminems hometown, Detroit. Maybe they want to celebrate their collaborations  The Monster, Love the Way You Lie (Part II)  which have served to soften Eminem and coarsen Rihanna, each achieving something they cant quite nail on their own. (Next Saturday and Sunday, MetLife Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J.; metlifestadium.com.)

title: Straight Out of Wales, With Murders
description: LONDON  In the first episode of Hinterland, a police drama set in a tiny town in Wales, an elderly woman is reported missing, and the lead investigator, Detective Chief Inspector Tom Mathias (Richard Harrington), finds a clue in a local landmark.

title: Rios Slums to Jacobs Pillow
description: As the protests surrounding the World Cup this summer underscored, Brazil is a complex country, blessed with gorgeous beaches and breathtaking landscapes, bursting with music, but also plagued by poverty and violence. Extremes of beauty and ugliness rub shoulders; they are intertwined in the national character. This tension is precisely what the choreographer Sonia Destri Lie, founder of the contemporary hip-hop troupe Companhia Urbana de Dana, strives to capture in her work. The company will appear at the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., from Wednesday to Saturday.

title: Financial Aid for the Talented, but What About the Needy?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Loss Isnt Only Reminder That Era of Yankees Dominance Has Waned
description: A postseason berth no longer comes easily for the Yankees, who dominated the baseball landscape not too long ago. But that was in a different era, with different players, a fact that became all too clear before Saturdays game, when the Yankees honored the former outfielder Paul ONeill with a plaque in Monument Park.

title: Baby Pictures at the Doctors? Cute, Sure, but Illegal
description: Pictures of smiling babies crowd a bulletin board in a doctors office in Midtown Manhattan, in a collage familiar to anyone who has given birth. But the women coming in to have babies of their own cannot see them. They have been moved to a private part of the office, replaced in the corridors with abstract art.

title: 99-Page Ruling in OBannon Case Is Missing Something: Clarity
description: The federal judge who on Friday declared that the N.C.A.A.s longstanding amateurism rules were a violation of antitrust laws left no uncertainty in her ruling about her views of the organizations arguments. She bluntly dismissed them.

title: With Judges Rebuke, a System Built on Hypocrisy Is Wobbling
description: Intercollegiate athletics became a little less of a plantation system Friday when a United States District Court judge in Oakland, Calif., ruled that athletes in big-time sports programs could reap some of the financial benefits of participating in those programs.

title: A Chance to Relish a Sibling Rivalry Before It Fades Away
description: MONTREAL  For the two hours and one minute of Saturdays first semifinal at the Rogers Cup, it wasnt 2014. Venus and Serena Williams had succeeded in turning back the clock.

title: No. 1 Friends
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  All together now: Awwwww! You cannot be sad doing this puzzle by Elizabeth C. Gorski, the mistress of visual puzzle art. Sorry, its not allowed. Even if youre not a dog lover, you have to admit that this puzzle is pretty awesome. Weve got an adorable pup drawn in the grid, and Ms. Gorski has managed to do that without even going over the 140 entry limit. Thats masterful in itself.

title: G.M. Loses Bid to Dismiss Suit Over Switch
description: General Motors was unable to persuade a judge in Georgia to dismiss a case that helped set in motion the companys worldwide recall of 2.6 million cars with a deadly ignition defect and that touched off the worst safety crisis in the automakers 106-year history.

title: An Epicurean Village Is Too Rich for Some Paris Appetites
description: PARIS  One recent sunny morning, Cdric Naudon, a wealthy French entrepreneur with a taste for fine food, walked down a quiet street in a neighborhood of Paris known as the Haut Marais and gestured toward a phalanx of shuttered storefronts as the sound of power drills pierced the air.

title: New V.A. Chief Promises to Mend Practices
description: LAS VEGAS  In his first public address since taking the helm of the embattled Department of Veterans Affairs, Secretary Robert A. McDonald vowed on Saturday to restore trust in the agency by initiating an independent audit of its scheduling practices and holding poorly performing officials accountable.

title: Amazon Takes the Muppets Off the Shelf
description: Amazon is refusing to allow orders for physical copies of forthcoming releases from yet another media company.

title: In the Valley, High Hopes for a V.A. Voucher Effort
description: WESLACO  The Rio Grande Valley landscape is painted with signs and banners proudly showcasing that people here are honored to serve those who have served in the military.

title: A New Test for Texas Abortion Restrictions
description: The latest legal challenge to Texas sweeping abortion measures went to trial in a federal courthouse in Austin last week, as federal judges around the country grapple with the question of how far states can go in regulating abortion  a question that seems likely to end up in the United States Supreme Court.

title: Growing Cities Opting to Rely on Impact Fees
description: As cities across Texas continue to spread out, water suppliers and local governments are faced with the question of who should pay for building the infrastructure needed to handle the growth.

title: At 100, Greyhound Rolls Back Toward Hipness
description: DALLAS  Megabus and other budget bus lines have crowded the highway in the last decade, but the nations oldest and biggest service is still Greyhound, now celebrating 100 years of operation. Its fleet of 1,200 buses in the United States and Canada carries 18 million customers each year.

title: Toning Down His Wardrobe and Letting His Play Do the Talking
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Rickie Fowler wore purple for the third round of the 96th P.G.A. Championship. A few years ago, the purple might have had a brilliant fuchsia hue or maybe something magenta. It would have been something eye-catching, for sure.

title: P.G.A. Championship 2014: Thinking on His Bare Feet, Jason Day Salvages a Peculiar Par
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Birdies were the rule during the third round of the P.G.A. Championship at Valhalla Golf Club, but an exceptional par save by Jason Day provided one of Saturdays most entertaining moments.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 9, 2014
Searching for Habitable Planets
description: Kepler is designed to measure tiny brightness variations in stars that might indicate orbiting planets. NASA hopes to find Earth-like planets orbiting stars at a distance that would permit liquid water, potentially allowing them to support life. Kepler will be placed in an orbit around the Sun, surveying more than 100,000 stars for three years.

title: Exclusive Interview: Obama on the World
description: President Barack Obama talks with the Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman about a wide range of issues at home and abroad.

title: Ledecky Adds 400-Meter Freestyle to Her World Record Collection
description: IRVINE, Calif.  Katie Ledecky on Saturday night became the third American woman, after Debbie Meyer and Janet Evans, to hold world records concurrently in the 400-, 800- and 1,500-meter freestyle.

title: Inspiration Aside, Giants Show They Have Work to Do
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When running back David Wilson bade a tearful farewell to the N.F.L. last week, a neck injury ending his career at age 23, he urged his Giants teammates to be great and reminded them how fleeting careers can be.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 10, 2014
description: I dont think were going to solve this problem in weeks. This is going to be a long-term project.

title: P.G.A. Championship 2014: Bernd Wiesberger Rises to Second and Raises Austrias Golf Profile
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Golfers from Continental Europe have made a big impression on the sport over the past few decades, among them Seve Ballesteros of Spain, Bernhard Langer of Germany, and the brothers Francesco and Edoardo Molinari of Italy.

title: Julie Siegel, Jordan Grossman

Floyd Prue of Severna Park, Md., was married Saturday to Kyle Andrew Rifkind, the son of Charlotte and Norman Rifkind of Arlington Heights, Ill. John H. description: Laura Rebecca Clawson and Arjun Kent Jaikumar were married Saturday at the Museum of Science in Boston. The event was led by Rose Costello, a friend of the couple who received a one-day license from Massachusetts to officiate.

description: Emma Liberty Fulkerson and Alejandro Ricardo Rodriguez were married Saturday by the Rev. Victoria Warren, an Episcopal priest, at St. Johns in the Wilderness Church in Glenbrook, Nev.

description: Its kind of amazing  the summer of two Tempests, said Scott Schwartz, the artistic director of Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor, when asked about the striking coincidence that both his theater and the Hamptons Independent Theater Festival, known as HITFest, are presenting The Tempest by Shakespeare outdoors in the Hamptons this month.

description: Julia Emmet Heald, a daughter of Caroline E. Heald and Seth G. Heald of Alexandria, Va., was married Saturday to Taylor Edward Burmeister, a son of Gail Y. Burmeister and Paul A. Burmeister of Calabasas, Calif. The Rev. Stephen K. Arbogast, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

description: Akilah Marie Robinson and Tristan Jere Allen were married Saturday in Atlanta. The Rev. John R. Allen, a Baptist minister and the father of the groom, officiated at Villa Christina, an events space.

title: Alexandra Penney, Ben Bowers
description: Alexandra Rose Penney, a daughter of Angela Penney and Paul Penney of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married Friday to Charles Benjamin Bowers, the son of Lucy McGough Bowers of Grundy, Va., and the late James W. Bowers. The Rev. Hugh B. Penney, a minister of the United Church of Christ and the paternal grandfather of the bride, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Awilda Mendez, Steven Hancock
description: Awilda Mendez and Steven William Hancock were married Saturday by the Rev. Thomas H. Feely, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Alexandra Amore, Peter Cavallaro
description: Alexandra Bravo Amore, a daughter of Sandra B. Amore and Rollin V. Amore of Washington, was married Saturday to Peter Thomas Cavallaro, the son of Diane L. Cavallaro and Peter I. Cavallaro of Westbury, N.Y. The Rev. James Williams performed the ceremony at St. Brigids Roman Catholic Church in Westbury.

description: Steven Reineke and Eric Gabbard were married Monday evening at the Riverside Church in New York. Ann Hampton Callaway, a performer and songwriter who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated. She wrote a song, One Door Opens, for the couple, which she sang at the ceremony.

Murphy III, of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, officiated, with Jitendrakumar Sevak, a Hindu priest.

description: Marissa Miller Grand and William Joseph Hettler III were married by Rabbi Charles Agin Saturday evening at Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

description: Kirsten Anne Boreen and Christopher Dillon Liedl were married Saturday by the Rev. George Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Julia Church in Weston, Mass.

title: Tommi Salmela, Gregory Peterson
description: Tommi Mikael Salmela and Gregory Jones Peterson were married Saturday at City Hall in Stockholm in a ceremony that was led by Rickard Sundeman, who was appointed to serve as an officiant for the government.

title: Amy Herskowitz, Gregory Pearl
description: Amy Helaine Herskowitz and Gregory Michael Pearl were married Saturday evening at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Goodman officiated.

description: Scarlet Ryane Shore and Thomas Michael Clifton were married Saturday evening at OceanCliff, an event space in Newport, R.I. Michael D. Grando, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Woman Is Fatally Stabbed in the Bronx, the Police Say
description: A 23-year-old woman died Saturday in the Bronx after her husband attacked her with a knife, the police said.

title: Corrections: August 10, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Hawaiian Governor Loses Primary by Wide Margin; Senate Race Is Undecided
description: HONOLULU  After nearly four decades in elected office in Hawaii, Gov. Neil Abercrombie was dealt a stunning defeat in his bid for re-election, becoming the first governor in the states history to lose in a primary race.

title: 44 Dead in Tour Bus Crash in Tibet
description: BEIJING  A tour bus careened off a highway in Tibet in a crash that killed 44 people and injured 11, Chinas state news media reported on Sunday.

title: What Cars Did for Todays World, Data May Do for Tomorrows
description: New technology products head at us constantly. Theres the latest smartphone, the shiny new app, the hot social network, even the smarter thermostat.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (Discovery) AIR JAWS: FINS OF FURY Shark Week 2014, the 27th annual version of this programming sensation, presents 12 new shows, starting with this special, above, in which the filmmaker Jeff Kurr uses high-tech cameras and underwater gadgetry to track down the huge great white known as Colossus. Shark of Darkness: Wrath of Submarine, at 9, hunts for a 30-foot great white that locals believe has terrorized the coastline of South Africa for decades. And the actors Jake Johnson and Damon Wayans Jr., the director Robert Rodriguez and the extreme eater Chris Schewe are guests on Shark After Dark, a talk show hosted by Jonah Wolf, at 11. Meanwhile, Nat Geo Wild kicks off its second annual SharkFest with Shark Kill Zone, which tracks 10 shark species as they hunt for prey, at 8.

title: If My Son Loves Football, Can He Still Love Me?
description: Its Thanksgiving and I should be inside watching the parade in my jammies, timing the marshmallow placement on the sweet potato casserole and deciding how soon is too soon for red wine. Instead, I am in 20-degree weather on an elementary school playground strapping flags on fourth graders and their parents. Theres no way I am joining this football game.

title: Abrons Announces Theater, Dance and Music Premieres
description: The coming season of the Abrons Arts Center, the performing arts arm of the Henry Street Settlement, will be devoted mostly to theater, dance and music premieres. The season also includes a six-month residency, from January through June, by the International Contemporary Ensemble, which will feature new works by Christian Wolff, George Lewis, John Zorn, Cory Smythe and Forrest Pierce.

title: Kerry Urges Myanmar to Stay on Path to Democracy, Despite Stumbles
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Secretary of State John Kerry called on Myanmars leaders on Sunday to move ahead with fundamental reforms amid concerns that the nation is stumbling on its path to democracy.

title: Use This Equation to Stop Robbing Yourself of Happiness
description: The researchers who developed the above equation call it a computational model of momentary subjective well-being. And while it may look and sound complicated to most non-mathematicians, its gist is pretty simple: How happy you are depends in large part on your expectations.

title: Agreeing to More Talks in Egypt, Israelis and Palestinians Begin Latest Cease-Fire
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli and Palestinian negotiators on Sunday accepted Egypts proposal for a new 72-hour cease-fire in the Gaza fighting, which began one minute after midnight on Monday, and agreed to resume Egyptian-mediated negotiations toward a more durable solution.

title: A Week of Carlo Bergonzi on Met Opera Radio
description: Carlo Bergonzi, the great Italian tenor who died July 25 at the age of 90, will be the subject of a weeklong retrospective starting Monday on the Metropolitan Operas satellite radio station.

title: Capitalizing on U.S. Bombing, Kurds Retake Iraqi Towns
description: GWER, Iraq  With American strikes beginning to show clear effects on the battlefield, Kurdish forces counterattacked Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Sunday, regaining control of two strategic towns with aid from the air.

title: 1939: U.S. Zionist Delegation to Geneva in Quest of Solution to Palestine
description: To work out a solution to the Palestine problem which will satisfy the Arabs as well as the Jews will be the principal concern of the World Zionist Congress meeting in Geneva on August 18, according to Herman P. Kopplemann, former Congressman for three terms from Connecticut and member of the large American delegation to the meeting in Switzerland. Outside influences have been creating discords which are unfortunate and unfair to both Arab and Jew in Palestine. We are far from satisfied with the British White Paper, which nullifies the Balfour Declaration, but we are going to do the best in our power to settle the controversy  particularly unfortunate at this time of racial discrimination  in a fair and peaceful way, said Mr. Kopplemann. Mr. Kopplemann is one of the members of the American delegation which is meeting in Paris before the start of the congress to act as a steering committee for the delegation as a whole, which numbers some thirty-two persons. We Americans feel that we have done a major part of the work of building up the wastelands and draining the swamps of Palestine, making that land, in fact, one of the most productive parts of the world. We have raised the standard of living there, not only of the Jew but also of the Arab. We feel that the American delegation should therefore participate in the congress to the fullest degree.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 11, 1939

title: Some Comedy and a Revival From Gotham Chamber Opera
description: New York City Opera is no more, and the Metropolitan Operas coming season has been thrown into doubt as its fraught labor negotiations continue. But the far smaller Gotham Chamber Opera announced Sunday that its 13th season would feature two productions this fall.

title: A Nascar Stars Deadly Run-In on a Dirt Track
description: Tony Stewart, a three-time Nascar champion, was moonlighting Saturday night. He had gone back to his racing roots for a few hours, competing in a local dirt-track event at Canandaigua Motorsports Park in upstate New York, bumping and sliding his high-powered open-wheel sprint car with the mostly unknown competitors on the track.

title: Another One Direction Film Is on the Way
description: There may be screaming soon in a theater near you: One Direction is scheduled to release a concert film in October.

title: Nigeria Struggles to Cope With Ebola Outbreak
description: Ebola, one of the worlds most fatal diseases, has surfaced in Africas most populous country.

title: Without Breaking a Sweat, a Doctor Tracks Ebola and Other Epidemics
description: The call came in on a Friday morning, as Dr. Michael S. Phillips worked at his desk at NYU Langone Medical Center in Manhattan. A patient had arrived in the emergency room burning with fever after returning from a trip to Liberia.

title: Ninja Turtles Reboot Tops Weekend Box Office
description: A five-year plan to resuscitate one of the quirkier entertainment franchises of the 1980s culminated in impressive form over the weekend, as Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles took in an estimated $65 million at North American theaters  at least 30 percent more than box-office analysts had projected. On Sunday, Paramount Pictures announced a sequel. (It must be said: Cowabunga.)

title: How to Look for Alien Life in Space Geysers
description: What we at the Planetary Society do is to do our best to explain the space sciences, says Bill Nye, the Science Guy, in an interview with Big Think. We strongly believe that the search for life is worthy because it would change the world.

title: 1964: Turkish Jets Again Raid Cyprus Despite Truce
description: NICOSIA  Turkish fighter planes today [Aug. 10] attacked Cyprus for the fourth consecutive day despite a cease-fire agreement. The strafing attack was made against the northwestern village of Polis, but it was believed to have been launched in error by pilots who had not yet received their cease-fire orders from Ankara. Throughout the rest of the island, the situation eased somewhat when it was learned that Turkish troops had not invaded the island as alleged last night by the Greek Cypriot government. The government had charged that four Turkish destroyers were unloading men and material at Kokkina, the last major stronghold of the Turkish Cypriots on the northwestern coast. But the UN found no evidence to support the allegation. Col. Johnas Waern, commander of the UN Swedish contingent on Cyprus, inspected the area and reported seeing only a very small ship offshore which was not unloading anything. There was a brief flareup of shooting in Nicosia tonight, but there were no reports of any casualties. Firing also continued sporadically throughout the day between Greek and Turkish Cypriots in the Kokkina area, according to reliable reports reaching Nicosia tonight.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 11, 1964

title: A Night in Brooklyn (Personal and Trivial)
description: Thats San Fermin. Also St. Vincent, not my sort of thing, but clearly excellent of its kind. And free!

title: Meanwhile, in Europe
description: Japanification is well underway. Not quite deflation yet, but headline at 0.4 percent, core at 0.8 percent. In the U.S. the Fed is, rightly in my view, focused on slow wage growth as an indication of slack; in the euro area annual growth in labor costs is sliding:

title: Sensing a Tsum Tsum Craze Afoot, Disney Rushes to Supply Fans
description: LOS ANGELES  Has Disney stumbled across the new Beanie Baby?

title: Eurozone to Release G.D.P. Data
description: EUROZONE TO RELEASE 2ND-QUARTER G.D.P. DATA

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 11
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Turkeys Premier Is Proclaimed Winner of Presidential Election
description: ISTANBUL  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who has led Turkey for more than a decade, is set to become the countrys first popularly elected president, apparently cruising to a victory on Sunday that positioned him to be the dominant political figure here for at least five more years.

title: Reimagining a Magical Pastoral Tale in an Urban Forest
description: Could that cherishable farce A Midsummer Nights Dream possibly be more daft and befuddling than Shakespeare made it, with romances spawned, crossed and erased in the blink of an enchanted eye?

title: Looking Ahead, Yankees Fall Behind for Their Second Straight Loss
description: The Yankees rode the Amtrak Acela train down to Baltimore on Sunday evening, but to say they were rolling into town, for perhaps their biggest series of the year, would not be quite accurate.

title: Dread, Desire and a Lovers Betrayal, All in the Passage of One Day
description: In the program note for her dance suite Tejas Luminous, Malini Srinivasan, a dancer and choreographer of the classical Indian style Bharata Natyam, writes of spiritual questions. Explaining how growing up in America she often visited her familys home in India, she recalls her early connection to the sensuality of ritual but also her fear and doubt and the resulting sense of alienation.

title: Making Artlessness an Art at the Podium
description: For about 10 seconds of Beethovens Eighth Symphony on Friday night, Osmo Vanska did nothing but beat time with his right hand, lean forward and point insistently at the cellists of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra.

title: Pop Culture on a Grid. Despicable. Brilliant.
description: The Approval Matrix is inspired by the back page of New York magazine, one of the better recurring magazine conceits of the last decade  a grid on which pieces of cultural effluvia are plotted according to their quality (Brilliant versus Despicable) and their smarts (Highbrow versus Lowbrow).

title: Mets Labor Woes Divide Opera Fans as Well as Participants
description: The labor strife at the Metropolitan Opera has inflamed the passions of opera lovers, stoking debate in a world that relishes rivalries even in happier times: Wagnerites versus Verdians, Callas worshipers versus Tebaldi-ites, modernists versus those who think opera ended with Puccini.

title: Life Revealed in Letters and Doodles
description: With his death in 1995, the American artist Ray Johnson left a vapor trail of interest that has grown and grown, far beyond what might be expected from a career that, from a conventional viewpoint, traveled the byways of art and produced inscrutable, disposable things.

title: When Trash Talk Becomes Brainy
description: WASHINGTON  Will the winner be Wile E. Coyote or the original Star-Spangled Banner? Woody Guthries This Land Is Your Land or a Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington? The space shuttle Discovery or a segregated Pullman railroad car from the Jim Crow era?

title: The Whole Shebang
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Well, its finally happened: I encountered a vowel progression that I actually enjoyed. I dont know if its because I get such a kick out of seeing a byline shared by the centenarian Bernice Gordon and teenage wunderkind David Steinberg (you can solve their other collaboration here), or because its just a really fun vowel progression, or both. No matter. This is a nice way to start our solving week.

title: N.C.A.A. Will Appeal the OBannon Ruling
description: The N.C.A.A. on Sunday announced plans to appeal the ruling in the so-called OBannon case, in which a federal judge took the legs out from under most of the justifications for the amateur model and kicked the billion-dollar college sports industry further down the road to professionalization than anyone before her ever had. An appeal had been widely expected.

title: Chinas Energetic Enforcement of Antitrust Rules Alarms Foreign Firms
description: HONG KONG  When almost 100 government antitrust investigators simultaneously marched into four of Microsofts offices across China late last month, they were not looking for tea and gossip.

title: Stalled Gazprom Antitrust Case May Suggest Unease for Energy Sanctions
description: BRUSSELS  Even as Russia and the West keep raising the stakes in their economic sanctions battle, the one commodity that could matter most  Russian natural gas  seems still to be off limits.

title: A Less Defiant Tack in a Campaign to Curb Smoking by Teenagers
description: SMOKING had long been a hallmark of teenage rebellion when Truth, a campaign from Legacy, introduced its first antismoking commercial in 2000. In the commercial, young people gather at the New York headquarters of the Philip Morris tobacco company and dump 1,200 body bags, representing the number of daily deaths attributed to smoking. The spot sought to shift a perception of cigarettes as a symbol of rebellion to one of the tobacco industry as the real enemy to rebel against.

title: Case of Divided Loyalty Still Divides the Public
description: The whole Jonathan Pollard Israeli spy scandal of the 1980s might have been avoided if only the United States Navy had subscribed to a simple bit of wisdom that Tina Fey attributes to Lorne Michaels: Dont hire anyone you wouldnt want to run into in the hallway at 3 in the morning.

title: Fast-Stepped Fury, Rooted in Detroit
description: DETROIT  Twenty years ago, it seemed to some of us as if serious footwork had passed out of Western popular dance; on the dance floors we knew, most of the movement was happening from the ankle up. But how wrong  how limited  we were! Its impressive to find that there are several current forms of American street dance that feature top-speed movement of the feet: notably Memphis jookin, Chicago footwork (which evolved from Chicago Jukin) and Detroit Jit.

title: China and Hong Kong: One Country, Two Systems
description: ...but are they compatible?

title: Artful Play at the Truscott Senior Swiss Teams
description: LAS VEGAS  Bridge columns reporting on tournaments tend to feature the top stars. But less illustrious competitors do produce beautiful plays, as in the diagramed deal from the Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams here last month.

title: Iraqs Rot Starts at the Top
description: TYRE, Lebanon  IRAQS situation is desperate. What makes it worse is that its political class, and many American officials, continue to push a cure that would be worse than the disease: a breakup of Iraq along sectarian lines.

title: Print Is Down, and Now Out
description: A year ago last week, it seemed as if print newspapers might be on the verge of a comeback, or at least on the brink of, well, survival.

title: Rethinking the Education of a Doctor
Stealthy, Like a Cat
description: To the Editor:

title: The C.I.A. and Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Solitary Confinement
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching Creole in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: The Enigma of Animal Suffering
description: One of the most provocative tactics used by opponents of animal exploitation is to draw an analogy between human and animal suffering. Marjorie Spiegels The Dreaded Comparison: Human and Animal Slavery finds parallels between white oppression of African slaves in America and human exploitation of nonhumans. Spiegel asserts that like human slaves, nonhuman animals are subjected to branding, restraints, beatings, auctions, the separation of offspring from their parents and forced voyages.

title: Sentencing, by the Numbers
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  IN a recent letter to the United States Sentencing Commission, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. sharply criticized the growing trend of evidence-based sentencing, in which courts use data-driven predictions of defendants future crime risk to shape sentences. Mr. Holder is swimming against a powerful current. At least 20 states have implemented this practice, including some that require risk scores to be considered in every sentencing decision. Many more are considering it, as is Congress, in pending sentencing-reform bills.

title: In Virginia Trial of McDonnell and Wife, an Imposing Judge Sets the Pace
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Judge James R. Spencer oversees his courtroom here with a brooding glare that is interrupted only to routinely admit evidence, consider an objection or call for a lunch break.

title: Mets Pitchers Are Hurting After a Loss
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets young pitchers this season have provided hope for the future while simultaneously keeping the team on the periphery of the postseason race. It has been a delicate balancing act, through each exuberant Jenrry Mejia save and Jacob deGrom strikeout.

title: An Audacious Studio Rattles Hollywood
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Christopher J. McFarland and Riza Shahriz Abdul Aziz, co-owners of Red Granite Pictures, which produced The Wolf of Wall Street, are stalking someone bigger than that films hero, the stock hustler Jordan Belfort.

title: Is Money Ruining Music Festivals?
Grief and Protests Follow Shooting of a Teenager
description: The fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager Saturday by a police officer in a St. Louis suburb came after a struggle for the officers gun, police officials said Sunday, in an explanation that met with outrage and skepticism in the largely African-American community.

title: Harpers Publisher Standing Firm in His Defense of Print and Paywall
description: When John R. MacArthur, the publisher of Harpers Magazine and a zealous promoter of the virtues of print journalism, sits down at his desk to write, he has three options  a typewriter, an ancient beige PC and a modern Apple desktop computer.

title: As Gannett Withdraws, Uncertainty at Sports on Earth Site
description: Last Tuesday morning, shortly after the Gannett Company announced it was splitting into separate print and broadcasting companies, word surfaced on social media that the website Sports on Earth, partly owned by Gannett, would be affected.

title: Smithsonian Summer Showdown
description: There are a dozen contenders left in a light-hearted competition to be named the most iconic item in the Smithsonians various collections.

title: Cars to Watch, and Wish For, at the Monterey Auctions
description: Rob Sass offers his take on some notable cars up for auction in Monterey.

title: In Atlanta, Jury Selection Is Set to Begin in Test Scandal
description: ATLANTA  The trial promises to be both bizarre and tragic, with elementary teachers facing the possibility of prison, a major metropolitan school district named as a racketeering enterprise and the likelihood that students stray pencil marks on bubble-lined testing sheets will be scrutinized like hanging chads.

title: 1,500 Meters Seems Out of Reach for Women in Olympics
description: IRVINE, Calif.  On Tuesday, Nike ran a full-page ad in a local newspapers sports section recognizing the 30th anniversary of Joan Benoit Samuelsons victory in the inaugural Olympic womens marathon. The next day, the USA Swimming long-course national championships opened with the women competing in the 800-meter freestyle and the men contesting the 1,500 meters.

title: Taliban Take Responsibility for Bombing in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide attack on a coalition convoy passing through Kabul on Sunday killed four civilians and wounded 35, a potent reminder of the Talibans capacity to strike the capital.

title: June Krauser Dies at 88; Set 154 Records in the Pool
description: June Krauser, who broke scores of world records while in her 40s, 50s, 60s and 70s in a sport she helped found  she was known as the mother of masters swimming died on Aug. 2 in Pompano Beach, Fla. She was 88.

title: Judge in N.C.A.A. Case Known as Evenhanded
description: For years, Claudia Wilken has been known in her neighborhood mostly as a familiar face at school meetings. When her two children were teenagers about a decade ago, growing up a few blocks from the campus of the University of California, Berkeley, Wilken spent several years on Berkeley High Schools Site Council, involved in curriculum and funding decisions.

title: The Empiricist Strikes Back
description: If climate change doesnt scare you, and our failure to act doesnt inspire despair, youre not paying attention. And the great sin of the climate deniers is their role in delaying action, quite possibly until its too late.

title: Renouncing Partnership Structure, Pipeline Group Kinder Morgan to Reorganize as Single Corporation
description: In recent years, master limited partnerships have become an increasingly popular  and lucrative  structure for oil and gas companies.

title: Life After a Heroin Overdose
description: Gail Morris cares for her son Alex, who overdosed on heroin 13 years ago.

title: Stars Duel Till Dusk, and McIlroy Prevails at P.G.A. Championship
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  First the rain came, flooding an already soft and vulnerable Valhalla Golf Club on Sunday afternoon until the greens were ponds and the fairways were streaked by flowing rivulets.

title: Ebola May Pose Little Threat to U.S., but It Looms Large on Twitter
description: As the shadow of the deadly Ebola virus looms over Africa, its danger clear and present, a lesser kind of contagion, diffuse but persistent, has infected social media feeds in the United States.

title: President Obamas Africa Push
description: One major purpose of President Obamas landmark White House summit meeting on Africa last week was to advertise this often underrated continents economic potential and ensure it a brighter future. But determined follow-through will be required if the aspirations of the president and more than 40 African heads of state who were his guests are to be realized and Africa is to satisfy its promise as the worlds last big economic frontier.

title: A Judge Rules for Alabama Women on Abortion
description: In large parts of the country, womens access to safe and legal abortion care is increasingly coming to depend on the willingness of judges to rigorously examine and reject new (and medically unnecessary) restrictions imposed by Republican legislatures.

title: Controlling the Ebola Epidemic
description: On Friday, the World Health Organization formally declared an international public health emergency in response to what its director general, Dr. Margaret Chan, called the largest, most severe, most complex outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus in the nearly four-decade history of the disease. And what has the world done in those 40 years to defend against the disease? Not much. Apart from inflicting a staggering human toll, the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa has laid bare how unprepared the United States and other advanced countries are to protect and treat thousands of Africans whose lives are threatened by an extremely dangerous virus for which there is no cure.

title: 50 Million New Reasons BuzzFeed Wants to Take Its Content Far Beyond Lists
description: Here are three completely crazy insights about BuzzFeed, the viral content start-up:

title: Intervening in Our Name
description: Americans, it must be admitted, are not always the most engaged people on world issues. Its a sad truth.

title: A Mother Lifts Her Son, Slowly, From Heroins Abyss
description: SPARTA, N.J.  When Gail Morris came home late one night after taking her daughter to college, she saw her teenage son, Alex, asleep on the sofa in the family room. Nothing seemed amiss. An unfinished glass of apple juice sat on the table. She tucked him in under a blanket and went to bed.

title: Phosphorus and Freedom
description: In the latest Times Magazine, Robert Draper profiled youngish libertarians  roughly speaking, people who combine free-market economics with permissive social views  and asked whether we might be heading for a libertarian moment. Well, probably not. Polling suggests that young Americans tend, if anything, to be more supportive of the case for a bigger government than their elders. But Id like to ask a different question: Is libertarian economics at all realistic?

title: Weathering Hard Year and Wet Final Day at P.G.A. Championship, Els Perks Up
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Before Ernie Els prepared to attempt a long putt for eagle on the par-5 18th hole on Sunday, he paused to take a look at the large leader board, where the birdie-heavy final round of the P.G.A. Championship was being tracked. He saw where he stood in the sea of red numbers, but also what might have been.

title: A New Life for Refugees, and the City They Adopted
description: UTICA, N.Y.  Sadia Ambure is relieved that it is summer. I hate the snow, Sadia, who is 16, said. It hurts my skin. Im like a snake  my face turns red, then ashy.

title: Simplifying the Bull: How Picasso Helps to Teach Apples Style
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Apple may well be the only tech company on the planet that would dare compare itself to Picasso.

title: The Crowded Market for Casino Gambling
description: More than half the population in the Northeast now lives within 25 miles of a casino featuring video lotteries, table games or slot machines, up from about 10 percent a decade ago. As the market grows crowded, many older casinos are declining or going bankrupt.

title: With History of Drug Problems, Sport Seeks Intervention
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Horse racing has long conceded that it has a drug problem. On Sunday, some of the sports leaders announced that it would finally seek help by surrendering to a higher power: Congress.

title: Menahem Golan, Passionate Auteur of the B-Movie, Is Dead at 85
description: Menahem Golan, the colorful Israeli filmmaker who began his prolific B-movie career with Roger Corman, introduced audiences to Jean-Claude Van Damme and during his 1980s heyday directed action stars like Sylvester Stallone and Chuck Norris, died on Friday in Jaffa, Israel. He was 85.

title: A Few Words From the Publisher
description: The email from Michael Pietsch, chief executive of Hachette, written to reply to emails about the publishing companys e-book pricing.

title: An Unlikely Home in Utica
description: An old manufacturing city in upstate New York has become a haven for refugee families.

title: In a Fight With Authors, Amazon Cites Orwell, but Not Quite Correctly
description: Amazon must be spooked by the idea of writers massing against it, because over the weekend it launched its own counterrevolutionary force.

title: Scrambling Down an Iraqi Mountain, Yazidi Families Search for Missing
description: FISHKHABOUR, Iraq  Like sleepwalkers moving under a blazing sun, family after family from the Yazidi minority made their way across the narrow bridge that spans the river between Syria and Iraq, hardly seeming to see where they were going until they reached the Iraqi side.

title: Popular Demand
description: The top on-demand movies in any given week tend to be recently released titles like Transcendance and Tyler Perrys Single Moms Club that people may have missed  or opted out of  in theaters. Popular childrens films sell very well, too: The Lego Movie earned $258 million domestically, and continues strong in on-demand and DVD rentals.

title: Midterms Give Parties Chance for Sweeping Control of States
description: LAS VEGAS  It was over 100 degrees here the other evening, but inside a buzzing office tucked away on a stretch of gun stores and pornography shops, Democrats were staring into computer screens and talking urgently into cellphones. The stakes were high: The Nevada Senate, which Democrats control by a single seat, could very well shift into Republican hands after November.

title: Rivals for Governor Court Voters as Connecticut G.O.P. Primary Nears
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Thomas C. Foley and John McKinney would love to focus on the Democratic incumbent in the campaign for governor. But first, one must eliminate the other in the Republican primary on Tuesday, making their different styles and policy prescriptions all that matter for the time being.

title: Author of Broken Windows Policing Defends His Theory
description: In 1982, after another year of record lawlessness in New York City, two college professors advanced  or, more accurately, rekindled  a plausibly uncomplicated theory that would revolutionize law enforcement in the city: Maintaining public order also helps prevent crime.

title: Bee Turns Down a Balcony Garden
description: Dear Diary:

title: True Blood Recap: As the End Nears, Its All About Healing
description: Season 7, Episode 8, Almost Home

title: Death Highlights History of Confrontation for Racing
description: Nobody will ever know exactly what led the young Kevin Ward Jr. to think it was fine to climb out of his crashed car and, in the middle of his dirt racetrack on Saturday, to try to confront Tony Stewart as Stewart continued to circle the track.

title: Renewed Shelling in Donetsk
description: Artillery pounded Donetsk, Ukraine, on Sunday as the West warned Russia that any attempt to send humanitarian troops into the region would be deemed unacceptable.

title: Cuomo Will Visit Israel With Legislative Leaders
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the leaders of the State Legislature said on Sunday that they would make a unity trip to Israel this week in an effort to show support for the country amid the fighting in Gaza.

title: In Gaza, Grief, Anger  and No Small Measure of Pride
description: JABALIYA, Gaza  Two families from a destroyed neighborhood of the northern town of Beit Hanoun, with 18 children between them, have made a tidy home out of side-by-side stalls in the concrete courtyard of a United Nations school here. Colorful cloths form the walls, shoes are removed on entry.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 10, 2014
Ukraine Steps Up Assault of Rebel City
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Ukraine pressed ahead on Sunday with its military assault to stamp out pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country with its most intensive artillery bombardment of this rebel capital yet.

title: After Tuneup for Trials, American Swimmers Evaluate Potential
description: IRVINE, Calif.  If there was any lesson to take away from the most important domestic meet before the 2016 Olympic trials it was this: Michael Phelps hates to lose, and the other Americans would do well to adopt the same attitude, because no ones global supremacy is secure.

title: U.S. Actions in Iraq Fueled Rise of a Rebel
description: BAGHDAD  When American forces raided a home near Falluja during the turbulent 2004 offensive against the Iraqi Sunni insurgency, they got the hard-core militants they had been looking for. They also picked up an apparent hanger-on, an Iraqi man in his early 30s whom they knew nothing about.

title: Two Defensive Injuries End the Jets Preseason Stroll
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  More than two weeks into training camp, everything had been going so well for the Jets. No quarterback chaos, contract holdouts or disgruntled receivers. Just the daily grind, and enthusiasm for the coming season.

title: An Academy for the Elite Stirs a Culture Clash
description: BEIJING  With most students gone for the summer, the campus of Peking University is relatively quiet in August, save for the busloads of awe-struck adolescents on organized tours who hope to be among the 2,600 freshmen admitted each year to the Harvard of China, as it is widely known here.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: Jumping Into an Ice Cold Lake
description: Season 2, Episode 5, Giants

title: On Day of Several Firsts, Tsonga Captures Rogers Cup in Straight Sets Over Federer
description: TORONTO  Jo-Wilfried Tsonga captured a title and a bit of history Sunday, defeating Roger Federer in straight sets to become the first Frenchman to win the Rogers Cup in the Open Era.

title: The Leftovers Recap: Fathers and Sons, and a Wild Dog
description: Season 1, Episode 7, Solace for Tired Feet

title: Albany Doubling Down as Casino Boom Fades
description: ALBANY  New York State is charging headlong into the casino business, with four full-service gambling resorts expected to be approved this fall and opened as early as next year, and talk of a torrent of new revenue, thousands of new jobs and a powerful economic jump-start for long-depressed upstate communities.
