title: Sliding Braves Look to Their Past
description: ATLANTA  The heroes of the Atlanta Braves remarkable run of 14 straight division championships frolicked on the diamond of Turner Field late Saturday afternoon in a softball game for old-timers. The eight-time All-Star Chipper Jones scooped up ground balls at shortstop. The Hall of Fame pitcher Greg Maddux tossed a two-seamer, underhand, from the mound. The All-Star catcher Javier Lopez crouched behind the plate.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 11, 2014
description: Im worried about this generation, what memories are in their mind, what will happen after a few years.

title: Foursome Helps Finish Final P.G.A. Round in Time
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  All the scene lacked were a few cars pulled up to the edge of the 18th green, their high beams on to illuminate the gloaming that had enveloped Valhalla Golf Club.

title: Treasury Wine Says Buyout Firm Matches K.K.R.s $3.2 Billion Bid
description: HONG KONG  Two of the worlds biggest buyout firms appear to share a taste for Australian wine.

title: In Chokehold Case, Staten Island District Attorney Faces Big Test
description: On Staten Island, where all politics is so personal it is practically familial, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the district attorney, can count many friends in high places  and one very prominent former friend.

title: With Park Avenue Closed Above, a Tunnel That Sounds Like the Sea
description: The idea of walking down into the Park Avenue tunnel, a cavern of dark gray granite and corrugated metal in Midtown Manhattan, prompted Jana Winderen, an artist from Norway, to think about descending into another environment that lies beneath the surface: the deep sea.

title: U.S. Conference of Mayors Study on Wage Gap
description: Mayors across the U.S. released a study on growing income inequality in America.

title: Small Indulgences
description: Gold timepieces as slender and delicate as a womans wrist.

title: Word of the Day | yore
description: yore \yor\ noun

title: Blaze in Tower Injures 8
Task Force of Mayors Addresses Income Gap
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and about 40 of his peers will release a report on Monday showing that the income gap between the wealthiest Americans and middle and low-income households continues to widen  a trend with no signs of slowing down without policies to shrink the disparity.

title: Red Bulls Shut Out by Fire on the Road
description: Sean Johnson made four saves for his fourth shutout of the season, and Mike Magee scored in the Chicago Fires 1-0 victory over the Red Bulls in Bridgeview, Ill.

title: With Time Growing Short, New Offense Has Giants Attention at Last
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants were slow to adjust to the up-tempo pace demanded by their first-year offensive coordinator, Ben McAdoo, during organized team activities, no one expressed concern, because so much time remained to learn his system.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE PAST (2013) An Iranian, Ahmad (Ali Mosaffa), returns to Paris to give his estranged wife, Marie (Brnice Bejo, above, with Mr. Mosaffa), the divorce she seeks  and in the process opens a Pandoras box of secrets and lies  in this drama written and directed by Asghar Farhadi. Tahar Rahim plays the man Marie has taken up with, whose wife is in a coma. Elyes Aguis is their son, whose presence in Maries house means a playmate for her younger daughter (Jeanne Jestin). And Pauline Burlet is Maries older daughter, who finds the situation nearly intolerable. The narrative complications can be distracting, at times exasperating, but theyre finally irrelevant because Mr. Farhadis filmmaking is so fluid, and the performers, Ms. Bejo, in particular, are so attractive, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. As in A Separation, Mr. Farhadi shows a masterly gift for moving his characters and camera through rooms that  with a raised voice, a violent exit  become stages in a ferocious domestic drama. But here, keep your eye on the littlest players, the small ones trembling in the wings. In French and Persian, with English subtitles.

title: Corrections: August 11, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Systematic Killings in Egypt Are Tied to Leader, Group Says
description: CAIRO  A day after Egypt barred representatives of Human Rights Watch from entering the country, the group disclosed the source of the governments alarm: a report implicating senior officials, including Egypts current president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, in what it called the widespread and systematic killings of protesters.

title: Q. and A.: David Hoffman on Antimonopoly Investigations into Foreign Companies in China
description: Are foreign companies engaging in monopolistic practices in China, colluding with one another to hike up prices and engage in other unfair tricks? The Chinese government seems to believe so.

title: Student Crossword | Plants
description: Test your knowledge of plants by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: South Korea Proposes High-Level Talks on Reunions With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Monday proposed high-level talks with North Korea to discuss holding a new round of reunions of aging Koreans separated by the Korean War six decades ago.

title: Kerry Issues Warning to Iraqi Leader
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Secretary of State John Kerry warned Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq on Monday not to interfere with the process of picking a new Iraqi leader, cautioning pointedly that a power grab would lead to a cutoff of international support.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Safe Haven That Quickly Became a Place of Danger for Iraqi Refugees
description: In For Refugees on Mountain, No Water, Nothing, Alissa J. Rubin reports on conditions faced by the Yazidis of Iraq as they flee their homes.

title: Crossing Rivers, Searching for the Future
description: Marking a portion of Mexicos southern border with Guatemala, the Suchiate River beckons many of those embarking on the odyssey from Central America to the southwestern United States. Its name originates from Xochiatl, the Nahuatl word for flower water. Some cross the river on makeshift rafts. Others have been known to go by zip line.

title: An Early Look at JFK Opera
description: David T. Littles opera JFK, which looks at the 12 hours leading up to John F. Kennedys assassination in Dallas, is scheduled to have its world premiere at the Fort Worth Opera on April 23, 2016. But New Yorkers will be able to get an advance look in November. The American Lyric Theater, which is developing the score in a partnership with the Fort Worth company, will present a workshop performance of the opera-in-progress at Merkin Concert Hall on Nov. 25.

title: Balfour Beatty Rejects New Carillion Merger Effort
description: LONDON  The British construction and services company Balfour Beatty said on Monday that it had rejected a renewed merger approach from its rival Carillion after calling off talks last month.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Libertarianisms Prospects
description: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about the rise of libertarianism. Draper is the author of When the Tea Party Came to Town. His last article for the magazine was about Wendy Davis.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: New York Today: Central Park, Untamed
description: Good morning on this sunny Monday.

title: From Metta World Peace to The Pandas Friend
description: Call him The Pandas Friend.

title: Morning Views
description: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the World Health Organization, has declared the Ebola outbreakin West Africa the largest, most severe, most complex in the nearly four-decade history of the disease, according to an editorial in The New York Times. Apart from inflicting a staggering human toll, the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa has laid bare how unprepared the United States and other advanced countries are to protect and treat thousands of Africans whose lives are threatened by an extremely dangerous virus for which there is no cure. Because drug companies have little financial interest in developing a vaccine, traditional public health measures, like finding and isolating patients who become sick, tracing their contacts and using stringent infection control procedures in hospitals, remain the best bet for containing the epidemic.

title: Vietnam Gives Brief Show of Openness in Standoff With China
description: The reporters trip with the Vietnamese Coast Guard started with a meal, and the meal started with toasts.

title: Daily Report: Acculturating New Employees at Apple Through Careful Training
description: Steven P. Jobs established his companys internal training program, the so-called Apple University, as a way to inculcate employees into Apples business culture and educate them about its history, particularly as the company grew and the tech business changed. Courses are not required, only recommended, but getting new employees to enroll is rarely a problem, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: It's Not Too Late for Republicans to Win Latino Votes
description: Sometimes it looks as if Republicans want to attract Latinos. The G.O.P. post-mortem on the 2012 election recognized the need to embrace and champion immigration reform. Reaching out to Latino voters was highlighted in the partys Growth and Opportunity Project report as essential to the partys long-term sustainability. With good reason: Only 27 percent of Latinos voted for Mitt Romney in 2012, down four points from the 31 percent supporting John McCain in 2008.

title: Lessons From the Low-Tech Defeat of the Guinea Worm
description: Given all the talk about the hepatitis C drug Sovaldi in recent weeks, as well as the high prices on many other recent innovations, you might think that were entering a time when leaps forward happen only at great cost. That misses the point. It also strengthens the false notion that we can move forward only through advances in technology. As I said in another column not long ago, people are more important than technology.

title: Trying to Understand the Impact of a Higher Minimum Wage on Small Businesses
description: Does the battle over the minimum wage pit employees against small-business owners? That was the notion put forth on the Real Clear Politics website recently. In an essay titled Living the Wage? Try Living the Small Business, Tom Bevan, a co-founder of the site, ridiculed Democratic politicians who had embarked on an effort to understand how people subsist on minimum wage.

title: A Taste of Russian Dance in London
description: LONDON  Russias two great ballet companies have been on the road of late. The Bolshoi, based in Moscow, just ended a two-week tour of New York, and the Mariinsky Ballet from St. Petersburg is in the middle of a substantial season here. Despite laments of cultural homogeneity, Russian ballet is clearly still a powerful cultural export with its own audience-luring mystique.

title: Iraqis Nominate Maliki Successor, Causing Standoff
description: BAGHDAD  Under heavy pressure from the United States, Iraqi lawmakers took a significant step on Monday by choosing a replacement for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, widely blamed for their countrys polarized politics. But Mr. Maliki angrily rejected the move, vowing to fight in the courts and perhaps by use of force, throwing the country into new uncertainty even as it fights an onslaught by Sunni militants.

title: R.B.S. Exploring Sale of International Arm of Coutts Private Bank Unit
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland is exploring options for the international operations of its Coutts & Company private banking unit, including possible joint ventures or a sale, according to an internal memorandum on Monday.

title: F.B.I. Steps In Amid Unrest After Police Kill Missouri Youth
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The F.B.I. on Monday opened a civil rights inquiry into the fatal shooting by a police officer of an unarmed black teenager here as protests bubbled into a third night in this St. Louis suburb.

title: Morning Agenda: Kinder Morgan to Consolidate
description: KINDER MORGAN TO REORGANIZE | The pipeline group Kinder Morgan, the biggest of the master limited partnerships, announced on Sunday that it would acquire its three associated companies and reorganize as one corporation based in Houston, DealBooks David Gelles writes. The new Kinder Morgan will have an estimated enterprise value of about $140 billion  $100 billion of market value and $40 billion of debt  making it the third-biggest energy company in the United States, after Exxon Mobil and Chevron.

title: On Supreme Court, Does 9-0 Add Up to More Than 5-4?
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court issued a remarkable number of unanimous decisions last term, and in their public remarks the justices seemed unanimous in saying that unanimity was a good thing. But is it?

title: Louis Vuitton Debuts at Dover Street Market, a New Moon Juice in L.A. and Dancing in the Bronx
description: Ts list of things to do and see in the week ahead.

title: From Hero to Hateful: Recalling an Afghan Soldiers Descent
description: The recent green on blue attack that claimed the life of Gen. Harold J. Greene, the deputy commander for the Combined Security Transition CommandAfghanistan, has, for good reason, caused a fury of questions in the media about these attacks and what they meant. Who are the Afghans that carry them out? Why do they seem to suddenly turn on the Americans that have been fighting with them for years and years, struggling to help Afghanistan build something from the ruins of three decades of war. The answers, it seems, are complex, but also nuanced. And the questions reminded me of the worst case of post-traumatic stress syndrome that Ive ever seen.

title: Despite Criticism, Cuomo Holds Wide Lead Over Republican Challenger, Poll Finds
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo continues to hold a wide lead over his Republican opponent, even after a drumbeat of criticism over his offices hobbling of ethics investigations, according to a Siena College poll released on Monday.

title: Dream of a Gaza Seaport Is Revived in Truce Talks
description: SHEIK EJLEEN, Gaza Strip  An unmarked dirt lot about the size of a football field, on a cliff above the crashing waves of the Mediterranean, could be a crucial element in ending the monthlong battle between Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip.

title: A Felt Frenzy
description: Inspired by industrial fabric, designers are adding heft and durability to ladylike looks.

title: Chiquita Banana Brand Receives a Counter to Its Inversion Plan
description: Updated, 11:38 a.m. | Chiquita Brands International, the banana producer that is seeking an inversion with a $526 million deal for its Irish rival Fyffes, received an unsolicited offer on Monday from an unlikely pair of private companies.

title: Understanding a Ballplayer Turned Writer
description: Ben Strauss is a contributing writer for The Times. We asked him about the back story of his recent profile of Adrian Cardenas, a baseball player from Florida, who left a career as a high-earning professional athlete to study creative writing at New York University.

title: Postal Service Quarterly Loss Was $2 Billion, Despite Higher Prices
description: WASHINGTON  Despite an increase in revenue for nearly all of the Postal Services products, the agency continues to be mired in debt because of a congressional requirement to pay about $5 billion into a future retiree health care fund, post office officials said on Monday.

title: Looting Erupts in Missouri After Vigil
description: Crowds smashed car windows and looted stores following a vigil for an unarmed teenager who was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis.

title: Relearning How to Eat Fish
description: On a recent weeklong cruise along the shores of southeast Alaska, the dining room menu included wild salmon, Dungeness crab and sablefish. Many of my fellow 63 passengers had neither heard of nor tasted sable.

title: Men in Blazers Soccer Duo Moving to NBC
description: Men in Blazers, the cheeky British soccer analysts who became breakout media stars during the World Cup, are taking their self-proclaimed suboptimal ramblings to network television.

title: Cool Beans
description: From Ralph Lauren to Bergdorf Goodman, somethings percolating in the fashion world.

title: Learning to Shun the Instagram Life
description: "We should just move to the country and live in a tent.

title: A College Beach Party With a Twist, and More Than a Few Wrinkles
description: Building a college directly atop its own beach does not at first glance seem to be a great formula for academic success. A beautiful, protected beach, no less, with gentle waters and a wide apron of sand. By the logic of 1960s cinema, a setting like that should make students drop their books, run outside and peel down to their bathing suits for a dance party and a bonfire.

title: Kerry Asks Maliki to Not Stir Waters
description: Secretary of State John Kerry said that the formation of an Iraqi government was critical for stability and urged Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to not stir those waters by interfering.

title: Medicaid Rolls Are Growing Even in States That Rejected Federal Funds
description: Call it a side effect of the Affordable Care Act: Even in states that havent changed their Medicaid programs, nearly a million people signed up for Medicaid this year.

title: 1939: Cannes Prepares Film Festival
description: CANNES  The first International Film Festival, which opens here on September 1, will last three weeks, during which the best films of world production will be presented at a series of brilliant gala performances. The most celebrated French and foreign screen stars will be present. All film-producing countries have been invited to participate in the festival. American producers are particularly enthusiastic about this unique festival, at which they expect to show Hollywoods most recent pictures.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 12, 1939

title: Mourning a Racer Who Died Living His Dream
description: PORT LEYDEN, N.Y.  One friend learned the terrible news at 3 a.m. Sunday when his ringing phone woke him. Another was riding the bus to work when he heard. A woman found out in church, where the pastor offered prayers for Kevin Ward Jr. and his family.

title: Stand Out With an Anti-Rsum for Your Next Job Application
description: The writer Monica Byrne has created an Excel spreadsheet of everything shes ever failed at. Well, not everything  there are almost certainly some childhood spelling bees or soccer games, or both, left off. But her spreadsheet, which she calls her anti-rsum, does include all the rejections shes received for her creative work over the past six years  over 500 of them.

title: U.S. Finds Fresh Use for Seldom-Used Statute in Subprime Cases
description: Like a child with a new toy, the Justice Department is using a powerful civil fraud provision to investigate potential wrongdoing in the marketing of securities backed by risky auto loans. This opens up a new front for the government to pursue large monetary penalties against companies that package loans made without paying too much attention to whether the borrowers are credit worthy.

title: In Britain, Nuclear Reactors to Be Shut Down in Fault Investigation
description: LONDON  EDF Energy, the British subsidiary of the French state-controlled utility, said on Monday that it was shutting down three nuclear reactors and that a reactor with a fault that has been shut down since June would remain so. The facilities, which are being investigated as a precaution, generate nearly a quarter of nuclear capacity in Britain.

title: Introducing 36 Hours
description: The new video series from The New York Times is a travelers guide to a citys most delicious, adventurous and fascinating must-see destinations.

title: In Performance | Ramin Karimloo
description: Ramin Karimloo, on banjo, with Sergio Ortega on guitar, performs Bring Him Home from the musical Les Misrables, now at the Imperial Theater.

title: Upscale Hotel, Working Farm
description: Many upscale hotels have on-site gardens, but the Home Ranch, a Relais & Chteaux property situated in the Elk River Valley in Clark, Colo., is going one step further with its new six-acre farm.

title: Daniel Finkels Flying Squirrel-Frog
description: This weeks challenge was suggested by regular contributor Daniel Finkel, who plunges us into the wild world of nature to witness a rare semi-amphibious creature in an unfortunate predicament. Heres Dr. Finkel with

title: Bloomberg Names New Head of Live TV Unit
description: Bloomberg has appointed Claudia Milne, a veteran news producer for the BBC, as its new head of live television in the United States.

title: No Comment Necessary: Join a Militia
description: Tom Tancredo, the former five-term congressman and co-chairman of the right-wing Team America PAC, suggested that if Republicans failed to make the case for impeaching President Obama, then the base might as well join a militia.

title: Rag & Bone Interprets Its Fall/Winter 2014 Collection Through Dance
description: For the fall season, we wanted to show our womens wear collection from different points of view, says Marcus Wainwright, the co-creative director, with David Neville, of Rag & Bone. Points of view are historically important to the label: in previous seasons, Wainwright and Neville have given models the freedom to photograph their own campaigns.

title: Barneys Agrees to Pay $525,000 in Racial Profiling Inquiry
description: After a nine-month investigation, Barneys New York has agreed to pay $525,000 in costs, fees and penalties and institute a host of reforms to settle accusations that it singled out minority shoppers for heightened surveillance at its store on Madison Avenue.

title: Bob Weir Cancels Tour; Kings of Leon Cancels One Show
description: A message appearedon Bob Weirs website on Sunday saying that Mr. Weir, 66, a founding memberof the Grateful Dead, was canceling all scheduled performances  specifically, a tour with his band RatDog  through January 2015. The tour was to have started in Boston on Thursday. Ticket refunds were offered, but no reason was given for the cancellation other than that it was necessitated by circumstances.

title: Statins Dont Require Routine Liver Tests
description: When statins first came into wide use, warnings about possible liver damage were common, and some patients on the cholesterol-lowering drugs have their liver function monitored. Now a study has found that the risk was probably exaggerated.

title: In a Novelists World, You Choose Your Race
description: In the weak light of a February afternoon, Kelly Thorndike has a strange chance encounter in a Baltimore parking lot with Martin Lipkin, an old friend from high school. But time has brought a big change. The Martin that Kelly knew was white. The man standing before him is black.

title: Aspirin May Cut Cancer Risk
description: A large review of available data has confirmed what many experts have long suspected: Taking small amounts of aspirin over long periods of time reduces the risk of colon cancer and certain other cancers.

title: Measuring the Apology of Kevin Rudd, Former Prime Minister of Australia
description: This is the third apology in our Apology Metrics series in which we present apologies for readers to assess. Our goal is not to evaluate apologies as theatrical performances but to evaluate the apologizers behavior over time to see whether there has been genuine change. This time, we will look at the apology of Kevin Rudd, the former prime minister of Australia, to Australias indigenous community in 2008. With the benefit of six years of hindsight, we are in a much better position to judge the apologys authenticity.

title: Coaxing Fire and Police Staffs in Arizona to Cut Own Pensions
description: PHOENIX  Bryan Jeffries, the chief of Arizonas firefighters association, has been arguing to anyone who will listen that his members  and the states police officers, too  should volunteer to cut their own pension benefits.

title: Cold Poached Pacific Cod with Spices
description: In the authentic Middle Eastern version of this fragrant/spicy dish, a whole fish is filleted, the bones are used to make a fish stock, and the fish fillets are rubbed with a spice mix and poached in the stock. But fillets off the bone are easier to find than whole fish, and Pacific cod is a good choice. I used a vinegar court-bouillon, an easy, lighter fish poaching stock to throw together. Alternatively, use a fish stock or a plain vegetable stock. You may need to poach the fish in batches, which is fine as they are served cold.

title: Monday Motorsports: Nascar Victory Shares Spotlight With Tragedy
description: A.J. Allmendinger scored a redemptive victory in the Nascar Sprint Cup race at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Sunday, but it was a day of mourning and soul-searching in the racing community.

title: Grilled Skirt Steak With Herbs
description: Melissa Clark shows how to grill and slice skirt steak, which she first marinates in a mixture of garlic and herbs.

title: Skirt Steak Works Great for Grilling
description: Skirt steak isnt winning any beauty pageants. Its a long, lanky, awkward contender for your grill. You wont be able to give it those pronounced crosshatched grill lines, and its flat shape gives you thin, squiggly slices rather than nice, wide planks. If you want pretty and iconic, splurge on a rib or strip steak.

title: An Unusual Gangster: Doug J. Swanson Talks About Benny Binion
description: Doug J. Swansons Blood Aces documents the colorful, violent life of Benny Binion, the gangster who made his bones in Depression-era Dallas before moving to Las Vegas (with the law in hot pursuit). In the desert, he opened the Horseshoe casino and introduced the World Series of Poker. The book also tells the story of Binions rivals, like Herbert Noble, nicknamed the Cat because he survived 11 attempts on his life  but alas, not the 12th. In a recent email interview, Mr. Swanson discussed Binions penchant for danger, the difficulties in researching his life and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Fantasy Football: Preseason Stock Watch, Week 1
description: Preseason games in the N.F.L. can sometimes be misleading when it comes to fantasy football analysis. Every coach has a different agenda in preparing for the season and players are competing in situations that do not resemble a regular season game, when fantasy points are calculated.

title: Jeff Goldblum and His Jazz Band to Kick Off Season at Caf Carlyle
description: Jeff Goldblum,Rita WilsonandMolly Ringwaldare among the actors set to display their musical merits at the Caf Carlyle this fall, organizers of the Carlyle Hotels cabaret announcedMonday.

title: Roger Viviers New Muse
description: The curator and design-world darling Ambra Medda has collaborated on a special sequined version of the houses classic Miss Viv bag, inspired originally in 2009 by another statuesque beauty: Frances former First Lady, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy.

title: Kasparov Is Soundly Defeated in Bid to Lead Chess Federation
description: Garry Kasparov, the former world chess champion, rarely tasted defeat in his long playing career. But on Monday, in an election for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, the games governing body, Mr. Kasparov received a stinging rebuke in his effort to unseat the incumbent, Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov. Mr. Ilyumzhinov won handily, by a vote of 110 to 61, in Tromso, Norway.

title: Clearing the Path Home
description: The transitions coach ducks into your mothers hospital room for a brief introduction before shes discharged. The coach explains that her job is to help keep patients safe at home and asks if she can call to set up a home visit.

title: Emmys 2014: Who Are Your Picks for Lead Actor in a Comedy?
description: In advance of the Emmy Awards on Aug. 25, were asking you to tell us who deserved their nominations and who should have been nominated. Next up is lead actor in a comedy series. Take a look at this alternative list  its made up of the actual nominees, popular and critical favorites who werent nominated, and my own choices. Cast your votes in the comments, and let us know whos still been left out.

title: New Deadline for Met Opera Negotiations: Sunday
description: Updated, 3:01 p.m. | The Metropolitan Opera, which has been threatening to lock out its workers if they do not agree to concessions, has set a new deadline for reaching an agreement with its unions: Sunday night, a little more than a month before the opera season is set to open.

title: Outrage Over Teenagers Death Erupts on Social Media
description: The weekend shooting of Michael Brown, 18, who was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., a St. Louis suburb, is drawing outrage on social media outlets such as Twitter and Facebook. The shooting is now being investigated by the F.B.I.

title: Italian Museum Removes Sculpture by Chapmans After Childrens Group Complains
description: ROME  A sculpture depicting two nude pubescent girls by the British artists Jake and Dinos Chapman was removed from Italys national museum for contemporary art over the weekend after a childrens rights organization denounced it as child pornography.

title: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Warns on Bitcoins
description: Bitcoin is in the cross hairs of another federal agency.

title: White House Picks Engineer From Google to Fix Sites
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  Faced with the politically devastating collapse of HealthCare.gov last year, President Obamas White House staff lured Mikey Dickerson away from Google to save the day.

title: Two Luxury Names Expand Their Marketing Collaboration
description: DuJour, the quarterly luxury lifestyle magazine, and the Gilt Groupe, the digital retailer, are collaborating on new cross-promotions and other initiatives, all aimed at making them both more attractive to high-end brands.

title: A Low-Brow Day in Harvards Backyard
description: Im a big fan of sports that Im not a big fan of. Earlier this summer, for example, I learned the rules of cricket watching a match on a wide screen at a bar in Guyana. Last fall I went to an equestrian event in upstate New York. I enjoyed both immensely  though I could do without ever seeing either again.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: Chicago Blues
description: Chicago is well known for its funky blues music. And some of the titles speak directly to the fate of the Red Bulls/MetroStars over the past decade in and around that city:

title: A Walk in the Woods to Open Keen Company Season
description: A Walk in the Woods, the play by Lee Blessing that follows Russian and American arms negotiators as they hammer out a deal on the outskirts of Geneva, will have its first major New York revival when it opens Keen Companys 15th season in September. Kathleen Chalfant (Wit,Angels in America) will star as the Russian diplomat, Andrey Botvinnik, with Paul Niebanck (Blood and Gifts) playing the American, John Honeyman.

title: Amid Iraqs Political Chaos, a New Polio Vaccination Campaign Faces Challenges
description: Increasingly worried about the possible spread of polio amid Iraqs escalating chaos, Unicef and the World Health Organization said Monday that they had begun a mass vaccination in what amounts to a test case of whether Islamist extremists will allow such an effort in areas they control.

title: To Solve a Problem of Size, Kinder Morgan Gets Bigger
description: Richard Kinders master class in financial engineering is back in session.

title: A Rift in Worldviews Is Exposed as Clinton Faults Obama on Policy
description: For the 19 months since Hillary Rodham Clinton departed as President Obamas secretary of state, she and Mr. Obama, and their staffs, have labored to preserve a veneer of unity over how they worked together and how they view the world.

title: Lupita Nyongo Wants to Braid Your Hair
description: In Braids, a short film for Vogue,the Oscar-winning breakout star of 12 Years a Slave, Lupita Nyongo,chats about her favorite pastime: braiding hair  a talent she picked up from an aunt, the owner of an African beauty salon, during her college years. I learned how to cornrow and box-braid and twist. Now I really enjoy braiding hair for my friends.

title: Norways Oil Fund Buys Londons Savile Row
description: LONDON  The famed custom tailors of Savile Row have a new landlord.

title: ScienceTake | To Eat, or Not to Eat
description: A very few neurons may control appetite.

title: A Mouse Switch Turns Off Appetite
description: Deep in the mouse brain, scientists recently found that a very small network of cells, a few thousand at most, turns appetite on and off.

title: Let Them Eat Pizza (Cheese or Pepperoni)
description: Hot on the heels of the pizza cookie comes a new pizza-related innovation: Push for Pizza, an app that lets you order a pizza by pressing a button.

title: Fed Official Warns Disappointing Growth Could Foretell Future
description: Sounding a somber note even as the economic outlook in the United States brightens, the Federal Reserves No. 2 official acknowledged on Monday that global growth had been disappointing and warned of fundamental headwinds that might temper future gains.

title: Walkabout: Airbnb Gains Ground in San Francisco
description: Airbnb Inching Out of Regulatory Shadow As the discussion of a sharing economy continues across the country, one city  San Francisco  moves closer to embracing Airbnb and similar companies with new legislation. (San Francisco Chronicle)

title: Five to Follow | A J.Crew Stylists Instagram, a New Global E-Commerce Site and More
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: A Cuomo Primary Opponent Can Run, a State Judge Rules
description: A New York judge on Monday rejected an attempt by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to block a little-known opponent, Zephyr Teachout, from challenging him in the Democratic Party primary on Sept. 9.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Aug. 5-11, 2014
description: Take the quiz to see what you know about the news stories below, and to find links to more information about each.

title: The World of Dancehall
description: The photographer Radcliffe Roye of Brooklyn has spent years exploring the exuberant dancehall music scene at clubs and parties in Jamaica.

title: In Brooklyn, Officials Court Democrats in Bid to Host 2016 Convention
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, bragging about his home borough of Brooklyn, name-checked Big Daddy Kane and Lena Dunham.

title: 1964: Paris Studying Les Halles Area
description: PARIS  The Paris Municipal Council said today [Aug. 11] that it has appropriated $300,000 to study what to do with the tradition-cloaked Les Halles market area once the market moves out two years hence. The cramped wholesale food market, which has tied up traffic near the center of the city for years, will be replaced by a new complex in the suburban town of Rungis. One of the most controversial plans for the Halles area would raze completely a 750-acre slice of land. Out of the rubble a business center would rise with Pariss first real skyscrapers. The war against a Brasilia-on-the-Seine has been mounting in the Paris press.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 12, 1964

title: The Work of Art That We All Inhabit
description: Bernhard Edmaier, who was trained as a civil engineer and geologist, decided 20 years ago to concentrate on photography. His Patterns of the Earth (2007) emphasized shapes; Earth on Fire (2009) focused on volcanoes and lava. His new book of geology-informed photographs, EarthArt: Colors of the Earth (the title page renders EarthArt as EARTH), ravishes the eye with combinations of pattern and riotous colors from around the world, in coffee-table size.

title: New Concerns About an Old Heart Drug
description: A large new study found that one of the oldest and most commonly used heart medications may shorten the lives of patients with atrial fibrillation, a common type of irregular heartbeat that afflicts about three million Americans. The findings are prompting some experts to warn that the drug should be prescribed less widely.

title: Do Living Wills for Banks Even Make Sense?
description: Last week, while some of us were trying to do our part to reduce the worlds oyster population, the Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation decided that it was time to reject the living wills submitted by all of the major financial institutions.

title: Russian Intervention in Ukraine Is Likely, NATO Says
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The prospect of a Russian intervention in eastern Ukraine appeared to rise sharply on Monday, threatening to tear open what is already the greatest fissure between the East and West in the post-Cold War era.

title: Rat Cages and Mixed Marijuana Messages in Colorado
description: The State of Colorado, national pioneer of legalized marijuana, began an ad campaign this week to prevent young people from getting high. It is spending $2 million on awebsite, TV and movie-theater ads and something you could call public-service conceptual art: a bunch of large wire cages placed in public places, like the ones for rodents, but big enough to hold teenagers.

title: Emma Stone in Talks to Join Cabaret Cast
description: Emma Stone (Magic in the Moonlight, The Amazing Spider-Man) is in talks to make her Broadway debut as Sally Bowles in the Roundabout Theater Company revival of Cabaret, a spokesman for the show confirmed on Monday. Ms. Stone would take over the role when Michelle Williams leaves the show on Nov. 9.

title: Jets Get Creative at Cornerback After Injuries to Two Players
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  At practice Monday, Antonio Allen played cornerback for the Jets. Before Monday, Allen had never played cornerback.

title: Best Selling Science Books
description: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little, Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of The Tipping Point and Outliers. (2)

title: Women of War Speak
description: When they signed up for the Indiana National Guard, the three women at the center of Helen Thorpes compelling new book, Soldier Girls, never imagined they would end up in a combat zone in Afghanistan or Iraq.

title: A Monster Stands Tall Among Her Colleagues
description: Ive been flying for business for about 20 years. I used to travel mostly to Asia and Mexico, and then started traveling mainly to Asia. If Ive learned one thing about flying so much its that it sure isnt making me younger. Right now as C.E.O. of the digital multimedia solutions company Fluendo I travel quite a bit, and basically Im somewhere other than home about two weeks out of the month. It can be difficult, but thats what I have to do.

title: One for All, and All for Hunt
From Scraps of Bass, Ceviche Is Born
description: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I.  My son Mick looked up from the big striped bass he had laid across the tailgate of our pickup. He had caught the fish the night before from rough water near Block Island in Rhode Island. Pulled from the ice in the morning, it measured 46 inches. But now he was dissatisfied.

title: Better Than First Class, an Entire Suite in the Air
description: LOS ANGELES  AIR travel in coach being more uncomfortable than ever, I was receptive when a woman with Etihad Airways flagged me down on the trade show floor at the Global Business Travel Association convention here recently and led me to a display of the newest example of luxury in commercial flying.

title: Scientists Create a 3-D Model That Mimics Brain Function
description: A doughnut created in a lab and made of silk on the outside and collagen gel where the jelly ought to be can mimic a basic function of brain tissue, scientists have found.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Gaza City and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Spain, Ukraine and Pakistan.

title: Heres Why Stealing Cars Went Out of Fashion
description: Auto theft isnt much of a problem anymore in New York City. In 1990, the city had 147,000 reported auto thefts, one for every 50 residents; last year, there were just 7,400, or one per 1,100. Thats a 96 percent drop in the rate of car theft.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Albums From Gaslight Anthem and Swallow/Talmor/Nussbaum
description: THE GASLIGHT ANTHEM

title: A Pat on the Bacteria, Hubble Led the Way, Larger Than Life
description: Hygiene

title: What to Watch (if Youve Seen the Rest)
description: The television gods doled out a fair number of decent shows in the first seven weeks of summer, but now comes a bit of a lull until the new fall series arrive. Its a chance to check out some lower-profile fare that has come along in recent weeks on TV and the Internet.

title: JPMorgan Strikes Deal to Spin Off Its Private Equity Arm
description: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to spin off its private equity unit through a deal with two investment firms, realizing a long-held goal for the bank.

title: Tactic in Alzheimers Fight May Be Safe, Study Finds
description: The 40-year-old man showed up in Dr. Mary Malloys clinic with sadly disfiguring symptoms.

title: Harassment in Science, Replicated
description: As an undergraduate student in biology, I spent several weeks in Costa Rica one summer with an older graduate student on a research project deep in the cloud forest. It was just the two of us, and upon arriving at our site, I discovered that he had arranged a single room for us, one bed.

title: To Binge at the Fringe
description: It says a lot about New York that a man dressed as a penguin attracted so little attention. The man was Xavier Toby, an Australian comic and coal miner, and the occasion was the 18th annual New York International Fringe Festival, which features Mr. Tobys high-concept, low-comedy walking tour, 2014: When We Were Idiots.

title: St. Louis Officials Ask for Patience
description: Chief Jon Belmar of the St. Louis County Police asked that the public be reasonable as the complicated investigation into the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black teenager proceeds.

title: The Latest Soho House, in Chicago, Comes With Its Own Boxing Ring
description: The members-only social club Soho House unveils its latest venue today, in Chicago. While the brand, which originated in London and has other American locations in New York, Miami Beach and West Hollywood, is defined by exclusive, refined luxury, the Windy City edition has a rough-and-tumble element that pays tribute to Chicagos pugilistic roots: a custom on-site boxing ring.

title: Untangling the Mystery of Spider Silk
description: For its size, spider silk is stronger than steel, yet it is extraordinarily lightweight and stretchy. Now scientists are learning how spiders produce it.

title: For Female Rappers, Steadiest Gigs Are on TV
description: Good news! The most popular rapper in America in the last few months may well have been a woman.

title: Mets Breathe Easier as Niese Gets His First Win Since a D.L. Stint
description: PHILADELPHIA  A string of indistinct injuries has recently hit the Mets pitching staff, giving the team and fans a sense of nervousness every time a pitcher shows the slightest pain.

title: In the Ocean, Clues to Change
description: A few weeks ago, some 300 miles off the coast of New Zealand, scientists aboard the research vessel Tangaroa gently lowered two funky-looking orange orbs into the sea. Soon they disappeared, plunging of their own accord toward the depths of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Obama Pledges Support for a New Iraqi Leader
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  President Obama said Monday that Iraq had taken a promising step forward in forming a more inclusive government even as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki appeared to resist efforts to replace him as the countrys leader.

title: Health Maze: Go-Ahead or Runaround?
A Galaxy That Doesnt Look Far, Far Away
description: A clear, detailed image of the Messier 33 galaxy has been captured by the V.L.T. Survey Telescope in Chile. Messier 33, the second-closest large galaxy to the Milky Way, is packed with bright star clusters and clouds of gas and dust.

title: Africa, With U.S. Help, Graduates More Doctors
description: An ambitious United States government project to strengthen medical education in sub-Saharan Africa is reporting broad progress in addressing the continents critical shortages of physicians and health care workers.

title: A Sour Note on a Day for Schubert
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  During a period when classical music institutions fret over how to entice audiences, the conductor and music historian Leon Botstein has asserted that the worst thing we can do is dumb down the programming. The longtime president of Bard College, Mr. Botstein has put this credo into practice with the annual music festivals he presents on the Bard campus, offering two jampacked weekends of concerts and lectures exploring the life and times of a particular composer. Friday night, the first weekend of the 25th anniversary Bard Music Festival, Schubert and His World, opened with an engaging lecture by Mr. Botstein, presenting an overview of Schubert, followed by a three-hour concert touching on several realms of his output.

title: Reflections on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-D Tool Guesses What a Photo Is Missing
description: A new digital editing tool allows users to turn and flip objects in a photograph, exposing areas not even captured in the original image  turning a chair or flipping a car, for example, to reveal hidden backsides and undersides.

title: Human Rights in Myanmar
description: To the Editor:

title: Tech-Savvy Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Try Reclaiming Your Money
description: To the Editor:

title: What Jenny Lewis, Macklemore, The Flaming Lips and More Wore at the Outside Lands Music Festival
description: Another summer weekend, another star-studded music festival. This one was the seventh edition of Outside Lands, held late each summer in San Franciscos Golden Gate Park. It calls for more covered-up, layered looks than other summer music bashes thanks to a unique set of climate conditions described by the locals as Fogust. Headliners such as Jenny Lewis (in a rainbow-hued pantsuit that matched her guitar) and the Flaming Lipss Wayne Coyne (in a shaggy tinsel-trimmed jacket) sported warm yet statement-making ensembles that hinted at fall styles to come. Audience members bundled up in sweaters, long skirts and one odd American flag jumpsuit. The photographer Andrea Sonnenberg snapped the action onstage and off.

title: Tall, Ancient and Under Pressure
description: SEQUOIA NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  High in the Sierras, biologists are struggling to find ways to protect some of the worlds oldest and most storied trees from drought, forest fires and climate change.

title: Ruling in Challenge to Zephyr Teachouts Residency
description: Zephyr Teachout, who is challenging Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for the Democratic nomination, has satisfied state residency requirements, a State Supreme Court justice said.

title: Wild Dogs, Sexual Harassment in Science, Light That Alters Appetite
description: African wild dogs hunt in selfless packs to take down big game; a survey finds that female scientists still face sexism in the workplace; researchers use blue light to turn off hunger in mice.

title: Top Doctors, Dead or Alive
description: The official letter is sitting on my desk, announcing that a relative of mine has just been named one of the worlds top physicians in his area of expertise. Once he confirms his biographical details, he is guaranteed inclusion in online and print directories of similarly honored peers (not only a tribute to your success, but also a valuable resource for potential patients).

title: Ex-Banker to Lead Los Angeles Times
description: The Los Angeles Times has named Austin Beutner, a former deputy mayor of Los Angeles and Wall Street banker, as its new chief executive and publisher.

title: Yankees Winning Record Goes Against the Statistics
description: The Yankees spent July trying to supplement their roster for a shot at the playoffs. Through trades they added Martin Prado, Chase Headley, Stephen Drew and Chris Capuano, veterans who could stabilize the franchise in a tumultuous season.

title: Arbitrators Ease Blame on Ernst & Young for Audits of Lehman Brothers
description: The finger-pointing over who was responsible for the collapse of Lehman Brothers continues nearly six years after the firm filed for bankruptcy at the height of the financial crisis.

title: S.E.C. Finds Bond Fraud in Kansas
description: Federal regulators said Monday that Kansas had defrauded investors by bringing $273 million of bonds to market in 2009 and 2010 without disclosing that its pension system was deeply underwater and that the investors ran a risk of not being fully repaid.

title: President Obamas Statement on Iraq
description: President Obama said Iraq has taken a promising step forward with the appointment of a new prime minister and he pledged continued support in Iraqs fight against terrorist forces.

title: Robin Williams, Oscar-Winning Comedian, Dies at 63
description: Robin Williams, the comedian who evolved into the surprisingly nuanced, Academy Award-winning actor, imbuing his performances with wild inventiveness and a kind of manic energy, died on Monday at his home in Tiburon, Calif., north of San Francisco. He was 63.

title: Giants Join Ice Bucket Challenge to Raise Awareness of A.L.S.
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Victor Cruz dumped a bucket of ice water on his head at home on Sunday and then stepped out on thin ice himself  challenging the Giants co-owners to do the same.

title: Writing Is a Risky, Humiliating Endeavor
description: This essay was born when my ex-wife unfriended me on Facebook. She was angry over my last novel, though to my mind, the resemblances to her and me were superficial. The story  which involves kidnapping, murder, private eyes  was clearly not about us. I was shocked and saddened  Id hoped she would like the book  but this was not the first time Id had this sort of experience.

title: A Mountain of Uncertainty in Iraq
description: Adam Ferguson has been covering the refugee crisis in northern Iraq, where a persecuted minority has been trapped on a mountaintop.

title: A Campaign to Pique the Interest of Those Who Revel in a Deal
description: THE website that aggregates coupons for e-commerce sites, RetailMeNot, is introducing a national advertising campaign designed, in part, to increase the use of its mobile app.

title: Maliki Vows to Protect Iraq Constitution
description: The Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, accused the Iraqi president, Fuad Masum, of violating the Constitution on Sunday.

title: Iraqi Relief Flights Rescue Dozens, but Leave Thousands Behind
description: Dramatic images posted online Monday showed small numbers of Iraqis driven from their homes by extremist militants scrambling aboard military helicopters in the Sinjar mountains, where tens of thousands of people, mainly from the Yazidi religious minority, have been stranded.

title: Hillary Clinton, Barbed and Bellicose
description: The other night, a prominent Democrat I know made the craziest statement.

title: Publishers Turn to the Crowd to Find the Next Best Seller
description: Sandy Hall was nervous. Ms. Hall, a librarian in Morristown, N.J., was preparing one recent night to lead her weekly book club meeting with a group of 14 teenagers. The book being discussed, a young-adult romance titled A Little Something Different, was her own debut novel.

title: Killings Rise in Karachi as Taliban Target Police
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Karachis embattled police force recently passed a grim milestone  the killing of its 100th police officer this year, putting the force on track to exceed the 2013 toll of 166 police deaths, which was itself a record.

title: Pioneer of a Crossover Move
description: SAN ANTONIO  On her flight home from the 2012 London Olympics, Becky Hammon had a familiar seatmate  Gregg Popovich, coach of the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Can the G.O.P. Ever Attract Black Voters?
description: STORRS, Conn.  ON the morning of March 6, 1989, students began to gather at a flagpole on the campus of Howard University. Then they entered the administration building, chained doors shut, locked arms and announced that they would not leave until key demands were met. A dozen or so stragglers  I was one of them  climbed in through a second-story window to join the protest. By nightfall, more than 2,000 students occupied the building.

title: Now Arriving at Pittsburgh International: Fracking
description: PITTSBURGH  Where 600 flights used to take off and land every day here at Pittsburgh International Airport, there are now about 300. Partway down Terminal B, the moving sidewalk that used to lead to a dozen gates now stops abruptly at a plain gray wall.

title: New York Prosecutors Charge Payday Loan Firms With Usury
description: A trail of money that began with triple-digit loans to troubled New Yorkers and wound through companies owned by a former used-car salesman in Tennessee led New York prosecutors on a yearlong hunt through the shadowy world of payday lending.

title: A Healthier Pineda Is Ready to Return
description: BALTIMORE  The right-hander Michael Pineda is scheduled to return to the Yankees rotation Wednesday and make his first appearance for the team in almost four months.

title: Standing Guard Over a Monarchys Tainted Legacy
description: ROME  For 136 years, the Honor Guard to the Royal Tombs of the Pantheon has stood watch over the mortal remains of the Savoy kings who formerly ruled Italy, paying a discreet, sober tribute to a once-powerful dynasty in recognition of its role in unifying the country.

title: Alofts Demo of the Botlr Bellhop Robot
description: In a promotional video, the robotic bellhop built for Aloft Hotels delivers an item to a guest in his room.

title: Beep, Says the Bellhop
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Think of it as the Terminators human-friendly sibling.

title: Public Housing in New York Reaches a Fiscal Crisis
description: Everyone, it seems, wants a piece of New York City public housing.

title: From Sneakers to OBannon
description: When I first heard about the decision, I was speechless, said Sonny Vaccaro. Speechless as in he never thought this day would come.

title: Invader Batters Rural America, Shrugging Off Herbicides
description: WHEATFIELD, Ind.  The Terminator  that relentless, seemingly indestructible villain of the 1980s action movie  is back. And he is living amid the soybeans at Harper Brothers Farms.

title: Remembering Robin Williams
description: Robin Williams, the groundbreaking stand-up comedian and Oscar-winning actor, died on Monday in home in Tiburon, Calif. He was 63.

title: Robin Williams, Oscar-Winning Actor, Dies at 63
description: Mr. Williams imbued his performances with wild inventiveness and a kind of manic energy

title: Fabian G. Palomino, 90, Legal Counsel to Democratic New York Governors, Dies
description: Fabian G. Palomino, who advised Democratic governors of New York State from W. Averell Harriman to Andrew M. Cuomo and who was particularly influential in the administration of Mario M. Cuomo, a friend since law school, died last Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: For 2 U.S. Presidents, Iraqi Leader Proved a Source of Frustration
description: WASHINGTON  One day in the fall of 2007, President George W. Bush joined Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki in a video conference to sign a declaration of principles on the future of the Iraqi-American relations. As Mr. Bush scrawled his name, Mr. Maliki in Baghdad just passed his pen over his copy, pretending to sign.

title: Dotty Lynch, Pollster Who Saw the Gender Gap, Is Dead at 69
description: Dotty Lynch, who was the first woman to be chief polltaker for a presidential campaign and one of the first to recognize the potential benefit of developing campaign themes aimed specifically at winning womens votes, died on Sunday in Washington. She was 69.

title: Kinder Morgans Reorganization Puts Master Limited Partnerships in Question
description: What happens when the pioneer of an industry abandons its own legacy?

title: A Teachout Moment
description: New York State voters rarely have enough real choice on their ballots, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo seems determined to keep it that way. Ever since another Democratic candidate for governor, Zephyr Teachout, arose on his left, Mr. Cuomo has tried to throw her off the primary ballot on the shaky grounds that she hasnt met the states five-year residency requirement.

title: Where Voting Is Now Easier
description: At a time when many states are making it harder to vote, 16 states have provided some good news over the last year by deciding to go in the opposite direction. In various ways, they have expanded access to the polls, allowing more people to register or to vote more conveniently. The list, compiled by the Brennan Center for Justice, includes these states:

title: At Heart of Ebola Outbreak, a Village Frozen by Fear and Death
description: NJALA NGIEMA, Sierra Leone  The signs of a deadly struggle remain: Scattered around the houses of the Ebola dead lie empty pill packages, their plastic casings punched through. Nearby in the mud are used packets of oral rehydration salts. The pills did not work, and the hurried trip to the hospital, if there was one, came too late.

title: New Deadline Set for the Metropolitan Operas Labor Talks
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which has been threatening to lock out its workers if they do not agree to concessions, has set a new deadline for reaching an agreement with its unions: Sunday night, a little more than a month before the opera season is set to open.

title: Iraq Needs a New Prime Minister
description: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki emerged from relative obscurity in 2006 when he was elected prime minister of the first government in Iraq formed after a period of caretaker rule. The best service he could perform now for his country would be to return to that obscurity as soon and as peacefully as possible.

title: Robin Williams in Pictures
description: A look back at the career of Robin Williams.

title: No Ignoring Elephant in Ryder Cup Room
description: LOUISVILLE, KY.  Hes back, or hes not back. Or its all about his back. The golf world wonders and waits once again on Tiger Woods.

title: Clinton, Obama and Iraq
description: Last week, Hillary Clinton had a fascinating interview with Jeffrey Goldberg of The Atlantic. The interview got immediate attention because of the way she discussed her differences with President Obama.

title: Accidents Cloud Future for Tony Stewart in Sprint Cars
description: This Saturday night was going to be a big deal at the Plymouth Speedway dirt track in Indiana. The Bob Newton Classic is scheduled to be run on the track, a three-eighths-of-a-mile banked oval, and Tony Stewart, the Indiana native and three-time Nascar champion, was planning to compete.

title: Pentagon Says Airstrikes Have Slowed but Not Stopped Sunni Militants
description: WASHINGTON  Four days of airstrikes have slowed the progress of Sunni militants laying siege to refugees on Mount Sinjar and advancing toward the Kurdish capital of Erbil, but the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria remains strong and on the offense, the Pentagon said Monday.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 11, 2014
Robin Williams in Pictures
description: A look back at the career of Robin Williams.

title: Will 3-D Printing Change the World?
Brown Beagle
description: Administrivial Blog Delay Alert! Due to it being mating season among the emus  and some scheduled website maintenance besides  the blog post for the Wednesday, August 12 puzzle, which normally posts Tuesday at 10:00 p.m. Eastern, will be delayed until 5:00 a.m Eastern Wednesday. The crossword puzzle will be live Tuesday night at 10:00 p.m., as scheduled.

title: Iran: Permanent Contraception Through Surgery Is Outlawed
description: Moving to allay the concerns of Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, about the countrys declining fertility rate, Iranian lawmakers on Monday passed legislation that prohibits all surgical operations to permanently prevent pregnancy. Passage of the legislation was part of a plan to prevent a population decline, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Under the measure, any violation would be considered a crime, punishable by fines. Exceptions were made for surgery urgently required for a patients health. Ayatollah Khamenei expressed alarm last winter about the conspicuous decline in births in Iran, saying he was shaking with fear about demographic trends that could reduce population growth to zero. The number of children per couple has fallen to 1.3 from a peak of 3.6 in the years after the 1979 Islamic revolution. Many young couples have said they are fearful of bringing children into the world, given Irans weak economy and isolation from Western sanctions.

title: Human Rights Council Plans to Investigate Gaza Conflict
description: The United Nations Human Rights Council on Monday appointed three legal experts to an international commission to look into whether violations of international humanitarian and human rights law were committed by Israel and the militant Palestinian group Hamas during the conflict in Gaza. The council, based in Geneva, set up the inquiry last month, and Navi Pillay, the United Nations top human rights official, said war crimes might have been committed by both sides in the conflict. A Canadian law professor, William Schabas, will lead the commission and will be joined by Doudou Dine, a lawyer from Senegal who has worked as a United Nations expert on racism. Amal Alamuddin, a British-Lebanese international law specialist, was announced as the third member, but later in the day she said she would be unable to serve on the commission, The Associated Press reported. Israel condemned the resolution setting up the inquiry as biased, misconceived and destructive.

title: Exhibit H From Lawsuit to Obtain Police Documents
description: A lawsuit seeking documents from the New York Police Department includes actual police reports from 1969 and 1970, describing surveillance of the Young Lords.

title: Lawsuit to Obtain Police Department Documents
description: Johanna Fernandez filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Aug. 7 asking a judge to order the New York Police Department to find and turn over documents regarding the Young Lords.

title: A Factory in Brooklyn That Constructs Homes Is Losing Its Own
description: Across from the Barclays Center sit hundreds of apartments built at a factory in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: A Village Devastated by Ebola
description: At the center of the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, the villagers in Njala Ngiema are afraid to return to homes where so many died.

title: Robin Williams, an Improvisational Genius, Forever Present in the Moment
description: Some years ago, at a party at the Cannes Film Festival, I was leaning against a rail watching a fireworks display when I heard a familiar voice behind me. Or rather, at least a dozen voices, punctuating the offshore explosions with jokes, non sequiturs and off-the-wall pop-cultural, sexual and political references.

title: Yanks Botch Chance to Narrow Gap
description: BALTIMORE  Buck Showalter was asked Monday afternoon about all the new players the Yankees have fielded since the last time he and the Baltimore Orioles encountered them, and he could not help joking.

title: At Unusual Hearing, Daughter Recounts 25-Year Quest to Catch Fathers Killer
description: Thanksgivings were the worst. Every year, when the family gathered, Joselyn Martinez would be reminded of her fathers death, how he had been gunned down in Upper Manhattan in November 1986.

title: The Man Who Drew the U.S. Back to Iraq
description: A look at Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, a militant group that now rivals Al Qaeda in power and popularity.

title: Police Files on Radicals Are at Center of a Lawsuit
description: With a radical political groups profile looming larger, police officials in New York kept watch on its movements, monitoring its takeover of a church, a demonstration outside of the Criminal Courts Building in Lower Manhattan and a school protest with parents and teachers.

title: Persecuted Yazidis Again Caught in Larger Struggle
description: The Yazidis are a religious minority of about 500,000 people whose ancient monotheistic faith has roots in Zoroastrianism and beliefs involving a 12th-century mystic and a peacock angel. Those characteristics make adherents, who are neither Muslim nor Christian, apostates in the eyes of Islamist fighters who are sweeping through villages across northern Iraq.

title: Manhattans Savor Spa Heads North to Woodstock
description: Since opening in the West Village in 2012, Savor Spa has drawn a loyal following among fashion industry types for its decadent-yet-affordable holistic facials and massages. Equally popular is the spas organic in-house skincare line, Om Aroma and Co., crafted from herbs grown in the Northeast and manufactured in the Catskills region near where the owner Angela Jia Kim and her family rent a weekend country house. So naturally, the next step for Kims business was to spin off a second location upstate. The newly opened 2,000-square-foot space, housed on the upper level of a barn house just east of downtown Woodstock  convenient to the Hudson Valley as well as the mountains to the west  offers yoga classes that incorporate aromatherapy and enough room to stretch out and stay all day. It is, Kim says, a place for people to come and breathe.

title: Word of the Day | ennui
description: ennui \n-we\ noun

title: Special Sauce for Measuring Food Trends: The Fried Calamari Index
description: Gather round, children, to hear tell of an ancient time in America, when cutting-edge restaurants would take cephalopods from the sea, slice them up, dip them in batter, fry them in hot oil, and serve the results with a wedge of lemon.

title: Protests Near St. Louis, Seen on Social Media
description: On Monday night, protests continued in Ferguson, Mo., a St. Louis suburb, in response to the weekend shooting of Michael Brown, 18, who was killed by a police officer. The chaotic night was captured on social media as police officers used tear gas and rubber bullets to try to disperse the crowds.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO Signature) ROCK OF AGES (2012) Tom Cruise, above, bares his torso to play Stacee Jaxx, an Axl Rose-like rocker, and Catherine Zeta-Jones is the neo-puritanical Patricia Whitmore, who has vowed to clean up the Sunset Strip to get her husband (Bryan Cranston) elected mayor of Los Angeles, in this jukebox musical turned big-screen attraction, directed by Adam Shankman. Diego Boneta and Julianne Hough are impressionable youths who dream of making it big in 1987 Hollywood. And Alec Baldwin and Russell Brand play a nightclub impresario and his sidekick. They make their stale buddy routine and romance amusing and, as with the rest of the adults, make the movie bearable, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. A whispering and writhing Mr. Cruise makes it watchable.

title: A Russian Convoy Carrying Aid to Ukraine Is Dogged by Suspicion
description: MOSCOW  A gift horse or a Trojan horse?

title: A Plea to Shun the Ivory Trade From Yao Ming
description: The Chinese basketball legend Yao Ming has for years lent his renown to wildlife conservation. In 2006 he took up the campaign against killing sharks for their fins, considered a delicacy in China. More recently, he has taken up the cause of elephants and rhinos, which are hunted for their ivory and horns.

title: U.S. Signals Willingness to Help New Iraqi Government
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The United States would consider expanding military and political support for Iraq if Haider al-Abadi assumes the duties of prime minister and leads a multisectarian government, Secretary of State John Kerry and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said on Tuesday.

title: Corrections: August 12, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Student Crossword | The Roaring Twenties
description: Test your knowledge of the 1920s by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Dismissed Officials in China Dont Always Disappear
description: When officials are fired in China, they dont always fade away. In fact, many make comebacks. An investigation by The Beijing News found that out of 85 officials who had lost their positions over the past six years, more than one-third eventually returned to public-sector jobs.

title: 6 Qs About the News | F.B.I. Opens Inquiry Into Police Killing of St. Louis Teenager
description: The questions below are based on three articles reporting on the police killing of a St. Louis teenager and the aftermath: Grief and Protests Follow Shooting of a Teenager, F.B.I. Opens Inquiry Into Police Killing of St. Louis Teenager and Outrage Over Teenagers Death Erupts on Social Media.

title: Memo to Self: Do Not Run for Office
description: Last month, Eliana Johnson of National Review gained access to a 144-page memo that was prepared by a team of political strategists working for the senate campaign of Michelle Nunn, the Georgia Democrat. Nunn, the daughter of Sam Nunn, the states longtime senator, is running against David Perdue, a Republican, to succeed Saxby Chambliss, who is retiring. While I am obviously not smart enough to be a political strategist  otherwise I would be paid more  it strikes me as advisable to keep a document like this under wraps, especially when it is so brutally self-critical in places (saying, among other things, that voters might dismiss Michelle Nunn as being a lightweight, too liberal and not a real Georgian). Already the document has become fodder for Twitter ridicule and at least one attack ad.

title: A Mountain of Uncertainty in Iraq
description: Over the last four days, Adam Ferguson has photographed members of Iraqs Yazidi minority religious group who had been surrounded on a mountaintop without water or food as a result of battlefield advances made by Sunni militants. As the refugee crisis continues, some have been able to escape into Syria this weekend. Mr. Ferguson, 35, freelances extensively for The New York Times as well as for National Geographic and Time magazine, and he spoke to James Estrin on Monday morning by phone from northern Iraq. Their conversation has been edited.

title: New York Today: Strong Moisture Transport
description: Good Tuesday morning to you.

title: Opting Against Ebola Drug for Ill African Doctor
description: The doctor who had been leading Sierra Leones battle against the Ebola outbreak was now fighting for his own life, and his international colleagues faced a fateful decision: whether to give him a drug that had never before been tested on people.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: Test Yourself | Dogs and Jealousy
description: Below, the first six paragraphs of Inside Mans Best Friend, Study Says, May Lurk a Green-Eyed Monster.

title: Morning Views
description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki ofIraqemerged from relative obscurity in 2006, a New York Times editorial begins. The best service he could perform now for his country would be to return to that obscurity as soon and as peacefully as possible. The country is in mortal danger from Islamist militants and needs a unifying hand at the helm, which Mr. Maliki emphatically is not. He bears heavy responsibility for the current crisis by alienating Sunni, Kurdish and other minority groups and undermining the Army and other national institutions through cronyism and corruption.Iraqs president named a more universally accepted candidate Monday, but Mr. Maliki refused to resign.Adding a constitutional crisis and a potential military coup to the great danger already posed by the jihadists is madness, the editorial board writes.

title: Photographing New York City in the Dark
description: Throughout The Timess headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: Dealing With the Press in China: Be Prepared to Sing!
description: Radio shows, TV appearances and print interviews are all part of a chief executives job, whether in China or the United States. But journalists work very differently in China, where editors typically give them a list of questions to ask  and very little leeway to go off script.

title: Salzburg Festivals Charlotte Salomon Falls Short on Drama
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Marc-Andr Dalbavie has long been a master of haze. Seuils (Thresholds), which this French composer wrote in 1991, the year he turned 30, opens with a ghostly, enveloping shimmer.

title: Morning Agenda: Uncertainty Over Master Limited Partnerships
description: When Kinder Morgan, a $100 billion empire that transports much of Americas oil and natural gas, announced on Sunday that it was abandoning the master limited partnership it helped popularize, questions emerged about what would happen to the many other such structures, DealBooks David Gelles writes. Largely because of Kinder Morgans success, the partnerships have become increasingly popular for energy companies. The structure allows them to pass all profits along to their investors as dividends and pay no corporate taxes, though the investors are subject to taxes on the distributions.

title: In a Word
description: Heres an extra-large grab bag of grammar, style and other missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and readers.

title: In Performance: Ramin Karimloo of Les Misrables
description: This week, as several theater critics of The New York Times revisit some long-running Broadway shows, our In Performance video is from the new Broadway revival of the musical Les Misrables, a show that originally opened on Broadway in 1987 and ran for over 16 years. The video features the number Bring Him Home sung by the actor Ramin Karimloo on banjo, with Sergio Ortega on guitar. Mr. Karimloo, in his Broadway debut, was nominated for a Tony Award for his performance as Jean Valjean. The show is at the Imperial Theater.

title: After 3-Year Hunt, Philippines Arrests Former General in Activists Disappearance
description: MANILA  The Philippine military on Tuesday captured a former army general wanted in connection with the disappearance of two students in 2006, a case that human rights groups say has come to symbolize the countrys legacy of abductions and abuses of leftist activists by members of the security forces.

title: Robin Williams, Irrepressible Character
description: Robin Williams was one of the most explosively, exhaustingly, prodigiously verbal comedians who ever lived, says film critic A. O. Scott. And the only thing faster than Williamss mouth was his mind.

title: A Deal Too Good to Turn Down, Unless Its Medicaid
Does the Prospect of Running for Office Discourage Women?
description: The electoral process is rarely described as pleasant. But is there something about facing voters that contributes to the relative lack of female candidates in American elections?

title: 25 Sentenced on Terrorism Charges in Western China
description: BEIJING  A court in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang has sentenced 25 people to prison for taking part in terrorist activities and harboring criminals, according to a report on Tuesday by Peoples Court Daily, an official publication.

title: Daily Report: Silicon Valley Hotel Puts Robotic Bellhop to the Test
description: On Aug. 20, the Aloft hotel in Cupertino, Calif., across the street from Apples corporate campus, will begin testing Botlr, a robotic bellhop that can shuttle items from the hotel lobby desk to guest rooms. Whether a gimmick or a sign of things to come, Botlr is the latest among a new generation of robots  like Googles self-driving car, Aetheons Tug hospital supply robot and Caddytreks electric golf caddy  that are starting to walk or roll around the everyday world, John Markoff reports.

title: Serious Fantasy on the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: Appetite for Online Orders Lifts Just Eat
description: LONDON  Reporting its results for the first time as a public company, Just Eat, an online food ordering service, said on Tuesday that its profit tripled in the first half of the year.

title: A New Line | Melitta Baumeister
description: Melitta Baumeisters sculptural designs are wild and weird but also eminently wearable.

title: Commissioner Vote Could Be Anybodys Ballgame
description: Some commissioner elections are landslides, with one favorite candidate and no opposition. Others are like old-style political conventions, filled with intrigue, rivalries and multiple ballots.

title: China Puts Pressure on Foreign Carmakers
description: HONG KONG  General Motors said on Tuesday that it had been contacted by the Chinese authorities as part of a broadening antitrust investigation into foreign automakers. One day earlier, Audi said that in one province, the dealership network of its Chinese joint venture had broken national antitrust rules and would be punished by the government.

title: With 4 Senior Lawmakers Retiring, Michigan Faces Loss of Its Clout in Congress
description: YPSILANTI, Mich.  When four senior members of Congress from Michigan retire this fall after a collective 134 years of service, they will leave a legacy that stretches from the woods of the Upper Peninsula to downtown Detroit.

title: Drummers Injury Sidelines Kings of Leon
description: Nathan Followill, the drummer forKings of Leon, will be out of action through the end of August, and with one exception  the groupsTuesdayevening performance on The Tonight Show  so will the band. Mr. Followills ribs were broken in a traffic accident on Saturday night, when the bands tour bus stopped suddenly to avoid hitting a pedestrian. The group canceled itsSundayevening show in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and posted a message about the accidenton its Facebook page, but held off on announcing further cancellations until Mr. Followills doctors weighed in. On Monday, they did.

title: Was an Accusation of Plagiarism Really a Political Attack?
description: There arent too many worse things you can suggest about an author than that his or her work is plagiarized. Its the book-world equivalent of spreading the word that a financial adviser has cooked the books or that the parish priest has designs on the altar boys. By its nature, even the suggestion is tarnishing.

title: An Alien at Home on TV
