description: In 1978, when Saturday Night Live still had almost all of its original cast, and prime time offered All in The Family, M*A*S*H, WKRP in Cincinnati, Taxi and Rhoda, there didnt seem to be any room  or need  for something fresh and different on television.

title: Weekly Quandary: Is It Impolite to Give a Child a Command?
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This weeks quandary, which is more in the nature of a discussion, comes from a recent blog post, in which Luisa Colon lamented her tendency to ask her kids almost everything:

title: The Incredible Bulk
description: More is more in modern furniture design, where what was once squared-off and sleek is now rounded, bulbous and supercomfy.

title: In Suburban New York, an Unlikely Link to a South Korean Ferry Disaster
description: BEDFORD, N.Y.  With its blue-and-gold regalia and its link to French royalty, the chocolate shop by the Bedford Hills train station looked as if it would fit right in when it opened several years ago in this well-to-do suburb.

title: Carlyle Invests in Chinese Classified Ad Site Ganji.com
description: The Carlyle Group is betting on online classified ads in China.

title: 1939: Grouse Head to White House
description: LONDON  A crate of grouse, destined for President Roosevelts dinner table at the White House, flew westward over the Atlantic tonight [Aug. 12] as part of the cargo of the Imperial Airways flying boat Cabot, making the second British air mail flight from Southampton to New York. The grouse were shot on Yorkshires famed Helmsley Moor early this morning soon after the dawn of the Glorious Twelfth of August which signals the open season on English and Scottish moors. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 13, 1939

title: Monogram Murders Mystery
description: One of the most famous detectives in literature returns, as Sophie Hannah takes up the mantle of one of the best-selling novelists of all time with her new mystery, The Monogram Murders. Solve the clues to find out who they are!

title: Which Book Is Begging to Be Made Into a Movie?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Dana Stevens discuss books that should get the big-screen treatment.

title: Helping Children Find Friends in a New Town (That Arent Your Friends, Too)
description: Theres a thing I do sometimes  I assume other parents do it, too  where I refer to myself and my children as a collective unit. It makes sense a lot of the time, because we do indeed go around as a group quite a bit. We are stuck in traffic. We love a lazy Sunday stroll. We hate banana-flavored candy.

title: Malikis Bid to Keep Power in Iraq Seems to Collapse
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis defiant fight to retain power in Iraq appeared to collapse on Tuesday after his former backers in Iran, the military and his own party all signaled that he could no longer expect their support.

title: What Happens When an Unarmed Teenager Is Killed  Again
description: The fatal shooting of an unarmed teenager, Michael Brown, by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., aSt. Louis suburb, has been met with outrage and skepticism in the largely African-American community, wrote Julie Bosman and Emma G. Fitzsimmons for The New York Times.

title: The Charles James Tour Is Not Yet Complete
description: Regret missing the much-lauded Charles James show at the Met, the satiny dark cool of which was predictably thronged with tourists through its last weekend?

title: 1964: Creator of James Bond Dies
description: CANTERBURY, England  Ian Fleming, 58, creator of the James Bond novels, died today [Aug. 12] following a heart attack. Mr. Fleming, a World War II naval intelligence commander, often was identified by Bond fans with the fictional hero. But the dapper former newspaperman scoffed at the idea, although some of those who served under him during World War II speculated that several of his exploits still might be cloaked by official secrecy. Mr. Fleming had been on vacation at Sandwich Bay, Kent, with his wife and son when he was taken ill suddenly last night, a friend of the family said. He died about 2:30 a.m. in Canterbury Hospital.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 13, 1964

title: Michael Muller on the Shark Photograph That Took One Year to Get
description: As a photographer who specializes in celebrity portraiture, Michael Muller has photographed some of the most famous people in the world, including Manny Pacquiao, Joaquin Phoenix and Rihanna. But one subject proved particularly elusive: a great white shark breaching at night. After a failed first try, Muller finally got his shot one year later when he returned to False Bay, South Africa. The resulting photograph ran in the Aug. 10 magazine.

title: Photoville Exhibition Returning to Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: United Photo Industries, the Brooklyn photography cooperative probably best known for The Fence  the 1,000-foot-long photo installation that began in Brooklyn in 2012 and has since had versions in Boston and Atlanta  will set up its third annual Photoville, a pop-up, modular exhibition space, in Brooklyn Bridge Park from Sept. 18 to 28.

title: Aurelie Bidermann Sets Up Shop in SoHo
description: Aurelie Bidermanns fanciful, travel-inspired jewelry has for several seasons been the toast of Paris. Tomorrow, the French designer opens her first U.S. boutique in New York, a city she calls her second home. The Lafayette Street storefront, with its striped awning and airy color palette, was inspired by New York and Los Angeles in the 60s and 70s, while the assortment within includes a series of exclusive scarab-themed pieces accented with lapis lazuli. The blue felt very New York to me, Bidermann explains.

title: Scenes of Chaos Unfold After a Peaceful Vigil in Ferguson
description: Three days of unrest have convulsed Ferguson, Mo., after Michael Brown, 18, an unarmed black teenager, was shot and killed by the police on Saturday. A peaceful vigil on Sunday was followed by rioting and looting that led to 32 arrests overnight. On Monday, scenes of unrest continued.

title: Officials on Russian Convoy Carrying Aid
description: Russias foreign minister, Ukraines deputy foreign minister and the European Union commissioner for international cooperation discussed the Russian convoy carrying aid to Ukraine.

title: Revel Resort in Atlantic City, Already Abandoned by Morgan Stanley, to Close
description: Banks have had a losing streak when it comes to playing in the casino sector. And the fate of the Revel Entertainment Group, an Atlantic City resort once backed by Morgan Stanley, serves as a prominent reminder of that.

title: W.H.O. on Use of Experimental Ebola Drug
description: Dr. Marie-Paule Kieny, the World Health Organizations assistant director general, announced that the agency would endorse the use of drugs untested in humans to combat the Ebola virus in West Africa.

title: A Meet-Cute of Professional Networking and Online Dating
description: Work and romance may seem like a bad combination, but as more work, and more romance, goes online, the two are meeting in interesting ways. LinkedUp is one startup banking on a version of the old saw that youre likely to meet your mate at work, while eHarmony, a veteran of online dating,has decided to deploy its expertise to match job seekers with potential employers.

title: Crash of Rescue Helicopter Kills Pilot; Times Reporter Is Injured
description: ERBIL, Iraq  A helicopter carrying aid from Iraqs Kurdish autonomous government to stranded Yazidis in the Sinjar mountains of northern Iraq crashed on Tuesday, killing the pilot and injuring other passengers, including a Yazidi member of Parliament and a New York Times journalist.

title: Why BuzzFeed Is Trying to Shift Its Strategy
description: In an interview about a new investment in BuzzFeed, Jonah Peretti, its co-founder and chief executive, told The New York Times, Were organizing ourselves to be a media company for the way people consume media today.

title: Shooting Spurs Hashtag Effort on Stereotypes
description: When Tyler Atkins heard about the fatal shooting of Michael Brown, 18, an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., he posted on Twitter a picture of himself in a tuxedo, with a saxophone around his neck, next to a photograph of himself dressed in a black T-shirt with a blue bandanna tied around his head and his finger pointed at the camera.

title: Cold Steamed Petrale Sole with Uncooked Tomato Sauce
description: This is one of my favorite ways to serve fish during the summer once my tomato crop comes in. The sauce is another version of the uncooked tomato sauce with mint that I gave you a few weeks ago with my tomato recipes, but this one is a bit sweeter, with balsamic vinegar, tarragon and basil standing in for mint. You could also use the minty sauce with these delicate fish fillets.

title: A Proper Setting for a Meal at the Beach
description: To Present: A Memorable Set of Nautical Plates

title: Bringing Down the Baby Walls
description: Dr. Mark V. Sauer of Columbia Universitys Center for Womens Reproductive Care talks about why collections of photos of the babies he has helped women to conceive can no longer be displayed there.

title: Robin Williams, R.I.P.
description: When Philip Seymour Hoffman died untimely earlier this year, my post on his legacy noted that he began to make his move as an actor  to make small roles big, to show that he deserved bigger chances still  around the time that I started to really pay attention to the movies, as a teenager in the late 1990s. So even if (like many people) I fully appreciated his place in the pantheon only after his death, there was never really a time when I didnt associate Hoffman with great acting, and that greatness with the moviegoing experience writ large.

title: Buffalo Bills Are Said to Draw Jeffrey Gundlach as a Bidder
description: The Buffalo Bonds? How about the Buffalo Treasury Bills?

title: Another Food Trend Story: Pizzas Inexorable Rise
Ed Nelson, a Star of Peyton Place, Dies at 85
description: Ed Nelson, a prolific actor who became a familiar face to American television audiences over 40 years, notably as a star of the prime-time soap opera Peyton Place, died on Saturday in Greensboro, N.C. He was 85.

title: Rihannas Summer Bucket Hat
description: August, for most of the fashion world, is the quietest month  a moment to soak up the sun before fashion week hits again in September. Its also a great time for both men and women to sport a no-fuss summer staple recently resurrected by Rihanna: the bucket hat. Also spotted at resort 2015 shows from brands such as Max Mara and Acne, the style will add swagger to any ensemble while shielding skin from ultraviolet rays. Whether plans call for yachting in Ibiza, camping in Oregon or astaycation in the city, these well-priced updates on the classic accessory balance function and fashion.

title: Baby Pictures at the O.B.s Office? No More.
description: If youve been charmed, annoyed, or brought to your knees with envy over the wall of photos of babies at your doctors office, prepare to be met instead by less personal photography or art (Georgia OKeeffe, perhaps?). Because of legal and privacy concerns, doctors offices are moving their bulletin boards of holiday cards into back offices and tucking into locked files the photos parents bring in to share. (Read more: Baby Pictures at the Doctors? Cute, Sure, but Illegal.)

title: The Lower Ambitions of Higher Education
description: Are you a HYPSter? Thats William Deresiewiczs term, in his new book, for Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Stanford, though it seems more idiomatic to apply that acronym to these schools graduates. With HYPSters, and with the recent graduates of the tier of elite American colleges a rung or two below them, he is unimpressed.

title: Teenagers in The Times | July 2014
description: Each month we publish a collection of articles about teenagers featured in The New York Times.

title: By the Numbers: An Interview With Obama
description: Last week, Thomas Friedman had a sit-down interview with President Obama. Here is a look at how many people it took to make the hourlong interview happen.

title: Kill Your Phone
description: Lawmakers in California on Monday passed a law that should help reduce cellphone theft by requiring phone makers to include a kill switch in their devices to prevent thieves from using them. Gov. Jerry Brown should sign the bill into law.

title: Winfried Bischoff Joins Board of JPMorgan in Europe
description: A lot of people who work on Wall Street, or in the City of London, choose a less-frenzied life by the time they reach 45 or 50. Winfried Bischoff, 73, has spent that long working in both, and has just signed on for more.

title: Wheelies: The Super-Size Sorento Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Fania All Stars Concert in Central Park Is Canceled
description: The Central Park concert by the Fania All Stars that was to have closed SummerStage onAug. 24has been canceled because of what a spokeswoman described as unexpected logistical, production and timing issues.

title: Ukraine Crisis Takes Toll on Germanys Economy, Powerhouse of the Eurozone
description: PARIS  An important reading on the health of the eurozone economy is expected to show this week that growth stagnated in the most recent quarter as German output faltered, confirming the assessment of many analysts that a lasting recovery remains out of reach for the region.

title: Prepping for the Obama Interview
description: Last week, President Obama sat down for an hourlong interview with Thomas Friedman, an opinion columnist. This video looks at how many people it took to prepare for the on-camera talk.

title: Robin Williams and the Science on Depression
description: The comedian and Academy Award-winning actor died Monday in a suspected suicide. Matthew Nock, a Harvard psychology professor who studies depression and suicide, talked to Benedict Carey about what we know about severe depression and suicide in the context of Williamss death.

title: Credentials Put in Doubt, Lawmaker Steps Down
description: JOHANNESBURG  Pallo Jordan, a veteran anti-apartheid politician and a leading intellectual in South Africa, resigned from Parliament on Monday night, a week after a newspaper reported that he had lied about his academic credentials.

title: Single Earrings
description: Jewels so striking that one, worn alone, is enough.

title: On Immigration, G.O.P. Starts to Embrace Tea Party
description: WASHINGTON  Late last month, as members of Congress were poised to leave for their summer recess, the House Republicans top policy experts found themselves in a barren conference room in the Capitols basement, negotiating with the partys most ardent opponents of immigration overhaul.

title: An SLS Hotel for Las Vegas
description: Las Vegas is already a popular weekend getaway for nearby Southern Californians. The new SLS Las Vegas hotel, opening Aug. 23, should make them feel right at home.

title: Missouri Police Cite Threats in Deciding Not to Name Officer Who Shot Teenager
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The chief of police here said Tuesday that he had reconsidered his decision to release the name of the police officer involved in the fatal shooting of an unarmed African-American teenager and would not do so because of concerns about the officers safety.

title: Did Kasparovs Outspoken Nature Cost Him the Election?
description: After a spirited campaign in which he traveled around the world,Garry Kasparov on Monday lost his bid to become the president of the international chess federation, bested by the eccentric incumbent, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, who has held the office since 1995. The race turned into a cold-war-like struggle over the future of chess and of Vladimir Putins Russia, and in the end it was not as close as Kasparov and his supporters expected.

title: Private Equity Battle for Treasury Wine Could Signal Its End as a Public Company
description: Wine may age better in the cellar than on the stock market.

title: After Human Rights Watch Report, Egypt Says Group Broke Law
description: CAIRO  The government on Tuesday accused the nonprofit group Human Rights Watch of breaking the law, violating Egypts sovereignty and insulting the judiciary after it issued a report criticizing top officials for the repeated mass shootings of Islamist demonstrators last summer.

title: Richard Chamberlain Returning to New York Stage
description: Richard Chamberlain will join the cast of Sticks and Bones, the revival of David Rabes 1971 play that is scheduled to open theNew Groups 20th season in October. No dates have been given for the beginning of previews or the opening, but the play is scheduled to run through Dec. 14 at the Pershing Square Signature Center.

title: Get Lost in Voices With George Saunders
description: The writer George Saunders wanted to be a somber realist when he was younger. That didnt exactly happen. Instead, his quirky, humorous writing blends science fiction with hyper-realism.

title: Shooting Stokes Unrest in Missouri
description: Protests and riots continued in Ferguson, Mo., over the shooting of a black teenager over the weekend.

title: Artists Claim Responsibility for Flags
description: The German artists Mischa Leinkauf and Matthias Wermke submitted this video as proof that they hoisted two white flags atop the Brooklyn Bridge earlier this summer.

title: German Artists Say They Put White Flags on Brooklyn Bridge
description: Mystery solved? A pair of artists in Berlin said they were the ones who pulled off the stunt of the summer, hoisting two big all-white flags atop the Brooklyn Bridge last month, swapping them for the usual red, white and blue.

title: Narendra Modis Quiet Beginning Dims Indias Hopes for Swift Change
description: NEW DELHI  During the months leading up to the spring parliamentary elections, Indians looked at Narendra Modi and saw what they wanted to see.

title: New York Architect Picked to Lead Columbia University Architecture School
description: Amale Andraos, a New York architect who was born in Beirut and has practiced in Montreal, Paris and Rotterdam, has been selected as the 13th dean of the Graduate School of Architecture, Preservation and Planning, the university announced Tuesday.

title: Robin Williams Died by Hanging, Official Says
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.  Robin Williams hanged himself with a belt at his home, a coroners office official said Tuesday in providing the first details of the actors death.

title: Salmon or Tuna Carpaccio with Wasabi Sauce
description: Seek out sushi-grade salmon or ahi tuna for this easy, delicate fish carpaccio. I buy mine at a Japanese market, where the pieces sold are exactly the right amount for one serving (about 3 ounces). You dont have to be a sushi whiz with a knife to get the thin pieces of fish; you just gently pound each piece between lightly oiled layers of plastic. If you dont use a light hand, you will tear the fish, so take care with your mallet or rolling pin.

title: Veal Farmers Adopt More Humane Methods
description: HISEVILLE, KY.  The 600 calves raised by Leland Glass in the south-central part of this state spend their days in pastures with trees for shade and ponds for wading. They nurse lazily alongside their mothers.

title: Smithsonian Turning to the Public to Help Transcribe Documents
description: The Smithsonian Institution has followed the crowdsourcing crowd, with the opening of an online transcription center allowing members of the public to help decipher thousands of digitized pages of Civil War diaries, botanical labels, correspondence and other documents that cannot be easily read by a computer.

title: Sardines in Vinegar (Escabeche)
description: I have eaten wonderful sardines in escabeche in Spain and in Provene, where I first learned to make the dish from Lulu Peyraud, the doyenne of the famous winery Domaine Tempier in Bandol. She used to serve the sardines at the amazing lunches she made every day for the workers during the harvest. I am combining ingredients from Provenal and Spanish recipes, as I love the saffron in the Spanish version.

title: Summer Reading Winner, Week 7 | On Freedom, Order and Subway Acrobats
description: Since were perilously near the end of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest, (only a week and a half left to post!), were receiving easily twice the number of submissions we got at the beginning of the summer, and winning gets harder every week.

title: Bond Insurer Syncora Claims Mediator Favors Detroits Retirees
description: One of Detroits chief remaining adversaries in bankruptcy said the citys exit strategy was tainted by what it called the biases of its chief mediator, whose job it was to impartially negotiate out-of-court settlements of as many of the citys debts as possible.

title: N.B.A. Approves Ballmers Purchase of Clippers
description: LOS ANGELES  When Steve Ballmer, a lifelong basketball fan, sat beside Los Angeles Clippers Coach Doc Rivers last month in Las Vegas and watched the teams rookies and free agents play in an N.B.A. summer league game, he must have gotten an inkling of what it is like to own a professional basketball team.

title: Accusations Fly Between Uber and Lyft
description: Updated | All is fair, they say, in love and war. And Uber and Lyft, two smartphone-based car services, are most certainly at war.

title: Iraq and the Risks of Inaction
description: Having used my Sunday column to make what you might call the war-skeptics case for our ongoing intervention against ISIS in northern Iraq, let me address the arguments from a writer more skeptical of military intervention than myself, Noah Millman of The American Conservative, who wrote late last week in opposition to the course the administration is taking:

title: Veracruzana Vinegar-Bathed Shrimp
description: The state of Veracruz in Mexico is home to many wonderful fish dishes. Its also a region where olive oil is used, a legacy of its once close trade ties to Spain. Many of the signature dishes of this region have much in common with Spanish cooking, with a widespread use of olives, capers and almonds, and indeed, this is a spicy cousin of Spanish escabeche. Vinegar is widely used in Veracruz, but it is a milder vinegar than our wine vinegars. The vinegar traditionally used in this dish is pineapple vinegar, something I saw being sold in fruit stands all over the state of Veracruz when I traveled there. I use rice vinegar instead, because its mild like the pineapple vinegar. If you want a smoky, spicy flavor, use chipotles. Either choice is typical of the region.

title: Calle Do Is Set to Open in Midtown
description: Headliner

title: Iraqi Who Made Emotional Plea to Help Yazidis Is Injured in Crash of Relief Flight
description: Vian Dakhil, an Iraqi lawmaker who represents the Yazidi religious minority, was reportedly injured in the crash of a relief flight in northern Iraq on Tuesday. She had helped draw global attention to the plight of her community last week with an impassioned speech in Parliament that was shared widely on social networks.

title: Palestinian Ambassadors Letter to Cuomo
description: In a letter made available to The New York Times, the ambassador, Riyad H. Mansour, invited Governor Andrew M. Cuomo and his group to hear our peoples stories.

title: Robin Williamss Death: A Note From the Night Desk
description: The first report of Robin Williamss death was at 6:54 p.m. Eastern time. Twenty-four minutes later, The Times posted its first article. A Times news team  including more than a dozen reporters, the Obituary, National and Metro desks and video producers  was quickly in gear reporting the obituary and related stories that ran in todays paper. The night note from Tom Jolly, the assistant managing editor, to staff editors provides an inside look at how the unexpected obituary came together.

title: A New Surgery Risk
description: Thousands of Americans every year develop an abnormal heart rhythm after having major surgery. These episodes have long been considered a fleeting phenomenon that is generally not a cause for concern.

title: Palestinian Invitation to Cuomo Is Declined
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and top New York lawmakers departed for Israel on Tuesday night to express support for that country in the Gaza conflict, but not before receiving an unexpected, and not entirely welcome, invitation: to visit territories that Palestinians regard as part of their future state, including East Jerusalem.

title: When in Paris
description: The designer Jacques Grange reimagines the Grand Palais as an enormous French garden under glass.

title: Undercover, With a History and a Lot to Hide
description: TNT is well aware that most television viewers confronted with Legends, a series beginning Wednesday night, arent going to be thinking, oh, a new show about an undercover F.B.I. agent. Theyre going to be thinking, oh, Ned Starks back! To capitalize on the affection fans feel for Sean Bean, the star of Legends, TNT is even promoting the hashtag #DontKillSeanBean.

title: Delaware Sees New Life for a Historic Base
description: FORT DUPONT, Del.  Wanted: developers for a historic military base who are willing to revive neglected buildings in return for cheap land.

title: To the Moon, Maybe
description: Remember the space race? Heroes in spacesuits. International superpowers one-upping each other. The world clustered around television sets to watch men walk on the moon.

title: Shakespeare With Strings (the Silly Kind)
description: Titus Andronicus  convoluted and graphically violent as all get-out  is not generally regarded as one of Shakespeares better plays. This tragedy about a Roman general whose family is at odds with the Goths is a relentless parade of revenge, cannibalism and bloodletting. But its excesses lend themselves to a comic shellacking, and at the Beckett Theater, the mischief makers in the Puppet Shakespeare Players have a semi-improvised field day.

title: Apples Diversity Mirrors Other Tech Companies
description: Similar to other Silicon Valley tech companies, Apple has a work force that is composed mostly of men, and most of them are white.

title: Las Vegas, Off the Eaten Path
description: LAS VEGAS  Perched at the counter of Sweets Raku, a small, year-old dessert restaurant where almost everything is the gleaming white of a new iPhone charger, I chose a three-course tasting from a rice-paper menu printed in gold.

title: You Dont Need to Tell Them Giada Sent You
description: LAS VEGAS  Guiding a table of first-time diners through the menu, a server said, The idea of the restaurant is that Giada wants you to feel like youre in her home.

title: A Universitys Partnership Reshapes Bowling Green, Ky.
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky.  When Gary A. Ransdell, the president of Western Kentucky University, invites alumni to view this citys redeveloping downtown from his universitys hilltop campus, the response is almost always exclamations of surprise.

title: Revel, Atlantic Citys Newest and Largest Casino, Is Closing
description: Atlantic Citys ailing casino industry is losing its biggest player.

title: Party People on the Streets of Blackpool
description: Dougie Wallace, an intrepid sort who has dodged the cabs of Mumbai, spent several years photographing people who go to Blackpool, England, for one final blowout before marriage.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Atlantas High Museum to Showcase Gordon Parks Photos
description: The High Museum of Art in Atlanta is mounting an exhibition this fall of important photographs by Gordon Parks, some of which have never been publicly exhibited, museum officials announced Tuesday. Gordon Parks: Segregation Story will be on viewfrom Nov. 15 through June 7, 2015.

title: Airlines Suspend Flights to Erbil, Iraq
description: The Lufthansa Group has extended its suspension of flights to Erbil, Iraq, indefinitely, the company said in a statement.

title: Maliki Comments on Iraqi Insurgents
description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq warned that insurgents could take advantage of the current political crisis and increase instability in the country.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Zetta San Francisco
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: 50 Kal in Naples, Italy
description: Competition among pizzerias is fierce in Italys undisputed pizza capital, Naples. For decades, institutions have reigned, attracting loyal admirers with their cheap pies and no-frills atmosphere. But recently, that pre-eminence has been challenged by pizzerias seeking to transform the humble native dish into a gourmet product made with top-notch ingredients.

title: Coroner on Robin Williamss Death
description: Lt. Keith Boyd, an assistant deputy chief coroner for Marin County, described the scene in Mr. Williamss bedroom when the actors body was discovered. Warning: Some details are graphic.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Indonesia, Pakistan, Ukraine and Spain.

title: Alibaba Aims to Collect More Money From Its Payments Affiliate
description: Even as the Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce juggernaut, moves closer to one of the most anticipated initial public offerings in recent history, potential investors are wondering about the future of its ties to its online payments affiliate, Alipay.

title: Battling the Ivory Trade
description: New Yorks Governor Andrew Cuomoon Tuesdaysigned one of the toughest laws in the nation banning the sale of elephant ivory and rhinoceros horns as a stand against a dangerous and cruel industry.

title: Spreading an Ancient Palette in Dimensions Seen and Unseen
description: All dance occurs in the three dimensions of space and the fourth of time  but it can be a beautiful shock to feel the invigorating intensity with which the South Indian classical dance form of Bharatanatyam brings all those dimensions keenly to life. On Monday evening at La MaMa, in one of the opening events of the weeklong Drive East festival of Indian music and dance, the dancer Nivedha Ramalingam stretched to the back of the stage with her right arm, then with her left, each time turning from the front with a 180-degree arc. Likewise she ardently addressed the air above her; next the floor below her; and also the spaces various diagonals and horizontals.

title: Charges Weighed in Flag Swap After 2 Say They Did It
description: The police investigation into the flag-swapping stunt on the Brooklyn Bridge had resulted in numerous tips, dozens of leads and even some DNA evidence.

title: Remarks Were Not an Attack, Hillary Clinton Tells Obama
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton called President Obama on Tuesday to assure him that comments she made in a recent interview with The Atlantic were not intended to attack him, his policies or his leadership, according to a statement released by Mrs. Clintons spokesman.

title: If Youre Tweeting, Are You Working On Your Novel?
description: The last few years have seen intense debate over the nature and value of Twitter  whether its public or private, influential or inconsequential, stupid or necessary. Into the midst of this comes Working On My Novel, a new book by the artist Cory Arcangel composed entirely of tweets, including the titular phrase, only one of them originally tweeted by him.

title: Moodys Tamps Down Concerns About Surge in Auto Loans
description: The market for auto loans may be bubbling with loans to borrowers with shoddy credit, but it is not going to burst, according to a new report from Moodys Analytics.

title: Serving Alt-Artists, a Proud Antilabel
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  In the world of digital music, CD Baby is a potent but quiet and thus frequently overlooked force. So its hardly a surprise that the companys headquarters should be in a nondescript building hard by the airport here, with only a small identifying plaque at the entrance, far from the microbrew pubs and locavore restaurants that have become a calling card for this city.

title: In Botox Maker Fight, Focus on Clever Strategy Overshadows the Goal
description: In Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Managements battle to take over Allergan, all sides are being clever  perhaps too clever for their own good.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: On Twitter, Mourning Is Collective
description: Within minutes of the news of Robin Williamss death on Monday, his legions of fans  regular people and celebrities, too  were creating an electronic scrapbook of his life in real time.

title: Michael Browns Shooting and Its Immediate Aftermath in Ferguson
description: Updates on the unrest in Ferguson, Mo., that followed the shooting of Michael Brown, an 18-year-old unarmed teenager, by a police officer on Aug. 9.

title: Exploring a Riviera Gem, From Seaside to Hilltop
description: Last year, riding the coastal train from Ventimiglia, on the Italian Riviera, to Nice, on the French Riviera, I stopped at the seaside village of ze-Bord-de-Mer to spend a few days with a family friend who has a house overlooking the Mediterranean.

title: With Natural Gas Byproduct, Iran Sidesteps Sanctions
description: Iran is finding a way around Western sanctions to export increasing amounts of an ultralight oil to China and other Asian markets, expanding the value of its trade by potentially billions of dollars a year.

title: Junk Bonds Gain Favor as Europes Banks Reduce Lending
description: Bruce Mackenzie and Toby Ali were young bankers in the late 1990s, traversing Europe to pitch the merits of high-yield securities, otherwise known as junk bonds, to chief executives. The corporate chieftains mostly said no.

title: Ira Zlotowitz
description: Mr. Zlotowitz, 38, is the founder and president of Eastern Union Funding, a private real estate mortgage brokerage business that specializes in small to midsize commercial borrowers. The company, which has offices in Brooklyn and Monsey, N.Y., was founded in 2001.

title: Excerpt: A Midsummer Nights Dream
description: Stephen Ouimette and Jonathan Goad performing in the play, directed by Chris Abraham, at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.

title: Beyond Shakespeares Wildest Dreams
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  Visitors to the Stratford Shakespeare Festival expect a generous array of works by the playwright in whose honor it was founded in 1952. But this year, in a nod to Shakespeares 450th birthday, the artistic director, Antoni Cimolino, decided to present, for the first time in the festivals history, two productions of a single play, A Midsummer Nights Dream.

title: Top Math Prize Has Its First Female Winner
description: An Iranian mathematician is the first woman ever to receive a Fields Medal, often considered to be mathematics equivalent of the Nobel Prize.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor Complicity in Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Back to the Table on Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Role in Gaza Talks Signals a Comeback for Abbas
description: JERUSALEM  For months Israel called on President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority to break with Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, and to dismantle the new government that resulted from the reconciliation agreement.

title: Analyzing New York Citys Pension Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: The Souths Lesson for the Tea Party
description: OXFORD, Miss.  LAST weeks Republican primary in Tennessee resulted in a comfortable win for Senator Lamar Alexander over his Tea Party-backed challenger, State Assembly Representative Joe Carr. But make no mistake: The Tea Party is on a roll across the South, having mounted major primary challenges in Texas, Mississippi and South Carolina, and knocked out Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia.

title: Perpetuating Schizophrenias Stigma
description: PHILADELPHIA  A FEW months ago, a patient came to our hospital, seeking help. One of us, Edward, was on the team that treated him. He was pleasant, if slightly withdrawn, and cogent. He was a college graduate in his 20s and had recently been fired from his job as a high school math teacher, because of unexpected absences. He had come to believe that government agents were conspiring against him, and he had taken to living out of a truck and sleeping in different parking lots. By the time he came to us, he was exhausted. A diagnosis became clear: he had schizophrenia.

title: Finding Your Comfort Food
description: What, people ask me, do you cook when youre not working? The answer is pretty consistent: pasta and fish and a vegetable, or pasta and salad and a vegetable, or salad and fish and a vegetable, or pasta and salad and fish and a vegetable. There are exceptions, of course, but theres a comfort level here and its been this way for a long time, through different kitchens and domestic arrangements.

title: Doing Enough to Prevent Sexual Assault on College Campuses?
Why Obama Is Helping the Yazidis in Iraq
description: With humanitarian crises around the world, a look at why President Obama decided to use military force to help the Yazidis, a religious minority in Iraq.

title: In Increase, U.S. to Send 130 Advisers to Aid Iraqis
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon has sent an additional 130 military advisers to northern Iraq to help plan the evacuation of thousands of displaced people trapped by Sunni militants on Mount Sinjar, Defense Department officials said Tuesday, raising the possibility that a larger American force may eventually be needed in the rescue attempt.

title: Geopolitical Football Engulfs Top Teams in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A leaked recording of a meeting of Russias top soccer executives appears to show them panicked at the possibility that their clubs might be ejected from major European competitions and Russia might be stripped of the 2018 World Cup as they discuss a vote to admit three clubs from Crimea into the Russian league.

title: As Data Overflows Online, Researchers Grapple With Ethics
description: Scholars are exhilarated by the prospect of tapping into the vast troves of personal data collected by Facebook, Google, Amazon and a host of start-ups, which they say could transform social science research.

title: Owners Refusal to Sell Islanders Draws Questions, and Now a Lawsuit
description: Despite enormous losses and a quixotic quest for a better arena, Charles Wang has held onto the Islanders as if he had found frackable reserves of natural gas beneath Nassau Coliseum.

title: Massachusetts: Former Associate Dean to Plead Guilty in Case on Investments
description: Federal prosecutors in Boston said Tuesday that a former associate dean at the Sloan School of Management of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and his son had agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy committed while they ran investment businesses, GMB Capital Management and GMB Capital Partners, that allegedly lost $140 million of investors principal. Prosecutors said the former associate dean, Gabriel Bitran, 69, and his son Marco, 39, a money manager with degrees from M.I.T. and Harvard, falsely told clients they would invest their money using a mathematical model based on the elder Mr. Bitrans research at M.I.T. that had earned returns between 16 percent and 23 percent, and later lied to investigators seeking to verify their claims. If their pleas are accepted, the Bitrans will each face between two and five years in prison.

title: Making the Case for High-Speed Rail
description: Most American passenger trains, including Amtraks popular Acela service, run at speeds that are far slower than the superfast European and Japanese trains that can zip along at 200 miles per hour or more. The main reason is that, despite modest investments, American lawmakers have not given high-speed rail the priority it deserves.

title: Battle on the Brooklyn Waterfront
description: It would not be New York if a disagreement involving two of its most precious things  green space and housing  did not end up as a ferocious debate, with fiery public meetings, petition drives, accusations of elitism and racism and the specter of doom for The City as We Know It.

title: The Death of Michael Brown
description: The F.B.I. may be able to answer the many questions surrounding the death of Michael Brown, an 18-year-old black student from Ferguson, Mo., who was a few days from heading off to college when he was shot by a police officer on Saturday. The shooting of Mr. Brown, who was unarmed, led to three days of protest, some of it violent, and several tense confrontations between residents of the St. Louis suburban town of 21,000 and the police.

title: Lauren Bacall Dies at 89; in a Bygone Hollywood, She Purred Every Word
description: Lauren Bacall, the actress whose provocative glamour elevated her to stardom in Hollywoods golden age and whose lasting mystique put her on a plateau in American culture that few stars reach, died on Tuesday in New York. She was 89.

title: Over 300,000 Must Prove Eligibility or Lose Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  More than 300,000 people who bought subsidized health insurance under the Affordable Care Act could lose it next month if they do not provide proof that they are living in the United States legally, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

title: With Turf, Women See Unequal Footing
description: Within minutes of the goal, the image was seen around the world: Robin van Persie, playing in the Netherlands World Cup opener in June, flying what seemed like dozens of feet above the ground, headfirst, to score a goal against Spain. The Internet went berserk. Van Persie, the Flying Dutchman. Van Persie as Superman. Van Persie, the newest Peter Pan.

title: Its the Loyalty, Stupid
description: WASHINGTON  I talked to Robin Williams once, about breasts.

title: A Fan Visits From Afar, and the Royals Come Alive
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  How do I begin this story? How can I convince you that the greatest story for Royals fans in 29 years is unfolding before our eyes, and its protagonist lives a hemisphere away, speaks imperfect (but diligent) English and had never set foot in Kauffman Stadium until last Thursday?

title: Lauren Bacall in Pictures
description: While her film career was a story of ups and downs, the theater was kinder to her, and she won Tonys for her starring roles in two musicals.

title: Young Jet Welcomes Chance to Move Up in Pass Coverage
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Players who succeed in the N.F.L. after plummeting into the final rounds of the draft or being completely overlooked tend to remember the damning comments that talent evaluators used against them. So, safety Antonio Allen is delighted that the Jets are pressing him into action as an emergency cornerback.

title: Busy Working, Robin Williams Fought Demons
description: LOS ANGELES  Peering through his camera at Robin Williams in 2012, the cinematographer John Bailey thought he glimpsed something not previously evident in the comedians work. They were shooting the independent film The Angriest Man in Brooklyn, and Mr. Williams was playing a New York lawyer who, facing death, goes on a rant against the injustice and banality of life.

title: Home of Johnny Cash Hopes History Will Help It Rise
description: DYESS, Ark.  Ruth Hawkins gestured to a white Chevy conversion van grinding to a stop on the gravel road outside the Johnny Cash Boyhood Home. Its plates were from New Mexico. This goes on all day long, she said. People stop and have their pictures made by the fence.

title: An Overnight Stunt That a Roebling Can Enjoy
description: For weeks, Kristian Roebling was barraged by emails from friends, demanding that he come clean about the two white flags raised over the Brooklyn Bridge last month.

title: In Popes Trip to South Korea, Church Envisions Growth
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Myeongdong Cathedral, the center of South Korean Catholicism, was a magnet for the countrys downtrodden for decades. Pro-democracy fugitives found asylum inside the red brick church in the center of Seoul during the darkest years of military dictatorship in the 1980s, and parents who lost their children to government torture sought solace there.

title: Indian Premier Denounces Pakistan for Proxy War
description: NEW DELHI  On a visit to Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi, made his toughest statement on Pakistan to date, saying it has lost strength to fight conventional war, but continues to engage in a proxy war through terrorism.

title: The Best Selling Sports Books
description: The 10 best selling sports books in July 2014, according to The New York Times Best Sellers List.

title: Using a Tactic Unseen in a Century, Countries Cordon Off Ebola-Racked Areas
description: The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is so out of control that governments there have revived a disease-fighting tactic not used in nearly a century: the cordon sanitaire, in which a line is drawn around the infected area and no one is allowed out.

title: For Matt Harvey, Physical Plight of Jeremy Hefner Carries a Cautionary Tale
description: They went down with elbow injuries within 15 days of each other last August, Matt Harvey and Jeremy Hefner, two young Mets pitchers with vastly different backgrounds who found themselves staring at the same long road to recovery.

title: At News Conference on His Stolen Prize Money, Pianist Shows Improv Talents
description: Cecil Taylor, the jazz pianist known for his wild improvisations and free-form performances, was sitting next to the Brooklyn district attorney on Tuesday. The stated purpose was a news conference on the arrest of an acquaintance who was accused of bilking Mr. Taylor of $500,000 in prize money.

title: Nationals Hitters Feast on deGroms Replacement
description: The Mets hoped for signs of progress from the rookie right-hander Rafael Montero, who made his fourth major league start on Tuesday after being recalled from Class AAA Las Vegas to replace the injured Jacob deGrom.

title: Obama Administration Loosens Ban on Lobbyists in Government
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday rolled back part of its ban on lobbyists serving in government, narrowing one of the presidents signature policies in the face of a legal challenge.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 12, 2014
Restoring the Boyhood Home of the Man Who Walked the Line
description: More than a decade after Johnny Cashs death in 2003, the old house in Dyess, Ark., is being restored, a tribute to the singers lasting influence.

title: Foley Wins G.O.P. Primary for Governor in Connecticut
description: The November election for governor of Connecticut will be a rematch of 2010s razor-close contest.

title: Charles Keating, Actor on TV and Stage, Dies at 72
description: Charles Keating, an actor known onstage for Shakespearean roles and on television for playing a villain on the NBC soap opera Another World, died on Aug. 8 at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 72.

title: In Upper West Side Playground Fight, Its Parents vs. Parents
description: Most playground brawls take place on, well, a playground.

title: At Upstate Racetracks, Passion and Peril Since Go-Cart Days
description: WEBSTER, N.Y.  A tree had fallen on the 1992 silver metallic Mazda Miata, shattering its windshield into a thousand glass splinters. For Dan Thiel, a budding driver who acquired the car around his 18th birthday, an insurance adjusters junk became his jewel. Mr. Thiel set to nursing it back to health, sandblasting its crusty frame, sucking out the remaining sand with a vacuum cleaner and applying two fresh coats of silver paint.

title: Columbia Cancels Concert Amid Safety Concerns
description: After months of criticism about its policies on addressing sexual assaults on campus, Columbia University has canceled a campuswide concert known as Bacchanal scheduled for next month, according to a student group that organizes the event.

title: North Korea: Captives Kin Apologize
description: The family of Jeffrey E. Fowle, an Ohio municipal worker arrested more than three months ago while visiting North Korea as a tourist, publicly offered its heartfelt apology on Tuesday to the North Korean authorities for whatever offense he may have committed and pleaded for his release on humanitarian grounds. In a statement issued by the familys lawyer, Mr. Fowles wife and three young children also said they had received only one letter and one telephone call from him. In an Aug. 1 Associated Press interview with Mr. Fowle that had been approved by the North Korean government from an undisclosed place of confinement, he expressed contrition and said he expected to be tried soon. Neither he nor North Korean officials specified the charges against him, but he is believed to have left a Bible in his Pyongyang hotel, which could have been construed as a hostile act. Mr. Fowle is one of three Americans known to be in the custody of North Korea, which has no diplomatic relations with the United States and regards the American government as its chief enemy.

title: Turkey: Aid Flotilla Is Planned for Gaza
description: An Islamist charity plans to send a new aid flotilla to the Gaza Strip this year to challenge Israels naval blockade there, thegroup announced Tuesday. The organization  the Turkish Foundation for Human Rights and Freedoms and Humanitarian Relief, known as I.H.H.  said it would also organize demonstrations at sea and in ports worldwide over the next months, and campaign for the opening of a port in Gaza for international marine traffic. A similar effort in 2010 ended with an Israeli raid that killed nine people and strained ties between Turkey and Israel.

title: India: Modi Criticizes Pakistan
description: On a visit to Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi made his toughest statement yet on Pakistan, saying it has lost strength to fight conventional war, but continues to engage in a proxy war through terrorism. The two countries have fought three wars over the disputed territory of Kashmir, as well as a more limited conflict, known as the Kargil war, in 1999. On Tuesday, Mr. Modi visited the town of Kargil, near the Line of Control, to inaugurate a power plant. Top civilian officials have rarely visited Kargil since the conflict there, in which India lost more than 500 soldiers. Estimates of Pakistans losses vary, but are believed to be higher. After being elected in May, Mr. Modi took a relatively warm tone toward Pakistan, inviting its prime minister to attend his swearing-in and leaving the impression that the two nuclear-armed neighbors were prepared for a period of calm. Since then, however, cease-fire violations on the Line of Control have become more frequent.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 13, 2014
description: This was not an anti-American statement.

title: 2 Programs Aim to Move New York Families From Shelters
description: State and city officials have agreed to create two rent subsidy programs to help families with children leave New York City shelters and move into their own apartments.

title: Patchwork Looks for Fall 2014
description: Patchwork is making its way into stores this fall, but the latest versions are no folksy throwbacks. Instead, designers are incorporating graphic shapes and unexpected color and material combinations that would make heads spin in your grandmothers quilting circle. Reworked classics such as McQs jeans and Roksanda Ilincics tweed shift dress sport geometric patterns, while that fall perennial, the crew-neck sweater, takes on a Frankensteinian quality in the hands of Junya Watanabe, thanks to contrasting textures and a sprinkling of sequins.

title: Flipping the Script
description: No longer content just to be making movies, a new generation of critically heralded female directors is rivaling the male establishment at the box office  and redefining what it means to be a woman in Hollywood.

title: Sam Taylor-Johnson, Lisa Cholodenko, Sarah Polley and Other Female Directors on the Movies That Influenced Them
description: In Flipping the Script, in the Fall Womens Fashion issue of T, Lauren Tabach-Bank profiles six fierce female directors who are redefining what it means to be a woman in Hollywood, and whose daring and thought-provoking work sets the standard for a whole new generation of filmmakers. Here, they talk about the films that made them want to direct.

title: Spring Has Sprung
description: Skye Gyngell makes a triumphant return to the culinary spotlight with her most ambitious restaurant yet.

title: 36 Hours in Madrid
description: Explore everything from culture to cuisine during a weekend in the Spanish capital.

title: How Exercise Helps Us Tolerate Pain
description: Regular exercise may alter how a person experiences pain, according to a new study. The longer we continue to work out, the new findings suggest, the greater our tolerance for discomfort can grow.

title: 36 Hours in Nice
description: On the southeast coast of France, Nice welcomes travelers with alluring restaurants, a broad beach, sherbet-hued buildings and gay-friendly night life.

title: Word of the Day | kudos
description: kudos \k-ds, ky-, -dos\ noun

title: 36 Hours in Nice, France
description: You have to pity Nice. Overshadowed by megawatt Riviera neighbors like aristocratic Monaco, red-carpet Cannes and Champagne-soaked St.-Tropez, Frances fifth-largest city is often written off as a dowdy haven of retirees. Yet Nice packs most of its neighbors lures  year-round sun, Mediterranean Sea, belle poque and Art Deco architecture  with the bonuses of an atmospheric old quarter, an evolving restaurant scene, the Rivieras best museums and some high-profile public works. Place Garibaldi, the central square, has been pedestrianized and spruced up, while the formerly lackluster port area is filling up with the citys coolest restaurants and bars. And thanks to the new Promenade du Paillon, Nice has an alluring public park in its heart. A city for all budgets, Nice now buzzes with an energy and diversity that often surpasses its coastal rivals.

title: Henry Stone, 93, Dies; Produced the Miami Sound
description: Henry Stone, who produced early recordings by Ray Charles and James Brown and whose Hialeah, Fla., company, TK Records, was a fountain of disco in the 1970s and the source of what came to be called the Miami sound, died on Thursday in Miami. He was 93.

title: 36 Horas en Madrid
description: Las galeras y restaurantes de Madrid estn llenos de creatividad, cinco aos despus que la economa de Espaa se vio afectada. Como dicen los madrileos, la necesidad es la madre de la invencin.

title: 36 Heures  Nice
description: La ville de Nice enchante les touristes avec dexcellents restaurants, ses plages de galets, et une vie nocturne ouverte  tous.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 9:45 P.M. (HBO2) ARGO (2012) Ben Affleck, above, directed and stars in this Oscar winner for best film, which covers a little-known chapter of the Iranian hostage crisis, in which Antonio J. Mendez, a Central Intelligence Agency officer and a wizard of disguise, was tapped to help free six State Department employees stranded in Tehran after revolutionary forces seized the United States Embassy on Nov. 4, 1979. His plan: to have them pose as a Canadian movie crew filming a science-fiction flick called Argo. John Goodman and Alan Arkin play the Hollywood makeup artist and producer who help him. Bryan Cranston, his neck tendons popping, is one of his bosses; and Clea DuVall, Tate Donovan, Scoot McNairy, Rory Cochrane, Christopher Denham and Kerry Bish are the escapees. After setting your pulse racing, Mr. Affleck smoothly downshifts, easing from the high anxiety of the opener  which evokes 1970s political thrillers like Sydney Pollacks Three Days of the Condor  into something looser, mellower and funny, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

title: Corrections: August 13, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lending in China Slowed Drastically in July
description: HONG KONG  Chinese lending unexpectedly and drastically slowed in July to the lowest level since the depths of the global financial crisis, as a weak property market appeared to drive down demand for new loans, despite recent moves to ease credit.

title: In State Newspaper, a Rare Discussion of Tiananmen Protests
description: A state-run newspaper carried a column on Wednesday about the deadly 1989 crackdown on demonstrators in Beijing, a rare mention of one of the most sensitive periods in recent Chinese history.

title: Bacall and Bogart, a Romance on Film
description: Lauren Bacall had a long career in film and theater, but she remains best known for the roles she played opposite Humphrey Bogart.

title: Student Crossword | Volcanoes
description: Test your knowledge of volcanoes by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: France Plans to Ship Arms to Embattled Kurdish Forces in Iraq
description: PARIS  European nations moved on Wednesday to intensify their involvement in Iraq, announcing further humanitarian aid and, for the first time, pledging to supply arms to the embattled Kurdish forces fighting the Sunni militants who have overrun much of northern Iraq.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Robin Williams, Oscar-Winning Comedian, Dies at 63 in Suspected Suicide
description: In Robin Williams, Oscar-Winning Comedian, Dies at 63 in Suspected Suicide, Dave Itzkoff reports on the death of the surprisingly nuanced, Academy Award-winning actor.

title: The Rise of Beefcake Yoga
description: A horde of screaming middle-aged wrestling fans gathered one Saturday evening in April at the Smoothie King Center in New Orleans to celebrate professional wrestlings Hall of Fame induction ceremony. The worlds most popular fake-sport organization, World Wrestling Entertainment doesnt maintain a brick-and-mortar Hall of Fame  no bronze plaques to commemorate its greats (the Ultimate Warrior, Superfly Jimmy Snuka), no interactive widgets to teach young fans storied techniques (the camel clutch, the piledriver). Instead, once a year, W.W.E.s former stars relive their glory together, on a stage, face to face with thousands of their most fervent admirers. Throughout the preceding week, these fans traipsed up and down Bourbon Street until 2 a.m., screaming the names of their favorite wrestlers into the night. Now they wore fake championship belts and chanted ecstatically as retired stars strutted by in big n tall tuxedos and sequined gowns. A deafening hoooe! greeted (Hacksaw) Jim Duggan; (Nature Boy) Ric Flair earned a high-pitched woooo! Hulk Hogan, who arrived in a black suit, black bandanna and yellow wraparound shades, sent hundreds of so-called Hulkamaniacs into a fit of rapture.

title: Party People on the Streets of Blackpool
description: You cant be a street photographer as long as Dougie Wallace has without learning a thing or two about surviving the streets of a place like Blackpool, an Irish Sea resort town that has drawn Britains working class for generations.

title: Loser to Paper
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE We see a sprinkling of words or phrases from other languages here and there in The New York Times crossword, but theres never anything that I would describe as a LANGUAGE BARRIER. That is, unless you happen to be the political reporter Matt Bai, who took the French theme in Brendan Emmet Quigleys November 4, 2012 puzzle surprisingly personally, but is otherwise a very strong solver and a nice guy.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: New York Today: Immigrant Children Head to Court
description: Good morning on this stormy Wednesday. There is widespread flooding on Long Island.

description: Coinciding with Little League Baseballs 75th anniversary, the backdrop for its World Series that commences Thursday in Williamsport, Pa., are two other milestones. Both relate to gender.

description: Below, the first six paragraphs of a July 30 article, Kim Kardashian, an Unlikely Mobile Video Game Hit.

title: Adviser to Government in Chinese Investigation of Qualcomm Is Ousted
description: HONG KONG  An adviser to a Chinese government antitrust committee has been dismissed, accused of accepting payments from Qualcomm, an American technology company under investigation in China on suspicion of antitrust violations, Chinese state news reports said on Wednesday.

title: Daily Report: As Social Media Studies Proliferate, Experts Weigh Ethics Guidelines
description: Social science researchers are exhilarated by the prospect of tapping into the vast troves of personal data collected by Facebook, Google, Amazon and a host of start-ups, Vindu Goel reports.

title: Morning Views
description: The F.B.I. may be able to answer the many questions surrounding the death of Michael Brown, an 18-year-old black student from Ferguson, Mo., who was a few days from heading off to college when he was shot by a police officer on Saturday, begins an editorial in The New York Times. But it doesnt take a federal investigation to understand the history of racial segregation, economic inequality and overbearing law enforcement that produced so much of the tension now evident on the streets. St. Louis, the editorial says, has long been one of the nations most segregated metropolitan areas, with whites dominating the City Council and police department. For decades whites used zoning laws to keep blacks out of desirable areas; among black residents within the city, poverty and unrest grew. The black population has also been subjected to intervention from the largely white police force far out of proportion to their population, according to the editorial. The circumstances of Mr. Browns death are, inevitably, in dispute, says the editorial, but what is not in dispute is the sense of permanent grievance held by many residents and shared in segregated urban areas around the country. Mr. Browns death serves as a reminder of a toxic racial legacy that still infects cities and suburbs across America.

title: Trying to Recover From Our Lost 50 Days, We Make Another Mistake
description: We are trying to stay calm. We have gained some confidence that we are figuring out how to run the parts.

title: Two Journalists Among 6 Dead in Gaza Bomb-Disposal Accident
description: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip  The bombs had stopped falling on the Gaza Strip, so a crew from The Associated Press set out Wednesday morning to do a story on the people who pick them up. Two of the journalists, an Italian videographer and a local Palestinian helping him with arrangements and translation, were killed along with four members of Gazas unexploded-ordnance squad as they attempted to defuse what officials described as an Israeli bomb.

title: Britains Recovery Gains Momentum, but Wages Slip
description: LONDON  The Bank of England on Wednesday raised slightly its forecasts for growth and inflation in Britain, and gave further indications that it was moving closer to gradually increasing its key interest rates if wages improve.

title: Key Hashtags in Black Twitter Activism
description: The speed with which the shooting of Michael Brown resonated on social media helped propel and transform a local shooting into a national cause, Tanzina Vega reports.

title: Obamas Free Rider Comment Draws Chinese Criticism
description: China employed state media on Wednesday to convey its displeasure at President Obamas recent remark that China is a global free rider.

title: Pakistan Calls Modis Remarks on Terrorism Unfortunate
description: NEW DELHI  Pakistan responded swiftly on Wednesday to a tough speech by Indias new prime minister, Narendra Modi, that accused Pakistan of conducting a proxy war against India. Pakistan called Mr. Modis remarks unfortunate and said it sought good relations with its neighbor.

title: Morning Agenda: Overly Cute Moves in Allergan Fight
description: As Valeant Pharmaceuticals International and Pershing Square Capital Management try to take over Allergan, each side appears to be so consumed with outmaneuvering the other that theyve lost sight of the ultimate goal: Allergans future, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. The spate of overly clever moves, something you might expect when an army of well-paid advisers is involved, has infected this hostile battle from the beginning, he writes.

title: Introducing 36 Hours
description: Want to get away for a weekend? Explore travel desinations like Madrid and Nice, France, with a new video series from The New York Times.

title: Somethings Going On in Kansas
description: In a decent year for Republicans, like this one, a longtime Republican senator should be having a pretty easy time in a state that hasnt voted for a Democratic presidential candidate since 1964, or voted in a Democratic senator since 1932.

title: Security App Lookout Attracts $150 Million in Venture Capital
description: Lookout, a seven-year-old mobile security company in San Francisco, is riding a wave of concern over cyberthreats, with 50 million people using its security app.

title: Germany Puts Curbing Russia Ahead of Commerce
description: BERLIN  Over recent months, something significant has happened in Europe: In the crisis over Ukraine, Germany has assumed leadership not just in its familiar fashion of trying to coax Russia away from belligerence and bluster, but also in standing firm and imposing sanctions on Moscow even if they hurt German business.

title: Tibetan Environmentalist Is Freed From Prison
description: A prominent Tibetan environmental activist sentenced to five years in prison on what critics say were trumped-up charges of inciting separatism has been released, according to a report this week on a website run by Tibetan exiles.

description: Dear Diary:

description: Designers are going where few have gone before, with everyone from Calvin Klein to Rick Owens getting into a sci-fi state of mind.

title: A Start-Up Provides a Picture of Our Shape-Shifting Planet
description: The techno-futurist Stewart Brand has said we are as gods for the way humans have profoundly changed how the planet works. Now a start-up in San Francisco is offering fresh evidence.

title: Rain on Long Island Breaks a Record, Floods Highways and Sets Cars Afloat
description: Over the years, Long Island has been blasted by hurricanes, drenched by tropical storms and battered by blizzards.

title: Boston Fed Chief Warns of Dangers to Repo Market
description: Updated, 9:43 p.m. | Wall Street banks continue to rely for billions of dollars in borrowing on a market that dried up suddenly in 2008, sending shock waves through the financial system and the wider economy.

title: Next Target for Amazon Is Credit Card Readers at Stores
description: The king of online retail is flexing its muscle to win over Mom and Pop.

title: Bangladeshi Police Capture Owner of Overloaded Ferry That Sank
description: NEW DELHI  The Bangladeshi police said on Wednesday that they had arrested the owner of a ferry that capsized and sank this month, leaving more than 100 people dead or missing.

title: Barclays Could Face $2 Billion More in Litigation Charges, Analyst Says
description: LONDON  Barclays could face as much as $2 billion in additional litigation and other costs this year as it continues to grapple with legacy and regulatory issues, a Sanford C. Bernstein analyst said in a research note on Wednesday.

title: Whats the Matter With Europe?
description: Just a few months ago Europes austerians were busy congratulating themselves, declaring that a modest upturn in southern Europe vindicated all their actions. But now the news is looking grim, with industrial production stalling out and good reason to fear yet another slide into recession:

title: Williams Opposed War, but Supported the Troops
description: Robin Williams opposed the war in Iraq. His many comedic riffs that punctured the rationale for the 2003 invasion, and the president who ordered it, are evidence enough.

title: While Some in G.O.P. See Obamas Competence as Rich Vein to Mine, Others See Little Reward
description: WASHINGTON  In the Republicans campaign for the grand prize of the midterm elections, control of the Senate, some party strategists say the key to winning a majority comes down to one word  competence  and voters perception that President Obama lacks it. Apparently, that is debatable, even among Republicans.

title: 1889: Cabourg Still a Favorite Resort
description: CABOURG The coast of Normandy, from Cabourg almost to Trouville, is just now alive with gaiety and fashion. Three weeks ago, but a few fishermen were here spreading their nets. Three weeks hence it will be again as deserted and silent as ever. But during this brief period wealth and aristocracy gather here, and countless health seekers and lovers of the seaside crowd the beaches, intent on health and diversion. Some of the villas which embellish these shores are massive in their proportions. The New York Herald, European Edition, August 14, 1889

title: Good for Margaret Sullivan
description: The Timess public editor weighs in on the sliming of Rick Perlstein, and concludes:

title: The Best Picnics Are Made at Home
description: Go to picnic hot spots  parks, beaches, outdoor concerts and the like  and see what people are carrying. Mostly, its bags of store-bought food, not coolers of home-cooked. While grab-and-go counters of picnicky food are almost universally mediocre and exasperatingly expensive, I do understand the temptation to outsource. The weather is hot, you might not feel like cooking in the first place and, in addition to actually making the food, you have to pack it, transport it and ensure that its still edible by the time it reaches its final destination.

title: They Heard America Playing
description: Virgil Thomson used the phrase the Commando Squad to describe a small band of American composers, including himself, who took collective action in the 1930s to establish that there was such a thing as an American composer.

title: The Whole Wide World
description: If you want to find the wildly creative people now, Im told, look in fields that have to do with science, math and technology. They say these days, thats where an imagination can really fly. Ive been skeptical. Growing up as a creative type, I experienced a plummeting sensation just catching a whiff of formaldehyde outside the science lab, or hearing the word cosine, which to me had a sinister ring. I couldnt see science and math as anything other than earthbound and rote, and yet all too often, confusingly abstract.

title: A Look at the Three Who Would Be M.L.B. Commissioner
description: Baseball owners are expected to vote Thursday to select Commissioner Bud Seligs successor, a process that a few months ago lacked much intrigue. Selig had announced last year that he would retire after the 2014 season, and it became clear with Rob Manfreds promotion to chief operating officer last September that he would be the logical choice as the next commissioner.

title: Ratmanskys Concerto Shines in Mariinsky Triple Bill in London
description: LONDON  Is Alexei Ratmanskys Concerto DSCH the best ballet to date of the 21st century? Its an impossible question to answer, but on Monday night, as danced by the Mariinsky Ballet at the Royal Opera House here, it certainly felt like the most exhilarating one.

title: Violence by Rikers Guards Grew Under Bloomberg
description: The portrait that emerged from the report on Rikers Island by the United States attorneys office in Manhattan last week was of a place with almost medieval levels of violence, meted out with startling ferocity by guards and their superiors.

title: Murray Hill for Family Living
description: A decade ago, when people asked Eve Moskowitz Parness where she lived, the Murray Hill resident frequently put them off with the vague answer Midtown East. Though she liked her Manhattan neighborhood, Ms. Parness said that, as a student, she was embarrassed to be associated with Murray Hill, particularly the bar scene on Third Avenue, with its reputation as a postgraduate playground.

title: 3-D Godard Movie Among New York Film Festival Offerings
description: A 3-D film by Jean-Luc Godard, a hotly anticipated wrestling thriller by Bennett Miller and new works by the seasoned directors David Cronenberg and Mike Leigh are among the 30 films that will make up the main slate of this years New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced Wednesday.

title: Are Protests Against Israel Anti-Semitic? Ask the Germans
description: Protests against Israels use of forcein Gaza  some peaceful, some violent  have proliferated across Europe, and they have made many people wonder if anti-Semitism is on the rise.

title: Pitfalls of Privilege
description: When asked about the difference between writing a short story and writing a novel, I invariably fall back on an analogy to painting: the delicate watercolor versus the large canvas in oil. But what of my favorite form, the novella, or the long story, as students say these days? The novella requires quick, deft strokes, but allows for enough space and time to build up layers. Light may show through in dark areas; deep shadows may fall. At its best, the novella has a specific density all its own, engaging the reader with a bright surface and hidden depths. Henry James, who adored what he called the dear, the blessed nouvelle, lamented that in his time it was foredoomed at the best, in more cases than not, to editorial disfavor.

title: Where Are the Nurses?
description: Theyre called nursing homes, so most of us assume that they have nurses  registered nurses  on the premises.

title: The Name Is Bond
description: Ian Fleming died 50 years ago this week, but his most famous creation, James Bond, has enjoyed a spectacular afterlife.

title: What You Get for ... $4,900,000
description: ALEXANDRIA, VA.

title: Ian Fleming Is Dead. James Bond Is Doing Just Fine.
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Ian Fleming Dead; Created James Bond appeared on August 13 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: In British Columbia, Slow Food by Bike
description: In Pemberton, British Columbia, cycling is the new golf, said the president of Tourism Pemberton, David MacKenzie. In the small valley community, about two and a half hours north of Vancouver, there are more bikes per capita than cars or children.

title: House Hunting in ... Mexico
description: A RESTORED FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE IN THE CENTER OF MRIDA

title: A Takeover Battle That May Put Tax Inversions to the Test
description: The unsolicited offer by the Cutrale Group and the Safra Group for Chiquita Brands International highlights the problems that tax inversions can create for American companies themselves in their mad dash abroad.

title: A Monthly Series of New Music From Avant Media
description: Avant Media, the organization founded by the composer Randy Gibson and the filmmaker Ana Baer, and best known for its multimedia Avant Music Festival, announced on Wednesday that it would expand its schedule to include a series of monthly concerts, in addition to the festival. With one exception, the performances are at Wild Project, 195 East 3rd Street.

title: Getting the Scoop on Apple U.
description: On Mondays front page, Brian X. Chen wrote about Apple University, the internal training program that, Mr. Chen reports, inculcates workers into Apples company values. How did Mr. Chen get information from inside a famously secretive corporate culture?Apple is a tricky company to cover. Its employees are told to keep everything they do at work confidential from outsiders, including friends, family members and especially journalists. So with the story on Apple University, Apples internal training program, I thought about how to carefully approach employees.

title: First on Earth to See Ebola
description: Dr. Frederick Murphy was the first person to photograph and study Ebola up close in 1976. He reflects on disease he has come to know over the last 38 years.

title: Once Powerful, Mary Jo Whites S.E.C. Is Seen as Sluggish and Ineffective
description: Mary Jo White took the helm of the Securities and Exchange Commission facing high hopes that she could turn around the once-proud agency. More than a year into her tenure, she has disappointed a wide swath of would-be allies.

title: Alibaba Aims for a Neater I.P.O.
description: Alibaba just cant stop tinkering with its corporate structure.

title: Convoy Said to Pause at Russian Base as Questions Persist
description: MOSCOW  Confusion swirled around the fate of an enormous Russian aid convoy as it apparently halted on Wednesday at a military base in the southern Russian city of Voronezh, temporarily suspending its march toward southeastern Ukraine.

title: Candy Crush Makers Post-I.P.O. Woes Continue With Tough Quarter
description: Early this spring, the maker of Candy Crush Saga went public amid high hopes that the game company could find another hit.

title: Jaguar Land Rover to Recall 40,000 S.U.V.s Over Air-Bag Issue
description: More than 40,000 Land Rover sport utility vehicles in the United States are being recalled because the passenger-side air bag may fail to deploy in a crash.

title: PTSD and the Civil War
description: Daniel Folsom, a tinsmith from northern New York, enlisted in the Union Army just days after the fall of Fort Sumter. His exemplary service through years of long marches and hard battles led to two promotions, but during the Battle of Fredericksburg in late 1862, something changed. Folsom seemed uneasy. He was still troubled months later when the regiment mustered out. He returned home, opened his own tin shop and tried to focus on work.

title: Mubarak Tells Court He Gave All For Egypt
description: CAIRO  In his first public statement since his ouster in the Arab Spring revolts, former President Hosni Mubarak told a Cairo court on Wednesday that history would vindicate his self-sacrifice as a servant of the people.

title: Intersection | Ridgewood Revival
description: Ridgewood is one of these really wonderful neighborhoods in New York that is really welcoming and inviting to some of the newer people, said Todd Broockerd, who has seen the neighborhood evolve.

title: Syria and the Risks of Intervention
