description: Now that Ive tried to make anddefend the casefor our current intervention against ISIS, I want to also expand on my reasons for skepticism about the kind of intervention that a number of hawks (including the next Democratic nominee for president, it would seem) believe would have made the current warunnecessary that is, the kind of military support for Syrias more moderate/liberal/secular rebels that, its argued, would have prevented more radical groups from getting traction in that conflict, and thus forestalled the rise of ISIS to its current bad eminence.

title: Fiscal Flimflam, Revisited
description: Brad DeLong reminds us of the original Ryan budget plan  or actually plan, as Ill explain  and emphasizes its dire warnings about a looming debt crisis that wasnt. But pointing out that the debt panic was unjustified only gets at part of what was wrong with that Ryan budget (and all his subsequent proposals). For the fact is that it wasnt a proposal made in good faith.

title: Caffeine May Reduce Tinnitus Risk
description: A new study reports that caffeine intake is associated with a reduced risk for tinnitus  ringing or buzzing in the ears.

title: Love Letters and Honeymoon in Vegas Swap Broadway Theaters
description: Two Broadway productions scheduled to open in the fall  Honeymoon in Vegas, a musical by Andrew Bergman and Jason Robert Brown, and Love Letters, a revival of A.R. Gurneys 1989 two-person play  will switch theaters to better suit their needs. The swap was announced by the Nederlander Organization, which operates both theaters.

title: Hillary Clinton Doesnt Know When to Stop
description: Its hard to dispute that Hillary Clinton is the smartest person in most rooms. Thats why The Times editorial board endorsed her in the Democratic primary in 2008 over Barack Obama.

title: Court Refuses to Stay Its Decision Striking Down Virginias Same-Sex Marriage Ban
description: The federal appeals court that last month struck down Virginias ban on same-sex unions refused Wednesday to delay the effects of its ruling. State officials said that unless the United States Supreme Court interceded, Virginia counties could begin issuing marriage licenses to gay couples next week.

title: Cuomo, Visiting Israel, Joins Growing U.S. List
description: JERUSALEM  It is high season for travel to the Holy Land.

title: 1939: Bastille Stone Found in House
description: SENS  Set in the wall of an old house in Saint-Julien-du-Sault is a stone from the Bastille, one of the few authentic relics of the grim fortress of which no vestige exists in Paris since its destruction in 1789 by the revolutionary masses. The stone bears the following inscription in Latin and French: This stone has been taken from the ruins of the Bastille. Patriotism has dedicated it to a better use by placing it here to give to this square the sweet name of Liberty. In the second year of French liberty. For several years, stones from the Bastille were very fashionable. Small fragments of them were set like jewels and worn by women in rings and necklaces. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 14, 1939

title: Man Is Shot and Killed by the Police in California
description: LOS ANGELES  The police shot and killed an unarmed black man in South Los Angeles on Monday night, the Los Angeles Police Department said. The police said that the man, whom the department did not identify, had tackled an officer and lunged for the weapon in his holster before being shot at by both the officer and his partner.

title: Militants Siege on Mountain in Iraq Is Over, Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Department officials said late Wednesday that United States airstrikes and Kurdish fighters had broken the Islamic militants siege of Mount Sinjar, allowing thousands of the Yazidis trapped there to escape.

title: Runway Report | Where the Wild Things Are
description: Leopard, the naughtiest of prints, is back in fashion. But the look is tailored and covered up, leaving any risky business to the imagination.

title: A Lighthouse Museum, 16 Years in the Making, Is Taking Shape
description: After 16 years of fog  thick as pea soup at times  a lighthouse museum is finally coming into view on Staten Island.

title: Smartphones Overstate Their Social Intelligence
description: When a smartphone app wants to alert you to a coming appointment, a text message or some bit of breaking news from your social network, it sends a tiny flare that lights up your phones lock screen. Depending on how youve set it up, the app might then buzz your pocket like a manic bee, sound a citywide panic alarm or begin playing La Cucaracha.

title: Maliki Plans to Carry Bid for Power to Iraq Courts
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Wednesday that he would press ahead in the Iraqi courts with his increasingly unlikely bid to retain power, and would not turn to the army.

title: 6 Climbers Killed in Fall From French Peak
description: PARIS  Six French climbers were reported dead on Wednesday after falling hundreds of feet as they began to descend one of the highest peaks of the Mont Blanc range in France, the authorities said.

title: David Furnish on Food, Fizz and Fun in Las Vegas
description: I think people go to Vegas to celebrate, to treat themselves, and I cant think of a better way to do that than with a glass of champagne, said David Furnish, the creative director behind the Las Vegas lounge Fizz in Caesars Palace, which specializes in bubbly. Fizz, which opened in March, has more than 40 champagnes on its menu, and offers 14 of them by the glass.

title: A Corner of Durham, N.C., Comes to Life
description: Like firecrackers exploding around downtown Durham, clusters of small businesses are popping up and enlivening one desolate block after another. Over the past months, the loudest bangs have been heard in the Central Park District near the corner of Rigsbee Avenue and West Geer Street. The intersection was first settled by Fullsteam Brewery, whose cavernous tavern lured locals (and lots of food trucks) to this previously neglected part of town. Now theres live music, top-notch barbecue, fair trade coffee, and even valet parking on a block that five years ago was deserted after dark.

title: Solving the Journalism Riddle  Somehow
description: On vacation last week I left my laptop behind and realized once more that cell service was spotty at the lakeside house where my family gathers. So it was easy to do what I planned to do: Unplug and get off the grid.

title: Teenager Slain in Ferguson, Mo., Mourned
description: A cousin of Michael Brown, a lawyer representing the Brown family and the Rev. Al Sharpton spoke at St. Marks family church in Jennings, Mo., days after the teenager was killed in nearby Ferguson.

title: Ackmans Sales Pitch for His Hedge Fund, and His I.P.O.
description: Ever the salesman, William A. Ackman told investors on Wednesday that if they had put money into his hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management when it started 10 years ago, they would have seen a 627 percent return.

title: In Middle Tier, College Sports Tries to Adjust
description: FRESNO, Calif.  As hundreds of universities try to make sense of the seismic jolts remaking the landscape of college sports, the only certainties appear to be that the rich are getting richer and that the poor will fall further behind. Stuck in the middle are universities like Fresno State.

title: In The Times: Remembering Lauren Bacall
description: Though born and raised in New York City  where she died on Tuesday  Lauren Bacall managed to evade the attention of The New York Times for 20 years.

title: Government Grants May Help Ease Business Challenges
description: For more than two decades, from a Willy Wonka-like studio in New Yorks garment district, Michelle Feinbergs company, the New York Embroidery Studio, has helped amateurs and brand-name designers embellish garments with decorative stitching, rhinestones, sequins and other items. So, when a longtime client, Ralph Lauren, approached her in 2010 and asked her to help create uniforms for Team USA at the Sochi Olympics, Ms. Feinberg jumped at the chance.

title: That Voice, and the Woman Attached
description: Her voice comes at you low and flat, wildly insinuating, electric and lingering. In another age, Lauren Bacalls voice might have been called mannish. When she opened her mouth in To Have and Have Not  taking a long drag on a cigarette while locking Humphrey Bogart in her gaze  she staked a claim on the screen and made an immortal Hollywood debut. But in 1944 at the exquisitely tender age of 19, she was also projecting an indelible screen persona: that of the tough, quick-witted American woman who could fight the good fight alongside her man.

title: Rainy Day Video Game Rules: Is iPad Monopoly Screen Time?
description: Its a rainy summer day here. Pouring, in fact. But it remains a weekday, and the usual household rules are still in effect: iPads, computers, television and all video games are for weekends only.

title: An Epic Road Trip in an Electric Tuk Tuk
description: A few years ago, Naveen Rabelli, 33, an electrical engineer from Bangalore, India, had an idea while sitting in traffic surrounded by the ubiquitous and polluting three-wheel vehicles known colloquially as tuk tuks. Why not, he recalls thinking, make one that runs on solar-electric power?

title: Nickelodeon Cartoon Pitches at Comic-Con Turn Up a Winner
description: LOS ANGELES  Nickelodeon said on Wednesday that an unusual open call for new cartoon ideas had produced a surprisingly strong result: Cupcakery of Doom. A 28-year-old newspaper employee pitched the idea, and it will be developed into an animated short with the potential to turn into a television series.

title: Culture Club to Tour With Original Lineup
description: The British band Culture Club will reconvene with its original lineup  the flamboyant singer Boy George, the guitarist and keyboardist Roy Hay, the bassist Mikey Craig and the drummer Jon Moss  for an American tour in November and a British tour in December, Boy George announced on his webpage. Reports of a reunion had been circulating since May, but the posting is the first official confirmation that the Culture Club has reunited and plans to tour.

title: Classical Playlist: Bruckner, Richard Reed Parry, Brahms and More
description: BRUCKNER: Symphony No. 7Budapest Festival Orchestra, Ivan Fischer, conductor(Channel Classics CCS SA 33714)For more than 30 years the conductor Ivan Fischer has been drawing inspired, fresh and intelligent performances from the impressive Budapest Festival Orchestra, an ensemble he co-founded and still conducts. Some Bruckner-lovers may find this account of the great Seventh Symphony lacking in mysticism and gravity. I suspect that most listeners, like me, will be drawn into the vibrant, glowing and revitalized performance Mr. Fischer draws from his excellent players. The sound of the orchestra is lush and rich, yet wondrously lucid. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Kimbra, the New Zealand Songstress Who Moved to a Sheep Farm in L.A.
description: The New Zealandborn pop singer Kimbra is full of surprises. Shes a Prince fanatic who studies the way the Purple Ones backing vocals jump into your face, so loud and invasive, like theyre characters themselves, or a gang. Shes an armchair philosopher who muses, Theres a rousing frequency in the universe that could be divine, or primal, or human, but its a sound that calls you outward to where you feel unbound by time and space.

title: Finding Neverland to Come to Broadway in March
description: Finding Neverland, a new musical based on the 2004 film about the Peter Pan playwright J. M. Barrie, will begin performances on Broadway in March, a spokesman for the shows producer, Harvey Weinstein, said on Wednesday. A tryout production of the musical is underway at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., where it will officially open on Wednesday night.

title: The Science Behind Suicide Contagion
description: When Marilyn Monroe died in August 1962, with the cause listed as probable suicide, the nation reacted. In the months afterward, there was extensive news coverage, widespread sorrow and a spate of suicides. According to one study, the suicide rate in the United States jumped by 12 percent compared with the same months in the previous year.

title: Man Gets Probation in Attack on Ai Weiwei Vase
description: MIAMI  As part of a deal with prosecutors, the man accused of smashing a vase by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei in a museum here pleaded guilty Wednesday to criminal mischief but avoided any more jail time beyond the two days he spent behind bars after his arrest.

title: A New Voice at the Tracks in New York
description: They are big binoculars to fill, but Larry Collmus will replace Tom Durkin as the voice of New York racing.

title: Bieber Pleads Guilty in Florida Case
description: Justin Bieber may be making more money for his lawyers, and for anger management clinics, than for his record company these days. Barely a month ago he pleaded no contest to egging a neighbors house in Los Angeles, and agreed to pay restitution and undergo anger management therapy.

title: After a Hawaii Storm, a Moment in the Sun: A Rural Area Will Cast a Close Races Last Votes
description: PUNA, Hawaii  Politics seldom intrudes on the easternmost district of the Big Island of Hawaii, a hard-to-reach paradise where the homes are nestled among lava-formed cliffs and the papaya and macadamia nut harvests loom larger than the machinations in Honolulu, let alone in Washington.

title: HBO Orders a Second Season of The Leftovers
description: HBO made official on Wednesday the expected news that The Leftovers would be renewed for a second season.

title: N.R.A. Model Sheriff Wins in Milwaukee
description: For the past 12 years, Sheriff David Clarke Jr. has been hard to ignore in the political arena of Milwaukee county, Wis. He favors posing confidently on his horse with a white cowboy hat, sunglasses and a pistol on his hip. His message to constituents has been to wise up and arm themselves against the criminal element. Police cant do it all. Its no longer a spectator sport, the sheriff told them last year in a public service announcement. I need you in the game.

title: Wheelies: The 99 Continental GT3-Rs Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Guardians of the Galaxy Soundtrack Is No. 1
description: Disney has sent another soundtrack to No. 1, as Guardians of the Galaxy follows Frozen to the top spot on Billboards chart.

title: A New Resort in Key West
description: According to the travel research firm STR Inc., hotels in the Florida Keys had the highest hotel occupancy and were among the top 10 in revenue per available room in the country in the first quarter of 2014.

title: Enlivening Beethoven With a Sprightly Pace
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival has been trying in recent years to enliven its offerings with contemporary music programs and unusual repertory. So playing Beethovens Ninth Symphony, as the festival orchestra did on Tuesday, though an ambitious undertaking, was not very daring.

title: Waiting Out Rain for Haydn, Schoenfield and Weber
description: Pleasant weather marked the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers concert at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park on Tuesday. Pleasant weather for the fish in the nearby lake, that is. Haydn was a famous exponent of Sturm und Drang, but the torrential rain that began as the societys players prepared to emerge for one of his piano trios seemed a joke too far.

title: The Art Book Publisher Gestalten Launches an Imprint for Kids
description: Kids will ask for the same book, night after night, for months, even years. So parents know how critical it is that an oft-requested tale be pleasing to both adults and little ones. The Berlin-based art publisher Gestalten has just launched a new childrens book imprint, Little Gestalten, that marries thoughtful storytelling with supercool visuals. Elsa and the Night, by the Swedish author, illustrator and filmmaker Jns Mellgren, tells the tale of a little girl who makes friends with both the night and an elephant named Olaf. In The Zoos Grand Opening, the German author and designer Judith Drews zips through the colorful letters of the alphabet, pairing each with an animal and witty remark (Our skunk might look all cute and fluffy/But you should run like mad if he gets huffy). Small hands will enjoy turning the oversize pages of the Japanese fairy tale Issun Bshi, which has been reimagined by Mayumi Otero and Raphal Urwiller, the duo behind the French design house Icinori. Even the classic Little Red Riding Hood seems new again in Little Gestaltens version, with cutout images that can be held up to the light to cast shadows on the wall until its time to say, My, what big, tired eyes you have.

title: Cuomo Meets With Netanyahu
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York expressed his solidarity with Israel in a meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

title: Celine Dion Puts Her Career on Hold Over Health Issues
description: A message posted on Celine Dions website early Wednesday said that the Canadian singer has decided to postpone all of her show business activities indefinitely in order to focus on her family and on health issues that both she and her husband, Ren Anglil, are facing.

title: Gift of GQ Magazine Prompts Outcry From Lands End Customers
description: The free magazine was meant as a gift from Lands End  the retailer known for its conservative, sturdy clothing  to its most valued customers.

title: Inevitable Mission Creep in Iraq
description: Just a few days after the American military operation began to help the refugees atop Mount Sinjar in northern Iraq, comes the inevitable headline: U.S. Could Use Ground Troops to Aid Rescue of Iraq Refugees.

title: Pryor, Jets Top Selection, Is Set to Make His Debut
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  When Saalim Hakim used a slant pattern to pull in a pass from Tajh Boyd during Jets practice on Tuesday, the rookie safety Calvin Pryor remained mindful that tackling is not permitted during training camp sessions. Since bumping is allowed, Pryor bumped Hakim, a reserve wide receiver, with enough force to send him sprawling.

title: A Pilgrims Progress, or Lack Thereof
description: Chalk up some of Haruki Murakamis rock-star status to the way he evokes the self-pitying narcissism of youth. At 65, Mr. Murakami can still channel the agonies of a high school student who thought that he and his four best friends were the center of the universe  until the cruel, fateful day when the friends stopped speaking to him for no apparent reason.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Germany, Ukraine, Spain and Switzerland.

title: What Are Teen Jokes, and Why Are They Taking Over the World?
description: What are the kids today up to? They are tweeting jokes about being losers.

title: Anonymity in Police Shooting Fuels Anger in Missouri
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  In the five days since an unarmed young black man was fatally shot by a police officer here, the selective release of information about the shooting, and especially the anonymity granted to the officer, has stoked frustrations in this largely African-American community north of St. Louis, where residents describe increasingly tense relations with the police.

title: Giants Manningham Wont Let One Catch Define Him
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Saturday nights preseason game between the Giants and the Indianapolis Colts will return Mario Manningham to the field where he made the defining catch of his career. But do not expect Manningham to feel nostalgic when he enters Lucas Oil Stadium, site of the Giants victory over the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLVI.

title: A Deal From the Fast Pairs Championship
description: The World Youth Team Championships start on Thursday in Istanbul. There are four events: juniors, girls (both for those born in 1989 or later), youngsters (born in 1994 or later) and kids (born in 1999 or later).

title: Digitizing Warhols Film Trove to Save It
description: Andy Warhol wrote lovingly of his ever-present tape recorder. (My tape recorder and I have been married for 10 years now. When I say we, I mean my tape recorder and me.) But for almost a decade beginning in the 1960s, his real boon companions seemed to be his 16-millimeter film cameras, which he used to record hundreds of reels, many of which are still little known even among scholars because of the fragility of the film and the scarcity of projectors to show them on.

title: Hedge Fund Holdouts Fail to Reach Private Deal Over Argentine Debt
description: Aurelius Capital Management, one of the hedge funds that has battled with Argentina over billions of dollars in bond payments, said on Wednesday that efforts to reach a deal with private parties in the wake of the countrys default had collapsed.

title: A Joint Laid to Ruin by Recession
description: See if you can spot the joke built into the title of the new rock musical at the Minetta Lane Theater: Revolution in the Elbow of Ragnar Agnarsson Furniture Painter.

title: An Editors Photos of Wartime France
description: For a few weeks after D-Day, John G. Morris, a photo editor, took pictures of French life during wartime. Seventy years later, they are being exhibited.

title: In Fashion | City Girl
description: An uncompromising youthquake revitalized the fall runways with collegiate starter jackets, short skirts and nubby sweaters that inspire a coltish confidence.

title: Laughing Off Threats in the Fight Against Fake Democracy
description: Chan Kin-man, a prominent Hong Kong democracy activist, receives many anonymous threats. He has gotten a razor blade in the mail and messages like: Hunt and Kill Traitors! Sophisticated hacking attempts occur daily, often from email addresses belonging to friends or students. Some threats are unprintable, about what the sender would like to do to Mr. Chans mother.

title: A Betrayed Wife, Clinging to Hope
description: Like so many spectacularly successful comic playwrights from the first half of the 20th century, George Kelly (the uncle of Grace) is mostly forgotten. The interest that he does occasionally draw from contemporary producers is for his early satires. In 2000 Dylan Baker directed a droll and flamboyant production of The Torch-Bearers, Kellys 1922 sendup of community theater, which featured a memorably bravura performance by Marian Seldes. The Show-Off, which Kelly wrote two years later, is also periodically remounted. But the Mint Theater is not content with producing an ignored writer. Drawn to obscurity like a certain kind of obsessed indie music fan, it searches out the ignored works of ignored writers. So this month, the Mint mounts a rare production of one of Kellys later plays, The Fatal Weakness (1946), about a woman in a 28-year marriage who discovers that her husband is having an affair. Her fatal weakness is that shes a hopeless romantic. (The Fatal Weakness starts previews on Tuesday at the Mint, 311 West 43rd Street, Clinton; minttheater.org, 866-811-4111.)

title: Be Yourself, Music Videos Tell the Young
description: In the music video for All About That Bass, Meghan Trainor bumps and grinds against a pastel background and brags about not being thin: Yeah, its pretty clear, I aint no Size 2./But I can shake it, shake it, like Im supposed to do.

title: The War of Words Over Amazon
With Profits Slipping, Cisco Plans to Cut Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Cisco Systems may be doing a little better than Wall Street expects, considering its technology and sales challenges. But that does not mean the company will avoid layoffs in the coming months.

title: The Mysteries of My Fathers Mind
description: OMAHA  Mom is doing makeup for the opera and Dad tags along. Beverly Sills has been brought in for the role of Lucia di Lammermoor and she has packed the house. Mom draws wrinkles on a tenor while Ms. Sills is called to the stage. The page is growing urgent. Shell miss her entrance if she doesnt show up soon. A crew member blows by and says they found her in the green room, apparently smitten to the point of distraction by a big strapping cowboy, my father. Bill Rotert, Mom would scold, later, on their drive home.

title: Ethics Question on Ebola
description: To the Editor:

title: Driving Ms. Bacall
description: To the Editor:

title: Enough Talk of Demons
description: To the Editor:

title: Cost of Nuclear Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: The Prison Guards Psyche
description: To the Editor:

title: Sierra Leone Again Loses a Top Doctor to Ebola
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  A second leading Sierra Leone doctor has succumbed to the Ebola epidemic sweeping across West Africa, dealing another blow to the countrys faltering efforts to stem the disease.

title: Back-Room Bickering Before the Final Say
description: BALTIMORE  Baseballs election campaign has at times been negative enough to resemble a race for Congress. The three candidates to succeed Bud Selig as the sports commissioner have not insulted one another in televised debates or paid for attack ads, but the contest has inspired back-room bad-mouthing nasty enough to make politicians wince.

title: Are Airstrikes Enough to Take on ISIS?
Louis Bacon and Peter Nygard Move Bahamas Feud to New York
description: Updated, 9:34 p.m. | The hedge fund billionaire Louis M. Bacon has filed a lawsuit against the Canadian clothing magnate Peter Nygard, claiming a long history of character assassination and numerous environmental misdeeds related to Mr. Nygards large property in the Bahamas.

title: Artists in the Foliage
description: WASSENAAR, The Netherlands  Twice a year, on what he refers to as wax day, the Dutch art collector Joop van Caldenborgh sets out armed with an array of household cleaners and tools (and several staff members) and spends the day in the 50-acre grounds behind his home in this suburb outside The Hague. His mission: to keep the gardens precious contents looking fresh and vibrant.

title: Quietly Off Kilter
description: If Isabelle Pribre were to articulate her philosophy of design, it would sound something like this.

title: Sales at Chista, Lillian August, CounterEvolution and DwellStudio
description: Furnishings are up to 80 percent off at Chista, through Saturday (the Parmesan stool, above left, regularly $4,200, is $2,100; the Heavy side table, top left, regularly $5,600, is $2,200); 537 Greenwich Street (Vandam Street), 212-924-0394.

title: A Monastic Setting for Sybarites
description: Fontevraud Abbey was founded in the 12th century in the Loire Valley by monks, later became a prison and, since the 1970s, has been a cultural center and one of Frances most treasured historical sites (Richard the Lionhearts tomb is there). So transforming one of the buildings, the Saint-Lazare priory, into a modern hotel and restaurant presented something of a difficult task for Sanjit Manku, a Canadian-born architect, and the French designer Patrick Jouin.

title: What Happened in Ferguson?
description: Heres what you need to know about events in Ferguson, Mo.

title: My Apartment Gets a Lot of Noise From the HallwayIs That a Problem?
description: Q. Our apartment is across the hall from the elevator and sometimes it gets kind of noisy. What can we do to make it less of an issue when were trying to sell?

title: A New Kind of E-Commerce Adds a Personal Touch
description: Katrina Lake is staring at the ceiling, trying to remember the last time she bought clothes in a store.

title: Your Own Online Personal Shoppers
description: Molly Wood tests personalized online services that use algorithms and user preferences to select items without customers ever needing to visit a store.

title: Art Thats in the Hands of the Buyer
description: I bought some art the other day  nothing too crazy, nothing too expensive, nothing made by an ex-graffiti artist going legit and now giddily bilking rappers out of their piles of new money. Just something beautiful, something I had an emotional response to, something that I perceived as having value independent of its function or cost of production.

title: A Marriage of Design and Application
description: The bridge between design and real-life application can sometimes be shaky. So when Paul Schatz, an interior designer, teamed with New Ravenna Mosaics to develop glass tiles, he said he wanted tiles that were easy on the eyes and on the user as well.

title: Putting a Shiny Spin on Childrens Tops
description: Five years ago, the ceramics artists James Klein and David Reid of KleinReid began creating limited-edition wood tops  inspired by the Eameses collection of the toys  for Herman Miller. Tops called out to us because theyre about form, a poised shape, and they are about spinning, which is what we do on a potters wheel, Mr. Reid said.

title: Recipes for Kitchen Redesigns
description: Kitchens tend to be busy, messy places thanks to the role theyve assumed as the hub of the home. And apartment kitchens are often cramped and lacking in natural light and views. These are not the sorts of kitchens you will find in The Kitchen Bible: Designing the Perfect Culinary Space (Images Publishing; $45), by Barbara Ballinger, Margaret Crane and Jennifer Gilmer, a kitchen designer of three decades. The aspirational spaces pictured here, many designed by Ms. Gilmer, are mostly amply sized, outfitted with the latest appliances and carefully propped for their close-ups. But the book also clearly lays out the steps involved in a kitchen redo. Although geared more toward those who will be working with a kitchen designer than those tackling makeovers themselves, the book offers advice on things like hanging stove hoods that is useful for do-it-yourselfers, too.

title: A Glistening Canopy Begins With a Lantern
description: Think Fabricate has taken its Think lantern, a minimal geometric pendant introduced last year, to new heights. Or rather, lengths. The Brooklyn design firms Lantern Helix ($8,600) is a four-foot-long corkscrew-shaped chandelier incorporating 14 Think lanterns of varying sizes, shapes and finishes.

title: Building an Outdoor Shower
description: I cant count how many times Ive finished a home-improvement project with the echoes of my own profanities ringing in my ears. I could finish the job with aesthetic flourishes, but usually I hate the thing so much by then that I just sneer at it and walk away.

title: Before You Can Shower
description: Youll need just a few things.

title: J.C. Penney Burnishes Its Liz Claiborne Brand
description: READY or not, here comes autumn, brought to you by Madison Avenue.

title: Mexico Opens Oil Fields to Foreigners
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexican officials on Wednesday outlined the changing landscape of the countrys oil and gas industry as the country looks to foreign players to help develop its energy future.

title: A Bid for a Better Olympics
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  THE Olympic movement is descending into a slow-motion crisis. Fewer and fewer cities are game for the Games.

title: Go Tell It on the Mountain
description: The cartoonist on humanitarian aid.

title: Runner Faces Ban for Drug Violation
description: The former world champion runner Amantle Montsho of Botswana faces a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, track and field officials said Wednesday.

title: The Power of Two
description: Ah, synergy: such a 90s term. In the age of social media, however, the concept has taken on new life, as the power couples of social media  romantic pairings in which each member enjoys professional prominence, as well as an army of followers online  have discovered co-branding opportunities of Twitter and Instagram.

title: Ex-Head of Washington Schools Steps Down at Advocacy Group
description: Michelle A. Rhee, the divisive former schools chancellor in Washington and one of the most public faces of a campaign to change public education, is stepping down as chief executive of StudentsFirst, the advocacy group she founded four years ago. In a blog post on the groups website on Wednesday, Ms. Rhee said that it was time for my next step in life and that she would focus on her family and support her husband, Mayor Kevin Johnson of Sacramento, as he continues to move forward with his career. She also has two children with her ex-husband, Kevin Huffman, the commissioner of education in Tennessee. Ms. Rhee, who raised millions of dollars from donors including the Walton Family Foundation and the Broad Foundation, pursued an aggressive agenda involving changes in state laws regarding teacher tenure, performance evaluations and testing. In her statement, she said: While I remain 100 percent committed to the success of StudentsFirst, its time for a shift in the day-to-day management of the team and our advocacy work.

title: Lucky Magazine Gets an E-Partner to Shop With
description: WHEN LUCKY MAGAZINE arrived on newsstands almost 14 years ago, it was the most exciting thing to happen to Cond Nast since Rice Krispies Treats in the Frank Gehry-designed cafeteria at 4 Times Square. And for readers, Lucky was not unlike a Rice Krispies Treat: hard to resist; easy to accuse of lacking nutritional value; sticky with its decals that one could affix, with the glee of a preschooler, to pictures of items one planned to buy. Hitherto American womens publications had cloaked their mercenary objectives in the soft batting of short fiction and horoscopes and etiquette advice; this one declared nakedly on the cover that it was the magazine about shopping.

title: Apply Outside the Lines
description: In 1996, the makeup artist Franois Nars was working on a shoot for Harpers Bazaar. He used his bronze Tangier lipstick on the model Carolyn Murphys lips, then applied it to her eyelids and cheeks as well. This monochromatic look became the inspiration for the Multiple, the multiuse product that is one of his lines best sellers.

title: For a Well-Played Hand, Far From P.C.
description: In an age where honesty is often reserved for anonymity, and social media accounts are scraped for off-color content, a deck of cards with the slogan a party game for horrible people on its box has, for many young people, an undeniable allure.

title: They Meet in the Middle
description: Thirty years ago, before the East End of London was a hive of hipsterdom, home to an Ace Hotel and an Opening Ceremony outpost, the first Casely-Hayford studio sat there, roughly the size of a football field. It was the creative home of the designer Joe Casely-Hayford, whose family home was just down the road. You couldnt buy a cappuccino here, said Mr. Casely-Hayford, speaking recently at what may pass for a tableau of Times Have Changed: the Ace Hotels thrumming lobby coffee bar. Youd be shot if you asked for a cappuccino.

title: A Moment in Time Captured in Pieces
description: The instrument itself is a two-tone Oyster Perpetual Datejust, with a 41-millimeter case, an unusual grooved dial of 18-karat gold, a gold-and-silver Jubilee bracelet and a signature flip-lock clasp. It is a chronometer, which is to say a precision watch that enables its wearer to measure elapsed time, not in the way a stopwatch might, but with great accuracy. It is a Rolex, one of millions of wristwatches produced over the decades by this notable producer of high-end timepieces, and when originally sold it cost roughly $7,700.

title: Where Artisans Meet Fashion
description: On a recent overcast Saturday morning, an eclectic group convened in an unassuming office near Bryant Park within walking distance of the United Nations.

title: Alabama: Federal Judge Loses His Docket After an Arrest
description: A federal judge who was arrested after he was accused on Saturday of assaulting his wife will not be assigned any new cases for now. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, in a statement posted on its website on Wednesday, also said that cases already on the docket of the judge, Mark E. Fuller, would be moved before other judges. Judge Fuller, of the Federal District Court for the Middle District of Alabama, was charged with battery after the police were called to a luxury hotel in Atlanta. He was released on bond on Monday on a misdemeanor charge. Judge Fuller joined the bench in Montgomery in 2002 after being nominated by President George W. Bush.

title: North of Boston, a Mix of Harbor and History
description: Marblehead, Mass., less than an hour up the coast from Boston, is one of those straightforward places where merely strolling around is the top attraction. Thats mostly thanks to its historic center, home to nearly 300 Colonial-era houses  the most of any town in the United States, according to the local Chamber of Commerce. The fishing town was one of the most prosperous in the colonies. Shipmasters, bakers and cordwainers alike found the money to build solid and beautiful homes that are still much in demand today.

title: Polishing Its Past and Preparing Its Future
description: O.K., you think you know Cape Ann, the North Shore peninsula that has been faintly patronized as Cape Cods little sister.

title: Investors Profit From Foreclosure Risk on Home Mortgages
description: Rises in housing prices have been profitable to private equity firms and institutional investors that bought foreclosed homes to flip them or to rent them out. Now the recovery in housing is fueling a niche market for newly minted bonds that are backed by the most troubled mortgages of them all: those on homes on the verge of foreclosure.

title: Two Sets of Rules for Surveillance, Within U.S. and on Foreign Soil
description: How the N.S.A.s surveillance programs are governed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act and Executive Order 12333.

title: E-Cigarettes Under Scrutiny for Listing as Flight Hazard
description: The Massachusetts fire marshal is focused on an e-cigarette as the possible cause of smoldering in a bag that had to be removed from a jet on Saturday night at Bostons Logan International Airport. Airport officials are asking the Transportation Department to consider classifying e-cigarettes as hazardous materials.

title: The Rise of 3-D Printed Guns
description: This week, instead of walking into a gun shop and handing over my credit card to buy firearms, bullets and grenades, I decided to try a different route: I downloaded highly detailed schematics  like blueprints for a house  of dozens of functional weapons and bullets.

title: Media Scrutiny Drags on Earnings at SeaWorld
description: SeaWorld is still reeling from the effects of the negative media attention it has received over its treatment of captive orca whales.

title: Michael Brown and Black Men
description: The killing of Michael Brown has tapped into something bigger than Michael Brown.

title: NFL Films Retains Its Name as It Goes Digital
description: For 50 years, NFL Films has built its reputation by immersing viewers in a cinematic experience unlike watching games on television. Spiraling footballs, muddy linemen battling at the line of scrimmage, wired coaches, leaping receptions and vapor rising from bald heads looked like Hollywood movies, especially when augmented with martial music and over-the-top narration by baritone voices.

title: Plane Crash Kills Brazilian Politician
description: Television footage of the immediate aftermath of a plane crash in a residential area that killed the Brazilian presidential candidate Eduardo Campos and six others.

title: Brazilian Presidential Candidate Dies in Plane Crash, Upsetting Race
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The campaign plane of Eduardo Campos, a Brazilian presidential candidate and scion of a resurgent political dynasty, crashed on Wednesday in the port city of Santos, killing him and six others and shaking up an increasingly competitive race in Latin Americas largest democracy.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 12, 2014
description: Other predators may be bigger and fiercer, but I would argue that there is nothing so enthusiastic as a wild dog. They live the life domestic dogs wish they could live.

title: Dont Dismiss the Humanities
description: What use could the humanities be in a digital age?

title: President Obama: No Internet Fast Lanes
description: The Federal Communications Commission, which could soon allow phone and cable companies to block or interfere with Internet content, has been deluged with more than a million comments. Last week, President Obama offered some thoughts of his own by saying that the Internet should be left open so that the next Google or the next Facebook can succeed.

title: Idea for New Ruler: Tweak a Few Regulations
description: Any minute now, Major League Baseball will have a new commissioner for the first time in 22 years, and whoever that lucky man turns out to be, his calendar will be packed.

title: App Smart | The Random and Serendipitous
description: Kit Eaton reviews Secret, Whisper and Random, three apps that can offer anonymous, unexpected or even inspirational tidbits of information.

title: Justice Denied for Abused Children
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo signed a bill last week that adds compensated public school coaches to the list of professionals, including teachers, required to report to authorities suspected cases of child sexual abuse and other maltreatment. This leaves uncovered some (but not all) private and parochial school coaches, volunteer coaches and college-level coaches. And it does nothing to elevate New Yorks low ranking when it comes to providing justice to the victims of child sexual abuse. That shabby distinction is directly related to the states failure to extend its severely short statute of limitations in child-sexual-abuse cases.

title: Apps for Sharing Secrets and Gossip
description: IF you crave randomness, something unexpected or even a little scandalous gossip, some intriguing apps can help.

title: Terrorism Trial of Mideast Bank Worries the Financial World
description: The judge called it the Beirut account.

title: Rocket Fire Casts Doubt on Truce in Gaza
description: CAIRO  Palestinian leaders said early Thursday that in the last moments before the midnight expiration of their cease-fire with Israel in Gaza, the two sides had agreed to hold their fire for an additional five days to continue talks about a more durable truce. But an exchange of rockets and missiles around the end of one cease-fire and the beginning of the next cast immediate doubt about whether it would even last until dawn.

title: Burger King to Phase Out Lower-Fat French Fries
description: Chicken fries or low-fat fries?

title: Whats Next With Hillary?
description: Well, lets hope thats over.

title: Cutting a Path to the Course, With the Help of Her Family
description: The L.P.G.A. Tour arrives this week at its fourth major of the year, the L.P.G.A. Championship in Pittsford, N.Y., with an American golfer having won the previous three.

title: As Ebolas Toll Rises, Drug Makers Race to Test Medicines
description: Because outbreaks are sporadic and mainly confined to Africa, the Ebola virus has not been a priority for profit-seeking pharmaceutical companies.

title: Saudis Give $100 Million to U.N. Fight on Terrorism
description: UNITED NATIONS  Increasingly worried about the spread of Islamist militant extremism reaching its own doorstep, Saudi Arabia donated $100 million to a fledgling United Nations counterterrorism agency on Wednesday and expressed hope that such an infusion  10 times what the Saudis gave to help create the agency three years ago  would strengthen its abilities and set an example for other donor countries.

title: Nothings Quite as Thoughtful as a Hat
description: Gigi Burris, a milliner known for creations like a barbed wire headband and a mohawk beanie. She is a finalist for the 2014 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award, only the second milliner to be nominated.

title: Woods, Citing His Back, Drops Out as Candidate for Ryder Cup Team
description: Tiger Woods took himself out of consideration for the United States Ryder Cup team on Wednesday, saying that his doctors had advised him to rest and rehabilitate his injured back. Woods, who did not qualify for the team but was an almost certain alternate choice if he were healthy, said he had called the American Ryder Cup captain, Tom Watson, to inform him.

title: Help Is on the Way for Repaying Student Loans
description: If you are struggling with student loans that you took out before October 2007, there is a new, more generous option in the works that may help you manage your debt payments.

title: The OBannon Ruling: College Athletes Win
description: There are two important consequences of a long-awaited ruling last week by a federal judge, Claudia Wilken, in the so-called OBannon case. College athletes will almost certainly be better off financially. And the notion that these athletes are pure amateurs  students first, athletes second  will be impossible to sustain.

title: The OBannon Ruling: Student-Athlete Is History
description: The myth of the pure student-athlete that Judge Claudia Wilken has now demolished has been around for a long time. The term itself is so widely used in conversation (by fans, the news media and the National Collegiate Athletic Association) that it sounds like a neutral description. In fact, its a deceptive term with a peculiar history.

title: Orioles Balance Outweighs Yankees Balance Sheet
description: BALTIMORE  The Baltimore Orioles put their prized third baseman, Manny Machado, on the disabled list Wednesday. They used Chris Davis, a slugger who entered the day with a sub-.200 average and 139 strikeouts, in the No. 2 hole. They did not reach base against Michael Pineda until the fifth inning and looked helpless against reliever Dellin Betances.

title: Virginia Ex-Governor and Wife Set to Begin Defense at Trial
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Prosecutors have cast Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia, as a desperate politician who was short of cash and more than willing to promote a donors product if it meant that he and his wife, Maureen, could live a more lavish life.

title: For U.N. Leader on Human Rights, Finish Line Looks Blurry
description: GENEVA  fIn her final days as the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay has neither slowed down nor shied away from controversy.

title: Souvenir of Venice
description: On a recent Saturday morning, Todd Broockerd was delivering coffee beans to a client, Normas, a cafe. He wore purple velvet gondolier slippers that he picked up in Venice on a business trip. This interview has been edited.

title: Six Members of Congress Ask Holder to Open Federal Inquiry in Chokehold Case
description: Six members of Congress have asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to open a federal investigation into the circumstances surrounding the death of a Staten Island man in police custody, and to extend the inquiry into other possible civil-rights violations committed by the Police Department through its broken windows approach to fighting crime.

title: Mexico: Lawmaker Punished in Scandal
description: Mexicos conservative opposition party has removed one of its congressional whips after a video emerged showing him and other legislators at a party with table dancers. The National Action Party, whose members often talk of maintaining wholesome family values, removed Luis Alberto Villarreal on Wednesday as coordinator of its legislators in the lower house as well as Mr. Villarreals deputy, Jorge Villalobos, who also appears in the video. It was taken earlier this year at a party at a beach resort but was disclosed this week on ReporteIndigo.com, a news website. Former President Felipe Caldern, a member of the party, said Wednesday in a radio interview that the video showed the moral decomposition of the party. Mr. Villarreal said in a statement that the video was illegally recorded at a private party for which no public funds were spent. The episode was the latest example of electronic eavesdropping that often propels political scandals here.

title: Doctors Advocate
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Interesting-looking grid, isnt it? I will confess that I didnt quite know what to make of the design before I started solving this second time at bat by Jason Flinn. But I will tell you what gave it away for me.

title: Working Anything but 9 to 5
description: Increasing numbers of low-income mothers and fathers are at the center of a new collision that pits workplace scheduling technology against the routines of parenting.

title: Recommendation Not Taken Meant Significant Changes for Executive Order 12333 Intercepts
description: An internal White House document that compiling steps to be taken on changes to National Security Agency practices, including recommendations by a review group President Obama appointed. It shows the administration recognized that the review groups would mean making significant changes to the use of American communications gathered without a warrant by the N.S.A. under Executive Order 12333.

title: Big Business Trip to Las Vegas for Ciscos John Chambers
description: John Chambers, chief executive of Cisco and a man who likes big bets, is headed for the right place.

title: A Stop at Hillary Clintons Book Tour
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton attends a signing session for her book Hard Choices at the Bunch of Grapes bookstore in Vineyard Haven on Marthas Vineyard, Mass.

title: Responses to Whistleblower Complaints
description: Earlier this year, John Napier Tie, a former State Department official who worked on Internet issues, filed an inspector general whistleblower complaint alleging that the National Security Agencys collection and storage of American communications abroad under Executive Order 12333 violates the Fourth Amendment. He also took his concerns to the House and Senate Intelligence Committees. He received these two letters back; he did not hear back from the Senate panel.

title: Is This Island Big Enough for Clinton and Obama?
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.  Hillary Rodham Clinton blew into this tiny island town like a fast-moving hurricane on Wednesday, creating a commotion at the Bunch of Grapes bookstore, where hundreds of admirers waited for hours in the rain for a glimpse of the woman who they hope will be the next president.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 13, 2014
With Gruffness and Glamour, Bacall Was a True New Yorker
description: Before the photograph in Harpers Bazaar that led to the call from Hollywood, she lived on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. And on Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn. The census takers found her.

title: World Trade Center Logo Captures Sites Destruction and Rebirth
description: Can you see a trident  an abstract trident recalling those three-fingered steel columns at the base of the twin towers, still standing after the 2001 attack, symbolizing New York Citys resilience?

title: Earl Cheit, Prescient Educator, Dies at 87
description: Earl F. Cheit, an educator who in 1970 wrote a sobering, influential report saying that two-thirds of the colleges and universities in the United States were in or near grave financial difficulty, died on Aug. 2 at his home in Kensington, Calif. He was 87.

title: Mary MacCracken, Who Wrote About Disabilities, Dies at 88
description: Mary MacCracken, whose memoirs about her intensely individualized approach to teaching children with emotional and cognitive disabilities were made into television movies, died on July 23 in Hanover, N.H. She was 88.

title: Letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.
description: The final signed letter sent to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Wednesday, urged the Justice Department to intervene in the case about the death of Eric Garner immediately.

title: A Replay Infuriates Girardi; Fast-Forward and the Yanks Lose Again
description: BALTIMORE  One of the more vivid signs of the Yankees recent frustrations materialized in the seventh inning Wednesday night. The Yankees were clinging to a 2-1 lead when Stephen Drew chopped a ball in front of the plate and sprinted toward first base. The throw to the bag from Nick Hundley, the Orioles catcher, deflected off Drew and dribbled into right field.

title: New Rule Is Fuzzy, but Mets Result Is Absolute: Another Loss to Nationals
description: If the Mets are going to have a glimmer of hope of catching the Washington Nationals in the National League East, they will first have to start beating them. This has not proved easy this year, last year or any year since 2011, when Washington began a stretch over which it has won 42 of 58 games against them.

title: Taking Break From Crises Elsewhere, Kerry Turns to Asia and Pacific
description: HONOLULU  After months of crisis diplomacy over the Middle East and Ukraine, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday that President Obama had asked him to redouble his diplomatic efforts in Asia and the Pacific through the remainder of his administration.

title: Reagan-Era Order on Surveillance Violates Rights, Says Departing Aide
description: WASHINGTON  After President Obama delivered a speech in January endorsing changes to surveillance policies, including an end to the National Security Agencys bulk collection of Americans domestic calling records, John Napier Tye was disillusioned.

title: The Race to Record the Ruins
description: As land values rise, Perus ancient sites are under threat from development. To respond, Peru is creating a drone air force to map, monitor and safeguard its endangered treasures.

title: New to the Archaeologists Tool Kit: The Drone
description: CHEPN, Peru  A small remote-controlled helicopter buzzed over ancient hilltop ruins here, snapping hundreds of photographs. Below, stone walls built more than a thousand years ago by the Moche civilization gave way to a grid of adobe walls put up only recently by what officials said were land speculators.

title: Public Schools Got a Brand-New Bag
description: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow of the CFDA-award-winning line Public School have been shaking up the mens fashion scene with their streetwear-inspired styles since they launched in 2008. On the fall/winter 2014 runway, they debuted their first womens collection; now theyve added accessories. Tomorrow, the duo will launch two limited-edition unisex bags  a weekender ($850) and a backpack ($575)  in collaboration with Killspencer, the L.A. leather goods brand run by Spencer Nikosey, a former industrial designer. Both styles are made from the same pressed Italian matte leather that was used in Public Schools fall collection and feature waterproof interiors and quilted topstitching details. The bags are intricate and functional, says Osborne. We wanted to make that type of bag for a guy  durable but still clean, sharp and exact.

title: William Helburns Playful Magazine Images from the 1950s and 60s
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Practicing on Patients
description: Who should do this case? That was the question a senior surgeon posed to me outside a patients room in the cardiac care unit. Judging by his expression, he already knew the answer.

title: Hydration Powder Attracts Grateful Deads Bob Weir as Investor
description: Bob Weir, a founding member of the Grateful Dead, used to keep water and Gatorade on hand to stay hydrated on tour. In particularly hot weather, he said, he would soak his T-shirt in a cooler, wring it out and wear it wet.

title: Word of the Day | stagnant
description: stagnant \stag-nnt\ adjective

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 14, 2014
description: I get why they want to protect him. But the people want answers. When we get answers, things will calm down.

title: Corrections: August 14, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Welcome to Rhode Island, Americas Least Polarized State
description: Wonder what Washington might look like if it were less polarized? Just look to Rhode Island. The political scientists Boris Shor and Nolan McCarty analyzed state legislative voting records from 1996 to 2013 and found Rhode Island had the least ideological difference between the typical Republican and Democratic lawmakers.

title: By Sea and by Ladder, Africans Seek Entry to Spain
description: Migrants from Africa continued to pour across the Mediterranean this week, and Spains sea rescue service picked up 681 people traveling in 70 small boats across the Strait of Gibraltar. Above, a Red Cross worker helped with a feeding at a sports center in the Spanish port of Tarifa. Below, new arrivals stormed border fences with ladders to try to enter Spains northwest African enclave of Melilla from Morocco. Around 50 stayed on one of the fences for hours.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: CHARLIE CHAPLIN An all-day tribute to Chaplin moves into prime time with The Birth of the Tramp (2014), Serge Bromberg and Eric Langes documentary about the actors rise from a disadvantaged childhood in London to one of the silent screens biggest stars, and the creation of his character the Tramp along the way. The lineup includes A Dogs Life (1918), in which a mutt lifts the Tramp (Chaplin) and his girlfriend, a dance hall singer (Edna Purviance), out of destitution, at 9; The Kid (1921), in which the Tramp plots to get his adopted son (Jackie Coogan, above with Chaplin) back after the authorities return him to his biological parents, at 9:45; and The Idle Class (1921), in which the Tramp incites chaos at a golf resort when he steals the balls, at 10:45.

title: From the Frontlines: Insider War Coverage
description: On Tuesday, Alissa J. Rubin, a Times correspondent, was aboard a helicopter carrying aid to stranded refugees in northern Iraq. The helicopter crashed. The pilot was killed. Alissa was injured. Also aboard was Adam Ferguson, a freelance photographer working for The Times, who suffered minor injuries.

title: Where We Came From and Where We Went, State by State
description: Updated charts now show two views: where people who live in each state were born, and where people who were born in a state moved to.

title: Family of Dissident Lawyer Fears for His Health After Prison
description: Relatives of a Chinese lawyer released from prison last week say they are concerned about his physical and mental health because of abuse he suffered during years in custody.

title: French-Chinese Venture Withdraws Bid for Club Med
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese and French investors who offered more than $700 million last year for the resort operator Club Mditerrane said on Thursday that they were withdrawing their bid, which had been trumped in June by a higher offer from an Italian private equity investor.

title: Student Crossword | Women of Distinction
description: Test your knowledge of women who have made significant contributions by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Russian Convoy Draws Stern Warning From Ukraine and Stops Short of Border
description: KAMENSK-SHAKHTINSKY, Russia  A Russian aid convoy rumbled toward rebel-held territory in eastern Ukraine on Thursday, stirring fears of a direct confrontation between Russia and Ukraine after months of hands-off sparring through armed proxies between the two bitterly estranged neighbors.

title: Eurozone Recovery Stalls, With Weakness in Germany and France
description: PARIS  This was supposed to be the year that the European economy decisively broke free of its shackles. But after a dismal round of economic growth reports on Thursday, the main question appears to be whether the eurozone will avoid tumbling back into recession.

title: Pontiff Voices Hope for Korean Peace and Grief for Ferry Victims
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Pope Francis, arriving in South Korea on Thursday, expressed hope for reconciliation on the divided Korean Peninsula and offered consolation to the relatives of the scores of children who died in a ferry disaster in April.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Girls in Little League World Series Become Less of a Novelty
description: In Girls in Little League World Series Become Less of a Novelty, Mike Tierney writes about the growing role that girls have played in the Little League Baseball World Series.

title: ThyssenKrupp Earnings Bounce Back
description: LONDON  The German steel-making conglomerate ThyssenKrupp said on Thursday that it earned 39 million euros in the second quarter, compared with a loss of 395 million in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 8 percent to 10.7 billion, it said.

title: Our Microbiome May Be Looking Out for Itself
description: Your body is home to about 100 trillion bacteria and other microbes, collectively known as your microbiome. Naturalists first became aware of our invisible lodgers in the 1600s, but it wasnt until the past few years that weve become really familiar with them.

title: Should You Fear the Pizzly Bear?
description: In New England today, trees cover more land than they have at any time since the colonial era. Roughly 80 percent of the region is now forested, compared with just 30 percent in the late 19th century. Moose and turkey again roam the backwoods. Beavers, long ago driven from the area by trappers seeking pelts, once more dam streams. White-tailed deer are so numerous that they are often considered pests. And an unlikely predator has crept back into the woods, too: what some have called the coywolf. It is both old and new  roughly one-quarter wolf and two-thirds coyote, with the rest being dog.

title: An Editors Photos of Wartime France
description: Closing in on 100, John G. Morris is perhaps the best-known living photo editor  partly because photographers usually become famous, not picture editors. He edited, and was close to, Robert Capa, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Alfred Eisenstaedt and W. Eugene Smith.

title: Protest in Missouri at Police Killing of Teenager Is Chronicled on Social Media
description: Demonstrators in Ferguson, Mo. gathered on Wednesday for another round of protests over the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager who was killed over the weekend by a police officer. Mr. Browns death has triggered days of protests that have brought national attention to racial tension between the police and the African-American community in the St. Louis suburb.

title: Throwback Thursday | 1916 New Jersey Shark Attacks
description: In honor of the 27th annual Shark Week, some history about how pop cultures shark mania first began, and a terrifying photo of a great white  even though, according to this analysis, your chances of being bitten by a shark are considerably slimmer than your chances of being bitten by the Uruguay striker Luis Surez:

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: Morning Views
description: Claudia Wilken, a federal judge, handed down a decision meaning college athletes will almost certainly be better off financially, according to an editorial in The New York Times. And the notion that these athletes are pure amateurs  students first, athletes second  will be impossible to sustain. Judge Wilken issued an injunction against a ban on payments to players for the commercial use of their names, images and likenesses, which she claims was in violation of antitrust law. She also ruled that college sports governing body, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, may not prohibit universities from offering cost-of-living stipends in addition to scholarships. The OBannon Ruling, as its known, is named for Ed OBannon, a former basketball player for the University of California, Los Angeles, and other plays like him who until now have been unable to share in the considerable wealth generated by their skill and hard work. The N.C.A.A. built a lucrative commercial enterprise that depended in large part on unpaid labor. Judge Wilkens decision is a step toward righting those decades of exploitation.

title: A Leading Export of New York State: People
description: New York was once the nations most populous state. Now its fourth. Thats in part because millions of New Yorkers have left the Empire State for opportunities elsewhere.

title: New York Today: City of Stunts
description: Good morning on this cool Thursday.

title: At Salzburg Festival, Mixed Results for New Productions
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Opera is a museum. It is devoted to the preservation and presentation of beautiful remnants from the past, prepared and arranged, with both thoughtfulness and flair, so that those musty objects take on new life.

title: The Downside of Running With Others
description: My husband wont talk to me when we run. Me, I need to carry on a conversation from the minute I start running to the minute I stop. The chitchat helps me forget the misery of the task at hand. But more than that, when I run alone, my mind will bully me into slowing down or stopping. When I run with other people, my mind wont dare speak up  and I wind up running longer and faster than when I run alone.

title: 1889: Londons Disgrace. Painful Experience of a Healthy Man on The Underground
description: At half-past three oclock yesterday a well-dressed man of thirty, with clean face, and a buoyant, healthy, contented expression entered the Charing Cross Station of the Underground Railway. At twenty minutes to five he came out again with a greasy, dirty face, with his eyes red, his ears full of cinders, his collar and cuffs soiled, his face pale, and his whole look weary, dejected, and limp. He scarcely seemed to be the same person as he sadly inquired the way to a bath. And he had simply taken a trip around the inner circle to personally undergo what millions of the traveling public have to suffer daily.

title: In Pursuit of Balfour Beatty, British Construction Giant Carillion Meets With Shareholders
description: LONDON  The British construction and support services company Carillion said on Thursday that it still believed a merger with its rival Balfour Beatty made strategic sense and could result in annual savings of 175 million pounds, or about $293 million.

title: Daily Report: Profits Slip, and Cisco Plans to Cut 6,000 Jobs
description: Cisco Systems may be doing a little better than Wall Street expects, considering its technology and sales challenges. But that does not mean the company will avoid layoffs in the coming months, Quentin Hardy reports.

title: NRG Energy Buys Goal Zero, a Start-Up, as Entry to Mobile Solar Business
description: NRG Energy, one of the countrys largest independent power producers, is getting into the mobile solar business with the acquisition of a start-up called Goal Zero, company executives said on Thursday.

title: 1939: Fascist Italy Issues Book Ban
description: ROME  The works of famous writers, including many Jews, and such books as the Nick Carter series of red-blooded adventures that thrilled American boys a generation or two ago, as well as Emil Ludwigs biography of Lincoln, have been condemned officially as unsuited to the Fascist spirit. Booksellers and librarians received the list, which included books that have been seized and destroyed and others of which the sale has been forbidden. The condemned authors include Casanova, Balzac, Boccaccio, Machiavelli, Rabelais, Voltaire and Poe. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 15, 1939

title: Morning Agenda: A Market for Delinquent Mortgages
description: The recovery in housing is creating a market for newly minted bonds that are backed by the mortgages on homes on the verge of foreclosure, DealBooks Matthew Goldstein writes. It is not just vulture hedge funds swooping in to try to profit from the last remnants of the housing crisis, he adds. The investors making money off these obscure bonds, none of which are rated by a top credit rating agency, include United States mutual funds. One of the biggest sellers of severely delinquent mortgages to investors is a United States government housing agency.

title: At Least 10 Injured After Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters
description: BEIJING  Chinese police officers opened fire on Tibetan protesters this week in a Tibetan area of southwest China, injuring at least 10 people, according to reports late Wednesday by the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group, and Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government.

title: Barney Harford of Orbitz, on Finding a Team That Fits
description: Q. Were you in leadership roles when you were younger?

title: Imbibing a World of Delight and Degradation
description: Henri de Toulouse-Lautrecs aristocratic parents were first cousins, and his numerous  genetic defects, including bone abnormalities, are attributed to a family history of inbreeding. At 13, he fell and broke a thigh bone, and at 14, the other. The breaks didnt heal properly, and his legs stopped growing. As an adult he stood 4 feet 11 inches. He had the body of a grown man but walked on childlike legs with the help of a cane. His lips and nose outgrew the rest of his face, causing him to lisp and drool and suffer from chronic sinus problems.

title: After Celebrity Drug Cases, Industry Signs Deal in Beijing
description: Forty-two artist management agencies in Beijing have signed an agreement with the police vowing to take action against illegal drug use within the industry, The Beijing News reported.

title: More Churches Lose Their Crosses Despite Protests
description: Crosses have been removed from two more Christian churches this week in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, part of a continuing campaign by the local authorities to lower the profile of the countrys fastest-growing religion.

title: Hong Kong Newspaper Prints Fake Obituary of Rivals Owner
description: It was the journalistic equivalent of putting a horses head in your rivals bed. Lai Chee-ying, 65, also known as Fatty Lai and a native of Shunde in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong, had died of AIDS and cancer on Aug. 7. Since his family members were also sick, there would be no funeral.

title: Arena Football Is Crossing Into New Territory: China
description: Marty Judge is fully convinced that China wants football  not the type played by the N.F.L. but the indoor version found in the Arena Football League, where the field is 50 yards long, there are eight players a side, and the ball can be rebounded off nets above the end zone.

title: Ask.com Buys Ask.fm, an Anonymous Q.&A. Start-Up
description: Updated | Ask, and ye shall receive.

title: The Curious Case of Kiesza
description: How a Canadian ballerina-turned-sailor became the seasons biggest pop music breakout.

title: Walmart, J.C. Penney and Other Retailers See a Tentative Shopper
description: Many consumers still appear reluctant to open their wallets, according to a mixed batch of retail earnings this week that shows little growth in spending at some of the nations biggest stores.

title: An Art Project on Wheels
description: Dear Diary:

title: Luis Surezs Ban for Bite Is Altered but Upheld
description: The Court of Arbitration for Sport on Thursday upheld Luis Surezs four-month ban from soccer, ruling that he could not play in an official game for his club team, Barcelona, until the end of October.

title: New Tack on Unrest Eases Tension in Missouri
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  President Obama on Thursday called for an end to the violence here, denouncing actions both by the police and by protesters. Hours later, the Missouri governor, Jay Nixon, ordered the state highway patrol to take over security operations from local law enforcement.

title: Music for Its Own Sake, Until a Dreamer Intrudes
description: Popular music has always had a place for eccentrics and visionaries, artists whose inventions sometimes take them to the borderlands of madness. Frank, a captivatingly low-key new film directed by Lenny Abrahamson, was inspired by the life and work of one such musician, a singer known as Frank Sidebottom, who flourished in Britain in the 1990s. At one point, Mr. Sidebottom hired a keyboard player named Jon Ronson  though hired may suggest too conventional an arrangement  who later embellished, edited and updated his experience into the screenplay for this movie, which takes place in the present-day world of social media and South by Southwest.

title: Changing South Is at Intersection of Demographics and Politics
description: The South is the fastest-growing region of the country, and Democrats are hoping that a flood of Northern expats and demographic change will allow them to turn red states to blue at a fast enough pace to counter the regions growing share of the Electoral College.

title: In Ferguson, Focus on Police Action, Not Police Gear
description: The web is full of ridicule at the dark armor and military weaponry of the suburban St. Louis police officers, who have been confronting unarmed protesters over the last few days as if they were ISIS militants. The anger, however, is misplaced. The focus should not be on police gear, but on police conduct, which is increasingly appalling. The vast amount of tear gas fired just last night seemed wholly unjustified.

title: Rent a Toy, Learn a Lesson
description: What would children learn if we made them give away some of their favorite toys after a month?

title: Terry Pratchett: By the Book
description: The author of the Discworld series  most recently, Raising Steam  read The Wind in the Willows and just exploded: I thought to myself, This is a lie, but what a fabulous lie!

title: British Government to Delay Lloyds Sale to Retail Investors
description: LONDON  The British government has delayed plans to sell a portion of its remaining stake in the Lloyds Banking Group to retail investors until after next years general election, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: The German Brand Nomos Offers Up Luxury for Less
description: In this weekly series, the mens fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Christopher David Ryan captures a timepiece from Nomos.

title: Blackstone to Buy Louisiana Shale Assets for $1.2 Billion
description: The Blackstone Group is going deeper into the natural gas business, with a $1.2 billion deal to buy into a Louisiana shale field.

title: Banks Watching Terrorism Trial in Brooklyn
description: Banks are watching the first civil trial against a bank under the Anti-Terrorism Act with some trepidation. Opening arguments start in the United States District Court in Brooklyn on Thursday.

title: Pope and South Korean President on Peace
description: Pope Francis, in his visit to Seoul, called for efforts toward reconciliation between North and South Korea. Meanwhile, President Park Geun-hye urged North Korea to give up its nuclear ambition.

title: Outpouring of Interest in Robin Williams News
description: News of Robin Williamss suicide clearly struck a chord with readers on Monday night.

title: Aug. 14 Updates on Protests Over Police Shooting in Ferguson, Mo.
description: Thousands of people gathered for peaceful vigils Thursday night in dozens of cities across the country from San Francisco to Boston to remember Michael Brown, the unarmed young black man shot and killed on Saturday by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo. In a move to restore calm, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri turned to a commander from the states highway patrol to oversee security efforts in Ferguson, where local and county police have clashed with protesters in recent days. The Times provided updates.

title: Birkenstocks Are on the Move
description: New Yorkers are sure putting the stock in Birkenstock.

title: Suburbs: Been There, Done That.
description: When Katherine Nguyen and Vincent Todarello shared a 400-square-foot studio near Canal Street, they rented a storage unit for the overflow of their stuff. Five years ago, caught in the whirlwind of wedding planning, they decided to buy a suburban house.

title: Checking In 20 Years After an Experiment With the American Dream
description: Twenty years ago, a group of classmates from Harvard started a summer camp for children from Mission Hill, Boston. Farah Stockman, now a writer at The Boston Globe, was one of the students. We didnt know it at the time, but we were watching an experiment that tested the validity of the American dream for Bostons poorest children.Now Ms. Stockman has written a series, with a video, exploring what happened to the kids who attended the camp:

title: What Sells Better: Sexy or Empowered?
description: Consider two advertising campaigns for womens clothing: In one, a world-famous ballerina spins, jumps and stands tall on point, displaying her perfectly sculpted, athletic body; in the other, a faceless model  or rather, her derrire  bends over a car door in a short, very revealing school-uniform-type skirt.

title: Vitamin D Tied to Alzheimers Risk
description: Low vitamin D is associated with an increased risk for Alzheimers disease and other forms of dementia, according to a new report, though whether low vitamin D is a cause of the disorders remains unknown.

title: Inside the Ballroom: Scenes From Baseballs Election Battle
description: BALTIMORE  The Hyatt Regency, a hulking hotel overlooking the harbor here, has a large ballroom on its second floor that, this week, has served as the epicenter for the 30 owners in Major League Baseball seeking to elect a new commissioner.

title: 1964: U.N. Fails to Control Nicosia
description: NICOSIA  United Nations Cyprus commander Gen. K.S. Thimayya today [Aug. 14] said the U.N. was unable to gain control of the situation in the tense capital city of Nicosia. Gen. Thimayya said he had received assurances from both sides that there would be no firing in the area of Kokkina, the only major port still dominated by the Turkish Cypriots. But, he said, he was not happy about the situation in Nicosia, where I have been unable to get control of the situation despite all my efforts. A U.N.- patrolled neutral zone (green line) through the city divides Greek and Turkish Cypriots. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 15, 1964

title: Rauschenberg Foundation Appeals Ruling Awarding $24.6 Million to Trustees
description: The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation has appealed a decision by a Florida court to award $24.6 million to three trustees who had administered the artists estate.

title: Creature Cast | Fiery Bodies Underwater
description: Pyrosomes, giant swimming colonies of transparent organisms, create brilliant underwater light shows.

title: Fiery Bodies Under the Waves
description: When we think of plankton, the organisms that live in the open ocean and drift with wind and currents, we usually think of tiny things like krill and the microscopic algae they eat. But not all planktonic animals are small.

title: Normcore Hall of Fame
description: The anti-style made famous by these six normcore icons.

title: Military to Ease Hairstyle Rules After Outcry From Black Recruits
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military is loosening its hairstyle requirements to allow more styles that are popular with black women, responding to criticism from some service members and lawmakers that black recruits had been treated unfairly by new restrictions.
