description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Far from being depleted by its recent sweep into Iraq, the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is pressing deeper into Syria, regaining territory it had lost to the mainstream Syrian insurgents just as the Syrian Army has come within five miles of encircling the insurgent-held section of Aleppo, Syrias largest city.

title: Ferguson Police Department Incident Report
description: The incident report of the convenience store robbery released Friday by the Ferguson Police Department.

title: An Ear to the Horn of Time
description: Peter Dilg motored his 13-foot skiff up to a one-room house sitting on stilts in the middle of Hempstead Bay, on Long Islands South Shore, then carried an old record player onto its deck.

title: Home Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Greta Gerwig, Marcus Samuelsson and Others Tell Stories About Beloved Garments
description: The artist, writer, teacher and editor Emily Spivack is a special kind of storyteller. The protagonist in her tales is always old, a little tired-looking and usually slightly beat-up: a used item of clothing. A year ago, Spivack lined the walls of the Philadelphia Art Alliance with garments she found on eBay. Each piece in the installation, Sentimental Value, was accompanied by an excerpt from the sellers tale in the eBay listing.

title: Cool Summer Fish
description: Fish can be challenging. Were told to eat it twice a week because its such a lean, high-protein, high-omega-3 animal, but were also told to avoid certain fish like swordfish and large tuna because of high mercury content, other types like Atlantic cod (or whats left of it) because of overfishing and farmed salmon because of ecological considerations.

title: Mapping the Spread of the Militarys Surplus Gear
description: Most U.S. counties have received at least some military equipment through a free Pentagon surplus program.

title: From Meditative to Modern, a Sense of Ripening Virtuosity
description: Eric Harlands Voyager

title: Dinner and Drinks on the Battlefield
description: When the city began plans to allow a restaurant in the 1928 Greek Revival-style pavilion at the north end of Union Square Park, some neighbors and park supporters objected, saying the area had plenty of bars and restaurants, but too little park space. That was 12 years ago. This spring, after lengthy court battles, the chow finally hit the tables. Let the kale chips fall where they may!

title: Thousands of Miles, Seven Days
description: The pioneering adventure travel outfitter Mountain Travel Sobek is best known for its remote adventures in wilderness destinations that, by virtue of location, require a fair investment of time to reach, let alone explore.

title: The Addict Down the Hall
description: Later this month, new residents will arrive at a nursing home in the Bronx. Like others coming to Jewish Home Lifecare, they will be recuperating from hospitalization for cardiac surgery, strokes, fractured hips  the whole panoply of senior ills.

title: Upright Citizens Brigade Will Invite the Audience to Help Write Blank! The Musical
description: The Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, a troupe that specializes in sketch comedy and improvisation, is planning to present Blank! The Musical, a new immersive work that will be composed afresh nightly, with the audiences help. The production, which opens at New World Stages on Nov. 1, and is expected to run six weeks, will use Internet technology to put some of the script decisions in the audiences hands.

title: As Europes Economy Stumbles, Britain Offers Some Glimmer of Hope
description: LONDON  Britain, once described as the sick man of Europe, now looks like the regions bright spot.

title: Ebola Epidemic Most Likely Much Larger Than Reported, W.H.O. Says
description: GENEVA  West Africas deadly Ebola epidemic is probably much worse than the world realizes, with health centers on the front lines warning that the actual numbers of deaths and illnesses are significantly higher than the official estimates, the World Health Organization said.

title: Ford Recalls 160,000 Turbocharged Vehicles
description: Ford is recalling about 160,000 Focus ST hatchbacks and Escape crossovers from the 2013-14 model years because the turbocharged, 2-liter 4-cylinder engine may lose power or stall, the automaker said Friday. The action includes about 133,000 vehicles in the United States and 25,000 in Canada.

title: By Using Language Rooted in Andes, Internet Shows Hosts Hope to Save It
description: Segundo J. Angamarca, half-hidden in a thicket of electronic equipment on a recent Friday evening, put on his headphones and glanced around the room, a makeshift Internet radio station in his apartment in the Bronx.

title: Can Statins Help Treat Ebola?
description: THIS week, the World Health Organization endorsed the use of experimental drugs in the fight against the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. That is the right decision. There is no proven vaccine or treatment for Ebola, and in light of the severity of the current outbreak, experimental treatments that have not been tested on humans should be an option.

title: Feta-Stuffed Grilled Flatbread
description: Melissa Clark shows flatbread at its best: grilled and stuffed with fresh oregano and feta cheese.

title: A Rolls-Royce With Your House?
description: Does the house go with the Rolls-Royce, or does the Rolls-Royce go with the house?

title: The Stuff of Great Grilled Flatbreads
description: A grilled flatbread is an excellent thing. But a grilled stuffed flatbread is even better.

title: Outside Lisbon, a Verdant World of Castles and Palaces
description: No matter how well it begins or ends, every fairy tale has a villain. In my storybook adventure in Sintra, a Portuguese town about 20 miles west of Lisbon, it was the hands of the clock. Roaming the pristine grounds of castles high in the hills, I wished that time would stand still.

title: On an Island Hunt for Pieces of My History
description: We had been in the lobby of our hotel in Oranjestad, Arubas capital, for only a few minutes when the Dutch territorys Arcadian One Happy Island front was shattered by a desk clerk whose petulance hit me like a left hook straight to the temple. As she delivered the rules and regulations like a stern lecture, scolding my daughter and me for the simple offense of standing before her, my mind drifted back home to New York City. There I was, at Mendez Boxing gym, and there she was, standing in place of my favorite heavy bag.

title: A One-Shake, Two-Straws Kind of Place
description: Most summer afternoons at Eggers Ice Cream Parlor on Staten Islands north shore unfold in the same way. Spoons clank against ice cream bowls, customers chat about birthday parties and coming T-ball games, and the heady scent of hot fudge perfumes the place. In a city of $7 milkshakes and extravagant flavors like black sesame seaweed or tarragon pink pepper, Eggers remains a great beacon of the classic cone.

title: Taking a Spin: How Democrats Could Keep Their Majority
description: Democrats hold on to the Senate by the skin of their teeth by winning Arkansas in this weeks spin of Leos Senate wheels. Every week we generate random election scenarios based on the probabilities from the Upshots Senate elections forecasting model.

title: A Food Scene Grows in Sioux Falls, S.D.
description: A city where chain restaurants rule when it comes to going out, Sioux Falls, S.D., has never been known for impressive dining. The cold winters and the three-tiered waterfall that inspired its name, yes, but not the food. Now, thats finally changing: In recent years, locals as well as transplants have opened noteworthy restaurants, cafes and bakeries that are giving this Midwest metropolis of about 166,000 a newfound culinary fame.

title: Portraits of Loved Ones, in Three Galleries on Three Continents
description: True to its name, The Ones We Love is an exhibition, website and book devoted to images shot by international photographers of their loved ones. Curated by the Des Moines, Iowa-based photographer Lindley Warren, who also edited the book, the show opens this week in three art galleries on three continents. Ive always been the type of person who is more interested in whats underneath the surface, says Warren, 26. Its about a deeper sense of connection.

title: When the Beach Is a Long, Long Trip
description: Looking for a fashionable way to cool down this August? These four beauty products may help you beat the heat.

title: Tracking Alibabas Buying Spree
description: With the disclosure of accounting irregularities at the Alibaba Pictures Group  formerly known as the ChinaVision Media Group  potential investors may now wonder whether the company has done thorough due diligence in its race to snap up what it deems as strategic assets.

title: Checking Accounts for Marijuana Businesses
description: Marijuana entrepreneurs in states that have legalized the drug for either medical or recreational purposes have had trouble finding banking partners. Because marijuana remains an illegal substance under federal law, few financial firms have been willing to provide checking accounts and other services to those growing, processing and selling the drug.Previously it was difficult to know the exact scope of this problem. But earlier this week a federal official involved in policing financial crimes offered some details: just 105 institutions in more than one-third of states are engaged in banking relationships with marijuana related businesses, Jennifer Shasky Calvery, the director of the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, said in a speech. (In addition to Colorados and Washingtons policies allowing recreational use, 35 states have legalized some form of marijuana consumption for medical purposes.) Ms. Calvery also said that financial firms had made 475 filings alerting regulators to the fact that they had terminated relationships with marijuana businesses as of Aug. 8 in order to maintain an effective anti-money laundering compliance program.

title: Answering a Question About a Tale of Human Sacrifice to a Tree
description: Q. What can you tell me about a New York newspaper hoax involving a man-eating tree?

title: Nigel Farage Picks District to Make Run for British Parliament
description: LONDON  Nigel Farage, leader of Britains populist U.K. Independence Party, on Friday confirmed plans to run for a seat in Parliament in next years general election, identifying Thanet South, in the south of England, as the constituency he hopes to represent.

title: An Eclectic Lineup for the Queer New York International Arts Festival
description: Among the highlights of the 2014 Queer New York International Arts Festival are the United States premieres of Marissa Perels More Than Just a Piece of Sky, a deconstruction of the Isaac Bashevis Singer story Yentl; and the Croatian experimental theater director Branko Brezovecs Confusions, a work based on Robert Musils 1906 novel, The Confusions of Young Trless.

title: A Multimillion-Dollar Estate, for Sale by Owner
description: BOB FISHER had an idea that seemed as if it would either work out brilliantly or fail miserably: He was going to sell his 50-acre estate on a mountaintop in North Carolina by himself, and he was going to do it in a few months.

title: Dominique Atchison Singing in Church
description: The young minister mixes her preaching with singing at the Brown Memorial Baptist Church in Brooklyn.

title: Art Market | The Not It Girl
description: At her gallery, Reena Spaulings Fine Art, the painter and performer Emily Sundblad is reviving the artistic spirit of downtown New York through creative collaboration  and a resistance to the cult of self-promotion.

title: At This Academy, the Curriculum Is Garbage
description: Rose-gold light was falling onto Jamaica Bay and sea gulls passed overhead on another beautiful morning at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, a far reach of New York City mostly devoid of New Yorkers and cars.

title: Coke Finds Right Formula in Monster Deal
description: Coca-Cola, the $180 billion soda giant, is paying $2.2 billion for 17 percent of Monster Beverage, a maker of trendy energy drinks. It goes to show how even a global powerhouse with significant distribution and marketing advantages can struggle to keep ahead of upstart rivals. At least Coke got the deal formula right.

title: Clip: Abuse of Weakness
description: A scene from Catherine Breillats film.

title: Mapping Migration in the United States
description: On Thursday, we published a series of interactive charts showing how Americans have moved between states since 1900. The charts show striking patterns for many states: You can trace the rise of migrant and immigrant populations all along the Southwest, particularly in Texas and Arizona; the influx of New Yorkers and other Northeasterners into Florida starting in the 1970s; and the growth in the Southern share of the Illinois population during the Great Migration.

title: Driven | 2015 Cadillac Escalade ESV
description: Because A-listers dont roll in a Suburban.

title: Sorry, Fans. Discovery Has Jumped the Shark Week.
description: Shark Week is an annual, weeklong block of programming that airs on the Discovery Channel  and as the name suggests, its all about the oceans toothiest predators. It was first broadcast in July 1988, and since then, has become a veritable network cash cow.

title: Oxford Dictionary Recognizes: YOLO, Amazeballs and Hot Mess
description: The Oxford Dictionaries will include YOLO  an acronym for you only live once, popularized by Drake in his 2011 song, The Motto  in the quarterly update of its online dictionary, released this week. And though the list is heavy with science and technology terms  clickbait, listicle and pharmacovigilance (monitoring drugs after they are approved for use)  several entries are arguably arts-related.

title: Together on the Road to Divorce
description: Valerie and Clark Tates wedding took place in 2000, and although they unhitched in 2007, they remain legally married, share a home and are raising their son, Jonah, together. Both have other romantic relationships. With their rabbi, they are preparing for a Jewish divorce in the fall that they view as a spiritual divorce. Both acknowledge a legally binding divorce may be ahead.

title: Amazon, Its Friends and Critics
description: The exact nature of the conflict between Amazon and Hachette is somewhat veiled. The parties confirm that it is over e-book prices, and Amazon obviously wants more money from the sale of e-books than Hachette is willing to give. But Hachette has been circumspect, while Amazon has been forceful if not always accurate.

title: Video: A New Cadillac Escalade, Still Large and in Charge
description: Cars and S.U.V.s are not solely about transportation. If that were the case, wed all be driving old Honda Civics and Ford Explorers. People want to drive their personalities, and because of that, the Cadillac Escalade looms large in pop culture. And if merely big isnt big enough, Cadillac offers the ESV model that I recently tested, with a wheelbase 14 inches longer than the standard models.

title: Bring Friends, Bring Checkbooks, Bring Both
description: The Bundler

title: I Want to Be a Producer (Me, Too!)
description: They couldnt get to the stage fast enough.

title: A Year After Drug Deaths, the Electric Zoo Music Festival Tries Again
description: With three weeks left until thousands of raver babies dressed in neon spandex descend on Electric Zoo, New Yorks largest dance music festival, Mike Bindra and Laura de Palma were running through their checklists in a state of high anxiety. The load-in for their giant show was about to begin. In a few days time, six performance stages  the biggest serving 30,000 fans  would spring up in a field on Randalls Island. Crates of pyrotechnics, trucks of LED screens and a stadiums worth of subwoofers would soon be coming in.

title: For Tiina Laakkonen and the Elder Statesman, Blue Is the Warmest Color
description: As anyone familiar with her styling work, her Amagansett, N.Y.,boutique, Tiina, or hernearby home already knows, Tiina Laakkonen really, really loves indigo. Blue is my favorite color and indigo is the most natural, alive version of it, she says. I used to live in black clothes when I lived in New York, but they seem too hard in both the light and the life out East.

title: So Youd Like to Invest in Broadway?
description: Broadway shows often rely on dozens of investors to finance their costly budgets. A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder, for example, had 130 investors providing between $25,000 and $850,000 for a total capitalization of $7.5 million.

title: Super Moonshine: Where Astronomy Meets Alcohol
description: This week, the full moon hung the lowest, brightest and largest it will all year, looming 14 percent closer to Earth and 30 percent brighter than other full moons, according to NASA.

title: Barbershop Goes Bollywood
description: When a genial, appealing quartet of old-timers called Benchmark made it to the finals of the 2011 season of Australias Got Talent, the groups tenor told viewers that even though they hadnt won, they had achieved their goal: demonstrating that singing a cappella music in the barbershop style is cool.

title: A Bit More City on City Island
description: New condo developments on City Island, which hugs the eastern edge of the Bronx, arent proposed often, and residents of this 230-acre island have a history of being tough to please.

title: Surveillance Footage of Ferguson Robbery
description: The Ferguson, Mo., police released surveillance camera video that officials said showed the convenience store robbery shortly before the shooting of Michael Brown.

title: The Student Taught, the Teacher Learned
description: With his hair, eyebrows and goatee dyed a flaming red, Jason Backe was hard to miss. But it wasnt his looks that first caught Ted Gibsons attention back in 1994. Nor was it Mr. Backes easy laugh or impish charm, or that Mr. Backe, a student at the time at the Horst Education Center, a beauty school in Minneapolis, had twice walked out on the Highly Textured Hair class Mr. Gibson was teaching.

title: In Idaho, Tracing What Remains After the Flames
description: As we neared Stanley, Idaho, a hamlet carved by creeks and framed by mountains with spiky peaks that reminded me of a punk rockers hair, the landscape surrounding the winding highway on which wed climbed 7,000 feet gave way from rugged canyon to flat expanse of grass speckled by lodgepole pine and aspen. We were on the northern edges of the Sawtooth National Recreation Area, three hours from Boise, when scars from an old fire came into view.

title: Under Cover: The Dark Shadows of Debt Collection
description: To illustrate Jake Halperns deep dive into the shadowy underworld of debt collection for the Aug. 17 cover, the magazine turned to Francesco Francavilla, an artist based in Atlanta who has illustrated a range of comic books, including Guardians of the Galaxy for Marvel Comics and Batman for DC Comics. He recently discussed the steps he took to bring the seedy world of debt collection into full color.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Pebble, Pebble Everywhere
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Weekend Reading: Derivatives, Mortgages and Repo Markets in 2014 or 2008?
description: A spotlight on derivatives, risky mortgages and repo markets  practices all linked to the 2008 financial crisis  gave DealBook a certain Groundhog Day quality this week.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: For a Raw Voice, the Balm of Serendipity
description: The first record Benjamin Booker ever bought was Elephant by the White Stripes, which came out when he was in eighth grade. When I was 13 it was, like, the coolest, he recalled. Now 25, Mr. Booker, the singer-guitarist, was recently plucked to be the opening act on Jack Whites current tour, though he had only written 12 songs in his entire life. Its just part of the dizzying whirlwind thats enveloped Mr. Booker this summer  from TV appearances with David Letterman and Conan OBrien to being named one of the most refreshing rock acts at Lollapalooza by Rolling Stone  ahead of the release of his self-titled debut album, due out Tuesday on ATO Records.

title: Those Manly Scowls of Summer
description: Its been a grim summer. Especially for men, mostly middle-aged white ones.

title: In the Air | Gargantuan Grandeur
description: In our video, Charlotte di Carcaci discusses the cultural lineage of the exaggerated shapes that are prevalent in todays fashion.

title: Educators in Their Virtuoso Years
description: Playing the piano beautifully is a demanding artistic endeavor. But to have a career as a touring pianist takes an extra measure of mental, emotional and physical stamina. The great Arthur Rubinstein was the model of an artist who thrived on the concert stage. He simply loved playing for people and did it splendidly right through his 80s. Not so Vladimir Horowitz, an astounding pianist who gave many phenomenal performances but was a nervous type who agonized about playing concerts, even in the early years, when he was the most dazzlingly brilliant young virtuoso of the day.

title: Its Alive
description: G.M. engineers cobbled together a Corvette prototype in 1968, which has since been cloned in a Michigan restoration shop.

title: To Preserve and Protect
description: LEBANON, N.J.  A 1922 Packard Twin Six with mottled gray paint and tattered upholstery sat forlornly in the driveway of Steve Babinskys shop, a garden hose clamped to its radiator feed and brown water pouring from its V12 engine block. It seemed impossible that in just two weeks this car would be driving onto the 18th fairway of the Pebble Beach Golf Links, sharing the manicured lawn with the scrubbed and waxed elite of the collector car world.

title: First, Do No Harm
description: The addition of the preservation class at Pebble Beach has aided the trend of unrestored classics.

title: Tennis Stars Touch Down in the Midwest, and They Crave Applebees
description: MASON, Ohio  Tennis players are used to hopping among some of the worlds most exciting cities, but here during the Western & Southern Open, they find a different sort of sizzle.

title: Turning Bounty Into a Bespoke Meal
description: Should we eat this next? asked my dining companion as he gestured toward the wildflower bouquet on our table at Blue Hill at Stone Barns. It wasnt a surreal question. We had already had a serving of weeds that ranged from pleasantly bitter to intensely sweet, a drink made with nasturtium, a pot of pea shoots brought to the table with scissors and instructions to cut the greens and drag them through an accompanying tarragon pesto.

title: Utility With a Dash of Derring-Do
description: TESTED2014 Lexus RX 350 F Sport

title: Coupe Earns Laurels While Losing Wreath
description: If Yoda were a luxury-car analyst, he would advise and soothe Cadillac with a Jedi epigram: Patience you must have.

title: 2015 Cadillac ATS Coupe
description: Cadillac follows up its terrific ATS sedan with a sporty coupe version that keeps the party going.

title: Rummaging in the Marquee Dustbin
description: Not Tonight, Josephine. It Had to Be Jew. Everybody Comes to Ricks. All three count among the most notable American films of all time. Dont sound familiar? Thats because in the end their titles became Some Like It Hot,""Annie Hall and Casablanca, respectively. Changing a film title, be it at the behest of a studio chief or because of audience feedback at screenings, is an enduring Hollywood tradition that came to the fore this summer, when these releases shed their original names:

title: Apple to Add Data Storage in China and Prohibit Two Chemicals
description: Apple this week made two major changes to its operations in China. The company said it had for the first time begun storing user data on servers in mainland China. It also barred the use of two potentially harmful chemicals that some factory workers had handled during assembly of iPhones and iPads.

title: Old Friends Make Good Marriages
description: On a recent afternoon, the actors John Lithgow, 68, and Alfred Molina, 61, were sitting side by side in spread-collar shirts, munching on club sandwiches in a private meeting room at the Loews Regency Hotel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Both men live in Los Angeles, but Mr. Lithgow was in New York playing the title role in King Lear at Shakespeare in the Park, and Mr. Molina had caught Mr. Lithgow onstage the night before.

title: Emmys 2014: What Was the Best Animated Program?
description: In advance of the Emmy Awards on Aug. 25, were asking you to tell us who deserved their nominations and who should have been nominated. Next up is animated program. Take a look at this alternative list  its made up of the actual nominees, popular and critical favorites who werent nominated, and my own choices. Cast your votes in the comments, and let us know whos still been left out.

title: Patrol Officer on Ferguson Standoff
description: Capt. Ronald S. Johnson of the Missouri Highway Patrol, who is heading the security efforts in Ferguson, Mo., said in a news conference that the standoff between protesters and the police had eased.

title: Skewers for a Party
description: You put something edible on a stick, add something to improve the flavor and hold it over a fire. Thats cooking, on a primordial level.

title: Resisting Nazis, He Saw Need for Israel. Now He Is Its Critic.
description: THE HAGUE  In 1943, Henk Zanoli took a dangerous train trip, slipping past Nazi guards and checkpoints to smuggle a Jewish boy from Amsterdam to the Dutch village of Eemnes. There, the Zanoli family, already under suspicion for resisting the Nazi occupation, hid the boy in their home for two years. The boy would be the only member of his family to survive the Holocaust.

title: Big Ticket | Sky-High Park Views for $32.5 Million
description: A view-grabbing condo at One57, the strategically placed 90-story spike of blue glass designed for the Extell Development Company by Atelier Christian de Portzamparc, the French architect, sold for $32,571,705.40 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: A Blast While It Lasted, Unique Corvette Earns an Encore
description: DETROIT  The Big Three horsepower race was at full gallop when a one-of-a-kind 1968 Corvette bolted from the starting line of a temporary dragstrip at the General Motors proving ground in Milford, Mich., accelerating with a fury that would have many of todays supercars inhaling its exhaust fumes.

title: Award Returned With Great Sorrow
description: In a letter to the Israeli ambassador to the Netherlands, Henk Zanoli returned his medal as one of the Righteous Among the Nations.

title: Pole Dancing, on the Move
description: Subway time is precious  theres nothing like summer reading in meat-locker air-conditioning, and currently Im deep into The Luminaries  but I raise my eyes for two words: Showtime, showtime!

title: Doll Flesh and Art Fetish
description: Ah, late August, when an art lovers heart turns to ... fetish?

title: A Smorgasbord of Rarefied Sounds
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival concludes with performances of Mozarts powerful Requiem at the end of the week. Meanwhile, the adventurous new-music arm of the festival presents the final two concerts by its artists in residence, the International Contemporary Ensemble, inside the hushed elegance of the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory on Tuesday and Thursday.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Sightlines
description: Audiences at this years Downtown Dance Festival can behold panoramas. For the first time since its inception in 1982, the festival, which opens on Sunday, will take place in Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Lower Manhattan, with views of New York Harbor. And whats staged will provide a broad vista of dance.

title: Before the Vice, the Bonbon
description: Paul Thomas Andersons take on Thomas Pynchons noirish novel Inherent Vice is one of the New York Film Festivals most anticipated movies. But summers end seems right for tasting an Anderson work of an entirely different flavor: his 2002 romantic bonbon, Punch-Drunk Love, at the Nitehawk Cinema next Saturday.

title: Time to Focus on a Jazz Stalwart
description: Being great within a tradition for a long time can lead to being overlooked, and the jazz pianist George Cables has some experience with that. Mr. Cables, Brooklyn-born, now 69, was a first-call jazz sideman in the 70s and 80s, with groups led by Art Blakey, Woody Shaw, Joe Henderson and Art Pepper, among others; hes long been a presence, though not often a high-visibility one. This year he made a deeply beautiful record as a leader, Icons and Influences (HighNote), which recognizes some old masters and some old friends, including Mulgrew Miller and Cedar Walton, who both died last year. But it also makes a case for Mr. Cables himself as a significant leader and arranger of the jazz trio. Time to focus on him. He made a memorable live record at the Village Vanguard as Peppers pianist in 1977; from Tuesday to Sunday hell work at that club as a leader, with the bassist Essiet Okon Essiet and the drummer Victor Lewis. (178 Seventh Avenue South, West Village; villagevanguard.com.)

title: Young Masters of Culinary Sagesse
description: Making an impression in the cooking-show universe is close to impossible these days, with a seemingly endless number of series and chefs. But a show that stands out through sheer charm returns on Sunday night at 8 on the Food Network. Its Rachael vs. Guy: Kids Cook-Off, and it looks, sounds and presumably smells and tastes a lot like many other kitchen competition shows, but the contestants are all 12 or younger.

title: In Their Own Words
description: Members of the millennial generation talk about their challenges.

title: Should We Teach Plato in Gym Class?
description: IF youve seen Woody Allens Annie Hall, youll remember Alvy Singers line about physical education: Those who cant do, teach. And those who cant teach, teach gym.

title: A Civilized Approach
description: Looking for a way to cross the street without getting hit by anything from a truck to a skateboard? The aerial bridge is just the answer.

title: Pictures of the Day: Liberia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Liberia, Ukraine, India and Gaza.

title: Playing the Numbers in Digital Dating
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  HERE are some ways to use Tinder: Swipe right on everyone; swipe left on everyone; screenshot guys who pose with guns or on treadmill desks in their profile photos and make a collection to laugh at with your friends at dinner; sit uncomfortably at a cocktail gathering when a man announces to the group that he saw your profile and was torn over which way to swipe. You can also use it to message people and then, when they get filthy or bizarre right away, post those conversations on Twitter for everyones entertainment.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: The Real Song of the Summer
description: BOSTON  IN the American mind, summer is a time of long drives to off-the-beaten-path places, stretches of doing nothing at the pool or the beach, or even just skipping out of work a couple of hours early. It also allows for more listening  car windows that would be rolled up to protect against frigid weather are cracked, the music playing on dashboard radios or from phones connected to speakers turned up just loud enough to float into the street.

title: Muscadet Just Doesnt Get Its Due
description: GORGES, France  The gently rolling green hills paint a picture of pastoral simplicity here in Muscadet country, about 15 miles southeast of the city of Nantes, near to where the Loire empties into the Atlantic. The placid surface belies the complex clash of soils underneath, where multiple forms of granite, clay, schist and metamorphic descendants of granite (like gneiss and orthogneiss) turn most discussions with grape growers into detailed geology lessons.

title: A New Dive Center in Petit St. Vincent
description: Among a series of environmentally inspired changes, the private Caribbean island resort of Petit St. Vincent plans to add a dive center run by Jean-Michel Cousteau, son of the underwater explorer Jacques-Yves Cousteau, in November.

title: Photos of the Day: Liberia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Liberia, Ukraine, India and Gaza City.

title: A Former Top SAC Capital Trader Names New Hedge Fund
description: Settling on a name for a hedge fund is often a very personal decision for the manager who runs it.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Generation Nice
description: Suddenly, as you may have noticed, millennials are everywhere. Not that this group of people born after 1980 and before 2000  a giant cohort now estimated to number at least 80 million Americans, more than the baby boom generation  was ever invisible. Whats changed is their status. Coddled and helicoptered, catered to by 24-hour TV cable networks, fussed over by marketers and college recruiters, dissected by psychologists, demographers and trend-spotters, the millennial generation has come fully into its own. The word millennial, whether as noun or adjective, has monopolized the nonstop cultural conversation, invariably freighted with zeitgeisty import.

title: Theres No Off in This Season
description: When my daughters were young, they had a book we all loved called Jump into January. Every month was illustrated with a search-and-find painting filled with seasonal items. Augusts was Sail into August / come along with me / That sand is soft, the sea is warm / What can you see? Items included a sailboat, shovel, crab, hammock, surfboard and sand castle.

title: Embracing Fantasy to Live the Dream
description: In 2010 an 18-year-old unknown named Porter Robinson began turning heads on the electronic dance scene for his spastic, high-octane production. Now Mr. Robinson is a star of electronic dance music, or E.D.M., but the sounds that appear on his first full-length album, Worlds (Astralwerks), released on Tuesday, would no doubt be puzzling to many of his fist-pumping boosters. After several years of performing at bacchanalian festivals like Ultra and Electric Daisy Carnival, Mr. Robinson has rejected that mind-set and the head rush of adrenaline that currently dominates the scene. On Worlds, he has opted instead for washes of gorgeous textures, contemplative storytelling and remarkably sharp melodies.

title: Name That Tune, and Hell Tell a Story
description: It was a little past 9 on Tuesday night, and a dozen or so show-tune-loving patrons were seated around the piano at Maries Crisis, the Greenwich Village bar, some looking as if they might already be on their second or third drink.

title: Taking City Moves From the Street to the Lawn
description: James Colter, who long ago earned the sobriquet Cricket, is an amazing dancer. A master of several styles of hip-hop, he is supple and explosive. But when he appeared on Wednesday evening at Wave Hill, the public garden in the Bronx, sparks flew, yet nothing caught fire. That was true not only of his segment, but also of the contributions by NiJa Whitson Adebanjo and Larry Keigwin, all part of Dancing Through the Bronx, a series of site-specific performances presented by Dancing in the Streets.

title: Al Gore Sues Al Jazeera Over TV Deal
description: Former Vice President Al Gore has filed a lawsuit against the Middle Eastern media group Al Jazeera, accusing it of fraud and breach of contract in its $500 million purchase of Mr. Gores Current TV cable channel.

title: Guests: Meet My Relatives (They Live Here, Too)
description: You told them about us, didnt you? I asked my husband, Daniel, as we watched our dinner guests get out of their car in the driveway.

title: If That NPR Guy Moved to Israel and Knew Hebrew ...
description: TEL AVIV  When Mishy Harman, a young Jerusalem native, decided to take a 13,000-mile road trip around the United States a few years ago, a friend offered him hundreds of downloaded episodes of a beloved podcast to help pass the time.

title: A Search for Reconciliation From the Mideast to America
description: The main purpose of DanceMotion USA, a cultural diplomacy program run by the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the State Department, is to send American troupes abroad. Yet the program also benefits New Yorkers directly by having an American company bring back a foreign one for a free, collaborative performance here. These visits have proven illuminating, even if the arranged artistic alliances havent always gelled.

title: A Contemporary Riddle for Champions of the Harp
description: Anyone curious to hear Smetanas Vltava arranged for harp need have looked no further than Lincoln Centers Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Thursday night.

title: 15th World Youth Teams Championships
description: ISTANBUL  The 15th World Youth Teams Championships began here on Thursday and will end next Saturday. Fifty-eight teams from the six main continents are competing.

title: All About Zero
description: The VoxEU servers were briefly overwhelmed by hits after I linked to their new ebook on secular stagnation, but you should be able to download it now. And I guess I should say a few more words about why it matters so much.

title: Women Beyond the Veil in Mali
description: Katie Orlinsky traveled throughout northern Mali for almost a month, speaking with women who had lived under Shariah law imposed by Islamic radicals.

title: First Justice Department Memo on Killing Anwar Al-Awlaki
description: The Obama administration on Aug. 15, 2014, released the first Justice Department Office of Legal Counsel memo on killing Anwar Al Awlaki, an American citizen deemed a terrorist, without a trial. The once-secret February 2010 memo would later be replaced by a lengthier version signed in July 2010. Both memos were made public, in redacted form, following Freedom of Information Act lawsuits by the New York Times and the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Friday Night Music: Lucius Does Buddy Holly
description: I love live concerts, and see Lucius whenever I get a chance. But let us also praise the internet for making moments like this  a few fine musicians who love what they do, doing their thing in a tiny space somewhere backstage  available to the rest of us.

title: Heading Off to College? Time to Think About Banking Needs
description: IF youre a student heading off to college for the first time, you have a lot of options for handling your money these days. It makes sense to think about it before you arrive on campus and find yourself swept up in the back-to-school whirlwind.

title: Lauren Bacall Remembered, Kate Moss Strikes It Rich and Barneys Pays Up
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Supervalu Discloses a Data Breach
description: Supervalu, a food retailer based in Minnesota, said on Thursday that its cash register system had been breached by hackers, possibly resulting in the theft of credit and debit card information from its supermarkets and liquor stores, as well as from an array of stores it sold last year.

title: A Contrast of Kings: Ubiquitous and Rare
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  King Lear and King John reside at opposite ends of the Shakespeare canon. One is at the pinnacle, considered by many his greatest masterwork and produced about as frequently as any of his plays. The other scuttles around furtively somewhere far beneath, poking its oddly shaped head up for public consideration only rarely. (I probably dont need to tell you which is which.)

title: Meredith Monk: Tune Body and Voice. Feed the Tortoise.
description: Meredith Monk, the composer, singer, director, choreographer, Buddhist practitioner and inveterate boundary pusher, will celebrate the 50th anniversary of her career this fall with performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Carnegie Hall. A taste of whats to come is offered on Aug. 23 at Guild Hall in East Hampton, Long Island, where she will perform with her Grammy-nominated Vocal Ensemble. When Ms. Monk, 71, moved into her West Broadway loft 42 years ago, visitors had to call from a pay phone, after which she would toss down a sock with a key in it. These days she has a buzzer and an elevator.

title: Revisiting the Nightmares of World War I
description: LONDON  A moonscape of craters, mud and shattered stumps fills a wall-sized video screen; you can hear shrieking shells and shattering blasts; an enormous British howitzer, meant to pulverize the enemys defenses, points toward the fields. The only thing missing in this gallery, devoted to the Battle of the Somme at the Imperial War Museum here, is the ability to conceive of 20,000 British dead and 37,000 wounded or missing in the first day of fighting, and more than a million casualties over all during five months.

title: New Vaccine Shows Promise Against Mosquito-Borne Virus
description: A new vaccine in its first human trials may offer protection against the chikungunya virus, a mosquito-borne infection that causes fever and severe joint pain, researchers reported Thursday in The Lancet.

title: A Song Born When Pain Is Still Fresh
description: In 1970, it took a few weeks for Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young to record and release the song Ohio in response to the shooting of unarmed college students at Kent State University.

title: The Summer Delights of Lobster Rolls on Long Island
description: SOUTHOLD  On a recent sunny afternoon at the Southold Fish Market and Seafood Takeout, Silvia Sherwin, 34, recalled the lobster pots her father would submerge in Long Island Sound just in front of their summer home in Greenport. Our parents would have to bribe us to eat the lobsters, said Ms. Sherwin, laughing, as she sat at one of the outdoor picnic tables here.

title: Rival Bidders Ask Chiquita Shareholders to Reject Fyffes Deal
description: An unlikely fight is about to break out over, of all things, bananas.

title: Boldly Seasoned Dishes in a Festive Atmosphere
description: In summer, I think of skirt steaks. My mother, not known for her talent in the kitchen, tossed these on a very hot grill, and when the outside was charred and the inside was just shy of raw, she removed the steaks, sliced them and inserted the pieces into the pillow-soft onion rolls for which our local bakery was famous. At least on summer weekends, we ate well.

title: Some Russian Aid Trucks Are Nearly Empty, Reporters Find
description: As the fighting intensifies in eastern Ukraine, and officials in Kiev and Moscow continue to trade claims about the movement of Russian armored vehicles close to or across the border between the two countries, reporters discovered on Friday that several of the white trucks in what Russia has described as a humanitarian aid convoy are nearly empty, which has only deepened the mystery about the Kremlins intentions for the mission.

title: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas Is Indicted on Charge of Abuse of Power
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A grand jury indicted Gov. Rick Perry on two felony counts on Friday, charging that he abused his power last year when he tried to pressure the district attorney here, a Democrat, to step down by threatening to cut off state financing to her office.

title: Shake Shack Owner Weighs an I.P.O.
description: In a little over a decade, Shake Shack has exploded from a simple hot dog stand in a New York City park to a global fast-food empire on three continents.

title: 3 Connecticut Farms Serving Homemade Ice Cream
description: No summer should be considered complete without a trip to a local farm. Beyond the sight of crops in bloom and livestock grazing in pastures, the pleasure of a visit to the countryside this time of year is heightened by stops at dairy operations that produce their own ice cream  and let visitors have a scoop or two. Here are three farms among the many across the state that offer a range of homemade ice creams.

title: Failure, Writings Constant Companion
description: Failure in writing is not like failure in business, where you lose money and have to fire everyone and remortgage your house. When youre a writer, most of the time, people dont depend on you to succeed. Although you may starve if your books dont sell, or your agent might yell at you for producing something that three people will read, failure in writing is more of an intimately crushing day-to-day thing. O.K., minute-to-minute. Measured against your ideal of yourself.

title: Evening Hours | Throwback Party
description: Dances, games and music from an earlier time.

title: Your Hijab Fashion on Instagram
description: As noted by Hannah Seligson in an article in this weeks Sunday Styles, a new generation of Muslim women are taking to social media to show off their hijab fashion and stylish examples of modest dressing.

title: A Makeover for the Hijab, via Instagram
description: A few years ago, AsciaFarraj tracked the fashion blogosphere with frustration. As a Muslim woman who wears a head scarf, known as a hijab, she rarely saw someone who looked like her. A fashion enthusiast from a conservative culture, she decided one answer was to create a blog of her own.

title: Taking In the History of New London, a City Shaped by the Sea
description: In May, ground was broken on the New London waterfront for the long-awaited National Coast Guard Museum. Set to open in 2017, the sprawling space will be the first national museum dedicated to the United States Coast Guard.

title: A Nation Shocked by Ferguson, Mo.
description: To the Editor:

title: One Might Kill for a Play Like That
description: If a gun hangs on the wall in the first act, it should be fired by the end of the play, according to a well-known theatrical rule often attributed to Anton Chekhov.

title: Bill Cunningham | Promenade in Nahant
description: The beautiful and rustic nature of Nahant, Mass., welcomed the vintage customs of the Nahant Vintage Dance participants.

title: Alec Baldwin Tells of a Crime That He Isnt Accused Of
description: In recent history, when the cops are called to 28 East 10th Street, Alec Baldwin explained in an interview on Friday, you could likely guess its about one particular person.

title: Philadelphia Schools to Open on Time Amid Millions in Budget Cuts
description: After having warned that schools might not open on time in Philadelphia, Superintendent William R. Hite Jr. said Friday that a series of temporary spending cuts would help administrators to close an $81 million budget deficit and that classes would start as scheduled next month.

title: Detectives Are Now Calling Gotcha Far From the Scene of the Theft
description: The police call them gym creepers, thieves who break into lockers while the unsuspecting victims are working out.

title: A Gold Mine Where Fools Rush In
description: An old play that has the words rarely produced appended to its title is doubly challenging for any director who chooses to take it on. First, it is rarely produced for a reason: Its deficient in some way, or it simply didnt age well. Second, the director has few prior interpretations to use as a barometer.

title: Witness in War Crimes Court Tallies Cost of a Decade in Hiding
description: THE HAGUE  SHE chose the anonymity of a railroad station to talk about the unbearable weight of leading a double life.

title: Bill Cunningham | Nature Rules
description: After last Sundays festivities at Nahant Victorian Dance Weekend in Nahant, Mass., guests promenaded to Lodge Park on East Point, the highest point of the tied island, in open fields with 360-degree ocean views and Queen Annes lace five feet tall, in their turn-of-the-century finest. The site was the former Nahant Hotel, where wealthy Bostonians vacationed before the Civil War. It burned down in 1860, and Newport, R.I., became the summer destination of choice.

title: Quicker Ways to Digitize Old Photographs
description: Q. Flatbed scanners are good but can be slow and bulky. Are there any such things as photo scanners with automatic feeders, or a faster way to scan many prints without paying someone else to do it?

title: Israel Offered Cuomo a New Stage and a Rehearsal for a Bigger Role
description: JERUSALEM  At times, he seemed like a tour guide leading a study-abroad trip. At others, he was afforded all the trappings of a visiting head of state.

title: Iraqs Last Chance
description: THE country is in your hands, whispered Iraqs president, Fuad Masum, on Aug. 11 as he charged the newly designated prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, with forming a cabinet. May God help you, another lawmaker added. Indeed, after last weeks sidelining of the countrys long-serving prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, Mr. Abadi will need all the divine intervention he can get if Iraq is to be spared a descent into all-out civil war.

title: The Confederate Torpedo
description: One of the great points of debate among Confederate leaders during the Civil War was the use of torpedoes  what today we call mines  against Northern military naval forces, merchants and civilians. President Jefferson Davis, who thought they were unethical and cowardly weapons, was opposed to using them in almost every context. But many of his advisers felt otherwise, and as the Confederate war effort grew more dire in 1864, their calls became louder.

title: Taking Up Arms Where Birds Feast on Buffet of Salmon
description: ASTORIA, Ore.  The salmon here in the Columbia River, nearly driven to extinction by hydroelectric dams a quarter century ago, have been increasing in number  a fact not lost on the birds that like to eat them. These now flock by the thousands each spring to the rivers mouth, where the birds have their young, and gorge at leisure.

title: Scrutiny Circles Track at Del Mar
description: DEL MAR, Calif.  The summer season has been a turbulent one at Del Mar. The track has enjoyed a renaissance in recent years, its summer postrace concert series drawing a younger, more party-hearty crowd  a much-desired demographic for an industry that has been plagued by drug scandals and flagging interest. In June, Del Mar was awarded the 2017 Breeders Cup, the first time it will host the prestigious event.

title: A Jewish Matchmaker Whose Hand Led Hundreds Down the Aisle
description: PITTSBURGH  When I walked into Tova Weinbergs large house here in the Squirrel Hill neighborhood of Pittsburgh, she looked me up and down and asked, Are you Jewish? I told her I was. Are you married? Yes, I said.

title: For Its New Shows, Amazon Adds Art to Its Data
description: LOS ANGELES  Joe Lewis, a television executive at Amazon, lies on his stomach on a rumpled bed. Jill Soloway, the Emmy-nominated writer and director, sits next to him, stroking the back of his head. The two stare at a pair of monitors, watching the filming of a scene in the next room from their new dark comedy about a family in which the father comes out as transgender.

title: Antibiotics on Farms
description: To the Editor:

title: Money for Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Shelter From Rain and, Possibly, Finding Love
description: Most of the time rain is a minor but undeniable annoyance, especially in New York, where it drips from deli awnings, slicks subways floors and chases cabs away. But every now and then, the rain  as in this weeks brief, torrential downpour  leads to something unexpected, like romance. The following poems about rain and love were found this week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

title: Celebrity Deaths in Threes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Return the Games to Athens
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Suspects Morocco Allowed a Brief Flood of Migrants
description: TARIFA, Spain  In just two days this week, the Spanish authorities intercepted as many migrants trying to slip into the country by sea from Morocco as they had in all of last year, the Spanish Red Cross said.

title: Climate and Population
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Would Prefer to See Overhauled Offense Develop Faster
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the Giants last preseason game, the starting offense picked up one first down. In two preseason games, Eli Manning has completed six passes for 43 yards. The best receiver, Victor Cruz, does not have a catch. No starting wide receiver has more than one reception.

title: Reaction to News Conferences in Ferguson
description: Residents of Ferguson, Mo., expressed frustration and anger after officials released the name of the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager.

title: The Draw of the New City-States
description: London is in the midst of a boom so giddy it has parted company with the rest of Britain. Construction is everywhere, from the new towers of the City of London (a global financial center larger than Wall Street) to the mansions of Kensington (where the worlds superwealthy burrow below ground to accommodate staff quarters and the de rigueur swimming pool) to ever-hipper eastern districts like Hoxton (sought after by the ordinary mortals driven from the center).

title: Arthur G. Cohen, Real Estate Developer, Is Dead at 84
description: Arthur G. Cohen, who began a roller-coaster real estate career with a $25,000 investment in tract housing on Long Island before creating the nations largest publicly held real estate company, teaming up with tycoons like Aristotle Onassis to build trophy Manhattan skyscrapers, died on Aug. 9 at his home in Kings Point, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Northern Exposure
description: Are you afraid of heights? a questioner asked Alaskan Senate candidates in a debate this week.

title: A Mound Becomes a Summit
description: SOUTH WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.  An unmistakable electricity ran through Howard J. Lamade Stadium on Friday as a team from Pennsylvania faced a team from Tennessee on the second day of the Little League World Series.

title: When Sports and Family Time Conflict, Speak Up
description: Try saying this out loud: Family and academics are more important than sports, until sports conflict, then sports win.

title: At Pebble Beach, Judged Show Cars Arent the Only Stars
description: The spotlight at the annual Pebble Beach Concours d'lgance may shine most brightly on flawless examples of the finest antique cars known to humankind. But todays automakers also claim a sliver of the limelight in the flurry of events crowded onto the Monterey Peninsula. Here are a few of the highlights of this years event:

title: In an Iraqi Town Hollowed Out by Jihadists, There Is No Going Back to How It Was
description: MAHMOUR, Iraq  The streets of this front-line town bear the scars of combat: the shops are closed or destroyed and most of the homes are abandoned, some still covered in graffiti scrawled by fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: A Youth, an Officer and 2 Paths to a Fatal Encounter
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Michael Brown let his 16th birthday come and go without bothering to apply for a drivers license. There was no need, his family said. He preferred to walk.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 15, 2014
Judge Hears Plea to Halt Tuition Plan at Cooper Union
description: What did Peter Cooper really intend to do when he founded one of the nations few free colleges?

title: To Know Suicide
description: BALTIMORE  WHEN the American artist Ralph Barton killed himself in 1931 he left behind a suicide note explaining why, in the midst of a seemingly good and full life, he had chosen to die.

title: Robert Richards, Marine Guilty in Taliban Desecration, Dies at 28
description: Robert W. Richards, a former sergeant who helped provoke international outrage when he and three other Marines were seen on videotape urinating on the corpses of Taliban fighters in Afghanistan in 2011, died on Wednesday at his home in Jacksonville, N.C., near Camp Lejeune, where he had once been based. He was 28.

title: As World Boils, Fingers Point Obamas Way
description: WASHINGTON  In this summer of global tumult, the debate in Washington essentially boils down to two opposite positions: It is all President Obamas fault, according to his critics; no, it is not, according to his supporters, because these are events beyond his control.

title: Holding Auditors Blameless
description: The list of accounting scandals, which includes Arthur Andersens disastrous thumbs-up of Enron, the Internet stock bust and the financial crisis, has just gotten longer.

title: Gov. Christie Takes On the Bail Bondsmen
description: Gov. Chris Christie, who often likens New Jerseys pretrial system to debtors prisons, signed two bills this week that offer hope for something a lot fairer. One bill would remake the system so it more nearly resembles the federal system  allowing judges to keep suspects in jail if they are a flight risk or a threat to society, but not because they cant post bail. The second bill authorizes a vote in November on a constitutional amendment that must be approved before Mr. Christies proposed reforms can take effect.

title: A Painfully Slow Ebola Response
description: The outbreak of the Ebola virus in West Africa appears more out of control than ever. By Friday, the virus had infected more than 2,000 people in four countries and had killed more than half of them. The World Health Organization, which snoozed on the sidelines for months after the outbreak was first identified in March, has issued increasingly frantic warnings in recent days. On Aug. 8, it declared the spread of the virus a public health emergency of international concern. On Thursday, it warned that the reported numbers of people killed or sickened by the virus may vastly underestimate the magnitude of the outbreak because many sick people escape detection. The next day, it said that patients flooding into newly opened treatment centers were filling beds faster than they could be provided.

title: Upstate Couple Are Accused of Kidnapping Amish Sisters
description: The authorities said Friday night that they had arrested a couple in the abduction of two young Amish girls from their farm in upstate New York on Wednesday night, a crime that prompted an extensive search and national media attention.

title: Trooper Listens to, and Connects With, a Ferguson Torn by Violent Unrest
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The governor of Missouri was the first person to speak at the news conference on Friday morning. But as has been the case since Capt. Ronald S. Johnson of the State Highway Patrol first entered the drama of race, violence and trust swirling in this St. Louis suburb, the veteran trooper dominated it.

title: Crack a Bottle
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Peter Broda is a very modest man. Hed probably even say that he doesnt deserve a compliment like that, being that hes so modest. I say this because Mr. Broda doesnt believe that todays puzzle is very good, but I disagree. I think its almost perfect, at least by my own solving standards.

title: Condemned but Undeterred, Boko Haram Is Still Abducting Nigerian Youths
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  The pattern is becoming all too familiar to residents of Nigerias embattled northeast: Gunmen believed to be members of the militant Islamist sect Boko Haram descend on a village, burn houses, round up scores of young people, load them onto trucks and then drive away.

title: Charges Against Rick Perry Outlined
description: A special prosecutor assigned to the case described the charges against the Texas governor, which include abusing his official capacity and coercing a public servant.

title: Adrift for Years, Bronx Childrens Museum Finds a Place to Park Its Purple Bus
description: The children come running when they spy the big purple school bus.

title: 3 Arrested in the Killing of a Livery Driver in the Bronx
description: Three men have been arrested in the fatal shooting of a Bronx livery driver during a carjacking this week, and the authorities say they are investigating whether they may have been involved in the killing of another livery driver this month.

title: The Scary, the Sad, and the Just Plain Bizarre
description: A psychiatrist once told me that people tend to focus more on bad news because human beings are genetically wired to identify dangers they should thereafter avoid. If so, people following the rioting in the small Missouri town of Ferguson most likely came away sensing that the danger to avoid was not the rioters, angered by the police killing of an unarmed 18-year-old African-American, but the police confronting the demonstrators, decked out like Marines preparing to retake Falluja.

title: Rookie, Age 27, Drives Mets Past Cubs
description: One of the pressing priorities for Mets Manager Terry Collins these days has been getting Eric Campbell more at-bats against left-handed pitchers.

title: A Town on the Front Lines of the Fight With ISIS
description: Nearly a week after American airstrikes paved the way for Kurdish forces to reclaim Mahmour from Sunni militants, very few people have returned.

title: The Knick Recap: Into an Electrified Light
description: Season 1, Episode 2 A couple of things it seems to safe say after Sunday nights episode of the hospital drama The Knick on Cinemax:

title: With Ebola Cases Still Few, Populous Nigeria Has Chance to Halt Its Outbreak
description: Health workers have fought the Ebola outbreak to a tentative standstill in Nigeria, Africas most populous nation, offering at least a chance to eradicate the disease there before it spins out of control, as it has in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, where a sluggish response failed to halt it early.

title: Tanaka May Return, but Perhaps Not to a Playoff Race
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Masahiro Tanaka continues to make progress in his rehabilitation from a torn ligament in his right elbow, but even if he can return in September, it may be too late for him to make a difference in the Yankees pursuit of a postseason berth.

title: Agencies Issue Warnings Over Bogus Ebola Cures
description: Panic over Ebola has the makers of dietary supplements aggressively targeting Africans, claiming to have a cure for the lethal virus.

title: Hospitals in the U.S. Get Ready for Ebola
description: Hospitals nationwide are hustling to prepare for the first traveler from West Africa who arrives in the emergency room with symptoms of infection with the Ebola virus.

title: The Cormorants of East Sand Island
description: Scientists studying the cormorant colony in Oregon are looking for the best way to remove most of the birds.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 16, 2014
description: In our anger, we have to make sure that we dont burn down our own house.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) 2 GUNS (2013) A couple of bad guys (Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg) find themselves on the lam after failing to infiltrate a Mexican drug cartel  only to discover that each is an undercover agent  in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called a slick, slippery thriller from the director Baltasar Kormakur. Edward James Olmos plays a drug lord with $3 million for the taking, Paula Patton is a Drug Enforcement Administration operative, Bill Paxton is a Central Intelligence agency whack job, and James Marsden and Fred Ward do business for the Navy. Working with an editor, Michael Tronick, who doesnt step on the sometimes wittily choreographed action by overcutting, Mr. Kormakur sets and keeps up a fast rather than frantic pace that never runs the movie off the rails even when the story nearly does, Ms. Dargis wrote. Much as he did in his last movie, Contraband, another thriller with Mr. Wahlberg, Mr. Kormakur has put his imprimatur on a pulp fiction that easily could have become another generic diversion instead of a fine genre one.

title: Corrections: August 16, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Modern Technologies and the Ebola Fight
description: How some modern technologies  from airport screening to cellphones  may help in the fight to contain the Ebola virus.

title: Midnight Curfew in Effect for Ferguson
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri on Saturday imposed a midnight to 5 a.m. curfew in this small city, declaring a state of emergency as violence flared anew after a week of street protests over the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer.

title: Papal Visit That Thrills Catholics Is Unsettling to Protestants in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a symbolic moment for the Vatican and South Koreas 5.1 million Catholics, hundreds of thousands of people cheered as Pope Francis rode through central Seoul on Saturday to lead a Mass to beatify 124 martyrs directly in front of the palace of the old Korean dynasty that killed them more than a century ago.

title: Senator Brian Schatz Wins Closely Fought Democratic Primary in Hawaii
description: PUNA, Hawaii  After nearly two years of campaigning, millions of dollars spent and one tropical storm that delayed voting in this easternmost corner of Hawaii for nearly a week, Senator Brian Schatz won the Democratic nomination for his seat on Friday, bringing one of the longest and most acrimonious primary contests in the states history to an apparent end.

title: Analytics: How Readers Reacted to Our Cover Story on Autism
description: The following pie chart appears on the Reply All page in the Aug. 17 issue of the magazine.

title: A Double Dose of Comfort
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: LiketoKnowit Lets You Shop Looks on Instagram
description: Ive long reported on the many ways that Instagram is quickly becoming a shoppers delight, like the boutiques and entrepreneurs that use the mobile application to tempt buyers with luscious photos of their colorful goods.

title: A Menagerie of Ideas, Unlocked in Odd Jobs
description: From the ages of 18 to 36  when I began to teach creative writing  I worked variously as a house cleaner, house painter, landscaper, masseuse, editor and secretary. I worked as a tree planter in Zambia for a half-year when I was 19, then as a produce worker at a co-op grocery store in San Francisco, where I grew up. My first salaried job was going door to door, raising money for Salvadoran refugees fleeing civil conflict and death squads.

title: Hesitating on the High Board of Investing
description: You have arrived at a pool for a swim: Do you plunge right in or just dip in a toe until youre comfortable?

title: Narinder Singh of Topcoder: Is It the Cards, or How You Play Them?
description: This interview with  Narinder Singh, president of Topcoder, which administers computer-programming competitions, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: The Mystery of Lofty Stock Market Elevations
description: The United States stock market looks very expensive right now. The CAPE ratio, a stock-price measure I helped develop  is hovering at a worrisome level.

title: Your 401(k) Is Healthy. So Maybe You Are, Too.
description: Before you suggest that friends or family members start to exercise or improve their diets, you might first want to ask a question: Are they saving for retirement?

title: Aug. 16: Scenes on Twitter From Ferguson, Mo., Overnight
description: As my colleague, Alan Blinder reports from Ferguson, Mo., protesters looted stores and clashed with the police overnight amid renewed tension over the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a police officer a week ago.

title: 3 Liberian Health Workers With Ebola Receive Scarce Drug After Appeals to U.S.
description: Three Liberian health care workers who have contracted Ebola received an extremely scarce experimental serum on Friday at a hospital outside the national capital, Monrovia, a Liberian health official said Saturday.

title: In a Bank Settlement, Dont Forget the Bulldozers
description: A win-win. Thats how people on both sides of the negotiating table will undoubtedly characterize the long-awaited, $16 billion-plus mortgage settlement that Bank of America is expected to reach with the Justice Department this week. For federal and state governments, the deal will mean billions in cash and borrower assistance. For the bank, the agreement will help it get past its mortgage woes, many emanating from its 2008 purchase of Countrywide Financial, a truly toxic lender.

title: Authenticity, Repurposed, in a Mason Jar
description: Maybe youve sipped a beer from a Mason jar. Or fished out a pickle swimming in brine from one. Or dined under illuminated clusters of them, dangling in chandelier formation, at a restaurant  especially if you dined in Brooklyn.

title: Everyone Gets a Share, of Everything
description: The sharing economy  or the prospect of whats mine is yours, for a price  has hit nearly every sector of the travel market. The success of operations like Airbnb in room rentals has spawned businesses related to recreation, dining and transportation.

title: Renting With Bad Credit
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Steps and the City (Fairly Trivial)
description: Emily Badger tells us that sprawl is bad for your health; so are movie theater concession counters, reports Sarah Kliff, which is why Tom Harkin and Rosa DeLauro want to include popcorn under the rules requiring calorie disclosure. (At the risk of sounding whiny, they arent exactly coming after your popcorn; youd be free to buy it, its just that the cinema would have to tell you how many calories youre about to consume.)

title: Tug of War Between Republicans Seeking Same Base Support
description: FORT WORTH  One week before a grand jury in liberal Travis County indicted Gov. Rick Perry on two felony counts, he and United States Sen. Ted Cruz were in friendlier territory, speaking at a conference hosted by a conservative blog here in the largest reliably Republican community in Texas.

title: Acclimating to Stardom and a New Coach
description: After being underrecruited in high school, undervalued in college and underappreciated in the N.B.A., Golden State Warriors guard Stephen Curry is getting used to being a star. In June, he earned a place on the all-N.B.A. second team, and he has spent this summer training to represent the United States in the FIBA World Cup, which begins Aug. 30.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Puns and Anagrams, or PandAs as they are affectionately called by some, are the reward we get for a sturdy week of straight crossword puzzle-solving. Yes, its still basically a crossword puzzle, but when was the last time you guffawed or slapped your forehead and groaned out loud while doing a Saturday crossword puzzle? PandAs are silly, and theyre a nice relief after the tough, late-week puzzles. At least I think so.

title: As (Very) Fast Friends, Two Young Americans Balance at Sports Peak
description: IRVINE, Calif.  They are USA Swimmings dynamic duo, but there is one competition that neither Missy Franklin nor Katie Ledecky can win: the popularity contest to anoint a single chlorine queen. It is a losing proposition for both Franklin, a six-time gold medalist at last summers world championships, and Ledecky, who will go into this weeks Pan Pacific Swimming Championships poised to win as many as five gold medals.

title: In the Sharing Economy, Workers Find Both Freedom and Uncertainty
description: Just after 4 a.m. on a recent Friday, while most of the neighbors in her leafy Boston suburb were still asleep, Jennifer Guidry was in the driveway of her rental apartment, her blond hair pulled back in a tidy French braid, vacuuming the inside of her car. The early-bird routine is a strategy that Ms. Guidry, a Navy veteran and former accountant, uses to mitigate the uncertainty of working in whats known as the sharing economy.

title: In Chinas Shadow, U.S. Courts Old Foe Vietnam
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, courted Vietnam over the past several days. He was the first chairman in more than 40 years to visit the old enemy of Washington, now envisioned as a new partner that will acquire American weapons and help offset the power of China.

title: Brokers of the Sharing Economy
description: Start-up companies in what is known as the sharing economy are gaining traction with consumers, freelance workers and investors alike. The companies are able to offer competitive prices to consumers in part by acting as labor brokers, rather than as employers who offer costly employee benefits.

title: Plotting Lassies Future
description: In 2012, DreamWorks Animation acquired the rights to Lassie. The studio is slowly reintroducing the character, once a big Hollywood star, through public media appearances.

title: Floods and Landslides Kill Dozens and Leave Scores Missing in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  More than 50 people died and scores are missing after three days of continuous monsoon rains set off multiple floods and landslides in Nepals low-lying plain near the Indian border, officials said Saturday.

title: Lassie as Salesdog: One More Trip to the Well
description: LOS ANGELES  Maybe it was the three publicists in tow. Maybe her hairdo was wilting under the hot television lights. Maybe a dog, even a showbiz one, was just not meant to be a meteorologist.

title: In Push to Shorten Games, Theres No Time to Waste
description: The fundamental problem facing Major League Baseball and its next commissioner, Rob Manfred, is that attention spans are getting shorter while games are getting longer. Confronting these clashing realities may be Manfreds top priority when he takes office in January. It will be the first transition at the top of baseballs hierarchy since Bud Selig replaced Fay Vincent in 1992.

title: Plight of Iraqi Minorities Worsens With Forced Conversions and Killings
description: BAGHDAD  The gunmen had surrounded the village for more than a week, refusing to let residents leave and saying they had limited time to save themselves by converting to Islam.

title: Deep Tensions Rise to Surface After Ferguson Shooting
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Garland Moore, a hospital worker, lived in this St. Louis suburb for much of his 33 years, a period in which a largely white community has become a largely black one.

title: Smashing a Ceiling and a Lot of Egos
description: Last month, inside a grand ballroom at the Aria Resort & Casino in Las Vegas, Michele A. Roberts stood before 117 N.B.A. players  towering international celebrities with millions in their bank accounts  and declared that she should be their leader.

title: Best Shortstop on the Cubs? Scan the Field
description: Just before the start of Javier Baezs senior season at Arlington Country Day School in Jacksonville, Fla., the baseball teams starting shortstop sustained a season-ending injury that prompted a major shift of the defensive alignment. The maneuvering ended with Baez, the teams catcher, moving to shortstop.

title: Amid Debate Over Who Overstepped, Perry Calls Indictment a Farce
description: A defiant Gov. Rick Perry on Saturday vowed to fight his indictment on charges of abuse of power, calling it a farce and a political prosecution.

title: No Longer an Impact Player, a Giant Finds a Way to Deliver a Kaboom
description: The 12th season of Israel Idonijes N.F.L. career finds him in New York, and this protagonist is worn down, fighting his bodys aches and scrambling to catch on at the end of the roster for the Giants, his third team in three years.

title: Licia Albanese, Exalted Soprano, Is Dead at 105
description: Licia Albanese, an Italian-born soprano whose veneration by audiences worldwide was copious even by the standards of operatic adulation, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 105.

title: A Skewed View of a Middle Tier
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Is Summer Different Now?
description: WE like to remember a childs summer as a season of no responsibility, unfettered by parental supervision, a time to indulge and explore. And we like to complain that summer has changed; that children have more responsibility, less freedom, fewer indulgences.

title: Couple Sexually Abused Amish Sisters, Officials Say
description: The two young Amish sisters who were kidnapped from their farm in upstate New York last week were sexually assaulted, the authorities said on Saturday.

title: Grand Canyon Symphony
description: Readers write eloquently about Americas cathedral and argue against its desecration.

title: Pope Francis in South Korea
description: The popes visit was a highly symbolic time for the Vatican and the countrys 5.1 million Catholics.

title: Bolivias Subway in the Sky
description: For many Bolivians, the Telefrico is a symbol that the country has arrived. Opened in May, its two other sections will arrive conveniently as President Evo Morales seeks a third term.

title: Wheres the Justice at Justice?
description: WASHINGTON  JIM RISEN is gruff.

title: China Confronts Its Coal Problem
description: The Chinese government has indicated a strong desire  and made some specific proposals  to reduce its reliance on coal, a step that would be a welcome development for the Chinese people and the planet as a whole. But there is a lot we dont know yet about Beijings strategy and whether it will be bold enough to have a meaningful effect on local air quality and climate change.

title: Strutting Back With a Vengeance
description: Whatever happened to Giuliani? No, not the ex-mayor with the comb-over. Giuliani the urbane wild turkey, the bold bird that drew raves from shocked city dwellers when she arrived at Manhattans Riverside Park 11 years ago to strut imperiously, residing in plain sight, deigning to tolerate handouts and a nickname. Giuliani was studied like an extraterrestrial by crowds more mindful of wild turkey as a libation  not the dominant roaming bird of colonial days that was nearly driven to extinction as settlers fed off the flocks and urban landscapes exploded.

title: Sister Acts
description: IN an age of villainy, war and inequality, it makes sense that we need superheroes. And after trying Superman, Batman and Spider-Man, we may have found the best superheroes yet: Nuns.

title: Fixing Immigration in the Field
description: President Obama is looking to give some unauthorized immigrants a temporary path out of the shadows, a legal way to stay and work. He promised to act by the end of summer if Congress didnt. Though a debate has raged about the legal and political restraints on Mr. Obamas executive authority to do this, the real question is how many of the unauthorized population, totaling about 11 million, will be lucky enough to win a temporary reprieve from deportation.

title: Playing Soldier in the Suburbs
