description: TO understand whats been happening in Ferguson, Mo., where protests and violence following a cops shooting of an unarmed teenager summoned up a police response that looked more like a military invasion, it helps to flash back to the heyday of the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: A Battleground and Bellwether
description: DENVER  GIVEN all of the smoky talk about Colorado and marijuana, you arrive here with the feeling that youre stepping into some freaky, one-of-a-kind laboratory.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 16
description: For a week, protesters filled the streets of Ferguson, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis, where an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, was shot and killed by a police officer. After several days of unrest and reports of excessive force by the police, Gov. Jay Nixon on Thursday had the state highway patrol take over security operations from the city police.

title: With Aid Doctors Gone, Ebola Fight Grows Harder
description: When people started dying of Ebola in Liberia, Clarine Vaughn faced a wrenching choice: Should she send home, for their own health and safety, four American doctors working for Heartt, the aid group she led there? Or should she keep them in the country without proper supplies or training to fight the virulent, contagious disease, which was already spreading panic?

title: Medicare to Start Paying Doctors Who Coordinate Needs of Chronically Ill Patients
description: WASHINGTON  In a policy change, the Obama administration is planning to pay doctors to coordinate the care of Medicare beneficiaries, amid growing evidence that patients with chronic illnesses suffer from disjointed, fragmented care.

title: On a Helicopter, Going Down: Inside a Lethal Crash in Iraq
description: Alissa J. Rubin, a veteran Times foreign correspondent, was injured on Tuesday in a helicopter crash in Kurdistan and dictated the following article from her hospital bed in Istanbul, where she was evacuated from Iraq. She suffered broken bones and a fractured skull but was in stable condition, and was scheduled to be taken by air to the United States on Sunday.

title: The Disappearing Volunteer Firefighter
description: IN most places in America, when a fire breaks out, a volunteer shows up to put it out.

title: Teaching Is Not a Business
description: TODAYS education reformers believe that schools are broken and that business can supply the remedy. Some place their faith in the idea of competition. Others embrace disruptive innovation, mainly through online learning. Both camps share the belief that the solution resides in the impersonal, whether its the invisible hand of the market or the transformative power of technology.

title: Leonard Fein, Provocative Writer on Jewish Affairs, Dies at 80
description: Leonard Fein, an intellectual and activist who wrote voluminously about contemporary Jews, Judaism and, in his words, the often stormy relationship between Jews and Judaism, and who founded a magazine and organizations to combat hunger and illiteracy, died late Wednesday or early Thursday in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Nadya Tolokonnikova
description: Nadya Tolokonnikova is a member of the Russian punk rock protest band Pussy Riot. She served a 21-month jail sentence on a charge of hooliganism following a 2012 performance that criticized President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: An SEC Partisan on Rooting for Greatness
description: Originally a newspaper reporter, Paul Finebaum found himself on the business end of a microphone 30 years ago when he began hosting a Birmingham, Ala.-based sports radio show called Fussin With Finebaum.

title: More Latinos on Farms Move From Fields to Office
description: WATSONVILLE, Calif.  When he was 15, an immigration raid at a Japanese flower nursery turned Arturo Floress life around.

title: A Choice Between Boredom and Blood
description: PARIS  I WAS born in Russia at the dawn of the Brezhnev era, and Brezhnev died when I was a senior in high school.

title: Man Is Accused of Stabbing 3 Inside Grand Central Station
description: An intoxicated man stabbed a man and slashed two others on a subway platform at Grand Central Station in Manhattan early Saturday, the police said.

title: 35 Are Found as Container Is Unloaded Near London
description: LONDON  Thirty-five people were found in a shipping container that was being unloaded at a dock east of London on Saturday morning, including a man who was pronounced dead at the scene, law enforcement officials here said.

title: Cancer and the Secrets of Your Genes
description: DALLAS  ON Aug. 6, researchers announced in The New England Journal of Medicine that they had found that mutations in a gene called PALB2 greatly increase the risk of breast cancer. This is one of the biggest developments since the discovery in the 90s of the role of mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes in breast and ovarian cancer.

title: A Protest Ignited
description: Protesters angered over the police shooting of Michael Brown, 18, squared off with law enforcement in the streets of Ferguson, Mo., again, looting some stores.

title: Finding My Voice in Fantasy
description: I wrote fiction for 17 years before I found out I was a fantasy novelist. Up till then I always thought I was going to write literary fiction, like Jonathan Franzen or Zadie Smith or Jhumpa Lahiri. But I thought wrong.

title: Eroni Kumana, Who Saved Kennedy and His Shipwrecked Crew, Dies at 96
description: Eroni Kumana, who lived his entire life on a tiny Pacific island called Rannoga, about 900 miles east of New Guinea, in a village without electricity, telephone service, running water or a paved road, left his mark on the history of the world on or about Aug. 5 and 6, 1943.

title: With Subway in the Sky, Valley Meets Plateau
description: LA PAZ and EL ALTO, Bolivia  In these two cities, geography and rank stand in inverse relation. La Paz  the seat of government, old money and a lighter-skinned elite  sits in a valley. Above it on a high plateau is the frenetic city of El Alto: poorer, younger and generally darker-skinned. La Paz has always looked down on its upstart younger sibling above.

title: As the L.P.G.A. Leaves Town, a Community Contemplates a Void
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  In suburban Rochester in 1984, Kathy Whitworth broke Sam Sneads record of 85 professional golf victories, and Snead called Whitworth in the clubhouse to offer congratulations.

title: What the Sparrows Told Me
description: To be honest, I never cared about birds. Then, almost nine years ago, Hurricane Katrina swallowed half the city of New Orleans, and something began to change.

title: Managers Provide Drama as English Fans Lament Talent Drain
description: LONDON  The most popular soccer league in the world began its season on Saturday, and along with the excitement and exhilaration about the games themselves  not to mention the sheer wonderment over the eye-crossing suit that the golfer Rory McIlroy chose to wear while parading his British Open trophy around Old Trafford in Manchester  there was a fair bit of hand-wringing from many longtime observers of Englands Premier League.

title: The Wisdom of the Exile
description: At one point in its history, the tango was popular in the world of Buenos Airess brothels. Toward the end of the 19th century, young immigrants  single, male, working class  who had come to Argentina to try their luck would seek comfort in the drink, entertainment and female companionship there. Argentines as distinguished as Jorge Luis Borges have insisted that the tango was born in these brothels. Others vehemently deny it. But the fact remains that the tango has preserved something of the anguish of the young and uprooted who danced it there.

title: Lack of Leadership and a Generational Split Hinder Protests in Ferguson
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The unrest in Ferguson began one week ago, on the quiet side street of Canfield Drive, when residents were startled by a series of gunshots and poured out of their homes. They watched and wept as the police stood guard for hours over the body of 18-year-old Michael Brown, splayed face down in the street.

title: The Obituary Lottery
description: A MINOR but talented actress named Arlene Martel died on Tuesday at age 78. Aficionados of small-screen science fiction and fantasy remember this exotic-looking woman as a creepy morgue attendant (and an equally creepy airline stewardess) in Twenty Two, a 1961 segment of The Twilight Zone.

title: Bomb Scare in Brooklyn Causes False Alarm
description: The police responded to reports of a possible explosive device at the Louis Pink Houses in the East New York neighborhood on Saturday, evacuating some residents. The device, described by the authorities initially as what appears to be sticks of dynamite wrapped in wires, was determined by the bomb squad to be wooden sticks.

title: Protesters Call for Pakistani Premier to Step Down
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  As rain poured down, young men draped in political party flags danced in the streets of Islamabad on Saturday, waiting for the next stage of the revolution promised by Imran Khan, the opposition leader and former cricket star.

title: Sittin Solve
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Boy, talk about Aha! moments. I had almost finished solving Caleb Madisons puzzle before I figured out what his theme was about.

title: Ink and Paper Make Comeback in Oil Towns
description: BOERNE  This town does not sit atop South Texas Eagle Ford Shale, but inside an air-conditioned advertising agency here, four editors produce a newspaper that has infiltrated that dusty drilling country.

title: Traffic Offense Program Is Seen as a Trap for Poor Drivers, but Proves Hard to Kill
description: AUSTIN  When Charles Farmer was pulled over for turning without signaling on last Thanksgiving morning, he learned that his license had been suspended for failing to pay surcharges on traffic tickets he had already paid. Shocked, Mr. Farmer took out his phone and paid the surcharges from the side of the road.

title: The Bridge Isnt Real; It Just Seems That Way
description: Last year, the FX program The Bridge won a Peabody Award for raising awareness of border issues, and many of the plotlines were based on the realities of life in El Paso and its violence-stricken Mexican sister city a bridge away, Ciudad Jurez.

title: A Haven for an Iraqi Minority
description: Fleeing forces of the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, some Yazidi families made their way to a camp near the border with Syria.

title: Flow of Olympiad Medals for Russian Men Dries Up
description: Last weeks Chess Olympiad results further tarnished Russias lingering reputation as the games dominant power. The tournament showed that, at most, it is first among equals, and that may be too generous an assessment

title: Artists Work Rises From the Destruction of the Israel-Gaza Conflict
description: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip  The images of so many houses destroyed, so many bomb blasts, even so many bodies wrapped in burial shrouds can begin to blur together, indistinguishable. But Belal Khaled, a young photojournalist and painter in this southern Gaza town, saw symbols and stories in the smoke all around him.

title: Montana Democrats Pick Novice for Senate Race
description: HELENA, Mont.  Montanas Democrats, scrambling to salvage their political fortunes after plagiarism charges forced Senator John Walsh to end his election bid, chose a high school math teacher and one-term state legislator on Saturday as their nominee for a fiercely contested Senate seat.

title: After Doctors Visit, Ivanovic Rallies Past Sharapova to Advance to Final
description: MASON, Ohio  It is common for an athlete to succumb to pressure. To be derailed by an opponent who just had her blood pressure taken? Not so common.

title: With Yankees and Their Spirits Slumping, Jeter Provides a Remedy
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  If everything had gone according to plan, Derek Jeter would have just been a footnote to the game, and Jacoby Ellsbury or Mark Teixeira might have been the hero in a much-needed win. But the plan fell apart thanks to some nasty pitches from the left-hander Jake McGee, and in its place came something even better: another in a long series of memorable moments for Jeter.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 16, 2014
Battling Ebola in Liberia
description: Efforts to identify and quarantine people infected with Ebola in the poor West Point neighborhood of Monrovia have been haphazard, chaotic and largely ineffective.

title: Configuring a Future, the Mets Cobble a Win, Too
description: Although the Mets have not fallen completely out of the National League wild-card race, they have subtly begun looking toward the future. Rebuilding is not a favorite word for Mets coaches or executives, but the teams recent actions suggest that is exactly what is happening as the season winds down.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 17, 2014
description: I would love to believe that modern children would sit down and watch lovely Lassie frolic with Timmy in the meadow. But I fear they would get awfully bored unless she turned into a superdog that blows things up, and that would be sacrilege.

title: Jets Win but Fail to Ease Worries Over Defensive Backfield
description: CINCINNATI  Andy Dalton completed the first pass he threw against the Jets on Saturday night. And the second. And the third. And the fourth. And the fifth. And the sixth. And the seventh. And the eighth.

title: Giants Get Last Laugh, but First Units Struggles Cause No Smiles
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Indianapolis Motor Speedway is six miles west of Lucas Oil Stadium, and the Giants almost certainly saw the two-and-a-half-mile oval and its 200,000-plus seats when they flew into central Indiana on Friday. Nearly everyone traveling by air here does.

title: A Beautiful Mind
description: After a stunning career in fashion, Federico Forquet turned his lifes work toward making exquisite houses and gardens. His own in the Tuscan hills is both a sanctuary and a masterpiece.

title: Elizabeth Forbes and Michael Siliciano
description: Elizabeth Anne Forbes, a daughter of Sabina C. Forbes and Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. of Bedminster, N.J., was married Saturday to Michael Robert Siliciano, a son of Janet M. Siliciano and Dr. Robert F. Siliciano of Baltimore. The Rev. David DeSalvo, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Lorraine Spradley and Sean Wilson
description: Lorraine Suzanne Spradley and Sean Donald Wilson were married Saturday evening at the Engineers Club of Baltimore. Judge Miriam B. Hutchins, an associate judge of the First District Court of Maryland in Baltimore, officiated with the assistance of the Rev. Walter S. Thomas Jr., a Baptist minister.

title: Laura Flannery, Colin Masters
description: Dr. Laura Diane Flannery and Colin William Masters were married Saturday at St. Augustins Catholic Church in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Peter M.P. Mongeon, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Diana Ren, Michael Senno
description: Diana Nicole Ren and Michael John Senno were married Saturday at Sullivan Vineyards in Rutherford, Calif. The Rev. Timothy J. Mills, an American Baptist minister, led a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Mary Kearns, Peter Naylor
description: Mary Veronica Kearns and Peter Victor Naylor were married Saturday at the Sherborn Inn in Sherborn, Mass. David R. Balsley, a son-in-law of the bride who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, officiated.

title: Caroline Balkonis, Andrew Usas
description: Caroline Bridget Balkonis and Andrew James Usas were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. William J. Bergen, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs associate pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Lauren Koppel, Eric Fraser
description: Lauren Yordi Koppel and Eric John Fraser were married Saturday at Locusts-on-Hudson, an estate in Staatsburg, N.Y. The Rev. Judith Johnson, an interfaith minister, officiated; Ronald N. Yordi, an uncle of the bride affiliated with the Church of the Movement of Spiritual Inner Awareness, took part.

title: Jill Springer, William Gostic II
description: Jill Elizabeth Springer, a daughter of Carol L. Springer and Andrew K. Springer of East Freetown, Mass., was married Saturday to Dr. William John Gostic II, the son of Elena M. Gostic and William J. Gostic of South Glastonbury, Conn. The Rev. Gregory Mathias, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. John Neumann Church in East Freetown.

title: Gowri Ramachandran, Anshul Amar
description: Gowri Ramachandran and Anshul Gupta Amar were married Saturday evening at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles by Judge Sidney R. Thomas of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, who has chambers in Billings, Mont.

title: Saba Bireda, Harambee Ryan
description: Saba Priscilla Bireda and Harambee Emanuel Ryan were married Saturday evening at Historic Oakland, a house in Columbia, Md. Mariama White-Hammond, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Rae Schweizer, Craig Story
description: Rae Nicole Schweizer and Craig David Story were married Saturday at the Sun Valley Club in Sun Valley, Idaho. The Rev. Kenneth Brannon, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Kate Berry, Will Sheppard
description: Kate Shively Berry and Will Handman Sheppard were married Saturday evening at the Doe Memorial Library at the University of California, Berkeley. Anne Shively Berry, the brides sister, received permission from Alameda County to officiate.

title: Tyrha Lindsey, Sidney Warren
description: Tyrha Marie Lindsey and Sidney Lovette Warren were married Saturday by Royce Winters, a Roman Catholic deacon, at the Church of the Resurrection in Cincinnati.

title: Carlisle Williams, Paul Engelhardt
description: Carlisle Alessandra Williams, the daughter of Leslie A. OBrien and Kenneth C. Williams of Indian Wells, Calif., was married Saturday to Paul David Engelhardt, a son of Nancy A. Engelhardt and Dr. Philip L. Engelhardt of Bay City, Mich. The Rev. Michael R. Nagle performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass., on Marthas Vineyard.

title: Jessica Brondo, Nicholas Davidoff
description: Jessica Ashlee Brondo and Nicholas Karl Davidoff were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Diane P. Hughes, a minister ordained by One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, officiated at Gotham Hall, an events space in New York.

title: Hope Wachter and Robert Kaplan
description: Hope Alison Wachter and Robert Blair Kaplan were married Saturday evening at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi Dennis S. Ross officiated.

title: Vivian Tsai, Austin Lin
description: Dr. Vivian Tsai and Austin I-Fong Lin were married Saturday at Roslyn Presbyterian Church in Roslyn, N.Y. The Rev. David Plant, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Sheila Bautista, Charles Toothill II
description: Sheila Lee Bautista and Charles Howard Toothill II were married Saturday. The Rev. Kavungal Davy performed the ceremony at the St. Anthony-St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, where he is the pastor.

title: Barbara Rice and Katherine Callaghan
description: The Rev. Barbara Lea Rice and Katherine Munson Callaghan are to be married Sunday evening by the Rev. Julie Peeples, a minister of the United Church of Christ, at the Prospect Park Boathouse in Brooklyn.

title: Amanda Thurston, Matthew Andrews
description: Amanda Lewis Thurston, a daughter of Prudence M. Thurston and George D. Thurston of Blooming Grove, N.Y., was married Saturday to Matthew Chase Andrews, the son of Ashley C. Andrews and Vincent S. Andrews of North Salem, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Edwin H. Cromey, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Jaffrey Meetinghouse in Jaffrey, N.H.

title: Emily Ward, Gary Lupyan
description: Emily Juniper Ward and Igor Lupyan were married Friday afternoon at Hollins House at Pasatiempo, an event space in Santa Cruz, Calif. Leonid Teytelman, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Savanna Thor, Simon Smith
description: Dr. Savanna Thor and Dr. Simon Narciso Smith are to be married Sunday at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y. Sarah J. Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister, will officiate.

title: Altaf Saadi and Sameer Ahmed
description: Dr. Altaf Saadi and Sameer Ahmed were married Saturday evening at Vibiana, an event space in Los Angeles. Imam Sayed Moustafa al-Qazwini performed a Muslim ceremony.

title: June Chan, Nancy Ferrone
description: Dr. June Mei Yee Chan and Nancy Grace Ferrone were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. AngelL.Lopezof the New York City Clerks office officiated.

title: Jessica Eisner, Michael Cabin
description: Jessica Lauren Eisner and Michael Alexander Comite Cabin were married Saturday at Onteora Mountain House, a bed-and-breakfast in Boiceville, N.Y. Cantor Josh Konigsberg officiated.

title: A Childhood Romance Grows Up
description: Sophie Elisabeth Fitzgerald, the daughter of Elisabeth C. Fitzgerald and Joseph M. Fitzgerald III of New York, was married Saturday to Samuel Bresnahan Burke, a son of Patricia B. Burke and William L. Burke III of Needham, Mass. The Rev. John F. Arens, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard.

title: Samuel Talone, Dickson Jean
description: Samuel Alexander Talone and Dr. Dickson Jean were married Saturday night at Housing Works Bookstore Caf in New York. Elizabeth Scaffidi, who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Kirby and Timothy Fuderich
description: Elizabeth Marie Kirby, a daughter of Sara P. Kirby and Ambassador Michael D. Kirby of Belgrade, Serbia, was married Wednesday to Timothy Santi Fuderich, a son of Urakorn K. Fuderich and Robert P. Fuderich of Tashkent, Uzbekistan. The couple were married at their home in Philadelphia in a ceremony held under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute.

title: Judith Scarl, David Williams
description: Judith Cohen Scarl and David Rowen Williams were married Saturday in Roslyn, N.Y. Melanie S. Rowen, a cousin of the groom and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Swan Club, an events space.

title: Elizabeth Olney, Aaron Goldfarb
description: Elizabeth Lynn Olney and Aaron Michael Goldfarb were married Saturday evening at the Custom House Maritime Museum in Newburyport, Mass. Richard Jones, a Newburyport city clerk, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Tepe, John Kneeland
description: Elizabeth Louise Tepe and John Patrick Kneeland were married Saturday at St. Anns Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Peter Cheney, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Leila Taha, Saed Shonnar
description: Leila Taha and Saed Shonnar were married Saturday at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Farida Ali, an interfaith minister who was ordained by the New Seminary, led a Muslim ceremony.

title: Corrections: August 17, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: Vows | Celebrity Stylists Wed on the Fly
description: Ted Gibson and Jason Backe, celebrity hairstylists who run Ted Gibson Beauty together, married flash mob style in a Manhattan park.

title: Transplant Brokers in Israel Lure Desperate Kidney Patients to Costa Rica
description: RAMAT GAN, Israel  Aside from the six-figure price tag, what was striking was just how easy it was for Ophira Dorin to buy a kidney.

title: An Impossible Wait List
description: Amos Canaf, founder of an advocacy group for renal patients, argues that the kidney shortage leaves patients with few choices other than to go overseas for a transplant.

title: Advocate for Deceased Organ Donation
description: Rabbi Shlomo Amar believes that recovering an organ from someone who is brain dead does not violate Jewish law.

title: Opposes Deceased Organ Donations
description: Rabbi Yeshayahu Heber set up an organization to promote living donation amongst Orthodox Jews but believes that organ donation by the brain dead violates Jewish law.

title: A Clash of Religion and Bioethics Complicates Organ Donation in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  In the Book of Genesis, it is written that when the great flood submerged the land it extinguished all in whose nostrils was the breath of life. Across nearly 2,000 years of Talmudic debate, Jewish scholars have returned to that verse in holding that life ends at the moment when breathing stops. One 19th-century code instructed that if a person appeared lifeless, a light feather was to be placed before his nose: If it does not flutter, the text advised, he is certainly dead.

title: Violence Flares in Ferguson After Appeals for Harmony
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Hours ahead of a second night of a mandatory curfew, the most chaotic violence in a week of unrest broke out here Sunday evening, with law enforcement officers facing off against angry protesters and responding to reports of gunfire and fire bombs.

title: Thousands in Hong Kong Rally in Support of China
description: HONG KONG  Tens of thousands of people marched under a blistering sun in Hong Kong on Sunday to express their opposition to a pro-democracy movement that has threatened to bring Asias biggest financial center to a standstill if the government does not open up the nomination process for electing the citys top leader.

title: After a Miscarriage, Seeking Permission to Grieve
description: It was at 11 weeks. Just the right amount of time to start to fall in love.

title: Reprogramming Government: A Conversation With Mikey Dickerson
description: President Obama owes Mikey Dickerson two debts of gratitude. Mr. Dickerson was a crucial member of the team that, in just six weeks, fixed the HealthCare.gov website when the two-year, $400 million health insurance project failed almost as soon as it opened to the public in October.

title: 1914: British Committee Helps Visitors in Paris
description: Thanks to the organization of the Information Committee of the British colony, several parties of British travellers arriving in Paris at the principal terminal stations were given valuable advice and help yesterday. In one case a party of thirteen Canadians was aided, and in many cases boarding-houses were recommended. Some English dancing girls who, owing to the present circumstances, had found themselves without help or employment, were looked after. The British Committee in Lucerne has been communicated with by telegraph and the services of the British Colony Committee, Paris, placed at its disposal as regards help to be extended to British visitors or residents arriving in Paris from that district. The New York Herald, European Edition, August 18, 1914

title: From Field to Front Office
description: Sergio Silva is one of a growing number of Hispanics who own or operate farms in the United States.

title: The Truth About Unmarried Moms
description: A new report shows that births to unmarried moms are down  and those unmarried women who do give birth are more likely than in previous years to live with a partner. And these findingscould change the way some people in America think and talk about family.

title: Readers Respond: Michael Brown and Black Men
description: As the nation bore witness to death and unrest in Ferguson, Mo., readers responded to what Charles Blow described in Thursdays column Michael Brown and Black Men as bigger than Michael Brown.

title: New Drug Helps Some Bald Patients Regrow Hair
description: The first thing Brian H. noticed was that he could grow a real beard. It had been years since that had been possible, years he spent bedeviled by hair loss on his head, face, arms and legs.

title: In the Bronx, an Unlikely Sanctuary for Birds, and People
description: Troy Lancaster lives in exile. In the Bronx. His relatives wont visit him, he says, because like a lot of folks with roots in the South, they are not keen on concrete, noise and narrow streets. He felt the same way in the 1980s when he moved to a stretch of Grant Avenue that had been reduced to an open-air drug market along a weed-choked street.

title: 1939: Tate Gallery Refuses Portrait by John Singer Sargent
description: LONDON  Art circles in London sought to discover today [Aug. 16] whether political motives lay behind the Tate Gallerys refusal to accept the late John Singer Sargents charcoal portrait of the Duke of Windsor as the Prince of Wales, a bequest to the museum by Sir Philip Sassoon, wealthy art patron and former First Commissioner of Works, who died in June. Although the Gallery trustees turned down the Windsor picture a week ago, they accepted Sassoons offer of another Sargent work, a portrait in oil of Sir Philip himself. Dr. John Rothenstein, director and keeper of the Tate Gallery, stoutly maintained today that the trustees decision was the result of consideration of the charcoal drawing purely on its merits as a work of art. He said it was not considered a good example of the artists work. Any suggestions that there was a prejudice against the personality or that there was an extraneous reason is entirely untrue, he said. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 17, 1939

title: Drawing the Line Between Soldier and Cop
description: Ferguson, Mo., has become a virtual war zone, write Elizabeth R. Beavers and Michael Shank in an Op-Ed for The New York Times. In the wake of the shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, outsize armored vehicles have lined streets and tear gas has filled the air. Officers dressed in camouflage uniforms from Fergusons 53-person police force have pointed M-16s at the very citizens they are sworn to protect and serve.

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center to Open a Summer Academy
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center is expected to announce on Monday that it will establish the Jazz at Lincoln Center Summer Jazz Academy, an intensive performance institute for high school musicians. The academy will be based at the Castleton Festival, the classical music and opera festival and summer training program that the conductor Lorin Maazel and his wife, Dietlinde Turban Maazel, founded in 2009 on their farm in Castleton, Va. (Mr. Maazel died in July; Mrs. Maazel has succeeded him as artistic director.)

title: United by Their Rough Edges
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Its difficult to think of Eminem  perhaps the most transformational pop music figure of the 2000s, and still a multiplatinum star  as a supplicant in need of a handout. But in 2014, he is merely a galaxy-size cult favorite, a 41-year-old white rapper far from the center of pop culture, leaning heavily on reputation and largely failing to innovate.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 10:05 P.M. (Showtime 2) THE CANYONS (2013) This low-budget, famously trashy film was supposed to herald the return of Lindsay Lohan (above, with James Deen) to respectability, or at least bankability. It didnt. But it was interesting. Written by the novelist Brett Easton Ellis (Less Than Zero, American Psycho) and directed by Paul Schrader (who wrote Taxi Driver and Raging Bull and directed American Gigolo), the movie is a dark, half-incoherent story about sex, movies and meaninglessness in Los Angeles. Every so often, wrote Manohla Dargis in The New York Times, Mr. Schrader manages to deliver a jolt, an image, a line reading and even a scene  like a narratively decisive down-and-dirty sexual four-way  that fleetingly lifts The Canyons. But his struggle is as palpable as his budgetary limitations.

title: In Wake of Indictment, Perry Defends Veto (and Criticizes Obama)
description: WASHINGTON  Rick Perry of Texas remained unrepentant on Sunday about a veto he made as governor that led to his indictment on charges of abuse of power, saying that if I had to do it again, I would make exactly the same decision.

title: Kurds Move to Retake Dam as U.S. Bombs Weaken ISIS
description: ALQOSH, Iraq  Seizing on the momentum of focused American airstrikes in recent days, Kurdish forces moved to retake the strategic Mosul Dam on Sunday night, in their most significant challenge yet to the Sunni militants advance in northern Iraq.

title: An Agent of Change
description: CLEVELAND  When Rich Paul was a boy, he would ride the bus here to the center of his hometown to treat himself to a $1 hot dog. One morning this month, he drove his Mercedes to the Ritz-Carlton Hotel and was halfway through his steak and eggs when his phone started dancing on the white tablecloth.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Ukraine Says Army Controls Center of a Rebel City
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The Ukrainian military on Sunday moved into the heart of the separatist hub of Luhansk for the first time, officials said, chipping at one of the cornerstones of the pro-Russia rebels disintegrating virtual state.

title: Liberia Expanding Space for Ebola Patient Care
description: Doctors Without Borders began accepting patients on Sunday at what is intended to be the organizations largest-ever Ebola treatment center, near Liberias capital, Monrovia.

title: Using a Tawdry 1990s Case to Put the Camera on Trial
description: Before Jodi Arias or Casey Anthony or even O. J. Simpson, there was Pamela Smart, and with her came the sort of hysteria that only a lurid trial can generate. A documentary on Monday night on HBO revisits the Smart case, a 1990 murder in New Hampshire that led to a televised trial the next year. The hair is bigger, but aside from that the goings-on and the news medias excesses could be from 2014.

title: In a Metropolis, a Messenger Bag Might Come in Handy
description: The Muppets took Manhattan in a 1984 movie. Curious George landed in a video game called Downtown Adventure in 2002. The worlds chattiest porker met the bright lights in 1998 in Babe: Pig in the City.

title: In Uncertain Times, a Suitors Rose Is Still Silver
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Strausss Der Rosenkavalier has arrived at the Salzburg Festival over the past 30 years with the regularity of a comet: 1984, 1995, 2004 and now 2014. Like clockwork, each decade has let us revisit this sprawling yet intimate opera, a paean to both nostalgia and transformation.

title: A Railroad Built Out of Prisoners Pain and Sweat
description: Of the horrors experienced by Allied soldiers, forced by their Japanese captors to build a railway between Thailand and Burma under appalling slave labor conditions, the hero of Richard Flanagans new novel observes that its impossible to convey the suffering, the deaths, the sorrow, the abject, pathetic pointlessness of such immense suffering by so many.

title: Encouraged by Defeat, Mets Stay Positive as Rookie Throws Aggressively
description: In the days leading up to his start Sunday against the Chicago Cubs, the rookie Rafael Montero and the Mets pitching coach, Dan Warthen, had a philosophical talk about Monteros approach in his first few major league games.

title: World Youth Teams Championships Unfold
description: ISTANBUL  At the 15th World Youth Teams Championships here, the final of the inaugural Kids Championship (under age 15) will be played Monday between France and Poland. In Sundays semifinals, France easily defeated Sweden by 137 international match points to 38. In the other match, Poland edged past China by 100 imps to 97.

title: The Expendables 3 Fumbles Its Mission
description: LOS ANGELES  Did prerelease piracy kill The Expendables 3, or was the culprit old-fashioned franchise fatigue?

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 18
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Monday and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Thanks to Pitchers, Yankees Finish Trip on an Upbeat Note
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The grim and near silent atmosphere in the visitors clubhouse Friday, when the hitting instructor Kevin Long noted that morale was low, suggested the dreary reality facing the Yankees.

title: Barbarians at the Art Auction Gates? Not to Worry
description: In one striking example, Jean-Michel Basquiats Warrior sold three times at auction between 2005 and 2012, the paintings price soaring during those seven years by 450 percent, to nearly $9 million.

title: My Life in Bicycles
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  MY Uncle Clarke woke me before dawn with a shake to the shoulder. He gave me a look that asked, You in? I nodded. I was in all right.

title: Edelman P.R. Firm Acts to Correct Faux Pas
description: A GIANT public relations agency that has been under fire for a couple of gaffes in the last couple of weeks says it is taking steps to try to make sure such blunders do not recur  the kinds of steps it would recommend to clients in the same predicaments.

title: For a Festival, Change Comes, Invited or Not
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  The Lucerne Festival, set in motion in 1938 by Arturo Toscanini, is one of Europes most venerable. Now, during Michael Haefligers term as executive and artistic director, change has become a way of life at the festival, which opened here on Friday.

title: The Pope Visits South Korea
description: Pope Francis began a five day visit in South Korea on Thursday.

title: The Witches, the Furies and Mozart
description: Witches and furies came out to dance on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall for a concert by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra under the direction of Louis Langre. Glucks Dance of the Furies, from the opera Orphe et Eurydice, and Berliozs Symphonie Fantastique, with its lurid Witches Sabbath, bookended the program. At its center: Mozarts pretty-as-a-porcelain-teacup Concerto for Flute and Harp with two polished and graceful soloists, the flutist Magali Mosnier and the harpist Xavier de Maistre.

title: Eclipsing a Fast-Food Clown With Beats and Break-Dancing
description: As anyone who has seen Pulp Fiction knows, a Royale with cheese is the name used in France for a McDonalds Quarter Pounder. But what is a McDonalds B-Boy Royale? In one sense, it is simply another competition between crews of B-boys (once known as break-dancers), this one sponsored by McDonalds.

title: Its a New Crown for Williams, but Its Old Hat to Federer in Ohio
description: MASON, Ohio  There are not many gaps in Serena Williamss theoretical trophy case, the shelves of which would already be bending under the weight of 61 WTA Tour singles titles.

title: Misfit
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Just a bit of prediscussion gushing: How cute is it when a married couple makes a puzzle? I dont know about you, but I just love that. Today, we get Ian Livengood and his lovely wife, Katie, who is making her debut.

title: Q. and A.: Wu Heng on Throwing Chinas Food Out the Window
description: I hope this book will make you feel that its time to throw unsafe food out the window.

title: The Music of 10,000 Nights
description: Is there a truism more rarely true than the notion that absence makes the heart grow fonder?

title: Experts Say a Second Work in Munich Was Looted
description: Two Riders on the Beach, above, a Max Liebermann painting found in the private collection of Cornelius Gurlitt, who died in early May, was wrongfully taken by the Nazis from the collection of its Jewish owner, a team of international experts has determined. Using archival material and other sources, the experts ascertained that the Liebermann painting rightfully belonged to the descendants of the industrialist David Friedmann, they said in a statement on Sunday. The work is only the second of 458 disputed paintings, prints and drawings in the collection, known as the Munich Art Trove, that the panel of experts, convened by the German government, has determined was looted. The other, a Matisse, was found in June to have been stolen from the collector Paul Rosenberg. Yet the Matisse has not been returned to Mr. Rosenbergs heirs, and the Liebermann is sure to face a similar fate, because of the legal limbo surrounding Mr. Gurlitts collection following his death. Although Mr. Gurlitt, the son of an art dealer who worked for the Nazis, left his collection to the Kunstmuseum Bern, it has not yet decided whether to accept the gift. An agreement signed between Mr. Gurlitt and German authorities binds the new owner to restitute any looted works, but that cannot happen until the gift is accepted. David Toren, a great-nephew of Mr. Friedmanns who lives in New York, filed a lawsuit against the German government in hopes of speeding the return of his familys art work. This is a very important first step in returning the painting to its rightful owners and we hope that the German government will not further delay returning the painting, Mr. Torens attorney, August J. Matteis Jr., said in a statement.

title: Emmys Go to Fallon, Orange and, Yes, HBO
description: HBO assumed its familiar role as the early leader in the Emmys race after taking home 15 Creative Arts awards this weekend, but a few new faces garnered notable wins as well. The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences bestowed the awards in a ceremony in Los Angeles on Saturday in categories like casting, editing, and animation. The ceremony precedes the major Emmys broadcast, which airs Aug. 25 on NBC. Game of Thrones and True Detective earned four awards apiece for HBO, but the most decorated show of the night was NBCs Saturday Night Live, which won half of that networks 10 awards. An episode hosted by Jimmy Fallon, below, was responsible for four of the trophies, including a win for Mr. Fallon as guest actor in a comedy series. Other guest acting awards went to Joe Morton in ABCs Scandal, Allison Janney in Showtimes Masters of Sex and Uzo Aduba, who took home one of the first three trophies for Netflixs series Orange Is the New Black for her breakout role as the inmate Suzanne Warren, known as Crazy Eyes. Zach Galifianakiss Between Two Ferns series on the comedy website Funny or Die won best short-format, live-action entertainment program for an episode in which Mr. Galifianakis interviewed President Obama.

title: Carnegie Hall Executive to Run Symphony Space
description: Symphony Space, the miniature arts center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is expected to announce on Monday that it has appointed Andrew Byrne as its artistic director. The space has been without a director since January, when the composer Laura Kaminsky left the post in a disagreement over programming. Mr. Byrne takes over on Sept. 15. Mr. Byrne, a 48-year-old Australian who came to New York in 1993 on a Fulbright Scholarship to complete his doctorate in music at Columbia University, has worked at Carnegie Hall for 10 years, eight of them as the director of festivals and special projects. Its a different model, Mr. Byrne said on Friday, obliquely acknowledging that Symphony Space gives him a smaller palette than Carnegie Hall. But we have performing arts, film and education programs within the house. What attracts me to Symphony Space is the opportunity not only to shape the full season, but also to shape the profile of the institution.

title: What Do You Remember From the First Time You Saw Pippin?
description: This summer, critics from The New York Times have been checking back in on some of Broadways biggest hits and longest runs. Theyre assessing the current state of several musicals, including The Phantom of the Opera, Mamma Mia!, The Book of Mormon, and Wicked and Pippin.

title: Trying to Ensure the Fundamental Right to Vote
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: View of #Ferguson Thrust Michael Brown Shooting to National Attention
description: Ferguson, Missouri, was just a place  a working-class suburb of St. Louis  before an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, was shot and killed by the police, before protests and looting erupted, before local forces responded with armored vehicles, tear gas and rubber bullets, and Ferguson became #Ferguson.

title: Despite a Turbulent Work Life, a Minister Doesnt Question Her Calling
description: The Rev. Dominique C. Atchison stood at the lectern in the church fellowship hall, her voice soaring, her body swaying. There were joyful and troubled hearts in the seats before her.

title: Court Filings From Arizona Prisoners Lawsuit
description: Prisoners on death row in Arizona brought a lawsuit against the states Department of Corrections in 2011, declaring that Arizonas lethal injection protocol violates the Eighth Amendment, or the right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Preseason Wind-Down? Not for a Giants Offense That Needs a Lot of Work
description: After three dreadful preseason performances by the Giants starting offensive unit, there are just two exhibition games left until the regular season. Typically, first-string players hardly appear in the final preseason game so they can rest and avoid injuries on the eve of the games that count.

title: Native Fantasy: Germanys Indian Heroes
description: Germanys biggest folk hero is an Apache named Winnetou who fights for justice outside of Hamburg. Best-selling author Karl May, who created him, never traveled to the American West.

title: Arizona Loose With Its Rules in Executions, Records Show
description: PHOENIX  In an execution in 2010 in Arizona, the presiding doctor was supposed to connect the intravenous line to the convicts arm  a procedure written into the states lethal injection protocol and considered by many doctors as the easiest and best way to attach a line. Instead he chose to use a vein in an upper thigh, near the groin.

title: In Ferguson, Black Town, White Power
description: POLITICS, wrote the political scientist Harold Lasswell in 1936, is about who gets what, when, and how. If you want to understand the racial power disparities weve seen in Ferguson, Mo., understand that its not only about black and white. Its about green.

title: Lost in Translation: Germanys Fascination With the American Old West
description: RADEBEUL, Germany  Hans Grunert is no stranger to requests from Native Americans regarding the display of sacred items among the headdresses, moccasins, jewelry and hundreds of other artifacts at the Karl May Museum, housed in a faux-log cabin behind a stately 19th-century villa in this eastern German town.

title: When Being Obsessed With Hillary Clinton Is Your Job
description: Amy Chozick is a national political reporter with a focus on covering Hillary Rodham Clinton. Since taking the beat a year ago, she has written on Mrs. Clintons regrets about Benghazi, on the super PACs that are raising money for her potential 2016 presidential campaign and about two musicals inspired by her life. Some have said she is obsessed with the Clinton story. We asked her about her experience.

title: Ice Bucket Challenge Has Raised Millions for ALS Association
description: Pete Frates can no longer speak. But in the last two and a half weeks, a video posted on Facebook by Mr. Frates, a 29-year-old former college baseball player, has inspired people like Bill Gates, LeBron James, Chris Christie and Taylor Swift to dump a bucket of ice on their heads and speak out for his cause.

title: Case in Which Abortion Was Denied Reignites Controversy Over Irish Law
description: DUBLIN  A young woman who was refused an abortion despite asserting that she was suicidal and protesting with a hunger strike has had her baby delivered by cesarean section in a case that has reignited the controversy over a relatively new Irish law that allows for abortion in limited circumstances.

title: Childhood Passion for Celebrity Still Drives the Editor of People Magazine, Jess Cagle
description: Last Monday, Jess Cagle, the new editor of People magazine, had just returned from a meeting in London with representatives of the royal family when he heard about Robin Williamss death. He ripped up the coming cover on Kate Middleton and ordered a 12-page spread on the comedian.

title: Jay Adams, Who Revolutionized Skateboarding, Dies at 53
description: Jay Adams, a member of the renowned Z-Boys team, which transformed skateboarding from a childish pastime into a raw and dangerous activity that is as much a lifestyle as it is a sport, died on Friday in Puerto Escondido, Mexico. He was 53.

title: Sophie Masloff, Ex-Mayor of Pittsburgh, Dies at 96
description: Sophie Masloff, a Democrat who campaigned with a big black pocketbook, charmed voters with homespun verbal gaffes and from 1988 to 94 was the first woman and the first Jew to serve as mayor of Pittsburgh, died on Sunday at a hospice in Mount Lebanon, Pa., a suburb of Pittsburgh. She was 96.

title: German Authors Join Protest Over Amazons Tactics in E-Book Dispute
description: BERLIN  Taking a page from their colleagues across the Atlantic, more than 1,000 writers from Germany, Austria and Switzerland have united to vent their frustration over the tactics Amazon is using against the Bonnier Group and the authors who are published under its name.

title: Why We Fight Wars
description: A century has passed since the start of World War I, which many people at the time declared was the war to end all wars. Unfortunately, wars just kept happening. And with the headlines from Ukraine getting scarier by the day, this seems like a good time to ask why.

title: Oil Industrys Taxes Create Odd Wedge for Alaskan Voters
description: ANCHORAGE  Many Alaskans chart state history along a timeline of before oil and after, so crucial were those first big strikes in the late 1960s in making the state what it is today. Now a proposal to shake up the way oil companies are taxed  headed for a vote Tuesday in a statewide referendum  has stirred a passionate public debate.

title: For Big-Data Scientists, Janitor Work Is Key Hurdle to Insights
description: Technology revolutions come in measured, sometimes foot-dragging steps. The lab science and marketing enthusiasm tend to underestimate the bottlenecks to progress that must be overcome with hard work and practical engineering.

title: Bank Overseer PwC Faces Penalty and Sidelining of Regulatory Consulting Unit
description: The giant consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers occupies a position of trust on Wall Street, acting as a shadow regulator of sorts that promises the government an impartial look inside the worlds biggest banks.

title: 2 Killed and Dozen Are Injured as Weekend Shootings Plague New York
description: The shootings followed a familiar pattern, erupting at outdoor gatherings and corner hangouts, in pockets of New York City long plagued by weekend violence that the Police Department has struggled to control.

title: Europes Recurring Malaise
description: No one should be surprised that the economy of the eurozone is once more going in reverse. This is an entirely predictable outcome of the misguided policies that European leaders stubbornly insist on pursuing, despite all evidence that they are exactly the wrong medicine.

title: PwCs Report, Before and After
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers was hired to prepare a report for regulators that detailed Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJs dealings with Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States. Bowing to pressure from the bank, PricewaterhouseCoopers watered down the report, documents show.

title: The Chasm Tilting Scots Toward Independence
description: MOFFAT, Scotland  David Mundell, the only Conservative Party member among 59 British lawmakers elected from Scotland, would love to have a colleague or two to help out with appearances on morning TV and radio shows.

description: With a photo and caption on Instagram last week, Stacy Peralta broke the news of the death of Jay Adams, which was somewhat appropriate given the many iconic images of the blond, tubular Adams that had helped spread the history of skateboarding and his tale of troubled fame.

title: The Verdict on a Troublesome Carcinogen
description: Formaldehyde, a substance widely used in consumer products and industrial processes, has been authoritatively judged a carcinogen despite the best efforts of the chemical industry to confuse the issue. A panel of experts convened by the National Academy of Sciences found sufficient evidence from human studies to declare formaldehyde a known human carcinogen that causes nasopharyngeal cancer, sinonasal cancer and myeloid leukemia. It also cited evidence from studies of animals and of carcinogenesis suggesting that formaldehyde may cause a much wider array of cancers than just those three.

title: The Displaced in Gaza
description: With 11,000 homes destroyed and many more damaged, a humanitarian crisis is just beginning.

title: In Torn Gaza, if Roof Stands, Its Now Home
description: GAZA CITY  Telltale signs of the displaced are everywhere in Gaza.

title: Lynxs Maya Moore Has Become a Leaner Scoring Machine
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The Monster  the nickname the Los Angeles Sparks interim coach, Penny Toler, pinned on Maya Moore of the Minnesota Lynx last week  fits Moores play better than it does her personality.

title: The Mayor, the Cops and the Chorus of Outrage
description: Former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani made one of his periodic unwelcome reappearances the other day, offering his advice to Mayor Bill de Blasio on the death of Eric Garner, the unarmed black man killed by the police on Staten Island for selling loose cigarettes.

title: A Critical New Role for the World Bank
description: A federal trial in Brooklyn is focusing anew on illicit money flows. Until now, federal crackdowns have targeted European banks that laundered dirty money into dollars for drug cartels and for sanctioned countries, like Iran. The Brooklyn case involves a bank headquartered in Jordan, called Arab Bank, which plaintiffs say handled transactions for people or organizations it knew were linked to terrorist attacks from 2001 to 2004.

title: In Silicon Valley, Mergers Must Meet the Toothbrush Test
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  When deciding whether Google should spend millions or even billions of dollars in acquiring a new company, its chief executive, Larry Page, asks whether the acquisition passes the toothbrush test: Is it something you will use once or twice a day, and does it make your life better?

description: The Williamsburg property, worth by one estimate just over $8 million, sits in Brooklyn on a prime corner of North First Street and Bedford Avenue, that hub of all things hip. It comes with plenty of private parking. It even boasts a miniature herb garden, tended by a local folk artist.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  When the financial crisis crippled the construction industry seven years ago, Joe DeGrellas contracting company failed, leaving him looking for what he hoped would be the last job he would ever need.

description: LEVERKUSEN, Germany  Markus Rehm, a long jumper, rocked forward and back and then took 18 strides down the track before he planted and took off, his body soaring some 25 feet through the air and landing with a splash of sand.

Jersey Boys is No. 60 and Get On Up: The James Brown Story is No. 61, compared with The Very Best of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons (No. 151), and 20 All-Time Greatest Hits! James Brown (No. 170).

title: Whats On TV Today
description: 4:10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) RUST AND BONE (2012) Ali (Matthias Schoenaerts), a former prizefighter fleeing with his young son (Armand Verdure) from a bad situation, arrives in Antibes on the Cte dAzur and becomes a bouncer at a nightclub, where he meets Stphanie (Marion Cotillard, above, with Mr. Schoenaerts), a trainer for a Sea World-like park. Then she loses her legs in an accident with a killer whale and calls Ali, thinking he might rouse her from her despair. The removal of Ms. Cotillards legs  including in scenes in which she wears a bathing suit or nothing  is surely one of the most impressive special-effects feats of the year, and a reminder that digital cinema is not all about accessorizing wizards, monsters and superheroes, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But the greater marvel is Ms. Cotillard herself, an actress of limitless bravery and supernatural poise, who is both beauty and beast. Mr. Schoenaerts is her perfect foil and complement, as large and coarse as she is small and delicate, and also as tender as she is tough.

description: The Metropolitan Operas efforts to cut its labor expenses have led to its most serious labor strife in three decades. Here is a look at some of the issues that were raised.

title: Pope Ends Trip With Plea for Korean Reconciliation
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Pope Francis wrapped up his five-day visit to South Korea on Monday with calls for forgiveness and renewed dialogue on the divided Korean Peninsula and for more humanitarian aid for North Korea.

description: Protests in Ferguson over the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager who was shot by a police officer on Aug. 9, erupted on Sunday, and The New York Times published an article on the results of a preliminary autopsy that said the teenager was hit six times.

title: Student Crossword | The 1950s
description: Test your knowledge of the 1950s by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Britain Says Iraq Campaign Will Last Weeks and Months
description: LONDON  As Kurdish forces in Iraq, backed by United States airstrikes, fought for strategic gains against Sunni militants, Britains defense minister was quoted on Monday as telling air force personnel that the campaign against the insurgents would last weeks and months and was no longer simply a humanitarian affair.

title: Missouri Tries Another Idea: Call In National Guard
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Missouri National Guard troops entered this battered city on Monday even as an overnight curfew was lifted, the latest in a series of quickly shifting attempts to quell the violence that has upended this St. Louis suburb for more than a week.

title: Zhang Tiesheng: From Hero Under Mao to Hero of Wealth
description: Once a hero of Mao Zedongs Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, Zhang Tiesheng is again being feted by the Chinese state news media, now as an embodiment of the countrys capitalist metamorphosis.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Be Free Strikes a Chord
description: In A Song Born When Pain Is Still Fresh, Ben Sisario writes about a song that has quickly ricocheted around the Internet.

title: Women Beyond the Veil in Mali
description: There are no beds in the small concrete home Madame Gassamba shares with her four teenage daughters. When night falls, cushions pushed against the spotted walls serve as makeshift beds. Everyday items are strategically stored away for additional space in the one-room home.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Jake Halpern on Debt, HBO and His Mother
description: Jake Halpern, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote the Aug. 17 cover story on an unlikely duo that collects credit-card debt after it has been sold off by banks. The article is adapted from Bad Paper: Chasing Debt From Wall Street to the Underworld, to be published by Farrar Straus and Giroux in October.

title: British Construction Giant Carillion Clarifies Statement on Estimated Merger Savings
description: LONDON  The British construction and support services company Carillion on Monday clarified comments made by its chairman, who had indicated in a newspaper interview that cost-savings estimates for a merger with its rival Balfour Beatty had been audited.

title: Macau Scholar Says He Lost His Job Over Pro-Democracy Activism

description: Good morning on this reasonably cool Monday.

description: Technology revolutions come in measured, sometimes foot-dragging steps. The lab science and marketing enthusiasm tend to underestimate the bottlenecks to progress that must be overcome with hard work and practical engineering, Steve Lohr reports.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: Medicare Advantage Is More Expensive, but It May Be Worth It
description: Medicare Advantage plans  private plans that serve as alternatives to the traditional, public program for those that qualify for it  underperform traditional Medicare in one respect: They cost 6 percent more.

title: Who Needs A Room? The Lobby Has Drama
description: SALZBURG, Austria  About a week ago, I was chatting at the Salzburg Festival with a friend who had seen the German director Sven-Eric Bechtolfs recent staging of Wagners Ring cycle in Vienna. I hated it, he said. But I cant remember why.

title: Julian Assange Says He Will Leave Embassy Soon
description: LONDON  Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, who was given asylum in the Ecuadorean Embassy here two years ago, said Monday that he will be leaving the embassy soon, but he provided no specifics.

title: Rival Bids for Family Dollar Stores as Retailers Fight to Sell to Working Poor
description: Updated, 9:30 p.m. | As more struggling Americans hit the bargain bins to get by, a bidding war is brewing for one of the countrys biggest deep-discount retailers.

title: China Says Mercedes-Benz Violated Antitrust Rules in Pricing
description: HONG KONG  Government investigators in China have found the Mercedes-Benz unit of Daimler, the German automaker, in violation of antitrust price rules, the Chinese state news media reported on Monday. The announcement was the latest in a spate of inquiries over pricing and sales policies that have raised pressure on foreign corporations across China.

title: What to Wear This Week: Aug. 18
description: Labor Day is two weeks away. Youve probably already grown sick of most of your summer outfits, and its still a bit too early to break out those fall items hanging, teasing you from your closest.

title: Improving Your Public Relations (Without a Public Relations Firm)
description: Like many entrepreneurs, Ive learned that regular press coverage can have an impact on my data-analysis companys visibility and growth. As such, Ive spent the past several years figuring out ways to get RJMetrics mentioned in major media outlets, and in doing so have steadily turned public relations into one of our best sources of leads. And weve done this without a pricey public relations firm.

title: Sensata Technologies to Acquire Maker of Tire Pressure Sensors
description: Sensata Technologies said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the Schrader group of companies from the private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners. The enterprise value of the transaction is $1 billion.

title: Metropolitan Opera and Two Unions Reach a Tentative Deal
description: The Metropolitan Opera reached tentative agreements early Monday morning with the unions representing its orchestra and chorus after an all-night bargaining session, and called off its threat to lock out workers a little more than a month before the new season is set to open.

title: Excerpts From Arizona Doctors Deposition on Executions
description: Following are excerpts from a deposition on Oct. 21, 2011, by an Arizona doctor who attended five executions as a medical team leader that sheds light on a process that is rarely presented in detail. The executions were between October 2010 and July 2011.

title: Scores Killed in Flooding in Nepal and India
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  The death toll from days of heavy rainfall and flooding in Nepal and India rose to more than 150 on Monday, according to officials in Nepal and India.

title: Troops in Iraq Rout Sunni Militants From a Key Dam
description: WASHINGTON  Iraqi and Kurdish ground troops overran Sunni militants and reclaimed Iraqs largest dam on Monday, President Obama said, as American warplanes unleashed a barrage of bombs in an expansion of the limited goals laid out by the president in authorizing the military campaign in Iraq.

title: Morning Agenda: Battle for Family Dollar
description: Dollar General said on Monday that it was offering $8.9 billion to buy Family Dollar Stores in an effort to break up its Family Dollars planned merger with Dollar Tree, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes. Under the terms of the deal, Dollar General would pay $78.50 a share in cash, significantly higher than the $74.50 a share that Dollar Trees original cash-and-stock bid was worth when it was announced last month. Including debt, Dollar Generals offer is valued at $9.7 billion.

title: Symphony Space Names Andrew Byrne as Artistic Director
description: Symphony Space, the Upper West Side arts center, is expected to announce on Monday that it has appointed Andrew Byrne as its artistic director. The space has been without a director since January, when the composer Laura Kaminsky left the post in a disagreement over programming. Mr. Byrne takes over on Sept. 15.

title: Now Booking | A Ladies Hotel Open to All
description: The Martha Washington hotel, built in 1903 to house unmarried women, will reopen in September in New Yorks NoMad neighborhood, with austere new interiors by Annabelle Selldorf. Our design for the hotel was very much influenced by the spirit of large, open spaces at the turn of the century, says the architect, who updated the Renaissance Revival landmark with a walnut palette, blue tile floors and tons of glass to offset the spaces gothic fluted columns. Danny Meyer will also be opening Marta, a restaurant serving rustic Italian food, yet another fitting nod to the Washingtons namesake, who was known for being an expert hostess.

title: Saudi Is Robbed in Paris, Quickly and Efficiently
description: PARIS  The brazen robbery had all the elements of a Hollywood thriller: a commando-style ambush, a suitcase stuffed with cash, mysterious stolen documents, and an anonymous member of the Saudi royal family heading to the airport.

title: 1914: Lord Kitchener Sends Messages
description: LONDON  The following instructions have been issued by Lord Kitchener to every soldier in the expeditionary army:  You are ordered abroad as a soldier of the King to help our French comrades against the invasion of a common enemy. You have to perform a task which will need your courage, your energy, your patience. Remember that the honor of the British army depends on your individual conduct.  In this new experience you may find temptation, both in wine and women. You must entirely resist both temptations, and, while treating all women with perfect courtesy, you should avoid intimacy. Do your duty bravely. Fear God; honor the King. (Signed) KITCHENER. Field Marshal.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 19, 1914

title: Ingersoll-Rand Buys Cameron Unit for $850 Million
description: Ingersoll-Rand has agreed to acquire Cameron Internationals centrifugal compression division for $850 million.

title: Rebels Killed Dozens in Attack on Refugees, Ukraine Says
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Separatist rebels on Monday attacked a caravan of cars carrying refugees trying to flee war-ravaged eastern Ukraine, killing dozens of people in a devastating barrage of artillery fire, Ukrainian military officials said, though rebel leaders denied there had been any attack at all.

title: A Mission Chinese Chef Pops up in Copenhagen, the FYF Fest in Los Angeles and More From the Cultural Calendar
description: Ts list of things to see and do in the week ahead.

title: XRay: A New Tool for Tracking the Use of Personal Data on the Web
description: A real problem with personal data today is that the terms of trade so often seem both opaque and askew. Browse for information, send messages or go shopping online and data about you, your habits and your preferences go off into the digital ether.

title: Departures Mount in Executive Ranks of Steven Cohens Family Office
description: Steven A. Cohens investment firm has undergone many changes this year: a new purpose, a new name and a number of departures.

title: Son of Jackie Chan Arrested on Drug-related Charges, Chinese Media Report
description: Updated, 10:07 a.m. ET| The current crackdown on drugs in China has ensnared one of its highest-profile celebrities yet, with Chinese state media reporting on Monday that Jaycee Chan, the actor and son of the Hong Kong movie star Jackie Chan, had been arrested in Beijing on drug-related charges.

title: Aide Describes Staff Revolt Against Former Virginia Governors Wife
description: RICHMOND, Va.  A longtime aide to former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia on Monday portrayed the governors wife, Maureen, as an unstable, angry woman who flirted with the businessman who lavished the couple with gifts allegedly in exchange for promoting his business.

title: Chinese Media Weigh In on Aftermath of Missouri Shooting
description: In the days following the shooting death of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., Chinese state media maintained a relative silence on the case, even as large protests and what many critics say was a heavy-handed official response attracted international attention.

title: With Nadal Out, Mystery Rules Mens Field at U.S. Open
description: Rafael Nadal announced his withdrawal from the United States Open on Monday because of an injured right wrist, costing the tournament its defending mens champion.

title: Aug. 18: Developments in the Police Shooting in Missouri
description: The New York Times is providing regular updates in the aftermath of a police shooting in Ferguson, Mo., that has caused unrest.

title: In Alaska Primary, Outlook Is Murky
Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Allison & Partners, part of MDC Partners, hired four senior executives. Three are based in New York: Jill Feldman, vice president for corporate practice; Corey Martin, managing director of the consumer practice group; and Kevin Nabipour, senior vice president for content strategies. The fourth, Marcel Goldstein, will be based in Washington, joining the agencys corporate practice as a senior vice president.

title: After Hong Kong March, Speculation Over Payments and Motivations
description: The aftermath of a mass gathering is not always pretty, be it the Woodstock festival or annual July 1 pro-democracy march in Hong Kong. To some extent, disorder and litter are inevitable.

title: From the Bronx, to Queens, Then Park Slope and Riverdale
description: With the move this summer of New Yorks first family from Park Slope to the Upper East Side, City Room is taking a look at the migration of New Yorkers from one neighborhood to another. Martin Kleinman shared his story, tell us yours here.

title: 1964: U.S. Financing for Africa Force
description: LEOPOLDVILLE  The United States today appeared ready to underwrite an African peace-keeping operation in the Congo. The U.S. position was outlined at a press conference by G. Mennen Williams, U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs. Asked if the United States would contribute to the cost of maintaining African troops in the Congo, Mr. Williams said the U.S. government would try to do what was helpful in that regard. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 19, 1964

title: Finra Says Wedbush Securities Failed to Detect Manipulative Trades
description: A Wall Street regulator accused Wedbush Securities on Monday of failing to adequately supervise its customers as it gave them access to the stock market.

title: Easy on the Environment, but Not Necessarily the Eyes
description: When Thomas Paino, an architect, decided to remodel a rowhouse he had bought in Long Island City, Queens, his ambitions were nothing short of trying to save the world  at least so far as a two-family home could contribute to the cause.

title: Altered Bank Study Draws Fine for Giant Auditor PwC
description: New York States financial regulator announced a settlement deal on Monday with the giant consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, capping an investigation into the firms cozy ties with one of the worlds biggest banks.

title: The Sudanese Soul Stylings of Sinkane
description: Usually, your first records are more pop and easy to listen to, explains Ahmed Gallab, the singer and multi-instrumentalist known as Sinkane. Then, as you grow as an artist, you get bored and start making abstract art music. Everyone from the Beatles to Radiohead did that. Me, Ive kind of constructed my career backwards. Following two arty, largely instrumental releases, Sinkanes 2012 album Mars (its first on the tastemaking DFA imprint) was a breakthrough, combining African-inflected rhythms, complex melodic textures and Gallabs seductively tuneful voice.

title: New Republican Leader Finds New Friends, and Quick Cash
Book Review Podcast: Abandon Ship!
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Robert R. Harris reviews Hampton Sidess In the Kingdom of Ice: The Grand and Terrible Polar Voyage of the USS Jeannette, about a disastrous expedition to the North Pole, funded by the newspaper owner James Gordon Bennett Jr. and led by a young Navy lieutenant named George Washington De Long. Mr. Harris writes:

title: Video Reviews of The Giver, Abuse of Weakness and Frank
description: In this weeks video, Times critics review The Giver, Abuse of Weakness and Frank. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: More Clashes With Police in Ferguson
description: The Missouri State Highway Patrol said it faced coordinated attacks in Ferguson on Sunday, but a protester said the demonstrations were peaceful.

title: What Happens When Robots Write the Future?
description: If recent talk about robots taking over our jobs has you scared, Jess Zimmerman has a solution: Let the robots think about the future for you.

title: Viral Video Parents and Non-Photo Sharers Debate
description: Ever wonder what the father from the David after the dentist video thinks of his viral sensation? Or the (clearly more intentioned) father who danced with his children in their #Xmas Jammies video? They add their voices as Room for Debate considers Children and Digital Privacy. Is sharing videos and pictures a violation of a childs right to privacy, or a simple act to remain connected to friends and family?

title: The Top Cat in These Ads Has an Attitude
description: There is a veritable Noahs ark of animals serving as pitchbeasts for Madison Avenue, particularly in the pet products category. But a character that represents a new line of cat litter is turning the conventions of spokescritters inside out. Instead of an animal with human qualities, the character is a human with animal qualities.

title: In Five Years, a Federal Prosecutor Has Taken On Terrorism, Corruption and Cuomo
description: The interview on public radio this April, a long-planned event to discuss a range of topics, seemed like a garden-variety appearance for Preet Bharara, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan.

title: Gordon Hamilton and Ariadnes String
description: Our challenge this week was suggested by regular contributor Gordon Hamilton, a Calgary-based math educator who uses this problem in eighth-grade classrooms. (Check out Dr. Hamiltons inspiring work at mathpickle.com.) The challenge is based on the eponymous Greek myth in which Ariadne gives the hero Theseus a thread to help him navigate the Labyrinth.

title: Five to Follow | A Floral Designers Lush Instagram, Communes Insidery Design Tumblr and More
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: India Cancels Talks After Pakistani Envoy Meets With Separatists
description: NEW DELHI  India called off planned talks with Pakistan on Monday after Pakistans top diplomat in New Delhi met with separatist leaders from Kashmir in defiance of an Indian warning, officials here said.

title: Fight for Maker of Botox Tests Scope of Insider Trading Laws
description: The disclosure that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Pershing Square Capital Management violated securities laws by purchasing shares of Allergan, the maker of Botox, ahead of a takeover offer by Valeant Pharmaceuticals raises the question once again of how far the prohibition on insider trading ought to extend.

title: Emmys 2014: What Is Your Pick for Top Comedy?
description: In advance of the Emmy Awards on Aug. 25, were asking you to tell us who deserved their nominations and who else should have been nominated. Next up is best comedy series. Take a look at this alternate list  its made up of the actual nominees; popular and critical favorites that werent nominated; and my own choices. Cast your votes in the comments, and let us know whos still been left out.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Aug. 12-18, 2014
description: Take the quiz to see what you know about the news stories below, and to find links to more information about each.

title: Hybrid Magazine-Cookbooks Put Recipes at the Fore
description: The small food magazine is a species on the rise. A number have arrived in recent years, like Lucky Peach, with its smarts and swagger, and Kinfolk, an ethereal and arty vision of food as lifestyle.

title: Behind Closed Doors, Obama Crafts Executive Actions
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced in June that he planned to bypass congressional gridlock and overhaul the nations immigration system on his own, he did so in a most public way: a speech in the White House Rose Garden.

title: Today in Small Business: A Start-Up About Nothing
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Whitney Museum to Open Mondays for Koons Retrospective
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art has been having trouble keeping up with the demand to see Jeff Koons: A Retrospective, an exhibition that fills most of the museums space and was described by Roberta Smith in The New York Times as the most cogent account of Mr. Koonss career in over two decades. And it may be that museumgoers want a last chance to walk through the Whitney as it is currently constituted, before the museum leaves its Marcel Breuer building for its new home, designed by Renzo Piano, in the meatpacking district.

title: Jana Says It Received Anonymous Tip in PetSmart Campaign
description: The activist hedge fund Jana Partners has added an anonymous package to its arsenal in a campaign for change at PetSmart.

title: The Times Used 25 Unnamed Sources in 7 Days, a Reuters Critic Says
description: Journalists arent known for their long attention spans and I must admit that Im no exception. So in recent weeks, Ive slacked off in my efforts to keep track of anonymous quotation and sourcing in The Times. (I also grew tired of the sound of my own voice crying in the wilderness.)

title: Uber Wins a Reprieve in Berlin
description: LONDON  Uber is back in business in Berlin, at least for now.

title: Jewish Film Festival to Return to London Theater
description: The Tricycle Theater in London and the UK Jewish Film Festival have resolved their dispute over funding and the conflict in Gaza that led to the festivals not being held at that theater this year, according to a joint statement posted on the festivals website. The theater and the festival, the statement said, have had lengthy discussions and have agreed to work together to rebuild their relationship. But the 2014 festival, to be held in November, will not take place at the Tricycle.

title: An Insiders Guide to CrossFit
