description: In the video, Nicole Carroll is grimacing, tears welling in her eyes. Shes in the final set of a workout  three rounds of 50 squats, seven muscle-ups (pull-ups on two overhead gymnastic rings) and 10 lifts of a 95-pound weight from hip to shoulder level.

title: The Intelligent-Life Lottery
description: Almost 20 years ago, in the pages of an obscure publication called Bioastronomy News, two giants in the world of science argued over whether SETI  the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence  had a chance of succeeding. Carl Sagan, as eloquent as ever, gave his standard answer. With billions of stars in our galaxy, there must be other civilizations capable of transmitting electromagnetic waves. By scouring the sky with radio telescopes, we just might intercept a signal.

title: Flawed President Who Dared to Dream
description: ASHLAND, Ore.  Christ, I feel like a catfish thats bit a big juicy worm only to find a right sharp hook in the middle of it, says Lyndon B. Johnson in The Great Society, the second part of Robert Schenkkans sprawling dramatization of Johnsons tumultuous years in the White House. As the play opens, Johnson has just been elected to a full presidential term, but theres no time for a celebratory fishing trip, because hes already facing a full slate of problems.

title: Assange to Leave Embassy in London Soon
description: After spending two years in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, cited health reasons for his decision to soon leave.

title: Go Ahead, Spice Up Your Investing Life
description: Im bored.

title: Doctor Who and the Eyebrows of Peter Capaldi
description: Its not as rare as, say, a total solar eclipse or the alignment of the planets, but the arrival of a new star on Doctor Who is still a significant galactic event, at least to fans of that long-running BBC science-fiction series. Last summer Matt Smith announced that he was leaving the lead role of the enigmatic time-and-space adventurer known as the Doctor, and the BBC said that he would be succeeded by Peter Capaldi, the Scottish actor best known to British audiences (and some Americans as well) as Malcolm Tucker, the explosively vulgar government official in the political satire The Thick of It and the film In the Loop.

title: TV Series as Inspiration for Symphony Season
description: One World Symphonys 2014-15 season will feature mashups of classical and contemporary music inspired by three popular television shows: Foxs New Girl, HBOs Game of Thrones and NBCs Hannibal.

title: Getting Groovy With Reactive Android
description: Slow, a word no one ever wants to see associated with their app. Delay and lag of as little as 100200 milliseconds will be perceived by users as poor, slow performance. Keeping long running tasks on the main thread will result in that perception, the dreaded Application Not Responding (ANR) and a bad user experience. This leaves us developers one choice: concurrent execution of code. The recent growth in popularity of functional programming is well deserved. As things become more asynchronous, the functional model really fits well. Being able to sequence, chain and transform asynchronous operations can be considered a must. However, the mechanisms for asynchronous programming provided in Android leave much to be desired, especially when compared to the web development realm. Many of the ideas and techniques from enterprise Java frameworks have not yet migrated to the Android world. Practices that some would consider table stakes for web development on the JVM have just begun to trickle in on Android; dependency management and a modern build system, for example. We can even dream of one day receiving proper support for unit tests.

title: From Tree Planting Along a Dirt Road to Car-Free Village Living
description: Some readers may have noticed a prolonged hiatus here, only half of which was because of a brief escape to Winter Harbor, Me., my mother in laws birthplace and home. The other half was because of my familys first move in 17 years  from a 1930s-era farm house on a dirt road to a brick home less than eight miles away, built in the 1860s in the village of Nelsonville, N.Y., by two Civil War veterans.

title: Turkey Expresses Outrage at Reports of Routine Spying by Germany, a NATO Ally
description: BERLIN  After angrily insisting for months that friends dont spy, the German government struggled Monday to respond to news media reports that its intelligence services routinely spy on Turkey, a NATO ally, and inadvertently captured at least one conversation each involving Hillary Rodham Clinton when she was secretary of state and her successor, John Kerry.

title: One Family Faces the Immigration Debate
description: With comprehensive immigration reform on hold in Congress, Nancy Paredos family is waiting on a promise from President Obama to take executive action. Heres a look at some steps he might take.

title: Iraqi Forces Recapture Mosul Dam
description: Lt. Gen. Qassim al-Moussawi, an Iraqi Army spokesman, said on Monday that security forces had retaken control of the Mosul dam from Islamic State in Iraq and Syria militants.

title: Alan Harding, a Brooklyn Restaurant Pioneer, Reshapes His Career
description: A couple of weeks ago, Alan Harding, the formerly quasi-famous chef, was conducting business on an old couch abandoned on the sidewalk near the Bedford Hill Coffee Bar in Brooklyn. The couch had been tossed out in the trash, but Mr. Harding had shamelessly reclaimed it as a temporary office. It was 9 a.m. and as curious coffee drinkers watched him from the windows, he sucked on a Dominican cigar and turned with a puff to the legal pad on which he had written a to-do list.

title: Lypsinka Returns With a Trilogy
description: Lypsinka, the lip-synching drag alter ego of the performer John Epperson, will return to the New York stage this fall for the first time in nine years in Lypsinka! The Trilogy, the shows producers announced on Monday.

title: Among the Poor, Women Feel Inequality More Deeply
description: The attention paid to income and wealth inequality spurred by the French economist Thomas Pikettys best-selling opus, Capital in the Twenty-First Century, comes with a caveat from some of its fans: What about women?

title: Plaza Hotel in Spotlight Again With Reported Bid by Sultan of Brunei
description: For a century, the Plaza Hotel stood as a symbol of New Yorks upper-crust glamor.

title: Fantasy Football: Preseason Stock Watch, Week 2
description: As we explained last week, preseason football is important in fantasy football analysis, but only if youre looking for the right things. Here is a look at the second week of preseason football and which players have helped or hurt their fantasy value.

title: These Coats Are Made for Walking
description: So lightweight and beautifully made, they do all the work.

title: In Iraq and Ukraine, Will History Repeat Itself?
description: Worlds apart, two leaders are planning to intervene in worsening conflicts outside their borders, and citing humanitarian concerns as their rationale. In Iraq, President Barack Obama and his administration are considering how to contain the violent march of radical Islamist militants and provide help to those whom the Islamists threaten with extermination. In the conflict in eastern Ukraine, Russian President Vladimir Putin sent a convoy of 280 trucks with what the Russians describe as humanitarian aid for the embattled region.

title: Aphex Twin Teases a New Album via Blimp, Spray Paint and the Deep Web
description: The reclusive electronic music producer Richard D. James, who works under the name Aphex Twin, has hinted that he may be preparing to release his first collection of new music since his 2001 album Drukqs.

title: Arms and the Cop
description: I wrote on police militarization over the weekend, taking what suddenly seems to be the consensus view that the spread of military gear and tactics to ordinary police departments has gone too far. Given how things went over the weekend in Ferguson, Missouri, with last nights chaos and this mornings news that the state is sending in the states national guard, its worth engaging with a contrary view, so here is the HotAir blogger Jazz Shaws case that police militarization in some form is both inevitable and necessary:

title: All Across America, Artists Are Taking Over Billboards
description: Visual pollution. Sky trash. Litter on a stick. The junk mail of the American highway. Thats how billboards are described on the website of Scenic America, a group devoted to preserving and enhancing the visual character of the country. But while preservationists deride the billboard, artists have long been intrigued by it for its role in American highway culture. (Besides, what artist wouldnt want a 300-square-foot canvas with a guaranteed audience?)

title: Walkabout: Travel Industry Grapples with Smokings Shifting Winds
description: Lighting Up With the legalization of recreational marijuana use in some states and the increasing popularity of electronic cigarettes, hotels and car rental companies struggle to deal with new trends in smoking. (The Washington Post)

title: Bitcoins Price Falls 12%, to Lowest Value Since May
description: Updated, 8:04 p.m. | Bitcoins price has been known to surge, but lately it has been in a bit of a slump.

title: Follow the Tweets From Ferguson
description: These Times reporters are on the scene covering the unrest in Ferguson, Mo. For updates, follow their Twitter feeds:

title: Hack of Community Health Systems Affects 4.5 Million Patients
description: Community Health Systems, a publicly traded hospital operator based in Franklin, Tenn., said that personal data, including names, Social Security numbers and addresses, for 4.5 million patients had been compromised in a Chinese cyberattack on its systems from April to June.

title: Private Autopsy Report on Michael Brown
description: Prof. Shawn L. Parcells, a pathologist assistant, explained the Brown familys independent preliminary autopsy report that showed at least six bullet wounds in the body of the slain teenager.

title: Seeing Purpose and Profit in Algae
description: Entrepreneurs have been trying for years to get something valuable out of algae.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Deepens Investigation of Honda Accord Air Bags
description: Federal regulators have intensified an investigation into the inadvertent deployment of side air bags on 2008 Honda Accords. The action comes as owners of Accords from the 2003-4 and 2008 model years face a deadline next month to file claims in a class-action suit over a similar problem.

title: Heather Graham Bows Out of New Neil LaBute Play
description: Late last month MCC Theater announced with some fanfare that it would open its season with The Money Shot, a new dark comedy by its resident playwright, Neil LaBute, with Heather Graham in one of the starring roles. But over the weekend, barely two and a half weeks before the production was scheduled to open for previews, Deadline first reported that Ms. Graham had bowed out to concentrate on the film Half Magic, which she wrote and will direct and star in. The television and film actress Elizabeth Reaser (True Detective and The Good Wife) will replace her, a spokesman for the production said on Monday.

title: Family of Michael Brown Says Autopsy Confirmed Witness Account
description: Lawyers for the family of Michael Brown said Monday that the preliminary results of an independent autopsy answered basic questions that had gone unanswered since the fatal confrontation between Mr. Brown, 18, and a police officer on Aug. 9.

title: A Start on No Days Rest Almost Rescues the Mets
description: Early Monday, Bartolo Colon learned that his mother, Adriana Morales, who earlier this year had been found to have breast cancer, was gravely ill. Colon, the scheduled starter for the Mets series finale against the Chicago Cubs, immediately left for the Dominican Republic to be by his mothers side.

title: Monday Motorsports: Power Moves Closer to Elusive IndyCar Title
description: Will Power held off the fast-closing Juan Pablo Montoya by 2.794 seconds at the finish of the IndyCar race in Milwaukee on Sunday and now is in better position of winning his first series championship. Before the race, Power estimated that he would have to win two of the remaining three races this season to clinch the title. The races remaining include one in Sonoma, Calif., on Sunday and another on Aug. 30 in Fontana, Calif. Power has a 39-point lead over Helio Castroneves in the standings.

title: At Manhattan Trade Show, an Unexpected Display
description: New Yorkers conflicting attitudes about the recent fighting between Israel and the militant group Hamas bubbled up unexpectedly on Saturday at a Manhattan trade show featuring the work of international artisans. In two separate incidents at Artisan Resource at NY Now, which runs through Tuesday on Pier 94, visitors created a disturbance at the booth of the Sulafa Embroidery Center from Gaza, a nonprofit organization founded in 1950 by a United Nations agency that employs impoverished refugee women to produce items like shawls, decorative pillows and Christmas ornaments.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Egypt, Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: An 800-Year-Old Shot of Youth
description: One hot day in 2004, Stefan Bloodworth and his 7-year-old son, Ethan, left a beaten path on their familys North Carolina homestead and stumbled right into horticultural history.

title: Ebola, Nurses for Africa, Seafood Apps, a Doctors Honor
description: Global Health

title: Bids for Family Dollar Leave Money on the Table
description: Dollar store mergers, it turns out, dont come cheap.

title: In Performance | Gunn and Magnussen
description: Anna Gunn and Billy Magnussen in a scene from the Laura Eason play Sex With Strangers, about a female novelist and her relationship with a young blogger. The show is at Second Stage Theater.

title: Stores Are Boarded Up but Open for Business in Ferguson
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  It is not typical for Maverick, a giant schnauzer, to guard the back door of Dan McMullens insurance agency here on West Florissant Avenue.

title: Wall Street Escapes Blame, Again
description: The news last week brought two fresh reminders of the governments failure to hold Wall Street accountable for the financial crisis. On Tuesday, the Timess Matthew Goldstein reported that an arbitration panel of three former judges had found no basis for a malpractice claim against Ernst & Young, the auditor of Lehman Brothers.

title: Humans of New York Goes Global
description: When Brandon Stanton, the photographer behind the enormously popular website Humans of New York, landed this month in Erbil, Iraq, he had no idea that chaos was about to engulf the city.

title: The Richard III Diet: Wild Birds, Frequent Feasts and Plenty of Wine
description: It is good to be king, even if only for two years. British researchers analyzing the bones of Richard III have found that Shakespeares most nefarious royal lived high on the hog after taking the throne, at age 30, in 1483. Even by the lofty standards of the nobility, he dined sumptuously and drank lavishly, judging by chemical traces left in his skeleton and examined, using multi-isotope techniques, by scientists at the British Geological Survey and the University of Leicester. Their findings were posted online by the Journal of Archaeological Science.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Dark Spots in Our Knowledge of Neptune
Pacific Octopus Holds Egg-Brooding Record
description: A Pacific deep-sea octopus called Graneledone boreopacifica has been found to have an egg-brooding cycle of 53 months  the longest period that any animal is known to protect its eggs.

title: Frolicking to Abba on a Greek Isle Retains Sweetness, if Not Shine
description: Theyre not dancing in the aisles at Mamma Mia! anymore.

title: All It Really Needs Is a Fairy Godmother
description: Take one put-upon, virtuous girl and test her steadfastness in love. Add a flamboyant, jealous witch. Stir in a case of mistaken identity, one mixed-up pair of lovers and spirited sidekicks. Sprinkle on liberal doses of magic.

title: Put Your Best Trick Forward (and Dont Forget the Spunk and Sass)
description: Magic and television are not a natural fit. In our cynical age, were inclined to write off a good illusion as a mere camera trick. But some series have overcome that credibility gap in one way or another, and on Tuesday Wizard Wars, on Syfy, becomes the latest to try, using a competition format and an emphasis on magic done with everyday objects.

title: Legal Marijuana for Parents, but Not Their Kids
description: When the antidrug educator Tim Ryan talks to students, he often asks them what they know about marijuana. Its a plant, is a common response.

title: Doctor Assists in Translation Emergency, but Passes on Medical Plea
description: IVE been flying most of my career. Im a professor, focusing on energy, especially natural gas policy and energy security. I serve as an adviser to a number of governments on their energy policies and frequently speak at international conferences.

title: Her Past: A Child Star in the Worst Kind of Film
description: Unless Chelsea Cains 2004 The Hippie Handbook: How to Tie-Dye a T-Shirt, Flash a Peace Sign, and Other Essential Skills for the Carefree Life was a lot grislier than it sounds, Ms. Cain discovered her dark side very suddenly. In 2007 she made a major debut on the crime scene with Heartsick, a hot-blooded thriller that was not for the faint of heart. Heartsick was the start of a series about Gretchen Lowell, a beautiful, exceptionally cruel serial killer, and Archie Sheridan, the cop who pursued her. Something about the way Gretchen drove nails into Archies rib cage during the long, long days they spent together left him hopelessly in love with her.

title: Chase Rice, Sam Hunt and Dr. John Release New Albums
description: CHASE RICE

title: Festival With Sunset and Harbor as Backdrop
description: In its 33rd year, the Downtown Dance Festival has a new viewpoint, at least physically. Its free outdoor performances have moved into Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park at the bottom tip of Manhattan. The temporary stage is backed by the harbor, passing ships, Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty. As the sun sank through the opening show early Sunday evening, it all looked postcard perfect.

title: Trying to Contain Ebola in Liberia
description: John Moore volunteered to cover the Ebola epidemic in Liberia, where the risks and challenges are many.

title: Man Who Helped Long Island Counselor to Kill Himself Makes Plea Deal, Lawyer Says
description: It has been five years since a self-help motivational speaker from Long Island hired a man in East Harlem to help him commit suicide and make it look like a murder.

title: Weighing Pradaxas Risks
description: Patients taking traditional blood thinners like warfarin must have tests every few weeks to ensure that blood levels of the drug are in an acceptable range. But 2010 brought a seemingly welcome alternative: Pradaxa.

title: South Asian Lessons in Rhythm and Artistry
description: The subtitle of the rich recent Drive East festival at La MaMa was A Journey Through South Asian Music and Dance. The word journey was just right: The range covered different geographical parts of India, different dance and music styles, different aspects of spirit and technique.

title: Fake Security Screener Highlights a Concern
description: THE man wearing a blue shirt and khaki pants stood casually inside a security screening area at a San Francisco airport terminal. As security officers and passengers bustled, he pointed to a woman and took her into the private screening room. Later, he pointed to another woman, and she followed him in as well.

title: White-Noise Nights
description: Q. For more than 40 years, I have needed to use a white-noise machine to get to sleep. Should I worry?

title: Dean of Fashion at Parsons Plans to Step Down
description: After six years as the dean of the School of Fashion at Parsons the New School for Design, Simon Collins will be stepping down at the end of 2014. An official announcement is expected Tuesday.

title: Now a Weed, Once a Prehistoric Cavity Fighter
description: Cyperus rotundus, commonly known as purple nutsedge or nutgrass, is considered one of the worlds worst invasive weeds. But new research suggests that prehistoric humans in what is now central Sudan may have gotten an unusual benefit from it.

title: Video Game Guinea Pigs at Play
description: In an on-demand world obsessed with the pleasures of now, theres an even more immediate way to play many video games: while theyre still being made.

title: Geckos Rely on Foot Hairs, Not Insurance
description: Geckos manipulate the hairs on the bottom of their feet to be sticky or not, allowing them to run on almost any surface, Oregon State University researchers say in The Journal of Applied Physics. The branched hairs, or seta, can unstick from walls and ceilings in an instant.

title: Professional Networking, Minus the Fees
description: Justin Gignac wouldnt miss the annual Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity. But he doesnt pay.

title: Marine Life You Can See Through
description: There are creatures in the oceans whose survival balances on their ability to almost disappear in the deep.

title: In Surprise Finale at Metropolitan Operas Labor Talks, Both Sides Agree to Cuts
description: In the end, the Metropolitan Opera and two of its unions agreed that to avoid the calamities that have silenced swaths of the classical music world, they would have to scale back.

title: Obama Announces Progress in Iraq
description: President Obama said Iraqi and Kurdish forces, backed by American airstrikes, have recaptured a strategically important dam near Mosul from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Useful Tools in Sentencing
description: To the Editor:

title: Albuquerque Revisited
Pope Francis in Seoul
description: To the Editor:

title: A World of Creatures That Hide in the Open
description: Snke Johnsen scuba dives in the middle of the ocean, far from land, miles above the seafloor. There are no shipwrecks to explore, no reefs to admire, just a disorienting oasis of blue.

title: A Righteous Man and Gaza
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Cruise to Tasmania
description: Tasmania, the Australian island about 150 miles south off the mainland, isnt the most frequented or easy to reach spot, but the French cruise line Compagnie du Ponant has a new excursion that gives travelers a chance to discover this remote destination.

title: Podcast: See-Through Sea Creatures, Update on Ebola, Saving Lemurs
description: Looking into the open ocean for animals who protect themselves by staying clear of danger; what we know about the Ebola outbreak raging through West Africa; Patricia Wright is a lemur expert who has spent decades in Madagascar protecting them.

title: The Civil War and the Southern Belle
description: In the beginning of the war, Southern women wanted their men to leave  in droves, and as quickly as possible. They were the Confederate Armys most persuasive and effective recruitment officers, shaming anyone who shirked his duty to fight. A young English immigrant in Arkansas enlisted after being accosted at a recruitment meeting. If every man did not hasten to battle, they vowed they would themselves rush out and meet the Yankee vandals, he wrote of Southern women. In a land where women are worshipped by men, such language made them war-mad.

title: A Lemur Rescue Mission in Madagascar
description: Lemurs, which live only on the island nation of Madagascar, are long-tailed, long-legged primates with an astonishingly graceful leap. They are also in serious peril: Of the 103 species of lemur, 90 percent are endangered, critically endangered or threatened, and several are on the brink of extinction, according to the primatologist Patricia C. Wright of Stony Brook University.

title: Devising a Faster, Better Rail System
On Books Since 1988, Ohio River Dam Project Keeps Rolling Along
description: OLMSTED, Ill.  The gargantuan marine construction project unfolding on the Ohio River here was first authorized by Congress in 1988 at a cost of $775 million. Assuming the future unfolds more smoothly than the past, it is now scheduled to be completed in 2020 at a cost approaching $3 billion.

title: Taxing Corporations
description: To the Editor:

title: Intersection | Casual Style in Glasgow
description: In the West End of Glasgow, Blossom Mccuaig cites old movies and local vintage shops as her inspirations.

title: Obama Calls for Peace Again in Ferguson
description: President Obama said Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. will go to Ferguson, Mo., on Wednesday to monitor the ongoing investigation into the shooting death of Michael Brown.

title: Advertiser-Friendliness May Have Played Role in Time Inc. Layoffs
description: Sports Illustrated rated its journalists on whether their work benefited advertisers, according to an internal document from its parent company, Time Inc.

title: Computer Eyesight Gets a Lot More Accurate
description: Just as the Big Bad Wolf promised Little Red Riding Hood that his bigger eyes were the better to see you with, a machines ability to see the world around it is benefiting from bigger computers and more accurate mathematical calculations.

title: Young Souls, Dark Deeds
Ambivalence About America
description: Attitudes in Europe toward an America that is regrouping are marked today by extreme ambivalence. Europeans have long been known for finishing their diatribes about the United States by asking how they can get their child into Stanford. These days, European after-dinner conversation tends to be dominated by discussion of the latest episode of House of Cards or Homeland or Mad Men. A French diplomat told me that every meeting he attended at the White House during his tour in Washington ended with one of his party asking if it might be possible to see the West Wing. He found it embarrassing.

title: The Trouble With Tenure
description: DENVER  Mike Johnstons mother was a public-school teacher. So were her mother and father. And his godfather taught in both public and private schools.

title: Breaking Out of the Party Box
description: FOR years, conservative politicians have been charged with indifference toward the plight of the poor and vulnerable. Republicans are accused of caring more about hedge fund managers than people who trim hedges, and when pollsters ask questions like Who cares more about people like you?, Democrats consistently come out on top. The George Washington University political scientist Danny Hayes has found that Americans, by significant margins, believe that empathy and compassion are traits owned by Democrats.

title: Jets Seek Aggression but Dont Want to Pay for It
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When Coach Rex Ryan took over the Jets in 2009, he expressed his determination to field a no-nonsense, physical team that would aim to overpower opponents on both sides of the ball. He emphasized how feisty he wanted his club to be by saying that a shot at one of his players would be countered by a swipe at two of yours.

title: Fight on Common Core Is Dividing Louisiana
description: A bitter fight over the future of academic standards in Louisiana has generated dueling lawsuits, a standoff between Gov. Bobby Jindal and the state superintendent of education he appointed, and a sense of chaos among educators and parents.

title: As Casinos Close in Atlantic City, a Push for More, Closer to New York
description: With as many as four casinos shutting down in Atlantic City by the end of September, New Jersey is suddenly awash in plans for, well, more casinos.

title: Attacks on Aid Workers Jump Worldwide, Group Says
description: Attacks on international aid workers have risen sharply over the past year and a half, with spikes in the numbers of killings, injuries and abductions, according to the updated figures of a database compiled by a humanitarian advisory group.

title: Not Just Ferguson: National Guard Has a Long History With Civil Unrest
description: Use of the National Guard to quell civil disturbances, especially race-related ones as in Ferguson, Mo., has a long history in the United States. It even technically predates the National Guard itself.

title: Airstrikes Over Tripoli Kill Six; Source of Bombing Is Unknown
description: CAIRO  Unidentified warplanes on Monday bombed a small arms depot and other locations in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, that are controlled by Islamist-aligned militias, suggesting that a foreign state had intervened in the escalating battle for control of the city.

title: Los Angeles to Reduce Arrest Rate in Schools
description: LOS ANGELES  After years of arresting students for on-campus fights and damaging school property, Los Angeles school officials are adopting new policies to reduce the number of students who are disciplined in the juvenile court system.

title: Giants Banged Up, Nothing More Serious
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants starting cornerback Prince Amukamara, who strained a groin muscle in Saturdays preseason game against Indianapolis, said on Monday that he did not believe the injury was serious.

title: Jim Jeffords, Who Altered Power in Senate, Dies at 80
description: Jim Jeffords, the former senator from Vermont who single-handedly redrew the national political map in 2001 when, after a quarter-century as a moderate Republican lawmaker, he declared himself an independent, shifting control of the Senate to the Democrats, died on Monday in Washington. He was 80.

title: American Apparel Narrows Its Losses, but Troubles Remain
description: With American Apparel and its newly restructured management facing intense investor scrutiny, the companys earnings for the second quarter reinforced the retailers troubled financial footing.

title: Livery Drivers Are on Edge After Two Killings This Month in the Bronx
description: Aboubacar Bah had just bought a security camera for his new livery car. He told friends at an early-morning service at the Futa Islamic Center in the Bronx last Tuesday that he was having it installed that night after work.

title: In One America, Guns and Diet. In the Other, Cameras and Zoolander.
description: In the hardest places to live in the United States, people spend a lot of time thinking about diets and religion. In the easiest places to live, people spend a lot of time thinking about cameras.

title: A Group Lifts Paraclimbers to Higher Goals
description: After working a shift at Big Happys, a now-defunct indoor skate and BMX bike park in Northeast Ohio, Jon Sedor and some friends were setting off homemade fireworks out back. Sedor cocked his arm back to throw one. He remembers a flash and a loud pop next to his left ear, then it was over. The concussion left Sedor in a daze, his ears ringing. I looked down and my arm was shredded, he said.

title: Surviving Ebola, but Untouchable Back Home
description: DARU, Sierra Leone  The neighbors lined up, smiling and mouthing soft congratulations when the van pulled in bearing Jattu Lahai and her 2-year-old daughter.

title: E-Bike Sales Are Surging in Europe
description: BERLIN  With a faint electric whir, Iris Marossek pedals her bicycle through concrete apartment blocks in the heart of old East Berlin, delivering mail to 1,500 people a day.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 18, 2014
Amid Election Impasse, Calls in Afghanistan for an Interim Government
description: A coterie of powerful Afghan government ministers and officials with strong ties to the security forces are threatening to seize power if an election impasse that has paralyzed the country is not resolved soon.

title: Taylor Swift Maximizes Use of Social Media in Release of New Album
description: For most pop stars, the announcement of a new album is a pretty routine affair. But most pop stars are not Taylor Swift.

title: The Man Who Blew the Whistle
description: Late last month, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued an oblique press release announcing that it was awarding an unnamed whistle-blower $400,000 for helping expose a financial fraud at an unnamed company. The money was the latest whistle-blower award  there have been 13 so far  paid as part of the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, which includes both protections for whistle-blowers and financial awards when their information leads to fines of more than $1 million.

title: Tax Burden in U.S. Not as Heavy as It Looks, Report Says
description: For years, chief executives have complained bitterly about the United States corporate tax code, arguing that it is too complicated and that rates are too high. The issue has reached a near boiling point this summer as many large American companies have sought to buy smaller foreign rivals so they can renounce their United States corporate citizenship and reincorporate overseas to lower their tax bills. Others are considering the move, known as an inversion.

title: Calling for Calm in Ferguson, Obama Cites Need for Improved Race Relations
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called for calm and healing in Ferguson, Mo., on Monday even as he acknowledged the deep racial divisions that continue to plague not only that St. Louis suburb but cities across the United States.

title: In China, Myths of Social Cohesion
description: KASHGAR, China  They come for the camel rides, the chance to dress up like a conquering Qing dynasty soldier or to take selfies in front of one of the most historic Islamic shrines in Xinjiang, the sprawling region in Chinas far northwest.

title: In Ratings Game, CBS Going Big on Thursday Night Football
description: FOR a new show on the CBS schedule for the 2014-15 season, network executives are promising advertisers and viewers that it will be intensely dramatic, although it is not a drama series; offer compelling competitive matchups, although it is not a reality competition series; and feature famous faces, though its stars belong to no actors union.

title: Who Speaks Wukchumni?
description: This short documentary profiles the last fluent speaker of Wukchumni, a Native American language, and her creation of a comprehensive dictionary.

title: Glens Falls, N.Y., Finds No Bidders as It Tries to Auction Off Civic Center
description: Available: one arena, Hudson River views, plenty of parking. Perfect for Phish concerts, minor-league hockey, mixed martial arts. Asking: $1.5 million or best offer.

title: Tennis Weighs Whether to Bring On the Noise
description: Muting tennis spectators has been one of the most revered rules in sports, but many top players say they would be ready for a new sound.

title: Who Speaks Wukchumni?
description: Throughout the United States, many Native American languages are struggling to survive. According to Unesco, more than 130 of these languages are currently at risk, with 74 languages considered critically endangered. These languages preserve priceless cultural heritage, and some hold unexpected value  nuances in these languages convey unparalleled knowledge of the natural world. Many of these at-risk languages are found in my home state of California. Now for some, only a few fluent speakers remain.

title: Obama Is Seen as Frustrating His Own Party
description: WASHINGTON  The meeting in the Oval Office in late June was called to give President Obama and the four top members of Congress a chance to discuss the unraveling situation in Iraq.

title: The Ice Bucket Challenge
description: The Ice Bucket Challenge has lit social media on fire, raising both money and awareness for A.L.S., also known as Lou Gehrigs disease.

title: Syrias Chemical Arsenal Fully Destroyed, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States said Monday that it had completed the destruction of the deadliest chemical weapons in Syrias arsenal, a rare foreign policy achievement for President Obama at a time when the Middle East is embroiled in violence and political turmoil.

title: Is Gov. Rick Perrys Bad Judgment Really a Crime?
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is one of the least thoughtful and most damaging state leaders in America, having done great harm to immigrants, abortion clinics and people without health insurance during his 14 years in office. But bad political judgment is not necessarily a felony, and the indictment handed up against him on Friday  given the facts so far  appears to be the product of an overzealous prosecution.

title: The Path Taken
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Before the advent of streaming video, one of the highlights of the winter season for millions of children including myself was the night we were allowed to stay up late to watch the entire television broadcast of The Wizard of OZ.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Agree to Lengthen Cease-Fire
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli and Palestinian officials agreed late Monday to extend a five-day cease-fire for Gaza that expired at midnight for 24 hours, reflecting the difficulty of reaching more durable agreements after two weeks of Egyptian-brokered talks but also an apparent lack of appetite on either side to resume the conflict.

title: New Threats to Democracy in Turkey
description: It is no surprise that Recep Tayyip Erdogan won Turkeys first direct election for president. He has served as prime minister since 2002 and, over the intervening years, has skillfully, and ruthlessly, established control and cowed any serious opposition, which was weak to begin with. The victory was not as big as many predicted. Even so, Mr. Erdogan and his ambitions have created new uncertainties for his country and the United States and other NATO members who depend on Turkey to be the bulwark of the alliances eastern front.

title: Wrights Innocuous Slide Precedes a Precipitous Tumble
description: On a rainy evening June 12 at Citi Field, in the 11th inning of a tie game against the Milwaukee Brewers, David Wright took off from first base on a steal attempt and dived safely into second.

title: Its Time to Overhaul Clemency
description: On Jan. 20, 2009, in his last moments as president, George W. Bush gave Barack Obama a hard-earned bit of wisdom: whatever you do, he said, pick a pardon policy and stick with it.

title: Council Speaker, on Twitter, Says She Has HPV Infection
description: Since she became speaker of the New York City Council this year, Melissa Mark-Viverito has been an avid user of Twitter.

title: Cities Rocked by Past Protests Offer Lessons in What, and What Not, to Do
description: The trigger for civil unrest in Ferguson, Mo.  the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a police officer  has also provoked riots in American cities both small and large in the last two decades. But few of those disturbances were as stubbornly resistant to resolution as the Missouri protests, which now have drawn the National Guard and even the White House into efforts to restore calm.

title: Billionaire Named in Suit Against Anti-Iran Group
description: WASHINGTON  A billionaire Wall Street commodities investor has been drawn into a court fight against one of the nations most influential anti-Iran advocacy groups, a case in which the Obama administration has introduced a sense of intrigue by its recent claim that, somehow, the group possesses important government secrets.

title: Judge Clears Way for Corcoran Takeover
description: A judge ruled on Monday that the Corcoran Gallery of Art, one of the nations oldest privately supported museums, could proceed with its plan to dissolve itself and be absorbed by the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University, dealing a fatal blow to a last-minute legal challenge that had sought to keep the museum in one piece.

title: The Market? Shared. The Network? Divided.
description: The Baltimore Orioles and the Washington Nationals are each in first place  a great moment in the history of the market they share.

title: A Fire in Manhattan Kills One and Injures 12
description: One person was killed and a dozen others were injured in a fire that ripped through a six-floor apartment building on West 136th Street in Manhattan on Monday evening, fire officials said.

title: A Grocery Chain With a Neighborly Feel Is Branching Out
description: Their battle began over cheesecake.

title: School Bus Drivers May Receive More Pay From New York
description: Just before school buses begin rolling with students adorned with new backpacks and fresh sets of pencils, Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council are hoping to reverse some of the policies that led drivers to strike unsuccessfully 18 months ago.

title: Jerry Lumpe, Infielder for Yankees in 2 World Series, Dies at 81
description: Jerry Lumpe, who played the infield for the Yankees in two World Series in the 1950s and was later an All-Star second baseman with the Detroit Tigers, died on Friday in Springfield, Mo. He was 81.

title: The Scottish Gin Thats Perfect for a Late Summer New York Cocktail
description: Off the western coast of the Scottish mainland lies Islay, an island three times the size of Marthas Vineyard. Its a place rich in whisky lore, thanks to its eight distilleries, all of which make a product with an unmistakably peaty flavor. But the Botanist, introduced by the whisky distillery Bruichladdich (pronounced brook-laddie) in 2010, is the islands only gin.

title: Brunch at Tiffanys
description: As the storied jewelry houses first female design director, Francesca Amfitheatrof is imbuing modern luxury with an unexpected hint of bohemianism  perhaps the result of her recent move to Brooklyn.

title: Word of the Day | coincidence
description: coincidence \ko-in(t)-s-dn(t)s, -s-den(t)s\ noun

title: Don Pardo, the Voice of SNL, Is Dead at 96
description: Don Pardo, who literally introduced television viewers to some of Americas biggest stars and soon-to-be-stars as the longtime announcer for Saturday Night Live, died on Monday in Tucson. He was 96.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 10:30 A.M. (HBO2) MOONRISE KINGDOM (2012) In this sweet, dreamy feature from the director Wes Anderson, 12-year-old Suzy (Kara Hayward, above) meets her soul mate, an orphan boy at scout camp named Sam (Jared Gilman). They exchange letters and plot an escape from their dreary worlds. In her case, its a house headed by a joyless mom and dad (Frances McDormand and Bill Murray), lawyers who call each other counselor in bed; in his case, its camp and a series of foster homes. Moonrise Kingdom breezes along with a beautifully coordinated admixture of droll humor, deadpan and slapstick, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Like all of Mr. Andersons films, though, theres a deep, pervasive melancholia here too.

title: National Guard Troops in Ferguson Fail to Quell Disorder
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Violence erupted here once more overnight, even as Missouri National Guard troops arrived, the latest in a series of quickly shifting attempts to quell the chaos that has upended this St. Louis suburb for more than a week.

title: Corrections: August 19, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 19, 2014
description: For him, eating his spinach is schmoozing with elected officials. This is not something that he loves.

title: In India, Human Pyramids Draw Crowds, and Protests
description: MUMBAI, India  On a recent evening in south Mumbai, a group of men in matching jerseys had arranged themselves in concentric circles and were hoisting smaller boys up and up, until their bare feet balanced precariously on the rounded shoulders below.

title: Student Crossword | Ancient Greek Theater
description: Test your knowledge of ancient Greek theater by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Dumping Ice to Raise Money and Awareness
description: In  Ice Bucket Challenge Has Raised Millions for ALS Association, Emily Steel writes about the phenomenon that has swept social media in recent weeks.

title: China Said to Deploy Drones After Unrest in Xinjiang
description: Three days after an eruption of violence in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang this summer left nearly 100 people dead, the regions antiterrorist command asked the countrys biggest space and defense contractor for help. It wanted technical experts to operate drones that the authorities in Xinjiang had ordered last year in anticipation of growing unrest. The target was terrorists, according to the online edition of Peoples Daily, a Communist Party media outlet.

title: Delivery Start-Ups Are Back Like Its 1999
description: Last year, I was excited to hear about a new start-up in San Francisco that delivered cheap bottles of wine within an hour. It was called Rewinery, and it was fantastic. I ordered a $5 malbec one day and a $10 chardonnay the next, delivered by bike courier for a modest fee. Already, San Francisco was crawling with bikes, inching up the hills, shuttling sushi and groceries and new clothes, all summoned with the tap of a finger. But Rewinery was the first of the delivery start-ups that made me feel the way I felt back in 2000, when I could order a video and a pint of ice cream to my doorstep from Kozmo.com. Rewinery felt too good to be true.

title: Trying to Contain Ebola in Liberia
description: After reading reports of the Ebola viruss virulent spread  with corpses left on the street and hospitals closing because of dangers to untrained health workers  I asked to be sent to Liberia.

title: California Court Limits Caregiver Suits
description: The California Supreme Court has ruled that a home health aide may not sue a client with Alzheimers disease for an injury incurred on the job. The case is one of the first in the nation to assess legal remedies available to paid caregivers who work with Alzheimers patients at home.

title: Why Some People Like to Travel in the Dark
description: Dark tourism is not a rebranded form of spelunking. It entails no bat watching, no guided tours of the Parisian catacombs, no visits to Fairbanks in sunless winter.

title: BHP Billiton to Spin Off Units, Reversing Consolidation Trend
description: Updated, 8:40 p.m. | BHP Billiton said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off several assets into a new global metals and mining company, undoing in large part the 2001 merger that created the mining giant ahead of a boom in commodities.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: New York Today: An Operatic Accord
description: Good morning on this fair, dry Tuesday.

title: More Details Emerge on Celebrity Drug Arrests in Beijing
description: The Beijing police have released further details about the arrests of Jaycee Chan, the son of the Hong Kong movie star Jackie Chan, and of the Taiwanese actor Ko Chen-tung on drug-related charges.

title: Protests in Ferguson
description: How not to manage civil unrest.

title: Ebola Death Toll in West Africa Tops 1,200
description: LONDON  As West African nations grappled with the worst-ever outbreak of the Ebola virus, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday that the death toll had exceeded 1,200 and announced increased efforts to forestall severe food shortages in areas isolated by quarantines.

title: Why I Do All My Recruiting Through LinkedIn
description: Recruiting the right team member is always difficult. I start off knowing that I need someone to perform a task, and imagine what qualities that person might possess. How, in a sea of people, can I find my ideal candidate?

title: James Schiro, Goldmans Lead Director, Dies at 68
description: James J. Schiro, a chief executive of two global giants in the accounting and insurance industries and a lead director at Goldman Sachs, died on Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 68.

title: Ukrainian and Russian Leaders Will Meet as Rebels Continue to Falter
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukrainian forces pushed deeper into territory controlled by pro-Russian rebels on Tuesday, fighting street battles in the besieged city of Luhansk and pressuring the outer defenses of Donetsk in a further blow to the separatists crumbling virtual state.

title: Lawyer for Malaysian Opposition Leader Is Charged With Sedition
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  A lawyer for the Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was charged with sedition on Tuesday, a move that Mr. Anwar denounced as part of a conspiracy to weaken his appeal of a sodomy conviction and orchestrate his return to prison.

title: Morning Agenda: Dollar Store Deal Frenzy
description: When Dollar General offered on Monday to buy Family Dollar Stores for $8.9 billion, it was hoping not only to break up Family Dollars merger with Dollar Tree but also to strengthen its share of the low-end retail market, Michael J. de la Merced and Nelson D. Schwartz write in DealBook. Prices at Family Dollar are kept low and its breadth of products is limited to items it can sell cheaply, they write. But the retailers success has become a symbol of the rush to cater to the working poor.

title: Daily Report: Delivery Start-Ups Are Back Like Its 1999
description: In the tech crash of the early 2000s, on-demand delivery services like Kozmo and Webvan werent just among the most colossal failures. They also became a sort of grim joke, symbolizing the excess that portended the bust. Afterward, conventional wisdom hardened: Web-enabled delivery was not a good business. Warehouses were too costly to build. There was too little opportunity to recoup expenditures in delivery fees. And people will pay only so much for toilet paper to be delivered before they decide to fetch it themselves.

title: In Performance: Anna Gunn and Billy Magnussen of Sex With Strangers
description: This weeks video features the Emmy Award-winning actress Anna Gunn (Breaking Bad) and the Tony-nominated actor Billy Magnussen (Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike) in a scene from Laura Easons play Sex With Strangers.

title: Red Pencils Ready?
description: PLEASE NOTE: After Deadline will be on vacation next week, returning on Tuesday, Sept. 2.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Lunch Break on a Hot Summer Day
description: Dear Diary:

title: Beauty | No Mistake
description: Messy hair and imperfectly applied makeup  smeared lips, ringed eyes or caked-on mascara  conjure the thrill of creativity and the rush of life.

title: Square Expands Its Cash Advance Service
description: Square, the e-commerce start-up, announced on Tuesday that it would broaden the scope of its cash advance program through a multimillion-dollar deal with Victory Park Capital, a Chicago-based firm known for backing small-business financing ventures.

title: Bank of America Co-Chief Operating Officer Will Become Sole C.O.O.
description: Updated, 7:30 p.m. | Bank of Americas head of investment banking and trading, Thomas K. Montag, has been named sole chief operating officer in a move that reflects the banks growing prowess on Wall Street.

title: Nicholas Felton: A Quantified Life
description: Mr. Felton, an information designer who used to work at Facebook, has tracked almost every aspect of his life, from the miles hes walked to the average length of his personal conversations.

title: A Life in Data: Nicholas Feltons Self-Surveillance
description: The information designer Nicholas Felton likes data: the more data, the better. Thats why for a number of years, he has released a compilation of information that he has collected and analyzed about himself, including where hes gone, the books hes read and whom hes talked to.

title: Two Good Omens for Housing Market
description: After a harsh winter, the nations modest housing recovery appears to be back on track.

title: Rockets From Gaza and Israeli Response Break Cease-Fire
description: JERUSALEM  As the latest short-term cease-fire between Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip collapsed Tuesday, rockets from Gaza reached Tel Aviv and Jerusalem and Israel resumed airstrikes in Gaza. But the most telling move came in Cairo, where Israel yanked its team from talks aimed at a more durable truce.

title: 1889: Express Wrecked on Tracks
description: SUNDERLAND  The Leeds express met with a serious accident to-night [Aug. 19] at about eight oclock on the North Eastern Railway at Ryhope station, about three miles from here. This train travels from Newcastle and calls at Sunderland on its journey. To-night the train seems to have run harder and faster than usual, indeed passengers were alarmed some minutes before the smash took place. All the coaches, except the last one, were thrown off the metals, and soon a scene of great confusion ensued. Strange to say, there was but one death, that of a child; but there were several injured severely. The New York Herald, European Edition, August 20, 1889

title: U.N. Plans Ambitious Operation to Help Displaced Iraqis
description: GENEVA  As Kurdish and Iraqi forces backed by American jets battled to dislodge Islamic militants from areas around Mosul Dam in northern Iraq, the United Nations refugee agency said Tuesday that it was planning one of its biggest aid operations in recent years.

title: Can Writing Be Taught?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Rivka Galchen and Zo Heller discuss whether writing can be taught.

title: Missouri Police on Protests and Arrests
description: Capt. Ronald S. Johnson of the Missouri State Highway Patrol said police came under fire Monday night and arrested 31 people.

title: Pope Francis Says He Would Visit China Tomorrow
description: The red banner hanging in the outer courtyard of Beijings oldest Catholic church said: Congratulations to the Holy Mother on Her Assumption intoHeaven.

title: Aug. 19: Unrest Continues to Roil Ferguson
description: The New York Times is providing updates as violent protests continue in Ferguson, Mo., after a police shooting.

title: A Bronck in the Bronx Gives a Swedish Town a Reason to Cheer
description: Nobody would mistake the municipality of Savsjo for the borough of the Bronx.

title: A Louise Lawler Billboard for the High Line
description: An interior scene from the world of art will be on very public display in the next High Line billboard, at West 18th Street and 10th Avenue. For the 15th installation in the billboard series, the artist Louise Lawler has created Triangle (adjusted to fit) (2008/2009/2011), an image photographed in a room at Sothebys auction house in New York, and itself featuring works by artists Donald Judd, Frank Stella and Sol LeWitt.

title: British Construction Company Carillion Improves Bid for Balfour Beatty
description: LONDON  The British construction and services company Carillion said on Tuesday that it would sweeten its takeover offer for Balfour Beatty after meeting with major shareholders of its rival.

title: The Discreet Charm of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn
description: In Brunch at Tiffanys in Ts Fall 2014 Womens Fashion Issue, the new Tiffany & Company design director Francesca Amfitheatrof reveals the ways in which her work is influenced by her relaxed life and eclectic home in Brooklyns Clinton Hill neighborhood. Once a fashionable suburb for Gilded Age families, the historic district features some of the citys loveliest, most low-key blocks, making it perfect for weekend wandering. It has also shaped some of the boroughs artistic luminaries: Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe were roommates on Hall Street, a block away from where Walt Whitman wrote Leaves of Grass on Ryerson Street; the rapper Biggie Smalls grew up on nearby St. James Place. Here, a few local highlights.

title: Back Spasms Trouble Missy Franklin
description: SOUTHPORT, Australia  Missy Franklins participation at the Pan Pacific Championships was in doubt after she left practice Tuesday night with back spasms and did not accompany the team to the Gold Coast Aquatic Centre on Wednesday morning. She was to have made her final tuneups for a program that includes a 200-meter freestyle/100-meter backstroke double on Thursday, the opening session of the four-day meet.

title: Israel on Broken Cease-Fire
description: An Israeli government spokesman, Mark Regev, said Israel was no longer bound by a cease-fire agreement with Hamas, after three rockets fired from Gaza struck southern Israel.

title: Grand Jury to Take Up Death Linked to Police Chokehold in Staten Island
description: Amid weeks of protests and calls for federal intervention, the Staten Island district attorney announced on Tuesday that he would open a grand jury investigation into the death of an unarmed black man during an arrest last month, a process that could lead to indictments of the police officers involved.

title: The Man Primed to Lead Iraq
description: Iraq is looking to a new leader in Haider al-Abadi as he prepares to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has said he will give up power.

title: Rick Perry, Fighting Charges, Hires High-Profile Legal Team in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  It has the makings of a legal dream team.

title: Should Red Wolves Be Allowed to Mate With Coyotes?
description: In the past century, a new medium-size predator has appeared in the Northeast. Some call it the coywolf; others prefer Eastern coyote. In times past, the animal was called coydog. All monikers are somewhat correct: The most recent genetic analysis suggests that the animal is roughly one-quarter wolf and two-thirds coyote. The remainder of its genome comes from dogs.

title: Unknown Dylan Songs Get Music by Elvis Costello, Marcus Mumford and Others
description: Bob Dylans Basement Tapes have always fascinated the singers fans. Some of these informal recordings, which Mr. Dylan made with the Band in 1967, while recovering from injuries sustained in a motorcycle accident the previous year, turned up on one of the earliest rock bootlegs, Great White Wonder, in 1969, and two dozen of them were released officially on the The Basement Tapes in 1975 (with a few more songs turning up on Mr. Dylans Bootleg Series compilations). Bootleg collectors have another 10 CDs worth of material, including original songs, covers and blues and folk tunes.

title: How to Keep Score: However You Like
description: North of the Mets-Willets Point stop of the No. 7 subway line and the Long Island Rail Road, there is a standard written language: When the second baseman, the shortstop and the first baseman combine for a double play at Citi Field, reporters in the press box and fans in the seats write 4-6-3 on their scorecards. If the next batter strikes out swinging, a K tells the story.

title: And Then The Dog Died: Things You Cant Plan for When Planning a Move
description: When planning my familys move to Nashville from Atlanta, one of the things I put a lot of thought into was creating a sense of consistency in order to manage how much change and disorder our children would experience this summer. I read somewhere that children need to know they can rely on some things to stay the same, even when a big transition comes along.

title: Afghan Officials Interrogate a Times Correspondent
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan attorney generals office called in a New York Times correspondent for questioning Tuesday, and later barred him from leaving the country, after The Times published an article about discussions among some officials of imposing an interim government.

title: When Technology Makes Work Worse
description: When we talk about robots taking peoples jobs, we often mean it almost literally  we envision if not the humanoid androids of science fiction, then at least machines programmed to do tasks once done by humans. Buttechnology may also be altering Americans working lives in another way, via the software and hardware that companies use to determine when and how they work.

title: I Tried to Work Out Like a Pro Wrestler and Failed
description: Much of the discussion in my recent profile of Diamond Dallas Page, the former-wrestler-turned-fitness-guru, centered on the therapeutic uses of DDP Yoga. Page created the program after rupturing a disc between his fourth and fifth lumbar vertebrae during a wrestling match. A handful of back specialists told Page hed never wrestle again  he was in his early 40s, after all. But he devised his own form of yoga using exercises that he learned during physical therapy, traditional calisthenics and something Page calls dynamic resistance  the secret sauce of DDP Yoga.

title: What Military Gear Your Local Police Department Bought
description: WASHINGTON  Since President Obama took office, the Pentagon has transferred to police departments tens of thousands of machine guns; nearly 200,000 ammunition magazines; thousands of pieces of camouflage and night-vision equipment; and hundreds of silencers, armored cars and aircraft.

title: Former Goldman Executive to Head Southeast Asia Private Equity Firm
description: The Everstone Group, a private equity and real estate firm with offices in India and Singapore, has named L. Brooks Entwistle, formerly chairman of Goldman Sachs South East Asia, as partner and chief executive.

title: Today in Small Business: Write a Letter
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Next Leader May Echo Maliki, but Iraqis Hope for New Results
description: BAGHDAD  The last time the United States pushed Iraqis to choose a new prime minister who could unite the country to confront a sectarian civil war was in 2006, and the Iraqis chose Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. The result was another civil war. This time, with the country again on the edge of collapse, they have chosen Haider al-Abadi.

title: David Hallberg, Citing Injury, Withdraws From Dance Performances
description: David Hallberg, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, and the first American to join the Bolshoi Ballet as a principal, has withdrawn from his performance commitments through the fall because of an injury, Mr. Hallberg announced through a spokeswoman on Tuesday. Mr. Hallberg had danced with both companies during the summer, but has been advised by his doctors that he needs ankle surgery.

title: Saluting the Women Behind the Screen
description: To be a video game critic is both a dream come true and a daily embarrassment.

title: In Hawaii, a Hands-On Food Festival
description: Hurricanes? What hurricanes?

title: Americas Racial Divide, Charted
description: Editors note: This article, first published last summer after protests erupted in Ferguson, Mo., remains a telling guide to where America is and is not narrowing the gap between whites and blacks.

title: Caught Backsliding, Standard Chartered Is Fined $300 Million
description: Updated, 8:34 p.m. | It took $667 million in fines and a promise to behave for the British bank Standard Chartered to emerge from the regulatory spotlight. All it took to return there was its failure to fully keep that promise.

title: BHP Spinoff Wont Appeal to Commodity Players
description: BHP Billiton plans to spin off unwanted parts of its business into a new company.

title: 1964: Saigon Moves U.S. Monument
description: SAIGON  The South Vietnamese government quietly hauled down a monument honoring President Kennedy under cover of curfew before dawn today [Aug. 19]. Official sources said the large concrete slab and plaque was removed from one of Saigons main squares with the concurrence of the U.S. embassy. Officials apparently believed the monument for an American president was an irritant to certain sectors of the Vietnamese public and was a source of propaganda for the Communists in their claim that the country is a puppet of Washington. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 20, 1964

title: Exonerated Man Reaches $10 Million Deal With New York City
description: After three years of litigation, Jabbar Collins, a man who spent 16 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, has reached a $10 million settlement with New York City.

title: The Voice of SNL
description: Don Pardo introduces the cast for last seasons final episode of Saturday Night Live on May 17.

title: Talking to Men About PSA Testing
description: My patient looked back at me with a blank stare. I had just finished my take on the pros and cons of having a PSA test, and he looked lost. What would you do if you were me, Doc? he said.

title: Sound and Fury in Bank Settlements, Still Signifying Nothing
description: Once again last month, we were treated to the sorry spectacle of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. holding a news conference to proclaim that a too big to fail bank had been brought to justice for its reprehensible behavior in the years leading up to the 2008 financial crisis. All things considered, it was fine theater with the obvious caveat that nothing even remotely close to justice had been served.

title: The Simpsons': Which Episode Should Everyone Watch?
description: So youd like to watch every episode of The Simpsons? Thats a perfectly cromulent idea.

title: Weekly Quandary: Should Siblings Spectate?
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This weeks quandary comes from a comment that surprised me on a recent blog post, When Sports and Family Time Conflict, Speak Up.

title: Monsters, Inc.
description: When you belong to a lowly regarded, often abused, all-but-anonymous segment of New York City society, how do you assert your rights and dignity? Youorganize and demand them. In Times Square at noon on Tuesday, a couple dozen costumed characters held a news conference to defend themselves and their right to work (posing for photos with tourists and soliciting tips), and to denounce what they said was routine police harassment. The group calls itself NYC Artists United for a Smile, a jaunty name that matched the performers mood as they cheered and applauded themselves and yelled Si, se puede, the yes-we-can chant of immigrants and the working poor.Except for Batman, who glowered as usual as he passed out handbills at the edge of the crowd.

title: Uber Picks David Plouffe to Wage Regulatory Fight
description: Uber wants your vote of support. And it has hired a campaign manager to win you over.

title: Tear Gas and Other Dangers in Ferguson
description: Alison Mitchell, national editor for The Times, has been at the nerve center of The Timess coverage of the violence in Ferguson, Mo., that resulted when a police officer shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, on Aug. 9.

title: On Senate Menu, Bean Soup and a Serving of Hyperpartisanship
description: WASHINGTON  A generation ago, here in the Senate Dining Room, Senators Mike Mansfield, a Democrat of Montana and majority leader, and George Aiken, a Republican of Vermont, met most mornings to have breakfast together, a scene almost unimaginable in todays polarized climate.

title: Pope Francis Flights Yield Candid Conversations
description: ROME  Francis is not the first pope to answer journalists questions on a broad range of topics during the empty flight time on papal trips. But he has managed to turn these impromptu news conferences into front-page-grabbing events.

title: Malala Yousafzai: By the Book
description: The activist and co-author of I Am Malala: How One Girl Stood Up for Education and Changed the World relished The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, the first book she read in the hospital when recovering from an attack by the Taliban. New York Times correspondent Jodi Kantor will continue the conversation with Malala Yousafzai at a Times Talk this evening; click here to watch it live or afterwards.

title: Ginsburg and Alito to Speak at New-York Historical Society
description: Supreme Court Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Samuel A. Alito Jr. are among the luminaries scheduled to speak at the New-York Historical Society this fall and winter, as part of a lineup heavy on reconsideration of legal issues past and present.

title: Chlo Grace Moretz in Miu Mius Mod, Modern Shift Dress
description: The Star: Chlo Grace Moretz

title: Islanders Owner Announces He Will Sell the Team to an Investment Group
description: The Islanders owner, Charles B. Wang, announced Tuesday that he would sell the team to Jonathan Ledecky, a former owner of a minority stake in the Washington Capitals, and Scott Malkin, a London-based investor.

title: Why We Care About Privacy
description: Noah Dyer is concerned about privacy. Specifically, he thinks we have too much of it.

title: Postwar Ferrari Wins Best in Show at Pebble Beach Concours
description: Since 1950, the Pebble Beach Concours d'lgance has crowned many fine cars as best in show. There have been multiple winners from manufacturers like Rolls-Royce, Bugatti, Alfa Romeo, Jaguar and Bugatti. This was the first year a Ferrari  a silver 1954 375 MM coupe  won the show, besting 216 entrants. The 375 MM was also the first postwar car to win in 46 years.

title: Beyond the Lies
description: Greg Sargent notes that the midterm election, which was supposed to be a referendum on Obamacare, isnt looking at all like that in practice; Republican ads denouncing health reform have been dwindling month by month.

title: Neither Obama Nor Congress Seems Eager for a Vote on Military Action in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  Mingling with Senate Democrats at the White House earlier this summer, President Obama had a tart comeback to the suggestion that he should seek a vote of Congress before deepening American military involvement in Iraq.

title: A New Art Biennial Among Offerings at BRIC House in Brooklyn
description: The inaugural installation of a biennial art exhibition, performances by Ronald K. Browns Evidence dance company, and a screening of Gia Coppolas film Palo Alto, with a live performance of its score by Devont Hynes are among the highlights of the fall season at BRIC House, the multimedia arts center in Brooklyn.

title: In the Race for Oscars, Toronto Puts Up a Hurdle
description: LOS ANGELES  Smaller movies, said Tom Bernard, the co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, are kind of like Petey the Puffin.

title: A Recipe Book That Does Not Stray Far
description: Are you hungry, right now, for green tomatoes baked in a pie?

title: Pakistanis Protest in Capital, Seeking Prime Ministers Resignation
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Thousands of Pakistani opposition supporters, some armed with sticks and wire cutters, marched into a fortified zone in the center of Islamabad on Tuesday night to press their demands for the resignation of the prime minister.

title: Steve Ballmer Quits Microsoft Board, Citing His Outside Duties
description: SEATTLE  Steven A. Ballmers era at Microsoft has come to a full stop.

title: Petaluma, a New York Staple, Is Reborn
description: Headliner

title: Voter Registration in Ferguson Called Disgusting
description: On Sunday the Rev. Al Sharpton, the civil rights activist and television host, mentioned that voter turnout in Ferguson, Mo., was a mere 12 percent in the last election, and pledged to help boost that number with a registration drive. Twelve percent, he said, was an insult to your children. He wasnt the first to think of channeling the anger over Mike Browns death in this particular direction. Twitter users on Saturday noted voter registration tables in front of the makeshift memorial where the unarmed teenager was shot by a police officer.

title: In Ferguson, Photographs as Powerful Agents
description: The history of black representation has resonated with the types of images now prevalent in social media.

title: Summer Reading Winner, Week 8 | The Art of Cabbage-Walking
description: This week we received 574 entries for our Summer Reading Contest. After running this contest for many years, weve learned that as the summer winds down, the competition heats up.

title: Inside Seidenberg Antiques
description: A tour of Seidenberg Antiques, the sprawling 74-year-old shop in downtown Manhattan where Eleanor Roosevelt hunted for rare treasures.

title: Veni Vidi Wiki
description: Vox has a great explanation of the Roman Empire in 40 maps (not all of them maps, really, but close enough); I love this sort of stuff.

title: Overstock to Allow International Customers to Pay in Bitcoin
description: One big retailer is about the conquer the next Bitcoin frontier.

title: Louis Garrel on Wearing PJs in Public and the Upside of Looking Like Everyone Else
description: Louis Garrel doesnt have to rely on fashion to be stylish. The Paris-born son of bohemian artists (the director Philippe Garrel and the actress Brigitte Sy) was born that way. The actor, best known for his role in Bernardo Bertoluccis 2003 sex-charged drama The Dreamers, says that his wardrobe is a patchwork of loaners from friends and collaborators. I really dont buy clothes, the 31-year-old insists. Of course, sometimes he does, but not from the gilded boutiques on rue Saint-Honor; he prefers hidden-gem shops with little signage and fewer brand names. Its an unexpected revelation from a guy who has been shot by Bruce Weber and styled by Carine Roitfeld, appeared on the cover of European fashion bibles and been the face of Valentinos Uomo fragrance since last year.

title: Immersed in the Integratron: A Sound Bath
description: Jody Rosen captured one of the sound baths from the famous Joshua Tree space.

title: Montauk Pearl Oysters for Your Kitchen and More
description: To Savor: Hamptons Pearls (The Edible Kind)

title: Paul Scialla
description: Mr. Scialla, 40, is the founder and chief executive of Delos, a developer in New York that focuses on so-called well building designs. Its projects include a condominium in Greenwich Village as well as the CBRE headquarters in Los Angeles and the MGM Grand resort in Las Vegas.

title: Sister and Wife of Ex-Governor Become Focus in Virginia Trial
description: RICHMOND, Va.  To save Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia, his defense lawyers appear intent on humiliating him. The once-rising Republican star is now portrayed as an amiable innocent at sea amid stronger women who either led him astray or failed to rescue him.

title: Beckham Jr., Giants Top Pick, Back on Sideline
description: The Giants first-round draft pick Odell Beckham Jr. has yet to fully participate in a training camp practice because of a hamstring strain. But in recent days, Beckham, a wide receiver, seemed to be recovering, running some plays from scrimmage, and the team had expressed hope that he could play in its next preseason game Friday against the Jets.

title: Peter Dinklage and Taylor Schilling to Star in A Month in the Country
description: Swords and shivs will give way to lovelorn prose next year when the 2014 Emmy Award nominees Peter Dinklage (Game of Thrones) and Taylor Schilling (Orange Is the New Black) star as Rakitin and Natalya in the Classic Stage revival of Turgenevs A Month in the Country, the company announced on Tuesday. Erica Schmidt, Mr. Dinklages wife, will direct the play, which is set at a Russian country estate in the 1840s. The show is to run Jan. 9 through Feb. 15, 2015, at Classic Stages East Village home on East 13th Street.

title: Cond Nast to Sell Fairchild Fashion Media for $100 Million
description: Cond Nast announced on Tuesday the sale of Fairchild Fashion Media, a group of trade publications including Womens Wear Daily and Footwear News, to Penske Media. The sale price was about $100 million, according to a person briefed on the deal.

title: The Pathos and Brilliance of a Stir-Crazy Stage Life
description: Louis C.K. once began a riff about how much he hated standing in the audience of a comedy show by joking that even if Richard Pryor came back from the dead, he would still see Pryors show only if he could sit down.

title: Photos of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Gaza, Bangladesh and Liberia.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Prized Possession
description: High-gloss handbags and heels in a range of decadent colors are the most covetable accessories of the season.

title: New Carriers Are All Business
description: There are two new entries in the high end of the air travel market.

title: Hammer Museum Announces Three Biennial Prizes
description: The Los Angeles Museum of Art is the important-sounding, official-seeming name that the artist Alice Knitz gives to her rather homegrown collaborative and curatorial efforts, which typically take the form of displaying others artworks on a mobile wooden platform. Now, its also the big winner of the Hammer Museum prizes given to artists in its Made in L.A. biennial, which runs through Sept. 7. Ms. Knitzs enterprise has received the $100,000 Mohn Award, named after Jarl Mohn, the art collector (and chief executive of National Public Radio) who sponsored the prize.

title: Man Killed by St. Louis Officers in Disturbance at Store
description: ST. LOUIS  An emotionally disturbed 23-year-old black man was shot and killed by St. Louis police officers on Tuesday afternoon, the authorities said, threatening to further inflame a community still reeling after another shooting by an officer in a suburb less than two weeks ago.

title: Why The Times Didnt Cover an Amnesty International Report on Torture
description: Many readers have written to me in recent days, protesting that The Times did not cover a new report from Amnesty International about charges of United States torture and another human rights abuses in Afghanistan. That report was covered in other publications, including The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times and The Daily Beast.

title: You Like a Hotel, It Likes You Back
description: These days it seems easier to get travel perks from Twitter and Instagram than from hotel and airline loyalty programs. Travelers active on social networks have scored airport lounge passes, deals on hotel rooms, free drinks and late checkouts. And a new hotel-booking site is aiming to go even further: Hotelied.com promises customized deals for travelers who join the site and link their various social media accounts.

title: Hotel Review: Ritz-Carlton Montreal
description: Rates

title: Readers Respond to Hotel Saving Tips
description: Judging from reader comments, my recent column detailing seven steps to finding a better hotel deal touched several nerves, including those that control memories of horrible hotel experiences, disdain for bargain hunters and physical pain. (Two readers contended that the article gave them a headache. Sorry, guys.)

title: Icelandic Team With Flair for Festivities Will Meet Inter Milan
description: Until this month, Stjarnan F.C. was known mostly as a middling Icelandic soccer team with a talent for elaborate goal celebrations.

title: A Physician With a Troubled Conscience Puts Himself on the Couch
