description: In Sandeep Jauhars arresting memoir about the realities of practicing medicine in America, Doctored: The Disillusionment of an American Physician, he describes an interaction he has with a patient at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, where he is the director of the heart failure program. The patient has an abdominal mass and has been transferred to the medical center from another hospital for a preoperative evaluation. Dr. Jauhar tells her that there are some things he needs to figure out before sending her to the operating room.

title: Afghanistan Bars Times Journalist From Leaving the Country
description: Given the dire threat Afghanistan faces each and every day from the Taliban, one would think senior government officials would focus primarily on that problem.

title: Relief Official Urges Groups to Step Up Ebola Efforts
description: The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is a complete disaster, and health agencies do not yet grasp its scope, the president of the relief group Doctors Without Borders said Tuesday.

title: More Than a Century Later, Sophia Tolstoy Has Her Say
description: In her long and often turbulent marriage to Leo Tolstoy, Sophia Andreevna Tolstoy put up with a lot, but The Kreutzer Sonata qualified as special punishment. Published in 1889, the story presented Tolstoys increasingly radical views on sexual relations and marriage through a frenzied monologue delivered by a narrator who, in a fit of jealousy and disgust, murdered his wife.

title: So How Did They Do?
description: Over the last month or so, the Automobiles section profiled a number of models destined for show or auction in Monterey. Heres a look at how they fared:

title: Wheelies: The Booming Classics Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Little Bit Naughty (and a Lot of Fun)
description: Lets hear it for those Broadway babies: those dancing Billys and gruel-spooning Olivers. Those pert Baby Junes and dreamy Cosettes. Lets even give it up for those simpering Annies. But really, there have never been kiddie roles as naughty and nice as those in Matilda the Musical, the adaptation of Roald Dahls novel.

title: Why the Humanities Still Matter
Is Keeping a Journal a Selfish Exercise, or Thoughtful?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Power of a Stunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Subsidies for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Framed by Sky, and Moving Like the Wind
description: In its new location at the bottom tip of Manhattan, the Downtown Dance Festival has a lovely view of the harbor. But its new showtime, 6 p.m., means that viewers gaze not only into sea and sky, but also directly into the setting sun. There was little on the festivals first two programs to match the blissful relief when a cloud temporarily intervened.

title: Trying to Contain Ebola in Liberia
description: John Moore volunteered to cover the Ebola epidemic in Liberia, where the risks and challenges are many.

title: In Retaking of Iraqi Dam, Evidence of American Impact
description: MOSUL DAM, Iraq  The two bodies lay festering in the midday sun on Tuesday, some of the only remnants of the Sunni militant force that until Monday night controlled the strategically important Mosul Dam.

title: Brisket Is Worth the Wait
description: As smoke from the oak-burning barbecue pits swirled around his head, Nestor Laracuente lit a Marlboro Red, inhaled hard and puffed out his own cumulus cloud. A pitmaster at Hometown Bar-B-Que in Red Hook, Brooklyn, Mr. Laracuente says nicotine and heavy metal help him through the marathon graveyard shifts he spends monitoring the combination of heat, meat and smoke that it takes to produce extraordinary barbecued brisket.

title: Angry Ghosts, Pretty Mushrooms, Temperance Jokes
description: Confession: When Ive had a truly extraordinary theatrical experience, an unmistakable part of my reaction is physical. No matter how late it is when the show ends, or how hard its raining out, or how tired I was when I got to the theater, my body is pumped to go for a long, brisk walk.

title: Taylor Swifts Shake It Off Video: A Dance Critics Take
description: The controversial music video of the moment is Taylor Swifts Shake It Off, which was released on Monday. The controversy seems mainly to be about three things: 1) Ms. Swifts move to pop material (a sign, for certain fans, of selling out); 2) her dancing; and 3) the supposed racism in a section on twerking. On Twitter, the rapper Earl Sweatshirt, after admitting that he hadnt actually watched the video, rather quickly accused Ms. Swift of perpetuating black stereotypes.

title: Owner of Winn-Dixie and Bi-Lo Supermarkets Pulls I.P.O.
description: The owner of the Winn-Dixie and Bi-Lo supermarket chains disclosed on Tuesday that it had canceled its forthcoming initial public offering, nearly a year after the company first registered for a stock sale.

title: The L.A. Art Invasion
description: Sun-soaked isolation seems just the thing to spark inspiration.

title: Her Hands Lead, Her Voice Follows
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  For a singer on a classical concert stage, hands and arms can often seem mere awkward protuberances, as useless as the human appendix.

title: Fighting Crime and Pain of Loss
description: On PBS, which is still Americas main source of televised British crime shows, a glance at the current Masterpiece Mystery! schedule reveals a boys club: Inspector Lewis, Detective Constable Morse, Hercule Poirot, David Tennant as a tricky lawyer, Jack Davenport as a crusading doctor.

title: Reviews: Kim Kardashian: Hollywood, Metrico, Hohokum and Road Not Taken
description: METRICO

title: Militant Group Says It Killed American Journalist in Syria
description: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria posted a video on Tuesday that it said showed the beheading of James Foley, an American journalist who was kidnapped in Syria nearly two years ago, according to a transcript released by the SITE Intelligence Group.

title: Mortgage Servicer Ocwen Subpoenaed by S.E.C. Over Its Business Ties
description: Ocwen Financial, a mortgage-servicing firm that promised to improve on the loan-modification process for struggling homeowners, faces new regulatory scrutiny.

title: Swaps Panel Delays Payout Auction on Argentine Bonds
description: Some investors were expecting to collect their winnings soon on a bet they made against Argentinas bonds using financial instruments called credit default swaps.

title: Court Orders Release of Hunger-Striking Indian Activist
description: NEW DELHI  A court in the northeastern Indian state of Manipur ordered the release of Irom Sharmila, an activist who has been imprisoned on charges of attempted suicide since she began a hunger strike nearly 14 years ago.

title: Lets Not Talk About Sex
description: PHILADELPHIA  EVERY year in the United States thousands of men and women die from cancers that can be prevented with a simple vaccine. Sadly, uptake of this cancer-preventing vaccine is abysmal. One reason: Doctors dont want to talk about sex. The good news is, they dont have to.

title: Who Will Stand Up for the Christians?
description: WHY is the world silent while Christians are being slaughtered in the Middle East and Africa? In Europe and in the United States, we have witnessed demonstrations over the tragic deaths of Palestinians who have been used as human shields by Hamas, the terrorist organization that controls Gaza. The United Nations has held inquiries and focuses its anger on Israel for defending itself against that same terrorist organization. But the barbarous slaughter of thousands upon thousands of Christians is met with relative indifference.

title: Under Pressure From Jana, PetSmart Says It Will Explore Potential Sale
description: After more than a month of pressure from the activist investor Jana Partners, PetSmart is publicly acknowledging that it is up for sale.

title: The War Against Online Trolls
Grappling With the Cost of Corporate Gadflies
description: Corporate America is being held hostage by three people you have probably never heard of.

title: History Written by Jeter Is Rewritten by M.L.B.s Scoring Change
description: History can be changed.

title: Relief Official on the Fear of Ebola
description: Dr. Joanne Liu, president of Doctors Without Borders, called for the Western world not to barricade itself against the Ebola epidemic.

title: Ebola Aid Official on Need for Doctors
description: Dr. Joanne Liu, president of Doctors Without Borders, describes the lack of doctors in the field to help Ebola patients.

title: Advocates Seek to Delay Deportations for Millions
description: Eleven people living in the United States illegally, including a high-profile activist, plan to apply for deportation deferrals on Wednesday as part of an effort to pressure President Obama to include many millions of immigrants in any executive action to reduce deportations.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Saudi Prince Is Identified as Target of Paris Heist
description: PARIS  The mystery prince whose convoy was robbed by masked gunmen on the northern edge of Paris turns out to be the youngest and reportedly favorite son of the late King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.

title: Man Killed by St. Louis Police
description: A man believed to be emotionally disturbed was killed by St. Louis police officers after a confrontation at a convenience store.

title: Report Faults Transport Canada in Fatal Train Derailment
description: OTTAWA  Canadian officials blamed lax oversight for the derailment of a runaway train carrying Bakken crude oil that killed 47 people and destroyed much of Lac Mgantic, Quebec, last year.

title: Ski Town May Face Winter Without Popular Path to Slopes
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Can a ski town survive if the ski lifts stop running?

title: Selling Milk to All Audiences, With a Unified Campaign
description: THE California Milk Processor Board, like many marketers, has one agency creating campaigns for the general market and another creating campaigns for ethnic audiences, in this instance Spanish-speaking consumers. Now, in a shift indicative of a movement on Madison Avenue known as cross-cultural marketing or a total market approach, the board asked its two agencies to collaborate on a campaign encouraging all Californians, regardless of ethnicity or the language they speak, to buy and drink more milk.

title: Dick Bavetta, N.B.A. Referee for 39 Years, Is Retiring
description: Dick Bavetta refereed his first N.B.A. game on Dec. 2, 1975, at Madison Square Garden. That night, Dave Cowens had 25 points and 21 rebounds, before fouling out, to lead the Boston Celtics past the Knicks in front of a crowd announced at 19,694.

title: Millennials Going to Kansas City, to Live and Work
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  On one of the hottest days of the year in mid-July, Michael Knight, a real estate developer, made note of the torn-up street outside Commerce Tower, which opened in 1965 as this regions first modern high-rise office structure with a glass curtain wall.

title: Plenty of Room at the Top of Ukraines Fading Rebellion
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  To outward appearances, Fyodor D. Berezin is the picture of a senior military commander. He wears camouflage, has bodyguards and confidently gives orders as the newly named deputy defense minister of the separatist Donetsk Peoples Republic. Yet, just four months ago he was an obscure author of 18 science fiction novels, one play and a dozen or so short stories.

title: Montana Skies, Childhood Wounds
description: WINTER IN THE BLOOD

title: Injury Claims Against New Yorks Correction Dept. Doubled in 5 Years, Report Says
description: Personal-injury claims against the New York City Department of Correction have more than doubled in five years, a significant jump that has coincided with a rise in violence at Rikers Island, according to a report by the city comptrollers office.

title: Swimming in Country Where Sport Is Beloved, Michael Phelps Is Right at Home
description: SOUTHPORT, Australia  This is not Michael Phelpss first circus, so when he arrived at the Gold Coast Aquatic Centre on Tuesday morning and saw that the 10-lane 50-meter racing pool was quickly filling with competitors in this weeks Pan Pacific Championships, he wove his way through the crowded deck and beneath the corporate boxes to an eight-lane, 50-meter training pool that is also part of the sprawling outdoor complex.

title: Sailing Toward an Arctic Armageddon
description: EXPEDITION TO THE END

title: Will the Ends, Will the Means
description: Hillary Clinton recently reignited the who-lost-Syria debate when she suggested that President Obama made a mistake in not intervening more forcefully early in the Syrian civil war by arming the pro-democracy rebels. Ive been skeptical about such an intervention  skeptical that there were enough of these mainstream insurgents, skeptical that they could ever defeat President Bashar al-Assads army and the Islamists and govern Syria. So if people try to sell you on it, ask them these questions before you decide if you are with Clinton or Obama:

title: The Gold and Blue Loses a Bit of Its Luster
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  A celebration was planned Tuesday for the once and future king of college football.

title: A Trove of Diaries Meant to Be Read by Others
description: PIEVE SANTO STEFANO, Italy  The rich and famous, the important and powerful, can always have their say. But what of the bulk of humanity who suffer the whims of history, whose everyday labors give it life? How will their voices be remembered?

title: As the Sun Sets Over Coney Island, Nostalgia Glows With Renewal
description: It was twilight Monday in Coney Island, the hour of the sea gull, and normally, the turning of the human tide.

title: The Right to Cheat and Maim?
description: In 2010, the Government Accountability Office found that nearly two-thirds of the 50 largest violators of federal wage and hour laws won new federal contracts for work ranging from food processing to cloud computing and that 20 of the 50 largest violators of workplace safety laws were also federal contractors.

title: Prime Minister Modi Fumbles on Pakistan
description: Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi, fumbled an early test of leadership this week when he canceled a high-level meeting with Pakistan. There are no two countries in the world that need to talk, and talk regularly, more than these nuclear-armed South Asian neighbors whose tensions must be carefully managed.

title: German Leader Emerges as Key Figure in Ukraine Talks
description: RIGA, Latvia  With President Obama facing a host of other problems around the world and at home, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is emerging more and more as a pivotal leader on the Ukraine conflict.

title: Better Governing Through Data
description: Government bureaucracies, as opposed to casual friendships, are seldom in danger from too much information. That is why a new initiative by the New York City comptroller, Scott Stringer, to use copious amounts of data to save money and solve problems, makes such intuitive sense.

title: Alone Again, Naturally
description: WASHINGTON  Affectations can be dangerous, as Gertrude Stein said.

title: Sports Illustrated and, Maybe in a Few Years, a Drivers License
description: SOUTH WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.  Mone Davis arrived for infield practice on Tuesday with yet another accomplishment, having appeared on the cover of Sports Illustrated before entering eighth grade.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 19, 2014
Atlantic City Grapples With Empty Spaces
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Inside the towering oval atrium of the Revel Casino Hotel here, visitors are greeted with a plain printed sign at the base of a four-story escalator, noting simply that the building will cease operations at 5 a.m. on Sept. 2.

title: Russia, Iran and Egypt Heckle U.S. About Tactics in Ferguson
description: After St. Louis county police officers in full battle gear trained sniper rifles on peaceful protesters in the suburb of Ferguson last week, and then proceeded to douse the streets in tear gas and round up journalists, a Russia analyst named Mark Adomanis observed that images of a crackdown on dissent in the United States would make life easier for the man recently put in charge of propaganda for the Kremlin, Dmitry Kiselyov.

title: Ferguson, Watts and a Dream Deferred
description: When rioting broke out in the Watts section of Los Angeles in the summer of 1965, African-Americans didnt  couldnt  know it yet, but the next three decades would turn out to be a period of sustained gains in terms of income, jobs, education and the status of blacks relative to whites.

title: A Caller Said Something; Had He Seen Something?
description: The stream of calls came into the 911 system from an unknown person in Brooklyn, each one describing an emergency in the heart of Williamsburg: a sound like an explosion in an L train tunnel; a man displaying a pistol; someone wielding a knife and issuing threats.

title: RadioShack in Need of Rewiring
description: In 1971, Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak hawked tiny machines called Blue Boxes that allowed long-distance phone calls to be made free by mimicking certain tones.

title: In Russia, Scenes From Ferguson Are Played as Nothing Shocking: Its America
description: MOSCOW  At least once an hour, sometimes more frequently, images of battalions of riot police officers in helmets clashing with demonstrators fill the screen of Rossiya 24, one of Russias major government-controlled television channels, and newscasters speaking in grave tones inveigh against the injustice and violence by the authorities.

title: Don Pardo: A Voice on Television That Stood Out
description: Jack Cafferty remembers what the camera on Live at Five did not show: the red socks.

title: Using Health Savings Accounts to Invest for Retirement
description: Health savings accounts are often promoted as a way to help cover continuing out-of-pocket medical costs. But the accounts, which have tax advantages, can also be used to save money for health expenses in retirement  and the savings can be substantial, a new analysis finds.

title: Outsize Production
description: The Houston Astros may be the most data-driven organization in baseball, or at least the one most willing to try new ideas. Yet there are no statistical models that would project the smallest player in the majors to be the games best hitter.

title: Obama Holds to Afghanistan Withdrawal Deadline
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama may have ordered American warplanes back to Iraq, but he has not changed his mind about his other big military withdrawal. Mr. Obama told advisers this week that delaying the pullout of American troops from Afghanistan would make no difference there as long as the country did not overcome its political rifts.

title: Shooting Accounts Differ as Holder Schedules Visit to Ferguson
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  As a county grand jury prepared to hear evidence on Wednesday in the shooting death of a black teenager by a white police officer that touched off 10 days of unrest here, witnesses have given investigators sharply conflicting accounts of the killing.

title: An Obstacle to Honoring an Archbishop Is Removed
description: SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador  A hold on the beatification of Archbishop scar Romero has been lifted, Pope Francis said, clearing the way to honor the archbishop, a hero of El Salvadors leftist opposition who was gunned down in 1980 while celebrating Mass.

title: Celebrity Fragrances Add to Slide at Elizabeth Arden
description: So much for the sweet smell of success.

title: Like the Number 8 to the Chinese
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  I wasnt totally sure what I was letting myself in for as I solved Zhouqin Burnikels puzzle. This one wasnt so much of an Aha! moment as an Ooooooh, I see whats going on here. And I didnt get to it until I had almost solved the entire grid and was wondering if a first initial at the beginning of each entry is all there was to the theme.

title: Iota of Risk for an Ample Reward
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It stands to reason that, if given a choice, the American N.B.A. fan base would rather see the United States entry in the 2014 FIBA World Cup return from Spain next month with a healthy Derrick Rose than with a gold medal.

title: Shared Vision, Varying Styles
description: WASHINGTON  The two men in open-collar shirts sat facing each other, papers and a BlackBerry strewn on a coffee table, sober looks on both their faces. One leaned forward, gesturing with his left hand, clearly doing the talking. The other sat back in his chair, two fingers pressed to his temple as he listened intently.

title: What Elmo and Spidey Want You to Know: They Have Rights
description: Minnie Mouse and the Penguin from Batman huddled together, looking concerned. They were soon joined by Super Mario, Elmo, Hello Kitty and Goofy, who was carrying his big, plush head in his hands. After a few minutes of talking, they lined up in a row and began to clap and cheer: Si se puede! Yes we can!

title: De Blasio Encounters Rising Friction Over Liberal Expectations
description: In a jovial ceremony last week at Gracie Mansion, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that his vision for a muscular liberal government was going national: More than 30 mayors had pledged to adopt the signature de Blasio agenda of creating what he calls more affordable, inclusive and equitable cities.

title: Settlement May Be Near in Career-Ending Attack That Has Shadowed N.H.L.
description: One of the most violent on-ice events in National Hockey League history seemed headed to resolution Tuesday more than 10 years after it took place, as lawyers prepared an out-of-court settlement to a $68 million lawsuit brought by Steve Moore, a former player, against Todd Bertuzzi, the opponent who attacked him during a game and ended his career.

title: John Blake Jr., Versatile Jazz Violinist, Dies at 67
description: John Blake Jr., a jazz violinist who combined strong classical technique with the expressive power of African-American spirituals, folk music and blues, died on Friday in Philadelphia. He was 67.

title: Edward G. Leffingwell, Curator, Dies at 72
description: Edward G. Leffingwell, a critic and curator who organized three important exhibitions at MoMA/P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens  most notably a survey of the experimental filmmaker Jack Smith  and who as director of the Los Angeles Municipal Art Gallery initiated a citywide biennial of contemporary art, died on Aug. 5 in Flushing, Queens. He was 72.

title: Selig Addresses Tedious Play and Oaklands Decrepit Park
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Commissioner Bud Selig said he felt the pain of fans who complained that Major League Baseball games have grown too tedious and long. He, too, shouts at the television when a batter takes ball one, and gets out of the batters box to adjust his equipment, or when needless seconds tick between pitches.

title: N.H.L. Concussion Lawsuits Consolidated
description: A federal panel ruled that all concussion-related lawsuits brought by retired N.H.L. players would be consolidated into a single suit and heard by the United States District Court in St. Paul, Minn.

title: Ex-Clerk for Staten Island Prosecutor Traded Information for Drugs, Judge Finds
description: New York Citys conflict of interest law is broad but fairly clear.

title: With Yankees Opportunity Knocking, Astros Rudely Slam the Door
description: The Yankees recognize the urgency of their situation as they attempt to keep the Baltimore Orioles from running away with the American League East and try to seal a postseason bid over the final six weeks of the regular season. They also are keenly aware of the opportunity presented by a six-game homestand made up of three games each against the Houston Astros and Chicago White Sox, noncontenders with problems greater than the Yankees.

title: The Making of Marlene Dumass The Widow
description: The South African painter Marlene Dumas routinely paints from photographs, often images of women, altering the compositions in profound ways. Here, she explains how an image of Pauline Lumumba mourning the slaying of her husband, the former prime minister of the Republic of Congo, inspired three works over the course of multiple decades, culminating with two paintings from 2013, both called The Widow.

title: Marlene Dumas
description: One of the most provocative painters of the human form, the South Africanborn artist Marlene Dumas doesnt match the stereotype of artist as solitary genius. Her way is chaotic, more responsive and uncertain  and that is her brilliance.

title: New Members for a Dance Family
description: There are people in the dance world who believe that single-choreographer companies are on their way out. The choreographer Stephen Petronio has not been one of those people. His troupe recently celebrated its 30th anniversary, and in an interview this year in The New York Times, he adamantly defended the idea of a dance company as an instrument of unparalleled value for a choreographer, speaking of the depth of research possible with a family of dancers.

title: A Close Look at Murray and Sharapova Preparing for the U.S. Open (Psst: Its Free)
description: Andy, your legs are jelly.

title: Feeding Your Canine Athlete
description: Many people who run or walk with their dogs treat them like human running partners, offering them sips of Gatorade or half of a sports bar during a workout. But the latest science about performance nutrition for canines underscores that dogs are not people. They have more fur and cellular mitochondria, the small structures in cells that generate energy; lower body weights; and fewer fecal-related inhibitions than their human companions, each of which affects their nutritional needs.

title: Word of the Day | poignancy
description: poignancy  \poi-nyn(t)-se sometimespoi(g)-nn(t)-se\ noun

title: Corrections: August 20, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 20, 2014
description: Reality became scarier than science fiction.

title: In Liberia, a Child Thought to Have Ebola
description: People in Monrovia, Liberia, on Tuesday gathered around, clothed, and later left a 10-year-old boy thought to have Ebola. Health officials later transported the boy to John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Monrovia. He was one of the patients pulled out of a holding center for those suspected of having Ebola when a mob overran it on Saturday.

title: George Hansen, Idaho Congressman and Convicted Swindler, Dies at 83
description: George V. Hansen, a Republican politician whose open disdain for federal authority made him a popular figure in Idaho, where he was elected to Congress seven times, and who twice landed in federal prison, died on Thursday in Pocatello, Idaho. He was 83.

title: Macys to Pay $650,000 to Resolve Bias Inquiry
description: After an 18-month investigation, Macys has agreed to pay a $650,000 fine and hire an independent monitor to address complaints that minority shoppers faced heightened surveillance and, in some cases, wrongful detention at its flagship store in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 7 A.M. (Cinemax) MUNICH (2005) Steven Spielberg ventures beyond this storys historical impetus  the 1972 Olympics, at which 11 Israeli athletes and coaches were killed by members of a Palestinian group known as Black September  to create a philosophical thriller about its aftermath: Israels apparent campaign of vengeance, using five agents who crisscrossed Europe to hunt suspects for years. Eric Bana (above, second from right, with Geoffrey Rush) portrays the films moral center, a former Mossad agent sent on a mission to eliminate those responsible for the deaths. Daniel Craig, Ciaran Hinds, Hanns Zischler and Mathieu Kassovitz play his team. Tony Kushner and Eric Roth wrote the screenplay, based on a book by George Jonas. An unsparingly brutal look at two peoples all but drowning in a sea of their own blood, Munich is by far the toughest film of the directors career and the most anguished, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. But more than anything, she added, Munich is a slammin entertainment filled with dazzling set pieces and geometric camerawork.

title: China Fines Japanese Auto Parts and Bearings Makers in Price Rigging
description: HONG KONG  Chinese regulators on Wednesday intensified their antitrust scrutiny of multinationals, finding 12 Japanese auto parts and bearings manufacturers guilty of fixing prices charged to the Chinese factories of at least five automakers, and imposing fines totaling roughly $200 million.

title: Student Crossword | Animal Life
description: Test your knowledge of animal life by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: After Strike on Family, Fate of Hamas Commander Is Unknown
description: JERUSALEM  The fate of Muhammad Deif, the commander in chief of Hamass military wing, remained a mystery on Wednesday, like much of his life spent in the shadows.

title: As Tension Eases on Fergusons Streets, Focus Turns to Investigation
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. arrived in St. Louis on Wednesday, meeting with community leaders and federal investigators even as local law enforcement officials said they were hopeful that they had turned a corner in calming the restive community of Ferguson after 12 days of protests and unrest.

title: British Construction Giant Carillion Drops Bid for Rival Balfour Beatty
description: Updated, 10:39 a.m. |

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Nearly Invisible World
description: In A World of Creatures That Hide in the Open, Kenneth Chang writes about the deep-ocean world of transparent animals.

title: Metropolitan Opera Clears Last Major Hurdle in Labor Talks
description: The Metropolitan Opera and the union representing its stagehands reached a contract deal early Wednesday morning, clearing the last major hurdle before the company could go ahead with its coming season of operas featuring murderously jealous lovers, dying sopranos and a fellow named Figaro  both before and after his marriage.

title: A U.S. Open to Remember: Navratilova and Evert Look Back
description: Within the bounds of a singles tennis court, Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova knew each other very well. Between 1973 and 1988, the two 18-time Grand Slam champs faced each other 80 times, with Navratilova holding a slight advantage, 43 to 37. Yet remarkably, despite their monumental rivalry, they were close friends off the court. Having so frequently found themselves alone together at the end of a tournament, Evert and Navratilova formed a bond that is difficult to imagine today between champions: They practiced together, helped tune each others strokes and hung out regularly. They even won Wimbledon and the French Open as doubles partners.

title: In Ferguson, Photographs as Powerful Agents
description: Thousands of photographs continue to flood out of Ferguson, Mo., some by photojournalists, but many more by local residents on social media. While these images document quickly unfolding events, they serve another purpose: providing the African-American community with an important outlet for reporting on  and taking control of  the chaos around it.

title: 5 Tibetans Are Said to Die In Chinese Police Custody
description: HONG KONG  Five Tibetans have died in police custody in southwestern China after a protest last week during which residents were shot and wounded, according to the exiled Tibetan government and other groups abroad. The accounts described a flaring of tensions in a mountainous area of Sichuan Province that has long been in turmoil over the Chinese governments rule.

title: Cities Air Problems Only Get Worse With Climate Change
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The threats from climate change are many: extreme weather, shrinking snowpack, altered ecosystems and rising and more acidic seas, to name a few. Another lesser-known issue may hit especially close to home for city dwellers. In the worlds already smoggy metropolises, pollution is likely to grow worse, a phenomenon scientists have taken to calling the climate penalty.

title: Test Yourself | A Mini Golf Champion
description: Below are the first six paragraphs of an Aug. 14 article, Mini Golfs Fresh Face Is Not a Clowns.

title: Battle for Senate Control Puts a Spotlight on Alaska
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  Alaskans are braced for a continued barrage of television ads between now and Election Day in November, bashing or burnishing the reputations of the two men seeking to win Alaskas potentially pivotal, nationally watched Senate race.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: In Berlin, Uber Has Yet to Earn Its Umlaut
description: Uber has brought its taxi-summoning service tothe European market, and last week it was banned in Berlin.

title: New York Today: Tennis Without Tickets
description: Good morning on this hot Wednesday.

title: Soul-Searching in China After Subway Passengers Flee Fainting Foreigner
description: A video of Shanghai subway passengers rushing away from a man who appeared to have fainted has once again sparked debate over whether people in China have become too callous to the needs of others.

title: Daily Report: Steve Ballmer Resigns From Board of Microsoft
description: Steven A. Ballmers era at Microsoft has come to a full stop, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: Landslides After Heavy Rain Kill at Least 36 in Japan
description: ASAHIKAWA, Japan  At least 36 people were killed and seven missing in the western Japanese city of Hiroshima on Wednesday after heavy rain caused flash floods and landslides that buried victims alive as they slept in their homes, the police said. Hundreds of soldiers have been sent to the scene to dig for survivors.

title: 1889: Wandering Cricketer Dies
description: NEW YORK  Charles A. Absoloms wasted life is ended. The famous Cambridge cricketers body lies at the port of Spain, Trinidad, far from the land he loved so well. For upwards of ten years he had lived in America. When he broke loose from associations which bound him to England he bought a rifle and dog and buried himself in the heart of the Rocky Mountains. The reasons for this he never gave. Some said it was a love affair, and that explanation was generally accepted. Wherever he was known, there is deep regret that a life began under such favourable auspices should have ended so sadly.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 21, 1889

title: 2 Bank of England Board Members Support Raising Rates, Minutes Show
description: LONDON  Two members of the Bank of Englands Monetary Policy Committee pushed this month for the central bank to raise interest rates, the first dissenting votes since Mark J. Carney became the banks governor last year, according to minutes of the two-day meeting published on Wednesday.

title: Times Up! We Finally Resolve Our Parts Fiasco
description: It has been 24 hours since I told our customer he could come by and inspect the parts weve been trying to clean and anodize for him. He will be here in another 24 hours.

title: Why More, Not Fewer, People Might Start Getting Health Insurance Through Work
description: In an earnings call last week, Walmart announced that its workers were signing up for health insurance en masse. The news was bad for the companys shareholders, since the added $500 million it will cost to cover them will eat into expected profits. But it also means that many more low-income families have health insurance now than did last year.

title: Where We Went, State by State
description: Last week, we showed you how domestic migration played out over the last 112 years in 51 charts. The reader response was strong, but many wanted the other side of the picture.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Alaska Might Be More Friendly to Democrats Than It Appears
description: Republicans need to win six seats to retake the Senate, and, at first glance, Alaska looks as if it ought to be one of the G.O.P.'s best opportunities. In presidential elections, its one of the most dependably Republican states, and the Democratic incumbent, Mark Begich, won his Senate seat in large part because his opponent was convicted of seven counts of corruption one week before the election. Mr. Begich still only won by less than 2 percentage points.

title: Morning Agenda: Standard Chartereds Backsliding Woes
description: In a settlement announced on Tuesday by New York States financial regulator, the British bank Standard Chartered will pay a $300 million fine and suspend its dollar-clearing activities because of its failure to weed out transactions prone to money-laundering, Ben Protess and Chad Bray write in DealBook. The deal comes two years after the bank paid a combined $667 million to state and federal authorities over similar accusations. Those settlements resolved accusations that Standard Chartered, in part through its New York branch, processed transactions for Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

title: Islanders Owner Announces He Will Sell N.H.L. Team to an Investment Group
description: The Islanders said the team would be sold to a former Washington Capitals co-owner and a London-based investor, Richard Sandomir reports in The New York Times. Read more

title: B. K. S. Iyengar, Who Helped Bring Yoga to the West, Dies at 95
description: NEW DELHI  B. K. S. Iyengar, who helped introduce the practice of yoga to a Western world awakening to the notion of an inner life, died on Wednesday in the southern Indian city of Pune. He was 95.

title: These Kids Today
description: CHICAGO  Late one June night, in the offices of the Steppenwolf Theater Company here, long after the audience had left and the lights were mostly turned out, Michael Cera and Kieran Culkin were busy with an after-hours project: teaching their co-star Tavi Gevinson how to chug.

title: Money Talks. We Sing.
description: As the Metropolitan Operas management and unions negotiated behind one set of closed doors, performers carried on with their rehearsals behind others.

title: Alain Jupp, Ex-Premier of France, Seeks Partys Nomination for President
description: PARIS  Alain Jupp, a former prime minister who rebounded in politics after a criminal conviction in a 2004 corruption scandal, announced on Wednesday that he was seeking the nomination of Frances main conservative party for president.

description: Dear Diary:

title: Michael Halbherr, Head of Nokias Mapping Division, Steps Down
description: Just months after Microsoft bought Nokias handset business for $7.6 billion, the Finnish technology company announced on Wednesday that a senior executive of one of its most important remaining businesses was stepping down.

title: The Thing
description: If Pomellato quietly cemented its reputation as the everyday jewelry of chic European women long ago, this new cabochon-cut coral ring is the Milanese houses most decadent party favor. A one-of-a-kind in the companys Pom Pom haute joaillerie collection, the titanic stone is set in white and rose gold, and surrounded by 141 white diamonds, orange sapphires and red spinels arranged in a mosaic pattern. Requiring more than 300 hours to design, the ring is inspired by the lush equatorial opulence of the 1930s. The only details left to be desired are a black-tie fete and a stiff cosmopolitan.

title: Calmer Protests, But Dozens Arrested
description: Missouri police arrested 47 protesters in Ferguson, Mo., late Tuesday night, as relative peace gave way to another night of demonstrations over the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.

title: Thumbtack, an Online Market for Services, Raises $100 Million
description: It was just a few months ago that Thumbtack, an online marketplace for hiring workers for particular tasks, raised $30 million of financing.

title: Calling Article Divisive, Afghanistan Orders Expulsion of Times Correspondent
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attorney general of Afghanistan on Wednesday ordered the expulsion of an American correspondent for The New York Times, Matthew Rosenberg, and barred him from re-entering the country.

title: A Brooklyn Map That Shows Battle Positions Instead of Trader Joes
description: Good God!

title: Bookshelf: Oh, Brother
description: New picture books include David Somans Three Bears in a Boat.

title: Indian Butter Chicken, by Way of Australia
description: Butter chicken is the General Tsos of Indian food, a great, ever-evolving, cross-continental dish found in Delhi, London, New York, Perth and most points in between. In its purest form, it is yogurt-and-spice-marinated chicken dressed in a velvety red bath comprising butter, onions, ginger and tomatoes, scented with garam masala, cumin and turmeric, with a cinnamon tang.

title: Theaters in China Screen Movies, and Viewers Text Messages
description: A moviegoers worst nightmare or the coolest wave of the future?

title: Leaders Express Outrage as Britain Tries to Identify Beheaded Journalists Killer
description: LONDON  A video released online of the beheading of an American journalist, James Foley, by a masked, English-speaking militant caused outrage on Wednesday, with Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain breaking off a vacation and President Obama vowing to protect Americans everywhere.

title: Loss for Democrats in Midterm Elections Could Be Boon for Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas international woes give his former secretary of state good reason to seek political distance. Hillary Rodham Clintons recent foreign policy criticisms made that clear.

title: Big Deals, Not Such Rich Fees for Bankers
description: In the world of mergers, big is good, but more would be much better.

title: After Jon Lester Deal, a Slump Also Arrives in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Summer was going as well as could be expected for the Oakland Athletics, the small-market, big-hope team with a habit of first-place finishes and first-round postseason exits.

title: Foreign Affairs
description: Mahnaz Ispahani Bartoss knowledge of political history, honed over 25 years as a global policy expert, serves her well in her new venture as a dealer of rare, vintage gems from around the world.

title: Emmys 2014: Whats Your Pick for Top Drama?
description: In advance of the Emmy Awards on Aug. 25, were asking you to tell us who deserved their nominations and who else should have been nominated. Next up is best comedy series. Take a look at this alternate list  its made up of the actual nominees; popular and critical favorites that werent nominated; and my own choices. Cast your votes in the comments, and let us know whos still been left out.

title: Tod Machover Named Composer in Residence for Lucerne Festival
description: Tod Machover, the prolific composer of electronic works and the inventor of several hyperinstruments  hybrids in which standard instruments are enhanced with computer and synthesizer technology  has been appointed composer in residence for 2015 at the Lucerne Festival. His main project will be Symphony for Lucerne, a work meant to capture the spirit and culture of the city, and an installment in a series of city works that already includes A Toronto Symphony: Concerto for Composer and City (2013), Festival City, for Edinburgh (2013) and Between the Desert and the Deep Blue Sea: A Symphony for Perth (2014).

title: 1914: Pope Pius X Dies After Illness
description: ROME  Pope Pius X. died at 1.35 this morning [Aug. 20], and the discussion as to his probable successor is already open. On Tuesday his Holiness passed an uneasy night, which was much troubled by fits of coughing, and his condition became seriously worse yesterday morning. Mgr. Zampini administered the extreme unction. Pius X. then said : May Gods will be done: it is the end. At 1.22 a.m. the Pope murmured some incomprehensible words, and thirteen minutes later Mgr. Bressan leaned over his bed and saw that he was dead.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 21, 1914

title: Rick Perry Turns Himself In
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas turned himself in to the authorities there after being indicted last week on two felony counts of abuse of power.

title: What the World Is Saying About Ferguson
description: The shooting of Michael Brown and the subsequent protests in Ferguson, Mo., have attracted media attention all around the world, prominently featured on the front pages of European dailies, used in the anti-American rhetoric of the state-run media in China, Iran and Russia, and analyzed from India to South Africa.

title: Clashes in Liberia After Ebola Quarantine Order
description: The government ordered the quarantine of West Point, a slum in Monrovia, to try to curb the spread of the deadly Ebola virus.

description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Welcome to the Integratron
description: A U.F.O.-like dome with sci-fi origins has become a mecca for spiritual seekers looking to zone out on its sound baths. One curious writer travels to the Mojave Desert to see what all the noise is about.

title: Who Will Win the Senate?
description: Our state-by-state forecasts are recalculated daily, adding new polls and responding to changes in the political climate.

title: Clashes Erupt as Liberia Sets an Ebola Quarantine
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Soldiers and police officers in riot gear blocked the roads. Even the waterfront was cordoned off, with the coast guard stopping residents from setting out in canoes. The entire neighborhood, a sprawling slum with tens of thousands of people, awoke Wednesday morning to find that it was under strict quarantine in the governments halting fight against Ebola.

title: 1864: Dough-Boys, Over Here
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Embracing Simple Pleasures
description: FROM HUNKS OF JUNK to the Hope diamond, jewelry is ne plus ultra of emotional purchases. It is why I believe (I may be wrong) that the many websites trying to sell it are doomed to be adjuncts. Hey, honey, come check out baubles-bangles-and-bright-shiny-beads.com just doesnt have the same ring to it, no pun intended, as serendipitously wandering into a little shop on the Rue de Beaucoup, or even joining the throng of tourists trying to recreate Audrey Hepburns germinal pastry-crunching scene outside Tiffany.

title: Smithsonians Most Iconic Item: Bao Bao the Panda
description: The voting has ended in the Smithsonian Institutions Summer Showdown, a competition to determine what the institution calls the most iconic item in its vast collection, and the winner is  Chinese. Bao Bao, a baby giant panda born last year at the National Zoo, has triumphed over three symbols of Americana: the original Star-Spangled Banner, Gilbert Stuarts portrait of George Washington and Woody Guthries This Land Is Your Land.

title: Clashes in Liberia After Ebola Quarantine Order
description: The government ordered the quarantine of West Point, a slum in Monrovia, to try to curb the spread of the deadly Ebola virus.

title: Instant Noodles Tied to Heart Risk
description: Instant noodles are cheap, convenient, and tasty to many. Now for the bad news.

title: 36 Hours in Glasgow
description: Drawing on its rich musical and industrial heritage, Glasgow has re-emerged as a vibrant hub of culture, food and night life.

title: 36 Hours in Glasgow
description: Since 2008, the year Glasgow gained Unesco status as a city of music, this reinvented industrial center in western Scotland has solidified its reputation as a night-life and cultural hub. On any given night, you can wander through the West End near the university or later in the centers Merchant City, and find lounges pulsing with electronica, pubs with traditional Gaelic music, sleek restaurants, dive bars and fringe theaters, a melting pot for every taste. This year  referendum for Scottish independence aside  Glasgow is stepping further into the spotlight. A few weeks ago, the Commonwealth Games drew thousands of athletes and visitors; next month the Ryder Cup comes to the Gleneagles resort in Perthshire, northeast of town. The vibrant student life that radiates from the gorgeous campus of the centuries-old University of Glasgow, the rich collections of art in the city museums, the concentration of small shops and vintage treasure troves, and unexpected leafy enclaves are only a few of the citys charms. But ultimately its the openhearted, hospitable and occasionally irreverent people who live here that create such a welcoming city.

title: Obama, Appalled by Beheading, Will Continue Airstrikes
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  President Obama declared on Wednesday that the entire world was appalled by the videotaped beheading of an American journalist by Islamic militants, speaking as American warplanes conducted 14 airstrikes in Iraq and the State Department asked the Pentagon to send as many as 300 more American troops to Iraq for security.

title: At California Resort, Bees Are a Plus
description: The Carmel Valley Ranch resort in Monterey County, Calif., will spotlight its tiny buzzing residents during National Honey Month in September through an array of activities.

title: Games for Your Itchy Trigger Finger
description: IT has been over 20 years since Wolfenstein 3D changed video gaming by giving players the perspective of someone shooting a weapon.

title: App Smart | First-Person Shooter Games
description: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that let people play combat games from their mobile devices.

title: Activist Hedge Fund Claims Victory Over Bob Evans
description: Updated, 12:41 p.m. | After nearly a year of pushing for change at Bob Evans Farms, the activist hedge fund Sandell Asset Management is claiming victory.

title: Today in Small Business: A Vending Machine for Pizza
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Warren Buffetts Company Fined by Justice Dept. Over Stock Purchase
description: Warren E. Buffett may be one of the most admired investors in the world. But that does not exempt his company, Berkshire Hathaway, from having to follow federal securities investment rules.

title: Adding Celebrity Sizzle to a London Neighborhood
description: On a recent, and unusually balmy, summer evening in the Marylebone neighborhood of London, families strolled outside landmark Georgian townhouses and into small playgrounds with lush gardens lined with oak trees. Along the High Street, the areas thoroughfare designed to mimic the main communal stretch of a smaller town, fashionable couples and groups of friends congregated outside local restaurants and bars.

title: Its Di Mondos World
description: As June drew to a close, the young man posed in Capri, Italy, wearing an indigo Prabal Gurung cardigan and sarong that coordinated perfectly with the Mediterranean Sea just behind him.

title: Johnny Manziel to Start Season as Browns Backup Quarterback
description: Not long after the Cleveland Browns selected quarterback Johnny Manziel in the first round of the N.F.L. draft, the teams owner, Jimmy Haslam, said Manziel would sit on the bench this year.

title: The Conservative Divide Over Ferguson
description: Were used to just about every American controversy polarizing swiftly along right-left lines, butthe discussion of events in Ferguson has been a striking exception thus far. Within the commentariat, the most interesting division hasopened within American conservatism, where a large group of conservative and libertarian writers have been much lessinclined than perhaps they/we would have been thirty years ago to give the police the benefit of the doubt. More interesting still is the breadth and diversity of this group: Its not only the predictable police skeptics, the Cato Institute and Reason types; you also have elite-media squishes like myself, fiercer polemicistslikeKevin Williamson and Mark Steyn, and the populist crew at RedState (Erick Erickson, Leon Wolf) raising similar questions about police conduct, along with manyother writers(and, of course, Rand Paul) as well.

title: To Feed More People, a Meal Service Asks Rich Donors for Help
description: Carlos Quijano stacked lunchboxes into the back of a red Ford truck and jumped in beside a driver to roll out to the South Bronx.

title: Holder Arrives in St. Louis
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. arrived at St. Louis airport shortly after noon. He is scheduled to meet with F.B.I. agents who have been conducting a civil rights investigation into the shooting of Michael Brown by a police officer.

title: Was a Recalled Car Fixed? Answer Is Now a Click Away
description: A new online search tool allows consumers to type in a vehicle identification number, or VIN, to check on whether recall repairs have been completed on a specific car, truck or motorcycle. The service, which began Wednesday, is available on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administrations website or the sites of individual automakers.

title: Standard Chartered Fine Should Raise Concern Among Its Investors
description: Standard Chartereds latest blunder hits the bank where it hurts the most. New York States Department of Financial Services has imposed a $300 million fine on the lender for compliance lapses. It reinforces the disturbing impression that Standard Chartereds top leaders are not on top of things.

title: Tuneful Rage, With Chaser
description: Though it has yet to be classified officially as a dangerous weapon, everybody knows that a microphone in the wrong hands is an instrument of torture. Just check out any nearby karaoke bar. Now the site-specific theater company Sister Sylvester has decided to lend a mike and a soundtrack to a seething, internecine set of characters inspired by Look Back in Anger, John Osbornes 1956 drama of high-volume hostility and social alienation. Directed by Kathryn Hamilton, this multimedia riff opens on Aug. 29 at the East Village bar Sing Sing Karaoke under the promisingly disaffected title Dead Behind These Eyes. (Previous pieces from Sister Sylvester, which creates dialogues with other works of art, include Werner Herzog on Wrestlemania.) Prepare for a night of off-key confessions, slurred lyrics, documentary video projections of a world in strife and bottomless shot glasses. (Through Sept. 19, 81 Avenue A, between Fifth and Sixth Streets; 212-352-3101, sistersylvester.org.)

title: Journalist and Afghanistan on Expulsion
description: Matthew Rosenberg, an American correspondent for The New York Times, and Basir Azizi, the spokesman for Afghanistans attorney general, discussed the journalists expulsion from the country.

title: Infineon to Buy International Rectifier, a Chip Maker, for $3 Billion
description: Infineon Technologies, the German chip maker, agreed on Wednesday to buy the International Rectifier Corporation, a specialty semiconductor producer, for about $3 billion in cash to bolster its international presence and gain greater scale.

title: Argentina Seeks to Sidestep U.S. Court in a Bond Dispute
description: Argentinas boldest move yet to sidestep a United States court ruling that sent the country into default last month has left investors scratching their heads.

title: Tuberculosis Is Newer Than Thought, Study Says
description: After a remarkable analysis of bacterial DNA from 1,000-year-old mummies, scientists have proposed a new hypothesis for how tuberculosis arose and spread around the world.

title: Old Greenwich, Conn.: A Front-Porch Kind of Place
description: One night last month, Lesley King received a Facebook message that reflected what she considers one of the finest qualities of Old Greenwich: a connected community.

title: Inequality Delusions
description: Via the FT, a new study compares perceptions of inequality across advanced nations. The big takeaway here is that Americans are more likely than Europeans to believe that they live in a middle-class society, even though income is really much less equally distributed here than in Europe. Ive truncated the table to show the comparison between the U.S. and France: the French think they live in a hierarchical pyramid when they are in reality mostly middle-class, Americans are the opposite.

title: John Boehners Right on Executive Secrecy
description: Its not often that The Times editorial board agrees with John Boehner. But yesterday the speakers office issued a laundry-list of complaints about the Obama administration, and it so happens that its mostly dead on.

title: Fish as Brain Food
description: Eating fish is associated with an increase in brain volume, but it is apparently not because of its omega-3 content, a new study has found.

title: Neanderthals in Europe Died Out Thousands of Years Sooner Than Some Thought, Study Says
description: Neanderthals, our heavy-browed relatives, spread out across Europe and Asia about 200,000 years ago. But when did they die out, giving way to modern humans?

title: A Leader Struggles to Sell Software Meant to Aid Sales
description: YESWARE is a four-year-old company that designs and sells software intended to make it easier for sales teams to record and analyze essential data. Released in late 2012, Yeswares basic version, which can be downloaded free, quickly attracted more than 100,000 users.

title: New App From the Met Museum Will Do  Something
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is introducing a free mobile app for iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch that the museum obliquely describes as a personalized portal to all the events, exhibitions, and artworks at the museum. The app will be available from Apples App Store on Sept. 2; the museum said on Wednesday that an Android version is planned for 2015.

title: Georgia Is the Reason the G.O.P. Is Edging Up in the Overall Senate Race
description: Careful observers will notice that our overall forecast for who will win the Senate this fall ticked slightly higher for the Republicans over the past week. After dropping to 54 percent after the release of second-quarter fund-raising totals, it has climbed to 61 percent, the highest number since mid-June for Leo, our election model.

title: Ancient Atlases
description: Several commenters on my Roman Empire post mentioned the Colin McEvedy historical atlas of the ancient world. Indeed, a great favorite of mine. And it fed right into my Asimov-psychohistory obsession with its declaration, early on, that

title: Ukrainian Troops Press Rebels in Their Eastern Strongholds
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  With street fights and artillery barrages, the Ukrainian military pressed its advance on Wednesday on the two eastern provincial capitals held by pro-Russian separatists in a day of violence that killed 52 civilians and Ukrainian soldiers and an unknown number of rebels.

title: Coalition Soldier Is Stabbed to Death in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A soldier with the NATO-led military coalition was stabbed to death in Kabul on Wednesday, according to Afghan officials and eyewitnesses.

title: In the Future, Life Could Be a Dream
description: Animation is not childs play for Ari Folman.

title: Does Yesware Need to Hire a Vice President of Sales?
description: We just published a case study about a frustrated founder of Yesware, a four-year-old company that makes software that helps sales teams by eliminating the need for sales representatives to spend time on data entry. To his dismay,Matthew Bellows, founder and chief executive of Yesware, saw his 10-person sales team fall far short of the sales goals hed set. And that was with 100,000 known leads  current users of the softwares free version  seemingly primed to be converted into paying customers.

title: Malalas Mother Learns to Read
description: A New York Times correspondent, Jodi Kantor, spoke with Malala Yousafzai, an education activist, about her mother learning to read as an adult.

title: A reading of Oranges & the Ocean by Ada Limon
description: The poet reads her verse on teenage posturing.

title: Experimental Drug Used for Ebola-Related Virus Shows Promise
description: An experimental drug has completely protected monkeys from lethal doses of a virus related to Ebola, bolstering confidence that a similar medicine might be effective if deployed in the current outbreak in Africa, researchers reported on Wednesday.

title: Mother of Malala Yousafzai Learns to Read and Write
description: Years after her own daughter became a global crusader for womens education, Tor Pekai Yousafzai, the mother of Malala Yousafzai, has finally learned to read and write, and to speak a bit of English.

title: Fed Dissenters Increasingly Vocal About Inflation Fears
description: WASHINGTON  An increasingly vocal minority of Federal Reserve officials want the central bank to retreat more quickly from its stimulus campaign, arguing that the bank has largely exhausted its ability to improve economic conditions.

title: T Presents | NYFFF + Monica Menez
description: The New York Fashion Film Festival, in a new collaboration with T, profiles director Monica Menez, whose fashion film Hors doeuvre features model Albe Hamiti in a surreal domestic environment.

title: The DP-100 Is Aston Martins Real-Life Interpretation of a Video Game Sports Car
description: Auto designers have a new place to show off their concept cars, beyond auto shows. Video games are now providing a venue where dream cars can not only be seen but also driven. And those video game cars are making their way into real life as well.

title: Uber Hires an Obama Alum
description: There appears to be a time in the life of every young technology company when its executives realize that they dont understand politics, public policy or public relations and must hire somebody who does. Uber just hit that milestone: On Tuesday it announced that it was hiring David Plouffe, who ran President Obamas 2008 election campaign.

title: Lewis Lapham
Guardians of the Galaxy Soundtrack Holds at No. 1
description: The top three places on the Billboard album chart this week are multiple-artist projects or soundtracks, a phenomenon that happened last in April 2009. Holding the top place for its second week is the Guardians of the Galaxy soundtrack, which, Nielsen SoundScan reports, sold 93,000 copies in the week ending Sunday, a 15 percent drop from the week before, to grab the No. 1 position. Guardians is, however, essentially an oldies album that revives songs like Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrells Aint No Mountain High Enough, Norman Greenbaums ubiquitous Spirit in the Sky, David Bowies Moonage Daydream and Blue Swedes Hooked on a Feeling, all of which sold heftily in their day.

title: House Hunting in ... Lithuania
description: A RENOVATED THREE-BEDROOM APARTMENT IN VILNIUS

title: The Bucket A List: Anna Wintour Takes the Challenge
description: In fashion, the words ice bucket tend to be closely followed by chilled Champagne. But this week, buckets have been more often emptied than filled.

title: Classical Playlist: Mozart, Schubert, Goffredo Petrassi and More
description: MOZART: Piano Concertos No. 25 in C (K. 503) and No. 20 in D minor (K. 466)Martha Argerich, pianist; Claudio Abbado, conductor; Orchestra Mozart(Deutsche Grammophon 4379 1033)The only problem with the artistry of Martha Argerich, one of the most brilliant pianists of modern times, is her occasional wild streak, something that has come out especially in solo repertory. But with the right colleagues in chamber music and the right conductor in concertos, reined in just a bit, Ms. Argerich is often incomparable. She has an ideal colleague in the conductor Claudio Abbado, who recorded two Mozart concertos with her live last March at the Lucerne Festival, now issued as a recording. The performances of the Concerto No. 25 in C and No. 20 in D minor are phenomenal, with Ms. Argerichs vibrant, colorful, imaginative playing held in check just enough by the masterly conducting of Abbado, who draws exciting playing from the festivals Orchestra Mozart. That Abbado died in January makes the recording even more special. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: What You Get for... $1,500,000
description: SEATTLE

title: Chain, a Bitcoin Start-Up, Raises $9.5 Million Led by Khosla Ventures
description: Another virtual currency start-up has attracted real dollars from prominent investors.

title: Big Dreams at the Art Factory
description: North Adams, Mass.  The word that Joseph C. Thompson had been waiting for finally arrived on Aug. 8: Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts had signed a $1.4 billion capital facilities bond bill. Inside was a $25.4 million earmark for the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, which gave Mr. Thompson, the museums director, funds to start the last phase of an effort he helped hatch nearly three decades ago: transforming an abandoned 19th-century factory complex into a destination arts center that could help revive the struggling economy of North Adams.

title: Why the Middle Class Isnt Buying Talk About Economic Good Times
description: For five years, the United States economy has been expanding at a steady clip, the stock market soaring, the headlines filled with talk of recovery. Yet public opinion polling shows most Americans still think the economy is pretty miserable.

title: Bob Marley Musical Set for Baltimores Center Stage
description: Marley, a new musical about Bob Marley, the Jamaican reggae star who died in 1981 at the age of 36, will have its premiere next year at Center Stage in Baltimore, the company announced on Tuesday. The show will feature music composed by Marley, including the songs Exodus and Rastaman Vibration, with a book and direction by Kwame Kwei-Armah, Center Stages artistic director. Set to run May 6 to June 14, 2015, the show is a collaboration between Center Stage and the Public Theater in New York, where Mr. Kwei-Armah directed Detroit 67 and Much Ado About Nothing last year. Oskar Eustis, the Publics artistic director, will be the shows dramaturg.

title: The Invasion of the Flats
description: Who knew that the humblest shoe could become a symbol of power in the working world?

title: Life Took on a Different Tone
description: For as long as I can remember, Ive been blond. As a child, I was a flaxen-haired anomaly in a country-school classroom dominated by redheads and brunettes, which is somewhat surprising given that it was a marauding army of fair-follicled Vikings who settled my hometown, Waterford, Ireland, in A.D. 853. Clearly, the Norsemens genetic legacy was diluted by subsequent waves of swarthy Anglo-Norman invaders.

title: How Dekiema Pogue, Military Spouse and Administrative Assistant, Does It
description: Dekiema Pogue is an administrative assistant at Bank of America in Virginia Beach, Va., supporting a team of seven in the United States, the United Kingdom and Singapore. She has three children, Daniel, 10, Elijah, 11, and Josiah, 16. Her husband is a chief petty officer in the United States Navy, currently stationed at the base in Virginia Beach but sometimes deployed for months at a time.

title: Teachout Can Stay on Ballot Against Cuomo, Appeals Court Says
description: ALBANY  A New York State appeals court ruled on Wednesday that Zephyr Teachout, a law professor who is running against Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in the Democratic primary, can remain on the Sept. 9 ballot.

title: Supreme Court Delays Gay Marriage in Virginia, a Day Before It Was Set to Begin
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday issued a last-minute order delaying same-sex marriages in Virginia, less than a day before officials there were to begin providing marriage licenses to gay couples.

title: What a Difference a Day Makes
description: Before a romantic Caribbean weekend with her new boyfriend, Amanda Sanders decided she needed a little lift. So she called her doctor, Dr. Norman M. Rowe, to help out.

title: A Negroni Summer
description: At the recent opening party for Grand Banks, a meticulously on-trend oyster bar on an old fishing schooner anchored at Pier 25 in Manhattan, all the colors of summer were on Technicolor display: the gold of the sunset, the steel-blue of the Hudson River and the red of the cocktails.

title: Carl Icahn Takes Stake in Hertz to Pressure Its Management
description: Updated, 7:22 p.m. | Carl C. Icahn, the longtime activist investor, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Wednesday that he had accumulated an 8.48 percent stake in Hertz Global Holdings, with plans to put pressure on the rental car companys management.

title: Elisabeth Moss, Mark Duplass and Charlie McDowell on The One I Love
description: Mark Duplass and Elisabeth Moss star in The One I Love, a movie (out Friday) that at first appears to be a talky low-budget indie about a couple who heads to a weekend retreat to repair their marriage. But when it premiered last January at the Sundance Film Festival, audiences were blindsided by a plot twist that takes place 20 minutes into the film and turns the familiar premise on its head. The biggest thing I got was, Thank God I saw this here before everyone ruins the story, Duplass says of the audiences reaction. And they were like, I hope theres some way that you can not tell everyone what happens. At the time, that seemed impossible, and the films cast and the first-time director Charlie McDowell expected their secret to be spoiled on social media and in reviews. Remarkably, that hasnt happened, and the movies distributor latched onto the twist as the linchpin for its marketing campaign. Recently, Moss, Duplass and McDowell joined T for lunch at the Mondrian Soho to discuss how their movie came to be, their own relationships and the art of keeping a secret in an age of oversharing.

title: Shaking Up the Status Quo on Fire Island
description: At 9 p.m. on a recent Saturday, around a pool below the Boatel on Fire Island Pines, the D.J. Vito Fun was playing Iggy Azaleas Fancy and Katy Perrys Dark Horse for a rousing crowd of about 200. When Deborah Coxs Nobodys Supposed to Be Here came on, a reveler threw his head back and said, How perfect is this song right now?

title: Ex-Governor Points the Finger at His Wife in a Virginia Trial
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Beginning the political sales job of his life, Bob McDonnell, the former Virginia governor and once rising Republican star, was called Wednesday afternoon to the witness stand, where he began to lay out the unusual defense that he could not have conspired corruptly with his wife because they were too estranged to manage it.

title: He Finds Homes for the A-List
description: AGE 27

title: After Sale to Bain, Tomss Chief Wants to Expand Global Reach
description: Blake Mycoskie built Toms into a darling of the retail industry in large part by selling simple canvas espadrilles and a unique charitable donation plan. So what is he doing with wealthy financiers known for dressing in designer suits and slick loafers?

title: Pictures of the Day: Liberia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Liberia, Gaza City, Japan and India.

title: President Obama on James Foley, and Muslim Victims
description: The men who killed James Foley, the American journalist, belonged to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, and claimed to be acting in the name of one of the great monotheistic religions of the world with the goal of establishing a caliphate.

title: The Face Is Familiar? Its From the 90s
description: In 1999, Revlon released a lipstick called Sandstorm, a sheer cocoa shimmer that quickly became a sensation. In Revlon ads, Cindy Crawford wore beige tones that contrasted starkly with her dark mocha lips.

title: Police Cameras Can Shed Light, but Raise Privacy Concerns
description: Michael Brown, the unarmed teenager who was shot during an encounter with police in Ferguson, Mo., on Aug. 9, was recorded by a convenience store surveillance camera a few minutes before he was killed, according to police. Then, just after he died, a picture of his body was snapped by a Twitter user who claims to have seen the shooting.

title: Making Old Video Less Shaky
description: Q. I was given some old home movies that were converted to DVD from 8-millimeter film. Wed love to see them clearly enough to recognize who is in them, but the original camera work is so shaky that it makes us queasy to watch. Is there any easy technology out there that can help?

title: A New Set of Believers, but the Same Peppy Faith
description: Clean living, it would seem, really does keep a body healthy. Just look at those nonsmoking, nondrinking boys in The Book of Mormon. Theyve been hanging around in the insalubrious, soul-sapping environs of Broadway for more than three years. Yet they dont look a day older than when they arrived.

title: In Cricket, Captains Wear Many Caps
description: LONDON  One day last week, over the course of about an hour at the famed Oval cricket ground here, Alastair Cook looked at a weather report, examined the condition of the grass, decided whether his team would bat first or second, altered the positioning of some players in the field, made an inquiry with the umpire, gave a pep talk to an important cog in the team and, when necessary, stomped around near a few pigeons that were loitering in the middle of the action. (The pigeons duly flew away.)

title: Soaked for A.L.S., George W. Bush Nominates Bill Clinton for a Bucketful
description: WASHINGTON  A disease-fighting publicity campaign gone viral now has at least one presidential participant. In a video posted on Wednesday, George W. Bush was doused with ice water in the A.L.S. ice bucket challenge  and nominated his predecessor, Bill Clinton, to get wet, too.

title: Earnings at Target Disappoint; Lowes Cuts Sales Outlook
description: A disparate batch of retail companies released lackluster, mostly disappointing earnings results on Wednesday, accompanied by a significantly lowered forecast from Target and more store closings from Staples.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Lip Color Escapes From the Tube
description: Many of falls newest lipsticks arent lipsticks at all. The fat pencils, slender markers and squeezable plastic vials make the traditional twist-up metal tubes look almost pass, retro and ... well,

title: Rebellious Diversity in Song
description: Gordon Voidwell favors brightly patterned sweaters over ripped plaid pants, basketball caps instead of a mohawk. His electro-R&B mixtape Bad tudes layers glossy falsetto harmonies and futuristic synths, not harsh guitar distortion and rude epithets about the queen. His style is just one example of the contrarian spirit in New Yorks growing Afropunk scene. When we think of what punk is, theres such a specific branding  the Ramones, the Sex Pistols  but the idea of punk is just to be counterculture, to take what we all perceive as the norm and revolt against it, said Mr. Voidwell, 30, who grew up in the Bronx. Afropunk is about fracturing the idea of what black arts are, what black music is.

title: Incentives for War, Beyond Material Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Why We Love What We Dont Understand
description: When I was a kid, I read Gaston Lerouxs novel The Phantom of the Opera. I dont remember much about it  very little about the titular phantom, or Christine, or the love story popularized in the Andrew Lloyd Webber version. What I remember is the rat-catcher.

title: In Iraq, Dread Is in the Air
description: Many soldiers, reporters and commentators have compared the Iraq war to a deadly, sickening version of the Bill Murray movie Groundhog Day  a war not of decisive battles but of seemingly endless efforts to take individual streets and towns, only to lose them and have to fight to take them again, all at enormous, heartbreaking cost.

title: Is Job Training Doing What Its Supposed to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Theyll Play the Garden, if Their Lives Let Them
description: ASHLAND, Ore.  Negotiating the choppy waters of middle age isnt easy for anyone, but its extra ornery for the almost-famous rock n rollers in Family Album, the half-marvelous, half-maddening new musical by Stew and Heidi Rodewald (Passing Strange), which is having its premiere here at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. Endless nights on the road, grotty club bathrooms, meager pay, fending off (or not) the groupies: Its all much easier to deal with when you have the resilience of youth and the energy of high ambition to fuel you.

title: Dont Raise Beer Taxes
Con Ed Sells Building Near Ground Zero Where Plans for Mosque Caused Uproar
description: Consolidated Edison, which once owned the nuclear reactors at Indian Point, has finally unloaded a property that may have been the source of even more controversy.

title: An Ethereal Performance, Flickering and Calm
description: The Belle poque splendor of the Park Avenue Armorys Board of Officers Room seems like an incongruous setting for performances of contemporary music. Yet this summer, the elegantly austere room with its recently renovated stenciled ceiling, mahogany wainscoting and bronzed chain curtains hosted the International Contemporary Ensemble during its residence at the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Inquiry Urged on Air Force Academys Handling of Sexual Assault Cases
description: Two senators called Wednesday for an independent investigation into the handling of sexual assault cases at the Air Force Academy, saying they were concerned about very serious allegations of wrongdoing.

title: Sharing, and Borrowing From, the Vacation Photo Album
description: MODERN-DAY vacation scenes unfolded this summer on a trip to Tuscany.

title: Arabs and Israelis Find Common Ground Under a Baton
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  It has been a success in a small way, the conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim said in an interview at his hotel here on Monday. The question had been whether he was ready to pronounce the experiment that is the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra a success.

title: Sharing Photos With Friends
description: In honor of vacation season, Molly Wood tests out several services designed to let you share photographs as a group, but still maintain your privacy.

title: Thom Yorkes All-Black Arm Accessories
description: Accessorizing for men can be tough, but Thom Yorke of Radiohead, recently seen out in Los Angeles, pulls off a bevy of pieces at once in a very rock n rollway. That is to say, all in black, and in great numbers. Here, some alternatives to get a similar monochromatic look on the wrist. Wearing them all at once or individually is up to you.

title: Americas Message: At Ease, Men
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton remarked, in her much-ballyhooed jab at the Obama administration, that Americans dont even tell our own story very well these days, she had clearly forgotten her old friend Ralph Lauren. Few story lines in the current global marketplace remotely approach the enduring narrative mojo of the American dream, and few designers have more truly emblematized it or exported it to greater success.

title: United Parcel Service Confirms  Security Breach
