Yet its setup has the makings of a comedy sketch: A Sicilian mobster, Salvo (Saleh Bakri, holding every inch of screen), meets a blind woman, Rita (Sara Serraiocco), who soon after begins to see the light. Its a moment that summons the New Testament prophecy about the blind seeing, but its also old-fashioned movie-made hokum.

title: Charting Love, Longing and Loss
description: Matthew Thomass devastating debut novel, We Are Not Ourselves, does not trumpet the fact that its an honest, intimate family story with the power to rock you to your core. It begins on a modest note. Instead of going to the priest, its opening sentence says, the men who gathered at Dohertys Bar after work went to Eileen Tumultys father. But if Eileen, the books wrenchingly credible main character, had not been raised by such a secular Irish-born strongman (and an alcoholic mother as tender as an ice cube), her life would never have followed the path it did.

title: A Spiritual Seeker Seeks Close to Home
description: KABBALAH ME

title: The Yankees No. 6 Looks Back
description: The Yankees retired Joe Torres number in a ceremony at Yankee Stadium. The New York Timess Tyler Kepner recently interviewed Torre about his long baseball career.

title: Hail, the Postwar Avant-Garde
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.  About halfway through the 20th century, the international postwar artists who called themselves the Zero Group tried to hit the reset button. As they saw it, modern art had been irretrievably damaged by two world wars. The only thing to do was start over.

title: A Crackdown on Law Firms
description: At least 1,000 borrowers who signed on to mass joinder lawsuits against their mortgage lenders were allegedly scammed by two law firms that claimed to be acting on their behalf, according to a suit filed by attorneys general in Connecticut and Florida.

title: One Expressive Evening
description: Musical lines are like sentences, and their character can vary as much as sentences do. Some players will produce a given passage plainly, like a quotation from John Grisham. But on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra under David Zinman, the star violinist Joshua Bell was like a Henry James in tone.

title: Four Days That Inspired Torres Four Rings
description: We measure greatness by championships, so the four that Joe Torre won as the manager of the Yankees are the cornerstones of his career, which the team celebrates on Saturday by retiring his No. 6 and unveiling a plaque in Monument Park.

title: Sisters Fight (It Keeps Them Together)
description: SEE YOU NEXT TUESDAY

title: Where Are the National Democrats on Ferguson?
description: There is something very strange about the national political reaction to the protests in Ferguson, Mo., (and nationally) over Michael Browns shooting. The protesters are angry, and theyre not aimlessly angry. They have a specific set of policy grievances about policing and criminal justice that are shared by a large slice of the electorate, particularly the Democratic primary electorate.

title: Two Silent Men, Deep in Conversation
description: Thequadricentennial celebration of the death of El Greco, the great painter of the Spanish Renaissance, will eventually include six East Coast museums this fall, but it is already off to a roaring start with a mouse-size exhibition at the Frick Collection. Men in Armor brings together only two canvases, both portraits of bearded Italian gentlemen wearing gleaming cuirasses, as upper-body armor has been called since the time of the Romans. One is a stalwart of the Fricks collection by El Greco, purchased in 1913, when Henry Clay Frick was building the Fifth Avenue mansion that was ultimately intended to become a museum for his extensive collection. The other painting, on loan from a private collection and rarely exhibited, is by El Grecos Roman contemporary, Scipione Pulzone.

title: We Pledge Allegiance ...
description: A friend of mine believes a king-size bed leads to a divorce. Her parents had a king-size bed, and when she was in college her father confessed to having an affair. He blamed the ensuing divorce on a lack of intimacy, but my friend blamed it on her parents too-big bed.

title: In Limbo, and in Love
description: This summer has been bookended by two movies, both based on young adult best sellers and starring gifted and ambitious actresses, about smart, independent-minded teenage girls finding love in the shadow of death. It is hard to avoid comparing If I Stay, which opens on Friday, with The Fault in Our Stars, but there is also no reason to choose between them. Each one is a cleanly directed, credibly acted machine for the production of tears.

title: In Praise of Hindu Gods, With Sharp Turns and Barefoot Rhythms
description: Krishna was evoked, Ganesha was praised, the 10 avatars of Vishnu were illustrated, seven of the eight classical dance forms of India were demonstrated  and the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island were on the horizon throughout. Passing runners and cyclists slowed down to gawp at the costumes, steps and gestures. Even yachts in the harbor veered in their course to get a better view.

title: Ferguson and A.L.S. Give Rise to the Bullet Bucket Challenge
description: Over the past three weeks, weve had our Facebook news feeds flooded with videos of friends and celebrities from Bill Gates to George W. Bush to Anna Wintour pouring buckets of ice and water on their heads, all to raise awareness of the degenerative condition A.L.S., known as Lou Gehrigs disease. As of Thursday, donations to the A.L.S Association topped $41 million.

title: Sex and the Single Sister
description: You would think that a movie involving sex websites, attractive young bodies, decapitations and Bangkok should easily deliver what its target audience wants: sleaze, gore, some low-grade thrills.

title: 100 Years of Gratitude
description: We forgot.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Racial Imagery
description: The phrase so wrong in so many ways could easily have been invented to describe the picture that flits by about four minutes into Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People. Its a print advertisement from the 1940s that shows a smiling black boy with a big slice of watermelon, under the headline, Its sweeter because of petroleum. The copy below, promoting Shell, suggests that buying gas makes the earth more bountiful. Racial stereotyping and petrochemical addiction, advanced in a single image.

title: Rumblings of Volcanic Activity in Iceland
description: Updated, 1:14 p.m. | Officials in Iceland closed the airspace over Bardarbunga volcano south east of Reykjavik Saturday afternoon after seismic activity data indicated that an eruption had occurred beneath the surface of the Vatnajokull glacier, under which the volcano sits.

title: Catch Me if You Can, Satan
description: Dim in wits and lighting, The Possession of Michael King strains our eyes, spits on our intelligence and saps our generosity of spirit. Relatively untaxed, however, is the part of the brain that processes new experiences: Theres scarcely a shot or an idea in this first feature from David Jung that we havent seen many times before.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Ukraine, Indonesia and China.

title: Savoring the Agony of Defeat
description: You get Bible verses. You get platitudes. And in the football movie When the Game Stands Tall, you get an overeager Foley artist who makes every physical contact on the gridiron sound like an explosion. On the other hand, you get Jim Caviezel, who, from time to time, makes you want to be a high school coach in your next life.

title: Botox Maker Allergans Suit Against Valeant Wont Delay Special Meeting
description: Updated, 7:00 p.m. | When Allergan, the maker of Botox, sued Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management this month in a federal court in California, claiming insider trading, its opponents said the suit was an attempt to prevent shareholders from calling a special meeting until the case was resolved. Pershing Square, Allergans largest shareholder, is pressing for a special meeting as it pursues a hostile takeover of the company with its partner, Valeant.

title: Mighty Women Wielding Words (and Swords)
description: During the climactic episode of Farewell My Concubine, one of the seminal works of Mei Lanfang, the acknowledged master of the genre of Peking Opera, the beloved concubine of the King of Western Chu entertains her man with a dizzying sword dance. On Wednesday night at the David H. Koch Theater, to open a four-day run of performances to commemorate the 120th anniversary of Meis birth, a theater troupe from Beijing performed a trimmed version of this work, starring the captivating Shang Wei as the devoted concubine. During that sword dance, a delighted audience kept breaking into applause as Ms. Shang twirled around in her stunningly colorful costume and headdress, thrusting her sword, tossing it skyward, catching it behind her back, never losing composure, always the picture of stoic, stylized beauty.

title: Video Nominees Wear Pride (Hats, Too)
description: A LTHOUGH MTV years ago abandoned music videos for reality shows, its annual Video Music Awards remains a barometer of mainstream pop. This year, Beyonc leads the field with eight nominations, followed by Eminem and Iggy Azalea with seven each. The show, now in its 30th year, will be broadcast from the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., on Sunday at 9 p.m. and will feature performances by Beyonc, Taylor Swift and Maroon 5. Spontaneous moments in the show have often upstaged the videos. Remember Kanye West interrupting Ms. Swift in 2009 or Miley Cyrus gyrating on Robin Thicke last year? But the five nominees for video of the year (four feature women) each have moments that subtly reveal the musicians larger artistic identities.

title: Riding With the Music of My Gears
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brick Beauty Bites the Dust
description: The preservation movement may have been born when Penn Station was demolished in 1963, but it had a long period of gestation. Probably the most regretted structure to be taken down in the years before the station fell was George B. Posts colossal New York Produce Exchange, on the east side of Broadway, opposite Bowling Green.

title: Pre-Wedding Jitters in Jordan
description: The May of May in the Summer is not the month but the main character (Cherien Dabis, who wrote and directed), a New York-based writer who returns to Amman, Jordan, to marry.

title: Martial Arts Warriors Crowd a Fried-Noodle Western
description: A Chinese swords-and-martial-arts adventure that takes place during the Ming dynasty, 14 Blades reframes the wuxia epic as another genre peopled by antiheroes with personal codes of honor: the spaghetti western. Its not a bad fit.

title: At an Israeli University, Freedom of Expression Prevails
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Final Frontier in Playful Celebrity Activism
description: Like other pop culture figures, George Takei  a.k.a. Mr. Sulu on Star Trek  cultivated a loyal fan base and became politically engaged. But fleshing out his timeline, as he does in Jennifer M. Kroots To Be Takei, uncovers something more surprising and even moving: a childhood in a Japanese-American internment camp during World War II; many years in entertainment lived as a closeted gay man; and, more recently, an outspoken stint as a marriage rights activist.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Clemency Commission
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: A Surfin Safari With Deserving Prey
description: The concept of prostituting the brand loses some of its impact with Jersey Shore Massacre, a spinoff of MTVs anthropological study of the bronzed, buffed and boneheaded. None of the original participants of Jersey Shore appear, although Jenni Farley, better known as JWoww, serves as executive producer.

title: Behind the Scenes of Bondage and S-and-M
description: We dont fake anything, a friendly director tells us in Kink, a fascinating profile of the online pornography provider Kink.com, the go-to destination for bondage and sadomasochism enthusiasts. But the authenticity of the orgasms is only one of the companys distinguishing features; in an industry not known for its respectful treatment of performers (known here as models), Kink offers a safe, consensual workplace where the submissives are in charge.

title: Two Psychiatrists, on Treating Schizophrenia
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Declining a Work Assignment, With Finesse
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Under Cover: Eugenie Bouchards Big Moment
description: Eugenie Bouchard is a player on the brink, as Susan Dominus puts it in this weeks cover story. To capture the 20-year-old Canadian tennis player in pictures at this moment of promise, the magazine turned to Ruven Afanador. The Colombian-born photographer has previously shot a number of women for the magazine, including Twyla Tharp, Tyra Banks, Anna Netrebko and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Kathy Ryan, the magazines director of photography, calls him a great portraitist who knows how to bring out the elegance of shape in a photograph. Recently he spoke about photographing Bouchard in a Montreal studio earlier this month.

title: Reactions to the Shooting in Ferguson, Mo., Have Sharp Racial Divides
description: The New York Times and CBS News interviewed adults nationwide about their views on race relations, their relationships with law enforcement and their reactions to the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo.

title: Poll Shows Broad Divisions Amid Missouri Turmoil
description: A poll taken since a white police officer in Missouri shot dead an unarmed black teenager shows blacks and whites sharply divided on how fairly the police deal with each group, along with a rising feeling, especially among whites, that race relations in the country are troubled. But when asked about their own communities, members of each race say their relations with the other are good.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 22-28
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: New York Times/CBS News Polling Results
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll reveals a racial divide in how Americans view the reactions of the president and the Missouri governor to the turbulence in Ferguson, Mo.

title: Hagel Says ISIS Is a New Kind of Threat
description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said that the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is more than just a terrorist group.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 22-28
description: Stories and Stilts

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 19 and 20 with 1,025 adults throughout the United States.

title: Rag & Bone Mens Wear Spring 2015 Collection
description: Designers on both sides of the ocean are creating their own grab bag of American looks for 2015.

title: Michael Kors Mens Wear Spring 2015 Collection
description: Designers on both sides of the ocean are creating their own grab bag of American looks for 2015.

title: Michael Bastian Mens Wear Spring 2015 Collection
description: Designers on both sides of the ocean are creating their own grab bag of American looks for 2015.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 22-28
description: Around Town

title: Ralph Lauren Mens Wear Spring 2015 Collection
description: Designers on both sides of the ocean are creating their own grab bag of American looks for 2015.

title: A Beach Project Built on Sand
description: EARLIER this month, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a $207 million plan to dredge millions of tons of sand off the south shore of Long Island and spread it along the beaches and dunes. The Army Corps of Engineers, which will direct the federally financed project, says it will stabilize Fire Island and reduce the storm surge hazard for the mainland.

title: Frustrated Judge Scolds Argentina but Does Not Hold It in Contempt
description: A federal court judge said on Thursday that Argentinas attempt to skirt one of his rulings was lawless but stopped short of finding the country in contempt of court.

title: An Inky World of Damaged Souls and Demented Evil
description: It has been almost a decade since Sin City heaved itself on to our movie screens, a dark parade of ugly mugs and uglier behavior. Back in 2005, the films worshipful, impeccable realization of Frank Millers graphic novels was divertingly original, even if none of its characters looked quite human or breached two dimensions.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 22
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images from a fire in Manhattan and the Ice Bucket Challenge in Brooklyn.

title: This Is Definitely Not Madison Avenue
description: When it played at last years Toronto International Film Festival, Are You Here was called You Are Here. That a statement could become a question  one so tentative it apparently didnt need a question mark  suggests the uncertain aims of the film, the second feature directed by the Mad Men creator Matthew Weiner and the first to receive a theatrical release.

title: Hawks Crying Wolf
description: According to a recent report in The Times, there is dissent at the Fed: An increasingly vocal minority of Federal Reserve officials want the central bank to retreat more quickly from its easy-money policies, which they warn run the risk of causing inflation. And this debate, we are told, is likely to dominate the big economic symposium currently underway in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

title: Patient No. 9413
description: My mother was a woman hollowed out like a tree struck by lightning. I wanted to know why.

title: Parents United in Their Pride
description: Portraits of parents whose children are competing in the Little League World Series.

title: Rebels Falter, but Russian Border Buzzes With Military Activity
description: DONETSK, Russia  They arrive every day, carloads of young men and women in camouflage who pass through this Russian border checkpoint before heading for the battlefields of eastern Ukraine.

title: A Fast-Food Symbol of America Falls in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Sanat Parmanova arrived at Moscows flagship McDonalds just off Pushkin Square on Thursday evening as a woman on a mission. Her friend Svetlana Toktorbayeva was carrying a takeout bag of wings from KFC, but Ms. Parmanova had a different dinner in mind: a double cheeseburger, country-style fries, cheese sauce and a medium Coke, no ice.

title: Nascar Sends Fans Into Battle to Expand Its Racing Empire
description: NASCAR is continuing efforts to broaden its appeal while holding on to longtime fans with a campaign that will portray popular drivers and their supporters as nation-states fighting for hegemony.

title: Marketers Are Sizing Up the Millennials
description: Millennials have been called a lot of names. Narcissistic, lazy, indecisive. They have been labeled the boomerang generation for the many unable or unwilling to leave their parents home, or even more negatively, the Peter Pan generation because they supposedly wont grow up.

title: At Arab Banks Terrorism Trial, Victim Recalls Seeing Suicide Bombers Body
description: It was a bit after midnight, and the crowd at Mikes Place, a beachfront bar in Tel Aviv, was still thick, as people stayed for a jam session that attracted local musicians.

title: Wall Street Banks Dig Deeper to Keep Best and Brightest Junior Bankers
description: Working on Wall Street once conferred a certain prestige, a path to riches and an oh-so-important swagger. The big-name investment banks had top candidates lining up at their recruiting tables and thousands of applicants for the few coveted spots.

title: A Faster Track to Teaching Raises Concerns Over Quality
description: AUSTIN  A billboard that periodically springs up along Texas highways asks two questions: Want to teach? When can you start?

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Innovation Within Reach
description: In a world with microchip implants, car-to-car communication, and talk of drone delivery services, it can seem as if innovation is becoming increasingly high-tech. But what about the worlds poorest, for whom such gadgets are out of reach? What types of innovation would be most beneficial for them?

title: Events in New Jersey for Aug. 24-30, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Death by Terror
description: The reaction to the terrible death of James Foley, the freelance journalist kidnapped and executed by Islamist extremists, comes in stages. First and foremost is the grief at the cruel death of a brave reporter who knowingly risked his life to tell a critical story.

title: Europe Fears Banks Lack Cash Cushion to Cover Bad Loans
description: As Europe slogs through its latest round of bank stress tests, a growing number of analysts have already reached their own conclusion: Eurozone banks need additional cash.

title: With School Closed, Teachers and Volunteers in Ferguson Work to Fill Gap
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The teachers stood on a street corner near Griffith Elementary School here on Thursday, jumping and dancing as they tried to get drivers attention. No, the school was still not open for classes. But children could at least pick up free lunches there.

title: Events on Long Island for Aug. 24-30, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Short-Lived Science Line From Lego for Girls
description: Lego is demonstrating this summer that role models in science and technology for girls are still fairly scarce in toy land, just as in the real world.

title: Judge Drops Charges for 8 in an Inquiry on Benefits
description: A state judge on Thursday dismissed charges against six police officers and two other city workers who had been accused in a huge fraud investigation of faking mental illnesses to obtain federal disability benefits.

title: German Broadcaster Fires Chinese Blogger
description: BERLIN  In the wake of a debate over the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, a well-known Chinese government critic has been fired from her job at a German public broadcaster.

title: Obama Cares. Look at the Numbers.
description: AS the predominantly black, disproportionately poor community of Ferguson, Mo., erupted in protest after the shooting death of Michael Brown, critics excoriated President Obama for his failure to empathize. Michael Eric Dyson, for example, called the presidents statement about the case on Monday a stunning epic failure.

title: Get Predatory Colleges Out of Job Training
description: For-profit educational institutions that leave students with heavy debts and worthless credentials do not belong in the nations job-training system. Yet institutions like Corinthian Colleges, which reached an agreement last month with the Department of Education to sell or shut down its campuses, have been ripping off students and taxpayers for years by making false promises and cashing in on federal job-training programs. Regulators and lawmakers have been slow to catch on.

title: Ice Bucket Challenge Raises Millions
description: With people as varied as former President George W. Bush and Justin Bieber, the viral Ice Bucket Challenge has now raised more than $41.8 million for Lou Gehrigs disease.

title: James Oseland, Saveurs Editor, Quitting to Revamp Magazine at Rodale
description: James Oseland, the editor in chief of the food magazine Saveur, said on Thursday that he was leaving his position to join the publisher Rodale.

title: Bank of America Papers Show Conflict and Trickery in Mortgages

title: In Steps of Grandfather, a German Soldier in France
description: MERCY-LE-HAUT, France  Most of the buildings in this tiny village in northeastern France are hidden behind trees that were not here a century ago. But the bell tower of the 150-year-old church of St. Salvin is still visible from a gentle rise about a half-mile away, where more than 6,000 German soldiers aimed their guns across a wheat field on the morning of Aug. 22, 1914.

The march of clergy members, black and white and demanding a full investigation into police actions in St. Louis County, wound from the well-groomed and highly regarded high school, past the curious onlookers out for sushi or Starbucks, and finally to the county prosecutors office.

It was a lousy morning to be on the backside, but the Clancy brothers were there Tuesday, braving the steady rain and up to their boots in mud as they distributed their daily newspaper and gathered the next days news. Theres no use publishing The Saratoga Special if you cant get it in the hands of your loyal readers. And for 14 years, Joe and Sean Clancy have been its paperboys as well as its owners.

title: Drought Said to Claim Trillions of Gallons
description: About 63 trillion gallons of groundwater have been lost across the West since the start of last year because of a severe drought, a study found. The loss is not only forcing farmers to drill deeper wells, it has caused the crust of the earth in the region to rise. A study from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego, found that the earths crust, which is normally weighed down by groundwater, had risen 0.15 inches over the last two years. The rise was most drastic in the California mountains, which have risen more than half an inch. The study was first published in the journal Science on Thursday.

title: For a Skin Cancer Survivor, the Sand Isnt Nearly as Menacing as the Sun
description: PARAMUS, N.J.  As Jimmy Walker stood on the tee at the fifth hole at Ridgewood Country Club, sun peered through the clouds, and a refrain popped into his head: reapply, reapply.

title: A Shield in Space

On a Friday, that kind of clue could go in all sorts of directions, and this was mostly straightforward, which my brain did not expect. I was thinking butterflies, and Mr. Ezersky was indulging in ROYALISM.

title: Saudi Arabia: Executions Draw Rebukes
description: Saudi Arabias judicial authorities have beheaded at least 19 convicted criminals since Aug. 4, nearly half of them for nonviolent offenses, including one for sorcery, Human Rights Watch said Thursday, calling the spate of executions particularly egregious. In a report on its website drawn from Saudi government news dispatches, Human Rights Watch said seven convicts were beheaded for drug smuggling, including four in the southeast city of Najran this week. Amnesty International, which also reported on the Najran beheadings, said the four had been forced to confess under torture. Saudi Arabia has executed at least 34 people this year, Amnesty International, said, and it executed at least 79 in 2013. The country has historically rejected international standards for offenses deemed insufficient for capital punishment, applying it to crimes that include adultery, armed robbery, apostasy, drug trafficking, rape and witchcraft.

title: A History of Sarah Burtons Inspired Collections and Stage Sets for Alexander McQueen
description: In The Genius Next Door, Andrew OHagan profiles the soft-spoken Alexander McQueen designer Sarah Burton, who since assuming the mantle of creative director after McQueens death in 2010 has emerged as a visionary talent in her own right. Over the course of eight seasons at the helm of the house, Burton has consistently turned out darkly romantic and fantastical collections. And the stage sets on which they have been presented  some stripped-down, others over the top  have been nearly as compelling. Here, a history of her runway presentations.

title: Loulou de la Falaise: The Real Deal

title: Who Is Elena Ferrante?
description: The writer known by that name has never been photographed, interviewed in person or even made a public appearance, but a collection of fiercely candid novels has earned her (him?) recognition as one of the keenest observers of Italian society. On the eve of the publication of Those Who Leave and Those Who Stay, the much-anticipated third volume in the authors Neapolitan series, three admirers celebrate this elusive talent.

title: The Genius Next Door
description: Shy, unassuming and nice, Sarah Burton, the Alexander McQueen designer, is everything that her magically haunting collections are not.

title: 10 Seminal Writers Who Hid Their Identities, From Jonathan Swift to J.K. Rowling
description: The identity of Elena Ferrante, the elusive author (and subject of a series of essays in the current issue of T) who has never been photographed, interviewed in person or seen in public, is a matter of intense debate thanks to her sharp, autobiographical novels, which explore female friendship in the context of Italian society. On the eve of the publication of Those Who Leave and Those Who Stay, the third volume in Ferrantes Neapolitan series, we offer a short history of literary masks, from Jonathan Swift to J.K. Rowling.

title: Judges Are People, Too
description: For centuries, Justice was routinely depicted as blind, but jurists knew otherwise. The life of the law has not been logic: it has been experience, Oliver Wendell Holmes said. Benjamin Cardozo agreed that the great tides and currents which engulf the rest of men, do not turn aside in their course and pass judges by. And Sonia Sotomayor, when she was still an appeals court judge, declared that a judges ethnicity and gender may and will make a difference in our judging.

title: Foleys Parents Release Email From Captors
description: The parents of James Foley, the American journalist beheaded by Islamist militant kidnappers, released on Thursday an email from his captors, dated Aug. 12, in which the militants proclaimed with strident bombast that he would be the first of many Americans to die.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) KILL YOUR DARLINGS (2013) A tale of the Beat movement in its larval stage, this film from John Krokidas pictures Allen Ginsberg (Daniel Radcliffe), Jack Kerouac (Jack Huston) and Lucien Carr (Dane DeHaan, above with Mr. Radcliffe at left) as restless young intellectuals in 1940s New York City. (William S. Burroughs, less young but equally restless, is played by Ben Foster.) Ginsberg is the films protagonist and moral center, but the plot revolves around Carrs friendship with his former teacher, David Kammerer (Michael C. Hall), which edged into obsession and ended with a fatal confrontation in Riverside Park. The film is at once a lurid true-crime chronicle and a coming-out story, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Its vision of the past is stereoscopic, affirming Allens erotic self-discovery even as it explores the shadows of the closet where he and his friends must dwell.

title: Afropunks, Come as You Are

In many Southern communities, desegregating white neighborhoods came slowly, as black families like mine fled cities in search of safer and affordable housing. In my case, we moved to Stone Mountain, famed for its enormous bas-relief of Confederate heroes.

title: The End of Liberal Zionism
description: LONDON  Liberal Zionists are at a crossroads. The original tradition of combining Zionism and liberalism  which meant ending the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza, supporting a Palestinian state as well as a Jewish state with a permanent Jewish majority, and standing behind Israel when it was threatened  was well intentioned. But everything liberal Zionists stand for is now in doubt.

One of them, Ms. Zheng, dropped down on one knee, revealing a message boldly written in red on a whiteboard behind them: My vagina does not come free with my labor. More words were written on the womens thighs, reiterating: Not freebies. And then, a food deliveryman who was briefly detained to serve as cameraman released the shutter.

title: Morning Agenda: The True Cost of Bank of Americas Settlement
description: THE TRUE COST OF BANK OF AMERICAS DEAL | The Justice Department has collected huge sums from big banks for their role in selling troubled mortgages before the financial crisis. But in the end, the financial pain inflicted by these settlements  including the $16.65 billion deal with Bank of America announced on Thursday  may not be as great as these numbers suggest, DealBooks Peter Eavis and Michael Corkery write. The actual financial burden for Bank of America, for example, may not exceed $12 billion, significantly less than the number the government trumpets.

title: Chinese Death Row Inmate Acquitted After 8-Year Ordeal
description: Nian Bin was sentenced to death four times, convicted of fatally poisoning two children in eastern China. Each time, he appealed and a higher court ordered another hearing. Then on Friday, judges declared Mr. Nian not guilty and freed him from death row, abruptly ending an eight-year ordeal that lawyers said exemplified the Chinese judiciarys reluctance to overturn its own gross injustices.

And that is what Wendel and Carolyn Thompson, of Columbia, Md., have been grappling with since January as they prepare to leave their split level and move to a retirement community this month.

title: Power of Attorney Is Not Always a Solution
description: FOR millions of people over the decades, the power of attorney has been an inexpensive way to give someone the right to act on another persons behalf. But its power is not always absolute and when it fails, the consequences can be nothing short of disastrous.

title: Blurred Lines in Big Bank Mortgage Settlements
description: The latest settlement with a big bank, this time Bank of Americas $16.65 billion resolution over shoddy mortgage and related mortgage-backed securities that lost much of their value, has all the accoutrements we have come to expect: a claim of historic significance supported by a statement of facts referencing a few embarrassing e-mails to establish the requisite venality for a large penalty. A prominent feature is a news conference where Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. hails the resolution as yet another blow against the reckless (or worse) banking practices that led to the financial crisis.

title: Lizzy Caplan, Sex-Ed Teacher to the World
description: The actress talks to Eric Spitznagel about awards shows, the allure of reality television and that one time she applied for the C.I.A.Youre nominated for an Emmy for outstanding lead actress in a drama series, Masters of Sex. Can we be presumptuous and assume youre going to win on Aug. 25? I dont think its fair to assume that at all. Im Jewish, so Im predisposed to assume theres no chance in hell thats going to happen.

title: Serena Williamss Secret Weapon
description: Sascha Bajin  Big Sascha, as hes known in tennis circles  figures that he spends about 330 days a year with Serena Williams. Usually, when he takes time off, he says, I tell her not to call me, not to text me, not to contact me at all. But this summer was different. After a disappointing Wimbledon, in which Williams lost in the third round in singles and retired from a doubles match with her sister Venus, Bajin whisked her away to Croatia for two weeks. When she returned to competition, Williams won the first tournament she played. Accepting the trophy, she dedicated the victory to the 29-year-old Bajin  her longtime hitting partner, a man with perhaps the most specialized job in all of tennis.

title: Can U.S. Mens Tennis Rise Again?
description: For an American growing up today, it can be difficult to imagine that the United States once dominated the mens professional tennis circuit. It would be nice if America actually had a famous tennis player, said Noah Rubin, an 18-year-old who will make his first appearance in the United States Open this week. In 2003, the last year an American man won a Grand Slam tournament  Andy Roddick at the U.S. Open  Rubin was just starting second grade on Long Island. Any of my friends who arent huge tennis fans have barely heard of Andy Roddick, he said the other day at the club where he trains on Randalls Island. Theyre like, Wasnt he a male model?  (Close, Rubins father said: Roddick is married to a model, Brooklyn Decker.)

title: A One-Man Milgram Experiment
description: Marsupial sunblock; Seth Meyers vs. Meyer Lansky.

title: Forgotten Postcards From Mexico City
description: On a handful of Sundays each year, my parents would pack my brother and me into the car with coloring books and crayons and shuttle us to visit my fathers family at his older sisters home 30 minutes away in the woods of Connecticut. I loved going there, and one reason was the model-train set in the basement. After dutifully sitting with the adults for a while, wed scramble down the stairs to gather around the oval track, which lay sprawled on a large table. The set had working lights, crossing signals and gates, and telephone wires were strung between poles. The trains motor whirred as it sped around the tracks  ambling across a field, over a bridge and through a tunnel  and its steady pace always lulled me into a daydream about some future, far-off journey of my own.

title: Who Made Those Bluejeans?
description: In the beginning, there were Levis. In 1853, during the heart of the gold rush, a Bavarian migr named Levi Strauss arrived in San Francisco from New York, looking to expand his familys East Coast dry-goods business. Among his wares were blankets, cloth by the yard and durable work pants, sometimes called jeans pants. Then in 1872, one of Strausss customers, a tailor named Jacob Davis, made him the offer that would change his fortunes  and the way Americans dressed  forever. Davis had been buying Strausss blue denim and duck cloth to sew waist-overalls and had perfected a method of reinforcing them with the same copper rivets he used on horse blankets. Unwilling to put up the $68 necessary to patent his creation, he suggested that Strauss pay the fee in exchange for a half-interest in the business.

title: My Parents Paid for My Education  Does That Mean I Need to Take a Soul-Crushing Job?
description: Thanks to the full financial support of my parents, I recently graduated from an expensive private college in the Northeast with no student debt. After graduation I secured a salaried job with benefits at a large publishing house. I found the work thoroughly soul-crushing, so I quit and began working a number of minimum-wage jobs that do not set me up for any sort of future. While I enjoy my current lifestyle, I fear I might be violating an obligation to my parents, since my college degree is irrelevant to these jobs. Do I have an ethical duty to find a better job even if Im unhappy with the work? NAME WITHHELD, BOSTON

description: BERLIN The German government has approved the sale of the utility RWEs oil and natural gas subsidiary, RWE Dea, to a team of Russian investors, the company confirmed on Friday.

title: 1914: France Plans to Free Brussels
description: Official communiqu from the French Ministry of War: The entry of the Germans into Brussels is a bitter experience for the Belgians and is also deeply felt by every Frenchman. The Government of the Republic has deemed it right to affirm that the sufferings of the Belgians are also our own. From the day when German soldiers entered Belgian territory, when Belgian blood was shed to resist their passage, the causes of the two countries became indissolubly associated and henceforward they are one and the same. France is resolved to do her utmost to liberate the territory of her ally. She considers that her duty will not be entirely accomplished until there is not a single German soldier left in Belgium. The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 23, 1914

description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Initially, Ms. Kantors high-impact story wasnt intended to be about Starbucks at all:

title: Ira Sachs Narrates a Scene From Love Is Strange
