description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Inside the List
description: Found in Translation: American readers of Haruki Murakami  whose Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage touches down on the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 1  have long wondered about the role translation plays in their experience of his work. When reviewing Murakamis new novel for The Atlantic, Nathaniel Rich puzzled over why no great writer writes as many bad sentences as Murakami does, enumerating a litany of sins that include awkward construction, clich addiction, lazy repetition and dialogue that is often robotic, if charmingly so.

title: Steven Sotloff, Journalist Held by ISIS, Was Undeterred by Risks of Job
description: Steven J. Sotloff, a 31-year-old freelance journalist, self-described stand-up philosopher from Miami, immersed himself in the tumult of the Middle East for years, repeatedly venturing into some of the most hazardous conflict zones. He reassured friends that he knew the risks as he wrote for publications that included Time magazine, The Christian Science Monitor and World Affairs Journal.

title: Fatal Confrontation Heightens Tensions in Staten Island Police Precinct
description: In a corner of Staten Island, on a sidewalk across from a tiny triangular park, a fatal police confrontation last month has drawn focus to an area plagued by disorder, and rife with simmering tensions over policing and poverty.

title: 1939: Franco Gathers Spanish Art
description: Art lovers the world over, and especially in France, are watching the progress of one of the biggest jobs the Spanish war left for General Franco to tackle: the reassembling of the dispersed Spanish art treasures. During the war, both sides made efforts to prevent the destruction of works of art in churches, museums and private collections. During the early phases of the struggle, anarchist fanatics defaced many sacred paintings, such as Jesus and the Virgin, by Roger Van der Weiden, in the St. Cruz Hospital in Toledo. The Republican authorities took pains to stop this destruction. As Francos troops occupied the countrys territory, the authorities immediately organized a service for the protection and reassembling of works of art. These services, directed by Eugenio dOrs, now are engaged in checking losses and putting together the famous collections which have been dispersed. Some priceless antiques and works of art are definitely lost.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 23, 1939

title: Dozens Killed at Sunni Mosque in Iraq After Attack on Shiite Leader
description: BAGHDAD  Dozens of Sunni worshipers were killed during a militant raid on a rural mosque in central Iraq on Friday, an attack that security officials said had followed the attempted assassination of a local Shiite leader.

title: Cooking Techniques: Stemming a Cabbage
description: Learn how to stem and cut cabbage.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Excellent Sheep
description: This week, William Deresiewicz discusses Excellent Sheep; Maria Russo talks about the Back to School issue; and Jennifer Szalai has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Excellent Sheep
description: This week, William Deresiewicz and Maria Russo.

title: Cooking Techniques: Steaming Vegetables
description: Use steam to cook your vegetables.

title: Metropolitan Opera Reaches Settlement With Last Unions
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced Thursday night that it had reached labor settlements with the last of its unions, including those representing its costume and wardrobe departments, hair and makeup artists, scenic artists and designers, camera operators and others.

title: Cooking Techniques: Cutting Eggplant
description: Dehydrate eggplant to reduce any bitterness before slicing it.

title: Core Success
description: In popular perception, the era since 2008 has been one of massive failure for economic analysis. The truth, as Ive often tried to explain, is nearly the opposite  at least for those of us who didnt forget Keynes, and took a more or less IS-LM-is model seriously. Weve actually had a very good run, successfully predicting the quiescence of interest rates despite huge budget dheficits, the quiescence of inflation despite huge increases in the monetary base, and the adverse effects of harsh austerity policies.

title: Cooking Techniques: Sauting
description: Learn how to saut ingredients in a pan.

title: Looking Beyond Brooklyn?
description: Even long-time Brooklynites are finding themselves priced out of the hippest neighborhoods. Do they look elsewhere, move further into Brooklyn or swallow the rising costs?

title: Life After Brooklyn
description: By many measures, Jeff Huston and his wife, Lisa Medvedik-Huston, arrived late to Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They werent among the first waves of artists and hipsters in the early-to-mid 90s to cross the East River in search of cheaper, grittier confines. When they rented a spacious, duplex loft two blocks from the Bedford Avenue subway stop in 2007, they found a safe neighborhood already dotted with clothing boutiques and wine shops. The height of the real estate boom was approaching, and condos were rising along both the waterfront and McCarren Park.

title: Duke of Hawaii: A Swimmer and Surfer Who Straddled Two Cultures
description: Duke Kahanamoku, who won a total of five swimming medals in Olympics from 1912 to 1924, probably did more than anyone else to bring the sport of surfing from his native Hawaiian islands to the United States mainland. Almost in reverse, he also played a substantial part in the Americanization of old Hawaii.

title: Cooking Techniques: Preparing Ribs
description: Remove the muscle membrane from ribs before cooking so that flavor can penetrate the meat.

title: The Enclosure of the American Mind
description: Last October, the New York Academy of Medicine hosted a wonder cabinet  a day of talks and films about medicine, the human body and much more. As I took my seat for one of the sessions, I recognized two young men sitting near me. They were former students, whose senior theses I had supervised years before. It was fun to learn how they were doing, one in law and one in medical school, and to see that they still found time to hear about 18th-century anatomical models and books bound in human skin.

title: Lauryn Hills Song for Ferguson
description: On Thursday night, the singer-songwriter Lauryn Hill released a version of her song Black Rage, which she has been performing since at least 2012, dedicating it to the protesters in Ferguson, Mo.

title: At the U.S. Open, Making a Statement Thats Clear, and Loud
description: Female tennis players have garnered much attention from the fashion-conscious in recent years, but at the United States Open this week, eyes are sure to dwell on Tomas Berdych.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Greyhound Across America
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Flags Taken From Brooklyn Bridge Are Returned to American Embassy in Berlin
description: The stunt seemed either a vaguely menacing security breach or a pointed political comment, but turned out to be a benign conceptual art piece by the Berlin artists Mischa Leinkauf and Matthias Wermke. The New York City police told ABC News that the American flags that Mr. Leinkauf and Mr. Wermke had removed from the towers of the Brooklyn Bridge on July 22, and replaced with hand-stitched all-white versions, have been returned to the United States embassy in Berlin.

title: Observed Planet: A Dawn Torrent of Tree Swallows
description: The New York City forecast office of the National Weather Service posted a stunning radar loop on Facebook from dawn this morning showing what is almost surely the daily commute of thousands of tree swallows rising from roosts on Goose Island in the Connecticut River near Old Lyme. They return in a similar flood at dusk.

title: Why the Robots Might Not Take Our Jobs After All: They Lack Common Sense
Book Review Podcast: Excellent Sheep
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Anthony Grafton reviews William Deresiewiczs Excellent Sheep: The Miseducation of the American Elite and the Way to a Meaningful Life, which argues that Ivy League schools graduate narrow-minded students who are later dissatisfied and purposeless. Mr. Grafton writes:

title: Small Dutch City, Major Flower Parade
description: Corso Zundert, which organizers call the worlds largest flower parade, will be held on Sept. 7 in the small Dutch city of Zundert, when floats covered with dahlia blossoms take to the bleacher-lined streets.

title: Growth Hormone for Children May Increase Stroke Risk
description: Childhood treatment with human growth hormone is strongly associated with an increased risk for stroke in early adulthood, a new study has found.

title: Secrecy About Salaries May Be on the Wane
description: NEXT time youre lunching with your colleagues, try this: Ask everyone their salary. You might end up dining alone in the future.

title: Vegetarian Taco Night
description: Taco night is nothing new, but over the last five days, weve had taco week. The markets are piled high with irresistible produce  summer squash, tomatoes, green beans, corn, peppers and chiles, greens and herbs  and corn tortillas are a great vehicle for them.Weve seen enough taco trucks, especially here in Los Angeles, the home of the Korean taco, to know that you can wrap a warm tortilla around just about anything and call it a taco. I leave the kimchi out of my own (though I did make one unconventional filling with tofu, a sort of picadillo cooked and mashed in a salsa ranchera that proved to be irresistible) and stick to the Mexican seasonings I love: chiles and cilantro, cumin and chili powder and salsas. Vegetables were the focus of each filling, and all of this weeks tacos are vegetarian. I combined sweet corn and green beans in one, and roasted peppers, squash and potatoes seasoned with cumin and chile powder in another. I grabbed chard from my garden for a few of the fillings, and made use of this summers bounty of squash.I love the flavor of corn tortillas, and theyre a godsend for friends who have trouble with gluten. I buy them in packs of three dozen, then divide the packages so I can freeze them by the dozen because I usually dont use 36 tortillas in a week (though this week, I did). As for how much filling to count on for each taco, I follow Rick Baylesss advice and use about a quarter cup. As he says, tacos are as much about the tortilla as they are about the filling, and you wouldnt want to overwhelm the tortilla any more than youd want to overwhelm pasta with too much sauce.

title: Russia Moves Artillery Units Into Ukraine, NATO Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Russian military has moved artillery units manned by Russian personnel inside Ukrainian territory in recent days and was using them to fire at Ukrainian forces, NATO officials said on Friday.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: A Tennis Board Woven With Conflicts
description: Jeff Williams, the longtime publisher of Tennis Media Company, sits on the board of directors of the United States Tennis Association, the sports governing body and the organizer of the star-studded United States Open.

title: Shelter Island Hits New Highs
description: A quick ferry ride from either the see-and-be-seen Hamptons on the South Fork of Long Island or the bucolic wine country of the North Fork, Shelter Island has long been the quiet, laid-back vacation haven in the middle, surrounded by Shelter Island Sound and Gardiners Bay.

title: Humpback Whale: Look! Out in the Harbor!
description: Nothing can prepare you for walking along the shore and spotting the great leap and surge of a humpback whale in the distance. The magical moment is yours alone. The Atlantic knows how to keep its secrets.

title: Carl Icahn Looks to Take the Wheel at Hertz
description: The activist investor Carl C. Icahn is just the latest financier to toy with Hertz Global.

title: A New Hero With Some Old Ghosts
description: Sometimes, Sam Heughan feels like a Beatle. As this 34-year-old Scottish actor has been promoting his role as Jamie Fraser, an 18th-century Highlands warrior in the new Starz drama Outlander, hes been greeted by hysterical devotees of the time-traveling romance novels that inspired the series.

title: An Exhibition of Movement
description: Within certain circles, theres been much talk about the growing trend of programming dance in museums. The Whitney Museum of American Art has included dance in its recent biennials, and the Museum of Modern Art has also commissioned work from choreographers. Artists both welcome this development and question how it changes the perception and reception of the form.

title: Gay History, on Display
description: Portraits of lesbians from the artistic circle of the photographer Berenice Abbott, who moved to Paris in 1921 and apprenticed with Man Ray; homoerotic prints by David Hockney; a sketchbook by Larry Stanton, featuring images of Greenwich Village faces in the 1970s, before AIDS: These are some of the works featured in the exhibition Permanency: Selections from the Permanent Collection at the Leslie Lohman Museum of Gay and Lesbian Art in SoHo.

title: Programming as an Art Form
description: Through much of his roughly 35-year career, Hal Willner has been the man behind the curtain: a producer, collagist and ringleader satisfied to hang back and savor the results of his design. But hell preside in person over the programming at the Stone this week, from Tuesday on, which runs about as eclectic as you might expect.

title: Photographers Portrait
description: Migrant Mother, Dorothea Langes most famous work, was but a face in the crowd. Across the Great Depression, the Dust Bowl and World War II, Lange trained her camera on the nations tired, its poor, its huddled masses, immortalizing their dignity and despair.

title: A Night Packed With Boulez
description: If anything can cut through the late-August humidity, its the bracing music of Pierre Boulez, the doyen of complexity and kaleidoscopic colors. Taka Kigawa, a gifted and daring pianist who specializes in 20th-century and contemporary music, takes on not just some Boulez, but all Boulez: the complete solo piano works, at least, which stretch from the 1940s to the past decade. The program on Monday will include 12 Notations, Incises, Une Page dphmride and all three sonatas, including the fearsomely difficult second, from the late 40s, with which the pugnacious Mr. Boulez, now 89, aimed to destroy the traditional sonata form. Sigle, a rarely performed fragment associated with the third, will be a treat for completists. (7:30 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village; 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com.)

title: Seeking to Escape From His Image
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Its not because the guy needs an acting coach. He can be mesmerizing on screen and has an Oscar to prove it. His work ethic is most definitely not the reason. He starved himself for one part, gained 25 pounds for another and has gone to other extremes  wetting his pants, for instance  when a role has required it.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Laura Kaminsky Named Composer in Residence at American Opera Projects
description: American Opera Projects, the adventurous Brooklyn company that has been commissioning, developing and staging new operas for a quarter century, has appointed Laura Kaminsky as its composer-in-residence, beginning Sept. 1, the company announced on Friday.

title: At Home With Rene and Plcido
description: My first summer covering classical music was shaping up as a colossal failure.

title: A 6-Year-Old Shouldnt Inherit a Stiff Upper Lip
description: I was slow to see her. But there she was, sobbing, holding on to the hand of a teachers aide.

title: This Weeks Movies | Aug. 22, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Sin City: A Dame to Kill For, If I Stay and The One I Love.

title: Wheelies: The Sexy Electric Hamster Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Emmys 2014: Tunnel Vision vs. Industry Buzz
description: To people working in television, the Emmy Awards are what street punks were to Charles Bronson movies: the perfect excuse for a little revenge. The 66th annual ceremony, which takes place Monday in Los Angeles, is the TV industrys one chance each year to strike back at its critics by rewarding itself for a job well done.

title: In the Style of Transitional Me
description: Nearly three years ago, when Leandra Medine got married and moved out of her parents apartment on East End Avenue, she made a vow, a codicil of sorts to the for richer, for poorer, in sickness and in health promises that are part and parcel of the wedding package.

title: Video Reviews of Sin City: A Dame to Kill For, If I Stay and The One I Love
description: In this weeks video, Times critics review Sin City: A Dame to Kill For, If I Stay and The One I Love. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Cooking Techniques: Zesting Citrus Fruit
description: Zest lemons, limes, oranges and other citrus fruits to add a floral note to recipes.

title: New Yorks Top Jail Investigator Resigns After Inquiry on Rikers Brutality
description: The top investigator at the New York Correction Department resigned on Friday under pressure from city leaders who are facing a federal mandate to regain control of the Rikers Island jail complex, where widespread brutality and corruption by guards routinely go unpunished.

title: Keeping It Green, and Suitable for Ninja Turtles
description: As his fans might expect, the rapper Wiz Khalifa was quite pleased to be in Denver, where recreational marijuana is legal and readily available. I am really excited about it, he said on Monday, a day before his album release show there. I brought my own, because I like to smoke what I smoke. But its good.

title: Facts & Figures: Presidents on Vacation
description: President Obama has been criticized for remaining on vacation despite the trouble in Ferguson, Mo., and the news of James Foleys execution. But compared with other presidents, Mr. Obama hasnt taken much time off.

title: Have You Played on an Unusual Tennis Court?
description: Have you played on an historic court, a hidden court, or courts located in a surprising or breathtakingly beautiful place

title: A Brash Style That Filled Pews, Until Followers Had Their Fill
description: SEATTLE  Mark Driscoll has long been an evangelical bad boy, a gifted orator and charismatic leader who built one of the nations most influential megachurches despite, or perhaps fueled by, a foul mouth, a sharp temper and frank talk about sex.

title: Richard Handler of Leucadia to Join Board of Ex-SAC Executives New Fund
description: Richard B. Handler, the chief executive of the Leucadia National Corporation, will join the board of a new hedge fund company run by a former executive of SAC Capital Advisors, according to a regulatory filing on Friday.

title: Movie Review: Sin City
description: The Times critic Jeannette Catsoulis reviews Sin City: A Dame to Kill For.

title: Movie Review: The One I Love
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The One I Love.

title: Movie Review: If I Stay
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews If I Stay.

title: Ai Weiwei and the Apocalypse
description: Jason Wishnows short film The Sand Storm, starring Ai Weiwei, in its entirety.

title: Android Phones Hit by Ransomware
description: You are guilty of child porn, child abuse, zoophilia or sending out bulk spam. You are a criminal. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has locked you out of your phone and the only way to regain access to all your data is to pay a few hundred dollars.

title: The Virtues of Green Bell Peppers
description: Most cooks I know despise green bell peppers. They deride them as bitter, virtually inedible versions of their older, sweeter red or yellow or orange selves. In fact, an article in this very space some five years ago chronicled the one-sided tug of war between the many detractors and few fans of these savory peppers.

title: Washington Post Editorial Board Joins Other Groups in Not Using Redskins
description: The editorial board of The Washington Post became the latest news group to abstain from using the name Redskins.

title: Pirouettes at the Tap of a Keyboard
description: The dancegoer of the 21st century no longer needs to go to the dance. Thanks to YouTube, Vimeo and other websites, we have dazzling access  at the touch of fingers or thumbs, on screens held in the palm, on the lap or at the desk  to performances that were unavailable, and to technological treatments that transform dance. No, its not the same as being in the same space and moment: The cameras single eye reduces the spatial complexity of movement, and separate takes chop up its continuity. Here, the dance critics of The New York Times write about a few of the many performances captured in videos.

title: Lesson From Old India: When an Economy Just Doesnt Get Better
description: Commentators have often compared the recent Great Recession of the United States and Europe to the Great Depression of the 1930s. In both cases, asset prices tumbled, financial systems turned insolvent and demand plummeted. One difference is that in the recent case, we mounted a swifter rescue effort than we did in the 1930s; for instance, Ben S. Bernanke, as chairman of the Federal Reserve in the recent crisis, drew upon his academic research in supporting bailouts and reflating the economy.

title: A Hoofer for the Ages
description: All footage of the great tap- dancer Baby Laurence is rare. Though he was hugely influential in the 1940s, adapting tap to bebop, this Charlie Parker of the feet was never very famous. Apart from a documentary filmed shortly before his death in 1974, the best and only surviving documentation of his art is an astonishing album he recorded in 1959  the only documentation, that is, besides a clip you can find on YouTube.

title: Movement That Streams
description: Have you ever tried watching an hourlong dance performance online, start to finish, without interruption? Its not easy, at least for anyone mildly distractible. As the choreographer Annie-B Parson recently wrote in a Facebook post, Watching one minute of anything on YouTube feels equivalent to an hour in the three-dimensional world.

title: Mixing Body and Lens
description: The moment the choreographer Celia Rowlson-Hall stepped onto the set of her first music video in 2007, she knew she was home. Here were all of my loves: of image, of photography, of fashion, she said. Even though she enjoyed working in the theater, she was inspired. I thought, Why dont I bring my dance to film?'

title: Chrysler Owners Sound Off on a Power Defect
description: Before Jeff Marlow bought a 2009 Dodge Journey, he had never heard of anything called a Totally Integrated Power Module. But now, like many consumers, hes unhappily familiar with the device, which distributes electrical power in the vehicle.

title: Dieppe After the Battle
description: Graphic newsreel footage shot by German soldiers of the aftermath of the Dieppe Raid on August 22, 1942.

title: Letters: A Troublesome Inheritance
description: A Troublesome Inheritance

title: Where We Enter
description: I was 14 years old when I first read Nikki Giovannis masterly collection of poetry, Cotton Candy on a Rainy Day. As with most everything I read between the ages of 12 and 16, there was so much I didnt understand. I was the first-generation daughter of people who came from a small country, a country so small that I had yet to meet someone from there who could not connect the dots to my family in five seconds flat. I didnt know a thing about Jim Crow, the American South, soul food or classic rhythm and blues. Yet like most kids who love to read, I understood the feeling behind the words, if not all of the meaning of the words. So when Giovanni wrote:

title: Gateways to the Classical World
description: Modern technology has been kind to ancient history. Scholars with iPads and other mobile gadgets can now leave the heavy books at home, opting for a variety of apps devoted to classical studies  Greek, Latin and the history of Greco-Roman civilization  saving time and money in the process.

title: For the Common Good of Humankind
description: Edmund Burke is enjoying a remarkable revival for a British statesman who has been dead since 1797. The last 18 months or so have brought books by Jesse Norman, Yuval Levin and Drew Maciag  a member of Parliament and two American scholars  placing him in the context of political traditions that endure to this day. Their subtitles tell the story: Burke is The First Conservative (Norman) or The Father of Modern Conservatism (Maciag) or present at The Birth of Right and Left (Levin).

title: The Mind
description: KIDDING OURSELVES  The Hidden Power of Self-Deception  By Joseph T. Hallinan  Crown, $25.

title: Must Love Dogs
description: I had trouble sitting down to write this review of three funny and appealing picture books about dogs because my cat refused to get off the keyboard. Even now she sits too close for comfort, flicking her tail resentfully across the screen.

title: Where the Wicked Things Are
description: Among the many magical or potentially magical objects in Gregory Maguires latest novel, Egg & Spoon, is a Faberg egg. Look at one side of the egg and you see the hut of Baba Yaga. Give it a turn and an ancient ice dragon comes into view. Turn it once more and the legendary Firebird is revealed. Each rotation requires a shift in focus, and one story can be viewed only at the exclusion of the others.

title: Solo Acts
description: Some people are natural performers. Give them a wedding D.J. or a karaoke mike and brace yourself, bystanders: Its Love Shack to the max. Other people, even if theyre secretly talented, need coaxing. The bathroom-shower soprano clams up in public. The dude who rocks the funky chicken behind closed doors folds up his wings and refuses to boogie. The risk of humiliation is simply too great: People may judge. People may laugh. And how do we know that? Because at some point along the way, perhaps when we were very young, someone did judge, or did laugh  and the reflexive urge we felt to shake, rattle and roll? Poof! Extinguished.

title: On the Syllabus
description: This week, we ask where the summer went, memorize our new locker combinations and turn our attention to books about the classroom. I asked a few reporters who cover education for The Times to recommend their favorite books about school.

title: A Unified Theory
description: For the last half-century weve had a popular notion that our intellectual culture is sundered in two  the literary and the scientific. The two cultures is the bumper-sticker phrase for this view. It dates back to a hugely influential 1959 lecture, also published in book form that year, by C. P. Snow  a moderately able research chemist who had become a successful novelist, in the historian Lisa Jardines not very adulatory description. According to Snow, on one side were the humanists, on the other the scientists, and between them lay a shameful gulf of mutual incomprehension.

title: Publish and Cherish
description: O, rocks! she said. Tell us in plain words. So goes Molly Blooms plea to Leopold to explain metempsychosis, the transmigration of souls.

title: To Be Young Again
description: Who doesnt enjoy a well-drawn curmudgeon? Childrens books are rife with them. From dour Eeyore moping about the Hundred Acre Wood to the irritable Mary Poppins, they come in all shapes and species. Proudly singular, such cantankerous characters are invariably exasperating, endearing and entertaining all at the same time. And now along comes Jennifer L. Holm with a doozy. Best known for her works of historical fiction, three of which have won Newbery Honors (Our Only May Amelia, Penny From Heaven, Turtle in Paradise), and the graphic novel series Babymouse, Holm uses a surprising twist to bring us a particularly memorable grouch in her latest, The Fourteenth Goldfish.

title: The New School
description: Education is not the filling of a pail, but the lighting of a fire. The greeting-card pithiness of this maxim obscures what is in fact a useful metaphor, and in Building a Better Teacher, Elizabeth Green introduces us to educators who stick to their kindling. Her project is both a history of the research on effective teaching as well as a consideration of how that research might best be implemented. What emerges is the gaping chasm between what the best teachers do and how we go about evaluating what theyve done.

title: Who Are They Kidding?
description: From Amelia Bedelias cheery misinterpretations to Dont Let the Pigeon Drive the Bus and its impertinent bird hoping against hope for the impossible, delusions fuel a certain stripe of hero. Early chapter books  and here we have three by much-lauded childrens book authors  offer the perfect bridge between the freewheeling dreams of picture books and the serious narratives of longer fiction. These characters come by their delusions honestly and do not force the issue. And the more we indulge in their scattershot dreams, the more we want to believe in them too.

title: On the Road
description: In Sisters, the latest graphic memoir by Raina Telgemeier, it is the summer before high school and Raina is stuck between a squirrelly little brother and a volatile younger sister in a van without air conditioning. They are on a weeklong drive from their home in San Francisco to a family reunion in Colorado Springs, and as temperatures rise, so do tempers. Raina and her sister, Amara, argue over everything, from what to do about a snake on the loose (What if we shut him in a suitcase till were home?) to their parents relationship (You dont think Mom and Dad are gonna split up . . . do you?). Memories of improbable pet deaths, their fathers unemployment and the difficulties of coexisting in a small apartment are woven into the tale of their emotional and sometimes tense journey through the American West.

title: In Providence
description: Every kid should have the chance to go to college: Americas future depends on our youth having four years to immerse themselves in experimental literature, plan campus protests, mainline coffee and make out with strangers.

title: Progress Report
description: America loves to dream an impossible dream when it comes to education. We see our public schools as the bedrock of the equal-opportunity society we wish to be, the land where a poor boy in a log cabin  or a bungalow in Honolulu  can grow up to be president. And teachers are the angel-magicians who make it all happen.

title: Editors Choice
description: KILL MY MOTHER: A Graphic Novel,   written and illustrated by Jules Feiffer. (Liveright, $27.95.) The renowned cartoonists terrific tribute to film noir and detective fiction is also a meditation on female identity and the morality of murder.

title: Of Two Minds
description: The pair is a precious unit  private, generative, even holy. We can explore a couples inner workings if we have an invitation to do so. Otherwise, we must use any available external means: letters in archives, revealing anecdotes, loose-lipped quips in interviews. In order to understand creativity, we must learn from couples, Joshua Wolf Shenk argues in his new book, Powers of Two. Defying the myth of the lone genius, he makes the case that the chemistry of creative pairs  of people, of groups  forms the primary (albeit frequently hidden) structural basis of innovation.

title: Not Giving an Inch
description: In the 1970s, children across America were learning the metric system at school, gas stations were charging by the liter, freeway signs in some states gave distances in kilometers, and American metrication seemed all but inevitable. But Dean Krakel, director of the National Cowboy Hall of Fame in Oklahoma, saw things differently: Metric is definitely Communist, he solemnly said. One monetary system, one language, one weight and measurement system, one world  all Communist. Bob Greene, syndicated columnist and founder of the WAM! (We Aint Metric) organization, agreed. It was all an Arab plot with some Frenchies and Limeys thrown in, he wrote.

title: Sonic Youth
description: In this appealing graphic memoir by the childrens book author and illustrator Cece Bell, young Cece is only 4 when she comes down with meningitis. She survives, but her hearing doesnt. At first, like any newly and suddenly deafened person, she retreats into herself, scared and confused (I stay close to Mama, no matter where she is).

title: Paperback Row
description: THE RESIDUE YEARS,  by Mitchell S. Jackson. (Bloomsbury, $17.) Told in chapters that alternate between mother and son, Jacksons raw, autobiographical novel describes a black family in Portland, Ore., struggling with the cycles of poverty and addiction. Grace, just out of rehab, is determined to get her kids back. Her eldest, Champ, is in college but deals crack, convinced its the only way to achieve his dream.

title: Learning Democracy
description: It isnt easy to track down a positive word about the Middle East these days. Then again, Juan Cole is not your typical observer. A professor of history at the University of Michigan, he is also a prolific and popular blogger on current affairs. An American, he spent part of his childhood in France and Ethiopia. A left-leaning idealist, he comes across as far more optimistic than the dour Occupy crowd. A cosmopolitan in constant touch with 20-somethings, he seems to be addressing boomers in his latest book, The New Arabs, which is replete with explanations that digital natives would never need. (Dont know what the meatspace is? Read on.)

title: Uncram
description: A spate of recent best sellers has trumpeted a supposedly surprising secret to success, both in school and in life. Its called hard work.

title: Wild on the Inside
description: Fifteen-year-old Anika Dragomir throws her arms around us and draws us in from the very beginning of Andrea Portess Anatomy of a Misfit: Youre never gonna believe what happened, she announces.

title: Bookshelf: Back to School
description: New picture books include Adam Auerbachs Edda: A Little Valkyries First Day of School.

title: Big Ticket | A San Remo Record for $26.4 Million
description: A rambling combination unit with prime Central Park vistas at the venerable San Remo, a 1929 showpiece designed by Emery Roth and lauded as the citys first twin-tower residential high-rise, sold for $26.4 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Restaurant Report: Travail Kitchen & Amusements in Robbinsdale, Minn.
description: As Styxs Mr. Roboto filled the dining room, a man in a full-bodied yellow chicken suit, with only his face showing, pushed out a small chariot-like vehicle; in it was a man dressed in a robot suit tossing bags of popcorn to waiting hands. The chicken clucked into a microphone and held it toward diners sitting at long communal tables, who clucked back with enthusiasm.

title: Dollywood: A Little Bit Country, a Little Bit Gay
description: At Dollywood, the place on a Venn diagram where gay camp and Southern camp overlap, cinnamon rolls might be the great equalizer.

title: Readers Respond: On European Anti-Semitism
description: A new wave of anti-Semitic incidents in Europe and a recent surge in global anger at Israels military action in Gaza inspired wide-ranging debates about global Jewish identity and the Israeli state in reader responses to two recent Op-Ed articles.

title: Dynegys Deals Mark Return of Ambition
description: Dynegy only got out of bankruptcy two years ago. Now two deals worth $6.25 billion, announced on Friday, mark a return of ambition for the power company. It once tried to buy Enron and eventually went bust after a spat involving activist Carl C. Icahn. The purchases look sensible, but the lesson from Dynegys past is to avoid getting carried away.

title: Blamed for Rise of ISIS, Syrian Leader Is Pushed to Escalate Fight
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The extremist militants of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have attacked Syrian troops with new ferocity in recent weeks, taking over three northeastern military bases, beheading scores of soldiers and seizing new territory.

title: Records Smashed as Usual, but Surprises as Well
description: PEBBLE BEACH, CALIF.  Whispers and educated guesses dominated conversations among classic-car followers for much of this summer: How much would it bring?

title: Show-Stoppers
description: The auctions held during Pebble Beach week brought in a record $430 million, topped by the $38 million paid for a Ferrari 250 GTO.

title: Administration Proposes New Health Rules Addressing Religious Objections
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  The Obama administration on Friday proposed new regulations intended to address the religious objections that some nonprofit organizations and private companies have to providing contraceptive coverage for their employees.

title: Is the Player Nervous? Just Ask His Shirt
description: TENNIS HAS an emotional impact that isnt confined to the court. Consider the ball boy, who speeds the game along by retrieving stray balls for the players.

title: Pie-in-the-Sky Flying Cars From the Past
description: Wizards and tinkerers have labored to make cars fly since the early 20th century, with mixed results. Some designs had detachable wings and tail ends for highway cruising; others used mechanisms to fold the wings for driving. Here is sampling of some noteworthy creations:

title: Vaylon Pegase
description: Infiltration, extraction, recognition and rescue may not be the first words that flying cars bring to mind, but Jrme Dauffy, founder of Vaylon in Strasbourg, France, is taking a pragmatic approach to marketing the Pegase. Though the Pegase, which mates a paraglider with a lightweight off-road vehicle, might seem to appeal to thrill-seekers like mountain climbers trying to reach remote peaks, Mr. Dauffy has played up its strategic capabilities to attract military and security business.

title: Terrafugia Transition
description: The ideal flying car might take to the roads and the skies with equal aplomb, but Carl Dietrich, a co-founder of Terrafugia in Woburn, Mass., is unapologetic about the raison dtre of his companys Transition. We think of it as a street-legal airplane, he said. Its an airplane that has the capability of driving safely on roads and highways and parking in a single-car garage.

title: Wheels and Wings
description: The quest to create a flying car is almost as old as the airplane and automobile.

title: Why Were Not Driving the Friendly Skies
description: A number of us can thank a cartoon character from the future, George Jetson, for instilling our longing. Students of aviation history might look for inspiration to the Autoplane prototype built in 1917 by the flight pioneer Glenn Curtiss. And tens of millions of motorists who have been stuck in traffic jams stretching toward the horizon must also feel a need to know: Where are the flying cars?

title: Aeromobil 2.5
description: In 1989, the Velvet Revolution deposed Czechoslovakias Communist government. The founders of the Slovakian company Aeromobil, who grew up behind the Iron Curtain dreaming of freedoms in the West, say their flying car offers the possibility of further liberation. Currently we are in the very same situation when it comes to traffic, said Stefan Vadocz, the companys head of communications. We are trapped in traffic, and we think traffic needs a revolution.

title: U.S. Finds Backoff Hacker Tool Is Widespread
description: More than 1,000 American businesses have been affected by the cyberattack that hit the in-store cash register systems at Target, Supervalu and most recently UPS Stores, the Department of Homeland Security said in an advisory released on Friday.

title: The Sinister Sinks Deeper Into the Fun
description: The acrobats still dazzle, the music still swells, but the chill has gone out of the room, and the menace is harder to find. Diane Pauluss dynamic, high-flying revival of Pippin has become a warmer, giddier show in its 16 months at the Music Box Theater, and thats really not a bad thing at all.

title: Beyond Potluck: A Bean Salad Worth the Shucking
description: I have had a lifelong fling with beans. It all began with green beans almondine. At our house, fresh-frozen French-cut beans, cooked to the perfect shade of bright green, were heaped with slivered almonds sizzled in margarine, That was a little bit of heaven.

title: Revisit the Golden Days of Long-Form With Lewis Lapham
description: In a recent podcast for Longform.org, Evan Ratliff of The Atavist spoke to theAmerican journalism legend Lewis Lapham about the golden days of long-form, playing the piano for Thelonious Monk and his accidental career transition from writer to editor.

title: A Porsche Reunion With a Personal Connection
description: CARMEL, CALIF.  A whole new world, one that included learning the difference between a racing driver and a driver of racing cars, came full circle here on the Central Coast last week, where I was reintroduced to my 1958 Porsche Speedster after more than half a century.

title: Dangers Abound for Thousands Taking to the Ocean in Search of Safety
description: GENEVA  The United Nations refugee agency sounded the alarm on Friday over tens of thousands of people, many of them Muslim Rohingyas from Myanmar, who are fleeing by boat across the Indian Ocean in search of asylum and in the process facing death, malnutrition and brutal treatment at the hands of traffickers, and often ending in detention in South East Asian countries or Australia.

title: Julien Farel: Hair Today, Hair Tomorrow
description: The hairstylist and entrepreneur Julien Farel owns four salons, including the 10,000-square-foot flagship at the Loews Regency Hotel on Park Avenue, which opened in April. For the United States Open, which begins tournament play on Monday, there is a fifth salon, albeit temporary, at Arthur Ashe Stadium, where participants can have their hair cut, braided, pulled back or trimmed  whatever they need to be court- and camera-ready. Boldface names like Novak Djokovic and Victoria Azarenka are tended to personally by Mr. Farel. When New Yorks Grand Slam event is not in session, Mr. Farel, 45, a native of France, and his wife, Suelyn, 45, the chief executive of the Julien Farel Group, retreat on weekends to their East Hampton home with their daughters, Chloe, 8, and Manon, 6.

title: Elite Mexican Police Corps Targets Persistent Violence, but Many Are Skeptical
description: MEXICO CITY  More than two years after first floating it during his presidential campaign as a signature effort to control rampant violence, President Enrique Pea Nieto on Friday swore in a new gendarmerie for Mexico, an offshoot of the federal police aimed at quelling outbreaks of violent crime.

title: Weekend Reading: The Evolving Bank Settlement Documents
description: If it feels as though the billion-dollar settlements from the financial crisis are blurring together, youre not alone.

title: Big Payoffs in HP Suit, for Lawyers
description: When lawyers for Hewlett-Packard shareholders filed a lawsuit contending HPs management and board abdicated their duties and engaged in unlawful behavior in the disastrous 2011 takeover of Autonomy, it looked as if we might finally find out what really happened.

title: Cooking Techniques: Rolling Pie Dough
description: Roll pie dough evenly for better cooking results.

title: Assault Charge Against City Councils Ex-Finance Director Is Thrown Out
description: Since his arrest in February on domestic violence charges, the City Councils finance director has been fired from his job at City Hall and has been forced to move out of his Upper West Side apartment, where he lived with a longtime partner.

title: Cooking Techniques: Crimping Pie Dough
description: Crimp pie dough to help seal it.

title: Cooking Techniques: Chopping Chives
description: Learn how to chop chives.

title: Cooking Techniques: Chopping Parsley
description: Learn how to chop parsley.

title: A Small Island Takes a Big Step on Ocean Conservation
description: Marine life in the Caribbean has been badly hurt in recent decades by everything from an introduced pathogen that killed off reef-grooming sea urchins to more familiar insults like overfishing and impacts of tourism and coastal development.

title: Cooking Techniques: Reducing Stock
description: Reduce stock to intensify flavor.

title: Peace Through Friendship
description: WHEN two groups are in conflict, how can you improve relations between them?

title: Cooking Techniques: Slicing Potatoes
description: Cut potatoes into slices for more even cooking.

title: Turning Off Website Alerts on a Mac
Cooking Techniques: Julienning Peppers
description: Cut peppers into matchsticks. Apply this technique to carrots and other vegetables.

title: Activist Rearrested in India After Resuming Hunger Strike
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian human rights activist Irom Sharmila, who has been on a hunger strike for nearly 14 years to protest a law that gives impunity to armed forces serving in the state of Manipur, was arrested Friday just two days after a court ordered her release from custody, said L.M. Khaute, a senior police official in Imphal, the capital of Manipur.

title: Trotting Out New Luxury
description: For decades, Caton Place, a street that runs for two blocks west of the Prospect Park Parade Ground, was best known for its horse stables, but now plans are underway to turn this short street into a destination for luxury rentals.

title: Cooking Techniques: Julienning Carrots
description: Slice carrots into matchsticks. You can apply this technique to other vegetables.

title: Cooking Techniques: Cutting an Apple
description: Cut an apple into same-size slices for a more even cooking time.

title: Perry Courts Primary State and Vows Fight at Home
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  As his lawyers in Texas worked to have the indictment against him dismissed, Gov. Rick Perry flew here on Friday to continue laying the groundwork for a possible 2016 presidential bid, exuding confidence as he spoke with businessmen and women in this first-in-the-nation primary state.

title: New York Council Speaker Says Biopsy Shows She Doesnt Have Cancer
description: Melissa Mark-Viverito, the speaker of the New York City Council, said on Friday that a biopsy had shown she was cancer-free.

title: Cooking Techniques: Trussing a Chicken
description: Truss chicken and other poultry to help prevent the meat from drying out.

title: Cooking Techniques: Trimming Beef
description: Trim beef to get rid of excess fat and sinew.

title: Tennis, Anywhere?
description: The United States has an estimated 250,000 tennis courts, and in such a big and sprawling country, a few of those courts are going to end up in unusual places. We highlight a few of them here.

title: Cooking Techniques: Pan-Roasting
description: Pan-roasting is a simple technique that results in a juicy pork chop.

title: U.S. Weighs Direct Military Action Against ISIS in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is debating a more robust intervention in Syria, including possible American airstrikes, in a significant escalation of its weeks-long military assault on the Islamic extremist group that has destabilized neighboring Iraq and killed an American journalist, officials said Friday.

title: E.C.B. Chief Seeks Tax Cuts and State Spending
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, said Friday that European governments needed to move from a focus on austerity to a more growth-friendly composition of fiscal policies.

title: Cooking Techniques: Spatchcocking
description: Remove the backbone from a whole chicken for speedier cooking.

title: Cooking Techniques: Mincing Rosemary
description: Learn how to mince rosemary. This technique also applies to thyme and other herbs.

title: Breaking the Monkey-Suit Mold
description: When Christy Ely was married at the Bowery Hotel in New York last December, she wore a sleek ivory gown. But unlike most brides, she wasnt the only person walking down the aisle dressed in white.

title: Cooking Techniques: Chiffonading Basil
description: Learn how to roughly chop basil and other leafy herbs.

title: Red Hooks Cutting-Edge Wireless Network
description: Robert Smith, a 19-year-old in a gray T-shirt and camouflage pants, climbed the stairwell of the Joseph Miccio Community Center in Red Hook, scaled a ladder at the top floor and jumped onto the roof. He soon found what he was looking for: bright, white plastic boxes, each about the size of a brick, some with little antennas sticking out. Mr. Smith pulled a laptop from his backpack and got to work, tending to the nodes of the Red Hook mesh, an ambitious plan to link up a local wireless digital network across the neighborhood.

title: Beyond the Dust Bowll With Dorothea Lange
description: In a new documentary, Dyanna Taylor explored the relationship between the photographer Dorothea Lange and her husband, Paul Taylor, the filmmakers grandparents.

title: Ex-Governor of Virginia Denies Graft Charges and Defends Wife
description: RICHMOND, Va.  In his final moments under defense questioning on Friday, former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia strongly denied he had corrupted his office, while saying that any blame for his travails should be put on him, not his wife, who has been pilloried by his defense team for the couples relationship with a wealthy donor who showered them with gifts.

title: A Near Tragedy Seals Their Commitment
description: Katie is smart, attractive, fun and she knows all the words to Live Like You Were Dying, said Brian Sumers as he described Katie Murphy, his girlfriend of three years.

title: A Drink and a Donation, With Ice
description: Over the past few weeks, the A.L.S. Ice Bucket Challenge has become the viral meme of the year, with Facebook feeds across the country filled with people including Mitt Romney and your Aunt Martha dousing themselves with icy water to support research into amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrigs disease.

title: Cooking Techniques: Dicing
description: Learn how to dice carrots, celery and other vegetables.

title: Cooking Techniques: Tempering Chocolate
description: Melt and cool chocolate so that it can be used for dipping or coating.

title: Pentagon Says Chinese Fighter Jet Confronted American Navy Plane
description: WASHINGTON  A Chinese fighter jet flew within 30 feet of a Navy surveillance and reconnaissance plane this week in international airspace just off the Chinese coast, the Pentagon said Friday.

title: Cooking Techniques: Clarifying Butter
description: Learn how to separate the milk solids from the butterfat. The resulting oil has a higher smoking temperature.

title: Japanese Swimming Has Momentum at Its Back
description: SOUTHPORT, Australia  In 2012, Michael Phelps saw the writing on Londons Aquatic Centre scoreboard. In the third of four preliminary heats of the Olympic 400-meter individual medley, the Japanese teenager Kosuke Hagino clocked at 4 minutes 10.01 seconds.

title: Cooking Techniques: Mincing Garlic
description: Learn how to mince garlic.

title: Cooking Techniques: Shucking an Oyster
description: Shuck an oyster to expose the meat.

title: Cooking Techniques: Cutting a Pineapple
description: Learn how to clean and cut a pineapple.

title: Cooking Techniques: Cutting an Avocado
description: Learn how to cut and pit an avocado.

title: The Sneaker Remix
description: The accessories designer Kerin Rose demonstrates how to revamp your sneakers by painting custom designs.

title: T Time | Marian McEvoy
description: Marian McEvoy recalls the heady Paris fashion scene of the 70s and 80s at her cottage in the Hudson Valley.

title: Secret, an Anonymous Social App, Tries to Clean Up Its Act
description: What would you say if no one knew you were the one saying it? In the case of Secret, the anonymous social app many in Silicon Valley love to hate, a lot of that chatter hasnt been so kind.

title: Champion of Jazz Talent Brings His Work Home
description: He was a regular sight in the jazz clubs of Manhattan. Tall gentleman in glasses. Pinstriped suit. Neatly trimmed white beard. Often seated with business associates, but quiet, eyes trained on the stage. This was Bruce Lundvall, president of Blue Note Records, checking up on the talent or taking stock of the scene.

title: An Empire Built by the Numbers
description: WESTLAKE, Ohio  It might surprise some people to learn that Phil Steele, the eponymous founder and publisher of a college football preview magazine now in its 20th year, is a real person, with a wife, two children, two rabbits and a freshwater pond that shimmers in front of a big house in this bustling Cleveland suburb.

title: Phil Steeles Conference Forecast
description: For 20 years, Phil Steele has been writing Phil Steeles College Football Preview, a highly regarded magazine known for its small type, obscure abbreviations (which require a glossary) and abundant statistics. Here, he offers some thoughts on the upcoming season for the so-called Big 5 conferences of college football.

title: Online Broker Offers Investments in Would-Be Inversion Targets
description: Inversions are among the hottest trend in mergers and acquisitions right now. American companies, hoping to reduce their tax rates and access overseas cash, are snatching up overseas competitors at a record pace.

title: Britain Rejects Calls at Home to Join Forces With Assad Against Jihadists
description: LONDON  As British security agencies worked to identify the jihadist in the video showing the killing of an American journalist, James Foley, the foreign secretary on Friday rejected calls to work with the Syrian government to defeat the larger threat of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Cooking Techniques: Cleaning Mussels
description: Learn how to rid mussels of grit and sand before cooking.

title: Cooking Techniques: Poaching a Fish
description: Poach fish in liquid with aromatics to impart flavor while cooking.

title: Tennis, Anywhere?
description: Some of locations of the nations estimated 250,000 tennis courts may surprise you.

title: Cooking Techniques: Cleaning Shrimp
description: Devein and clean shrimp before cooking.

title: Fast Thoughts, Slow Jams
description: First things first. The day before Brian Williams and Seth Meyers met for lunch at the Sea Grill restaurant in Rockefeller Center, Mr. Meyerss publicist had staked out his seat. You see, Mr. Meyers, 40, the host of NBCs Late Night with Seth Meyers, a former anchor of Weekend Update on Saturday Night Live and the host of the Emmy Awards this year (to be broadcast on Monday), likes to be photographed from the left.

title: The Long March to Peace
description: Gary Hill, an associate minister, lives in Ferguson, Mo., just a few blocks from where Michael Brown was killed on Aug. 9. Hes urged for peace amid the volatile protests, with mixed results.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Turin Operas Music Director Threatens to Leave
description: In recent years, many Italian opera houses have been better known for financial, managerial and labor tumult than for their way with bel canto or verismo. A bright spot, though, has been the Teatro Regio in Turin, which has been raising its profile with ambitious recordings and tours, including one that will bring the company to Carnegie Hall in December.

title: More Space for Pottery at Minnesota Museum
description: The Pottery Museum of Red Wing in Minnesota more than quadrupled its space this summer when it opened a new 13,000-square-foot facility showcasing a wide range of pottery and stoneware produced in the town.

title: Behind the Book Review Cover
description: This week features our third annual back-to-school issue, this year themed The Way We Learn. We introduced the back-to-school issue in 2012 centered on a new childrens book feature to supplement our spring childrens books special, which runs in May, and our biggest childrens book section of the year, in November, when we announce the winners of the New York Times Best Illustrated Awards. The end of the summer seemed an ideal time to cover the big fall childrens books, as well as address those sticky issues that children, parents and educators face at the beginning of the school year  from separation for toddlers to social media bullying for teenagers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Malaysia, Ukraine and Pakistan.

title: Poised for a Comeback, on Court and Off
description: Its been just over three months since the golf star Rory McIlroy called his then-fiance, the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki. It was a very brief phone call. The wedding invitations had been sent out days earlier. And what Mr. McIlroy had to say surprised everyone. Fans didnt see it coming. Friends certainly didnt.

title: A Symphony of Varying Touches
description: During the aptly named Shimmer, the entrancing third movement of John Luther Adamss The Mathematics of Resonant Bodies (2002), Steven Schick created a celestial, kaleidoscopic palette of sounds by playing on several triangles. Another alluring section unfolded with intriguing rhythmic patterns on the cymbals. In Roar, a halo of sounds emerged in a vigorous crescendo from the tam-tam (a type of gong).

title: Should the U.S. Work With Assad to Fight ISIS?
Of Myself I Sing
description: In April, Rebecca Makkai, a fiction writer, published a satirical piece on the blog for the literary magazine Ploughshares titled Writers You Want to Punch in the Face(book). In it, she depicted the Facebook posts of a fictional writer, Todd Manly-Krauss, who is the worlds most irritating writer.

title: Cooking Techniques: Macerating Fruit
description: Use a light coating of sugar to break down berries and other fruit.

title: For Student Loan Borrowers in Default, Redemption Just Got Easier
description: AS college campuses prepare for a new academic year, revised federal rules now in effect should make it easier to return student loans in default to good standing.

title: The Long March to Peace
description: Gary Hill, an associate minister, lives in Ferguson, Mo., just a few blocks from where Michael Brown was killed on Aug. 9. He has been urging peace during the protests since the shooting.

title: What to Watch For in the 2014 College Football Season
description: FIVE TEAMS TO WATCH

title: Friday Not Music: Cats of the Great War
description: Not feeling inspired today  maybe because Im focused on tonights concert. So how about cats instead  it turns out that a lot of them actually did serve in World War I.

title: Valeant and Pershing Square Say They Have Votes for Special Meeting of Botox Maker Allergan
description: Updated, 6:44 p.m. |

title: College Football Playoff Possibilities
description: In the new College Football Playoff, the top-ranked team will play the fourth-ranked team and the second-ranked team will face the third-ranked team in the semifinals, to be played on Jan. 1 this season. The two bowls selected for the semifinals this season are the Rose and the Sugar. Future semifinals will rotate through a group of six bowls, including the Rose and the Sugar.

title: Bill Cunningham | Streets Paved in Gold
description: The illusion that the streets of Manhattan are paved with gold almost came to a reality this week.

title: Getting Up Close to Nature, if Not in the Most Natural Way
description: Anything can inspire a work of art, but two copulating orcas  one inflatable, the other an actual person wearing a whale suit  seem like a joke that hardly bears repeating. Nevertheless, the idea for the performance work So Long, Willy (Lets Go Home) began after Adam Rigg, a director of the interdisciplinary group I Am a Boys Choir, came across a clip on the Internet of a person in an orca suit delicately grinding against an inflatable orca. As whale sightings go, its a bizarre one.

title: Enter No. 12, Quiet and Dangerous
description: In Matt Smiths last episode as the star of Doctor Who, his character, the 11th Doctor, was asked how he was going to get out of a sticky situation. Talk very fast, he said. Hope something good happens. Take the credit.

title: A Concert Where a Shellfish Helps With the Sound
description: Consider the lobster. As a musical instrument, that is. Or, more precisely: as a resonant body capable of dispersing delicate music box tinkles. The International Contemporary Ensemble certainly did for Alvin Luciers Chambers, a work for an unspecified array of instruments collected and assembled according to the composers instructions.

title: Golden Days
description: The streets arent paved with gold, but it was applied to the Crown Building on Fifth Avenue. The gilding was reflected on women in gold beads and shoulder bags, and dresses entirely of gold or gold-flecked. Participants in a Fifth Avenue parade, bottom left and top right, also wore it. And on a Hamptons-bound train, gold sandals stretched up to a baggage rack.

title: The Truth Out There? Its Strange Indeed
description: Intruders, a new eight-episode thriller from BBC America, works hard to get its creep on. In Saturday nights premiere, we get a child who sees visions in a sand dollar and later kills her cat; a wife who suddenly starts listening to vintage jazz before disappearing during a business trip; a conspiracy theorist who broadcasts warnings from a secret trailer; and a pair of guys in black suits who appear to perform an exorcism in reverse, putting a bad spirit into someone rather than taking it out.

title: Brewing T
description: Id like to be able to say that each month the T team sets out to craft the issue in your hands according to a clear, preordained editorial concept to which we all adhere, but the truth  as so often  is a bit messier, the process a bit more free-form.

title: Drawing Words From the Well of Art
description: On a recent afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, two standard poodles could be found lounging among the Monets. No one was looking at the water lilies; everyone was photographing the animals (allowed there as medical-alert dogs), particularly the white one, which had fine braids woven into its hair.

title: An Emerging Price War in the World of Investment Advice
description: So lets say you want to put all of your investments in index or exchange-traded funds, having realized that neither you nor the professionals stand much of a chance of picking stocks or mutual funds that will outperform the overall market.

title: 15th World Youth Teams Championships in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  At the 15th World Youth Teams Championships here, the three main finals end on Saturday.

title: Evening Hours | A (Dance) Step Back
description: The Jazz Age Lawn Party, now in its ninth year, takes over Governors Island for two days.

title: A Brother Moves Out
description: Rick Brown, Shyaporn Theerakulstit and Danaher Dempsey sing, play, and act through their feelings about Mr. Brown leaving Fortress Astoria on the eve of his move.

title: Time Marches On, Even at Fortress Astoria
description: They have been together for 20 years and are now in their 40s, paying less than $1,000 a month each to live in a converted office building in Queens.

title: Inexpensive Advice for Index and Exchange-Traded Fund Investments
description: These companies offer help picking and rebalancing index and exchange-traded funds or similar investments, and none charge more than about 0.5 percent of your assets each year for the privilege.

description: To the Editor:

title: Congress and Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Syrias Moderate Opposition
description: To the Editor:

title: De Blasio and Expectations
description: To the Editor:

title: Agyness Deyns Return to Fashion, Tickets to Victorias Secret Fashion Show and Giseles Yearly Income
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Paying Homage to a Homespun Troubadour
description: The rapper J. Cole may have been the first to respond musically to the events in Ferguson, Mo., but is there any doubt that he wont be the last? And is there any doubt that whether or not they realize it, these bards are following the example set in the first half of the 20th century by one Woodrow Wilson Guthrie, whose now-classic songs chronicled the Great Depression, the Dust Bowl, the union movement and World War II?

title: More Affordable Textbooks
description: To the Editor:

title: Nikki Finke Goes Silent in Reported Legal Dispute With Penske Media
description: The Hollywood journalist Nikki Finke has stopped writing about the movie industry while she and a former employer, Penske Media Corporation, try to reach a legal settlement, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Unrest in the Midwest
description: On Aug. 20, 1864, Oliver P. Morton, the governor of Indiana, received an anonymous letter in his Indianapolis office. The letter, postmarked from Buffalo, tipped him off to the arrival of arms and ammunition shipped secretly from the East Coast. The guns were intended, it said, for antagonists of our Govt who planned to foment unrest before the coming presidential election. The informer gave details about the whereabouts of shipments from a New York City arms dealer in boxes marked stationary [sic].

title: Arvind Subramanian Said to Be Top Pick for Indias Chief Economic Adviser
description: NEW DELHI  With Prime Minister Narendra Modis new government promising to ramp up economic growth, an economist based in the United States has emerged as the most likely candidate to serve as its chief economic adviser.

title: T Womens Fall Fashion Issue
description: In our fall womens fashion issue, T celebrates the quiet rebels leading the way in fashion and the culture at large. We start with Sarah Burton, the shy and unassuming designer who is embracing her independent streak four years after the death of her mentor and close friend, Alexander McQueen. We remember the French icon Loulou de la Falaise, whose effervescent personality and inimitable style brought out the best in her close collaborator Yves Saint Laurent, and manifested in her own designs too.We visit Federico Forquet at home in Tuscany, where the former couturier long ago put fashion in the rearview to focus on a career in interior design and gardening. And in Elena Ferrante, a novelist so elusive that no one knows what she  or he, as the case may be  even looks like, we examine the nature of literary stardom and the value of unbiased self-reflection. Elsewhere, Claire Messud visits the provocative South African-born painter Marlene Dumas at her studio in Amsterdam; Ts critic-at-large Jody Rosen heads into the Mojave Desert to investigate the Integratron, a U.F.O.-like structure that serves as a Mecca for spiritual seekers; Jenna Lyons and Courtney Love rock out to Beats and try on the latest Dior heels; and a new generation of female directors step out from behind the camera, revealing the personal experiences and passion for original filmmaking that led them to take on the Hollywood status quo. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Efforts to Revive Rich California Mine Hit Strong Resistance
description: NEVADA CITY, Calif.  It is quiet at Tim Callaways gold mine, with its crumbling concrete, rotting wood and the occasional butterfly accustomed to undisturbed access. But there is plenty of commotion over whats below the surface: an unseen 240,000 ounces of gold.

title: Deborah Sussman Dies at 83; Dressed Buildings in Vivid Colors and Shapes
description: Deborah Sussman, a pioneer of environmental graphics who lifted colors, shapes and visual icons off the printed page and applied them to buildings, campuses and cityscapes, including the simulated ones of Disney World and Disneyland Paris, died on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 83.

title: A Preview of the U.S. Open
description: All eyes will be on Serena Williams and Roger Federer at this years United States Open.

title: The Danger of Combustible Dust
description: WASHINGTON  This month, 75 people were killed and 185 others injured after an explosion ripped through a metal products factory in Chinas eastern Jiangsu Province. The culprit? Dust.

title: Goldman to Pay $3.15 Billion to Settle Mortgage Claims
description: Goldman Sachs is paying its largest bill yet to resolve a government lawsuit related to the financial crisis.

title: Blood Industry Shrinks as Transfusions Decline
description: Changes in medicine have eliminated the need for millions of blood transfusions, which is good news for patients getting procedures like coronary bypasses and other procedures that once required a lot of blood.

title: Building on U.S. Tradition, Camp for Hindu Children Strengthens Their Identity
description: MACEDON, N.Y.  Just before the July a decade ago when Neha Dhawan turned 11, her mother informed her, Youre going to Hindu camp this summer. Invoking her most age-appropriate tone, Neha emitted a diffident, Oh, yeah?

title: Saudis Must Stop Exporting Extremism
description: ALONG with a billion Muslims across the globe, I turn to Mecca in Saudi Arabia every day to say my prayers. But when I visit the holy cities of Mecca and Medina, the resting place of the Prophet Muhammad, I am forced to leave overwhelmed with anguish at the power of extremism running amok in Islams birthplace. Non-Muslims are forbidden to enter this part of the kingdom, so there is no international scrutiny of the ideas and practices that affect the 13 million Muslims who visit each year.

title: A Prominent Location to Remember Veterans Who Were Wounded
description: WASHINGTON  On a patch of land in the shadow of the Capitols dome, a new memorial for soldiers will honor those who died as well as those who survived the nations wars, with an emphasis on the survivors. What is unusual about it is that it will be the only monument in Washington dedicated solely to those who have been disabled.

title: The Invisible Ink That Wasnt: A Player Pleads Guilty to Marking Cards at a Casino
description: Bruce Koloshis strategy for cheating at poker at the Mohegan Sun casino in Connecticut one night last September was, the authorities said, unusual. He marked the cards with ink that he believed only he could see with the special contact lenses he was wearing.

title: Giving Email a Holiday
description: Daimler, the German automaker, has given new meaning to the escape command on workers computers this summer by instituting an automatic program to delete incoming emails to employees on vacation, so they are not tempted to peek at business traffic at the seashore and can start with a clean slate when they return to work.

title: Questions for the Patent Office
description: Representative Darrell Issa, the California Republican with a penchant for evidence-free bombastic statements, may be on to a legitimate issue: allegations of abuse by employees of the Patent and Trademark Office who work from home.

title: As Arizona Primary Nears, Governor Candidates Turn Eyes to Border
description: BULLHEAD CITY, Ariz.  Mexico is at least 200 miles south of this city that neighbors Nevada. But that distance seemed irrelevant to the retirees, disabled veterans and civic leaders gathered at a community centers gym recently for what was billed as a border security forum held by Christine Jones, one of six candidates vying to be the Republican Partys nominee for governor in Tuesdays primary election.

title: Sri Lankas Intransigence
description: Sri Lankas president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, said Tuesday that his government would not cooperate with the United Nations investigation begun last month into suspected human rights abuses, including possible war crimes, committed during Sri Lankas civil war. Mr. Rajapaksas intransigence puts Sri Lanka in the company of North Korea and Syria, two countries that also barred access to United Nations human rights investigators.

title: Reform Conservatism From All Over
description: The pace of recent events has led me to neglect the (crucial, essential, ineffable) reform-conservative beat for the last few weeks, sohere is a brief weekend roundup on the subject.

title: B.C.S. Makes Way for College Football Playoff (and New Debates)
description: In an office in Irving, Tex., there is a jar that as of early August contained about $17. The College Football Playoffs staff members had decided to donate a dollar every time one of them referred to the new system as the college football playoffs.

title: Two New Cases of Ebola Stem From Secondhand Contact
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  Two new cases of Ebola were reported in Nigeria on Friday, both in spouses of health workers who died after caring for the Liberian-American who brought the disease there last month.

title: U.S. Faces Suit Over Tactics at Immigrant Detention Center
description: In a challenge to the Obama administrations strategy for deterring illegal border crossings by Central American migrants, civil rights groups filed a federal lawsuit on Friday claiming that the government committed egregious due process violations against women and children held for deportation at a detention center in New Mexico.

title: Cashing In Could Compromise Eligibility
description: SOUTH WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.  Between her star turn at the Little League World Series and the start of eighth grade, Mone Davis has a trip planned for a round of talk show appearances.

title: In a New York State Park, a Rustic Summer Camp for the Whole Family
description: HARRIMAN STATE PARK, N.Y.  The picnic tables were set in the stone-and-timber pavilion. Oversize grills billowed smoke. And 250 pounds of beef tenderloin were ready.

title: Key Factor in Police Shootings: Reasonable Fear
description: Each time police officers draw their weapons, they step out of everyday law enforcement and into a rigidly defined world where written rules, hours of training and Supreme Court decisions dictate not merely when a gun can be fired, but where it is aimed, how many rounds should be squeezed off and when the shooting should stop.

title: U.S. Officials and Experts at Odds on Threat Posed by ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  Earlier this year, President Obama likened the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria to a junior varsity basketball squad, a group that posed little of the threat once presented by Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda.

title: Gift Horses Gone Wild
description: Its a tribute to the level of terrible news weve been inundated with this summer that the corruption trial of ex-Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell may qualify as a feel-good story. Unless, of course, you are McDonnell.

title: Red Sox Win Bidding Contest in Deal With Cuban Outfielder
description: Less than a month after trading for Yoenis Cespedes, the Boston Red Sox reached a contract agreement with another Cuban outfielder to play alongside him.

title: To the Elevators, and Then to the Pit
description: THE ELEVATOR HISTORICAL SOCIETY is up a flight of stairs. Near Long Island Citys Silvercup Studios, where Girls and Person of Interest are filmed, the society is a museum founded in 2011 by Patrick Carrajat, 70. He has been entranced with elevators since he was 11 and made $5 from fixing one alongside his father, a repairman.

title: New York Process Servers Lose a Suit on New Rules
description: It is one of the basic elements of law: When you are sued, you have to be notified so that you can appear in court to defend yourself.

title: A March for a Safer City
description: The protest planned for Saturday on Staten Island promises to be a galvanizing moment for New Yorkers angered at the death of Eric Garner, the 43-year-old African-American who was unarmed when he was fatally assaulted in July by the police. Marchers, led by the Rev. Al Sharpton, will demand justice for Mr. Garner and his family, and will denounce police brutality.

title: New Trial Sought in Death of Man Pulled From Cell
description: Lawyers for the mother of a mentally ill man who died in 2010 while being forcibly removed from his cell in a Nashville prison asked a federal court on Friday for a new civil trial against prison officials.

title: Stars Struggle to Make Barclays Cut
description: PARAMUS, N.J.  There was Phil Mickelson, scrambling to make the cut at the Barclays tournament on Friday, scrambling the way only Mickelson knows how.

title: Gaza Talks Build at U.N.
description: With Egyptian-brokered talks to halt the Israel-Hamas conflict in Gaza frozen, discussions have intensified at the United Nations in recent days over a possible Security Council resolution that would end the fighting and attract broad-based support, including from the United States, Israels most important ally.

title: Lessons Not Learned
description: The death of Fernand St Germain last week, at the age of 86, got me thinking about the financial calamity that he was long associated with: the savings and loan crisis of the late 1980s. There are things it could have  and should have  taught us as we spiraled toward the financial crisis less than two decades later.

title: Florida Judge Deals a Blow to Democrats on Districting
description: MIAMI  In a blow to Florida Democrats, a state judge on Friday approved a slightly modified congressional map drawn by the Republican-dominated Legislature and decided that the 2014 election could proceed under the old map, which he had ruled unconstitutional.

title: Blackouts in Egypt Prompt Accusations
description: CAIRO  Facing the most severe summer power shortages in recent memory, with blackouts shutting factories, crippling small businesses and darkening some homes for more than 12 hours a day, Egyptian officials blamed supporters of the deposed Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, for sabotaging the electricity grid.

title: First Part of a Hit
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  No, youre not having a nervous breakdown. Come sit here by me and lets discuss the hardest, most diabolical puzzle Ive ever solved.

title: Despite Similar Shooting, Los Angeless Bank of Trust Tempers Reaction
description: LOS ANGELES  When Los Angeles police officers shot and killed Ezell Ford, an unarmed 25-year-old black man last week, it took less than 24 hours for Lita Herron to get a phone call from a ranking officer at a nearby station.

title: Americans Star Power Unrivaled in Japan
description: TOKYO  DAVID SPECTOR is a relative unknown in his native Chicago, but here in Japan he is a household name.
