With his bleach-blond hair, and ability to deliver one-liners in flawless Japanese, Mr. Spector has been a fixture in this nations often raucous talk-show world for three decades, making him perhaps the most recognizable American living in Japan.

title: A Grim Week of Executions and Racial Strife
description: As new conflicts erupt around the globe, older ones often get pushed off the international radar. But that does not mean they have gone away: The Syrian war, for example, is still raging. Indeed, it is metastasizing outwards in an uncontrollable process whose eventual limits we cannot predict, said Navi Pillay, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, in her last address before the Security Council. (Her term ends Aug. 30.)

title: Stars Rackets: Not Just Like Ours
description: When Roger Federer decided to switch to a larger racket, it was tenniss most buzzed-about change since Jimmy Connors flashed his neon yellow Estusa at the 1991 United States Open.

title: Robert Sherrill, Author Who Skewered Right and Left, Dies at 89
description: Robert Sherrill, a provocative journalist and author who rose to prominence in the 1960s and 70s for his sharp assessments of gun culture, military justice, Lyndon B. Johnson and other complicated topics, died on Tuesday in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 89.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 22, 2014
A Tale of de Blasios Neighborhoods: Park Slope and Yorkville
description: Hes finally in the new place now, his Dickensian catchphrase having taken him from the leafy idyll of Park Slope to the sleepy outpost of Yorkville.

title: Talented Field for Travers Stakes Will Also Be Missing Some Names
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  There are some very nice racehorses signed on for the 145th running of the Travers Stakes on Saturday: the Belmont Stakes winner, Tonalist; the Haskell champ, Bayern; and the Jim Dandy victor, Wicked Strong. The field of 10 is deep, as well: Mr. Speaker beat a pair of highly touted international colts in the Belmont Derby, and V. E. Day has won three in a row.

title: Recent Acquisition Gives Yankees Playoff Hopes a Lift
description: The Yankees did not make any blockbuster moves at the July 31 trade deadline, but they acquired several veteran complementary players who they believed could provide help toward a playoff run. One of those players, Martin Prado, might have helped keep them in the playoff race Friday.

title: The Knick Recap: The Rogue Clinic  in the Hospital Basement
description: Season 1, Episode 3, The Busy Flea

title: Jean Redpath, Prolific Scottish Folk Singer, Dies at 77
description: Jean Redpath, an esteemed Scottish folk singer whose arresting repertoire of ancient ballads, Robert Burns poems and contemporary tunes helped energize a genre she described as a brew of pure flavor and pure emotion, died on Thursday at a hospice in Arizona. She was 77.

title: Legal Woes of Owners Help Put the Plaza Back in Play
description: The rumor sent a shudder through the bell captain on Monday as he hustled across the lobby of the Plaza Hotel, the Manhattan landmark at Fifth Avenue and Central Park South.

title: Emails Show Bigger Fund-Raising Role for Wisconsin Leader
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin played a greater role than previously known in arranging for wealthy contributors to donate to a powerful conservative organization in his home state as it battled a two-year campaign to recall Mr. Walker and Republican lawmakers, according to court documents released Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 23, 2014
description: Let the physical evidence tell us what happened. How badly injured was the police officer? Was he dazed? Was Michael Brown on drugs? Lets see whats really going on here.

title: Sand and Surf, Speedos and Spirits
description: On a midsummer Saturday, under a sapphire sky, a ferry shuttled festive weekenders from Sayville on the South Shore of Long Island to Fire Island Pines, much as motorcars once brought eager revelers out of the city to the Long Island of Jay Gatsbys blue gardens.

title: Large Dams Just Arent Worth the Cost
description: THAYER SCUDDER, the worlds leading authority on the impact of dams on poor people, has changed his mind about dams.

title: Weekend Ho!
Chung Eun-yong,Who Helped Expose U.S. Killings of Koreans, Dies at 91
description: Chung Eun-yong ran to his wife and embraced her. She collapsed in his arms, sobbing. He asked and asked about their two young children, but she could not answer.

title: Onstage, a Ghost and a Swordsman
description: Cape May has gentle beaches, Victorian architecture, fine restaurants and two long-established yet contrasting professional theater troupes. The East Lynne Theater Company rediscovers vintage plays. Cape May Stage usually presents newer works drawn from recent Broadway and Off Broadway seasons.

title: Case File on Fund-Raising for a Group Helping Gov. Scott Walker
description: These court documents detail an investigation into whether the campaign of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin improperly coordinated fund-raising with conservative groups fighting efforts to recall him in 2012.

title: New York Council Vote to Pay School Bus Drivers More Is Criticized
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio came into office promising to use the levers of government to battle economic inequality and to improve the lives of struggling New Yorkers.

title: Two Arrested as New York City Focuses on Deed Fraud
description: They wandered into New York City government offices this week, indignant at how the cogs of bureaucracy had slowed their grand plans of thievery.

title: Coming Off a Strong Performance, Smith Is Named the Jets Starter
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets came into Friday nights preseason game against the Giants hoping quarterback Geno Smith would continue to show progress as an evolving leader of the teams offense.

title: In Japan, Another Leader Takes Heat for Golfing During a Crisis
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe now shares at least one thing in common with President Obama: criticism for an ill-timed game of golf.

title: After Season of Despair, All the Pressure Is on the Coach
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  It is so hot at football practice here in August that even the referees wear shorts.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 6:30 A.M. (Sundance) BLUE VELVET (1986) The director David Lynch uncovers savagery and perversity behind the bland facades of a small town in this film, for which Mr. Lynch received a best director Oscar nomination. Kyle MacLachlan plays Jeffrey Beaumont, a dull American teenager who discovers a severed ear and sets out to find its owner. Along the way, he witnesses terrible and beautiful things  including Dennis Hopper, at his most unhinged, and Dean Stockwell, deranged and in pancake makeup, lip syncing Roy Orbisons In Dreams into a table lamp. Isabella Rossellini, above, smolders as the abused nightclub singer who becomes the object of Jeffreys desire. For those with the temerity to follow it anywhere, Blue Velvet is as fascinating as it is freakish, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. It confirms Mr. Lynchs stature as an innovator, a superb technician and someone best not encountered in a dark alley.

title: Errors Make for Comedy, but the Mets Arent Amused
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a routine grounder to shortstop. Wilmer Flores scooped the ball up, but then he dropped it. Flores retrieved the ball, but as he tried to fire it to first, his spikes caught in the ground.

title: Corrections: August 23, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Analytics: How Readers Reacted to Our Cover Story About Libertarians
description: The following pie chart appears on the Reply All page in the Aug. 24 issue of the magazine.

title: The Growing Blue-State Diaspora
description: Californians have moved to Colorado and Nevada. Massachusetts natives have moved to New Hampshire. New Yorkers have moved to North Carolina and Virginia  and, of course, have continued moving to Florida.

title: Germany Pledges Aid for Ukraine as Russia Hails a Returning Convoy
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Pulling back a huge aid convoy whose entry into Ukraine stirred Western outrage, Russia on Saturday cheered the completion of what it called a successful humanitarian mission, while Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany visited the Ukrainian capital and pledged more than $690 million for the rebuilding of war-ravaged areas of eastern Ukraine and aid to refugees.

title: Two Countries, Two Vastly Different Phone Bills
description: If your monthly cellphone bill seems high, that may be because American cellphone service is among the most costly in the world. A comparison of two similar plans, one in the United States and one in Britain, reveals a marked difference.

title: Julie Myers Wood: Eat Your Sushi, and Expand Your Horizons
description: This interview with  Julie Myers Wood, chief executive of Guidepost Solutions, a security, compliance and risk management firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: How to Polish a Baseball Diamond
Another Night In Brooklyn
description: Arcade Fire at Barclays Center. Ive been following their music more or less obsessively for years, but this was my first live concert. Its quite an experience  watching the videos doesnt give you anything like the feel for the sheer energy and joy, both of the band and the audience. I have to admit that the sound in a big arena is a bit murky  the bass was too loud  so it helped if you already knew and loved all the songs, which I did. Wake Up was a stunning climax, as always.

title: Yes, Flexible Hours Ease Stress. But Is Everyone on Board?
description: Everyone with a job knows how stressful it can be when personal priorities clash with work schedules. The conflict could involve a continuing medical concern, taking care of children or aging parents, or getting enough exercise or running errands. A too-strict schedule combined with too many demands can cause workers to feel that they have let down their companies, their families and themselves.

title: One Way to Fix the Corporate Tax: Repeal It
description: Some people are calling these companies corporate deserters.

title: Draghi at Deflation Gulch
description: Full disclosure: I know Mario Draghi, a bit, since we overlapped in grad school, and I both like and admire him; he did a fantastic job of containing the euro crisis of 2012. And I like to imagine that he knows and understands more than he can say in his position. Still, I dont think Im projecting too much in reading his Jackson Hole speech as the words of a man who knows perfectly well how dire the situation is, and is sailing as close to the wind as he can, but is all too aware of how inadequate thats likely to be.

title: An Unfinished Chapter at Countrywide
description: Is Angelo R. Mozilo in the cross hairs again?

title: 1914: Kitchener Congratulates British Troops in France
description: LONDON  Lord Kitchener, speaking in the House of Lords for the first time, made an important statement on the situation yesterday [Aug. 25]. He prefaced his remarks by explaining that, as a soldier, he had no politics and that his present position as Secretary of State for War did not imply political sympathies of any kind. The terms of his services were for the war.

title: Home on the West Side Range
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Raising a Glass to American Upstart Distillers
description: In March 2011, Michael Vachon, an American expatriate working for a struggling tech start-up business in London, was in Austin, Tex., for the South by Southwest festival, trying to drum up interest in his company.

title: At Hotels, Hearing the Scream for Ice Cream
description: Travelers in the mood for grab-and-go ice cream scoops cant usually find them at their hotels, but that is changing this summer with properties setting up stands serving house-made versions of the frozen treat. At theGansevoort Park AvenueinNew York City, the Italian restaurant Asellina has an outdoor gelato cart most days until mid-September selling $5 scoops of flavors like pistachio and Nutella (they are free on Wednesdays from noon to 2 p.m.).

title: Coverage of Eric Garner Rally on Staten Island
description: Demonstrators marched on Staten Island on Saturday against overly aggressive policing after the death of Eric Garner.

title: Attack of the Crazy Centrists
description: Im by no means the only person, or even pundit, who sometimes (often) feels that centrists are the craziest people in our political life. Liberals these days rarely stake out really extreme positions (more on that in a minute); conservatives may denounce Obama as a Muslim atheist communist, but at least they know what they want. The really strange people are those who insist that there is symmetry between left and right, that both are equally far out and equally at fault for polarization, and make up all kinds of strange stories to justify this claim.

title: Katie Ledecky Improves on Her World Record in the 400 Freestyle
description: SOUTHPORT, Australia  Katie Ledecky broke her world record in the 400-meter freestyle on Saturday at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships. With the Gold Coast Aquatic Centre crowd here cheering her on, Ledecky was timed in 3 minutes 58.37 seconds. Her United States teammate Cierra Runge finished second in 4:04.55.

title: A Stars Bumpy Trail to Oregon
description: HONOLULU  Near the base of Koko Head, on the south shore of Oahu, an abrupt change in the ocean floor causes the steep, violent waves that crash onto Sandy Beach.

title: Latvias Tensions With Russians at Home Persist in Shadow of Ukraine Conflict
description: RIGA, Latvia  History has bequeathed this Baltic port capital much beauty, captured in elegant Art Nouveau buildings or the Gothic church steeples that stud the windswept skyline. But it has also left a nasty ethnic rift that has persisted despite Latvias absorption into NATO, the European Union and the euro currency, and which has now deepened with the crisis in Ukraine.

title: Michael Bloombergs Harder Sell
description: On a sweltering Saturday in June in Istanbuls old city, Michael R. Bloomberg, power-dressed in a dark blue suit, monogrammed white shirt and cuff links, sat down to a late-morning breakfast with local antismoking activists on a rooftop overlooking the glittering Sea of Marmara.

title: Variety: An Acrostic That Takes Work
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Relationships need work: Both members need to show up and put in the time it takes to keep a relationship afloat.

title: Bid to Expand Medical Marijuana Business Faces Federal Hurdles
description: WRAY, Colo.  Behind a tall curtain of corn that hides their real cash crop from prying eyes, the Stanley family is undertaking an audacious effort to expand their medical marijuana business to a national market.

title: Michael Phelps,Unfazed by Poor Weather, Wins Gold Medal in the 100 Butterfly
description: SOUTHPORT, Australia  The towel draped around Michael Phelpss shoulders was dripping wet as he stood shivering in the interview area after his preliminary swim Saturday in the 100-meter butterfly.

title: Devoted to Rural America
description: Patrick Gottsch, founder of the rural cable channel RFD-TV, is taking up the fight against big media mergers.

title: Unions Face Backlash for Joining March on Staten Island
description: On the eve of a demonstration over the death of a black Staten Island man in police custody, organizers were making sure the official signs carried messages that, while protesting aggressive policing, did not castigate the New York Police Department.

title: Timeline for a Body: 4 Hours in the Middle of a Ferguson Street
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Just after noon on Saturday, Aug. 9, Michael Brown was shot dead by a police officer on Canfield Drive.

title: A Matchup of Unsinkable Spirits
description: When Richard Norris Williams II won the 1914 United States National Tennis Championships in Newport, R.I., upsetting the defending two-time champion, Maurice E. McLoughlin, he completed what might still be considered the greatest comeback in his sport or any sport.

title: In Washington, Second Thoughts on Arming Police
description: WASHINGTON  Jolted by images of protesters clashing with heavily armed police officers in Missouri, President Obama has ordered a comprehensive review of the governments decade-old strategy of outfitting local police departments with military-grade body armor, mine-resistant trucks, silencers and automatic rifles, senior officials say.

title: With a Bit More Polish, Geno Smith Takes the Controls
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After last years annual preseason game against the Giants, an injury to the right shoulder of Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez required Coach Rex Ryan to eventually name the rookie Geno Smith the teams starter.

title: The One-Handed Backhand Has All but Disappeared
description: But the Swiss winner of the Australian Open, Stan Wawrinka, may be the man to save it.

title: Moving East, an Artist Doubles His Productivity
description: Jules Feiffer, the award-winning cartoonist, playwright, screenwriter and author, was for a long time the quintessential New Yorker. Born in the Bronx, he was a cartoonist for The Village Voice for over 40 years, living inBrooklyn and later on theUpper West Side, while working with luminaries like Mike Nichols (Carnal Knowledge), Alan Arkin (Little Murders) and Robert Altman (Popeye).

title: Henrys Artistry Inspires His Latest Strike Partner
description: HANOVER, N.J.  Over the last few summers, the coziest space on a Major League Soccer field has been the radius of grass around Thierry Henry.

title: Imagine a Foul Ball as Strike 3
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Those Who Serve Ebola Victims Soldier On
description: KENEMA, Sierra Leone  The best defense against despair was to keep working. Many times, that choice was far from obvious: Josephine Finda Sellu lost 15 of her nurses to Ebola in rapid succession and thought about quitting herself.

title: A Familiar Figure on the Santo Domingo Waterfront
description: The Vatican ambassador who serves as a personal envoy of the pope has been accused of sexually abusing minors in the Dominican Republic

title: For Nuncio Accused of Abuse, Dominicans Want Justice at Home, Not Abroad
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  He was a familiar figure to the skinny shoeshine boys who work along the oceanfront promenade here. Wearing black track pants and a baseball cap pulled low over his balding head, they say, he would stroll along in the late afternoon and bring one of them down to the rocky shoreline or to a deserted monument for a local Catholic hero.

title: U.S. Court to Hear Case on Voting Restrictions as Arizona Prepares for Polls
description: PHOENIX  A decades-old effort by Congress to make voter registration simple and uniform across the country has run up against a new eras anti-immigration politics. So on Tuesday, when Arizonas polls open for primaries for governor, attorney general and a host of other state and local positions as well as for Congress, some voters will be permitted to vote only in the race for Congress.

title: Putting Aside Xs and Os to Ponder Life and Death
description: PHILADELPHIA  Forty-five minutes after his team defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers in an ugly preseason game on Thursday, Eagles Coach Chip Kelly was walking through the locker room. Kelly stopped, said hello and asked what had brought me to Philadelphia for a relatively nondescript preseason game.

title: Burial Boys of Ebola
description: In Sierra Leone, a group of young men take on the dirtiest work of the Ebola outbreak: finding and burying the dead.

title: Anthony Davis, Now on the World Stage, Is the Next Superstar
description: The United States will soon send a 12-man team of N.B.A. standouts to play in the FIBA World Cup  formerly the world basketball championship  in Barcelona, Spain. It was there in 1992 that Americas so-called Dream Team, led by Michael Jordan and a sparkling roster of future Hall of Famers, captivated the world during the Summer Olympics.

title: In Afghan Election, Signs of Systemic Fraud Cast Doubt on Many Votes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When the campaign team led by Manawar Shah came under threat on the day of the Afghan presidential runoff, it was not from the Taliban, he said, but from the people who were supposed to be keeping order: an alliance of government officials, security forces and supporters of the candidate Ashraf Ghani.

title: Someday Soon, There May Be No Such Thing as a Free Pass
description: The indelible image of the intentional walk is Barry Bonds stepping to the plate, sending the crowd into a frenzy, and then pursing his lips when the opposing catcher sticks an arm out and signals to send the slugger to first.

title: A Better Credit Card
description: American banks and retailers are finally embracing credit card technology that has been shown to minimize fraudulent transactions in the rest of the world. Given recent data breaches in which hackers stole the card numbers of millions of consumers from cash register systems at retailers like Target and Supervalu, the change cant come soon enough.

title: The Climate Swerve
description: AMERICANS appear to be undergoing a significant psychological shift in our relation to global warming. I call this shift a climate swerve, borrowing the term used recently by the Harvard humanities professor Stephen Greenblatt to describe a major historical change in consciousness that is neither predictable nor orderly.

title: Teachings Human Touch
description: Readers discuss whether proposed reforms are too focused on metrics and technology.

title: How the Carolinas Fixed Their Blurred Lines
description: DURHAM, N.C.  BORDER disputes between American states are as old as the republic, but in todays highly charged political atmosphere they often take an ugly turn.

title: Rethinking Eating
description: HAVING radically changed the way we communicate, do research, buy books, listen to music, hire a car and get a date, Silicon Valley now aims to transform the way we eat. Just as text messages have replaced more lengthy discourse and digital vetting has diminished the slow and awkward evolution of intimacy, tech entrepreneurs hope to get us hooked on more efficient, algorithmically derived food.

title: An Unusual Hire, for Uncommon Times
description: SINCE I arrived in the newsroom of The Times two years ago, Ive watched vast change take hold. The digital revolution has hit the newspaper business like a hurricane roaring ashore.

title: Black, White and Baseball
description: SOUTH WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.  IF you were looking last week for a thread of hope amid all the hurt in America and savagery abroad, for something to thrill to and cheer about, this is where you found it, on a baseball diamond in central Pennsylvania that really did amount to a field of dreams.

title: Our Thoroughly Modern Enemies
description: IN his remarks on the murder of James Foley, the American journalist decapitated by the terrorists of ISIS, President Obama condemned Foleys killers, appropriately, as a cancer on the Middle East and the world. But he also found room for the most Obama-ish of condemnations: One thing we can all agree on, he insisted, is that the would-be caliphates murderous vision has no place in the 21st century.

title: Thomas W. Geisbert
description: Thomas W. Geisbert is a virologist who specializes in viral hemorrhagic fevers such as the Ebola virus. He and his team at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston are currently working on developing vaccines to treat these diseases, which have mortality rates as high as 90 percent.

title: The Debate on Salty Foods, Continued
description: For years, there have been contentious debates over reducing the amount of salt in the American diet. Now warring studies in The New England Journal of Medicine have brought new evidence to bear.

title: The Golf Address
description: FORE! Score? And seven trillion rounds ago, our forecaddies brought forth on this continent a new playground, conceived by Robert Trent Jones, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal when it comes to spending as much time on the links as possible  even when it seems totally inappropriate, like moments after making a solemn statement condemning the grisly murder of a 40-year-old American journalist beheaded by ISIL.

title: Order vs. Disorder, Part 3
description: THE United States is swamped by refugee children from collapsing Central American countries; efforts to contain the major Ebola outbreak in West Africa are straining governments there; jihadists have carved out a bloodthirsty caliphate inside Iraq and Syria; after having already eaten Crimea, Russia keeps taking more bites out of Ukraine; and the U.N.s refugee agency just announced that the number of refugees, asylum-seekers and internally displaced people worldwide has, for the first time in the post-World War II era, exceeded 50 million people. If it feels as though the world of disorder is expanding against the world of order, its not your imagination. Theres an unfortunate logic to it.

title: Dealing With Digital Cruelty
description: ANYONE who has ever been online has witnessed, or been virtually walloped by, a mean comment. If youre going to be a blogger, if youre going to tweet stuff, you better develop a tough skin, said John Suler, a professor of psychology at Rider University who specializes in what he refers to as cyberpsychology. Some 69 percent of adult social media users said they have seen people being mean and cruel to others on social network sites, according to a 2011 report from the Pew Research Centers Internet and American Life Project.

title: Bug Love
description: LARAMIE, Wyo.  ITS summertime, the season of insects, and if you spend any time outdoors (or even indoors), youve probably been swatting and stomping your way toward fall. Mosquitoes and midges dance over ponds, butterflies and bumblebees tussle on daisies, crickets and katydids trill melodies, moths zigzag around lights leaving dusty trails.

title: My Daughter, Her Rat
description: Somehow, we have to get Eden, my daughters pet rat, from Brooklyn to Portland, Ore., where Olivia will start college next month. Like E. B. Whites Stuart Little, Eden has become part of our family, a kind of miniature sibling to my only child, who is about to leave home. Eden is one of a klatch of pet rats we know (picture three young women and their animals at our kitchen table, eating tacos, our two cats asleep in a corner). According to Robert Sullivans book Rats, fancy descendants of the homely gray Rattus norvegicus had an earlier moment as womens companions during the Victorian era. Is Eden part of a revival zeitgeist thing, a moment soon to be documented by pop culture media?

title: Why Interest Rates Need to Stay Low
description: A sharp debate within the Federal Reserve over when to raise interest rates was publicly aired last week at the annual central bankers conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo. On one side is a small yet vocal minority of Fed officials who want to head off inflation by raising rates sooner rather than later. On the other is a majority that thinks a near-term rate hike would stifle growth and, with it, any chance of restoring health to the labor market. That group includes Janet Yellen, the Feds chairwoman, and most members of the Feds policy committee.

title: On Not Writing
description: I started writing this essay five years ago, and then I stopped. That I was not able to finish the piece did not strike me at the time as ironic but as further proof that whatever I once had in me  juice, talent, will  was gone. In any case, completing it would have made moot the very point I was attempting to make: Not writing can be good for ones writing; indeed, it can make one a better writer.

title: Underdogs Who Make the Most of a Chance
description: The Los Angeles Angels arrived at Fenway Park on Monday in a tie with the Oakland Athletics atop the American League West. After four victories in a row, they left on Thursday alone in first place before their weekend matchup at Oakland. But they also left without Garrett Richards, their most reliable starting pitcher.

title: Populists Brash Tactics Stir Fears of Crisis in Pakistan
description: LONDON  Only last year, Imran Khan was casting himself as the savior of Pakistani politics: a playboy cricketer turned opposition leader who enjoyed respect and sex appeal, filling stadiums with adoring young Pakistanis drawn to his strident attacks on corruption, American drone strikes and old-school politics. When Mr. Khan promised that he would become prime minister, many believed him.

title: Pakistan and India Trade Fire
description: NEW DELHI  Indian and Pakistani forces exchanged heavy fire along the border in the region of Jammu early Saturday, resulting in reported deaths of civilians on both sides, and forcing villagers to flee their homes.

title: A Driving School in France Hits a Wall of Regulations
description: PARIS  Alexandre Chartier and Benjamin Gaignault work off Apple computers and have no intention of ever using the DVD player tucked in the corner of their airy office. But French regulations demand that all driving schools have one, so they got one.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 24
description: On Tuesday, James Foley, an American journalist, was executed at the hands of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. President Obama said the entire world was appalled by Mr. Foleys beheading, as American warplanes conducted more than a dozen airstrikes in Iraq.

title: Marchers Demand Justice for Eric Garner
description: Demonstrators on Staten Island protested the chokehold death of an unarmed black man who was in the custody of police officers trying to arrest him for selling loose cigarettes.

title: China Denies Confrontation With U.S. Surveillance Plane
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government rejected the Pentagons claim that a Peoples Liberation Army fighter jet had buzzed dangerously close to an American surveillance plane in international airspace, and it warned that frequent surveillance flights were risking an accident near the Chinese coast.

title: Cavaliers Complete Deal to Acquire Kevin Love From Timberwolves
description: When LeBron James decided to rejoin the Cleveland Cavaliers this summer, it was a foregone conclusion that the move would have an enormous effect on the N.B.A. for years to come. Such is the power that James wields, and as the start of training camp approaches  a little more than a month from now  the ripples continue to lap at the leagues shores.

title: Dozens Rally for Officer in Ferguson Killing as Funds Are Raised Online
description: ST. LOUIS  An online fund-raising drive for the Ferguson, Mo., police officer who shot an unarmed African-American teenager to death on Aug. 9 surpassed $300,000 by Saturday afternoon, as dozens of people gathered at a St. Louis pub to rally on the lawmans behalf.

title: On Staten Island, Thousands Protest Police Tactics
description: They came by ferry from Manhattan, in caravans from Brooklyn and New Jersey or on foot from the gritty neighborhood in northeast Staten Island where an unarmed black man, Eric Garner, died last month after an encounter with the police.

title: Gay-Themed Events Part of the Game
description: LOS ANGELES  Friday night was not much different from most others at Dodger Stadium. An actor, Jesse Tyler Ferguson, threw out the ceremonial first pitch. A recording artist, Mary Lambert, sang the national anthem. And there was not much more hand-holding than usual among couples during the postgame fireworks show.

title: John F. Akers, 79, Dies; Led IBM as PCs Ascended
description: John F. Akers, the chief executive and chairman of IBM during a turbulent time when the rise of the personal computer undercut the profitability of the mainframe computer business, died on Friday in Boston. He was 79.

title: After Joe Torre Is Honored, the Yankees Gain a Win
description: It was just before the start of the 1996 baseball season, and Joe Torre, who had just been hired to manage the Yankees, needed a new uniform number.

title: A Challenging Dinner, Layer by Layer
description: About a half-mile away from a restaurant called That Italian Joint, and down the road from the disaster-courting Action Park, sits Restaurant Latour, a rarefied establishment where matcha green tea cocktails are served with yuzu bubbles and local pickled elderflowers grace buttermilk granita.

title: Venturing Beyond the Usual Bar Food
description: When Douglas and Daneen Grabe named their new restaurant Little Pub, they were not kidding about the size. This Ridgefield restaurant, which opened in June 2009, is tiny, seating a mere 25 to 35 diners inside, giving it a built-in noisiness. The good news is that an attached screened porch (seating 35 to 40) makes conversation possible while dining.

title: A Bit of the Bosporus
description: Of restaurants on the East End, few have better word of mouth than Turkuaz Grill, a four-year-old establishment serving Mediterranean cuisine in the revitalized town of Riverhead. Locals speak of it with reverence; the superlatives can get a little mushy. At the same time, this is a land almost entirely bereft of authentic ethnic food, and its inhabitants are desperate for menu options beyond grilled or blackened.

title: TV Chief Takes 2-by-4 to a Proposed Cable Merger
description: MEDINA, Minn.  As the oom-pah-pah oom-pah-pah of the band fades, Patrick Gottsch makes his way through silver-haired couples circling the dance floor at The Mollie B Polka Party in this quiet Midwestern town.

title: Second Shift
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  I dont know about you, but it was a huge relief to do Patrick Berrys puzzle after the Saturday puzzle where I thought I was losing my mind. I feel like I have my sanity back and all is right with the world. Heaven knows what Will Shortz and his constructing cabal have in store for us next week.

title: Best Woman to Ever Play Chess Retires From Competition
description: The best woman to ever play chess has called it a career.

title: The Flow of Money and Equipment to Local Police
description: Following two weeks of images from protests in Ferguson, Mo., where police officers deployed military gear and equipment to quell unrest, President Obama ordered a review of several federal programs that provide money and equipment to local police.

title: Papier-Mch Heads and a Surprise Guest
description: Misdirection, the essential tool of magicians and hustlers, served no less tactical a purpose for Arcade Fire in Brooklyn on Friday, in its first of three nights at the Barclays Center. At the top of the encore, a fake four-piece band calling itself the Reflektors  in oversize papier-mch heads, suitable for a carnival  popped up on a platform in the middle of the arena to mime a version of Personality Crisis, by the New York Dolls.

title: Response to Attack Reflects Iraqs Sectarian Divide
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs politicians were struggling to meet the constitutional deadline to form a new government when, in an isolated village, two masked men stepped into a Sunni mosque and opened fire on Friday, killing dozens of worshipers.

title: Thousands in Texas Lose Cars Amid Calls for Loan Restrictions
description: AUSTIN  Tiffany Richardson had a job as a nurse, money in savings and no reason to imagine she would ever need to swap her car title for a quick loan.

title: A Waste Solution May Lean Again on a Low-Income Area
description: HOUSTON  The McCarty Road Landfill is an unwelcome mountain in this flat city: The giant mound covered by sand and grass towers over the Settegast neighborhood of Houston.

title: Israeli Strike Destroys Apartment Tower in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli missile strike on an 11-story apartment tower in Gaza City brought the entire building crashing down on Saturday, soon after its residents were told to evacuate, according to residents and the military. The attack signaled Israels willingness to take more audacious military action in Gaza, as Palestinian militants continued to fire barrages of rockets and mortar rounds into Israel.

title: County Casts Long Shadow, Even to Perry
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: An Opera Comes to El Paso by Way of Bhutan
description: When the University of Texas at El Paso stages its free performance of Handels English-language opera Acis and Galatea this Saturday, it will mark the latest expression of a century-old connection between El Paso and Bhutan.

title: Homage to the Flavors of Far Southern Italy
description: Its exciting to find an Italian restaurant with a menu that promises to deliver the rich flavors of Southern Italy, specifically Puglias Salentine Peninsula, the area at the heel of Italys boot. The kitchen of Massa Coastal Italian Cuisine in Mamaroneck is influenced by the produce from the peninsulas inland farmsteads (or masserias) and by the plentiful seafood fished from the adjoining Adriatic and Ionian Seas.

title: The New Man Bringing the Bard to Boscobel
description: Davis McCallum just happened to be in the neighborhood, on the western fringes of Manhattans theater district. He had a design meeting that morning at Playwrights Horizons about Pocatello, a new play by Samuel D. Hunter, which Mr. McCallum described as being set entirely in an Olive Garden restaurant. But that was not what he had come to talk about.

title: Scenes From Saturdays March
description: Thousands gathered to protest the death of Eric Garner, who died after being placed in a chokehold during a confrontation with the police.

title: Novak Djokovic Says Family Is Now His No. 1 Focus
description: Despite his status as the top seed and the hot favorite with oddsmakers to win the United States Open, Novak Djokovic arrives in New York considerably undercooked.

title: After His Mother Gives Him a Lift to the Course, a Player Makes a Leap
description: PARAMUS, N.J.  By the time Morgan Hoffmann made his way up the 17th fairway, looking at a birdie putt for a share of the lead, a sizable crowd had begun to form and people were already whispering to one another, You know hes from Wyckoff?

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 23, 2014
In a Tight Travers Finish, a Trainer Cant Lose
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Jimmy Jerkens had been here before, waiting for the placing judges to decipher a photo finish in the biggest race at Saratoga Race Course, the Travers Stakes. Four years ago, a late rush by a horse named Fly Down looked to have caught Jerkenss colt Afleet Express at the finish line.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 24, 2014
description: If I have a long life, I can go back to my people. I can talk to them: Im doing this job for you. Maybe they can understand me.

title: Hundreds in Washington Protest Missouri Shooting
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of protesters marched through busy, commercial streets here on a damp Saturday evening  with arms raised  protesting the killing of Michael Brown, the unarmed African-American teenager who was fatally shot by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., earlier this month.

title: Identity and Youth
description: The multimedia artist Pae White addresses the complexities of being true to oneself as explored in Ada Limóns verse on teenage posturing.

title: The Business of Style
description: Straightforward, commercial clothes used to be the antithesis of high fashion. Now, they are the benchmark.

title: Isis Ward and Austin Kivett-Ripmaster
description: Isis Katarina Ward, a daughter of Susan Bennis Ward and Joseph S. Ward Jr. of Milford, N.Y., was married Saturday at her parents farm to Austin Rutland Kivett-Ripmaster, the son of Joel D. Ripmaster and Margaret Kivett-Ripmaster of Boulder, Colo. The Rev. Robert J. Kazinski, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Celene Menschel and Alexander Egan
description: Celene Arlt Menschel and Alexander Landon Egan were married Saturday at the summer house of the brides family on Nantucket Island in Massachusetts. The ceremony was led by Charis Menschel Drant, a sister of the bride, who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Genavieve Shingle, Jordana Jaffe
description: Genavieve Casey Shingle and Jordana Trencher Jaffe are to be married Sunday at Penthouse 808 in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Eliott Perlstein, Ms. Jaffes stepfather, is to officiate.

title: Michael McGovern and Gregory Alcock
description: Michael Erin McGovern and Gregory Ronald Alcock were married Saturday. The ceremony was led by Ronald L. Alcock, Mr. Alcocks father and the mayor of Geneva, N.Y., who became a Universal Life minister for the ceremony. It was held at Lamoreaux Landing, a winery in Lodi, N.Y.

title: Ashley Valliere, Keith Margulis
description: Ashley Nicole Valliere, a daughter of Barbara A. Valliere and Walter E. Valliere of Clifton, Va., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Keith Stuart Margulis, the son of Felice J. Margulis and Justice Ira H. Margulis of Hollis Hills, Queens. The grooms father, a State Supreme Court justice in Queens, officiated at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth Tunick, Andrew Cedar
description: Elizabeth Georgina Tunick, the daughter of Elizabeth S. Tunick of New York and David P. Tunick of Stamford, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Andrew Newman Cedar, a son of Dr. Meryl Newman-Cedar and Philip M. Cedar of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Robin A. Joseph officiated at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Lauren Shockey, Ross Fabricant
description: Lauren Dara Shockey and Ross Winthrop Fabricant were married Saturday in Stone Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi Evan B. Moffic, a cousin of the groom, officiated at the ElmRock Inn.

title: Sarah Filous, Benjamin Spector
description: Sarah Lynn Filous, the daughter of Laura J. Filous and Dale A. Filous of Valley City, Ohio, was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Jay Spector, the son of Barbara Alberton Spector and Dr. Stephen H. Spector of Toms River, N.J. Rabbi Susan Stone officiated at the Renaissance Hotel in Cleveland, with the Rev. Thomas Fanta, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

title: Goedenmooi Monds, Matthew Medina
description: Goedenmooi Florence Monds and Matthew David Medina were married Friday at the Charisma Ballroom in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. The Rev. Natalie Parks-Wiggan, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: How Could She Refuse Billy Idol?
description: Samantha Ilise Gutterman, the daughter of Cindy R. Gutterman and Jay B. Gutterman of New York, was married Saturday evening to Joshua Adam Moshen, a son of the late Virginia L. Moshen and the late Jerome M. Moshen of Matawan, N.J. Rabbi Nadia Gold officiated at Naninas in the Park, an event space in Belleville, N.J.

title: Jodie Valade, Nate Ryan
description: Jodie Valade, the daughter of Delia Valade and Ronald J. Valade of Rochester Hills, Mich., was married Saturday to Nate Ryan, the son of Susan E. Ryan of Naperville, Ill. and the late John J. Ryan. Doug Lesmerises, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Hale Farm and Village meetinghouse in Bath, Ohio.

title: Erum Jilani, Gregory Whitten
description: Erum Rubina Jilani and Gregory Hartley Whitten were married Friday evening at the Biltmore Ballrooms, an event space in Atlanta. Imam M. Jamal Daudi performed a Muslim ceremony.

title: Brittany Jesser, Peter Bellard
description: Brittany Hayes Jesser and Peter Christopher Bellard were married Saturday at Christ Our Savior Parish in Manchester, Vt. The Rev. James Holden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jenna McCann and Gil Messer
description: Jenna Elizabeth McCann, the daughter of Katherine I. McCann and Christopher G. McCann of Matinecock, N.Y., was married on Block Island Saturday to James Gilchrist Messer, the son of Betsy W. Messer and Jakob Messer III of Danville, Va. The Rev. Julia W. Messer, an Episcopal priest and the grooms sister, performed the ceremony during a Mass led by the Rev. James T. Ferry, a Roman Catholic priest and the brides great-uncle, at St. Andrews Catholic Church in New Shoreham, R.I.

title: Katharine Modisett, Kevin Lander
description: Dr. Katharine Lyons Modisett and Kevin Wesley Lander were married Saturday at St. Columbas Chapel in Middletown, R.I. The Rev. Erik W. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Parisa Haghshenas, Steven Seitz
description: Parisa Haghshenas, a daughter of Sima Rafizadeh and Mehdi Haghshenas, both of Durham, N.C., was married there Saturday to Steven Erik Seitz, a son of Cindy J. Seitz and Robert E. Seitz of York, Pa. Joseph W. Marion, a minister of the American Fellowship Church, officiated at the Washington Duke Inn. Earlier in the day, Jalil K. Shirazi, a cousin of the bride, led a Persian cultural ceremony at the hotel.

title: Andrea Mauro, Evan Gotlob
description: Andrea Marie Mauro and Evan Joshua Gotlob were married Saturday evening at Rosecliff in Newport, R.I. Judge Robert E. Hardman, of the Rhode Island workers compensation court in Providence, officiated.

title: Nicole Ruffini, Jordan Liss
description: Nicole Alexa Ruffini, a daughter of Amy C. Ruffini and Dr. Robert A. Ruffini of Livingston, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Jordan Lawrence Liss, a son of Elise N. Liss and Andrew R. Liss of Livingston. Rabbi Eliot Baskin, an uncle of the groom, officiated at the Four Seasons Resort in Vail, Colo.

title: Whitney Eulich, Matthew Walter
description: Whitney Anne Eulich and Matthew Brian Walter were married Saturday. The Rev. Dr. Robert E. de Wetter, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Coldstream Trout Lodge in Woody Creek, Colo.

title: Cate Candland, Craig Clancy
description: Cate Eva Candland and Craig Ford Clancy were married Saturday at the St. Regis Resort in Park City, Utah. Kamrin Carver, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Kristel Adler, John Cote
description: Kristel Erika Adler, the daughter of Patricia E. Adler and Max David Adler of Shiloh, Ill., was married Saturday to John David Cote, the son of Linda M. Cote of New York and David M. Cote of Summit, N.J. Jesse I. Rosenthal, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Peabody Opera House in St. Louis.

title: Katherine Gribble, William Motley
description: Katherine Diane Gribble and William Washburn Motley were married Saturday evening at the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America in Philadelphia under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute.

title: A Connection Before the Connection
description: Bobbi Janelle Thomason and Matthew Harry Magenheim were married Wednesday morning at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an employee of the New York City Clerks Office, officiated. On Saturday evening, Robert O. Jones, affiliated with the International Churches of Christ, officiated at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York.

title: Anne Butler, Michael Duncan
description: Anne Summers Butler and Michael Patrick Duncan were married Saturday evening by the Rev. William L. George, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart in Princeton, N.J.

title: Whitney Fogle, Chequan Lewis
description: Whitney Patrice Fogle and Chequan Aldorez Lewis were married Saturday. The Rev. Bryan L. Carter, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Marty Leonard Community Chapel in Fort Worth.

title: Hayley Phelan, Christopher Black
description: Hayley Honor Phelan and Christopher Ryan Black were married Saturday at the Bowery Hotel in New York. The Rev. Katherine Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister ordained by the New Seminary, officiated.

title: Rebecca Gridley, Derek Wikstrom
description: Rebecca Eleanor Cotton Gridley and Derek Saland Wikstrom were married Friday in Brooklyn. Helen K. Rosenthal, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion and is a city councilwoman from the Upper West Side of Manhattan, officiated at the Brooklyn Winery.

title: Elizabeth Fleming, Ryan OConnor
description: Elizabeth Wells Fleming and Ryan Patrick OConnor were married Saturday at Christ Church Greenwich in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Jessica Paindiris, Anderson Libert
description: Jessica Nicole Paindiris, the daughter of Lynne K. Heston and Nicholas Paindiris of Glastonbury, Conn., was married Saturday to Anderson Brown Libert, the son of Martha D. Brown and Jeffrey A. Libert of Cambridge, Mass. William Harper, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Yale Club of New York, with the Rev. Dr. George Zugravu, a Greek Orthodox priest, taking part.

title: Katherine Gensheimer, David Friedman
description: Katherine Mary Gensheimer and David Garrett Friedman were married Saturday at their country house in Fayston, Vt. Rabbi Michael S. Friedman, the grooms brother, led the ceremony.

title: Sari Schneidman, Jordan Rosenblum
description: Sari Melissa Schneidman and Jordan Maxwell Rosenblum were married Saturday evening, by Rabbi David Levy at Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Krista Caiazza, Shawn Hoffman
description: Krista Andrea Caiazza and Shawn Hoffman were married Friday evening at the Bryant Park Grill in New York. Jason A. Grauer III, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Laurie Campanella, Patrick Crockett Jr.
description: Laurie Anne Campanella and Patrick John Crockett Jr. were married Friday at Good Shepherd Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Jim Cunningham, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Valentine Lysikatos, Erich Carey
description: Valentine Michael Lysikatos and Erich Collins Carey are to be married Sunday evening by the Rev. Michael Kolias at Holy Apostles Greek Orthodox Church in Tolo, Greece. On Sept. 27, the Rev. Peter DeSanctis, a Roman Catholic priest, is to lead a blessing ceremony for the couple at Our Lady of the Isle Church on Shelter Island in New York.

title: Kimberly Ong and Ian Marcus Amelkin
description: Kimberly Wan-Peng Ong, the daughter of Donna B. Ng and Dr. Kenneth R. Ong of Douglaston, Queens, was married Saturday to Ian Howard Marcus Amelkin, the son of Donna S. Amelkin of Parkland, Fla., and the stepson of the late Dean M. Amelkin.

title: Pauline Yu, John Charles
description: Pauline Jennifer Yu and John Russell Charles were married Saturday in St. Johnsbury, Vt. Stephen E. Laurie, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Alerin Barn, an events space.

title: Alexandra Miller, Michael Blank
description: Dr. Alexandra Michelle Miller and Michael Adam Blank were married Saturday at Grasmere Farm in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Rabbi Renee Feller officiated.

title: Teresa Walker and Diallo Williams
description: Teresa Heather Walker and Diallo Noel Williams were married Saturday evening at the Green Building, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Joi R. Orr, a minister of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, officiated.

title: Safe in Each Others Company
description: Gabriella Pamela Hoehn-Saric, a daughter of Pamela Feitler Hoehn-Saric and R. Christopher Hoehn-Saric of Gibson Island, Md., was married at her parents house Saturday to Colin Lynam Goddard, the son of Anne L. Goddard and Andrew L. Goddard of Richmond, Va. Lance Orchid, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Wrights Struggles Continue as Dodgers Top Mets
description: LOS ANGELES  When David Wright stepped into the batters box Saturday night with two out in the ninth inning, it almost did not matter what the Los Angeles Dodgers closer Kenley Jansen was going to throw.

title: Corrections: August 24, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: China Says 8 Executed in Western Region; Charges Stem From Separatist Attacks
description: HONG KONG  The authorities in Xinjiang, the ethnically divided region in far western China, said on Saturday that eight people had been executed on charges related to separatist violence, including an attack last year in which a car plowed through tourists near Tiananmen Square in Beijing and erupted in flames.

title: 1889: Sarah Bernhardts Courage in Real Death Scene
description: Sarah Bernhardt, who has so wonderfully impersonated death in all its phases, has just had a painful experience of its dread reality on the occasion of the funeral of her husband, M. Damala. A report was spread by the Rappel to the effect that when the body was carried down to the ground floor of the house, the coffin was found to be too small, and it took an hour to make it large enough. During this operation, said the report, the body was placed in an armchair, and Mme. Bernhardt had the courage to support the head on her shoulder the whole time. The sight was blood curdling, and created a sad impression on those present.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 25, 1889

title: Hackers Target Video Games for Fun, Profit and Better Scores
description: Hackers are breaking into American companies for credit card numbers, passwords, trade secrets and  it turns out  for phony video game scores.

title: Losses From California Quake Could Top $1 Billion
description: NAPA, Calif.  Early Sunday morning, Franz Oehlers house blew apart.

title: In a Stepfamily, Whose Fairness Wins Out?
description: Years ago, when Bob (now my husband) and I were cohabiting but not yet married, we started taking our children to Florida over April vacation to take advantage of my mothers unused timeshare week. My daughter, Katy, was around 7 at the time, and Bobs two youngest girls, Whit and Hilly, were teenagers. The layout of our condo featured, on the beach side, a spacious master suite with a king-size bed and a balcony. Its distinct Yin, at the other end of the unit, was a rayless chamber with twin beds and a view of the parking lot. Per my advance request, the housekeeping crew had stuffed a rollaway bed into the room before we arrived. The three girls were squeezed together like industrially farmed piglets.

title: In Eastern Ukraine, Rebel Mockery Amid Independence Celebration
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  On a day when Ukrainians celebrated their independence from the Soviet Union with parades and speeches, pro-Russia separatists in the eastern part of the country staged a grim counter-spectacle: a parade that mocked the national army and celebrated the deaths and imprisonment of its soldiers.

title: Children Need Free Play, but Are Unschoolers Giving Them Too Much?
description: With the school day and school year increasing, homework loads growing and ballet, soccer and Mandarin taking over the rest of their time, children today have very little opportunity to simply  play.

title: New Hampshire Town Honors James Foley
description: ROCHESTER, N.H.  Residents of this quiet city came together Sunday to remember James Foley, the New Hampshire native and freelance journalist who was killed last week by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Katie Ledecky Sets World Record in 1,500-Meter Freestyle
description: SOUTHPORT, Australia  Michael Phelps was part of a group of American swimmers lingering over lunch at the teams hotel and savoring Katie Ledeckys swims at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships as if they were so many local Lamington spongecakes.

title: Strife in Libya Could Presage Long Civil War
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The fire is inside the airport! a militiaman cried, as he fired an antiaircraft cannon on the back of a pickup truck toward the runway of Libyas main international airport. God is great, the flames are rising!

title: Michael Browns Body
description: For at least four hours after he was shot by a police officer, the body of Michael Brown lay in the middle of Canfield Drive. What happened in those hours set the stage for two weeks of unrest.

title: Ukraine Leader, Set to Meet Putin for Talks, Warns of Long Struggle
description: KIEV, Ukraine  With a parade of troops, armored vehicles and missile launchers through the center of its capital, Ukraine celebrated its national day of independence on Sunday with a surge of martial fervor as it prepared for peace talks with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

title: 1964: Paris Celebrates 20th Anniversary of the Liberation
description: PARIS  Why are the bells ringing, Herr General? a young German secretary asked Dietrich von Choltitz, commander of German forces in Paris, 20 years ago tonight. Turning to his guest at the final dinner of the German headquarters staff in the Htel Meurice, on the Rue de Rivoli, Gen. Choltitz replied: They are tolling for us. They are announcing the arrival of the enemy armies in Paris. Led by the 13-ton bell of Notre Dame Cathedral, church bells in Paris resounded again in unison tonight as they did on Aug. 24, 1944, after four years of silence under the German occupation. In the continuing ceremonies marking the anniversary of the liberation, Parisians again gathered tonight on the Place de la Concorde. The program included a giant fireworks display. Two orchestras provided music for dancing until dawn. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 25, 1964

title: With Tears, If I Stay Leads New Releases
description: The summer moviegoing season blubbered its way toward an end over the weekend, as If I Stay, a tear-jerker starring Chlo Grace Moretz, took in an estimated $16.4 million at North American theaters. That total made If I Stay (Warner Bros.) the best-performing new wide-release film, but Hollywood expected ticket sales to be significantly stronger given the generosity of Warners marketing campaign. If I Stay, based on Gayle Formans young adult novel, cost Warner and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer about $11 million to make.

title: 5 People, Including 3 Children, Are Killed in Long Island Crash
description: The coming school year promised big things from each of Myriam Lebruns three children: a first high school basketball season for Marcus Jeanty, 14, who towered over classmates; a thickening portfolio of cartoon drawings for his 9-year old brother and loyal follower, Marcel Jeanty; and a next chapter in the fledgling modeling career of the ever-glamorous Kayla Jeanty, 8.

title: Iran Says It Shot Down an Israeli Drone
description: TEHRAN  Irans Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps said Sunday that it had shot down an Israeli drone as it was heading toward the Iranian nuclear enrichment site in Natanz, local news media reported.

title: Roche to Buy InterMune for $8.3 Billion
description: The Swiss drug maker Roche agreed on Sunday to buy InterMune  which sells a drug to treat a deadly lung disease  for $8.3 billion, as pharmaceutical companies continue to seek new products to bolster their offerings.

title: Britain Said to Be Close to Identifying ISIS Suspect in Journalists Beheading
description: The British ambassador to the United States said on Sunday that investigators were close to identifying the young militant with a British accent who beheaded the American journalist James Foley on a video released last week by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Chappelle Returns to Hartford (All Is Forgiven)
description: HARTFORD  One year after he bombed in one of the most notoriously disastrous stand-up sets in memory, Dave Chappelle made a surprise return here  and no one seemed more surprised than he.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 4:30 P.M. (Starz) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Woody Allens film about a Manhattan socialite brought low is his most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since Match Point, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. The socialite is Jasmine (Cate Blanchett, whose performance won her an Oscar for best actress), an Upper East Sider whose husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), had been sent to prison for financial crimes. Jasmine, suddenly penniless, seeks shelter and comfort with her sister (Sally Hawkins, above center, flanked by Ms. Blanchett and Andrew Dice Clay) in San Francisco. Slowly, in flashbacks, Mr. Allen reveals why Hal went to prison, what happened to him and whos been most victimized. The more you learn about the people on screen, the worse you feel for them.

title: How to Stop Time
description: Lucy Hilmer has spent 40 years photographing herself every year on her birthday. Her Birthday Suits photographs show Ms. Hilmer, usually out of doors, wearing only high-waisted white underpants, a pair of hiking boots and some tube socks.

title: Quake Rattles San Francisco Bay Area
description: A magnitude-6.0 earthquake early Sunday damaged buildings, knocked out power and injured dozens of people.

title: U.S. Open 2014 Preview: Final Major Could Settle Wide-Open Season
description: In a tennis season in which no player has taken the reins for long, the United States Open just might clear up the confusion about the chain of command.

title: U.S. Writer Held by Qaeda Affiliate in Syria Is Freed After Nearly 2 Years
description: Held for nearly two years in a prison run by an affiliate of Al Qaeda in Syria, an American freelance writer was unexpectedly freed on Sunday, following extensive mediation by Qatar, the tiny Gulf emirate and United States ally that has successfully negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages in exchange for multimillion-dollar ransoms.

title: The Death of the One-Handed Backhand
description: Back in January, when Stan Wawrinka won the Australian Open, it was the first time in more than four years that someone not named Federer, Nadal, Djokovic or Murray captured a grand-slam championship. This was heartening for tennis fans, who have grown tired of watching the so-called Big Four dominate the sport for the last decade. But for a small and perhaps dwindling set of tennis aesthetes, it was noteworthy for a less obvious reason. Wawrinka, a 29-year-old Swiss player, uses one of the prettiest strokes in tennis: a singular display of agility, balance and precision timing known as the one-handed backhand. It is far superior for slice, or underspin; it is also much better for drop shots and volleys and for retrieving difficult-to-reach balls. Good players can conjure exquisite angles with it.

title: Suge Knight, Hip-Hop Record Executive, Is Shot at a Nightclub Party
description: LOS ANGELES  A billboard advertising Chris Browns next album overlooks the east side of the 1Oak nightclub on Sunset Boulevard here, where a party Mr. Brown helped host on Saturday night went from star-studded revelry to chaos to crime scene in less than 24 hours.

title: Methane Is Discovered Seeping From Seafloor Off East Coast, Scientists Say
description: Scientists have discovered methane gas bubbling from the seafloor in an unexpected place: off the East Coast of the United States where the continental shelf meets the deeper Atlantic Ocean.

title: Bronx Caregiver Is Charged With Manslaughter in the Death of a Toddler
description: After months of uncertainty, life seemed to be settling into a rhythm for Carlyle Williamson and his 19-month-old son, Cardell. Mr. Williamson had gained custody of the boy after a long legal battle, found a landscaping job after a lengthy search and begun dropping Cardell off every day at 6 a.m. with a licensed child care worker who lived on his block in the Mount Eden section of the Bronx.

title: Strokes of Genius: The Best of the Men
description: Determining the best players in tennis seems a straightforward matter of consulting the rankings and the tournament results. Determining the best strokes in tennis remains a more subjective affair even with the recent growth in statistics and analytics. More than two dozen leading coaches, players and analysts were asked to list at least three top men and women in each category. Extra weight was given to those with firsthand experience. For example, Ivo Karlovic, one of the worlds best servers, seems particularly well qualified to determine top returners. The men who have hoarded Grand Slam titles over the past decade dominated these rankings, and though this is far from Serena Williamss finest season, she made a strong showing in many categories.

title: A Makeover for Vogues Website, With a Faster Pace for Covering News
description: For more than 120 years, Vogue magazine has tried to present a rarefied world, filled each month with striking people and high fashion spread across several hundred glossy pages.

title: Performances Ponder Future of Scotland
description: EDINBURGH  Among the weighty issues that remain unclear if the Scots vote for independence from Britain next month, and that are faced head-on in the unapologetic show Nows The Hour at the 2014 Edinburgh Festival Fringe: Will Scotland run out of Earl Grey tea, and might a future trade embargo cause a dearth of it for years to come?

The men who have hoarded Grand Slam titles over the past decade dominated these rankings, and though this is far from Serena Williamss finest season, she made a strong showing in many categories.

title: These Hand-Me-Downs Still Shine Like New
description: The proposition that jazz is a continuum, with elders passing down knowledge, guildlike, to their successors, can be found almost anywhere the music manages to thrive. But it finds a special traction at the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem, where the audience comes with judicious expectations, implicitly on guard against posturing or pandering  but eager to be reached and to respond in turn.

title: At the U.S. Open, They Know the Ins and Outs
description: Line umpires are charged with a fairly simple task: to sit or stand around the perimeter of the court and monitor one specific line, calling the ball out if it lands beyond that line.

title: McCanns Dramatic Homer Is Welcome Sight for Yankees
description: Just before Brian McCann left the dugout for the on-deck circle in the 10th inning, he handed Brett Gardner his sleek red-and-white sunglasses. For good luck, Gardner promptly put them on and watched perhaps the best moment of the Yankees season through McCanns lenses.

title: Exorcising Ghosts From Classrooms
description: When it comes to books on public education, we crave a diet of meat as red as a teachers cruel pen. In case you plan to write one, heres a brief primer: 1) Pick a contentious and complex topic, like charter schools, teacher evaluations or standardized testing. 2) Reduce that issue to a Manichaean battle for the soul of the American student, presenting your side as inarguably salvific. 3) Fire off some frightening statistics about Finland or South Korea. 4) Ignore evidence that might dampen your zeal; just remember, above all, that nothing sells books like outrage.

title: Youngsters Play at World Youth Teams Championships
description: ISTANBUL  The 15th World Youth Teams Championships concluded here on Saturday afternoon with two sessions of 14 boards each.

title: A Master of Many Universes
description: If you traveled to a small parish outside the coastal town of Clonakilty, Ireland, and asked one of the local people to introduce you to the resident writer, youd invariably be led to David Mitchell.

title: A Jolt in Northern California
description: A magnitude-6.0 earthquake early Sunday morning sent residents fleeing from their homes and knocked out power in Northern California.

title: Beijing Film Festival Is Shuttered Again
description: The 11th edition of an independent film festival set to begin on Saturday in Beijing was shuttered before the cinema doors were even open. The Chinese authorities confiscated documents and films and briefly detained organizers of the Beijing Independent Film Festival, The Associated Press reported. The festival has faced numerous hurdles over the years, including a power failure in 2012 that organizers attributed to the government. This year, however, was different, Wang Hongwei, the festivals artistic director, told The A.P. In the past few years, when they forced us to cancel the festival, we just moved it to other places, or delayed the screenings, he said. But this year, we cannot carry on with the festival. It is completely forbidden. Mr. Wang and Li Xianting, the founder of the festivals organizing group, were arrested on Saturday night but later released.

title: Martha Graham Dance Announces Season
description: Architectural influences will provide the framework of the Martha Graham Dance Companys 2014-15 season, organizers announced on Sunday. Titled Shape&Design, the companys two-week season at the Joyce Theater (Feb. 10-22) will explore the structural aspects of works by Graham and others. Highlights include new commissions by Kyle Abraham, Michelle Dorrance, Liz Gerring and Sonya Tayeh. In honor of the 85th anniversary of Grahams Lamentation, each choreographer will contribute a work for Lamentation Variations, a series that began in 2007 and features pieces inspired by Grahams signature solo. The season also plans to feature works exemplifying Grahams collaborations with the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. In addition to the Joyce season and a 20-city tour, the troupe is scheduling performances at various New York locations throughout the fall and winter. The Graham Deconstructed series, which takes audiences behind the scenes, begins with Peter Sparlings look at the 1953 piece Voyage (Sept. 16 and 17), followed by a company performance of Appalachian Spring (Oct. 30) to celebrate the 70th anniversary of its premiere; both will be at the Martha Graham Studio Theater in the West Village. The Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology will host a performance on Oct. 28 in conjunction with its Dance and Fashion exhibition, which includes several Graham Company costumes. And from Dec. 10 through 13, Hauser & Wirth will host the dancers as part of that Chelsea gallerys Thomas Houseago exhibition. More information is at marthagraham.org.

Hed just graduated from high school, but this night was the real cause for celebration  a concert hed been planning for months. He called it Raurfest.

title: Indias Pain Is One Womans Mission
description: Clearly, the Bollywood queen Rani Mukerji has had it with crimes against girls and women in India. In No One Killed Jessica (2011), based on a true-life miscarriage of justice, she played a television reporter hunting a man who killed a beautiful bartender. The son of a former government official, he is almost immune to prosecution.

title: Courting Young Ears Abroad
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  For a critic already stretching his travel budget (ever thus), it was hard to know just when to leave the monthlong Lucerne Festival, with its tight-knit web of overlapping themes, programs and series. Friday was perhaps as good an exit as any, with the festival rounding into its second weekend and offering a rich cross-section of its varied and often innovative activities.

title: The Dog Ate My Homework
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  When you sit down to solve a  oops, SORRY, was that someones foot? As I was saying, a crossword puzzle is  ouch! My head! Who put that grid there? Me? Whoops, MY BAD. Maybe I should just sit down and not move while were talking about Greg Johnsons third time out in The New York Times.

title: Whats Really Wrong With Rikers
description: A RECENT investigation by the Department of Justice concluded that a culture of violence permeated the jails on Rikers Island in New York City, particularly the facilities housing adolescent detainees. The report came just a few weeks after this newspaper published its own investigation into violence against mentally ill patients at the jails.

title: Its Edge Intact, Vice Is Chasing Hard News
description: In early 2010, I wrote a column about Vice in which Shane Smith, one of the founders, suggested that he and his band of insurgents were building the next MTV. And then there was a promise to become the next CNN  outrageous claims at the time, but they are becoming truer every passing day.

title: Facing Ire, Mark Driscoll Says He Will Take a Leave
description: Mark Driscoll, the conservative evangelical leader, said Sunday that he would take a leave from running his megachurch in response to a parade of complaints that he has been a bully and abusive to staff members.

title: Saving Scraps From the Past Amid New Havens Revitalization
description: NEW HAVEN  Robert S. Greenberg has been prying this citys secrets from its soil since he was a boy digging up coins at the beach. He divines information about its former denizens from the color of the dirt, and from the litter he finds, layers beneath the surface, from almost four centuries ago, when the British first settled here.

title: Bearing Down on Data Upstarts
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Nothing concentrates minds at a tech start-up like living in the middle of a price war between Amazon and Google.

title: What Does It Mean to Throw Like a Girl?
description: Mone Davis, the 13-year-old pitcher for the Taney Dragons from Pennsylvania, has been the sensation of the Little League World Series. A 70-mile-per-hour fastball, impeccable control, back-to-back shutouts, shes been on the cover of Sports Illustrated and has been interviewed by nearly every major television network. Though the Taney teams run was ended by an exciting game against Chicago  the most-watched Little League game in ESPN history  Mones achievement is impressive by any standard. But why is it that her gender is the anomaly that makes her talent mediaworthy?

title: Hopes Heal Faster Than Quarterback
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Overlooking the bustle of Olentangy River Road, on the outskirts of Ohio States sprawling campus, an electronic billboard burns bright with the words Get Better No. 5.

title: Teenager Cites Ordeal as Captive of Israelis
description: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip  A Palestinian teenager says that Israeli soldiers detained him for five days last month, forcing him to sleep blindfolded and handcuffed in his underwear and to search and dig for tunnels in Khuzaa, his village near Gazas eastern border, which was all but destroyed in the fighting.

title: Treating Depression to Prevent Suicide
New Thinking About Ebola Treatments
description: A radical but promising proposal to help treat victims of the Ebola epidemic in West Africa appears to be gaining support among knowledgeable experts.

title: Fishermen Cross an Imperceptible Line Into Enemy Waters
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Fishermen bustled through a ramshackle harbor, a knot of narrow streets and one-room houses on the edge of Karachi, as they prepared to set out to sea for the summer fishing season. But one man was going nowhere. As other fishermen mended their nets in a field, Abdul Shakoor hunched outside his front door, weaving a rug.

title: An August Classic Propels a Surge Toward October
description: In six weeks or so, if the Yankees play a game the way they did on Sunday, it will immediately become part of franchise lore.

title: Emmys Live Broadcast Gets a Chance to Shine
description: FOR many years, advertisers have been less keen on the Emmy Awards than awards shows like the Oscars, Grammys and Golden Globes, evincing an attitude that was more Em-meh than enthusiastic because the Emmys draw lower ratings. However, as Madison Avenue becomes increasingly interested in so-called event television  big events that viewers watch live  the 2014 Primetime Emmy Awards show, to be broadcast on Monday night by NBC, is getting a You like me, you really like me moment.

title: With a Future in Question, a Showing Beyond Doubt
description: LOS ANGELES  In another trying season, it is not often that a baseball game unfolds as seamlessly as it did for the Mets on Sunday.

description: As the country struggles to combat the growing abuse of heroin and opioid painkillers, a new battlefield is emerging: the courts.

title: Israel Says Missile Strike Killed Hamas Official Handling Terror Funds
description: GAZA CITY  An Israeli missile strike that killed a man riding in a car in Gaza City on Sunday afternoon ripped open the vehicle, revealing bags of American dollars inside and scattering currency on the street, some burned by the blast, according to a witness.

title: NBC News President Rouses the Network
description: In her first year as president of NBC News, Deborah Turness received one message loud and clear: Welcome to the feeding frenzy.

title: Weary of Pro Tennis Delays? Cry Into the Towel
description: When the United States Open begins Monday, the best tennis players in the world will unleash overpowering serves, crackling forehands and paralyzing returns. Then they will retreat behind the baseline and use a no-less-visible weapon of choice: a 100 percent cotton official tournament towel.

title: Central Bankers New Gospel: Spur Jobs, Wages and Inflation
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  The last time the economic policy conference held here every August devoted its agenda to labor markets, it was 1994 and the Federal Reserves vice chairman scandalized the audience by suggesting central banks worried too much about reducing inflation and not enough about unemployment.

title: Britain Appeals to Anti-Extremist Imams in Effort to Uproot Seeds of Radicalization
description: COVENTRY, England  The beheading of American journalist James Foley, apparently by a British jihadist, has drawn renewed attention to the dangers posed by radicalized young British Muslims.

title: ISIS Tightens Its Grip With Seizure of Air Base in Syria
description: BAGHDAD  Extremist fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria seized a military base in northern Syria on Sunday from forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, further solidifying control inside their self-declared Islamic state spanning the Syria-Iraq border.

title: Ronald Johnsons Steady Voice Makes Itself Heard Above the Shouting
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  It will be hot in St. Louis on Monday morning, as temperatures approach 100 degrees and multitudes flock to a church on Dr. Martin Luther King Drive for the funeral of a young black man whose shooting death by a white police officer ignited unrest and renewed a familiar national conversation. There will be grieving relatives, resolute citizens, solemn politicians, several celebrities, and even emissaries from the White House.

title: South Korea Secures Title in Return to Little League World Series
description: SOUTH WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.  It was difficult to tell who had more fun Sunday at the championship game of the Little League World Series, South Koreas players or its supporters.

description: In little more than 24 hours this weekend, the Rev. Al Sharpton led a march on Staten Island to protest the death of a black man in police custody, went to Washington to appear on Meet the Press and flew to Ferguson, Mo., where on Monday he is to eulogize the 18-year-old black man whose fatal shooting by the police set off days of unrest.

title: Rugby Outsiders Try to Find a Foothold
description: LONDON  At first glance, the London Broncos postgame locker room last Sunday was the same as in any other week. Crumpled tape under the benches. Plastic cups strewn about. That unmistakable odor of sweat mixed with desperation (as well as a fair bit of antiseptic cream).
