title: Medicare Star Ratings Allow Nursing Homes to Game the System
description: CARMICHAEL, Calif.  The lobby of Rosewood Post-Acute Rehab, a nursing home in this Sacramento suburb, bears all the touches of a luxury hotel, including high ceilings, leather club chairs and paintings of bucolic landscapes.

title: At Barclays, Two Surprise Guests, One of Them Tiny, Greet Hunter Mahan
description: PARAMUS, N.J.  When he dropped his arms after sinking his eight-foot putt on the 18th hole, the look was one more of relief than of exhilaration for Hunter Mahan. He had made an adventure out of the final hole at Ridgewood Country Club on Sunday, hitting into the woods, then finding the rough before finishing with a bogey.

title: Michael Brown Spent Last Weeks Grappling With Problems and Promise
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  It was 1 a.m. and Michael Brown Jr. called his father, his voice trembling. He had seen something overpowering. In the thick gray clouds that lingered from a passing storm this past June, he made out an angel. And he saw Satan chasing the angel and the angel running into the face of God. Mr. Brown was a prankster, so his father and stepmother chuckled at first.

description: The George Washington Bridge Bus Station in Upper Manhattan will be shut down for one year, starting Monday morning, as part of its biggest renovation project in five decades.

On the early afternoon of Feb. 28, 2013, Officer Darren Wilson answered a police call of a suspicious vehicle where, the police said, the occupants might have been making a drug transaction. After a struggle, Officer Wilson subdued the suspect and grabbed his car keys before help arrived, the police said.

title: Soho Rep Plans Varied Productions
description: Soho Rep will take audiences from a South African kitchen to a Brooklyn laundromat in its 2014-15 season, the theater is to announce on Monday. The season will open with the United States premiere of Debbie Tucker Greens Generations (Sept. 30-Oct. 26), a coproduction with the Play Company that centers on three generations of a South African family preparing a meal. The play will reunite Ms. Tucker and Leah C. Gardiner, the writing-directing team behind the Obie-winning 2011 production of Born Bad. The new year will begin with Winners and Losers (Jan. 2-Feb. 1), directed by Chris Abraham. The work is about two friends  portrayed by the plays creators Marcus Youssef and James Long  who are forced to take a frank look at their lives through a made-up game. In May, Soho Rep will welcome the world premiere of Anne Washburns 10 Out of 12. Directed by Les Waters, the production is about making a play and about how work shapes us. The season will wrap up with Washeteria, taking place in an unused storefront in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Created by Louisa Thompson, with Sarah Benson and Adrienne Kapstein, the play is a compilation of episodes created by cast members and a team of second-graders, with each story lasting about the length of a wash cycle. More information is at sohorep.org.

title: Word of the Day | lugubrious
description: lugubrious \lu-g-bre-s also -gy-\ adjective

title: Healing Teenage Cancers Scars
description: The teenage years can be tough enough under the best of circumstances. But when cancer invades an adolescents life, the challenges grow exponentially.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 6:15 P.M. (Showtime 2) MAD HOT BALLROOM (2005) This documentary, filmed in three New York City schools, finds fifth-graders of various backgrounds and ethnicities training for and participating in a ballroom dancing competition. The director, Marilyn Agrelo, sheds a little light on the citys class differences without making a big deal about them. The young sophisticates of TriBeCa seem not only materially better off than their counterparts uptown or in Brooklyn, but also confident of their superiority, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. In spite of their teachers concerns about foisting too much competition on them, they expect to win. The children of Washington Heights, on the other hand  or at least their passionate, dynamic teacher  feel as if they need to win. (Above, the students Wilson and Jatnna.)

title: VMAs 2014: Miley Cyrus Causes a Stir Again, This Time by Staying in Her Seat
description: LOS ANGELES  A year after bringing debauched dance moves and wild tongue gyrations to MTVs Video Music Awards, Miley Cyrus returned to the live show on Sunday night and stirred up trouble without ever taking the stage.

title: A Series Draws to a Close, and Innocence May Soon Follow
description: SOUTH WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.  I felt a twinge of sadness Sunday as Chicagos last-gasp rally fell short and South Koreas players celebrated their Little League World Series victory by piling on one another at the pitchers mound.

title: DraftKings, a Fantasy Sports Site, Raises $41 Million
description: Fantasy sports are becoming big business. At least investors in DraftKings, an online hub for armchair general managers, seem to think so.

title: Pops Newborns Dominate Video Music Awards Ceremony
description: There are parents, and there are children, and never do they seem more like foreigners to each other than at the MTV Video Music Awards.

title: Corrections: August 25, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Student Crossword | Botany
description: Test your knowledge of botany by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Stampede at Indian Temple Kills at Least 10
description: NEW DELHI  At least 10 people were killed in a stampede at a Hindu temple in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh on Monday morning during a pilgrimage for a festival celebrating the new moon, according to a police official in the state.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Earthquake Rocks Northern California
description: In State of Emergency Declared After California Earthquake, Quentin Hardy and Ian Lovett report on the aftermath and clean-up following Sundays earthquake.

title: Beyond the Dust Bowl With Dorothea Lange
description: Dyanna Taylor had to look no farther than her own family to make a compelling film. After all, her grandmothers photograph of Florence Thompson is seared into the American psyche as Migrant Mother, the Dust Bowl madonna enshrined by Dorothea Lange.

title: China Touts Itself as Winner in High-Speed Rail Stakes
description: High-speed rail has brought many benefits to China, and now one more can be added to that list: a handy point to lord over the United States.

title: Should We Be Seeing Gruesome Acts? And If So, Where?
description: The brutal killing of the American journalist James Foley by ISIS militants in Syria became a modern guillotine execution spectacle, with YouTube as the town square. The video of Mr. Foleys beheading was posted online by the executioners, incitingnot only outrage at the killing itself but also a discussion about censorship, propaganda and Western hypocrisy.

title: Test Yourself | A Dance Critic on Taylor Swifts Shake It Off Video
description: Below are the six paragraphs that comprise the Aug. 19 article Taylor Swifts Shake It Off Video: A Dance Critics Take.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: Chinas Eye in the Sky Zooms In on Illicit Activity
description: The biggest tracts of cannabis to have been detected in China since the founding of the Peoples Republic in 1949 are in the northern provinces of Jilin and Inner Mongolia. Inner Mongolia is also home to extensive fields of illicit opium poppies, as are the provinces of Heilongjiang and Hebei.

title: New York Today: Now Better for Birds
description: Good morning on this sunny Monday.

title: Choking the Oceans With Plastic
description: LOS ANGELES  The world is awash in plastic. Its in our cars and our carpets, we wrap it around the food we eat and virtually every other product we consume; it has become a key lubricant of globalization  but its choking our future in ways that most of us are barely aware.

title: French Cabinet Is Dissolved, a Victim of Austerity Battles
description: PARIS  The collapse of the French government on Monday exposed widening divisions both within Frances leadership, and Europe more broadly, over austerity policies that many now fault for threatening to tip the eurozone back into recession.

title: Daily Report: Online Data-Storage Providers Search for Better Niches
description: Nothing concentrates minds at a tech start-up like living in the middle of a price war between Amazon and Google, Quentin Hardy reports.

title: Dash of Salt Does No Harm. Extremes Are the Enemy.
description: For years, we have known that diets high in salt can be bad for people with high blood pressure. A study published recently in The New England Journal of Medicine confirmed this fact. It monitored more than 100,000 people in 18 countries and found that people who consumed more sodium generally had significantly higher blood pressures than those who did not.

title: Investors Urge Ann Taylor to Explore Sale of Chain
description: Updated | Ann Inc., the parent company of the Ann Taylor stores, is being pressed to explore options, including a sale by the activist investor Engine Capital and the hedge fund Red Alder.

title: What to Wear This Week: Aug. 25
description: Theres something about the Burning Man festival that can spark creativity, from the free spirits frolicking in the desert to the life-size art installations. Traditionally, attendees of the weeklong event heighten what we know as festival style. Theatrical costumes, often handmade, are common, even expected.

title: O.K., So Maybe We Do Need Some Company Policies
description: When I started RJMetrics with my co-founder, Jake Stein, we set out to build a lean, agile company. This was easy in our early days because leanness and agility were about the only things we could afford. When your whole company is two dudes in an attic, shaping culture isnt terribly hard.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: True Blood Recap: Finale Says Farewell to Bad Things
description: Season 7, Episode 10 , Thank You

title: 1939: Roosevelt Sends Peace Appeals
description: WASHINGTON  In an ultimate attempt to use his influence for peace, President Roosevelt addressed peace appeals early this morning [Aug. 25] to Chancellor Adolf Hitler and President Ignace Moscicki of Poland. The messages, which were not identical, suggested three possible methods of arriving at a peaceful solution of the dispute between the two countries: direct negotiation, submission of the dispute to neutral arbitration, agreement to solve the controversy through the procedure of conciliation. The President suggested that the parties select as conciliator or mediator a national of one of the traditionally neutral states of Europe or of the American republics.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 26, 1939

title: Morning Agenda: Burger Kings Deal Talks
description: Burger King said on Sunday that it was in talks to buy Tim Hortons, the Canadian doughnut-and-coffee chain, in a potential deal that would create one of the worlds biggest fast-food chains, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes. Should the deal be completed, it would mean Burger Kings corporate headquarters would move to Canada, raising the prospect of yet another United States company switching its national citizenship to lower its tax bill. The two companies are expected to argue that a merger would bring a host of strategic benefits, but it would nevertheless count as a so-called corporate inversion.

title: Amid Mourning for Michael Brown, Call for Change
description: ST. LOUIS  His gold-and-black coffin was topped by a baseball cap  a palpable, personal reminder of the young man who was fatally shot by a police officer only weeks ago. But the calls from the pulpit were for Michael Browns memory to live on in a broad movement for justice, for voter participation, and for answers to vexing and unending questions about race and policing.

title: Researchers Find Illegal Bear Trade Expanding in Asia
description: The illegal traffic in bears nearly tripled in Asia between 2000 and 2011, according to a study by Traffic, the wildlife trade monitor, of trade data and customs seizures in 17 countries. That increase suggests that the establishment of bear farms, to meet the demand for bile and other bear products, has not shielded wild bears from poaching, the organization said.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 13 in Baghdad as New Leader Calls for Unity
description: BAGHDAD  Shortly after Iraqs new prime minister-designate called for national unity at his first official news conference on Monday, a suicide bomber detonated his explosives inside a Shiite mosque here, killing 13 people and underscoring the great challenges the countrys leaders face in trying to hold the nation together.

title: MTV Video Music Awards vs. the Emmys: The Red Carpet Challenge
description: Theres a certain cosmic justice in the scheduling of the MTV Video Music Awards and the Emmys on back-to-back evenings (Sunday and Monday). For anyone who wants to understand the business that the red carpet has become, it doesnt get any clearer than the difference between the two.

title: Reader Idea | Personal Writing Based on The Timess Sunday Routine Series
description: Welcome to a week of great ideas from our readers about new ways to teach with The Times. Every day this week, well be featuring the work of teachers who have shared their lesson plans and inspirations with us.

title: A Couture Embroidery Class in L.A., a New Brooklyn Beer Hall and More From the Cultural Calendar
description: Ts list of things to see and do in the week ahead.

title: Echoes From 15 Years Ago: Ad-Supported Services, Sluggish Speeds and More
description: On Sunday, Claire Cain Miller transported us back to 1999, when Webvan, Kozmo and a crop of upstarts tried their hand at perfecting delivery service. Webvan is perhaps one of the more memorable names of this era, and it came to symbolize the ethos that anything was possible when you put a few smart people in a room south of San Francisco.

title: Cutting the Corporate Tax Would Make Other Problems Grow
description: The current debate over corporate inversions, in which American companies like Burger King consider renouncing their citizenship for tax-reduction purposes, is only the latest reminder that the United States corporate tax code has deep problems.

title: As Peace Talks Approach, Rebels Humiliate Prisoners in Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  On the sidewalk of a busy street beside a checkpoint, a bearded gunman wrapped a woman in a Ukrainian flag and forced her to stand, sobbing in terror, holding a sign identifying her as a spotter for Ukrainian artillery. She kills our children, it read. Because the woman was a spy, said the gunman, a pro-Russian militant, everything that would happen to her would be well-deserved.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
350 Years Ago, New Amsterdam Became New York. Dont Expect a Party.
description: On Aug. 26, 1664, 350 years ago Tuesday, a flotilla of four British frigates led by the Guinea, which was manned by 150 sailors and conveying 300 redcoats, anchored ominously in Gravesend Bay off Brooklyn, between Coney Island and the Narrows.

title: An Intensifying Presidential Campaign Brings Tension to Brazils Markets
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  As Brazil absorbs the shock over a plane crash that killed a presidential contender this month and upended an increasingly combative race, another source of tumult may emerge as some banks, hedge funds and other big investors raise their bets against the leftist incumbent, President Dilma Rousseff.

title: Calls for Peace Ahead of Michael Browns Funeral Today
description: Michael Browns funeral will begin at 10 a.m Central time this morning, nearly two weeks after the 18-year-old was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo. The funeral is at the Friendly Temple Missionary Baptist Church in St. Louis, and an array of national, community and political leaders are expected to attend. Monica Davey reports that the two lines to get into the funeral are already stretching around a block, and the heat is oppressive. One man is selling T-shirts that say Hands up, dont shoot. Someone else is handing out leaflets about a candidate for a city political position.

title: Cooking Techniques: Making Medallions
description: Pound meat into thin, tender cutlets.

title: Dont Fear the Okra
description: Kim Severson shows you how to shop for okra and make a simple dish without the slime.

title: Cooking Techniques: Poaching an Egg
description: Learn how to poach an egg.

title: Fruit Galette
description: Melissa Clark shows you how to sweeten and thicken any type of fruit for a go-to galette.

title: How the Internet Could Protect Your Memory
description: The Internet is frequently blamed for messing with our minds, making us superficial, distracted and even deluded. But a new study suggests that for some people, using it could actually be healthy.

title: First Day of School
description: The funeral of Michael Brown coincides with the first day back at school for children in Ferguson. As Motoko Rich and Mosi Secret write, the town delayed the start of the academic year because of the protests and violence immediately after the shooting.

title: An Unusual and Inspiring Pinterest, Zac Posens Cooking Hashtag and More
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Cold Tomato Soup with Farro
description: Farros role in this gazpacho of sorts (without the traditional bread thickener), is that of a garnish. It contributes texture and substance to the light summer soup. I spoon about 1/4 cup of the cooked wheat berries into each bowl and also add diced cucumber. The farro sinks, the cucumber floats. When you get to the bottom of the bowl, youll find some lingering grains of farro enrobed in the delicious, tangy soup.

title: How Will You Teach About Ferguson?
description: Update: Sept. 1 | We will publish a lesson about Ferguson on Sept. 3, not Sept. 2 as previously announced. Please let us know below how you will be addressing the topic with your students.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Aug. 19-25, 2014
description: Update: Sept. 1, 2014

title: Iraqs Next Leader on Political Vision
description: Haider al-Abadi, the Iraqi prime minister-designate, predicted a unified government would emerge within the next two days.

title: Teenager Arrested in Killing of Imam in Western China
description: BEIJING  Chinese authorities have arrested an 18-year-old man from a village near the oasis city of Kashgar, in far western China, accusing him of inspiring and planning a fatal attack last month on the imam of the nations biggest mosque, according to state news media reports.

title: Chinese Authorities Block Beijing Film Festival
description: The Chinese authorities prevented one of Chinas most prominent independent film festivals from opening over the weekend, blocking roads, confiscating documents, computers and films, and temporarily detaining two of the events officials.

title: Kingslayer Me
description: OK, this has to be the funniest headline Ive seen for a while, on Business Insider: The French Government Has Collapsed, And Its Partly Paul Krugmans Fault. The French prime minister has tendered his resignation amid a dispute set off by the economy ministers decision to go public with opposition to austerity orthodoxy, and since he cited me on the subject, Business Insider has made a funny.

title: 1964: Buddhists Raze Catholic Village
description: SAIGON  Bloody religious rioting erupted today [Aug. 25] in the coastal city of Da Nang and an entire Roman Catholic community was demolished by a Buddhist mob. At least 19 persons were reported killed and about 70 injured. The community of 3,000 is on the outskirts of Da Nang, which also was devastated by the rioters. Before the rioters swept down on the neighboring village, most of the Roman Catholic residents had been evacuated. Many embarked in sampans into the South China Sea. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 26, 1964

title: Cooking Techniques: Butterflying Meat
description: Butterfly meat before stuffing and tying it, or to give it more surface area for cooking.

title: The Arrival of Michael Browns Family
First Superman Comic Sold for $3.2 Million
description: Talk about faster than a speeding bullet! It took just 48 bids to get from a 99-cent starting price to a final sale of $3,207,852 Sunday for a copy of Action Comics No. 1 that was auctioned on eBay by Pristine Comics of Federal Way, Wash.

title: The S.E.C.s Use of the Rocket Docket Is Challenged
description: There is a nickname litigators use for courts that push cases through the system with great alacrity: the rocket docket. Perhaps the most famous is the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, where complex civil cases will wrap up discovery in a few months and be decided in less than a year.

title: Chopped Herb Salad with Farro
description: Notice that Im calling this dish a chopped herb salad with farro and not a farro salad with chopped herbs. Its modeled on an authentic Middle Eastern tabouli, which should be all about the parsley, with just a small amount of bulgur. I add just one cup of cooked farro or spelt to a generous mix of chopped parsley, mint, arugula and other herbs like basil or dill. There are also chopped tomatoes in the mix, all of it tossed with lemon juice and olive oil.

title: Long-Simmered Eggplant Stuffed with Farro or Spelt
description: This is a riff on imam bayildi, the long-cooking eggplant dish bathed in tomatoes and onions that is one of the great achievements of Turkish cuisine. I added cooked farro to the tomato-onion mix, making this more like a stuffed eggplant dish. The active cooking time is minimal, but the smothered eggplant must simmer for about 1 1/2 hours to achieve the intense, syrupy sauce and deep, rich flavor that make this dish such a wonder. Make it a day ahead for best results, and serve at room temperature on a hot night.

title: Hands Up on the Way In
Peppers Stuffed with Farro and Smoked Cheese
description: I was inspired to make this filling by a delicious stuffed tomato dish I ate recently at Oliveto in Oakland, Calif., in which the tomatoes were stuffed with a smoky barley filling. I used a Dutch smoked goudalike cheese that was labeled, simply smoked cheese. I added paprika to the mix, which contributes to the smoky flavor, and walnuts, because I love the crunchiness with the grains. The cooked farro or spelt should be soft, so make sure to simmer until the grains splay.

title: The Two Cookies Puzzle
description: For this weeks adventure in puzzling we have two very different challenges: one through an enchanted forest, and the other against a playful computer program. The first gets the headline because the second is more game than puzzle. Well start with

title: ScienceTake | The Frog Slap Shot
description: The fearsome Pac-Man frog has a huge mouth and a really sticky tongue.

title: Andre Agassi on Sneaker Maintenance, Neon and the Perils of Pierced Ears
description: Clean-shaven and wearing a crisp white T-shirt and dark jeans, Andre Agassi today bears little resemblance to the mulleted bad boy he once was. Sitting in the back room of the pop-up Nike Court in TriBeCa, the 44-year-old tennis icon is all cool, effortless swagger. It feels full circle, Agassi says of re-signing with Nike in late 2013 after an eight-year hiatus. It feels like Im coming home. Since becoming a brand ambassador for the company, Agassi has brought back his signature sneaker, the Air Tech Challenge, and partnered on the Designed to Move initiative, which seeks to get kids motivated to exercise.

title: A Frog Thats a Living, Breathing Pac-Man
description: The South American horned frog is a sit-and-wait predator. It huddles close to the ground or partly buried, well camouflaged, and waits until a juicy cricket or other prey wanders too close.

title: Yellen, Wages, and Intellectual Honesty
description: Jared Bernstein is a bit puzzled by the piece of Janet Yellens talk at Jackson Hole in which she suggests that some of the weakness in wages may reflect delayed adjustment rather than unemployment. Since her message was basically that the Fed should keep its pedal to the metal for a while yet, why blur the message?

title: Summer Big Bowl with Farro and Ratatouille
description: Ratatouille tastes best the day after you make it, and in the summer, I like to serve it chilled or at room temperature, with a vinaigrette drizzled over the top. Here I turn it into a meal with farro at the base of a summer big bowl. You can top the ratatouille with a poached egg, or simply with crumbled feta or grated Parmesan.

title: Frans Brggen, Pioneer in Early Music, Dies at 79
description: Frans Brggen, a Dutch pioneer of the early music movement, a co-founder and conductor of the influential Orchestra of the 18th Century, and a virtuoso recorder player who in his youth became (literally) a poster boy for the instrument, died on Aug. 13 in Amsterdam. He was 79.

title: MTV Awards Red Carpet
description: Some highlights from the red carpet included Beyoncs beaded gown and Rita Oras barely-there slip dress.

title: Abbas Is Seen as Ready to Seek Pact on His Own
description: JERUSALEM  With no clear resolution in sight to the battle between Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip, President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, who has been largely sidelined as his popularity sank during the conflict, is making a new play to reassert his role and cast himself as the leader of all Palestinians.

title: Remembering the Battle of Brooklyn
Techniques: Cleaning Leeks
description: Wash leeks to get rid of any dirt.

title: Arab Nations Strike in Libya, Surprising U.S.
description: CAIRO  Twice in the last seven days, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates have secretly launched airstrikes against Islamist-allied militias battling for control of Tripoli, Libya, four senior American officials said, in a major escalation of a regional power struggle set off by Arab Spring revolts.

title: The Galette Forgives You
description: A pie is homey. A tart is fancy. And a galette splits the difference, but is easier than either one.

title: Prince to Release 2 New Albums
description: Prince has been unusually busy lately, touring Europe with his band, 3rdeyegirl, starting his own publishing company and negotiating a contract with Warner Brothers, the label that released his earliest albums, in which he gained control of his early master tapes and agreed to return to Warner after an 18-year absence. He has spent some time in the recording studio as well, and released a teaser, Breakdown, in April.

title: Outside, Signs and Summer Heat
description: The National Weather Service in St. Louis forecast afternoon temperatures in the high 90s in St. Louis, and the authorities put out the word that the city would offer some kind of assistance for the crowds expected.

title: Ore-Ida Campaign Focuses on Authenticity of Tater Tots
description: A maker of frozen foods is marking six decades of a popular product with a campaign that takes a humorous tack in asking shoppers to say no to look-alike competitors.

title: Today in Small Business: The Skills Gap
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Signs From Central Bankers Send S.&P. 500 Over 2,000 for First Time
description: Updated | The Standard & Poors 500-stock index rose above 2,000 for the first time on Monday after a meeting of central bankers opened the door to more stimulus measures.

title: Monday Motorsports: Flawless Ricciardo Scores Formula One Win at Spa
description: Driving a flawless Formula One race on Sunday, Daniel Ricciardo became the first Australian to win at the Belgian Spa-Francorchamps track since 1960. Sir Jack Brabham was the last to claim that honor. Nico Rosberg, the pole position winner, came in a frustrated second, and Valttieri Bottas, of Williams, was third.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
Virginias Ex-Governor Pushes Back in Testy Exchange With Prosecutors
description: RICHMOND, Va.  In clipped tones occasionally soaked in indignation, Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia on trial for public corruption, squared off on Monday with federal prosecutors who sought to undermine his contention that he knew little about lavish gifts and did even less in return.

title: Four-Star Disappointments
description: Medicares ratings of nursing homes are based in large part on self-reported data that the government does not verify, The Times reports. Only one of the three criteria used to determine the star ratings relies on assessments from independent reviewers. Read the full story.

title: New York Theater Ballet Sets New Season
description: The New York Theater Ballet spent much of the last year searching for a new home after its longtime office and training space was sold and the company was asked to find new quarters. It found a new home in May when St. Marks Church in-the-Bowery offered its space starting in September. The company has lately been fitting the space with offices, dressing rooms, a sprung floor, mirrors, barres and a lobby, and on Monday it announced that its educational arm, Ballet School NY, would offer an expanded schedule of classes for both adults and children, starting Sept. 15. The company also announced its 2014-15 season, which as in past seasons, has it performing in several spaces around town.

title: Wedding Q.&A.
description: Left Waiting by the Bride and Groom

title: Monique Peans Latest Jewelry Collection
description: Ryan McGinley shot this film on Icelands Vk  Myrdal beach for the jewelry designer Monique Pean. It features the model Liya Kebede.

title: Resist Changing Direction Because of a Single Event
description: I recently went backpacking in the Uinta Mountains. Its a range of gorgeous peaks close to my home in Park City, Utah. A group of friends planned to spend a few days in the backcountry, so we got together to discuss everything wed need for the trip. We had a lot of experience hiking and camping in this area, and we talked about a lot of things. But one subject never came up: bears.

title: Speeches and Reflection at the Funeral
description: The hundreds of the mourners gathered for Michael Browns funeral are now moving outside, accompanied by the choir singing.

title: Modern Research Borne on a Relic
description: Airships are dusty relics of aviation history. Lighter-than-air vehicles conjure images of the Hindenburg, in its glory and destruction, and the Goodyear Blimp, a floating billboard that barely resembles its powerful predecessors.

title: Excerpt: And I and Silence
description: Rachel Nicks and Samantha Soule in a scene from the new Naomi Wallace play at the Signature Theater.

title: Future of Export-Import Bank Is Wild Card in Key Senate Races
description: WASHINGTON  In North Carolina, Senator Kay Hagan, a Democrat, is siding with big business in her support of the Export-Import Bank of the United States and attacking Thom Tillis, her Republican challenger who opposes the bank but is endorsed by big business.

title: Joni Ernst Talks With John Harwood
description: Mr. Harwood interviewed Ms. Ernst, a Republican state senator from Iowa who is running for the Senate.

title: Bruce Braley Talks With John Harwood
description: Mr. Harwood Interviewed Mr. Braley, a Democratic United States representative from Iowa who is running for the Senate.

title: Cooking Techniques: Dicing an Onion
description: Peel an onion and chop it into same-size pieces for more even cooking.

title: Cooking Techniques: Making a Roux
description: Make a basic roux with equal parts butter and flour.

title: Edward Weston Photos to Be Auctioned
description: A collection of 548 photographs taken by Edward Weston and printed posthumously by his son Cole Weston  the only person Weston authorized to print from his negatives  will be auctioned by Sothebys in New York on Sept. 30. The house is estimating that the prints, which are being sold in a single lot, may bring as much as $3 million.

title: Cooking Techniques: Holding a Knife
description: Learn how to properly grip a knife.

title: Cooking Techniques: Caramelizing Onions
description: Slowly cook onions until they are a deep, rich brown.

title: Ryan McGinley Shoots a Short Film for Monique Pan
description: Each season, the designer Monique Pan visits a different destination to source materials and ideas for her fine-jewelry collection. The latest line out this fall, titled Lahnse, had its genesis in Norway and Iceland, whose rugged landscapes provided both stones (such as labradorite) and inspiration for the pieces geometric shapes. When Pan won a CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund contest  for which Kate Spade New York partnered with the designer to produce a campaign to appear in the September issue of Vogue  she enlisted the artist Ryan McGinley, who is amazing at shooting in nature, she says. The sense of exploration captured in Ryans work aligns with my design process of traveling the world. The black sand and rock formations at Icelands Vk  Myrdal beach, one of the shoot locations, also made their way into an accompanying short film, which, like the campaign, features the model Liya Kebede. (The location also figured prominently in the recent indie film Land Ho!, whose directors shared a travel diary with T.) Here, a first look at the clip.

title: Cooking Techniques: Deglazing a Pan
description: Use steaming liquid to scrape the flavorful burnt bits off the bottom of the pan while cooking.

title: Iranian TV Shows Remains of What It Says Is Downed Israeli Drone
description: TEHRAN  Irans state television showed video footage on Monday of what it said were the remains of an Israeli drone shot down by Irans Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps in the vicinity of a nuclear enrichment site in Natanz about 155 miles south of Tehran.

title: Cooking Techniques: Stemming Greens
description: Learn how to cut the stems off collards and other large, leafy green vegetables.

title: First Session at U.S. Open Presents Challenges for Seeded Players
description: For most seeded players in the United States Open, the opening matches are a chance to work out a few wrinkles, shake off some rust and become used to the swirling winds, the warm conditions and the speed of the courts.

title: Weekly Quandary: Revisiting Limits on Screen Time
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This weeks quandary comes, as they often do, from the comments on last weeks Open Thread. Mama of 3 wrote:

title: Attack the Donor: From Bloomberg to the Koch Brothers
description: Last week my colleague Frank Clines wrote about a National Rifle Association ad campaign targeting Michael Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor whos investing millions in the name of gun safety. The N.R.A., instead of arguing the issues, figured theyd have better luck beating up on the billionaire elitist hypocrite.

title: Cooking Techniques: Shocking
description: Shock steamed vegetables to stop them from cooking.

title: Cooking Techniques: Boiling Eggs
description: Learn how to boil eggs.

title: Cooking Techniques: Segmenting Citrus
description: Segment lemons, limes and other citrus fruits for cooking.

title: A Business Owner Stands By Zane Benefits Controversial Health Insurance Plan (for Now)
description: In June, we reported on the controversy surrounding Zane Benefits, a company that has won over many small businesses by promising them that they can cancel their group health insurance plan and still offer their employees a health benefit. Zane sells software that helps small businesses reimburse workers  with tax-free dollars!  when they buy their own individual insurance policies.

title: Wearing the Message
Danger! White Girl Twerking
description: Taylor Swift releaseda splashy new music video last week  Shake It Off, a single from her forthcoming album, 1989. The videofeatures Ms. Swift trying her hand at a variety of dance styles  pointe, interpretive, break  to the tune of abrassy pop anthem about players, haters and fakers, a measurable departure from the soft-sung country love ballads that brought her worldwide fame.

title: Generation Later, Poor Are Still Rare at Elite Colleges
description: As the shaded quadrangles of the nations elite campuses stir to life for the start of the academic year, they remain bastions of privilege. Amid promises to admit more poor students, top colleges educate roughly the same percentage of them as they did a generation ago. This is despite the fact that there are many high school seniors from low-income homes with top grades and scores: twice the percentage in the general population as at elite colleges.

title: Okras Triumph of Taste Over Texture
description: Okra has been like the awkward girl no one but her family thought had any talent. But just look at okra now.

title: Roches Merger Bet Outsmarts the Ice Bucket Challenge
description: Roches latest $8 billion merger bet may outsmart the ice bucket challenge. The challenge has become a social media phenomenon to fund research on amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrigs disease, and is a great way to raise charitable cash. But the drug made by InterMune, which is being taken over by Roche, treats an obscure yet equally fatal disease with more sufferers.

title: Facebook Takes Steps Against Click Bait Articles
description: Facebook announced on Monday that it had adjusted the way users see articles on its site to reduce what it called click bait  items that tempt readers with a beguiling headline, but dont deliver much more.

title: Murder Clues in Teenage Slang
description: A hallmark of Tana Frenchs intense Dublin Murder Squad series is her use of some minor character from an earlier book as the main figure in each new one. For her latest, she could not have found a better recruit. Stephen Moran appeared in Faithful Place, the 2010 book that is still the most dazzling introduction to this authors talents, as the smart young detective playing second fiddle to a formidable murder investigator, Frank Mackey.

title: September Science Events: Beautiful Pathogens and Extreme Close-ups
description: September events and books at the intersection of science and art.

title: Whats Twitch? Gamers Know, and Amazon Is Spending $1 Billion on It
description: The video in video games is suddenly a billion-dollar business.

title: Premature Labor Drugs Underused, Study Says
description: Each year, roughly 1 million children worldwide die after being born prematurely, yet two strategies that are effective in preventing these deaths are largely underused, researchers have found.

title: For a Gaza Athlete, There Is Nowhere to Run
description: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip  Everything looked about the same in this town near Gazas northern border with Israel: piles of smashed concrete to the left and right, up ahead and in the rearview. As we drove through the destruction earlier this month, Fares Akram, my Gaza-based reporting partner, somehow recognized a certain street as one we had been on four months before, to visit Nader al-Masri, Gazas premier distance runner.

title: Jets Suspend Cornerback Amid Inquiry Into Absence
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Cornerback Dimitri Patterson, who was absent from the Jets for at least 48 hours, beginning with a preseason game against the Giants on Friday night, has been suspended indefinitely.

title: Afropunk Music Festival Style
description: Festivalgoers in Brooklyn did not disappoint with their unique and colorful style.

title: Demonstrations and Remembrances Today and This Week
description: As funeral services for Michael Brown came to an end Monday afternoon, community leaders, universities and other organizations in St. Louis and elsewhere prepared for a week of demonstrations. Many participants and organizers stressed that today would have been Mr. Browns first day of college.

title: Midriff-Baring Looks at the 2014 MTV Video Music Awards
description: Last night, Jourdan Dunn (in Balmain), Kendall Jenner (in Alon Livne and a Jennifer Fisher x Stop it Right Now Choker) and Miley Cyrus (in Alexandre Vauthier Couture) stood out on the 2014 MTV Video Music Awards red carpet in all-black, midriff-baring ensembles.

title: Walkabout: Earthquake Rattles Napa and Its Wineries; Iceland Lowers Warning of Volcanic Eruption
description: AftermathThe 6.0-magnitude earthquake that struck Northern California early Sunday and sent more than 100 people to the hospital also dealt a blow to the regions wine industry. (CNN)

title: Highlights From the 2014 Emmy Awards
description: The 66th Primetime Emmy Awards, recognizing televisions best, took place at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on Monday night. Breaking Bad and Modern Family repeated last years wins for best drama and comedy, respectively.

title: Sharpton at Michael Browns Funeral
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton spoke at Michael Browns funeral at the Friendly Temple Missionary Baptist Church in St. Louis.

title: A Rare Lover of Air Travel, Turbulence Included
description: I USED to be creative director for a brand strategy firm with offices all over the world, and I enjoyed all the international travel. But now with my own company, Jonathan Taylor Design, Im doing a lot of coast-to-coast travel since I have offices in both New York and Oakland, Calif. I also take a lot of quick trips to various places around the country, even just for a day. I work in Virginia often, as well as the Washington, D.C., area.

title: Technology Adviser Expected to Leave White House Post
description: WASHINGTON  Todd Park, President Obamas top technology adviser and an important figure in the emergency effort last year to fix the federal governments online health care marketplace after a disastrous beginning, is leaving the White House, a person familiar with the matter said Monday.

title: The McLaren P1 GTR: Form Equals Function
description: The Pebble Beach Concours d'lgance started out in the early 1950s as a showplace for some of the finest contemporary automobiles on the planet. Since then it has morphed into one of the worlds most prestigious vintage car shows, but it still hosts some significant new product reveals as well.

title: An Ill-Chosen Phrase, No Angel, Brings a Storm of Protest
description: Two words  no angel  have become a flash point for many of the difficult, contentious, entrenched issues that have arisen in Ferguson, Mo. On Twitter, in my email queue and across the Internet, many Times readers are angry and disappointed about the use of those words, which have become yet another Ferguson-related hashtag.

title: One-Man Empire Brings Locavore Cuisine to Myanmar
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Tired of running a nightclub in Geneva, the businessman known as Sharky was looking for a second act. So he returned to his native Myanmar and hatched an unlikely idea: growing and making fine food in an impoverished military dictatorship.

title: The Rev. Al Sharpton at Brown Funeral: This Is About Fairness
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, the final speaker at Michael Browns funeral, sharply criticized inequality and the reaction of the police to the protesters.

title: Moving Back Home Together
description: FORT BELKNAP AGENCY, Mont.  In the employee directory of the Fort Belknap Reservation, Bronc Speak Thunders title is buffalo wrangler.

title: Texas Governors Lawyers Seek Dismissal of Abuse-of-Power Case
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Defense lawyers for Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Monday sought to throw out a felony abuse-of-power case against him, calling it an unconstitutional prosecution that would set a dangerous precedent for future governors.

title: Save the Fav, Twitters Digital Body Language
description: Theres a kerfuffle at the moment on Twitter about what should happen when you fav something.

title: Even With Michael Phelps Back, U.S. Squad Needs Work
description: SOUTHPORT, Australia  Michael Phelps woke up Sunday morning feeling awful. His limbs were leaden and his back was stiff. In his first international meet since the 2012 Olympics, Phelps had undertaken a program considered ambitious by anyones standards other than his own.

title: Lowering Interest Rates on Loans Isnt the Best Way to Help College Students
description: As students return to college, they may notice that the interest rates on their loans are up. The rate on Stafford loans for undergraduates is now 4.66 percent, compared with 3.86 percent last year.

title: A New Boutique in New Orleans Co-Owned by Solange Knowles
description: Though it opened its doors in April, the only thing the New Orleans boutique Exodus Goods has done to announce its existence until now is hang a colorful wooden sign outside its French Quarter storefront. The sisters Darlene and Lizzy Okpo, along with the co-owner Armina Mussa, have deliberately managed to keep word of their project confined mostly to their cult Instagram following  despite the fact that the stores fourth partner and creative director is Solange Knowles. Chalk it up to being in New Orleans, where the pace of life is slower, Lizzy Okpo explains. Weve developed a feeling of building things organically until theyre right. Now, however, with the launch this week of Exodus Goods new e-commerce site, the secret is out.

title: Coal Leases Were Illegally Granted, an Indian Court Says
description: MUMBAI  Indias top court on Monday ruled that coal fields allocated by the government between 1993 and 2009 were assigned illegally, a decision that could ultimately hinder the industry.

title: Cooking Techniques: Tying a Roast
description: Tie a roast to give it a uniform shape, which will result in more even cooking.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Bangladesh, Ukraine and Germany.

title: Ways to Protect a PC With Windows 8.1
description: Defending

title: Sales Droop for Hedwig After Harris Departs
description: Ticket sales came back to earth last week for the Broadway musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch, which had been breaking box office records at the Belasco Theater this summer thanks to the drawing power of Neil Patrick Harris, who won a Tony Award in the title role. Mr. Harriss run in the show ended Aug. 17 and Andrew Rannells, an original star of The Book of Mormon who is also known from the HBO series Girls, has taken over as Hedwig. For Mr. Rannells first week, the musical grossed $648,738  a healthy amount, though far less than the $1,139,903 for the previous week with Mr. Harris. Mr. Rannells is scheduled to star through Oct. 12.

title: Former New York Judge on U.N. Gaza Panel
description: GENEVA  The president of the United Nations Human Rights Council on Monday named a former New York judge to be the third member of a three-person panel established to investigate possible international law violations by Israel and Hamas in the Gaza conflict.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Lively Accounts Examining Death
description: The great highway of life is a one-way road, but that never stopped anyone from ignoring the traffic signs and trying to drive back up the offramps.

title: Peeks at Revamped U.S. Open Practice Courts Still Feel Like a Perk
description: Hes really tall!

title: Real Americans and Real Economics
description: Maybe Im deluding myself, but it seems to me that were not hearing as much as we used to about real Americans  the notion that the true essence of the nation is white people living in small towns, associated these days with Sarah Palin but also invoked by whatshisname, the guy who lived in the White House between Clinton and Obama and misled us into war. But Im sure thats still how a lot of people on the right see it.

title: A New York Food Tour With a Batali Touch
description: The new tour operator Walks of New York has landed a star among food personalities around which to build its newest Manhattan itinerary: Mario Batali.

title: Fighting Ebola, and the Conspiracy Theories
description: Misinformation about politics may often seem silly  the immigration bill will give out free cars!  but the consequences of false beliefs in public health can be deadly.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on Eugenie Bouchards Family, Fame and Potential
description: Susan Dominus, a contributing writer for The Times Magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about the almost-tennis-star Eugenie Bouchard. Her last article for the magazine was about a heroin-addicted mother-turned-informant.

title: In Performance | Kelvin Moon Loh
description: Kelvin Moon Loh sings God Draws Straight from Here Lies Love, a musical about the life of Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos. The show, conceived by David Byrne, is at the Public Theater.

title: The Decisive Marriage
description: Do you have a decisive marriage?

title: Holding a Mirror to Their Natures
description: MONTREAL  When twins have similar personalities, is it mainly because they share so much genetic material or because their physical resemblance makes other people treat them alike?

title: Burly, a Word With a Racially Charged History
description: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999.

title: Drugs and Teens, Seafood on the Menu
description: Marijuana

title: In a Healthy Travel Industry, Signs of Disruption
description: FOR a heads-up on what to expect as the pace of business travel picks up after Labor Day, consider that airlines all summer have been reporting planes more full than ever, flight delays are at six-year highs and hotels are raising rates.

title: A Personal Organizer Arrives, but the Entanglements Just Get More Knotty
description: Like an earnest Lifetime TV movie bleached of plot and tension, Voices of Swords is occasionally tolerable but mostly just talky. This is a play eager to chatter on about accepting yourself and others. Trouble is, all those speeches are at the expense of any real drama.

title: Mothers Death Tests a Familys Ties
description: Last year, the actress-playwright Laoisa Sexton delivered a bleak, funny and flavorful take on womens lives in recession-ravaged Dublin with her winning For Love at the Irish Repertory Theater. With The Last Days of Cleopatra, now at Urban Stages, she again depicts that citys working class, but across genders and generations.

title: Clues in a Disease Spreaders Reaction
description: Each year, more than a million people in tropical countries a contract leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease spread by female sand flies. After the insect delivers an infectious bite, there are several possible outcomes for the human host, including disfiguration and death.

title: New Releases From Brad Paisley and Ty Segall
description: BRAD PAISLEY

title: Scenes of Michael Browns Funeral
description: Family and supporters celebrated the life of Michael Brown, a black teenager killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo.

title: The Hummingbirds Special Sweet Tooth
description: Hummingbirds can detect the sweetness of nectar because of a taste receptor that took an unexpected evolutionary path, researchers say.

title: Haunting Atmosphere of Whispers and Enigma
description: MOUNT TREMPER, N.Y.  We tend to think of dance as nonverbal, but what about the words that go into passing it from person to person, generation to generation? Tatsumi Hijikata, who founded the Japanese movement art Butoh in the 1960s, left behind a wealth of words when he died, in 1986, texts that can be as unsettling to read as Butoh is to watch. In an essay, the filmmaker and critic Nanako Kurihara describes the strange, equivocal images that populated his writings: rotting space, dribbling candy. A corporeal response to the emotional wreckage of postwar Japan, Butoh channeled those images through the flesh.

title: Appointment at Chinese Journalism School Highlights Growing Party Role
description: Lin Zhibo, who first came to widespread public attention when he angered many Chinese with his remarks dismissing the scale of the Great Famine of 1958-61, has once again found himself at the center of a heated debate.

title: Fungus Turns Ants Into Zombie Booby-Traps
description: A fungus compels infected ants to die near their colonies, ensuring access to a steady stream of new victims, researchers say in PLOS One. Before killing a carpenter ant, the fungal parasite prompts it to climb vegetation in rain forests. After the ant dies, it stays attached to the leaf, from where the fungus can drop spores on unsuspecting passers-by.

title: AIDS Progress in South Africa Is in Peril
description: VERENA, South Africa  A fading roadside ad for Selala Funeral Service here captures what was, until recently, the essence of South Africas AIDS epidemic: Tombstones Are Available, it reads. Buy One, Get One Free.

title: Rashaad Newsome Marries Voguing With Art History
description: Yesterday, the artist Rashaad Newsome hosted the second edition of the King of Arms Art Ball in Riverside Park in Manhattan. The event consisted of a series of performances that married the elements of a vogue ball with art historical moments. In one segment, dancers were asked to show their moves while wearing looks inspired by the drapery seen in Renaissance painting; in another, they were challenged to embody the qualities of Abstract Expressionism. An all-star jury that included ballroom legends like Meeka Prodigy and Hctor Xtravaganza awarded prizes. The photographer Dina Litovsky was on hand to capture the action.

title: Richard IIIs Rich Diet of Fish and Exotic Birds
description: A chemical analysis of the teeth and bones of King Richard III reveals that his diet was decadent even by standards of medieval royalty.

title: Dont Judge Them by Their Shells
description: Q. Is there any nutritional difference between brown and white eggs? What accounts for the difference in shell color?

title: Tap-Dancer and Crooner Reclaim Sidewalk Spotlight
description: It was a tale of neighborliness and of a New York as many New Yorkers wish it to be. On a Friday evening in August 1997, Nick Drakides was walking home from work. When he arrived at his apartment building at 124 East Fourth Street in the East Village, he found Laraine Goodman, a neighbor he barely knew, tap-dancing on the sidewalk out front. She knew he had a big music collection, and she asked him to provide some accompaniment. He brought out CDs, a microphone and an amplifier and started crooning Frank Sinatra songs. A crowd began to gather.

title: Celebrating as Well as Mourning Michael Brown
description: Michael Browns funeral was marked by messages of hope for the future, calls for renewed action against gun violence and jubilant gospel music.

title: Architecture Critic Acknowledges a Mistake in Critique of Zaha Hadid
description: The critic Martin Filler has acknowledged a significant error in a scathing review he wrote for The New York Review of Books that mentioned the architect Zaha Hadid.

title: Three Approaches to Beating the AIDS Epidemic in South Africa
description: South Africas AIDS epidemic is at its worst in high-risk subgroups like gay men, prostitutes, truckers, prisoners, miners and patients who dont take their drugs regularly.

title: A Pesky Fan Creates a Buzz
description: Kimiko Date-Krumm and Venus Williams had to deal with a bee that interrupted their match at the U.S. Open on Monday.

title: The Many Looks of Afropunk Festival 2014
description: Ten years ago, the first Afropunk Festivalhosted a free concert to 100 or so revelers at BAMcaf in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. Now, the event has grown into one of New Yorks biggest and most spirited summer happenings. This past weekend, acts such as SZA, Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings and DAngelo drew crowds in the tens of thousands to Commodore Barry Park, near the Navy Yard. Diversity ruled the day, from the sounds onstage to the faces in the crowd to the wildly styled looks on parade. As expected, fairgoers brought their fashion A game, sporting elements of Africana, hip-hop, punk rock and sportswear  often all together in a single outfit. The photographer Daniel Lord was on hand to capture the action.

title: Studio Deals Unlock a Trove of Reruns
description: LOS ANGELES  Thousands of hours of television programming are becoming available to rerun on digital networks and cable channels after new residual agreements between studios and Hollywoods three largest guilds.

title: AIDS in South Africa, Airships Revisted, Animal Grammar
description: Progress against an epidemic may be in peril; a search for a cheaper way to view space is on; scientists discover a mathematical model behind animal language.

title: Saving Indonesian Rain Forests and Orangutans
description: Sandra Hoyn prefers covering stories that maker her angry. The plight of Indonesias orangutans set her off.

title: When Tragedy Hits, Should a President Forgo Vacation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands Mourn Michael Brown in St. Louis
description: Family, friends and celebrities remembered the unarmed black teenager who was shot and killed more than two weeks ago by a Ferguson police officer.

title: Red Carpet at the 2014 Emmy Awards
description: Teyonah Parris, Sarah Hyland, Laura Prepon, Jesse Tyler Ferguson and others arrived for the 66th annual Primetime Emmy Awards in Los Angeles.

title: Judge Rejects Settlement Proposal in HPs Autonomy Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The long fight over Hewlett-Packards $11.1 billion purchase of Autonomy got a new wrinkle on Monday, which might spell more legal pressure on Autonomy executives.

description: A scene from the film directed by David Mackenzie and starring Jack OConnell.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Hedge Funds Sue to Get Argentine Bond Payment in London
description: A group of hedge funds, including George Soross Quantum Partners and J. Kyle Basss Hayman Capital, is seeking a 226 million euro interest payment on Argentine bonds from Bank of New York Mellon that was blocked by a United States judge last month.

title: Fashion at the 2014 Emmys
description: Looks from the red carpet at the 66th Primetime Emmy Awards.

title: Harried Travelers Take the Bus
description: Until recently, John Alday either drove or flew the 200-mile trip between his companys headquarters in Dallas and its satellite office in Austin.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,330 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: California Governor Signs Law Requiring a Kill Switch on Smartphones
description: Governor Jerry Brown of California on Monday signed into law a measure that requires smartphones sold in California to include smarter antitheft technology, a feature that lawmakers hope will help reduce phone theft.

title: Obama Authorizes Air Surveillance of ISIS in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has authorized surveillance flights over Syria, a precursor to potential airstrikes there, but a mounting concern for the White House is how to target the Sunni extremists without helping President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Este Lauder to Weave Pink Ribbons Through the Internet
description: FOR 2014, the 23rd annual breast cancer awareness campaign from the Este Lauder Companies will have more of a focus on digital and social media, executives say, and become a year-round initiative rather than be concentrated in October, when Breast Cancer Awareness Month is marked each year.

title: On To-Do List: Deposit Cash in Bitcoin A.T.M.
description: Welcome to the A.T.M. of the future, where customers insert cash and leave with nothing.

title: Judge Blocks a Local Pesticide Law in Hawaii
description: A federal judge in Hawaii has struck down a local ordinance that would have restricted or regulated the use of pesticides and genetically modified crops on the island of Kauai, saying the measure was pre-empted by state law.

title: Liberian Doctor Treated With an Experimental Drug Dies From Ebola
description: A Liberian doctor with Ebola who was given ZMapp  the same experimental drug given to two infected Americans  has died, officials said Monday.

title: A Marriage to Remember
description: In this short documentary, the filmmaker Banker White explores how Alzheimers disease has revealed the strength of his parents marriage.

title: Grain Piles Up, Waiting for a Ride, as Trains Move North Dakota Oil
description: FARGO, N.D.  The furious pace of energy exploration in North Dakota is creating a crisis for farmers whose grain shipments have been held up by a vast new movement of oil by rail, leading to millions of dollars in agricultural losses and slower production for breakfast cereal giants like General Mills.

title: Funeral for Michael Brown in St. Louis
description: Thousands attended the service for the unarmed black teenager who was fatally shot Aug. 9 by a Ferguson, Mo., police officer.

title: A Marriage to Remember
description: My mother, Pam White, has had a full life. In her 67 years, she has raised three happy children, enjoyed a rewarding career as a social worker and been a devoted partner to my father, Ed. But, as she puts it, Theres just one little glitch. In 2009, at age 61, she was told she had early-onset Alzheimers disease.

title: Oklahoma: Suit Seeks Reporting Access at Executions
description: Reporters should have the right to witness executions in Oklahoma from start to end, a federal suit filed in Oklahoma City on Monday by the American Civil Liberties Union contends. The suit was prompted by the bungled execution of Clayton D. Lockett on April 29, where witnesses were not allowed to watch as officials spent 51 minutes struggling to insert catheters into Mr. Locketts veins and where witnesses had their view blocked again after Mr. Lockett began to writhe and moan. At the moment when public oversight was most important, the suit states, citing the First Amendment and Oklahoma law, the state unlawfully shrouded its execution proceedings in secrecy.

title: E-Cigarette Use Said to Rise Among Tobacco-Free Youths
description: The number of middle school and high school students in the United States who say they have tried e-cigarettes but not traditional cigarettes increased by about 60 percent from 2012 to 2013, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Monday. An estimated 263,000 middle and high school students used e-cigarettes but had never smoked regular cigarettes, up from about 160,000 in 2012 and about 79,000 in 2011. Youth smoking rates dropped by half from 1997 to 2011, according to federal data, but the pace of the decline has slowed. Many health advocates worry that e-cigarettes may lead teenagers to use conventional cigarettes.

title: U.S. Says It Told Qatar Not to Pay a Ransom
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Monday that it brought the family of the American hostage Peter Theo Curtis together with the government of Qatar in an effort to secure his release, but insisted that it told the Qataris not to pay a ransom for the captured journalist.

title: No Link Found for Deaths and Veterans Care Delays
description: An investigation by the watchdog office for the Department of Veterans Affairs has been unable to substantiate allegations that 40 veterans may have died because of delays in care at the veterans medical center in Phoenix, according to a letter from the new secretary of Veterans Affairs.

title: Tiger Woods Parts Ways With Swing Coach
description: Whatever Tiger Woods accomplishes the rest of his career, it will apparently be without the assistance of the instructor Sean Foley, from whom he announced a split Monday after four years of working together.

title: Ex-Diplomat for the Vatican Could Be Tried
description: The Vaticans former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, who has been accused of paying underage boys there to engage in sexual acts, has lost his diplomatic immunity and could ultimately face prosecution in criminal courts outside of the Vatican, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church announced on Monday.

title: Sam Hunter, Curator and Museum Founder, Dies at 91
description: Over six decades, Sam Hunter could usually be found at the center of some of the most exciting times for art in New York and beyond. He was an art historian (an authority on 20th-century art), a museum director, a curator, an art critic and an art adviser to museums, corporations and private collectors.

title: French Economy Minister, Arnaud Montebourg, Was Often Out of Step With President
description: PARIS  When Arnaud Montebourg, Frances combative economy minister, learned in April that Alstom, one of the countrys biggest industrial companies, had been secretly negotiating its takeover by General Electric, he responded by publicly castigating the French companys boss.

title: Samples of the Export-Import Bank Debate
description: The debate over the reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank, which provides loans to foreign buyers of American goods, has become a somewhat unlikely election issue on Capitol Hill.

title: Lost in America
description: More and more Im convinced that America right now isnt a country dealing with a mere dip in its mood and might. Its a country surrendering to a new identity and era, in which optimism is quaint and the frontier anything but endless.

title: Poland Embraces Football That Has a Rougher Side
description: WARSAW  Piotr Zaremba pounded the bass drum slung from his neck with utter absorption while leading the chant, in English: Lets go, Eagles, lets go!

title: Emmy Award Winners
description: The 66th Primetime Emmy Awards took place at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on Monday.

title: A Knock on the Door, a Stranger, Then a Killing at a Rural Summer Home
description: A woman is alone at her home on a quiet country road.

title: The Making of a Disaster
description: LONDON  Almost 13 years after 9/11, a jihadi organization with a murderous anti-Western ideology controls territory in Iraq and Syria, which are closer to Europe and the United States than Afghanistan is. It commands resources and camps and even a Syrian military base. It spreads its propaganda through social media. It has set the West on edge through the recorded beheading of the American journalist James Foley  with the promise of more to come.

title: Absorbing Events Past in a Summers Reading List
description: As the summer comes to an end, Ive been trying to squeeze as much reading as I can into the final days. A benefit of this job is the opportunity to get sneak peeks at books before they are released, so Ive been catching up on a pile of books that I missed earlier in the year as well as trying to get ahead by polishing off a couple that wont be published until later this fall. So while Amazons Jeff Bezos continues to battle it out with Hachette (now that should be a book!), heres a list of highlights from my summer reading list that I hope will appeal to your inner financial geek:

title: How to Get Kids to Class
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  FOR the 16 million American children living below the federal poverty line, the start of a new school year should be reason to celebrate. Summer is no vacation when your parents are working multiple jobs or looking for one. Many kids are left to fend for themselves in neighborhoods full of gangs, drugs and despair. Given the hardships at home, poor kids might be expected to have the best attendance records, if only for the promise of a hot meal and an orderly classroom.

title: John G. Sperling, For-Profit College Pioneer, Dies at 93
description: John G. Sperling, a pioneer of for-profit education who turned a $26,000 investment into the multibillion-dollar University of Phoenix, calling himself an unintentional entrepreneur and an accidental C.E.O., died on Friday in the San Francisco area. He was 93.

title: Louis Freeh, Ex-Head of F.B.I., Hurt in Vermont Car Crash
description: WASHINGTON  Louis J. Freeh, the director of the F.B.I. from 1993 to 2001, was hospitalized on Monday after sustaining significant injuries in a one-car accident in Vermont, according to law enforcement officials.

title: In India, an App for Chats and for Keeping Secrets
description: BANGALORE, India  Naitik Gohain, 17, has a secret.

title: Courting Tim Hortons, Burger King Has Plans for a Fast-Food Empire
description: When Daniel Schwartz took over as chief executive of Burger King last year, he set about pinching pennies.

title: Afghanistans Moment of Reckoning
description: Afghanistan faces ever deepening security and political crises. As American troops withdraw, Taliban military advances are threatening entire districts, and government coffers are dwindling.

title: Andy Murray Overcomes Cramping at U.S. Open to Win His First Match
description: Andy Murray now knows that he can serve at severely reduced speed and contort himself into pained positions that bear more resemblance to modern dance than modern tennis and still win a match at the United States Open.

title: Syria Declares Its Readiness in Backing Efforts to Fight Jihadists
description: BAGHDAD  Syrias foreign minister said Monday that his government was ready to cooperate with international efforts to fight the extremists of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. But in a nod to the possibility of expanded American airstrikes, he warned that any action inside Syria without the governments approval would be considered aggression.

title: Woman Dies After Fall From Greenwich Village Roof Deck
description: A young woman who fell off a roof during a party in Greenwich Village early Sunday morning has died, the police said.

title: Election Panel Enacts Policies by Not Acting
description: WASHINGTON  The three Republican and three Democratic appointees of the Federal Election Commission had reached yet another deadlock: They would issue no advisory opinion on whether the Conservative Action Fund could accept contributions of Bitcoin, the online currency created to be untraceable.

title: Deported From the Middle of Nowhere
description: When the influx of young Central American migrants to the border erupted as a crisis this summer, President Obama correctly called it a humanitarian emergency. He promised that the administrations response would combine compassion with respect for the law.

title: When Five-Star Care Is Substandard
description: Medicare has devised a rating system for nursing homes that portrays many of them as much better than they really are. Consumers should be aware that a top five-star rating from Medicare, achieved by a fifth of the more than 15,000 nursing homes nationwide, may mask serious and potentially dangerous deficiencies.

title: At Least 4 Inmates Are Killed During Bloody Prison Uprising in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Abloodyprison uprising in southern Brazilthat left at leastfour inmates dead at the hands of fellow prisoners, including two by beheading, seemed to easeon Mondayafter negotiatorssaid theyhad reached an agreement withthe revolts leaders,but tension persisted as inmates feared a crackdown by security forces.

title: Is Tennis Strung Too Tight?
Bonding Behind Bars
description: Women in prison: the new black?

title: Crossword Needs
description: Administrivial Will Shortz Alert! Its the puzzle masters birthday today! Stop by in the comments and wish Will Shortz a happy one!

title: Napa Mops Up Wine and Tallies Its Losses After Quake
description: NAPA, Calif.  The gardens at the Hess Collection, one of this regions better-known wineries, reeked of spilled cabernet on Monday. The wine barrel storage warehouses by the airport were a jumble of tumbled oak barrels. The wine library at Saintsbury  a room filled with old vintages  had the smell of a day-old party, a result of 500 bottles shattering on the floor.

title: An Opening Day of Distraction
description: A comedy routine broke out Monday during Venus Williamss first-round match at the United States Open.

title: Tourist Is Held After Climb on Brooklyn Bridge Cable
description: A month after two American flags flying atop the Brooklyn Bridge were stolen and replaced with white ones, security on the world-famous crossing was back in the spotlight  this time, according to the authorities, because of an overly adventurous Russian tourist.

title: Scotland: Rivals Clash Again in Independence Debate
description: The leading rivals on the issue of whether Scotland should vote for independence from the United Kingdom clashed Monday in their second and final televised debate ahead of next months independence referendum. During an acrimonious 90-minute exchange, Alex Salmond, the first minister of the Scottish government and a longtime proponent of independence, appeared to gain the upper hand over his opponent, Alistair Darling, a former chancellor of the Exchequer and a member of the Labour Party, accusing him of siding with the austerity policies of the conservative government in London: Youre in bed with the Tory Party, Mr. Salmond said. The question of which currency an independent Scotland would use if Britain refused to share the pound again featured prominently, and Mr. Darling repeatedly challenged Mr. Salmond to reveal his Plan B. Mr. Salmond, who had been on the defensive on this point during the first debate, was better prepared this time. Refusing to be drawn in a debate over an alternative, he said that it was in the best interests of Scotland to continue to use the pound and that he wanted a mandate from the Scottish people to negotiate a currency union after a vote for independence.

title: Mobile Home Park on the Atlantic Appeals to the Rich
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  When they were growing up in the 1970s and 80s, Cherie and Merry Doughan spent their summers at Montauk Shores, a mobile home park that is about as far east as you can live on the East End of Long Island and still have a roof over your head. Only the Montauk Association Houses, where Andy Warhol and Dick Cavett summered, and the lighthouse keepers place lie beyond.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 25, 2014
TVs Red Carpet Style, All Dressed Up in Cinemas Glamour
description: Since the dark shadings of The Sopranos first transformed our televisions, cultural observers have agreed that whats on there is as good as what used to be grandly known as the cinema. But has TVs ceremonial clothing kept pace?

title: Uncertainty for Workers Losing Jobs at Atlantic City Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITY  As the summer season winds down, the air in this beachfront resort carries the sense of foreboding that precedes a tsunami. Casino shutdowns and mass layoffs are about to hit the boardwalk, leaving thousands of people out of work and unsure where to go or what to do next.

title: Sheep Are Given Room to Roam, and in Return, They Manage the Land
description: SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y.  Before Chris OBlenness started wielding a shepherds crook, it took him a while to warm up to the resident flock of sheep.

title: Emmys 2014: Breaking Bad and Modern Family Take Top Honors
description: LOS ANGELES  The 66th Primetime Emmy Awards was a win for broadcast and cable television, which earned numerous awards as the digital gate-crasher Netflix was nearly shut out.

title: A Season Disrupted by Passion and Ukrainian Politics
description: After losing in straight sets Monday afternoon to become one of the first men knocked out of the United States Open this year, Sergiy Stakhovsky admitted that his mind had been elsewhere.

title: Yankees Keep Firing on All Cylinders in Fifth Straight Win
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Sitting at his locker, signing photographs and other memorabilia after the Yankees latest win, Derek Jeter was asked if he felt things were starting to come together for the Yankees, whose up-and-down season is back in the ascent.

title: Maria Sharapova Routs Ex-Doubles Partner at U.S. Open
description: In her first appearance at the United States Open since 2012, fifth-seeded Maria Sharapova looked a little rusty playing against Maria Kirilenko, her close friend and former doubles partner.

title: MAD4 Food Festival in Copenhagen: A Rallying Cry for Social Change
description: What is cooking? was the question posed by the organizers of this years MAD symposium. During the two-day festival in Copenhagen, which culminated yesterday, it was perhaps never fully answered.

title: The Chef Alex Atala Reveals Surprises in Store for Danish Food Conference MAD4
description: This Sunday and Monday, under a big tent in a field in Copenhagen, many of the culinary worlds most influential figures will gather for the fourth MAD Symposium. Founded by the Noma chef Rene Redzepi and his team in 2011, the annual gathering has matured from a party for like-minded chefs to a themed conference that informs conversations in kitchens worldwide. Last years theme, Guts, was co-curated by Momofukus David Chang and saw a roster of international presenters speak, both metaphorically and literally, about the subject. This year, Atala, the Brazilian DJ-turned-chef and owner of acclaimed Sao Paulo restaurant D.O.M. (who controversially demonstrated the reality of working with meat by decapitating a live chicken onstage at last years festival), returns as co-curator.

title: Word of the Day | gesticulation
description: gesticulation \je-sti-ky-la-shn\ noun

title: In Poland, American Football Gains a Toehold
description: The relationship between America and Poland is a complex and emotional one, and among the ways to view it these days is through the prism of full-contact football.

title: Quake Damage and Spilled Wine in Napa
description: The cleanup continues in the Napa Valley as wineries assess the damage after a 6.0 earthquake shook the area early Sunday.

title: Emmy Winners Mostly Fall Behind TVs Pay Wall
description: It is the Gilded Age of Television.

title: A New Reason to Question the Official Unemployment Rate
description: The Labor Departments monthly jobs report has been the subject of some wacky conspiracy theories. None was wackier than the suggestion from Jack Welch, the former General Electric chief executive, that government statisticians were exaggerating job growth during President Obamas 2012 re-election campaign. Both Republican and Democratic economists dismissed those charges as silly.

title: Nick Kyrgios, Amid Fits of Fury, Advances at U.S. Open
description: Nick Kyrgios battled himself as much as he battled Mikhail Youzhny in winning a tight first-round match at the United States Open on Monday.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 10:05 A.M.
