description: In the second rock band tour bus accident of the summer, Dusty Hill, the bassist for ZZ Top, slipped and fell on the bands bus on Tuesday evening, and sustained unspecified injuries that have forced the band to cancel some of its dates. The accident follows an accident in which Nick Followill, the drummer for the Kings of Leon, broke his ribs when the groups tour bus stopped to avoid hitting a pedestrian, and canceled several weeks of concerts.

title: $13.2 Million in Gifts for the Minnesota Orchestra
description: Months after the management and players of the Minnesota Orchestra settled the contract dispute that led to a 16-month lockout, and returned to performing  with its music director, Osmo Vanska back in place after resigning during the lockout  the orchestras supporters seem intent on helping it address the financial issues that led to the dispute. The board announced on Wednesday that the ensemble had received four gifts totaling $13.2 million during the summer.

title: ISIS Said to Kill 150 Syrian Captives in 2 Days, Videotaping the Horror
description: BAGHDAD  Fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have killed more than 150 captured soldiers in northern Syria in the last two days, a monitoring group said on Thursday. Video images posted online appeared to show the men being marched through the desert in their underwear by the extremists and then lying dead in the sand.

title: What We Write When It Wont Rain
description: We do what we can to make it rain.

title: Asking Congress to Back ISIS Strikes in Syria Is Tricky for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama summoned his closest advisers to the Oval Office a year ago this week to tell them he was holding off on a missile strike against Syria, one of his arguments was that if he acted without Congress, he might not get congressional backing for military intervention the next time he needed it.

title: Why The Times Identified and Photographed Teenagers in a Sex Abuse Article
description: Several readers wrote to me concerned about a Times article earlier this week that told the stories of some Dominican teenagers who described sexual abuse by a former priest and Vatican official. They told me they were surprised and dismayed to see the young people identified by name with their photographs used in an accompanying gallery.

title: Fifty Years Ago and Today, Japan Blazes Trails With Trains
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. High-Speed Train Tested in Japan appeared on Aug. 26 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: In Iowa, an Oasis of Family Vacations Past
description: I remember doing this when I was a kid, Linda Clarksean said with a laugh as she walked up the steep ramp to the 84-year-old Tipsy House holding the hands of her 5- and 6-year-old grandsons. Battling the tug of gravity through the fun house of impossibly angled rooms, they arrived at the peaked roof for the view of Okoboji, a resort on the Iowa Great Lakes.

title: Is Obamacare No Longer a Big Deal?
description: It looks as though Republicans are no longer betting on the Affordable Care Act as a surefire political weapon. The Upshot reported on Wednesday that, in the summer of 2013, lawmakers churned out 530 news releases using the term Obamacare. So far this summer, in advance of the mid-terms when one might expect that number to go up, its fallen dramatically, to 138 so far.

title: How to Complain to Medicare
description: How Medicare handles complaints and appeals is no trivial matter  the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services says it reviews more than 100,000 of them a year. Beneficiaries file roughly 16,000 annually related to hospital care (mostly contesting discharges) and 18,000 about nursing homes, home health services and hospice programs. And 30,000 other complaints and appeals concern Medicare Advantage programs.

title: In Plastics and Cans, a Threat to Women
description: A few years ago, Jodi Flaws, a bioscientist at the University of Illinois, began testing a theory about the risks to women posed by the widely used industrial compound bisphenol A, or BPA.

title: Economic Data Points to Upward Trajectory
description: The United States economy grew faster than first thought last quarter, the Commerce Department said on Thursday, the latest in a series of signals that point to a period of sustainable growth ahead.

title: The Pride of Cold Spring, Minn.
description: Jets receiver Eric Decker was a three-sport star in high school and a product of the schools and ball fields of Cold Spring, Minn.

title: Jets Big-Time Receiver Nourished by Small-Town Roots
description: COLD SPRING, Minn.  His friends would call his house on summer days, and if Eric Decker was not around, they knew where to find him.

title: Joan Rivers Hospitalized in New York
description: Updated, 12:59 p.m. | Joan Rivers was hospitalized in New York on Thursday morning after she was unconscious and unresponsive and had gone into cardiac arrest, law enforcement officials told The New York Times. Ms. Rivers, 81, the brassy, pioneering comedian and host of the E! series Fashion Police, was brought to Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan by emergency workers who responded at 201 East 93rd Street at 9:40 a.m.

title: 1963: The Beatles Get a Headline
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: In First Year of Pre-K Expansion, a Rush to Beat the School Bell
description: Shant Jones walks around central Brooklyn for hours every day, visiting playgrounds, lingering outside public pools, trolling the cereal aisles in supermarkets  anywhere she thinks she might find small children and their parents.

title: Today in Small Business: Independent Contractors
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: After Quick Rise, Halep Savors Seed, and a Hot Dog on Every Corner
description: Simona Halep, a 22-year-old Romanian, has had a meteoric rise from outside the top 60 in May 2013 to being the No. 2 seed at this years United States Open. In that span she has won eight WTA titles and was runner-up at the French Open in June. After her second-round victory over Jana Cepelova on Wednesday, Halep spoke to The New York Times about life and tennis in New York, and the pluses and minuses of newfound fame. BEN ROTHENBERG

title: In Tuscany, Working the Harvest at a Farm Owned by Sting and Trudie Styler
description: The singer Sting and his wife, the actress and producer Trudie Styler, are opening their home in Tuscany, called Il Palagio, for the first time this fall to travelers interested in participating in the estates grape and olive harvests.

title: Bundesliga and Premier League Teams Collide in Champions League Draw
description: A top-heavy UEFA Champions League increasingly dominated by the same top clubs from the same top leagues is finding it increasingly hard to keep them away from one another.

title: Conservative Party Lawmaker Defects to Anti-Europe Party in Britain
description: LONDON  A British lawmaker with strongly anti-European views defected from the governing Conservative Party on Thursday to join the U.K. Independence Party, dealing an embarrassing blow to Prime Minister David Cameron.

title: When a Customer Has Two Reasons to Say Ouch
description: As a fictional construct, the Haggler does not have worries associated with the corporeal world. Like body hair. Sometimes this can seem like a very lucky break.

title: A Book for Children, and Others, by Bruce Springsteen
description: Bruce Springsteen has joined what is by now a long parade of rock stars (including Keith Richards, three of the Beatles, and Jimmy Buffett) who have written childrens books  or at least, what look like childrens books.

title: No Invitation Necessary
description: Branches twine above. Balkan folk-punk pulses below. The mural on the back wall is a postcard writ large, of a cave monastery a millennium old, transplanted from the cliffs along the Dniester River to a utilitarian strip of Midwood, Brooklyn. The tablecloths are red and the chairs hooded in brocade, and every table seems to seat at least eight.

title: New Study Offers Clues to Swift Arctic Extinction
description: Seven hundred years ago, the Dorset people disappeared from the Arctic. The last of the Paleo-Eskimos, the Dorset had dominated eastern Canada and Greenland for centuries, hunting seal and walrus through holes in the ice and practicing shamanistic rituals with ornate carvings and masks.

title: Horror Is a Constant, as Artists Depict War
description: LENS, France  The nightmare images come one after another: Three women, half-clothed, one with her legs spread open, lie on the floor, apparently raped; the naked body of a decapitated man hangs from a tree branch, his severed head stuck on a shorter branch; a man hauls a dead woman by her legs, her dress flipped up, exposing her underwear.

title: Will a Gun Retailer Get Away With Negligence?
description: Dawn Nguyen was scheduled to be sentenced today in federal court for knowingly acting as a straw purchaser of assault weapons that were used in 2012 to kill two firefighters and wound two others, among other victims, in Webster, N.Y. But late yesterday, her lawyer argued successfully for a delay to challenge the prosecutions request for a stiffer sentence than the 18 months to two years called for by federal guidelines.

title: In Sickness and in Health
description: He was already sitting on the examination table when I walked into the room, and he looked smaller than I had ever seen him. Perhaps it was the way he held his shoulders, or how he didnt quite meet my gaze. I took his nonverbal cues and greeted him quietly.

title: Outbreak in Sierra Leone Is Tied to Single Funeral Where 14 Women Were Infected
description: Sierra Leones explosion of Ebola cases in early summer appears to stem from one traditional healers funeral at which 14 women were infected, according to scientists studying the blood of victims.

title: The Playful God of a Manic Valhalla
description: You may not know the name Chuck Jones, but you surely know his progeny Wile E. Coyote, the Road Runner and Elmer Fudd. And you certainly know the antic creatures fathered by others whom Jones adopted, including Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. One of the great creators of animated cartoons in the predigital era, Mr. Jones is the subject of Whats Up, Doc? The Animation Art of Chuck Jones at the Museum of the Moving Image.

title: Even Amid Swirling Winds, Serena Williams Coasts Into Third Round
description: It became apparent early in Serena Williamss second-round match Thursday at the United States Open that she was not going to be yielding the title of top American anytime soon. As Williams battled the swirling winds of Arthur Ashe Stadium, growing annoyed with the conditions and occasionally with herself, the young American on the other side of the net remained less bothersome than a speed bump.

title: Uber and Lyft Have Become Indistinguishable Commodities
description: If you need a ride, pull out your phone and load up the Lyft app. Or try Uber. Really, it doesnt matter which you pick.

title: Shell Submits a Plan for New Exploration of Alaskan Arctic Oil
description: Royal Dutch Shell submitted a plan to the federal government on Thursday to try once again to explore for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, following years of legal and logistical setbacks as well as dogged opposition from environmentalists.

title: Erdogan Is Sworn In as President of Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys former prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was sworn in Thursday as the countrys first directly elected president, a position from which he is expected to continue to exercise power for at least another five years.

title: Charlie Palmer Rethinks His Empire
description: For 26 years, the chef and restaurateur Charlie Palmer has kept his flagship Aureole a success, even after he moved it from the Upper East Side to Midtown in 2009. During that time, he also planted his flag across the land, on properties from the California wine country and the gambling meccas of Nevada to Dallas and Washington, D.C.

title: Drug-Selling Charges Dropped Against Man Arrested in Philip Seymour Hoffman Case
description: The Manhattan district attorney on Thursday dropped all charges related to the sale of drugs against Robert Aaron, a musician and a friend of the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman who had been arrested and charged with intent to sell heroin just days after Mr. Hoffmans fatal drug overdose in February.

title: Fantasy Football: Analyzing Draft Tiers With Advanced Statistics
description: Applying a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com, the algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. See the charts here.

title: As Ebola Grips Liberias Capital, a Quarantine Sows Social Chaos
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Some people are swimming in and out of the Ebola quarantine zone in this seaside capital. One man slips out every day to reach his job at a Western embassy. Another has turned his living room into a tollbooth, charging others to escape through his apartment at the edge of the cordoned area. Countless others have used a different method: bribing their way out with fees that soldiers determine according to a persons appearance, circumstances and even gender.

title: The Stuff of Life, Urgently Altered
description: David Hammonss African American Flag  with its Pan-African red and black stripes and green field of black stars  floats high over the sidewalk outside the Studio Museum in Harlem. Originally created nearly a quarter-century ago, it has become an identifying emblem for a museum dedicated to nurturing the careers of artists of African descent.

title: Accounting for the Expanding Carbon Shadow From Coal-Burning Plants
description: Steven Davis of the University of California, Irvine, and Robert Socolow of Princeton (best known for his work dividing the climate challenge into carbon wedges) have written Commitment accounting of CO2emissions,a valuable new paperinEnvironmental Research Letters showing the value of shifting from tracking annual emissions of carbon dioxide from power plants to weighing the full amount of carbon dioxide that such plants, burning coal or gas, could emit during their time in service.

title: Taking the Crown, Then Taking Orders
description: BACK when I still watched the Miss America pageant, I saw Kate Shindle win in September 1997. She was a student at Northwestern University who competed as Miss Illinois on the platform of AIDS education  a dynamo, burning with smarts and passion.

title: Questions for IBMs Watson
description: Sometimes, figuring out the right question is harder than finding the answer. Just ask Watson.

title: Forming Attachments Near and Far
description: One of the most unforeseen benefits of living with cancer is the intimacy it creates with individuals we barely know. Affections spring up with surprising force.

title: Missing Americans Body Found Near Jerusalem, Israeli Police Say
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli police said a body found on Thursday in a forest on the outskirts of Jerusalem was that of an American student who went missing while hiking in the area last Friday.

title: New Cycle Begins as Klinsmann Picks U.S. Team
description: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann on Thursday picked 22 players for the United States mens national teams first game since the World Cup in Brazil  a match against the Czech Republic in Prague on Wednesday (2:15 p.m., Eastern, NBC Sports Network).

title: Vivendi Looks Out for Its Shareholders in Talks for Its Brazil Unit
description: Vincent Bollor, Vivendis chairman, is doing right by his shareholders. Vivendi says it has entered exclusive talks with Telefnica on its 7.5 billion-euro ($9.8 billion) bid for Vivendis Brazilian business, GVT. The French conglomerate spurned a lower bid from Telecom Italia. It might have squeezed a bit more from Telefnica, but has chosen the surest exit. That leaves Telecom Italia facing an uncertain future.

title: A Brooklyn Dining Institution With Roots in Both Italy and a Great Love
description: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out whats new with the people behind them.

title: At Peabody Essex, 300 Years of Indian Chintzes
description: AN EXOTIC FABRIC THROUGH THE AGES

title: Two Roosevelts and Their Legacies
description: The loss of Robin Williams was especially poignant for the Miser household, whose members happen to be big fans of Ben Stillers Night at the Museum franchise, in which Mr. Williams played an equestrian statue of Theodore Roosevelt come to life, serving as guide and foil to Mr. Stillers security guard protagonist.

title: N.F.L. Domestic Violence Policy Toughened in Wake of Ray Rice Case
description: In a rare mea culpa, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Thursday that he had mishandled the Ray Rice case, in which the Baltimore Ravens running back was suspended for two games after being accused of assaulting his fiance.

title: Judges Ruling Could Affect Bondholders in Corporate Bankruptcies
description: A federal bankruptcy judges ruling in a closely watched corporate case seems to have made the distressed debt market a bit unhinged.

title: Critics Question High Ratings on New York State Teacher Evaluations Amid Poor Test Scores
description: New York State released teacher and principal evaluations on Thursday that for the first time allow parents and administrators to assess the effectiveness of local teachers at the county, district and, in some cases, the school level.

title: A Long Life Lived in the Shadow of Others
description: PHILADELPHIA  Since the publication of Linda Nochlins groundbreaking 1971 essay, Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?, feminist art historians have worked hard to rescue forgotten female figures from oblivion. One interesting candidate for recovery is offered by a traveling exhibition now at the Woodmere Art Museum here. Theresa Bernstein: A Century in Art presents more than 50 paintings dating from 1912 to 1972. Its the first retrospective ever dedicated to Ms. Bernstein (1890-2002), who came of age during the heyday of early-20th-century American realism.

title: A Womans Journey From Vienna, and the Nazis, and Back
description: The documentary Shadows From My Past grew out of an earlier project in which Gita Weinrauch Kaufman, who directed with her husband, Curt Kaufman (he died in 2011), shared letters from family members, many of whom were killed by the Nazis. As a young girl, Ms. Kaufman escaped Vienna for New York. In Shadows From My Past, she returns to Austria to see what has changed.

title: A New American Oil Bonanza
description: THREE RIVERS, Tex.  Whenever overseas turmoil has pushed energy prices higher in the past, John and Beth Hughes have curbed their driving by eating at home more and shopping locally. But the current crises in Ukraine and Iraq did not stop them from making the two-hour drive to San Antonio to visit the Alamo, have a chicken fried steak lunch, and buy fish for their tank before driving home to Corpus Christi.

title: Wheelies: The Swift Sorento Sales Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Into a Lava-Lined Underworld Near Albuquerque
description: The green plastic helmet I took off the rack looked a lot like a construction hard hat, except for the logo of a bat printed on the front.

title: A Japanese Fable Hinges on 180 Degrees of Separation
description: An orphaned girl and a fatherless boy bridge opposing societies in Patema Inverted, a delightful animated fable from Yasuhiro Yoshiura.

title: Eric Decker High School Highlights
description: A compilation of highlights from Deckers playing days at Rocori High School, courtesy of the teams coach, Joel Baumgarten.

title: Law Boosts Oversight of Use of Solitary Confinement at Rikers Island
description: In the wake of growing criticism over conditions at Rikers Island, Mayor Bill de Blasio enacted legislation on Thursday to boost oversight of the use of solitary confinement at the jail.

title: Come to Granny. On Second Thought, Better Not.
description: THE DAMNED

title: Waiting Patiently for the Wall to Crumble
description: I met him on the bus. The No. 9 was my daily commute from the University District of Seattle to the Rainier Valley, where I worked in an overcrowded elementary school. Because I got on early in the route, I always settled in the back, a prime people-watching spot as we traveled through Seattles varied neighborhoods.

title: On Flings and Friends
description: An old friend has a perennial problem being faithful to girlfriends. His current mate, whom he met while cheating on his former girlfriend, recently discovered a number of his dalliances. She decided to stay with him, but asked me to stop being friends with one of the women he cheated with. (I was not aware of the affair while it was going on, if that matters.) Trouble is, I am not that close with the girlfriend, but Ive become quite friendly with the woman Ive been asked to drop. Thoughts?

title: Trailing an Artist Who Lost His Way
description: Chief Inspector Armand Gamache, the brooding, wounded protagonist in Louise Pennys splendid series of mystery novels, has officially shed his professional title in her latest book, The Long Way Home. He has left the Montreal police force after an (almost literally) explosive confrontation with corrupt elements that had been poisoning the force from within. Gamache emerged triumphant, but not unbloodied, in Ms. Pennys last book, How the Light Gets In, which was perhaps her most sensationally plotted, reaching its climax in the foiling of a terrorist act that would have claimed thousands of lives.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: In Season of 63 Losses So Far, Yankees Find Few as Agonizing as This One
description: DETROIT  The Yankees sat in silence, eating their postgame meals or sitting at their lockers, staring at their phones, perhaps searching for solace. For several minutes, though, after an agonizing loss, they seemed as inconsolable as they had been all season.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, China, Malta and India.

title: Two Viewers, Two Countries, Two Points of Focus
description: NEW HAVEN  Bruce Davidson/Paul Caponigro: Two American Photographers in Britain and Ireland, at the Yale Center for British Art, is a strange but memorable pairing. It joins the Magnum photojournalist Bruce Davidson, best known for his aggressive New York street and subway photography, to a spiritually minded landscape photographer in the mold of Ansel Adams and Minor White. And although its title suggests some shared expatriate experience, a split quickly develops.

title: Obama Urges Calm in Face of Crises in Ukraine and Syria
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama confronted a pair of volatile international crises with restraint on Thursday as he said he was not close to authorizing airstrikes against Islamic extremists in Syria and played down the latest escalation of Russias military intervention in Ukraine.

title: Books Are Like Football, Only Safer
description: The first hardcover book I bought with my own money was Fighting Back: The Rocky Bleier Story (1975), published the week I turned 10.

title: A Friendship in Limbo
description: JAMIE MARKS IS DEAD

title: A Summer Favorite, Now Growing on the East Coast: Grilled Artichokes With Salsa Verde
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Standout Wine Lists in New York City
description: Great wine lists dont need to be epic length. They dont require classic, expensive bottles. And they dont appear only in conventional places; some of the best, in fact, show up where you least expect them.

title: President Obamas Personal Chef
description: Since 2009, Sam Kass, the presidents personal chef, has become a prominent East Wing figure in the news media. A sampling of some of his recent appearances.

title: Irish Panel to Pick a Regulator With Global Reach in Overseeing Data Privacy
description: In the coming weeks, an Irish government committee is set to pick the countrys new data privacy regulator, a relatively obscure position but one with global sway.

title: Juggling Worlds
description: I dont summon anything up, protests Holly Sykes, the down-to-earth protagonist of The Bone Clocks, David Mitchells latest head-spinning flight into other dimensions. Voices just . . . nab me. Shes trying to explain to a skeptical, curmudgeonly English writer how she occasionally falls out of time and sees whats going to happen next. Embarrassed about her gift  shes just a regular daughter of the owner of the Captain Marlow pub in Gravesend, Kent  and reluctant to credit such way-out ideas as precognition, she goes on, Oh, Christ, I cant avoid the terminology, however crappy it sounds: I was channeling some sentience that was lingering in the fabric of that place.

title: A Setting Sun at the End of the Dock
description: A Chekhovian spirit hovers overLast Weekend,about a Labor Day family gathering at a vast estate on Lake Tahoe in California. Celia (Patricia Clarkson) and Malcolm (Chris Mulkey) are parents to Theo (Zachary Booth), a gay screenwriter, and Roger (Joseph Cross), a caustic financier. Theo bickers with his boyfriend, Luke (Devon Graye), while Roger tangles with his wife (Alexia Rasmussen) over an office scandal. Theo has also invited another couple and a TV star (a skillful Jayma Mays, from Glee), who dallies with Roger.

title: Oklahoma Loses Waiver From No Child Left Behind Provisions
description: As a result of its retreat from Common Core, a set of reading and math standards adopted by more than 40 states, Oklahoma was notified Thursday that it lost its waiver from key provisions of No Child Left Behind, the signature Bush-era education law.

title: The Delusions We Deserve
description: Joel Gold first observed the Truman Show delusion  in which people believe they are the involuntary subjects of a reality television show whose producers are scripting the vicissitudes of their lives  on Halloween night 2003 at Bellevue Hospital, where he was the chief attending psychiatrist. Suspicious Minds, which he wrote with his brother, Ian, an associate professor of philosophy and psychology at McGill University, is an attempt to use this delusion, which has been observed by many clinicians, to pose questions that have gone out of fashion in psychiatry over the last half-century: Why does a mentally ill person have the delusions he or she has? And, following the lead of the medical historian Roy Porter, who once wrote that every age gets the lunatics it deserves, what can we learn about ourselves and our times from examining the content of madness?

title: White-Hot, Illicit Passion and All the Trouble It Causes
description: HUDSON, N.Y.  Ah, the sudsy thrill of watching shallow people drowning in deep waters! This dubious pleasure is one I associate with summer  with glossy movies viewed furtively in air-conditioned theaters and books about the randy rich read through sunglasses on beach towels.

title: Not Quite 76 Trombones, but More Than Usual
description: Ten trombonists walk onto a barge. It sounds like the start of a joke, and probably not a good one. But no, it was David Taylor and the New York Trombone Consort, assembling for the premiere of Mr. Taylors The Banned Bamboozler for bass trombone and trombone orchestra.

title: The Story Behind the Photos
description: The documentary is a little long for its type and has some structural problems, but you cant deny the power of the photographs in Dorothea Lange: Grab a Hunk of Lightning, an American Masters episode Friday night on PBS.

title: Nods to the 1960s, Straight-Ahead Jazz and Brazilian Pop
description: Annette Peacock

title: On the Ground in Israel and Gaza
description: Two photographers captured scenes from the most recent outbreak of war.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Life of Crime
description: Daniel Schechter narrates a sequence from his film Life of Crime.

title: Editors Note: How We Thought About Our Photo Essay on Israel and Gaza
description: As any depiction of the conflict between Israel and Gaza has the potential to stir controversy and raise questions, I offer this note as a window into some of the thinking behind the photo essay by Paolo Pellegrin and Peter van Agtmael in the Aug. 31 issue of The New York Times Magazine. Toward the end of July, we began talking to Paolo and Peter about going into Gaza and Israel, respectively, to make some pictures. We had noticed that during this summers outbreak of violence, the prevalence of cellphone cameras and social media led to many more images of Gaza than in previous iterations of this long-running conflict. This imagery made the cost of war visually appreciable in a way that it had not been even as recently as 2009. Yet as powerful as these photos were, the speed and fervor of their dissemination tended to bring them to us isolated from context. Paolo and Peter, working more slowly, could try to capture a deeper and more narrative sense of the texture of life on the ground.

title: Leader Calls on Military to End Crisis in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani Army stepped into the countrys two-week-old political crisis on Thursday when Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif requested that the army chief, Gen. Raheel Sharif, help defuse a standoff that has crippled the government.

title: California Power Substation Attacked in 2013 Is Struck Again
description: The Silicon Valley power substation that was attacked by a sniper in April 2013 was hit by thieves early Wednesday morning, according to the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, despite increased security.

title: Tony Soprano Lives! Or Maybe Not
description: HBOs The Sopranos ended with one of the most infamous cliffhangers in television history a suddencut to black.

title: Troubled Children, Baring Their Psychic Pain
description: The title of The Naked Room (El Cuarto Desnudo) doesnt lie: This documentary from Nuria Ibez takes place almost entirely in an office at a childrens psychiatric hospital in Mexico City. Nearly all of what we see consists of patients, typically framed in head-and-shoulders shots, sharing their thoughts. Asking persistent questions, the doctors remain unseen. Parents occasionally appear but mostly speak from off camera.

title: Enduring War and Adults Cruelty
description: There is something irresistible  and also something questionable  about the artistic impulse to filter fictional accounts of real-world horror through the eyes of children. The juxtaposition of innocence and cruelty, of a nave ignorance of political causes with a vivid understanding of their human effect, can refresh and deepen our perception of past atrocities. But there are risks, too: of sentimentality, of vagueness and of a wide-eyed navet that mystifies events we have an ethical duty to see as clearly as possible. For every Pans Labyrinth, which mines archetypes and fairy tales to unearth the hidden truth of Spanish fascism, there is The Boy in the Striped Pajamas, which turns the Holocaust into maudlin kiddie-kitsch.

title: Daniel Schechter Narrates a Scene From Life of Crime
description: In this video, the director Daniel Schechter discusses a moment from Life of Crime, the film adaptation of the Elmore Leonard novel The Switch. The scene  which features Jennifer Aniston, Will Forte, John Hawkes and Yasiin Bey (previously known as Mos Def)  involves a kidnapping that is interrupted by a romantic gesture.

title: Always Let Them See You Sweat
description: Overshare doesnt begin to cover the behavior of Carla Juris teenage character, Helen, in Wetlands. Within minutes, we learn about Helens body odor, a raunchy snack-stand tryst and her unusual approach to public toilet seats. The coming-of-age comedy, which adapts Charlotte Roches scatological memoirlike novel, is a mothers nightmare, but Ms. Juri brings a fresh sense of mischief and a touching vulnerability to the role.

title: Alice in All Its Teenage Subconscious
description: Just a few years back, it seemed as if evening-length ballets with detailed story lines were a thing of the past, a relic of the pre-postmodern imagination. Athleticism and abstraction were in; plot points and well-defined characters were out. Thus, the announcement, in 2010, that the Royal Ballet, with the National Ballet of Canada, had commissioned Christopher Wheeldon to create a new ballet based on Alice in Wonderland was greeted with a flurry of interest, and some eye rolling.

title: A Swordsman to the End
description: The Last of Robin Hood takes place during the final two years of Errol Flynns life, when his stardom and health had waned, but his ardor for girls had not. As played by Kevin Kline with an almost disconcerting low-key openness, Flynn trades on his name recognition with an earnest, self-deprecating manner, though that is itself a form of entitlement. A go-between reaches out first to 15-year-old Beverly Aadland (Dakota Fanning), who is invited to a play audition in a country house borrowed for the purpose, which is not to audition. (In 1943 Flynn was acquitted of statutory rape in a case whose notoriety stuck.)

title: Dance: Fleeting Onstage, Forever on DVD
description: Alastair Macaulay

title: HUD Reverse Mortgages for Co-ops Unlikely
description: A long-awaited regulatory change that would open up the federal governments reverse mortgage program to co-ops is unlikely to happen, presenting a problem for older New Yorkers.

title: A Sukkot Special in Orlando
description: Sticking to a kosher diet on the road can be challenging, but Prime Hospitality Group, a New York City-based glatt kosher restaurant and catering company, is trying to make it easier by partnering with luxury resorts around the country for Jewish holidays.

title: Felicity Jones in Modest, Modern Miu Miu at the 2014 Venice Film Festival
description: The Star: Felicity Jones

title: Spare Times for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Labor Day Weekend

title: In Defense of the Knee Defender
description: I have a set of Knee Defenders, the devices that hook onto the tray table of an airliner seat back and prevent the seat from reclining.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Two Murders, Many Plot Twists
description: As head of a police station in a small town in Ontario, Hazel Micallef (Susan Sarandon) doesnt see many murders. When two victims turn up in close succession  one nearly decapitated, the others disgorged stomach gnawed at by dogs in the snow  Hazel assumes, to paraphrase Marge Gunderson from the film Fargo, that the cases just might be connected.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Back to School at the Paley Center for Media

title: Its a Jungle Out There, Behind Enemy Lines
description: While not much is said in the Australian director Aaron Wilsons small-scale first feature, Canopy, the film conveys volumes about war and humanity. It is an immersive experience akin to J. C. Chandors All Is Lost and Alfonso Cuarns Gravity, though our hero is facing off against not only nature but also man.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop & Rock Music Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Fears and Desires, a Missing Wife and Lots of Blood
description: Enervatingly synthetic, The Strange Color of Your Bodys Tears slices and dices the images and tropes of Italian giallo-style slasher films into an inert pile of style. The directors Hlne Cattet and Bruno Forzani one-up their similarly referential debut feature, Amer (2010), by thoroughly disfiguring a story of a man whose wife goes missing.

title: Taser Use in Arrest Leads to Suit in Georgia
description: ATLANTA  More than four months after a 24-year-old man died following an arrest in which the police used Taser devices on him up to 13 times, his family Thursday filed a wrongful-death suit against the Atlanta suburb of East Point and two of its former officers.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: 2015 Subaru Outback 3.6R Limited
description: The family-friendly, wildnerness-friendly Subaru Outback continues down the same path with upgraded gear.

title: Mayor Announces Pre-K Figures
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that 50,407 children have been enrolled in full-day prekindergarten for this fall, up from 20,000 last year. He called the expansion his No. 1 platform agenda.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Husband of Kidnap Victim: Take My Wife, Please
description: LIFE OF CRIME

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 29
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes a Staten Island march that drew thousands and Ganesha Chaturthi celebrations.

title: A Miracle Drug or Quackery?
description: When your public relations guy starts describing you as diabolical, theres a problem. Ralph W. Moss, the center of Eric Merolas documentary Second Opinion: Laetrile at Sloan-Kettering, was that guy, working in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Centers public affairs department in the 1970s. He loved the job until the men at the top did something odd: They traveled to Washington to seek research funding for a promising new treatment, then changed their minds  collectively, unequivocally and overnight.

title: Few Thrills, but More Frills
description: SUGAR HILL, N.H.  In 2010, with middle age fading in the rearview mirror, Practical Adult Syndrome struck my wife and me. The telling symptom: the purchase of our first boring car, a 2011 Subaru Outback.

title: Ahmed Seif al-Islam Hamad, Pioneering Rights Lawyer, Mourned by Egyptian Activists
description: Egyptians who continue to fight for the goals of their 2011 revolution, even after most of its gains have been undone, were in mourning Thursday as they buried the pioneering human rights lawyer Ahmed Seif al-Islam Hamad.

title: The Robin Hoods of Ancient Korea
description: With its swooping close-ups, Ennio Morricone-lite score and horseback riders heading into a sunset, Kundo: Age of the Rampant could be a western. But its a martial arts spectacle, set in 1859 and loaded with familiar elements, including a corrupt ruler, a motley bandit gang stealing from the rich to feed the poor, and, of course, a revenge story. But the movie looks great, its visual details bearing a dusty polish.

title: Barclays Agrees to Lend Detroit $275 Million to Exit Bankruptcy
description: Barclays Capital has agreed to provide $275 million to finance Detroits operations as it comes out of bankruptcy, according to documents filed in bankruptcy court.

title: The Strange Color of Your Bodys Tears
description: A scene from the film.

title: Obamas Priorities for Fighting ISIS
description: At a news conference at the White House, President Obama discussed his strategy for combating the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Obama on Russian Culpability in Ukraine
description: President Obama said at a news conference that while he would continue to pressure Russia, he did not foresee a military confrontation between Russia and the United States.

title: A Gay Haven on Fire Island
description: Susan Kravitzs photos from Cherry Grove eschew the sun and surf in favor of documenting the gay men and women who flock there each summer.

title: Hillary Clinton Praises Obama on Ferguson Response and Echoes Call for Inquiry
description: Nearly three weeks after the shooting of Michael Brown prompted widespread protests in a St. Louis suburb and a national examination of race and police tactics, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday praised President Obamas response to the episode and called for a swift investigation into the circumstances that led to the unarmed black teenagers death.

title: Too Much Salt, or Not Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Move Toward More Abortion Restrictions
Ethical on Food Supply
description: To the Editor:

title: Safer Garbage Collection
description: To the Editor:

title: Carmen Faria: An Old-School Abuela
description: As chancellor of the New York City Education Department, the largest school district in the country, Carmen Faria, 71, will have the daunting task of overseeing about 1.1 million students when they return to school on Sept. 4. But on weekends Ms. Faria is first and foremost an active and engaged grandmother. Two of her grandsons, Charlie, 10, and Ben, 8, sleep over every weekend at the Brooklyn waterfront apartment she has shared with her husband, Antonio, 74, for 15 years. The Farias have both lived in and around Cobble Hill since they were born.

title: In China, Dueling Scholarship Programs From Billionaires
description: Higher education has a new trans-Pacific rivalry: billionaires scholarship funds.

title: End the Tyranny of 24/7 Email
description: THIS Labor Day weekend, odds are youll peek at your work email on your day off  and then feel guilty about it.

title: Businesses Are Winning Cat-and-Mouse Tax Game
description: A pharmaceutical company moved its headquarters to Ireland, sharply reducing its tax rate. A billboard company reclassified itself as a real estate concern, meaning it will no longer pay corporate taxes. And a big oil producer split itself in two, cleaving off a multibillion-dollar division that now operates tax-free.

title: The Truth About Down Syndrome
description: LAST week the biologist Richard Dawkins sparked controversy when, in response to a womans hypothetical question about whether to carry to term a child with Down syndrome, he wrote on Twitter: Abort it and try again. It would be immoral to bring it into the world if you have the choice.

title: The Fall of France
description: Franois Hollande, the president of France since 2012, coulda been a contender. He was elected on a promise to turn away from the austerity policies that killed Europes brief, inadequate economic recovery. Since the intellectual justification for these policies was weak and would soon collapse, he could have led a bloc of nations demanding a change of course. But it was not to be. Once in office, Mr. Hollande promptly folded, giving in completely to demands for even more austerity.

title: Lawyer Seeks to Reinstate Suit Over Alleged Abuse Cover-Up at Yeshiva High
description: A lawyer for dozens of men who say they were sexually abused as high school students by rabbis at Yeshiva University High School for Boys in Manhattan asked a federal appeals court on Thursday to reinstate a lawsuit claiming that the school had covered up the misconduct for decades.

title: Incident Report from East Point, Ga., Police Dept.
description: This report, provided by lawyers representing the family of Gregory Towns Jr., includes the testimony of the officers present when Mr. Towns was apprehended and struck with a Taser. The Times has redacted graphic language in one sentence.

title: Theme Park Offers Respite for War-Weary Iraqis
description: ZAKHO, Iraq  Just over the final mountain pass leading to this beleaguered town in Iraqi Kurdistan, a blinding array of lights dazzles in the distance.

title: Obama Wore a Tan Suit (and Spoke About World Crises)
description: Let no one say male politicians do not experience sartorial scrutiny and criticism just as their female colleagues do.

title: Injected Drugs Said to Kill Man in Flawed Execution
description: Clayton D. Lockett, the prisoner whose prolonged writhing during his execution on April 29 led Oklahoma to suspend executions and caused national questioning of lethal injection methods, was killed by the injected drugs and not by a heart attack as state officials originally announced, according to a state-commissioned autopsy report released Thursday.

title: With Gaza War, Movement to Boycott Israel Gains Momentum in Europe
description: LONDON  A branch of Sainsburys grocery store removed kosher products from its shelves, it said, to prevent anti-Israel demonstrations. The Tricycle Theater in north London, after hosting a Jewish film festival for eight years, demanded to vet the content of any film made with arts funding from the Israeli government. George Galloway, a member of Parliament known for his vehement criticism of Israel, declared Bradford, England, an Israel-free zone.

title: In China, Detecting Fraud Riskier Than Doing It
description: It can be very risky to do things in China that are taken for granted in other countries.

title: Little Rest for McIlroy Before the Ryder Cup
description: NORTON, Mass.  Rory McIlroy turned 25 in May and is playing the best golf of his career. He said he briefly considered taking a week off to rest for next months Ryder Cup, as three of his 30-something teammates are doing this week. He just as quickly dismissed it.

title: What Doctors Cant Do
description: Mary White makes house calls. Shes a senior community health worker in Philadelphia in the IMPaCT program at the Penn Center for Community Health Workers. She has 25 of the University of Pennsylvania Health Systems toughest patients. Its her job to help them set health goals and, step by step, carry them out.

title: The Mental Virtues
description: We all know what makes for good character in soldiers. Weve seen the movies about heroes who display courage, loyalty and coolness under fire. But what about somebody who sits in front of a keyboard all day? Is it possible to display and cultivate character if you are just an information age office jockey, alone with a memo or your computer?

title: Homegrown Terrorists and the West
An Israeli App Tracking the Gaza Conflict Has Followers Near and Far
description: JERUSALEM  Many Israelis and, especially, their supporters abroad, experienced the intensity of this summers long battle against Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip primarily the way they do so much of modern life: on their smartphones. Every day of the fighting  sometimes every hour or multiple times a minute  their phones flashed, or sounded a siren, signaling each of the more than 4,200 rockets flying toward Israel from Gaza.

title: Google Joins Amazon in Dreams of Drone Delivery
description: Related:

title: Paying Homage to an Illustrator From the Industrys Golden Era
description: AN artist whose work is emblematic of what was once a golden age of illustration on Madison Avenue is being celebrated with a coming retrospective at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Evictions Soar in Hot Market; Renters Suffer
description: MILWAUKEE  Just after 7 a.m., sheriffs deputies knocked on the door of the duplex apartment, holding a fluorescent orange eviction notice. The process was quick and efficient. A moving crew began to carry out the familys possessions and stack them neatly at the curb. Celeste Wilson, the tenant, appeared on the front step in pajama pants.

title: Anonymous Site Spurs Talks Between Nikki Finke and Ex-Boss
description: The journalist Nikki Finke has long struck fear into the hearts of Hollywood executives and entertainers, publishing a blend of vitriol and scoops on her blog Deadline Hollywood.

title: This Weeks Movies | Aug. 29, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Starred Up, Through a Lens Darkly and The Notebook (Le Grand Cahier).

title: Roger Goodell and N.F.L. Right a Wrong, but Only After Further Review
description: The most stunning aspect of the N.F.L.s new policy on domestic violence is that the league, through Commissioner Roger Goodell, admitted that it had made a mistake.

title: With His Parents Home at Risk, Atlantic City Piano Man Prepares for a Fight
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Anyone who has played Monopoly knows that Oriental Avenue is in a low-rent neighborhood of this surf-and-slots town, whose street names were borrowed in the 1930s by the makers of the game.

title: Pennsylvania to Purchase Private Care for Its Poor
description: WASHINGTON  Pennsylvania will become the 27th state to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration announced Thursday, using federal funds to buy private health insurance for about 500,000 low-income residents starting next year.

title: Events on Long Island for Aug. 31-Sept. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Fixated on Every Pitch, Victor Martinez Helps the Tigers Stay Focused
description: DETROIT  Victor Martinez was not on base to score the winning run Thursday when shadows crept over the right-field fence at Comerica Park. Martinez was removed for a pinch-runner after doubling through the infield shift to start the bottom of the ninth. A backup catcher, Bryan Holaday, crossed the plate to end the Detroit Tigers 3-2 victory over the Yankees. The Tigers manager, Brad Ausmus, deemed Holaday a better use of legs than Martinez.

title: A Childs Visit to the Gun Range
description: One moment, the 9-year-old girls parent was proudly recording video of her recreational adventure at an Arizona gun range  the childs very first firing of a live Uzi submachine gun, a powerful weapon designed for war that shoots 10 bullets per second.

title: An Ominous Ebola Forecast
description: The World Health Organization warned on Thursday that the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, already the largest outbreak ever recorded, is going to get much worse over the next six months, the shortest window in which it might conceivably be brought under control. By then, the organization said, the virus could infect more than 20,000 people, almost seven times the current number of reported cases.

title: The Ones Who Were Left Behind
description: The end was crazy, like so much of the war itself.

title: Mr. Putin Tests the West in Ukraine
description: The evidence has been mounting for some time, but there is no longer any doubt: Russian troops are in Ukraine, not as volunteers, as the rebel commander in Donetsk would have the world believe, but in units equipped with mobile artillery and heavy military equipment.

title: No Pension Until Miguel Martinez, an Ex-New York Councilman, Pays Back Stolen Funds
description: Making good on a new policy of going after the pensions of corrupt public officials, the United States attorney in Manhattan announced on Thursday that Miguel Martinez, a former New York City councilman convicted in a federal corruption case, had agreed to forfeit his city pension until he pays back $106,000 that he stole.

title: Drugs, Beats and Other 1950s Perils
description: Nothing is what it seems in the joyously ersatz High School Confidential!, a 1958 exploitation film produced by Albert Zugsmith, newly available from Olive Films on Blu-ray and DVD.

title: Events in New Jersey for Aug. 31-Sept. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Glad to Try Something Terrifying
description: Samuel Beckett said, A writer who explains his writing is like a snail explaining his shell, the playwright Israel Horovitz recounted one steamy August morning.

title: As Blackwater Trial Closes, Focus Turns to Moments Before Chaos
description: WASHINGTON  When jurors begin deliberating next week in the murder and manslaughter trial of four former Blackwater Worldwide contractors, so much will depend not on the frenzied minutes of heavy gunfire in the busy Nisour Square in Baghdad, but on the moments of relative calm just before the chaos.

title: Wild Rides to Inner Space
description: Twenty years ago, Johnny Depp played the title B-movie director in Tim Burtons frisky biopic Ed Wood. The film introduced the eccentric Wood, then mostly known to fans of cult cinema, to a mainstream audience and renewed interest in his darkly trashy works like the aliens-amok film Plan 9 From Outer Space (1959), a clunker classic that sits on many a list of the worst movies ever made.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 28, 2014
New Flag and, She Hopes, Fortunes
description: While most players ignore their introduction by the chair umpire, one player at the United States Open recently paused to listen to hers.

title: U.S. Identifies Citizens Joining Rebels in Syria, Including ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence and law enforcement agencies have identified nearly a dozen Americans who have traveled to Syria to fight for the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the militant group that the Obama administration says poses the greatest threat to the United States since Al Qaeda before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

title: In U.S. Open Match Featuring Three Juniors, a Seniors Experience Shows
description: A late-arriving spectator to Court 4 on Thursday was puzzled at the mens doubles match before her.

title: Events in Westchester for Aug. 31-Sept. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Sam Kass, the Obamas Foodmaster General
description: WASHINGTON  Back in 2005, when President Obama was a mere freshman senator, his wife, Michelle, found herself overwhelmed with the stress of being a full-time working mother, largely alone in her Chicago home, with two daughters who got sick a little too often. Sluggish and above her fighting weight, she wondered if her familys diet  lots of prepared food and a few too many Cheetos  might need an adjustment.

title: For a Band of Steel-Pan Drummers, Summer Means Practice, Practice, Practice
description: Their racks of steel-pan drums strung together, the musicians of the Despers USA band trudged alongside as the entire operation  drum racks, stage, cooking tent, portable toilet  rolled down Washington Avenue in Brooklyn last weekend. They were under tremendous pressure, but there was no way to rush to their new home with that teetering cargo.

title: Cool Red Giant
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Well, this was a trip and a half. As someone who has a poor memory for names, I struggled with this one. I dont mind proper names in a puzzle, and I dont even mind a lot of proper names in a puzzle, but these were a lot of proper names that were not in my wheelhouse. Fortunately, there was some entertaining cluing in Daniel Raymons grid to help keep me going.

title: Events in Connecticut for Aug. 31-Sept. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: U.S. Open 2014: CiCi Bellis, the Toast of the Tournament, Goes Home
description: There was live tennis inside Arthur Ashe Stadium on Thursday night, but fans began to filter out as word spread about the match over on Court 17. Soon enough, the South Plaza was clogged with people, all of whom were craning their necks for a view of the huge video board on the stadiums south facade.

title: Air Encounter More Likely to Cause Alarm Than Change
description: BEIJING  Although China and the United States have long been at odds over American surveillance flights near Chinese territory, the all-too-close encounter of an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter last week has forced both countries to consider the potential for the dispute to escalate disastrously.

title: Construction Is Shut Down at Atlantic Yards Complex
description: The project had started out with so much promise.

title: Mets Are Stifled in Loss to Braves
description: As David Wright first came to bat on Thursday, the sparse crowd at Citi Field lightly applauded.

title: David Rosand, an Art History Scholar Whose Heart Was in Venice, Dies at 75
description: The churches of Venice and the classrooms of Columbia University formed the tent poles of the work of the revered art historian David Rosand, who died at his home in Manhattan on Aug. 8 at 75.

title: Debate Over Jury Instructions at Ex-Governors Trial
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Closing arguments in the corruption trial of former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, are scheduled for Friday after 23 days of testimony that has often played as a soap opera and has drawn wide attention.

title: Jeremiah Healy, Who Created Boston Private Eye, Dies at 66
description: Jeremiah Healy, an acclaimed mystery writer whose best-known creation, the conflicted private investigator John Francis Cuddy, was a Vietnam veteran who solved crimes and confronted sensitive political issues with compassion, wit and the occasional burst of violence, died on Aug. 14 in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 66.

title: Quarantine Creates a New Reality
description: Shortages, suspicion and anger grip a neighborhood in Monrovia, Liberia, where the Ebola outbreak is at its worst.

title: Whom to Cut? For Jets, a Tough Call, and an Easier One
description: PHILADELPHIA  Their final preseason game complete, the Jets can now begin the process of paring their roster to 53 by Saturdays 4 p.m. deadline. Releasing 30 percent of your team is never enjoyable, Coach Rex Ryan says, especially when some of those players have been with him for months, if not years.

title: Manning and Giants Offense Do Little to Soothe Concerns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Coughlin estimated earlier in the week that Eli Manning and the starting offense would be given at least a dozen snaps in the preseason finale against the New England Patriots on Thursday night, hoping that would be enough time for them to show their grasp of the new West Coast attack.

title: Democrats Wary of Benghazi Inquiry Stretching Into 16 Election Season
description: WASHINGTON  A House Republican-led investigation of the 2012 terrorist attack on an American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, will extend well into next year, and possibly beyond, raising concerns among Democrats that Republicans are trying to damage Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential prospects.

title: Texas Hospitals Say Theyve Lost Insured Patients to Urgent Care
description: AUSTIN, Tex.,  Opting to skip the wait at hospital emergency rooms, an increasing number of Texans are choosing to use urgent care centers that are popping up in strip malls and shopping districts.

title: Swelling School Districts Find Costly Way to Put Off the Pain
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In 1994, the Leander school district had 7,200 students and was growing fast. To handle the hundreds of additional students expected in the coming year, the Central Texas district embarked on a building binge, including the construction of its sixth and seventh elementary schools.

title: Public Integrity Without Smell of Politics
description: AUSTIN, Tex.,  Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: A Carribean Beat in Brooklyn
description: Steel-pan players prepare for the Panorama competition in Brooklyn.

title: Word of the Day | reciprocal
description: reciprocal \ri-si-pr-kl\ adjective and noun

title: Irish Hold Out 5th Player
description: The Notre Dame senior Eilar Hardy, a reserve safety, will join four higher-profile players being held out of practice and competition during an investigation into accusations of academic fraud. No other players are expected to be implicated. The players, who include standouts like wide receiver DaVaris Daniels and cornerback KeiVarae Russell, have not been suspended.

title: For All the Hype, Respect the Elders
description: It took some legwork to track the teenagers playing singles at the United States Open on Thursday.

title: Syrian Refugees Surpass 3 Million, U.N. Says
description: GENEVA  The number of refugees from the Syrian civil war has risen above three million, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday, calling the crisis the biggest humanitarian emergency of our era.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 1:30 P.M. (Cinemax) UP IN THE AIR (2009) George Clooney, above, his smile as bright as ever, portrays Ryan Bingham, a corporate assassin  he fires people for a living  and frequent flier who reaches a crossroads when an upstart (Anna Kendrick) tries to change the rules of the game in this film from Jason Reitman. Vera Farmiga is Alex, the fast-moving executive who, for the first time, causes Bingham to rethink his life. Up in the Air is an assertively, and unapologetically, tidy package, from its use of romance to instill some drama into the narrative (the book introduces disease instead) and the mope-rock tunes that Mr. Reitman needlessly overuses, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of the Walter Kirn novel. Still, one of the films pleasures is that its actresses share the frame with Mr. Clooney as equals, not props. The film, chosen by Ms. Dargis as a critics pick, received Oscar nominations for its three leads and Mr. Reitman, as well as a best picture nod.

title: CiCi Belliss Run Elicits Memories of Another Young American, Melanie Oudin
description: Although turn-back-the-clock runs by Jimmy Connors, Andre Agassi and Andy Roddick have captured fans attention at past United States Opens, the imagination typically runs wilder with an unexpected arrival, and the hysteria that follows is exponentially greater when that arrival  like CiCi Bellis this year  is an American.

title: Never Rich Enough
description: On an evening during the last stretch of summer, 385 people arrived at the studios of LTV, a cable-access programmer in Wainscott, on the East End of Long Island, for a town-hall meeting to discuss mounting aural assaults from commuter helicopters going to and from Manhattan. The issue had been igniting tempers all season  especially in the communities of Shelter Island, the Springs and parts of the North Fork, areas where a lot of the noise has been absorbed and where local self-perception runs less toward the glossy and indulgent than it does elsewhere on the East End.

title: Isner Hopes to Finally Solve Kohlschreiber at U.S. Open
description: Its dj vu time for the top American John Isner.

title: Corrections: August 29, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 29, 2014
description: Theyve got to start off fresh, get new friends, new neighbors. It might not show now, but maybe later on in life.

title: To Compete Against Alibaba, Wanda Joins Forces With Baidu and Tencent
description: HONG KONG  The Dalian Wanda Group, the Chinese real estate, cinema and retail conglomerate controlled by the billionaire Wang Jianlin, announced on Friday that it would enter the e-commerce industry in an $800 million partnership with Baidu and Tencent, two of Chinas biggest Internet companies.

title: Princess Fragrant Mixes Messages on Ethnic Unity, Expert Says
description: This week, The New York Times reported on the production in China of an animated television series with an exotic 10-year-old heroine, Princess Fragrant. The 104-episode series is loosely based on murky historical narratives about the Fragrant Concubine, an ethnic Uighur woman who in the 18th century was brought thousands of miles east to the Chinese imperial court in Beijing of the Qianlong Emperor, an ethnic Manchu, to be one of his consorts.

title: Chinas Antigraft Campaign Expands to a Coal-Rich Northern Province
description: HONG KONG  Newly disclosed investigations into senior politicians in Shanxi Province, an area in northern China rich in coal and opportunities for graft, reveal an emerging front in Communist Party leaders efforts to show they are serious about eradicating corruption.

title: Student Crossword | Saying Thank You Around the World
description: Test your knowledge of ways to say thank you around the world by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Herms Posts Rise in Profit, Despite Slowing Sales in China
description: PARIS  The French luxury group Herms International said on Friday its profit rose 8 percent for the first six months of 2014, despite signs of slowing sales growth for high-end goods in China.

title: 6 Qs About the News |   Stealth Invasion of Ukraine by Russian Troops
description: In Ukraine Reports Russian Invasion on a New Front, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael R. Gordon write about the continuing conflict in that nation.

title: Praising Rebels, Putin Toughens Tone on Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  As Russian-backed rebels entrenched themselves in a newly captured, strategically located town in southeast Ukraine on Friday, President Vladimir V. Putin bluntly strengthened Moscows hard-line position that the government in Kiev must be compelled to negotiate regional autonomy.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 29
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes a Staten Island march that drew thousands and Ganesha Chaturthi celebrations.

title: Why We Cant Agree on Paying Ransom
description: JamesFoley was detained more than two years ago by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and the grouphad pressed the United States to provide a multimillion-dollar ransom for his release, writesRukmini Callimachi for The New York Times. The United States  unlike several European countries that have funneled millions to the terror group to spare the lives of their citizens  refused to pay.

title: A Gay Haven on Fire Island
description: The anthropologist Esther Newton described going to Cherry Grove, Fire Island, in the 1980s and feeling, finally, at home.

title: Eurozone Inflation Dips Again to Increase Pressure on E.C.B.
description: FRANKFURT  Inflation in the eurozone continued to decline in August while unemployment hovered near record levels, according to official data released on Friday, reinforcing expectations that the European Central Bank will soon take more forceful action to prevent a dangerous downward price spiral.

title: Test Yourself | Designing New Airships to Carry Science Into the Stratosphere
description: Below are six paragraphs from the Aug. 25 article Modern Research Borne on a Relic.

title: Malaysia Airlines to Cut Work Force and Get Almost $2 Billion Bailout
description: BANGKOK  Malaysia Airlines will cut 6,000 jobs, or about 30 percent of its work force, and receive a bailout from the Malaysian government amounting to nearly $2 billion, according to a restructuring plan announced on Friday.

title: On Hong Kong, Democracy and Protecting the Rich
description: In an unusual theoretical leap for a state that is still at least nominally socialist, a top Chinese academic who works closely with the central government in Beijing said democracy in Hong Kong must be limited in order to protect the interests of its capitalist class.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: New York Today: Pick Up a Paddle
description: Good Friday morning to you on this prelude to a long weekend.

title: Relatives of Russian Soldiers Captured by Ukraine Demand Answers
description: KOSTROMA, Russia  Dozens of women gathered at the checkpoint of a military base outside this provincial town on Thursday, demanding to know how their sons and husbands had ended up on Ukrainian videos being interviewed as captives.

title: Irelands Data Privacy Regulator Will Have Global Sway
description: In the coming weeks, an Irish government committee is set to pick the countrys new data privacy regulator, a relatively obscure position but one with global sway, Mark Scott reports.

title: A Lot of Places Resemble Ferguson, Statistically
description: Ferguson, Mo., stands out for the level of racial turbulence it has experienced this month. But as an economically lagging community that has undergone rapid demographic change in the last couple of decades, its not unusual at all.

title: Babys Drug Co-Pay Jumps, and a Health Reporter Is Stumped
description: Its not easy being an educated health care consumer.

title: The N.F.I.B. Is Certifying Small-Business-Friendly Politicians
description: With the fall midterm elections approaching, the National Federation of Independent Business has released a measuring stick to rate congressional candidates on their fidelity to small businesses. While this is standard political advocacy, this year it goes under the novel banner of making candidates small-business certified. But N.F.I.B.s acid-test positions are hardly new.

title: Are Russian Forces on the Move in Ukraine?
description: Russian officials deny sending soldiers or weapons into the country, satellite images suggest otherwise.

title: After Loss of Alibaba I.P.O., Hong Kong Weighs Changes to Its Listing Rules
description: HONG KONG  Its been nearly a year since Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, broke off talks with stock market regulators in Hong Kong, deciding instead to pursue its gargantuan initial public offering in the United States.

title: Morning Agenda: Playing the Tax Game
description: BUSINESSES WINNING THE TAX GAME | Across corporate America, companies large and small are finding new ways to avoid paying taxes, making it harder than ever for the federal government to replenish its already depleted coffers, DealBooks David Gelles writes. As a result, business income tax revenue remains stagnant at about 2 percent of gross domestic product even as corporate profits hit records. Business taxes now make up less than 10 percent of federal revenue, down sharply from the years after World War II, when about 30 percent of federal revenue came from corporate taxes.

title: A Liquid Fear
description: Two childhood experiences with water left Attis Clopton with a phobia that lasted for decades, until another major life event inspired him to face his fears.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Hong Kong Prepares for Decision on Election Rules
description: The countdown to Beijings decision on how Hong Kong people will elect their next leader has not been short of drama.

title: A New Yorker Faces His Phobia, One Stroke at a Time
description: On the morning before he was to report to the pool, Attis Clopton sat in a storefront breakfast spot near his Brooklyn apartment munching a glazed doughnut. He was worrying. It was a glorious day, blue sky and hot. The kind when they say the only sensible place to be is in the water.

title: Karen O Goes Solo with Crush Songs
description: LOS ANGELES  I think we just ooh-ed it out, Karen O said, instructing her musicians in a steady singsong. Ooh-ed it on out.

title: More Mega-Change in the Retail World: Sarah Rutson Leaves Lane Crawford
description: Another major shake-up is in the works in the world of global department stores: After 21 years, Sarah Rutson, fashion director of Lane Crawford, Asias most recognizable luxury emporium, is leaving to pursue new personal opportunities, according to an announcement from the store.

title: Reader Idea | From Article to Infographic: Translating Information About Sneakerheads
description: Slide show from the April article, For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips, which inspired this lesson.

title: Blocked In for Prayer
description: Dear Diary:

title: Chief Executive of Rovio, Maker of Angry Birds Game, to Step Down
description: LONDON  The chief Angry Bird is leaving the nest.

title: Denis Colombs Cashmere Connection to the Holy City of Kathmandu
description: Twice a year for the past decade, the Los Angelesbased designer Denis Colomb has traveled to Kathmandu with his wife and business partner, Erica Lennard. They spend their weekdays visiting the five Nepali workshops that help create the cashmere collections for Colombs eponymous label. But on Saturdays the workshops are closed and the couple is free to roam Nepals capital. Initially drawn here to Nepal by the quality of the hand-weaving techniques and the ability to procure the finest cashmere, Lennard explains, we are constantly in awe of the deep spirituality and traditional lifestyle that have been part of the Nepali way of life for centuries. Their Nepali-Tibetan production coordinator, Namdu Bajracharya, shares with them the holiest corners of the city, from small temples to stupas, or Buddhist monasteries, with breathtaking views.

title: Austerity and the Hapless Left
description: In todays column I am not nice to Francois Hollande, who has shown about as much strength in standing up to austerians as a wet Kleenex. But one does have to admit that hes not alone in his haplessness; where, indeed, are the major political figures on the European left taking a stand against disastrous policies? Britains Labour Party has been almost surreally unwilling to challenge Cameron/Osbornes core premises; is anyone doing better?

title: Death Toll in Ukraine Conflict Exceeds 2,200, U.N. Says
description: GENEVA  The United Nations said on Friday that casualties in the fighting between Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian rebels had doubled in the past month, with an average of 36 people killed every day.

title: Germanys Sin
description: Simon Wren-Lewis has two very good posts about the European situation, first laying out the problem, then taking on those who dont get it. I just want to add a bit to one of his key points: the impossibility of a resolution unless Germany accepts higher inflation.

title: Video Reviews of Starred Up, Through a Lens Darkly and The Notebook
description: In this weeks video, the Times critic A. O. Scott shares his thoughts on Starred Up, Through a Lens Darkly and The Notebook (Le Grand Cahier). See all of this weeks reviews.

title: A Weary Rebel Retreats to Fight Another Day
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  AS he rode onto the base of the Fourth Division, the formidable Syrian Army unit that had been starving and bombarding his town near Damascus for months, Kassem Eid prepared for a moral reckoning tougher than any he had faced in three years of civil war.

title: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
Classical Playlist: Gluck, Jonathan Biss, Morton Feldman and More
description: DUETS OF LOVE AND PASSIONJames McCracken, tenor; Sandra Warfield, mezzo-soprano(Decca 480 8165) Though the tenor James McCracken and the mezzo-soprano Sandra Warfield, who were married, did not make a point of performing together, they shared the stage many times in operas and concerts. This reissued recording, Duets of Love and Passion, originally released in 1964, presents the couple in scenes from Saint-Sans Samson et Dalila, Bizets Carmen and two Verdi operas, Otello and Aida. McCrackens muscular voice and intensity combine excitingly with Warfields dark colorings and warmth. Though Warfield, who died in 2009, had to accommodate her voice with some awkwardness to the subtle demands of Verdis Desdemona, a classic soprano role, she smolders as Verdis Amneris. The recording includes bonus tracks from McCracken on Stage, an aria album that shows this important tenor, who died in 1988, was not just in his element in Wagner, but bending phrases sensitively in Verdi. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Increasingly, Retirees Dump Their Possessions and Hit the Road
description: SOME call themselves senior gypsies. Others prefer international nomad. David Law, 74, a retired executive recruiter who has primarily slept in tents in several countries in the last two years, likes the ring of American Bedouin.

title: 1914: Correspondent in the War Zone
description: Location withheld: I have just arrived here from the Belgian frontier after inspecting the situation in the North. There was an air of expectancy in  when I reached it on Monday forenoon. News was scant and people were evidently becoming restless. Crowds were massed in the principal square watching the arrival from time to time of French soldiers with trophies captured from the enemy. Knots of men and women were gathered around villagers from the countryside and listening intently to vague accounts of fighting outside the city. About five oclock the atmosphere in the streets began to change. It seemed panicky. Rumors were afloat that the Germans were arriving; that the Prefect had given orders for all the flags to be hauled down; that the Prussian cavalry would enter the city at nine oclock! What these reports were worth at the time I do not know. But when, an hour or two later, I saw the officers in my hotel suddenly begin to pack their bags and pay their bills I considered it was time I prepared to move on, too, having no desire to be taken prisoner by the Germans. The tactics of the German cavalry is to appear here, there and everywhere, and the effect on the population is inevitable. We reached  at noon. We felt at once that the Germans were near. There was that unmistakable atmosphere. A general air of deadness, stagnation and stifled fear; suspense and anxiety on every face. Scant news has filtered through of the great battle between Mons and Charleroi. It is, of course, a secondary line which has wisely fallen back on a stronger line in order to cope better with the German cavalry movement on our left, a movement which must be watched.The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 30, 1914

title: Residency Questions Roil Senate Race in Louisiana
