description: WASHINGTON  The embattled re-election campaign of Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana was damaged further on Friday by the revelation that she uses her parents home address to establish her residency in the state.

title: Reply All: The 8.17.14 Issue
description: INSIDE THE DARK, LUCRATIVE WORLD OF DEBT COLLECTION

title: The Accidental Phone Tap
description: My sisters called me on a conference line, hoping to connect the three of us for an important discussion. I wasnt home, so one sister left a voice mail message and then disconnected  or at least she thought she did. But my voice mail kept recording as she and my other sister continued their conversation. When I returned home and retrieved the message, was I obliged to stop listening and hang up after my sister believed she had ended the call? JANET FLETCHER, NAPA, CALIF.

title: Richard Branson Searches for Virgins Next Big Thing
description: The entrepreneur talks to Amy Chozick about airplanes, spaceships, submarines and second chances.

title: Straight Duds
description: Rejecting vanity sizing; summers soundtrack.

title: Who Made That Tabasco Sauce?
description: In the years before the Civil War, Edmund McIlhenny was a New Orleans banker and bon vivant whose pleasures included boats, horses and spicy food. But after the war, with much of the South in ruins, McIlhenny was unable to find work. After pounding the pavement in New Orleans for months, he retreated to his wifes familys sugar plantation on Petite Anse (now called Avery) Island, a 2,200-acre salt dome rising from the marshes of southern Louisiana. There, in the late 1860s, he tended his garden  particularly his bushes of spicy red peppers.

title: The Unexpected 3 a.m. Guests
description: When you know a house well, especially an old house, there arent many sounds that surprise you. The squeak of the stairs, the metallic chime of heat traveling down the baseboards, the whine of the northwest wind running up along the siding edge  if you have lived in a place for long, these become familiar.

title: Exclusive Preview of Transparent
description: A scene featuring Gaby Hoffmann, Jay Duplass and Amy Landecker, directed by Nisha Ganatra, from the new series created by Jill Soloway.

title: Can Jill Soloway Do Justice to the Trans Movement?
description: In April, Jill Soloway sat on a cushion on the floor of her home office in Silver Lake as she waited for the glue on her fake eyelashes to dry. She was reading through a list of talking points that Glaad, the L.G.B.T. media advocacy organization, had distributed to those walking the red carpet at its annual Media Awards show. Soloway was invited as a special guest. The list was mostly made up of words and phrases to avoid, some that were obviously offensive but others that seemed innocuous: gay marriage (which suggests its a different thing from the nongay variety); gay lifestyle (which suggests its a choice); homosexual (which has been hijacked by anti-gay activists).

title: New N.F.L. Policy Is One Step on a Long Road to Regaining Some Fans Trust
description: Hooray for Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner who finally came to his senses and decided that, gee, yes, domestic violence is really a serious issue and should be punished accordingly.

title: Domestic Violence On the Rise Among Syrian Refugees
description: Last summer, Lauren Wolfe, the director of Women Under Siege, a project at the Womens Media Center, visited the Zaatari refugee camp on the Jordan-Syria border. There, she met a young woman with a baby who said her husband, out of work and angry, had started beating her every day.

title: Book a Room, Be a Pop Star for a Day
description: Travelers who harbor dreams of being pop stars have the chance to make their wishes come true  at least in part  with the new Superstar Package at Chewton Glen, the luxury estate hotel in Hampshire, England.

title: Letters: One Nixon
description: One Nixon

title: Priority Mail
description: Throughout the years, authors collected letters have often featured in our pages (this week, Henry Giardina reviews The Animals: Love Letters Between Christopher Isherwood and Don Bachardy). Assessing Sylvia Plaths Letters Home in 1975, Maureen Howard said the authors dispatches can be read like a novel, including those Plath sent while studying at Smith College: The letters are like little stories; here she is, Cinderella waltzing in her silver dress at a debutante party, or talking about life and love with handsome boys at any number of Ivy League colleges, or stunning her professors (all of them dears) with another villanelle.

title: Stories We Tell Each Other
description: In 1956, Christopher Isherwood wrote from Cheshire, England, to his partner, the artist Don Bachardy. It is the first entry in a 14-year correspondence: a brief, eccentric document that mentions, in a short space, Alexander Kordas memorial service, incest between two cats and Courbets Diligence in the Snow.

title: Muses and Inspiration
description: MRS. HEMINGWAY  By Naomi Wood  Penguin, paper, $16.

title: Choose Your Own Race
description: Do you ever dream of starting again in a new skin? This is the central question of Jess Rows provocative and intriguing first novel, Your Face in Mine. Its also a tag line of the shady enterprise in Bangkok where the books central character, Martin Wilkinson (n Lipkin), has paid a hefty sum to undergo something called racial reassignment surgery, to transform from a white Jewish man to an African-American one.

title: Expatriate Acts
description: Elise, the mother in Brittani Sonnenbergs debut novel, Home Leave, is one of those unknowable blondes often glimpsed in business-class lounges. Neither delayed flights to Singapore nor fussy children can rattle her poise, because looking serene while traveling is what she does. Elises husband, Chris Kriegstein, is a former high school basketball star who was mostly benched come senior year of college. He is competitive but not ambitious in the way of todays Zuckerbergian entrepreneurs. Rather than start his own company, he stumps for someone elses in conference rooms in Seoul, Bombay, Dubai  anywhere thats not Chariton, Ind.

title: Bridge to Nowhere
description: The title of Richard Flanagans sixth novel comes from a 17th-century Japanese classic, a little book by the poet Basho that mixes a prose travel narrative with haiku in its account of a long journey on foot. Basho went north from present-day Tokyo through a mountainous land of often shattering beauty. Yet his walk was marked by moments of terrible loneliness, and he seemed to travel under a kind of compulsion, without a defined goal or purpose. Basho walks because he must, and in reading him the old clich comes alive: Life is a journey. Whether that journey has any meaning, whether theres anything beyond putting one foot in front of the other . . . well, thats another question entirely.

title: His Penetrating Gaze
description: What is the line between creating and copying? How does the subject of a portrait, like a particle in a physics experiment, change and transform under the portraitists watchful gaze? How do writers hide and reveal themselves in their work, leaving sly traces that only their intimates might recognize? These questions lie at the heart of Mr. Gwyn and Three Times at Dawn, two clever interlocking novellas by the Italian writer Alessandro Baricco.

title: Love and Visas
description: The ambitiousness of Vanessa Mankos debut novel is well represented by its title, which Homer might have blushed to use. The Invention of Exile spans four decades and three continents to tell the story of an epic love frustrated but never destroyed by political antagonism between nations, namely the United States and the brand-new Soviet Union. Its beleaguered hero, Austin Voronkov, debarks on Ellis Island (where his given name, Ustin, is quickly and permanently Americanized) in 1913; despite his engineering background, he takes a proletarian job at the Remington gun factory in Bridgeport, Conn. The reasons for his emigration are never divulged, though the fact that he didnt believe that workers and trained engineers were equal suggests he has picked an opportune time to get out of Russia.

title: Out of His Shell
description: Hank Chu is your run-of-the-mill Chinese-American drenched in filial piety and surrounded by shelves of simple carbohydrates in his familys grocery store. When we meet him, in the 1930s, hes content to be a facsimile of his father, passing his days, item by item, behind the counter. The Chus sweep, they stock, they eat and if theyre lucky, one day theyll die. Hanks mother, Hua Chu, is the only one with enough chutzpah to desire more. She escapes the Chu family Groundhog Day by taking a job with a Mrs. Olson, who could be Miss Daisy, Cruella de Vil or any flavor of distinguished Caucasian woman with garden party headwear and a big body sedan.

title: Seoul Survivors
description: In 1985, a 12-year-old Euny Hong moved with her family from suburban Chicago to Seoul, South Korea. Not just any place in Seoul, South Korea, but a neighborhood known as Apgujeong  the wealthiest, most exclusive cluster of addresses in the Gangnam district. The Hongs, in short, went Gangnam Style 27 years before it was a thing. And when it comes to South Korean history  as with meme superstardom  three decades is a long time.

title: A Long Road to Recovery
description: In January 1967 a land mine blew up under the not-quite-armored-enough Amphibian Tractor, or Amtrac, carrying United States Marine Lt. Robert Timberg. He was on a routine mission to deliver pay to front-line units in Vietnam. The gas tank carried 456 gallons of fuel with little protection from underneath. If it exploded, anyone inside would be, as the Marines said, fricasseed. So the passengers sat on the top or clung to the sides. Timberg was watching the road ahead, he writes, when I felt myself lifted from the top of the Amtrac, as if in the eye of a hurricane, except in place of wind and rain I was being carried aloft by flames.

title: Bodies of Evidence
description: The cast includes women whove been abducted, hooded, forcibly tattooed and released with no explanation. A bum, a stripper, a life coach, a real estate agent. They have nothing in common but the maps inked onto their backs  evidence of an unskilled hand, the maps illegible and crude. Playing the leads: a killer, Wrobleski; a hired thug, Billy Moore; his precocious 12-year-old daughter, Carla; a real estate mogul; and one cranky driver. In addition, two innocents turned amateur detectives  think the Bloodhound Gang (see PBSs 3-2-1 Contact, not the band)  who commit themselves, with no prelude or wherewithal, to solving the mystery of the tattooed women. And, as backdrop, a nameless city that feels like New York in about 50 years, but isnt New York. Just some run-down urban mecca: corrupt, filthy, mysterious, cinematic. Put it all together and youve got Geoff Nicholsons new crime novel, The City Under the Skin, which compels the way a good crime novel should: by making you turn the pages at a clip.

title: Paperback Row
description: COMMAND AND CONTROL: Nuclear Weapons, the Damascus Accident, and the Illusion of Safety,  by Eric Schlosser. (Penguin, $18.) How do you deploy weapons of mass destruction without being destroyed by them? Thats the question at the heart of Schlossers disquieting examination of nuclear risk, which weaves a riveting account of an accident at a nuclear missile silo in rural Arkansas with a crisp historical narrative covering more than 70 years.

title: Editors Choice
description: GEEK SUBLIME: The Beauty of Code, the Code of Beauty,  by Vikram Chandra. (Graywolf, paper, $16.) With great subtlety and depth, Chandra, who is both a novelist and a programmer, traces the connections between art and technology.

title: Inside the List
description: Whistle-Stop: Representative Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin Republican who was Mitt Romneys running mate in 2012, has been on the road lately to promote his first book, The Way Forward, which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5. In it, Ryan offers voters  oops, readers!  a softer, more personal account of his life, discussing among other things his courtship of his wife and opening up for the first time about his fathers alcoholism and early death. Before I lost him to a heart attack, Ryan writes, whiskey had washed away some of the best parts of the man I knew. None of this, of course, means the book isnt full of your basic agitprop. Running a column about it last month, one Texas newspaper used the succinct headline Ryan Blames Everything on Left. So is this the first volley in a presidential campaign? Ryan has been noncommittal in interviews, saying hell wait until 2015 to decide. And despite the books calculated stagecraft and careful red-meat rhetoric (I believe the conservative vision can appeal to the majority of our fellow citizens), theres at least one good reason to think hes telling the truth: His whistle-stop book tour includes no scheduled appearances in Iowa or New Hampshire.

title: Living in the Mix
description: Brandon Deese lives just a few blocks from where he grew up, but it might as well be another world.

title: Is Owning Overrated? The Rental Economy Rises
description: Things that you can now rent instead of buying: a power drill, a song, a tent, an office for an hour, a Prada handbag, a wedding dress, a painting, a dog, your neighbors car, a drone.

title: In Greenpoint, a Situation Ripe for a Doughnut War
description: Once Dominique Ansel secured a trademark for the Cronut this year, some New Yorkers might have thought that the citys doughnut wars, or at least heated conversations about doughnuts, were over. Peace, whether in the form of a hybrid, classic jelly, or red velvet, had finally come.

title: With Howard Out, U.S. Net Is Open for Guzan
description: When the United States national team takes the field against the Czech Republic on Wednesday in Prague, it will do so without its most recognizable and valuable player from the World Cup: goalkeeper Tim Howard, who announced last week that he was taking a year off from international play.

title: Harry Belafonte and Maureen OHara Among Academy Honorees
description: LOS ANGELES  The actress Maureen OHara, the screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrire and the animation filmmaker Hayao Miyazaki will receive honorary Oscars for their lifetime achievement, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Thursday.

title: One Residence, Two Different Worlds
description: In New Yorks mixed-income buildings, market-rate tenants live right next door to low-income tenants.

title: Here Comes September. There Lie the Mets.
description: Ah, to be a Mets fan in late August. The twilight is cool and sharp shadowed, and Citi Field is a retro delight. As for the state of the team as it makes its inevitable turn toward the autumn moon?

title: Tough Decisions: Investing for a Nonprofit
description: AFTER a steady run-up in the stock market, the members of the investment committee of the HudsonAlpha Institute for Biotechnology were faced with a decision this year that would affect the future of the nonprofit and the cutting-edge biotech research it funds.

title: The Economic Value of Treating Workers Humanely
description: There has been so much regression on democracy and human rights in Myanmar recently that many people, this editorial page included, have suggested the United States must consider reinstating broad sanctions.

title: Along the High Line: Top This!
description: Soo K. Chan, an architect and developer from Singapore who has designed and built residences, hotels and museums around the world, is launching his first two projects in the United States in New York City. And it seems as if Mr. Chan and his company, SCDA Architects, intend to come on strong, with two condominiums along that magnet for brand-name architects, the High Line.

title: Gaia Repossis Favorite New York Art Destinations
description: For the past seven years, the Repossi creative director Gaia Repossi has been turning out jewelry that toes the line between fashion and fine art. On September 3rd and 4th, her delicate new collection  called White Noise and informed by the mobiles of Alexander Calder and the color palette of Franz West  makes its debut in a special installation at Dover Street Market New York, marking the first time an entire Repossi collection will be available stateside. In honor of its arrival  and to kick off New York Fashion Week, which begins after Labor Day  the Paris-based designer shares a list of some of her favorite sources for visual inspiration in New York, where she frequently travels for work and to visit her boyfriend, the artist Jeremy Everett.

title: Why a Video Game Critic Was Forced to Flee Her Home
description: This week, a critic of sexism in video games tweeted that shed been threatened, severely enough that she notified law enforcement and left her home. And her experience has prompted some to ask whether gaming culture is dying  or changing into something new.

title: After Napa Jolt, Quake-Proofing Your Homeowners Insurance
description: AS Napa County, Calif., recovers from the earthquake that jarred the area last weekend, many homeowners may be wondering whether they should buy special earthquake insurance.

title: Seeking to Ease Worries, Obama Says the World Has Always Been Messy
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  If the world seems troubled by all manner of calamities these days, President Obama does not want Americans to worry too much. After all, he said Friday, The world has always been messy; it is just more apparent because of social media. And, he added, todays geopolitical threats are far less perilous than those of the Cold War.

title: James Murphy Turns U.S. Open Matches Into Music
description: James Murphy has kept fairly busy since he disbanded LCD Soundsystem in 2011, with projects that have included writing film music, producing an album for the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and working with Arcade Fire. Over the next few weeks, he plans to add 400 hours of new music to his catalog.

title: The Ringmaster Leaves Salzburg
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Alexander Pereira, whose final day as the artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, after three summers here, is Sunday, stood in the wings a few weeks ago at the Haus fr Mozart, one of the festivals theaters. The curtain had just fallen at the end of opening night of Schuberts seldom-performed Fierrabras, the first time an opera by that composer had been staged here. Mr. Pereira, 66, grinned widely and doled out congratulations as the singers left the stage.

title: New Cabinet in Turkey Mirrors That of Last Premier
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys prime minister-designate, Ahmet Davutoglu, announced a new cabinet on Friday that is dominated by holdovers from the administration of his predecessor, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Mr. Erdogan is now the president and seeking to maintain a grip on power after moving to what until now has been a largely ceremonial office.

title: Indian Economy Grows 5.7%, Its Fastest Pace in More Than 2 Years
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias economy grew 5.7 percent in the three months that ended in June from the same period a year ago, according to government estimates released on Friday, signaling a gradual revival in Asias third-largest economy in the quarter in which it elected its new leader, Narendra Modi.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Suspicious Minds
description: This week, Gary Greenberg discusses Suspicious Minds: How Culture Shapes Madness; David Carr talks about Hack Attack; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Euny Hong discusses The Birth of Korean Cool; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Cheddar Scallion Dip
description: Melissa Clark makes a creamy cheese dip with orange juice and paprika that will be perfect for your child to snack on during lunch.

title: Picking Up an Elusive College Dream
description: At the corner of Seventh Avenue and 27th Street, Tenille Warren waited impatiently for the light to change. She swept under the purple welcome banner into the Fashion Institute of Technologys industrial-looking building, raced upstairs to her class and slid into the front row beside a mannequin dressed in a Lululemon jacket. This was no time to be fashionably late.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Suspicious Minds
description: This week, Gary Greenberg, David Carr and Euny Hong.

title: For Some, Tis a Gift to Be Simple
description: Last month, I spent a day in a library for the first time in over 20 years. I was there to work, but I appeared to be the only one doing so. Everyone else lolled about as the rain fell outside, helping themselves to the endless shelves of newspapers and magazines or browsing the newest fiction.

title: No PB&J Allowed? Put Dips Into Lunchboxes
description: Looking for ideas for what to pack in your childs lunchbox? Melissa Clark will answer readers questions and share lunch tips in a Facebook chat on Friday, Sept. 5, at1 p.m.Eastern time onfacebook.com/nytimes.

title: Big Ticket | A Glimpse of the Park for $17.8 Million
description: A three-bedroom sponsor unit at the Marquand, a century-old building at 11 East 68th Street that underwent an extravagant conversion by the HFZ Capital Group last year, sold for $17,819,375 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Today in Small Business: Google Dorking
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Readers Continue Argument Over Airline Reclining
ISIS Fears Prompt Britain to Raise Terrorism Threat Level
description: LONDON  Alarmed by the suspected presence of hundreds of British jihadists among Sunni militants in Syria and Iraq, Britain increased its assessment of the terrorism threat on its own soil on Friday and said new laws would be introduced to counter what Prime Minister David Cameron called a greater threat to our security than we have seen before.

title: Receiving Could Be a Problem Area for the Giants
description: A look at the 2014 season for the Giants:

title: 13, and Surviving in the Woods on Squirrel Pizza
description: Mom, Mom, I ate a squirrel testicle! shouts my sons friend Ollie as he darts out of the woods toward his mother. The expression on his face can be described only as ecstatic.

title: Green Acres, the Place to Be
description: NEW LEBANON, N.Y.  Small rural communities are perpetually marketing themselves. Witness the annual Heritage Spudfest in Boonsboro, Md., or the Worlds Largest Ball of Twine in Cawker City, Kan.

title: On One Chinese Beach, a Parade of Curiously Covered-Up Style
description: The German-born, New York-trained photographer Philipp Engelhorn has spent the past 11 years living just off the beach in a village near Hong Kong. There, he has long been accustomed to seeing the local Po Pos (a slang term for elderly women) going for their morning swim. Engelhorn became intrigued, however, when he heard about how women in the northern Chinese city of Qingdao undertake the same ritual wearing colorful head masks and bodysuits. (The custom originated as a method of protection against the areas giant stinging jellyfish, thoughmany bathers also told Engelhorn their objective was to block the suns rays.) For eight days, he captured Qingdao swimmers in their elaborate armor  much of which, it turned out, was homemade.

title: In Crown Heights, Small-Batch Food Scene Meets Beer Hall
description: After raising the tent on Brooklyns small-batch food scene, the Smorgasburg empire has expanded into Crown Heights. Bergn, a new beer hall with longtime food vendors from the weekend festivals, threw open its glass garage doors on Wednesday, revealing a nearly 9,000-square-foot room of dark wood and light-painted brick walls that felt instantly cool and comfortably full by lunchtime. Culinary options include Asia Dog and Pizza Moto, while the bar offers craft brews like Peekskill Simple Sour and Sixpoint Sweet Action.

title: Vice Media Stakes Future on A&E Networks Deal
description: After spending the summer flirting with various suitors, Vice Media said on Friday that it was close to choosing a partner: A&E Networks.

title: Hammerstein Festival Seeks to Inspire Great Lyrics
description: Robyn Goodman and Alexander Fraser, the directors of the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., are presenting the first Oscar Hammerstein Festival next month. The festival, Sept. 26-28, will offer a weekend of performances and panel discussions, all open to the public. An affiliated yearlong mentorship program intends to remind composers and, particularly, lyricists in the early stages of their careers that musicals were once known for their sophistication and wit, and that they can be again.

title: With $38 Million Ferrari, Classic Car Market Revs Up
description: Last year, two Manhattan condominiums sold for over $90 million and a Francis Bacon painting went for $142.4 million. Now comes the $38.1 million car.

title: Home Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Apple Appeals Judges Decision to Deny a Ban on Samsung Products
description: .big-quote { color: #444; padding: 20px 40px 10px 40px; box-shadow: inset 0 0 5px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 20px 0 20px 0; position: relative; font-size: 17px; line-height: 35px; background-color: #fffff5; } .big-quote .story-body-text { font-size: 16px !important; line-height: 21px !important; font-family: nyt-franklin, arial, helvetica, sans-serif !important; font-weight: 200 !important; } .big-quote .page-promo { display: none; position: absolute; bottom: 20px; right: 20px; color: #eeeeee; background-color: rgba(0,0,0,.65); padding: 8px 15px 8px 15px; font-family: nyt-franklin, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px; font-weight: bold; border-radius: 4px; } .big-quote:hover .page-promo { display: block; }

title: Forensic Hydrology at the Gowanus Canal
description: Several times each week, Eymund Diegel does something unthinkable to most New Yorkers: He dips his bare hand in the Gowanus Canal.

title: Book Review Podcast: Culture and Madness
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Gary Greenberg reviews Suspicious Minds: How Culture Shapes Madness, by Joel Gold and Ian Gold. Mr. Greenberg writes:

title: Preseason N.F.L. Games May Not Count, but They Can Have Meaning
description: At this stage of his now 11-year pro football career, here is Eli Mannings take on the games that do not count.

title: Inequality and Web Search: Q. and A. With Google Researchers
description: Our recent analysis of economic inequality and web searches generated a lot of discussion and hundreds of online comments. Two of the Google researchers who helped with the analysis  Hal Varian, the companys chief economist, and Seth Stephens-Davidowitz  offered to answer reader comments.

title: Height, Not Age, Restrictions at the Firing Range
description: Maybe the real problem was the 9-year-old girl wielding that deadly Uzi was a bit too short to be shooting it. Thats the postmortem thinking of the proprietor of the Arizona gun range where the pony-tailed youngster lost control of a war weapon in a burst that killed her instructorMonday.

title: Just Add Farro
description: Wheat berries like farro, spelt and kamut are hearty, and I usually associate them with cool-weather dishes. But Im working on a pantry cleanout, as I do every summer, and I found a number of half-filled bags that needed my attention. I cooked up big pots of farro and spelt after soaking the grains overnight. I usually soak wheat berries for only an hour, but I thought Id see what an overnight soak yielded. Then I used them in several cool summer dishes.

title: Where Harmony Resided
description: A quaint yet elegant apartment at the Beresford that was owned by Broadway royalty, the author/composer/philanthropist Mary Rodgers and her husband Henry Guettel, and served for decades as a musical salon and gathering place for the denizens of Broadway theater, is about to enter the market for the first time in a quarter of a century.

title: Experimental Drug Would Help Fight Ebola if Supply Increases, Study Finds
description: A new study provides strong evidence that the experimental drug given to two American aid workers stricken with Ebola in Africa really works and could make a difference in the current outbreak  if more of it could be produced.

title: A Tower in Brooklyn, but Soon Just a Memory
description: From the East River Ferry, it seems to belong more to the industrial Brooklyn Navy Yard than to the increasingly glass and steel skyline of Williamsburg: a hulking mass of brick, covered with graffiti, that could pass for a ruined castle were it not for the insistent modernism of the beige refinery tower that squats to its right. But the tower holds what to many is the most important part of the whole structure: the yellow letters that spell out Domino Sugar.

title: Embarking on a New Path
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the final minutes of the Giants loss at Chicago last October, a game that included three Eli Manning interceptions and dropped their record to 0-6, the teams co-owner John Mara vaulted from his seat in a rooftop box, growled in disgust and stormed into a hallway, where he stamped back and forth with his hands in his pockets.

title: On Flights, Reclining Seats and Rage
description: On Wednesday night, air marshals intervened when two passengers aboard an American Airlines flight from Miami to Paris began fighting over the right to recline their seat.

title: U.S. Adds Penalties Amid Resistance by Iran to Inspection of Nuclear Work
description: Amid signs that Irans military is resisting efforts to open its nuclear program to deeper inspection, the Obama administration on Friday imposed sanctions on several Iranian organizations, including one run by the reclusive scientist who is widely believed to direct research on building nuclear weapons.

title: Ask Well: The Problem With Bunions
description: Question:

title: The S.&P.s Slow, Bumpy Climb to 2,000
description: THE Standard & Poors 500-stock index has doubled in value, and it only took 16 and a half years.

title: Square Feeling Squeezed From All Sides
description: Square is starting to look oddly hollow. The payments company, set up and run by Jack Dorsey, is set to raise $200 million in new financing, according to Bloomberg. That would value the company at $6 billion. While big, it is a deflated figure, considering Squares former hype, the small amount raised and rivals ease in securing higher valuations.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: mouse brains, growth hormones and all-star lineups. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Obama Weighing Delay in Action on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is considering a delay of his most controversial proposals to revamp immigration laws through executive action until after the midterm elections in November, mindful of the electoral peril for Democratic Senate candidates, according to allies of the administration who have knowledge of White House deliberations.

title: Shakeup at the Pennsylvania Ballet
description: In what looks like a sudden bloodletting occasioned by a recent change of artistic leadership, the Pennsylvania Ballet has dismissed Jeffrey Gribler, who was ballet master, and Tamara Hadley, who was ballet mistress, as well as William DeGregory, who was director of the companys ballet school and the Pennsylvania Ballet II training company. Michael Sheridan, the assistant to the artistic director, and others in the companys marketing and fund-raising departments were also let go. Most of those who were fired had been with the company for most of their careers. Mr. Gribler, for example, came to the company as an apprentice in 1975.

title: The Mystery of the New York City Parks Departments Chandelier
description: Q. The lobby of the Arsenal, the former weapons storehouse in Central Park, which is now the headquarters of New York Citys Department of Parks and Recreation, has an odd feature for such a utilitarian building: a huge crystal chandelier that would be at home in an opera house. How did it get there?

title: As Virginia Trial Ends, Jury Is Asked to Decide if Ex-Governor Was Corrupt, or Hapless Husband
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Ending a five-week trial that pulled back the curtain on a Virginia governors acceptance of a Rolex, a borrowed Ferrari and sweetheart loans, jurors hearing the case against former Gov. Bob McDonnell and his wife, Maureen, were asked on Friday to decide if Mr. McDonnell was a corrupt politician who traded his office for luxury goods or a hapless husband caught up in a mess created by his wifes greed.

title: Extraordinary Angles Inspired by...Gardens
description: The Sothebys International Realty brand presents Extraordinary Angles the lifestyle video series showcasing unique properties and lifestyles from around the world. In this episode, host Mark Thomas tours through some of the most remarkably cultivated private gardens the world over.

title: Extraordinary Angles Inspired by... Pools
description: The Sothebys International Realty brand presents Extraordinary Angles the lifestyle video series showcasing unique properties and lifestyles from around the world. In this episode, host Mark Thomas dives into some of the worlds most impressive swimming pools.

title: Extraordinary Angles Inspired by... Equestrian Living
description: The Sothebys International Realty brand presents Extraordinary Angles the lifestyle video series showcasing unique properties and lifestyles from around the world. In this episode, host Mark Thomas takes a ride through some of the most premier equestrian lifestyle estates.

title: Dizzying Times
description: Mom, youre only dizzy. What are you making such a big deal about?

title: U.N. Forces Are Caught in New Standoff
description: BAGHDAD  Another contingent of United Nations peacekeepers was caught in a standoff with Syrian rebels on Friday, a day after an armed group captured 44 peacekeepers in the area near the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.

title: Subarus Mainstay Stays That Way
description: The 2015 Outback is significantly better in everything, from handling to fuel economy, without surrendering its core role as practical all-weather transportation.

title: When a Child Kills
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  WHEN I was 12 years old, I killed a younger brother in a hunting accident near our home in upstate New York. I returned to that memory this week, when I read about what happened to the young New Jersey girl who lost control of a submachine gun at a shooting range outside Las Vegas, killing her instructor.

title: Tony Stewart Says Kevin Ward Jr.s Death Will Affect Him Forever
description: HAMPTON, Ga.  Tony Stewart ended nearly three weeks of silence since his racecar struck and killed a young driver at an upstate New York dirt track, voicing sympathy on Friday for the family of Kevin Ward Jr. and suggesting a return to Nascar competition this weekend would help him cope with lingering grief.

title: Photographing Politics
description: Throughout The Timess headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: Look at Life Through Autistic Eyes
description: For their senior film at the Ringling College of Art and Design, Marisabel Fernandez and Alexander Bernard created an animated simulation of life through the eyes of a non-verbal child with an Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and her constant struggle to cope with the world around her, as they write in their artist statement.

title: Iggy Azaleas Shoe Line, Chlo Sevignys Book Deal and Instagrams New App
description: Zaras Nazi shirt scandal

title: Divisions Grow as a Downturn Rocks Europe
description: PARIS  Six years after being struck by economic crisis, Europe is facing a fresh downturn, with few new ideas on the table for reigniting growth and deepening political divisions over the austerity policies that many blame for worsening the malaise.

title: Chelsea Clinton to Leave Well-Paid NBC News Job
description: Less than three years after she embarked on a new and lucrative career as an NBC News special correspondent, Chelsea Clinton said on Friday that she would leave that position.

title: Group Adventures, With a Sense of Play
description: Every few months, at Musha Cay, a private resort in the Bahamas owned by David Copperfield, the magician gathers his guests and tells them the legend of the unknown pirate. In an old book bought in an antiques store, he explains, he found a pirate, a relative of his. Then he asks the guests for help finding his treasure.

title: Freuds City, From Couch to Cafes
description: Sigmund Freuds feelings about Vienna ranged from ambivalence to outright hatred. Vienna oppresses me, he wrote in his letters, describing the city alternately as disgusting or almost physically repulsive, calling its glorious cathedral, St. Stephens, that abominable steeple, and complaining of his exceedingly cultivated, music-loving, cafe-crazed Viennese followers, I wish they had a single backside so that I could thrash them all with one stick.

title: Set in Flight by Gouache and Oil
description: A century ago, the windows of East 57th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues were the art showcase of New York, but now not a single oil, gouache, etching or sculpture tempts the passer-by.

title: 1,000 Islands, 2 Worlds
description: The restaurant was somewhere near the presidential palace. At least thats what the Internet had said. It was dark in Mal, the capital of the Maldives, where we had woken up at our hotel, hungry after traveling for more than 40 hours. Wed slept through our chance to eat there: The kitchen downstairs was already closed. But Google Maps proposed a takeout place a couple of blocks away.

title: Movie Review: Through a Lens Darkly.
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People.

title: Movie Review: Starred Up
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Starred Up.

title: Movie Review: The Notebook
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Notebook: (Le Grand Cahier).

title: Glaring Weakness Could Mean Trouble for the Jets
description: A look at the 2014 season for the Jets:

title: On Instagrams Hyperlapse, and Fast-Forwarding to the Future
description: Most days, my Instagram feed is full of artfully arranged plates of food, dreamy vacation photos, gurgling babies and, of course, plenty of selfies.

title: A Roasted Green Chile Evokes Santa Fe
description: During late August and early September in New Mexico, the air is filled with the pungent aroma of roasting green chiles. Just the thought of it makes me nostalgic for the years when I lived in Santa Fe.

title: For Andy Murray, the Idea of an Independent Scotland Starts to Hit Home
description: The issue of what it means to be Scottish is a rising debate, with a referendum scheduled for Sept. 18 to determine if Scotland should be an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom. Andy Murray, one of the worlds most famous Scotsmen, has stayed quiet about his opinion on the vote, but says he has been following the debate very closely. After his comfortable 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 second-round victory over the qualifier Matthias Bachinger on Thursday night, Murray spoke to The New York Times about going home to Scotland. In previous conversations at the U.S. Open, Murray has discussed his perspective on this years tournament and female coaches in tennis. (This interview was condensed and edited.)

title: At Play in the Cardboard Jungle
description: On a recent weeknight in Greenwich Village, amid the circus of New York University dive bars, comedy-show hecklers and the drummers of Washington Square Park, there was a different sort of chaos.

title: Obama Again Tips the Scales Toward Caution on Syria
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama said on Thursday that he had no strategy yet for dealing with lethal Sunni militants in Syria, he seemed out of sync with his top military advisers and aides, who only days earlier had taken a more aggressive tone about military action.

title: Obituaries for the Pre-Dead
description: If you can read this, then you are almost certainly pre-dead.

title: And a Box of Tissues
description: Heres something you rarely see: New York psychotherapists in their offices in August. It took Sebastian Zimmermann, a psychiatrist on the Upper West Side, 13 years to produce Fifty Shrinks, a book of portraits depicting therapists in their natural habitats. Dr. Zimmermann, who began studying photography as an outlet to counterbalance all the trauma and drama he was taking in as a therapist, said he was struck by the diversity of spaces in which his colleagues worked.

title: Of Pot and Percocet
description: PRESCRIPTION opioid painkillers like Percocet, Vicodin and OxyContin have come under intense scrutiny in recent years because of the drastic rise in overdose deaths associated with their prolonged use. Meanwhile, access to medical marijuana has been expanding  23 states and the District of Columbia have legalized its broad medical use  and chronic or severe pain is by far the most common condition reported among people using it.

title: A Topsy-Turvy Match in a Draw Turned Upside Down
description: Almost concurrently, three womens matches pounded away at the United States Open on Friday afternoon, and their combined effect was to all but detonate the expectations for one half of the draw.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Hand-Built Hall of Fame
description: A General Motors retiree and self-taught sculptor in Flint, Mich., has been putting local automotive pioneers back on their feet.

title: Growing Together on the Vine
description: Robust, complex, balanced  such are the words that oenophiles often use in the pursuit of their passion: the obsessive, competitive world of wine.

title: Cure for the Howling at the Door
description: Acuras that chirp and Toyotas that seep oil are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Its a Long Way to the Top
description: TESTED 2014 Ram 2500 Power Wagon Laramie Crew Cab 4x4

title: Sharing the Family Genes
description: The 2015 Subaru Legacy shares its underpinnings and powertrains with the vastly more popular Outback  the crossover outsells the sedan by a large margin  so it also benefits from that models significant improvements in fuel economy, handling and all-around civility that came with this years redesign.

title: In Flint, a New Bronze Age
description: FLINT, MICH.  When Joe Rundell decided to become a sculptor at age 71, he didnt get a lot of encouragement. A great-grandfather, he had already been retired for 20 years after three decades as a machine repairman at a General Motors engine plant. Also, he didnt know how to make sculptures.

title: Shuffle, Deal and Learn
description: For the most part, apps are not vehicles for new ideas; instead, they usually digitize old ones, providing exciting new ways to hail a cab, get your laundry and shopping done, or report municipal problems to the appropriate authority.

title: Lyft Says Ubers Recruitment Efforts Are Hurting Drivers
description: The saying All is fair in love and war apparently applies to recruiting employeesnow, too.

title: Obamas Rhetoric vs. Kerrys on Syria
description: As Washington debated military action against Syria in 2013, Secretary of State John Kerrys statements were notably hawkish. Five days later, President Obama shocked his aides by voicing caution.

title: Obama: No Strategy Yet on Syria
description: The president made a statement, at the White House briefing room on Thursday, about possible action in Syria.

title: Revisiting Life and Death in Africa
description: Yunghi Kim went to Somalia 20 years ago expecting to cover a famine. She found herself instead in a war zone.

title: In New Jersey, Making Labor Day Less Laborious
description: Labor Day is supposed to be about honoring workers with a day of rest. But for families with young children, the holiday can be anything but relaxing. Camp is over, summer vacations are winding down and school, for many, hasnt started yet. Thankfully there are plenty of public events on Sept. 1, many of them free, to help entertain families in need of escape from their own backyards. After Labor Day, some of these outdoor attractions will continue for weekends to come, as long as the temperate weather holds out.

title: An Ensemble That Lives in a Tower
description: The neo-Gothic tower of Riverside Church plays refuge to a number of rare, if no longer actively endangered, species. Exhibit A: Henry and Henrietta, the pair of peregrine falcons that nest on a ledge high above Morningside Heights. Exhibit B: the Locrian Chamber Players, one of the most uncompromising contemporary-music ensembles in the city.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: S.E.C. Commissioner Rebukes His Colleagues
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is the regulator that is supposed to crack down on executives who put misleading and fraudulent numbers into their financial filings.

title: A Front-Row Seat for a Gaucho Festival
description: Every spring in Argentina, the local cowboys, called gauchos, gather in the historical town of San Antonio de Areco for a nine-day festival to show off their equestrian skills, and for the 75th year running from Nov. 1 to 9, the 19th-century ranch La Bamba de Areco is giving travelers a chance to participate in the celebration.

title: Handmade Landscapes
description: THE earth isnt the same when you fly over it at 3,000 feet. Its easy to lose your bearings. All the reassuring textures of daily life are lost. But its a grand perch for viewing our tracks on the ground  visible everywhere and just as readable as the cleft-heart footprints left by white-tailed deer.

title: Ouch. My Personality, Reviewed.
description: THE other week I was riding crosstown in an Uber car, chatting with the very nice driver about how much I liked Uber, and the driver said, by way of being helpful, I believe, You have a 4.5 rating. If it drops to 4.0, no driver will pick you up.

title: Comic Books Even Teachers Can Love
description: When fifth graders at P.S. 124 in Brooklyn were given a sneak peek last winter of Theseus and the Minotaur, a retelling of the classic Greek myth by the French writer and cartoonist Yvan Pommaux, they immediately took to the tale, their teacher, Daniel Tandarich, said. And why not? The book, the first from Toon Graphics, is filled with gruesomely creative murders, feats of superhuman strength, misbehaving gods and bloodthirsty beasts. A scene in which a rampaging bull gores a Cretan youth was a particular favorite, Mr. Tandarich said. The best part about Theseus and the Minotaur, at least for this audience: Its a comic book.

title: Gin and Tonic, Revised Downward
description: The good news this week: The government is spending less on Medicare, the health insurance program for older people and the disabled.

title: Medicares Rating System for Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Inspiration From a Dramatic Landscape
description: When explaining the roots of the exhibition Iceland: Artists Respond to Place at the Katonah Museum of Art, Pari Stave, the curator, is careful to note that not all Icelandic artists allow the countrys dramatic landscape to guide their work.

title: The Discomfort Over HPV Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Credit Card Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: In Las Vegas, Gun Ranges Are Tourist Draws
description: Mary Bonner, a medical receptionist from San Luis Obispo, Calif., said that she makes it a point to stop in at a gun range when she is in Las Vegas for her annual holiday. She held her first gun just over two years ago when her boyfriend asked her to accompany him to a Las Vegas shooting range.

title: Dealing With Myanmar
description: To the Editor:

title: Things Dr. Spock Never Suggested
description: It used to be that if you had kids, you gleaned child-rearing advice from your parents or your neighbors or your religious community. But these days, that seems pretty last century, or perhaps the century before that.

title: Honoring an Instrument of Few Strings With the Strength of a Symphony
description: Most mystics begin their lives in the wider community and then retreat into seclusion, but the musician and philosopher Ostad Elahi (1895-1974) followed the opposite path. After a sequestered youth perfecting his skills on the tanbur  a long-necked lute  in the company of mystics like his father, he moved to Tehran, became an influential judge and helped establish a new legal system in Iran.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Liberia, Italy and Moscow.

title: Mythology Lessons in the Paris Catacombs
description: The experience of watching As Above/So Below is much like observing a colonoscopy in the hands of a particularly inexpert and excitable physician. Instead of human intestines, we have the bowels of Paris  the mass cemetery known as the catacombs  into which a small group of rash young folks spelunks in search of the legendary Philosophers Stone.

title: Pre-Labor Day Food News
description: California: As the three-year drought drags on, the Bureau of Reclamation has decided to save some water for the fish. Last week the agencybegan releasingadditional water from a nearby reservoir to supplement flows in the lower Klamath River. Thousands of adult Chinook salmon are struggling to survive in the river, whose waters are running dangerously low and warm due to diversion of river flows into the Central Valley for agriculture. While the move is a win for environmental groups and Indian tribes that depend on the salmon for subsistence, drought-weary farmers are crying foul.

title: A Criminal With Charm
description: Too many recent Bollywood movies have felt frantic, so eager to please that they seem like flop-sweat machines spitting out knockabout gags and silly shtick. And those arent even the comedies.

title: A Queens Forbidden Love
description: THEIR relationship titillated a nation. For more than a century, biographers have tried to fathom the improbable friendship Queen Victoria had with her Scottish servant John Brown. It has been posited as one of the great unanswered questions of her reign. How intimate were they?

title: Saving Our Birds
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  THE passenger pigeon is among the most famous of American birds, but not because of its beauty, or its 60-mile-an-hour flight speed. Nor is it a cherished symbol of our great country. No, we remember the passenger pigeon because of the largest-scale human-caused extinction in history.

title: Behold! New Lebanon
description: A new tourism project in the Hudson Valley town of New Lebanon, N.Y.

title: Judge Rejects Texas Stricture on Abortions
description: A federal judge in Austin, Tex., blocked a stringent new rule on Friday that would have forced more than half of the states remaining abortion clinics to close, the latest in a string of court decisions that have at least temporarily kept abortion clinics across the South from being shuttered.

title: The 15th World Youth Teams Championships in Bridge
description: ISTANBUL  At the 15th World Youth Teams Championships here last week, in the girls event, for players born after 1988, the round-robin qualifying matches were followed by four 56-board quarterfinals. In these, there were easy victories for China, Italy and the Netherlands (over the United States). In the fourth, Australia led France by 27 international match points, with 14 boards to be played, but in a big last session, France triumphed by 12 imps.

title: Federal Judge Approves California Plan to Reduce Isolation of Mentally Ill Inmates
description: Corrections officials in California will make significant changes in the use of solitary confinement for mentally ill prisoners, revising decades-old policies that have kept thousands of inmates who have psychiatric disorders in isolation.

title: Friday Night Music: Rodrigo y Gabriela
description: Boy, am I behind the curve here  didnt even know they existed, and they turn out to have a huge following and have just appeared on Letterman again. But anyway, quite something (and very different):

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Vintage Cars Return to Lime Rock
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Film Fests for a Few (Oddballs Especially)
description: Overwrought because you missed the first anxiety film festival this summer in London? Fear not.

title: A Refuge of Natural Light
description: From Winslow Homer, William Merritt Chase, Jackson Pollock and Robert Dash to contemporaries such as Chuck Close and David Salle, many notable artists have cited the revered light of Long Islands East End as a source of inspiration. The coastal atmosphere it illuminates has been described as wet, magical, hallucinatory, special, moist and, in a 1972 poem by John N. Morris, clear as gin.

title: Ruling Strikes Down Restrictive Texas Abortion Law
description: In this 21-page ruling, Judge Lee Yeakel of the United States District Court in Austin, Tex., said the restrictions, which would have closed more than half the states abortion clinics, placed an unconstitutional burden on a womans right to an abortion.

title: Movies Have Worst Summer Since 1997
description: LOS ANGELES  American moviegoers sent a clear message to Hollywood over the summer: We are tired of more of the same.

title: Hillary Clintons Gay Rights Evolution
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  The crowd of supporters stretched around Main Street on a busy Saturday in August, hundreds of Hamptonites curving past the Ralph Lauren and Tiffany & Co. stores, waiting patiently to greet Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Focus Is Mediterranean; Ingredients Are Local
description: Its the summer tomato salad that may have delivered the most succinct summation of the considerable appeal of the restaurant 8 North Broadway in Nyack.

title: Bubbles Carry a Lot of Weight
description: Its called the typing awareness indicator, and a few months ago, my therapist ordered me to disable it on my phone. Its causing you too much anxiety, she said, pointing to the iPhone I had in a white-knuckle grip. Its giving monumental weight to matters of a text message.

title: Medicare Will Settle Short-Term Care Bills
description: Sharply criticized by Congress and others, Medicare quietly announced on Friday that it would settle hundreds of thousands of hospital appeals over bills for short-term care, by offering deals that could add up to several hundred million dollars.

title: John Seversons New Book on Surf Culture
description: A look at work from a founding father of American surf culture.

title: The Invasion of the Lobster Legs
description: The gastro pub. Downton Abbey. Adele. Now, red pants?

title: The Memories Come Back in Waves
description: Its been easy to forget these days  this summer  what it was supposed to be about. How could it not be when weve just gotten a glimpse of the worlds first $1.3 million surfboard? Or when the brokerage firm Scottrade runs television ads with a surfer-investor equating stock picks with wave selection? Then theres this new Brooks Brothers ad that has some stylized Biff in a sweater carrying a board under his woolly arm.

title: A Farce of Love, Obsession and Betrayal
description: Barbara lives alone and wouldnt have it any other way. There she is, in the first scene of Alan Ayckbourns Things We Do for Love, graciously entertaining in her elegant, spotlessly clean London living room. A windowed dining area is a few feet upstage at the Westport Country Playhouse.

title: Bill Cunningham | Transition to Fall
description: Crossroad As summer fades, women are adjusting to autumn with a deeper palette, from fir-tree greens to burgundies, charcoal and black. This summer will be remembered for its cool weather, calling for jackets and cardigans. The curiosities were the popularity of city shorts and one-piece playsuits, and of gladiator sandals. Lace shorts gained momentum for a second year. And the summer was not without whimsy.

title: Swirls of Dust and Drama, Punctuating Life in the Southwest
description: PHOENIX  The best way to explain a haboob is to say it is a tsunami of sand, in the sense that there is no stopping it or outrunning it. It is a supreme spectacle. The fierce winds that precede it make the leaves on palm trees stand as if they are hands waving an effusive goodbye, the sky darkens and the world takes the color of caramel as the dust swallows everything in its path.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fall Transition
description: As summer fades, women are adjusting to autumn with a deeper palette, from fir-tree greens to burgundies, charcoal and black.

title: Evening Hours | Nostalgia at the Gardner
description: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum recalls its earliest days.

title: Seeing Just One Way for Greece to Go: Up
description: ATHENS  The first time Gikas Hardouvelis left his job as a bank economist to try his hand at Greek politics, in 2000, the country was preparing to join the euro currency union, looking forward to a period of prosperity and optimism.

title: Yankees, Still Uncertain on Tanaka and Playoffs, Dispatch Blue Jays
description: TORONTO  Injuries have been so much a thread woven through the Yankees season that even on nights when they should be celebrating an important victory, ailments to key players keep dominating the conversation.

title: To Defeat Terror, We Need the Worlds Help
description: IN a polarized region and a complicated world, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria presents a unifying threat to a broad array of countries, including the United States. Whats needed to confront its nihilistic vision and genocidal agenda is a global coalition using political, humanitarian, economic, law enforcement and intelligence tools to support military force.

title: Stop Dithering, Confront ISIS
description: AFTER more than three years, almost 200,000 dead in Syria, the near collapse of Iraq, and the rise of the worlds most sinister terrorist army  the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, which has conquered vast swaths of both countries  President Obamas admission this week that we dont have a strategy yet to deal with this threat is startling. It is also dangerous.

title: Quarantine for Ebola Lifted in Liberia Slum
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Liberias government announced Friday night that it would lift an Ebola quarantine on a large slum here in the capital, 10 days after attempts to cordon off the neighborhood from the rest of the city sparked deadly clashes and fueled doubts about President Ellen Johnson Sirleafs ability to handle the outbreak.

title: Evening Hours | Nostalgia at the Gardner
description: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum recalls its earliest days.

title: At Gateway to Hamptons, Ku Klux Klan Advertises for New Members
description: HAMPTON BAYS, N.Y.  All along the bucolic back roads of this blue-collar gateway to the more opulent Hamptons, residents agree: There is nothing sophisticated about the Ku Klux Klans continuing drive to recruit new members.

title: Mediterranean Themes at a Culinary Bazaar
description: When exactly did Middletown become cool? Its spacious Main Street, sunlit and broad like a Midwestern town, seems an unlikely setting for culinary bohemianism. Yet its crammed with different kinds of restaurants  Vietnamese, Tibetan, Mexican; a diner; a pizza-and-bourbon joint; a vegetarian place; and on and on.

title: Nuclear Waste Is Allowed Above Ground Indefinitely
description: As the country struggles to find a place to bury spent nuclear fuel, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has decided that nuclear waste from power plants can be stored above ground in containers that can be maintained and guarded indefinitely.

title: New West Renaissance
description: LAKEVIEW, Mont.  Just a teardrop down from the Continental Divide, in one of the most remote hideaways in the United States, is a place that should be called Hope. At 6,700 feet above sea level, Centennial Valley is high, mostly dry, and slack-jaw beautiful. The fact that there are more trumpeter swans here than people is a story that tells much about why the American West has never been more vibrant.

title: Iraqi Kurds Expand Autonomy as ISIS Reorders the Landscape
description: WASHINGTON  The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria has thrown Iraq into crisis, precipitated the ouster of Nuri Kamal al-Maliki as prime minister and brought the American military back to the country it left more than two years ago.

title: Feast of Season Openers in College Football Worthy of Top Billing
description: On Thursday, No. 9 South Carolina was routed at home by No. 21 Texas A&M, 52-28, and newly ascendant Mississippi, ranked 18th, blasted formerly ascendant Boise State, 35-13, in Atlanta. On Saturday, No. 12 Georgia will host No. 16 Clemson; No. 1 Florida State will play Oklahoma State in Arlington, Tex.; and last years top midmajor, Central Florida, will play Penn State in Ireland  now that the volcano gods have forestalled a feared Icelandic eruption, permitting the teams to travel.

title: Handshakes and Hugs, Hallmarks of the Stump, Are Rare With Cuomo
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had no time for tortellini. Marching in a parade on Staten Island recently, he paused to pose for a picture with Vincent J. DAntuono, the owner of Pastosa Ravioli, an Italian specialty shop, who proudly invited the governor to step inside for a look around.

title: Saturdays College Football Games to Watch
description: 14 WISCONSIN vs. 13 L.S.U.

title: Leadership and Calm Are Urged in Ebola Outbreak
description: With the SARS outbreak in 2003, Taiwans news media was so alarmist that the government finally ordered every television channel to devote two minutes, three times a day, to a calm presentation of facts by Dr. Lee Ming-liang, a retired health minister in charge of the task force dealing with the disease.

title: Imagining Successful Schools
description: What should teacher accountability look like?

title: A Chef Finds a Kitchen of His Own
description: And still I think of the pear pizzetta appetizer. What a marvel: pizza dough cooked so expertly in a 500-degree convection oven that its light and flaky texture resembled that of pastry dough, with slivers of fresh pear, shaved radicchio, walnuts toasted to release oils that tasted like butter, and a thin layer of tangy Gorgonzola cheese running like lava across the surface of the whole, misshapen, messy pie. A drizzle of port wine, reduced until it resembled honey, united all the disparate elements.

title: U.S. Colleges See Little Risk From Ebola, but Depend on Students to Speak Up
description: With college students from countries hit by the Ebola outbreak entering the United States for a new school year, universities are downplaying the risk they might pose while admitting that they have limited ability to track students travels or their health.

title: Council Replaces President in Election Thats More Than a Popularity Contest
description: The past president of the ATP Player Council was preparing Friday for a prime-time match at the United States Open, in front of thousands at cavernous Arthur Ashe Stadium. His successor had played on the far less daunting locales of Court 6 and Court 7.

title: A New Spot on the North Fork
description: No one could accuse Tom Schaudel of lacking a sense of humor. In June, Mr. Schaudel, a restaurateur and chef, opened a new place called Petulant Wino in the heart of North Fork wine country. He told his staff the name was autobiographical. The employee who related this conversation to me in a phone call after my visits there said, Hes not a bit petulant.

title: 50 Days of War Leave Israelis and Palestinians Only More Entrenched
description: JERUSALEM  Only time will tell whether Israel will maintain the quiet it so desperately sought during 50 days of war with Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip, and whether Hamas will leverage the worlds outrage over so many civilian casualties to improve the lives of the coastal enclaves 1.7 million residents.

title: In First for Court, Woman Is Ruled Eligible for Asylum in U.S. on Basis of Domestic Abuse
description: The nations highest immigration court has found for the first time that women who are victims of severe domestic violence in their home countries can be eligible for asylum in the United States.

title: Onetime Prodigy Turning Heads Again at 32
description: After she popped an ace past Simona Halep on match point, Mirjana Lucic-Baroni dropped her racket to the court, turned to a small group of family and friends who were sitting nearby and stretched her arms out wide with her palms up. It was an expression with a meaning understood by everyone at the Grandstand on Friday afternoon: What just happened?

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 29, 2014
Choices for the Legislature and the Civil Court
description: Winners of Democratic primary races in New York City often go on to win the general election in November because so few Republicans offer strong competition. For the Democratic primaries on Sept. 9, here are our recommendations for four competitive races for New York State legislative offices and two Civil Court seats in Brooklyn.

title: Pakistan, Its Own Worst Enemy
description: Pakistan faces very big problems: a failing economy; a Taliban insurgency; and persistent tension with India, which has resulted again in exchanges of cross-border fire. The countrys leaders and citizens obviously need to join in common cause to put the country on a steadier course.

title: The Agony of Victory, Felt After Beating a Mentor
description: The quest for tennis excellence creates unexpected bonds and angst.

title: Pre-K Clash May Hint at the Start of a Rivalry Between de Blasio and Stringer
description: Scott M. Stringer has the sort of appearance  gray hair, rimless spectacles  that invites descriptions like mild-mannered and unassuming. But since taking office as New York Citys comptroller in January, he has proved to be an occasional thorn in the side of Mayor Bill de Blasio, clashing with his fellow Democrat over accounting and issuing harsh audits of city agencies.

title: Yes to Housing in Our Backyards
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios mission to fix New Yorks affordable-housing problem is both daunting and necessary, like fortifying a sandy coastline against a rising sea. The waves in this case would include smothering rents and decades of decay and disinvestment in government-subsidized housing for the working class and the poor.

title: Vicks Product
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I never thought Id say this, but thank goodness its the Saturday puzzle. Fridays grid by Daniel Raymon was a rough one for me, so I wasnt surprised in the least when the Saturday puzzle  the one New York Times puzzle thats for the truly brave  seemed easier to me in comparison.

title: Taxi Kills Pedestrian in Manhattan
description: A 58-year-old woman was struck and killed by a taxi on the Upper East Sideon Fridayafternoon, the police said, in the latest in a string of pedestrian fatalities in Manhattan.

title: Chronicling Mississippis Church Mothers, and Getting to Know a Grandmother
description: SUMNER, Miss.  Toward noon on a torrid Monday in the Mississippi Delta, Alysia Burton Steele drove down Highway 49, looking for the crossroads near the Old Antioch Baptist Church. There, at the corner of a road called Friendship, she turned into the African-American section of Sumner, a dwindling hamlet of about 300 that suffices as a county seat.

title: Putin Rushes In, Pretending Not to; Obama Stands Back
description: When a state sends more than a thousand troops with mobile artillery and heavy equipment into a neighboring state and takes control of territory, thats an invasion, right?

title: Modi Rebukes Pakistan After Cancellation of Talks
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  In his first public comments since India called off high-level talks with Pakistan last week, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said Islamabad had made a spectacle of the tentative peace process by meeting with separatist leaders from Kashmir, but added that India seeks peaceful, friendly and cooperative ties with its neighbor.

title: McConnells Campaign Manager Steps Down
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell, already facing what could be the toughest election in his career, lost his campaign manager on Friday night.

title: Ahmed Seif, Who Was Tortured in Egypt and Became Rights Defender, Dies at 63
description: Ahmed Seif, whose experience of torture as a political prisoner in Egypt inspired him to become a leading human rights lawyer defending leftists, Islamists, atheists and gays, died on Wednesday in Cairo. He was 63.

title: Werner Franz, Survivor of the Hindenburgs Crew, Dies at 92
description: Just before 7:30 p.m. on May 6, 1937, the Hindenburg, an immense German zeppelin that had spent three days crossing the Atlantic, erupted in flames as it approached its mooring mast at the Lakehurst Naval Air Station in central New Jersey. Seen around the world in newsreel coverage and photographs, the disaster, which was attributed to an electric spark igniting the hydrogen gas that kept the airship aloft, killed 35 of the 97 people on board and another man on the ground.

title: Rookies Bumpy Debut Is Still a Mets Victory
description: As the Mets warmed up Friday afternoon and Dilson Herrera played catch in the outfield, a popular Colombian song, El Preso, by the salsa group Fruko y Sus Tesos, rang throughout Citi Field. It seemed to be an attempt to welcome Herrera, the Mets 20-year-old second baseman, or at least ease his transition in some way.

title: Death of Man in Police Custody Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The New York City medical examiner announced on Friday that a mans death in police custody while he was high on PCP was a homicide.

title: Echoing Times Square, Downtown Jersey City Gets a No-Car Zone
description: JERSEY CITY  Class had just let out on a recent Monday evening at JC Taekwondo and Kickboxing Academy on Newark Avenue. Children wearing bright white keikogi practiced their moves on the sidewalk and chased each other through the street. They darted around families pushing strollers, diners sitting at painted picnic tables and weary commuters trudging home from the Grove Street PATH station a block away.

title: Jack Kraft, Villanova Basketball Coach, Dies at 93
description: Jack Kraft, who brought Villanova University to national basketball prominence in his 12 seasons as the Wildcats head coach and took them to the 1971 N.C.A.A. tournament championship game, died on Thursday at an assisted living facility in Cape May Court House, N.J. He was 93.

title: Afghanistan: 6 Killed in Assault on Intelligence Office in Jalalabad
description: JALALABAD  Insurgents early Saturday attacked the headquarters of the Afghan intelligence service here in this eastern city, setting off a huge bomb that killed at least six people and wounded 45 others, Afghan officials said. The attackers, who included suicide bombers, were believed to have taken up positions in a nearby building to continue the assault, the officials said. The initial bomb, which the authorities described as huge, was hidden in a car and detonated outside the provincial headquarters of the National Directorate of Security here about 5 a.m. It was not immediately clear if the victims were intelligence employees or civilians. The bomb damaged many homes in the vicinity of the directorate offices, witnesses at the scene said.

title: Investigation at Saratoga
description: There have been 11 horse deaths so far at the Saratoga meeting that ends Monday, up from eight last year, said Scott E. Palmer, the New York State equine medical director. He said in a statement that a thorough investigation of all of the racing fatalities during the 2014 Saratoga meet is being conducted.

title: Inheriting Successful Tour, New ATP Chief Looks to the Future
description: After the death of Brad Drewett last year, the ATP appointedChris Kermode as itsexecutive chairman and president. Kermode, 49, was a player on the lower tiers of tennis before serving as the director of two tournaments in his hometown, London.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 30, 2014
description: She still has her bedroom. She slept there last night and will sleep there again tonight.

title: Corrections: August 30, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG (2013) Benedict Cumberbatch lends his voice to Smaug, the menacing dragon who lords over the lost dwarf kingdom and vast treasure in this second installment in Peter Jacksons adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkiens book. Martin Freeman (who plays Watson to Mr. Cumberbatchs Holmes on the television series Sherlock) once again portrays Bilbo, the hobbit who has been chosen to lead the fight for the reclamation. Mr. Jackson has taken roughly five chapters from the middle of Tolkiens book and turned them into a relentless adventure tale, teeming with rowdy action, slavering enemies and Elven gymnastics, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, noting the directors tendency to pile it on. Once again, she said, there are too many busy, uninterestingly staged battles that lean heavily on obvious, sometimes distracting digital sorcery. But there are also pacific, brooding interludes in which the actors  notably Mr. Freeman, an intensely appealing screen presence  remind you that theres more to Middle-earth than clamor and struggle.

title: Alibaba to Begin Investor Roadshow in Week of Sept. 8
description: Investors hoping to finally buy a piece of the Alibaba Group will have to wait a little longer.

title: Analytics: How Readers Reacted to Our Article About Hybrid Species
description: The following graphic appears on the Reply All page in the Aug. 31 issue of the magazine.

title: New Novartis Drug Effective in Treating Heart Failure
description: An experimental drug has shown a striking efficacy in prolonging the lives of people with heart failure and could replace what has been the bedrock treatment for more than 20 years, researchers said on Saturday.

title: Getting a Clear Picture of a Computer Networks Security
description: Security experts say the only hope of protecting corporate networks from hackers is something the industry calls defense in depth.

title: How to Manage Google Location Tracking
Midterm Election Mind-Reading: The Market Tends to Win
description: Will the Republicans win control of Congress? With summer drawing to a close, the midterm election is just two months away and this question is likely to be analyzed and debated with increasing urgency.

title: 1914: Details of Construction Mark German Aeroplanes
description: At least one German aeroplane has flown above Paris on each of the past three days. Owing to the particular construction of many of these machines, they are, as a rule, easily recognizable. In this connection, however, the Petit Parisien publishes an interesting article drawing attention to the essential differences between the principal makes of French and German aeroplanes.

title: A Rare Peek at a Protected Island
description: The government shutdown last October was a spoiler for anyone who planned to visit a national park during the impasse. But in one case, it led to a rare opportunity to experience one of the most pristine environments along theCaliforniacoast.

title: When Apartments Become Hotels
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Are Police Bigoted?
description: IF anything good has come out of this months fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., it is that the death of the black teenager shined a spotlight on the plague of shootings of black men by white police officers. And maybe now, the nation will begin to address the racism behind it.

title: Day of IMFamy
description: Two pieces I did for the IMF are online. First, my Mundell-Fleming lecture, on the possibility or lack thereof of Greek-style crises in countries that borrow in their own currencies. Second, a set of brief notes from various recipients of the Swedish thingie.

title: Lindsey Ueberroth of Preferred Hotels: When Running a Meeting, Speak Last
description: This interview with  Lindsey Ueberroth, chief executive of the Preferred Hotel Group, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Losing Our Touch
description: Are we losing our senses? In our increasingly virtual world, are we losing touch with the sense of touch itself? And if so, so what?

title: Scylla, Charybdis, and the Euro
description: Ive been talking to some people I respect about the fate of the euro, and specifically yesterdays column, and it seems to me that the key issue here involves the balance of risks.

title: Zubin Mehta
description: Zubin Mehta is an Indian-born conductor who has directed many of the worlds finest orchestras. He is the music director for life of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra and the chief conductor of the Orchestra del Maggio Musicale Fiorentino.

title: The Future of the Corporate Tax
description: The Future of the Corporate Tax

title: Between Godliness and Godlessness
description: ALMOST midway through Sam Harriss new book, Waking Up, he paints a scene that will shock many of his fans, who know him as one of the countrys most prominent and articulate atheists.

title: ISIS Displaying a Deft Command of Varied Media
description: The extremists who have seized large parts of Syria and Iraq have riveted the worlds attention with their military prowess and unrestrained brutality. But Western intelligence services are also worried about their extraordinary command of seemingly less lethal weapons: state-of-the-art videos, ground images shot from drones and multilingual Twitter messages.

title: For a Career Guide, 42 Years of Soft Landings
description: Richard Bolles does not mince words. Let us put the matter simply and candidly, he writes. The whole process of the job hunt in this country is Neanderthal.
