title: Variety: Camouflage
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Well, this was a fun and refreshing puzzle. As it says in the instructions, this puzzle was completed in seven minutes and 40 seconds by Jeffrey Harris of Nashville, Tenn., at the recent National Puzzlers League Convention in Portland, Me. Thats not exactly news, as he is an exceptionally brilliant person who tends to win most of these things, so sincere congratulations, Mr. Harris. To the rest of you, a word of warning: If you ever see Mr. Harris sharpening his pencil within your line of sight at a puzzle tournament, run for your lives.

title: A Family Hits the Road
description: RUSTED ROOTs song Send Me on My Way is blaring as my sister, Cassidy, winds our little Nissan Sentra through the serpentine roads of the Cascade Mountains in Oregon. The fresh basil my dad bought as a car freshener is wilting on the dash, adding to the smells from our dirt-covered clothes, rich with the odors of helping out at a friends farm.

title: No Canvas, No Leather: A Reboot for the Sneaker
description: When people first pick up a pair of sneakers designed by Steven Weinreb, they are typically perplexed.

title: Ukraine President Says Europes Security Depends on Stopping Russia
description: BRUSSELS  Accusing Russia of waging a campaign of military aggression and terror against his country, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine told European leaders here on Saturday that their own countries security depended on stopping Russian troops from stoking a conflict in eastern Ukraine that he said could escalate into a wider war.

title: When Did We Get So Old?
description: JOHNATHAN RODGERS, who is 68, knew that it was time to step down as president and chief executive of the cable channel TV One when he looked around the conference table. I had almost always been the youngest through most of my career, says the former media executive. Now I was the oldest, and it caused great discomfort.

title: Liberal Zionism Today
description: Strong reactions to an essay saying that Israeli policies have tarnished the Zionist ideal.

title: Endless Assault on Health Care Reform
description: The opponents of the Affordable Care Act make no secret of their consuming hatred for the law that has already provided health care to millions of lower-income people.

title: Stop Hiding Images of American Torture
description: A hooded man standing on a box, electrodes wired to his fingers. A naked prisoner lying on a cement floor, a leash around his neck held casually by an American soldier. The bloody bodies of dead inmates with their heads bashed in.

title: Attack Kills 12 at Afghan Compound
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  A dozen people were killed when insurgents attacked the headquarters of the Afghan intelligence service in this eastern city Saturday.

title: Broken Promises on National Service
description: AmeriCorps turns 20 on Sept. 12, and as the nations main public service program in those two decades, it has benefited numerous communities and given 900,000 Americans a chance to help people.

title: With Memories Entrenched, Hallowed Site of U.S. Open Plows Forward
description: There is a Big Dig in Flushing Meadows Park  trash bins lined up in a gouged hillside off the Grand Central Parkway.

title: High Tea With Mr. Fancypants Sheen
description: IS sex more important than music, war, sports and vampires? Is sex more important than Nixon?

title: Diplomat and Warrior
description: ON Sept. 8, 2011, Hillary Clinton, then secretary of state, wrote to the secretary of the Army requesting that an exception to policy be granted to allow Richard C. Holbrooke to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery. Holbrooke had collapsed in her office nine months earlier. He died soon after while serving in the most thankless of his many assignments, as President Obamas special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: When Whites Just Dont Get It
description: MANY white Americans say they are fed up with the coverage of the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo. A plurality of whites in a recent Pew survey said that the issue of race is getting more attention than it deserves.

title: Lesotho Military Moves on Police
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A military coup in the tiny southern African kingdom of Lesotho has chased out the prime minister and apparently put the army in control of the landlocked nation, witnesses and journalists in the capital said on Saturday.

title: Facing Hard-Liners and Sanctions, Irans Leader Toughens Talk
description: TEHRAN  For more than a year, Irans president, Hassan Rouhani, had been walking a political tightrope by trying to restore some level of relations with the countrys archenemy, the United States. His hard-line opponents pelted him with eggs for his efforts, while those who voted for him hoped for a possible thaw.

title: The Original Charter School Vision
description: ALTHOUGH the leaders of teachers unions and charter schools are often in warring camps today, the original vision for charter schools came from Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers.

title: A Former Ace Nurtures His Work in Progress
description: LAS VEGAS  As Frank Viola walked toward the mound, Noah Syndergaard kicked at the dirt and hung his head like a child who knew he had misbehaved.

title: Getting Ferguson Majority to Show Its Clout at Polls
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Down the street from where the body of Michael Brown lay for hours after he was shot three weeks ago, volunteers have appeared beside folding tables under fierce sunshine to sign up new voters. On West Florissant Avenue, the site of sometimes violent nighttime protests for two weeks, voter-registration tents popped up during the day and figures like the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr. lectured about the power of the vote.

title: In E-Sports, Video Gamers Draw Real Crowds and Big Money
description: SEATTLE  A bewitching creature  half woman, half deer  battles a shaman and a sentient tree. Lightning bolts strike. Weapons explode. Nasty spells are cast.

title: Kvitova Is the Latest High Seed to Be Ousted; Djokovic Advances Easily
description: The first week of the United States Open has had no shortage of improbable stories: the victory by 15-year-old CiCi Bellis, the comeback of Mirjana Lucic-Baroni, the first Open experience for the 34-year-old fan favorite Victor Estrella Burgos.

title: Syrian Rebels Trade Fire With Troops From U.N.
description: ISTANBUL  Two bases for United Nations peacekeepers came under fire in southern Syria on Saturday, the United Nations said. One base was evacuated, and soldiers on the second returned fire, and later left the area.

title: Hey, Chef: Next Time, Skip the Fennel
description: It was a late July evening, and Christopher Sorter had just finished cooking an exotic five-course meal that included such triple-dare dishes as beef heart rag and crme brle with bone marrow. When the dinner began, there had been some apprehension about the food among the 120 guests who had gathered in a warehouselike space in Silver Spring, Md. But as waiters cleared the last plates, the event had a relieved and jubilant air, as if everyone had just narrowly dodged a bus.

title: Palestinian May Push for Deadline to End Occupation
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority may use the global stage of the annual General Assembly here in a few weeks to publicly demand a deadline for ending Israels occupation, according to his ambassador, while expecting that the Israelis  and almost certainly their American allies  will oppose that demand.

title: Fire Sale Begins to Pay Off for Marlins, for Now
description: Five major league teams lost at least 95 games last season, and four find themselves far below .500 again, a bystander to the pennant races. The Houston Astros, the Chicago White Sox, the Chicago Cubs and the Minnesota Twins are all but assured of another lonely October.

title: What the Arbitration Panel Didnt Want to Hear
description: Five years ago, Sean Martin, a registered representative at Deutsche Bank Securities in New York, saw something troubling on his trading desk.

title: In the W.N.B.A., Womens Coaching Journey Gets Easier
description: Seventeen years ago, Lin Dunn was coaching the Portland Power of the short-lived American Basketball League. Dunn believed in sharing her knowledge of the game, so she allowed college coaches to watch her practices.

title: Using Gambling to Entice Low-Income Families to Save
description: While building up savings offers the best route out of poverty, the glamourless grind of socking away a dollar here and there has a tough time competing with the heady fantasy of a Mega Millions jackpot. But instead of attacking lotteries, a growing number of credit unions and nonprofit groups are using them to encourage low-income families to save.

title: Pakistani Opposition Clashes With the Police
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Clashes broke out in the Pakistani capital on Saturday night after thousands of protesters led by two opposition leaders tried to march toward the residence of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.

title: George Galloway, British Lawmaker, Is Released From Hospital After Attack
description: LONDON  George Galloway, a member of the British Parliament known for his vocal criticism of Israel, was released from a hospital on Saturday after being treated for injuries suffered when an assailant attacked him on the streets of London.

title: Ukraines Success Rooted in an Atlanta Connection
description: Ask Mike Fratello how in the world he became the coach of Ukraines national basketball team, and a history book opens. It doesnt rewrite the consensus belief that N.B.A. globalization began earnestly with the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. It does provide a supplemental context that the growth of the game wasnt all Magic, Larry and Michael.

title: And Fairly Won
description: One hundred fifty years ago today, William Tecumseh Shermans corps, which had pulled back from in front of Atlanta  deceiving the Confederates into believing that they were in retreat  were scything around south of the city, cutting the rail lines. Hoods army got away, but the victory was nonetheless decisive, for political reasons: the fall of Atlanta convinced voters that the war could and would be won, and Lincoln was reelected.

title: The Culinary Contenders
description: For 10 weeks, a group of Dinner Lab chefs cooked at events around the country, vying for high scores from diners and the opportunity to open their own restaurants. Here is a quick look at the three finalists and the types of restaurants they have in mind.

title: The N.F.L.s Cultural Juggernaut May Risk Market Saturation
description: When the Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban said the N.F.L. was getting hoggy in reference to the expansion of its television package and predicted a decline in its popularity in a decade, he was mocked by the true believers.

title: Hal Finney, Cryptographer and Bitcoin Pioneer, Dies at 58
description: Hal Finney, a cryptographer and one of the earliest users and developers of the virtual currency Bitcoin, died on Thursday in Phoenix. He was 58.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 31
description: In a news briefing on Thursday, President Obama urged restraint and calm amid the continuing violence in Iraq and Ukraine, but he drew criticism when he said we dont have a strategy yet for military action against Sunni extremists in Syria. Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, appeared on several networks that evening to clarify the comment, saying that Mr. Obama was only speaking of Syria, and that the White House did have a strategy to combat the ISIS extremists who have crossed into Iraq.

title: Heartsick City Imports Hope
description: BEREA, Ohio  A Cleveland Browns fan for 36 years, Geoff Myers cringed when his team fell short of the Super Bowl in the 1980s, wept when it left for Baltimore in the 1990s and sulked as its successor failed to make the playoffs every year except one since the Browns resumed play a decade and a half ago.

title: Jets Make Two Prominent Cuts; Saints Release a 12-Time Pro Bowler
description: Cornerback Dimitri Patterson and receiver Stephen Hill, two of the Jets training-camp disappointments, were the most prominent among 21 players cut as the team trimmed its roster to the league-mandated 53-man limit.

title: Arthur H. White Dies at 90; Gauged Public Opinion and Encouraged Reading
description: Arthur H. White, a co-founder of Yankelovich, Skelly & White, an innovative opinion research firm that shed light on American cultural and political changes, who later became a prominent leader in the nonprofit world, died on Aug. 25 in Stamford, Conn. He was 90.

title: California Governor Appeals Court Ruling Overturning Protections for Teachers
description: LOS ANGELES  Wading into an intense national battle that has pitted teacher unions against a movement to weaken tenure protections, Gov. Jerry Brown has appealed a California judges sweeping ruling that threw out teacher job protection laws on the ground that they deprived students of their constitutional rights.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Towel Use Seen as Foul, In More Ways Than One

title: In Nod to Eastern Europe, E.U. Names Poland Premier to Key Post
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union selected an Eastern European to one of the blocs top posts for the first time on Saturday as tensions increased with Russia over its incursions into Ukraine.

title: Massachusetts May Shut Down Casinos Before Even One Opens
description: BOSTON  With the casino industry showing signs of retrenchment, voters in Massachusetts may do something that voters nowhere else have done, at least in the last century: slam on the brakes on casino gambling.

title: A Screenplay Challenge
description: Music buffs have a host of singing competition shows to choose from. Fashionistas have Project Runway and its imitators. And now comes a competition series for film geeks: The Chair, in which two first-time directors face off to see who can create the best movie from the same script.

title: A Footwork Challenge
description: Five minutes is barely enough time to make an entrance, let alone a clear and complete artistic statement, but thats the challenge posed by the annual DanceNow Festival. In this spirited contest and cocktail hour at Joes Pub, 40 choreographers (10 each night) vie for audience approval within a strict time limit. The dimensions of the pubs petite stage also encourage brevity. The nightly winners share an encore bill on Sept. 13 and, having made efficient use of time and space, receive more of both in the form of a creative residency in rural Pennsylvania.

title: The Working Class Made Colorful
description: The self-taught artist Ralph Fasanella (1914-97), born in the Bronx to Italian immigrants, believed that painting could be a form of labor advocacy. He worked as an ice delivery man, a truck driver, a gas station owner and a union organizer, all the while developing his colorful and detailed scenes of working-class life (as in Family Supper, which shows his mother, a garment worker, taking her second shift at a crowded dinner table). He also made historical paintings, like the mid-1970s series of canvases documenting the 1912 Bread and Roses strike in Lawrence, Mass.

title: Praise the Lord, and Chase the Ratings
description: A few years ago, Deitrick Haddon  son of a preacher, a gospel music star and a preacher himself  fled his Detroit home and ministry for Los Angeles and a war against God.

title: Chamber Music Festival Fills a Void
description: In recent years, the New York Chamber Music Festival has stepped up during the early September lull in the classical music calendar with innovative programs at Symphony Space featuring both established and emerging artists. This years festival offers some intriguing programs on Friday and Saturday.

title: Project Inspired by Klezmer
description: John Zorn  the indomitable composer, saxophonist and multiplatform ringleader  has lately enjoyed a flourishing of his music in notionally unlikely places, like the Newport Jazz Festival and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This week, hell be at the Village Vanguard, perhaps an even more surprising locale, presiding over 12 ensembles in a festival of his Jewish klezmer-inspired Masada project.

title: At Ferguson March, Call to Halt Traffic in Labor Day Highway Protest
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Activists on Saturday called for mass civil disobedience on the highways in and around this St. Louis suburb to protest the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer, with the leaders of one coalition encouraging supporters to stop their cars to tie up traffic on Labor Day.

title: Rams Cut Michael Sam, First Openly Gay Player Drafted in N.F.L.
description: Michael Sam, the first openly gay player drafted by an N.F.L. team, was cut by the St. Louis Rams on Saturday.

title: John Edwin Mroz, Clandestine Envoy to Arafat, Dies at 66
description: John Edwin Mroz, a consultant to governments in Europe, the Middle East and elsewhere who conducted secret talks with Yasir Arafat on behalf of the Reagan administration in an unsuccessful effort to persuade the Palestine Liberation Organization to accept Israels right to exist, died on Aug. 15 in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: Top Bitcoin Proponent to Plead Guilty to Federal Charge
description: A prominent supporter of Bitcoin, Charles Shrem, says he will plead guilty on Thursday to resolve federal charges that he helped smooth the way for drug transactions on the online marketplace Silk Road. He is to plead in New York to one count of aiding and abetting the operation of an unlicensed money transmitting business.

title: With Ellsbury Out, Yankees Are Shut Out
description: TORONTO  Even with Jacoby Ellsbury in the lineup, hits and runs from the Yankees offense have been scarce for most of the season. In recent weeks, though, the trend had begun to change. The Yankees went on the road, and suddenly they were averaging more than five runs a game during the first five games of their current trip.

title: John A. Walker Jr., Ringleader of Spy Family, Dies at 77
description: John A. Walker Jr., a former Navy officer who in 1986 pleaded guilty to recruiting his son, a brother and a friend into a spy ring that stole military documents and sold the information to Soviet agents, died on Thursday at the federal prison complex in Butner, N.C. He was 77.

title: Expected to Dazzle, Jameis Winston and Florida State Survive
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Florida State had secured its No. 1 ranking in a landslide vote, and why not? The Seminoles were the defending national champions, and pundits had pretty much given them a pass into the semifinals of college footballs playoff bracket.

title: 2014 N.F.L. Team Capsules
description: Quarterbacks take too much of the credit, and too much of the blame, on most football teams. An intricate dance of 22 players on the field is ignored in favor of the easy hero or scapegoat.

title: Heard at the Movies
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Its a really good thing that Joel Fagliano and Will Shortz put the years of the movies in this theme, because the first and last theme entries were particularly tricky for me.

title: Footage From an ISIS Drone
description: A scene from a recent hourlong ISIS documentary opening with footage shot from a drone over the Iraqi city of Falluja.

title: As Scots Weigh Independence, Wales Takes Note
description: CAERNARFON, Wales  Twm Morys was boiling carrots for his children when he momentarily stopped to recite a 15th-century battle chant in Welsh. Beating out the guttural consonants with a stave on his kitchen floor until they rang in every last corner of his farmhouse, Mr. Morys, a well-known poet, said it was time to put fire in the belly of his people.

title: Coverage for End-of-Life Talks Gaining Ground
description: DUNDEE, N.Y.  Five years after it exploded into a political conflagration over death panels, the issue of paying doctors to talk to patients about end-of-life care is making a comeback, and such sessions may be covered for the 50 million Americans on Medicare as early as next year.

title: A Lot of Races but Little, or No, Drama
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Community Makes Itself Known, With Discretion
description: LUBBOCK, Tex.  The rainbow flag did not fly at Lubbocks fourth gay pride festival on Aug. 23. Instead it was tied to a chain-link fence behind a community center east of Interstate 27 in a rundown industrial part of town. Despite the humble location, the daylong event with speakers and live music attracted about 400 people and was a milestone for the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community in this mostly conservative and religious Panhandle city.

title: For Two-Year Colleges, a Chance to Grant More Four-Year Degrees
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Since 2003, when South Texas College, Midland College and Brazosport College received permission to offer bachelors degrees, several other community colleges have tried to acquire the same authority.

title: Out of Sight? Not James Brown
description: James Browns 18-minute performance in the 1964 concert film The T.A.M.I. Show, in which he upstaged the Rolling Stones, is a performance as electrifying as Michael Jacksons 1983 moonwalk dance moves, which it foreshadowed. It can be revisited in the James Brown Performance Compilation, which has two screenings on Sunday at the Walter Reade Theater, as part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center series James Brown: The Hardest Working Man in Show Business. Here is the godfather of soul in his limber prime, with his group the Famous Flames, performing a medley of Out of Sight, Prisoner of Love, Please, Please, Please (the high point) and Night Train. In the throes of passion, he feigns a collapse from which his musicians revive him, and executes a one-legged precursor of Jacksons moonwalk.

title: On Climate, a Younger Bushs Ideas Stray From Party Ideology
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  On the campaign trail in Texas for a little-known statewide office, George P. Bush is generally toeing the Republican Party line: He is attacking the federal health care overhaul, decrying abortion and championing gun rights.

title: An Artist Is Rebuked for Casting South Koreas Leader in an Unflattering Light
description: GWANGJU, South Korea  After 250 South Korean high school students died in the sinking of the Sewol ferry in April, the artist Hong Sung-dam lashed out at a political and business elite he considers responsible for the disaster, doing so in the way he knows best. He painted, pouring his protest onto canvas just as he did during the countrys long years of military dictatorship.

title: At Risk in Senate, Democrats Seek to Rally Blacks
description: WASHINGTON  With their Senate majority imperiled, Democrats are trying to mobilize African-Americans outraged by the shooting in Ferguson, Mo., to help them retain control of at least one chamber of Congress for President Obamas final two years in office.

title: Rallying Conservatives
description: Americans for Prosperity, a group backed by the Koch brothers, hosted a summit in Dallas ahead of the midterm elections that drew several potential presidential contenders.

title: Kochs Network Wrestles With Expectations for Presidential Primaries
description: DALLAS  The network overseen by Charles G. and David H. Koch has knocked on the doors of a million voters this year, elbowed aside some of the Republican Partys top strategists and built one of the biggest fund-raising operations in politics.

title: Calling His Shots Comes Naturally
description: If groomzillas are a rare breed, it may seem rarer yet that the Miami Heat guard Dwyane Wade nearly qualified for the role.

title: Latest in Line of Elite Swiss Players: A 17-Year-Old With Ties to Hingis
description: At the 1997 United States Open, Melanie Molitor coached her 16-year-old daughter, Martina Hingis, to her third Grand Slam title. Now, Molitor has led Belinda Bencic, 17, into the fourth round of the tournament.

title: Death of Caddies Wife Casts Pall Over Tournament
description: NORTON, Mass.  Saturday was easier for Matt Kuchar. It certainly showed on his scorecard, with a five-under-par 66. But even as he was rattling off six birdies in a row at the Deutsche Bank Championship, he said he could not shake the memory of Angela.

title: Michael Sam Has a Spot in History, if Not With the Rams
description: The St. Louis Rams made history in the spring when they drafted Michael Sam, an all-American defensive end from Missouri, making him the first openly gay player selected by an N.F.L. team.

title: 13-Year-Old Is Set to Become Youngest U.S. Grandmaster
description: Samuel Sevian, at age 13, is poised to make history, aided by a strong performance this month at the Washington International tournament.

title: Navy Tradition Makes the Trek to Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE  Just before kickoff at every Navy home game and the Army-Navy game, what seems like an endless stream of midshipmen files onto the field, company by company, until the group takes up nearly every patch of grass. It is called the March On, and it is one of Navys most honored traditions.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 30, 2014
George Barrett, Tennessee Lawyer Who Fought for Desegregation, Dies at 86
description: George E. Barrett, a tenacious Nashville lawyer who represented unions, consumers, a strip club and the Democratic Party but was best known for his victorious 38-year campaign to desegregate Tennessee universities, died on Tuesday in Nashville. He was 86.

title: U.S. Strikes Militants Besieging Turkmen in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  American warplanes launched airstrikes on Sunni militants who have been besieging the town of Amerli in northern Iraq on Saturday, in a broadening of the campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: On Granderson Bobblehead Night, the Mets Offense Does the Nodding Off
description: Two hours before the Mets game against the Philadelphia Phillies on Saturday, fans entering Citi Field were handed bobbleheads carved in the likeness of Curtis Granderson, the Mets starting right fielder, who entered the night hitless in his past 17 at-bats.

title: For Mets, Bold Words of Spring Give Way to Reality of Summer
description: It was never quite clear why General Manager Sandy Alderson floated the idea in the spring that the 2014 Mets might be capable of 90 victories. Few believed it was possible, and it was not clear if Alderson really did, either.

title: Man Charged in Pellet Gun Attacks in Central Park
description: A 20-year-old Manhattan man was arrested on Saturday and charged in a pair of pellet gun attacks on two joggers in Central Park, the police said. One of the victims was also taunted with racial insults by a group of young adults.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 31, 2014
description: I didnt have $500 to start a C.D., and when they said it was only $25, I knew I could do that. I got addicted when I won $100.

title: Otherworldly Landscapes Made to Feel Like Media Artifacts
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Crystal Agi, Chike Aguh
description: Dr. Crystal Ugochi Agi and Chike Randolph Aguh were married Saturday at the Evergreen Museum and Library in Baltimore. The Rev. James A. Marshall Jr., a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Cara Ben, David Ruda
description: Cara Melissa Ben, the daughter of Sheila K. Ben and Stuart L. Ben of Manlius, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to David Scott Ruda, a son of Suzanne G. Ruda and Dr. Neal Ruda of Holmdel, N.J. Rabbi Andrew Pepperstone is to officiate at the Turning Stone resort and casino in Verona, N.Y.

title: Lauren Sprott and David Leapheart
description: Lauren Ashley Sprott and First Lt. David Theophilus Leapheart are to be married Sunday. Deacon Wayne J. Otlowski is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in South Plainfield, N.J.

title: Nancy Northup, James Johnson
description: Nancy Jean Northup and James Edward Johnson were married Saturday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The Rev. Cheryl M. Walker, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Dr. Paul Smith, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

title: Sarah Smith and Keith Butts
description: Sarah Stoll Smith, a daughter of Flora J. Smith and David S. Smith, both of Darien, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Keith Hunter Butts, the son of Diana C. Butts and Larry H. Butts of Medford, Ore. The Very Rev. Elton O. Smith Jr., an Episcopal priest and a grandfather of the bride and a former executive director at the National Cathedral in Washington, performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church in Providence, R.I.

title: Genve Bergeron, Paul Campbell
description: Genve Christina Bergeron, a daughter of Josephine T. Wydrinski of New Lenox, Ill., and Douglas G. Bergeron of Atherton, Calif., is to be married Sunday to Paul Marshall Campbell, the son of Patricia G. Campbell of Port Orchard, Wash., and David M. Campbell of Chehalis, Wash. The Rev. John Coleman Campbell, an uncle of the groom and a United Methodist minister, is to officiate at the St. Regis Deer Valley, a hotel in Park City, Utah.

title: Jill Lange, Harrison Liss
description: Dr. Jill Hannah Lange and Harrison Saul Liss were married Saturday at Della Terra Chateau, an event space in Estes Park, Colo. Josh Tyrangiel, a cousin of the groom who was ordained by the First Nation Ministry for the occasion, led the ceremony, which incorporated Jewish traditions. Mr. Tyrangiel oversees editorial content at Bloomberg Media in New York.

title: Florencia Segura, Ali Damavandy
description: Dr. Florencia Maria Segura and Dr. Ali Alexander Damavandy were married Saturday afternoon by the Rev. Mario Dorsonville, a Roman Catholic priest, at the St. Mary Mother of God Church in Washington.

title: Kristen Breslin, Anthony DeFelice
description: Dr. Kristen A. Breslin and Anthony C. DeFelice were married Saturday by the Rev. Mark F. Horak at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Allison Yang, Brian Murn
description: Allison Louise Yang and Brian Feneis Murn were married Saturday at the Varsity Theater in Minneapolis. The officiants were the brides brother, Jonathan R. Yang, and stepbrother, Matthew R. Roznovak, who became ministers of the Church of the Latter-Day Dude for the occasion.

title: Tess Bridgeman and Elizabeth George
description: Theresa Ann Bridgeman and Elizabeth Lynn George are to be married Sunday at the Healdsburg Shed, a restaurant and events space in Healdsburg, Calif. The officiant will be Chief Judge Theodore A. McKee of the United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals, with chambers in Philadelphia and for whom Ms. George was a clerk from 2010 to 2011.

title: Silvia Camporesi, James Knuckles
description: Silvia Camporesi and James Albert Knuckles were married Saturday at City Hall in Forli, Italy. Davide Drei, the mayor of Forli, officiated.

title: Jessica Davis, Nicholas Adams
description: Jessica Ashley Davis and Nicholas Cule Adams are to be married Sunday evening at Pippin Hill Farm and Vineyards in Charlottesville, Va. Capt. W. N. Marshall Sr., the chief deputy sheriff of Charlottesville, will officiate with permission from the Charlottesville circuit court. Immediately preceding that, Dr. David B. Adams, an uncle of the groom, will lead the couple in their vows as part of a nonreligious ceremony that he wrote with the couple.

title: Nicole Martinez, Lily Szajnberg
description: Nicole Millia Martinez and Lily Rachel Szajnberg are to be married Sunday at the Herreshoff Marine Museum in Bristol, R.I. Caroline Q. Brown-Albanese, a friend of the couple who became Universal Life minister for the event, will officiate, with participation from Rabbi Joshua A. Franklin.

title: Caurie Putnam, Eric Ferguson
description: Caurie Putnam and Eric David Ferguson were married Saturday at the Morgan Manning House, a historic home in Brockport, N.Y. The Rev. Mark Mutton, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Blair Hartzell, Jonathan Schwartz
description: Blair Allison Hartzell and Jonathan Maxwell Schwartz are to be married Sunday at the brides family home in Hailey, Idaho. Nigel E. Campbell, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate.

title: Jonathan Massey, Marc Norman
description: Jonathan Rider Massey and Marc Dennis Norman were married Saturday at a block party outside their home in Brooklyn. Daniel Mendelsohn, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Layla Moughari, Daniel Nasaw
description: Layla Yousefi Moughari and Daniel Allen Nasaw were married Saturday at Goodwood Museum and Gardens in Tallahassee, Fla. Dr. Jana Bures-Forsthoefel, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at a ceremony that incorporated Persian and Jewish wedding traditions.

title: Jody Martin, Kyle Stein
description: Jody Raphaella Martin, the daughter of Dianne H. Martin of Richardson, Tex., is to be married Sunday evening to Kyle Noah Stein, a son of Barbara B. Stein and Sheldon I. Stein of Dallas. Rabbi Zvi Drizin is to officiate at Union Station in Dallas, with Rabbi William Gershon taking part.

title: Jessica Johnston, Mark Taticchi
description: Jessica Courtney Johnston and Mark David Taticchi were married Saturday at St. Gabriels Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Domenic Rossi, a priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Patricia Shea, James Liddle
description: Patricia Kathleen Shea and James VanDerveer Liddle were married Saturday by the Rev. Charles D. Morris, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, at the Old Dutch Church in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y.

title: Alexis Maruca, Constantine Tsoutsoplides
description: Alexis Nina Maruca and Constantine George Tsoutsoplides were married Thursday evening at Agios Sostis Chapel in Mykonos, Greece. The Rev. Nicholas G. Anctil, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Elisa DiStefano, Mo Cassara
description: Elisa Marie DiStefano and Richard Morgan Cassara were married Thursday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Hauppauge, N.Y. Msgr. James M. McNamara performed the ceremony.

title: Two Worlds That Came Together Online
description: Sandy Natasha Jabado and Brett Alexander Benowitz were married Saturday evening at the Garrison, an event space in Garrison, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Meltz officiated with Imam Qazi Qayyoom.

title: A Romance in Several Acts
description: Eliza Bent and Dave Malloy were married Saturday by Charles I. Clough, a Roman Catholic deacon, at St. Francis de Sales Church in Phoenicia N.Y.

title: Tiffanie Jones, Anthony Artis
description: Tiffanie Ernesta Jones and Anthony Museem Artis are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Jeffery Thompson, a Baptist minister, at the Embassy Suites Downtown Lakefront hotel in Chicago.

title: Katherine Miller, Lou Ventre
description: Lisa Katherine Miller and Donald James Ventre Jr. were married Saturday afternoon at the home of Anna Strickland and Edward Earle, an aunt and uncle of the bride, in Belfast, Me. Jay Guenthner, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Polly Silverman, Jan Ahlgren
description: Mary Rollings Silverman and Jan Gustav Vilhelm Ahlgren were married Saturday at Riverside Farm in Pittsfield, Vt. The event was led by Craig Rubano, who received a one-day license from Vermont to officiate.

title: Natalie Mundy, Daniel Branch
description: Natalie Jenice Mundy and Daniel Jackson Branch are to be married Sunday. Ellen Craver Young, a Universal Life minister, officiated at Nestldown, a private retreat in Los Gatos, Calif.

title: Amy Pochodylo, Jacob Uebler
description: Amy Louise Pochodylo and Jacob Wayne Harold Uebler are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Kya Rose, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, at Michigan State University, where the couple, both 23, met and from which they graduated.

title: Amber Permsap, Matthew Ahearn
description: Amber Dawn Permsap and Matthew Ahearn were married on Friday at Bryn Athyn Cathedral in Bryn Athyn, Pa. The Rev. Charles E. Blair, a Swedenborgian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Leslie Modlin, Frederick Bartholomew
description: Leslie Ann Modlin and Frederick Benjamin Bartholomew are to be married Sunday evening by the Rev. Robin Renteria, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Fearrington Inn in Pittsboro, N.C.

title: Pedro Porro, David Loud
description: Pedro Manuel Porro and David Roger Loud are to be married Sunday at their home in Eldred, N.Y. Kathleen McNenny, a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, is to officiate.

title: Samantha Peikoff, Trevor Adler
description: Samantha Susan Peikoff and Trevor Todd Adler were married Saturday evening at the Hempstead House, an event space in the Sands Point Preserve in Sands Point, N.Y. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson officiated.

title: Julia Mehlman and Joseph Goldstein-Breyer
description: Julia Rachel Mehlman, a daughter of Harriet L. Gluckman and Frederick K. Mehlman of Larchmont, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Joseph Irving Goldstein-Breyer, the son of Sydney R. Goldstein and Judge Charles R. Breyer of San Francisco. Rabbi Lester B. Bronstein is to officiate at the Pioneer Works Center for Art and Innovation in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Diana Newmark, Shalev Roisman
description: Diana Louisa Newmark and Shalev Gad Roisman are to be married Sunday in Hopewell Junction, N.Y. Rabbi Marc C. C. Katz is to officiate at Camp Kinder Ring, a summer camp.

title: Gabrielle Greene and Arthur Sulzberger Jr.
description: Gabrielle Elise Greene, a partner in an investment firm, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., the chairman and publisher of The New York Times, were married Saturday on Marthas Vineyard. The ceremony, at the Outermost Inn in Aquinnah, Mass., was led by Flash Wiley, a friend of the couple, who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Brittany Katz, Scott Phillips
description: Brittany Lynn Katz, a daughter of Joyce L. Katz and Dr. Alan S. Katz of East Hills, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Scott Benjamin Phillips, a son of Rebecca L. Phillips and Dr. Malcolm C. Phillips of Great Neck, N.Y. Cantor Lauren R. Phillips, the sister of the groom, is to perform the ceremony at the Harbor Club at Prime, an event space in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Anjali Vaidya, Gourab De
description: Anjali Vaidya and Gourab De are to be married Sunday at the Lodge at Pebble Beach in Pebble Beach, Calif. Dr. Satish Kulkarni, a Hindu priest, will officiate, using a blend of Maharashtrian, Punjabi and Bengali rituals.

title: Cashing In Their Chips as Winners
description: Tracy Weiler and Ken Davenport were married Saturday at Walhill Farm in Batesville, Ind. The Rev. David A. Johnson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at a ceremony led by Ryan Lympus, a friend of the couple.

title: Christine Ryan, Theodore Hertzberg
description: Christine Elizabeth Ryan, the daughter of Dr. Catherine S. Ryan and Edward A. Ryan of Summit, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Theodore Stuart Hertzberg, the son of Barbara G. Hertzberg and Steven G. Hertzberg of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Silberman is to officiate at the Ryland Inn in Whitehouse Station, N.J.

title: Dina Gohar and Hesham Shaban
description: Dina Gohar and Dr. Hesham Yousef Shaban were married Friday evening at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in Manhattan. Imam Khalid Latif, the executive director and chaplain of New York Universitys Islamic Center, performed the ceremony, which incorporated Islamic and Western traditions.

title: Hannah Lebovich, Michael Testani
description: Hannah Erika Lebovich, a daughter of Leonora Lebovich and Joseph Lebovich of Fair Lawn, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Michael Edward Testani, the son of Mary Y. Testani and Mario R. Testani of Pound Ridge, N.Y., at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y. Rabbi Frank Tamburello will officiate at a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish and Catholic elements, with Rev. Noel Clarke, a minister affiliated with CITI ministries, assisting.

title: Thomas Sweitzer Jr., Jerome Boryca
description: Thomas Cummings Sweitzer Jr. and Jerome Robert Boryca were married Saturday at the home of their friends Marta E. Moret and Peter Salovey in New Haven. Mr. Salovey, president of Yale University and a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: To Beat Kvitova, Krunic Was Tough Between Points and Quick During Them
description: One of the best things a player can do in a tennis match is pretend the scoreboard does not exist.

title: Corrections: August 31, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: China Restricts Voting Reforms for Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Chinas legislature laid down strict limits on Sunday to proposed voting reforms in Hong Kong, pushing back against months of rallies calling for free, democratic elections.

title: 1939: Britain on War Basis With Reservists Called, Navy Fully Mobilized, Telephone Connection Cut
description: LONDON  Britain, with its Navy completely mobilized and all Army reservists called up, was on a war basis tonight [Aug. 31]. A rigid press censorship was put in force during the day and all telephonic connections with foreign countries were cut. Evacuation of children, sick persons and invalids from London will begin tomorrow. A decree was promulgated tonight making it a violation of the law for a person to purchase more than one weeks supply of food at one time. The decree announcing the new military measures follows: Following the measures already adopted, it has been decided to complete the naval mobilization and to call up the remainder of the reserves and supplementary reserves of the Regular Army. New effectives of the volunteer reserves of the Army of the Air will also be called up. The officers and men will await further instructions which will be made public immediately by each of the three Ministries concerned.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 1, 1939

title: San Francisco Exhales During Burning Man Exodus
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As the annual Burning Man festival wrapped up over the holiday weekend, thousands of weary festivalgoers were somewhere in Nevada packing up yurts, washing off body paint and dreading their eventual re-entry to the real world. Here, particularly in the citys rapidly gentrifying Mission District, their neighbors were dreading something else: the moment the Burners come home.

title: Pakistani Army Calls for Calm After Protest Turns Deadly
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A political standoff on the streets of Pakistans capital escalated into a national crisis on Sunday after clashes between the police and protesters attempting to storm the prime ministers house left three people dead and at least 500 wounded, raising the specter of a government collapse.

title: Affiliate of Al Qaeda Confirms Capture of U.N. Peacekeepers in Syria
description: ISTANBUL  The Syrian branch of Al Qaeda has acknowledged that it captured 45 United Nations peacekeepers in southern Syria, saying they were being held in retaliation for what the group called the United Nations failure to help the people of Syria during the countrys civil war.

title: The Changing Face of Temporary Employment
description: Temps arent just employees who sort mail and answer the bosss phone.

title: Putin Urges Statehood Talks for Eastern Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called on Ukraine on Sunday to begin talks on the statehood of that countrys rebellious southeast, a vague and provocative turn of phrase he used while demanding that the Ukrainian government negotiate directly with pro-Russian separatists.

title: The Secret to Happiness Can Be Found by Digging in the Dirt
description: By now, many of us are familiar with the hygiene hypothesis  the idea that an environment thats too clean may actually increase our risk of disease. This hypothesis usually gets discussed in terms of ailments like allergies or autoimmune disorders, but some research shows that dirt might be good forour mental health, too.

title: U.S. and Iran Unlikely Allies in Iraq Battle
description: BAGHDAD  With American bombs raining down from the sky, Shiite militia fighters aligned with Iran battled Sunni extremists over the weekend, punching through their defenses to break the weekslong siege of Amerli, a cluster of farming villages whose Shiite residents faced possible slaughter.

title: Tepco Tries to Stem the Flood of Litigation
description: Many lawsuits have been filed following the meltdown at the Fukushima nuclear plant.

title: Officer and Gunman Are Wounded in Brooklyn, Police Say
description: A gunman who shot a police officer in the leg was in turn shot and wounded by other officers early Sunday morning in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: As Chain Restaurants Move In, a Bronx Cafe Fights for Its Future
description: Charles Maselli has spent more than 25 years selling coffee, food, lottery tickets and newspapers at Bagel Caf, his 24-hour business at the Bay Plaza shopping center in the Bronx. But this summer he got one order that he refused to fill: one restaurant, to go.

title: Guardians of the Galaxy Stays on Top
description: The runaway hit Guardians of the Galaxy will repeat as the No. 1 movie in North America over a quiet Labor Day weekend, as two new wide-release films arrived with meager results. Guardians of the Galaxy (from the Disney-owned Marvel) is projected to take in $21.2 million over the four-day holiday, for a five-week domestic total of $279.5 million, according to studio estimates released on Sunday.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 6:40 P.M. (Starz Cinema) MIDNIGHT IN PARIS (2011) In Paris with his fiance (Rachel McAdams) and her parents, Gil (Owen Wilson, above, with Ms. McAdams), a California screenwriter and aspiring novelist, goes for long walks each night and is magically transported to the 1920s in this film written and directed by Woody Allen. Though Gil wakes up each morning in the present, he spends his evenings consorting with Picasso (Marcial Di Fonzo Bo), F. Scott Fitzgerald (Tom Hiddleston), Salvador Dal (Adrien Brody) and a beguiling beauty (Marion Cotillard), delighting in what Hemingway (Corey Stoll) calls a movable feast. The film, for which Mr. Allen won an Oscar for best original screenplay, is marvelously romantic, even though  or precisely because  it acknowledges the disappointment that shadows every genuine expression of romanticism, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times.

title: Libyans Overrun Compound Abandoned by U.S. Embassy in Tripoli
description: CAIRO  Libyans have overrun a residential compound abandoned by the American Embassy when it pulled out of Tripoli in July, according to a video circulated online Sunday. Dozens of gleeful trespassers could be seen gathered around a swimming pool inside the compound, and a few dived in from the second-floor balcony, all fully clothed.

title: East Meets West to Fill European Post, and Its Harder to Tell Them Apart
description: WARSAW  The election of Donald Tusk, the veteran Polish prime minister with deft political skills, a shaky command of the English language and no French, as president of the European Council is both an acknowledgment of Polands rising profile and yet another sign that the old distinctions between Eastern and Western Europe are rapidly crumbling.

title: Our New Culture War: Do You Recline, or Decline?
description: Sit back, relax and enjoy the flight or dont!

title: Mens Draw Has Its First Major Surprise, and Event Has Its First Rain
description: When the second week of the United States Open began Sunday, five of the top 10 womens seeds were out of the tournament, while the 121st- and 145th-ranked players remained.

title: Telluride Film Festival: Finding Familiar Faces in New Poses
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  Film festivals dont really have themes, even though deadline-stressed journalists sometimes suggest otherwise. But seeing a lot of movies over a short stretch of time can lead you to notice patterns, trivial  like a fox showing up on screen in two consecutive movies, a horse in three  and less so.

title: Israel Claims Nearly 1,000 Acres of West Bank Land Near Bethlehem
description: JERUSALEM  Israel laid claim on Sunday to nearly 1,000 acres of West Bank land in a Jewish settlement bloc near Bethlehem  a step that could herald significant Israeli construction in the area  defying Palestinian demands for a halt in settlement expansion.

title: 1964: Mississippi Integrates Schools
description: BILOXI, Miss.  After years of resistance, Mississippi today [Aug. 31] desegregated its public schools for the first time. Sixteen Negroes were accepted in four elementary schools here and by 10 a.m. this morning 14 were in first-grade classes. One of the two remaining Negroes was rejected when it was learned that the childs parents live outside the state. The other is to attend a school that starts classes later. The fact that there were no incidents today contrast sharply with the rioting that claimed two lives when Negro James Meredith enrolled at the University of Mississippi at Oxford two years ago. White parents sat in their cars in the vicinity of the four Biloxi schools long after their children had entered, but there was no attempt to interfere when the Negro youngsters appeared and walked shyly, holding their parents hands, into the schools. The mother of one of the Negro pupils later told a reporter: Everything is OK, but it aint over yet. School desegregation also came peacefully today to Columbia, S.C., for the first time as six formerly white schools in Columbia enrolled 22 Negro students.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 1, 1964

title: Jays Honor Jeter in Final Visit but Treat His Team Rudely
description: TORONTO  Before Sundays game, which was almost certainly the last regular-season engagement here for Derek Jeter, the Toronto Blue Jays presented him with a special gift for his impending retirement: an all-expenses-paid trip to the resort town Banff, Alberta, including a helicopter tour of the Canadian Rockies, cooking lessons from the Jays executive chef and either skiing or golf tutorials, depending on the season.

title: Anti-Euro Party Wins Its First Seats in a German State Legislature
description: BERLIN  A party that wants Germany to stop using the euro as its currency and generally strikes a populist chord won its first seats in a state legislature on Sunday.

title: 12 Are Killed as Militants Attack Prison in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  An attack by members of the Shabab militant group on a government detention center in Mogadishu on Sunday left at least 12 people dead, including seven attackers, officials said.

title: Wright Steps Up as Hitter and Guru to Help Mets Outlast the Phillies
description: Despite his struggles this season, David Wright remains the cornerstone of the Mets. Surrounded by young and largely inexperienced players on Sunday, Wright left his mark early and often.

title: Driven to Break Free From an Ordinary Life
description: Harry Houdini spent his later years debunking mystics and their sances, but he inadvertently proved that there is life after death in at least one sense: Make your time on earth grand and eventful, as he did, and people will be fascinated by you long after youre gone.

title: Amid Choruses of Despair, an Aria of Hope
description: SAN DIEGO  The offices of the San Diego Opera once filled the penthouse atop the Civic Center Plaza, with 12-foot ceilings and sweeping views of this city and its harbors. No more. These days, opera executives toil away in the decidedly less glamorous former offices of the public defender, with hallways stacked with boxes and unhung pictures lined against the walls.

title: A Dancer Dreams Across the World
description: This week, like many other teenagers across the country, Mire New will return to school. She will reunite with the friends she missed over the summer, see familiar teachers and turn to homework in the evenings.

title: Upsets Persist at U.S. Open as Caroline Wozniacki Ousts Maria Sharapova
description: As long as Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova remained in the United States Open, the rash of upsets in the womens draw was merely a novelty. With 22 major championships between them, Williams and Sharapova have often risen above chaos to bring tournaments to a more predictable conclusion.

title: Delving Deep Into the Crannies of a Brutal War
description: In our high school history classes, teachers might have mentioned Verdun or the Battle of the Somme, but its unlikely they got around to the Brusilov Offensive, the Siege of Przemysl or the battles of the Masurian Lakes. Though World War I was the first truly global conflict, and the first to employ the technologies that now dominate warfare, most Americans knowledge of the fighting that began 100 years ago this summer is limited.

title: Following Trails at the Welsh Countryside
description: The title of the cop series Hinterland refers to its location, a windy and rugged stretch of coast in western Wales, an out-of-the-way part of an out-of-the-way country. But it could also be a television in-joke: For the last decade, Wales has served silently as the home base and filming location for some of the most acclaimed TV shows set in England, including Doctor Who, Life on Mars and Sherlock. Here, finally, was a major show made by the Welsh about the Welsh.

title: Cagey Play Is a Winner at World Youth Championships
description: ISTANBUL  At the 15th World Youth Teams Championships here last month, in the Junior event, for players born in 1989 or later, the 56-board quarterfinals featured easy wins for France, the Netherlands (over USA-1) and Poland. In the fourth match, Norway was down to China by 28 international match points at halftime, but won by 29 imps.

title: As Critics Play Favorites, Readers Line Up to Join
description: Critics for The New York Times plumbed the depths of their disciplines this summer to play the role of curator as part of the Imagine This series. Their task was to create their own dream shows, festivals or exhibitions, and the results were diverse: a Shakespearean battle royale, an art museum of the mind, eclectic music festivals and an exhibition of video games designed by women.

title: Want More Wonka? A Lost Chapter Is Found
description: It appears that Roald Dahl, below, once planned for Charlie Bucket to have a lot more company and a somewhat wilder adventure in Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. A lost chapter of an earlier version of this 1964 book that was found after Dahls death in 1990 was recently published for the first time in The Guardian. It reveals more temptations for a larger cast of characters and some variations on character names. The chapter opens with eight children  including Charlie, escorted by his mother instead of his Grandpa Joe  entering the Vanilla Fudge room. At this point, two other children, Miranda Grope and Augustus Pottle, who later became Augustus Gloop, have already fallen into the chocolate river. Inside the room, the visitors see a mountain of chocolate where hundreds of workers (later called Oompa-Loompas) are chipping away chunks of fudge that are then loaded onto wagons and transported through a dark hole in the wall. Two children, Tommy Troutbeck and Wilbur Rice, disobey Willy Wonka and jump into the wagons. They are quickly swept away through the hole into the Pounding and Cutting Room. Wonka tells the parents that this room is where the fudge is pounded against the floor until it is all nice and smooth and thin. After that, he says, a whole lot of knives come down and go chop chop chop, cutting it up into neat little squares, ready for the shops. The chapter did not make the book because it was deemed too wild, subversive and insufficiently moral for the tender minds of British children almost 50 years ago, The Guardian said. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory has sold more than 20 million copies worldwide in 55 languages, according to RoaldDahl.com, and has been made into two movies and a musical.

title: Taylor Swift Joins Mentors on The Voice
description: Players gonna play, haters gonna hate. Those and other words of wisdom from Taylor Swifts latest Billboard-topping song, Shake It Off, might come in handy when she steps in as an adviser to contestants on NBCs The Voice this fall. Ms. Swift, 24, left, is to appear as a mentor to competitors in its seventh season, Us Weekly reported. Shell join previously announced guest mentors, including Gavin Rossdale, Stevie Nicks, Little Big Town and Alicia Keys, who are to work with members from teams led by the judges, Adam Levine, Blake Shelton, Gwen Stefani and Pharrell Williams. Ms. Swift, however, will work with competitors from all four teams, much as Chris Martin of Coldplay did in Season 6, according to US Weekly. NBC would not comment on the news. The Voice is scheduled to return on Sept. 22, and Ms. Swift is set to release her fifth studio album, 1989, on Oct. 27.

title: Absurd Tales Absurdly Long Trip to the Stage
description: The spring he turned 50, John Wulp won a Tony Award as a producer of Dracula, a show he shepherded from Nantucket, Mass., to Broadway. That was 1978, the high point, so far, of his career in theater. But Mr. Wulp, who is 86 and has lived since the 90s on an island in Maine, can be a very persistent man.

title: A Bit of Caution Beneath the Thump
description: How orderly can an electronic dance party be and still stay fun? That was the question facing the sixth annual Electric Zoo Festival, the three-day event on Randalls Island that started on Friday. In 2013, two festivalgoers died after using the drug known as Molly, containing MDMA, and the festivals third day was shut down at the request of New York City. This year, caution was omnipresent. Concertgoers were required to watch a two-minute antidrug video clip, drug-sniffing dogs met arrivals, bags were searched, uniformed security personnel were plentiful all over the site, and there were highly visible booths and roving ZooKeepers to offer medical attention.

title: Fantasy Football: Breaking Down the Rookies, Part 1
description: The conventional wisdom in fantasy football has traditionally been to avoid rookies. While some are definitely more flash than substance, rookies should not be underestimated or ignored. In recent years, many rookies have emerged to become top players at their position right away. Just last season, Eddie Lacy, LeVeon Bell, Zac Stacy, Giovani Bernard and Keenan Allen emerged to be top 20 players at their respective position. Of those five rookies, only Lacy was expected to play to that level, and all five proved to be steals in fantasy drafts.

title: Whats in a Word? A Chinese Dictionary Updates
description: The revised edition of the Dictionary of Modern Standard Chinese has just been released, and with it, more than 100 new terms  many slang or online neologisms  have been granted admission to the august realm of official Chinese lexicons.

title: Breaks
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This was a clockwise solve for me, starting in the northeast.

title: Pregnant Woman Is Killed in Shooting on Long Island
description: Police officers on Long Island responding to a report of gunfire on Saturday evening discovered the body of a pregnant woman who had been shot several times.

title: One Judge to Decide the Future of Detroit
description: DETROIT  In a trial set to open in the federal courthouse here on Tuesday, nothing short of this citys future is at stake.

title: Is Your Student Prepared for Life?
description: AS 16 million young adults set off for college this fall, they are looking at some frightening statistics. Despite the ever-rising cost of getting a degree, one number stands out like a person shouting in a campus library: According to a recent poll conducted by AfterCollege, an online entry-level job site, 83 percent of college seniors graduated without a job this spring. Even when these young people finally do get jobs, the positions are often part time, low wage or not related to their career interests. The problem isnt the quality of higher education in the United States, so whats missing?

title: Sympathy for a Desert Dog
description: Dog adopted me in 1995, six months or so into my first spell of ethnographic fieldwork among the Ju/hoansi Bushmen in Namibias Kalahari Desert. I was living in the village of Skoonheid, named after an Afrikaner farm. He was the bravest of all the village dogs in seeking affection. The others loped around, their tails between their legs, trying to be invisible. They shied from physical contact with people but would respond with surprise and simpering gratitude if it was offered. Most of their physical interactions with people came in the form of kicks or flying stones.

title: Europes Migration Crisis
description: Unusually calm seas in the Mediterranean and stagnant European economies are contributing to a perfect storm over migration.

title: Andy Murray Discusses Favorite Courts, and the Future
description: Andy Murray won the United States Open boys singles title ten years ago, but since then, he has had few chances to play on the outer courts of major tournaments. In his latest conversation with The New York Times, Murray spoke of what makes a good court and his thoughts on life after tennis. In previous interviews at theU.S. Open, Murray has discussedhis perspective on this years tournament,female coaches in tennis and the idea of an independent Scotland.

title: Glenn Cornick, Original Bassist in Jethro Tull, Dies at 67
description: Glenn Cornick, the original bassist in the popular British rock group Jethro Tull in the late 1960s, died on Thursday at his home in Hilo, Hawaii. He was 67.

title: The Medicare Miracle
description: So, what do you think about those Medicare numbers? What, you havent heard about them? Well, they havent been front-page news. But something remarkable has been happening on the health-spending front, and it should (but probably wont) transform a lot of our political debate.

title: In a Tough Place to Farm, Discovering Much to Love
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  The glorious taste of a late-summer tomato, fresh off the vine, is a chin-dripping wonder for many Americans. Except, as many gardeners might assume, up here.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday, and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.
